site_title: JPMorgan buys air rights from Midtown church to build new HQ
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co will buy up to 660,000 square feet of air rights from St Bartholomew's Church in Manhattan to build its new headquarters, a 2.5-million-square-foot skyscraper. The bank agreed to pay $178.6 million for the additional rights, with a deadline to decide by next February. The deal comes as New York City implemented a rezoning plan for east Midtown, allowing for taller buildings. Construction is planned to start next year, pending necessary approvals.

site_title: New Banksy art a tribute to 1968 uprising
summary: Street artist Banksy has confirmed that he created up to a dozen murals in Paris as a tribute to the 1968 uprising, targeting the French government's stance on migrants. The stencilled images appeared on walls across the city, with Banksy initially keeping his identity hidden. He later posted two of the murals on Instagram and confirmed another near the Sorbonne university was his work, sparking a mix of excitement and skepticism among fans. The murals aim to honor the rebels of the 1968 uprising and challenge the French government's hard line on migrants.

images.alt_text: A rat wearing a bow tie. Banksy took on the rat as his avatar - a symbol of the vilified and downtrodden - in hommage to the Paris street artist Blek le Rat, who started out in 1968 when a general strike by students and workers brought France to a halt.
Mural of a businessman or a politician - in a suit holding a handsaw behind his back and offering a bone to a dog having first sawn the animal's leg off.

site_title: Morgan Stanley pays US$3.6m fine for weak investor protection rules
summary: Morgan Stanley agreed to pay a US$3.6 million fine to the US Securities and Exchange Commission for failing to have adequate systems to detect and prevent the misappropriation of client funds. The regulator found that a broker was able to misappropriate US$5 million from clients' accounts between 2015 and 2016 without their permission. As part of the settlement, Morgan Stanley did not admit or deny the findings and has stated that it will continue to improve its controls to ensure client asset safety.

images.alt_text: Morgan Stanley agreed to pay a US$3.6 million fine on Friday after regulators found it failed to have systems in place to help it detect and prevent the misappropriation of client funds, the US Securities and Exchange Commission said.

site_title: China expected to defend yuan at key level as losses mount
summary: China is likely to intervene to defend the yuan if it falls to a key psychological level of 6.7 per dollar, as it risks worsening sentiment in China's financial markets. A survey of 18 traders and analysts found that policy makers will act to slow the currency's slide once it gets close to this level, which is about 1% below current levels. The yuan has slumped 3.5% since June 14 due to concerns over China's slowdown and trade war with the US, but Chinese officials appear comfortable with the currency's slump so far.

images.alt_text: Most of the 18 traders and analysts surveyed by Bloomberg say policy makers will act to slow the currency's slide once it gets close to 6.7 per dollar in China's onshore market. That's about 1 per cent below current levels.

site_title: Pricey Hong Kong set to impose vacancy tax on empty new flats
summary: Hong Kong proposed a 200% vacancy tax on empty new homes, with the tax translating to about 5% of a flat's value. The measure aims to discourage developers from hoarding, but analysts expect little impact on prices in the world's least affordable property market. The tax would apply to flats not rented out for six of the previous 12 months, and would not affect resold flats. The city's chief executive, Carrie Lam, also announced plans to modify a pre-sale consent scheme to require developers to sell at least 20% of their flats during pre-sales.

site_title: Canada hits back at US with tariffs on metals, bourbon and orange juice
summary: Canada retaliated against US tariffs on metals and consumer goods with C$16.6 billion in countermeasures, targeting items like Florida orange juice, Kentucky bourbon, and Wisconsin toilet paper. The move aims to pressure US President Donald Trump ahead of November's midterm elections. The tariffs, set to take effect on Sunday, will add 25% to US steel and 10% to aluminium and consumer goods, with Ottawa citing "regret" and "sorrow" against a close ally.

site_title: Europe: Stocks shrug off trade worries with quarterly gain
summary: European stocks ended the second quarter with a 2.4% gain, despite trade war fears, after China eased foreign investment limits. The pan-European STOXX 600 rose 0.8% and Germany's DAX jumped 1.1%. The tech sector rebounded with a 1.6% rise, while banks also saw gains. However, the European banking sector remains one of the worst performers of 2018, with a decline of over 12% since the start of the year.

Tan, who joined DBS in 1993, has held various risk management roles, including senior credit approver and loan workout unit leader. He will bring his experience to the new role, which has seen the bank improve its risk methodologies and digitalise its risk management processes. Tan's appointment is seen as a continuation of the bank's internal mobility programme, which aims to give employees experience in different positions and regions.

Singapore's Straits Times Index ended 0.34% higher, despite year-to-date losses of 4%. Analysts at Morgan Stanley and DBS predict a challenging regional market environment due to trade tensions and a stronger US dollar, but remain optimistic on Singapore's bank earnings and valuations.

site_title: Nest egg advocate
summary: Daniel Houston, chairman and CEO of Principal Financial Group, emphasizes the importance of saving for retirement and changing lives. He advocates for a disciplined approach to saving and investing over the long term, citing data that suggests 90% of workers can replace 85% of pre-retirement income with proper planning. However, he notes that the biggest issue is that people do not save enough, with the US average at 7-8%. Houston argues that advisers and investors often get bogged down in debates over asset allocation, which is less important than the simple act of saving. He recommends a balanced portfolio with a 15% deferral every year for 35 years to replace 85% of income in retirement.

site_title: Chinese firm eyes 'strata-sales', high debt for flipping Hong Kong towers
summary: Chinese firm Henglilong Investments plans to buy two Hong Kong office towers for $2 billion, borrowing 80% of the cost and selling individual floors separately, known as "strata-selling". This strategy aims to quickly pocket profits and repay high-interest debt. The move is rare in Hong Kong premium property deals and could further drive up property prices, potentially harming long-term asset value and management quality. The deal is set to close in April 2019 and is being discussed with investment banks, including Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs.

site_title: Oil drillers cut US rig fleet in aftermath of Opec moves
summary: US oil drillers reduced their rig fleet by four to 858, the largest drop since March, following OPEC's decision to raise production. Shale fields in South Texas and North Dakota were hardest hit, while the Permian Basin in West Texas and New Mexico saw its rig count remain steady at 473. The Permian Basin accounts for 55% of active rigs in the US, making it the most-prolific American oil field. The decline in US rig count is a response to OPEC's production increase.

site_title: Big oil pushes gas as fossil fuel answer to global warming
summary: Big oil companies are pushing natural gas as the fuel of the future to reduce emissions and provide affordable electricity. They argue that gas has half the carbon emissions of coal and is abundant and relatively cheap. However, critics say that methane leaks from gas production facilities can be a potent greenhouse gas. Companies like Total and Shell are participating in programs to address methane leaks and see gas as a complement to renewable energy. Despite this, some companies, like ConocoPhillips, have expressed skepticism about the industry's efforts to reduce emissions.

images.alt_text: To reduce emissions and provide affordable electricity, the world needs to burn more fossil fuels, not less.

site_title: Women independent directors add to companies' financial performance: NUS study
summary: A study by the National University of Singapore (NUS) Business School found that having one woman independent director on a company's board increases its financial performance by 11.8%. The study also discovered that a one-person increase in female independent directors raises a company's corporate governance score. This positive effect is observed even with just one additional female director, suggesting a direct and significant impact on a company's financial and governance performance.

site_title: Trump says he is not seeking new chief of staff, but 'things happen'
summary: US President Donald Trump stated he is not seeking a new chief of staff, but "things happen" as John Kelly's tenure nears its one-year mark. Kelly, a retired general, could be leaving soon. Trump has occasionally expressed dissatisfaction with Kelly's restrictions, but frequently praises him publicly. Possible replacements include Mick Mulvaney and Nick Ayers, who could be chosen if Trump seeks to bring more political experience to the role, particularly ahead of congressional elections.

site_title: Del Monte posts Q4 profit of US$12.3m on one-off gain
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a Q4 net profit of US$12.3 million, up from US$2.9 million in the year-ago period, driven by a one-off gain from purchasing DMFI loans at a discount. Revenue fell 8.5% to US$499m, and excluding one-off items, the company would have incurred a net loss of US$2.1 million. The group expects to be profitable in FY2019, barring unforeseen circumstances.

site_title: Malaysia, Indonesia 'should work together against EU curb on palm oil'
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad expressed hopes for closer bilateral ties with Indonesia during his two-day visit to the country. Mahathir urged cooperation between the two nations to counter the European Union's plan to phase out palm oil from transport fuels by 2030, which would impact major palm oil producers Indonesia and Malaysia. The two leaders discussed bilateral relations, trade, and territorial disputes, including the South China Sea, and reaffirmed their commitment to fighting corruption.

MAS will assess the adequacy of the financial institutions' change management processes and may take supervisory actions. Both parties have apologized for the incident and implemented measures to prevent similar errors in the future.

The company's co-founder, Ismail Gafoor, expressed encouragement over the strong response from investors, citing recognition of the company's growth potential.

site_title: GM says US import tariffs could mean 'smaller' company, fewer jobs
summary: General Motors warned that higher US import tariffs on vehicles could lead to a "smaller" company, fewer jobs, and increased prices. The company, which buys $22 billion in US parts annually, imports 30% of vehicles sold in the US market, with 86% coming from Canada and Mexico. GM said tariffs could delay breakthrough technologies and reduce US investment. The company's shares fell 2.8% on the news, with Toyota Motor Corp also filing comments opposing the tariffs. The Commerce Department plans public hearings next month to consider the tariffs, which could be imposed by the end of July or August.

site_title: USDA supply/demand forecast could factor in Mexico, China tariffs
summary: The US Department of Agriculture will factor in China and Mexico's tariffs against American farm products in its global supply and demand crop report, assuming the tariffs hold for the rest of the year. The USDA chief economist stated that tariffs of up to $450 billion on Chinese imports, set to begin July 6, will be included in the forecast. This move comes as the US is in a growing trade fight with top agricultural export markets.

site_title: Air pollution plays significant role in diabetes: study
summary: A US study found that air pollution caused 1 in 7 new diabetes cases globally in 2016, with 3.2 million new cases attributed to pollution. The study, published in the Lancet Planetary Health, linked pollution to reduced insulin production and increased diabetes risk, even at levels considered safe by the EPA and WHO. The research suggests that current levels of air pollution are not sufficiently safe and should be tightened, contradicting industry lobbying groups. This finding highlights the significant role of air pollution in diabetes, affecting over 420 million people worldwide.

site_title: US: Wall Street ekes out gain as Nike surges

The Dow rose 0.7%, the S&P 500 gained 2.94%, and the Nasdaq jumped 6.33% for the quarter. Concerns over US international trade relations eased, allowing energy and growth sectors to advance. The major indexes ended the week down, but Nike's strong performance helped the Nasdaq reach a fresh record high.

site_title: A Toronto school where the kindergartners speak 40 languages
summary: In Toronto's Fraser Mustard Early Learning Academy, kindergarten students from diverse immigrant backgrounds speak 40 languages but learn English together. The school, built for 630 students, employs specialized programs to cater to the needs of its students, including a science and technology program and a remedial physical education program. With a focus on inclusivity, teachers use visual aids and assistive technology to help students with special needs, such as deafness. The school's resource team develops individualized plans to support each child's progress, reflecting the city's emphasis on multiculturalism and diversity.

site_title: JLL aims to conquer Canadian real estate with a boost from tech
summary: JLL Canada, a division of global real estate services firm JLL, aims to become the top commercial real estate services company in Canada by leveraging technology. Under CEO Brett Miller's leadership, the company has grown tenfold to over 1,500 employees and increased revenue by 1,000%. JLL has developed a 3D mapping tool called Blackbird and launched an international venture fund to invest in tech companies improving protocols in development, investing, leasing, and management. The company's tech-based services, including building-management technology platform IntelliCommand, are key to its growth strategy.

site_title: Road rage: Drivers seethe as France lowers speed limit
summary: France has lowered the speed limit on the Nationale 7 highway to 80 km/h from 90 km/h, prompting widespread anger among drivers. The change, implemented in 2015, is part of a broader effort to reduce traffic fatalities. While some drivers have adjusted to the new speed limit, many remain frustrated, with some expressing concerns about safety and the potential impact on travel times. The move is seen as a step towards reducing congestion and promoting a safer driving culture in France.

site_title: Thyssenkrupp seals landmark steel venture with Tata Steel
summary: Thyssenkrupp's supervisory board approved a 50-50 joint venture with Tata Steel, the European steel sector's biggest shake-up in over a decade. The venture, set to have 48,000 workers and 15 billion euros in sales, will be based in the Netherlands and forms the core of Thyssenkrupp's plan to transform into a technology company. The deal is seen as a response to European steelmakers facing tariffs on US exports and comes after Thyssenkrupp CEO Heinrich Hiesinger extracted more commitments from Tata Steel, addressing concerns over valuation and environmental risks.

site_title: Time split to the nanosecond is precisely what Wall Street wants
summary: Computer scientists at Stanford University and Google have developed technology to track time down to 100-billionths of a second, a precision that could be crucial for Wall Street's high-speed trading. Nasdaq, the New York-based stock exchange, is testing an algorithm and software to synchronize its network of computers with this level of precision, essential for accurately ordering millions of stock trades every second. The goal is to prevent the fastest traders from taking unfair advantage of slower firms and ensure fair placement of orders. This technology is also seen as a step towards enabling Nasdaq to offer "pop-up" electronic markets on short notice.

summary: A new framework has been launched by Enterprise Singapore and Workforce Singapore to help retailers redesign their operations and build a more productive workforce in today's digital age. The Retail Job Redesign Framework offers step-by-step guides and resources to identify areas for job redesign, develop solutions, and measure outcomes. The framework aims to help retailers adapt to the changing retail landscape, driven by e-commerce and rising consumer expectations. Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo emphasized the need for bold adoption of new technologies and job redesign to support shifts in business strategies and worker adaptation.

summary: In Q2 2018, the residential sector dominated property investment sales, accounting for 65% of total volume with S$7.1 billion in sales. Market activity is expected to remain robust, with potential for increased residential collective sales and office activity, driven by sustained price momentum and depleting office supply. Total investment volume is projected to exceed S$40 billion for the full year.

summary: Johor Crown Prince Tunku Ismail Sultan Ibrahim thanked Singapore for helping during drought seasons and water crisis, calling them a "neighbour and a friend". summary: Ryobi Kiso Holdings announced that its subsidiary Ryobi Tactics is beginning the winding up process. summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reprimanded Oriental Group and eight connected individuals for misconduct related to three fundraising activities and unauthorized transactions between 2012 and 2015. The breaches included misleading announcements, unauthorised corporate guarantees, and unauthorised transactions. Those reprimanded include former non-executive chairman Wu Dingrong, former CEO Lee Wan Sing, and former independent directors Tan Song Kwang and Koh Choon Kong. The regulator has also imposed conditions on the individuals, requiring SGX RegCo's nod before appointing them as directors or to management teams.

site_title: World Cup roars into knockout phase
summary: The 2018 World Cup has entered its knockout phase, with top contenders Argentina and Portugal facing off in the quarterfinals. Lionel Messi's Argentina will rely on the star player to overcome a struggling team, while Cristiano Ronaldo's Portugal faces challenges with their over-reliance on the 33-year-old forward. France, armed with talented players like Paul Pogba and Kylian Mbappe, must improve to keep their hopes of a second World Cup title alive. The knockout stage promises thrilling matches, with potential semi-final matchups against Spain or England.

site_title: ST Engineering divests 25% interest in Airbus Helicopters S-E Asia JV
summary: ST Engineering's aerospace arm divests its 25% stake in Airbus Helicopters South East Asia (AHSA) to Airbus Helicopters SAS for 9.125m euros (S$14m). The joint venture was established in 1977 to provide helicopter services. The divestment is part of ST Engineering's business review to streamline capabilities and optimize resources. It is expected to have no material impact on the company's net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Xiaomi IPO raises US$4.7b after pricing at low end
summary: Xiaomi Corp raised $4.7 billion in its Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO), pricing 2.18 billion shares at HK$17 each, valuing the company at about $54 billion. The IPO, led by Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, was at the low end of the marketed range and met its initial goal. Billionaires George Soros and Hillhouse Capital were among investors, with Soros' fund placing an early order and Hillhouse placing $600 million. The offering is Hong Kong's largest first-time share sale since 2016, and Xiaomi's IPO will allow its founder, Lei Jun, to maintain outsized voting rights.

site_title: NUS, Singapore Maritime Institute set up S$18m research centre
summary: NUS and the Singapore Maritime Institute (SMI) have established an S$18 million research centre, the Centre of Excellence in Modelling and Simulation for Next Generation Ports (C4NGP), to enhance the global competitiveness of Singapore's maritime and port industries. The centre will focus on areas such as designing and building maritime systems, navigational channel capacity studies, and port terminal systems over the next five years. The centre aims to collaborate with companies to improve technical know-how, efficiency, and productivity, and will be jointly led by NUS researchers and industry partners.

site_title: Stress test results signal more flexible new-look Fed
summary: The Federal Reserve's stress test results signaled a more flexible approach to bank supervision under new leadership chairman Jerome Powell and vice chairman Randal Quarles. Banks received conditional passes, with Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley receiving a pass despite falling below the Fed's minimum capital requirements, due to a one-off capital hit from the 2017 US tax overhaul. The Fed's pragmatic stance may signal a shift towards a more industry-friendly tone, but analysts and industry insiders still call for further changes to make the process more transparent.

site_title: Adidas warns US customers of possible data breach
summary: Adidas has warned US customers that their data, including contact details and usernames, may have been stolen following a potential data breach on its US website. The company claims no credit card information or fitness data was compromised. Adidas is working with data security firms and law enforcement authorities to determine the scope of the issue and alert affected consumers.

summary: US President Donald Trump stated he will discuss alleged Russian election meddling with President Vladimir Putin during their planned July 16 summit in Helsinki. Trump also plans to address conflicts in Syria and Ukraine, and other international issues. The meetings, facilitated by the Securities Investors Association (Singapore), aim to provide transparency and address concerns. This move comes after CW Group's default, which has affected the company's noteholders. The outcome of the meetings is uncertain, but the meetings demonstrate the company's commitment to addressing the issue.

site_title: Citi avoids CFPB fine for overcharging cardholders US$335m
summary: Citigroup Inc. has avoided a fine from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) for overcharging cardholders by more than US$335 million. site_title: Why self-care is not selfish
summary: The article emphasizes the importance of self-care and mental well-being in the workplace. It argues that self-care is not selfish, but rather essential for maintaining a healthy work-life balance and overall well-being. The author shares their personal struggles with self-care and how it has evolved over time, highlighting the need for mindfulness, discipline, and responsibility. The article also encourages readers to prioritize their own needs, set boundaries, and practice compassion towards themselves and others. It suggests that a supportive workplace culture can foster a sense of community and help individuals recognize when someone is struggling, leading to a more caring and empathetic work environment.

summary: The European Union warned Britain that time is running out to reach a Brexit deal, as leaders agreed to step up preparations for a possible collapse in talks. EU Chief Negotiator Michel Barnier said progress had been made, but serious divergence remained on the Irish border issue. Britain aims to agree a withdrawal deal and future partnership terms by October, but the EU expressed concern over lack of progress. summary: Pacific Radiance, a marine support services provider, narrowed its Q1 net loss to US$12.8m, a 13% decrease from last year. summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index and won rose on Friday following China's easing of foreign investment curbs, with the Kospi up 11.89 points or 0.51% at 2,326.13. summary: Wall Street experienced a sharp downturn in 2018, contrary to investor expectations, with emerging economies and global growth facing significant challenges. site_title: Electricity tariffs to increase by average of 6.9% in Q3 of 2018
summary: Electricity tariffs in Singapore are set to increase by an average of 6.9% in Q3 2018, with a 1.50 cents per kilowatt hour (kwh) rise from July 1 to Sept 30. The increase is mainly due to higher natural gas costs for electricity generation. Households will see their average monthly bill rise by S$5.61, marking the fourth consecutive quarter of tariff hikes. The increase is based on guidelines set by the Energy Market Authority and has been approved by the electricity industry regulator, SP Group.

site_title: Key risks to consider when investing in corporate perpetuals
summary: Hyflux's issuance of S$900 million of retail perpetuals has raised concerns about the risks involved in buying non-vanilla products. Corporate perpetuals, also known as corporate hybrids, are quasi-equity instruments that offer attractive yields but lack guaranteed fixed payments and principal redemption. Key risks to consider include structural risks, such as the issuer's ability to defer payments, and credit risks, which are exacerbated by the company's negative operating cashflows. The article highlights the need for enhanced investor education and sophistication to create a more robust and sustainable market.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon trading at 3,280.45, up 0.7% on day

site_title: SGX reprimands Oriental Group, past and present directors
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reprimanded Oriental Group and eight individuals for breaching listing rules, including providing misleading announcements on fundraising exercises. site_title: Wrong deductions for Prudential customers in May due to 'file format change'; MAS reviewing findings
summary: A technical glitch on May 24 affected over 20,000 Prudential Singapore customers, resulting in incorrect deductions of monthly insurance premiums. Both Prudential and Standard Chartered Bank apologized for the incident and have taken remedial actions. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is reviewing the findings and will take supervisory actions if necessary to ensure adequate change management and incident handling processes. The issue has since been fully rectified.

site_title: Hearing of winding-up application against Big Box owner adjourned
summary: A hearing for the winding-up application against Big Box Pte Ltd, a subsidiary of TT International, has been adjourned. site_title: Trump says SoftBank Son's US investment hitting US$72b
summary: US President Donald Trump announced at a Wisconsin ceremony that SoftBank Group Corp chief executive Masayoshi Son's US investment has reached $72 billion, exceeding the initial $50 billion pledge made in 2016. This increase came during a groundbreaking event for a Foxconn manufacturing facility. Son made the remarks without referencing the new figure, while Foxconn Chairman Terry Gou attended the ceremony alongside Trump. The announcement marks a significant boost to US investments under Son's Vision Fund.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Shares end higher
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose on Friday, ending a tough quarter marked by concerns over a China-US trade war. summary: The 2018 World Cup is halfway through, with 16 teams remaining in the knockout stage. Croatia stands out as the top-performing team, winning all three group matches. site_title: China unveils easing of investment curbs as trade war looms
summary: China has announced easing of foreign investment rules in sectors such as finance, car industry, and infrastructure, with 48 fields now open to foreign investment, down from 63 last year. The move aims to portray China as opening up despite a looming trade war with the US. The new "negative list" also removes curbs on petrol station ownership and allows 51% foreign control in some financial fields for three years. However, critics say the policy only benefits large foreign banks, and China's rhetoric contrasts with the US's calls to limit Chinese investment.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB taskforce freezes bank accounts of former PM Najib Razak's party
summary: A taskforce investigating 1MDB, a Malaysian state fund, has frozen bank accounts of the United Malays National Organisation (Umno), the party of former Prime Minister Najib Razak. The accounts are believed to have received funds from 1MDB, which is under money laundering probes in six countries. The investigation, which includes the accounts of several companies, aims to recover misappropriated funds. The move follows a long-running scandal involving Najib and 1MDB.

site_title: Retailers to get help for digital makeovers under new scheme
summary: The Singapore government has launched the Retail Job Redesign Framework to help retailers adapt to the digital economy. The initiative provides access to consultants, online training, and funding to support companies in updating their business models and alleviating manpower crunch. Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo emphasized the need for brick-and-mortar stores to reinvent themselves to compete with the digital economy. The framework can be accessed at http://jobredesign.sra.org.sg.

site_title: Asian markets swing as painful quarter draws to close
summary: Asian markets are experiencing volatility as investors approach the end of a tumultuous quarter, with China-US trade tensions showing no signs of easing. The Chinese stock market is in bear territory, and the yuan continues to struggle, fuelling concerns about global growth. Analysts warn that a trade war with the US would likely hurt China more, but the ongoing US strength, including expected interest rate hikes, is expected to benefit the US economy. Markets are swinging back and forth, with some indices ending with gains, while others, such as Tokyo and Seoul, are down.

site_title: Bike rental wars: ofo, Mobike apply for licences; Mobike scraps deposit
summary: Bike-sharing operators ofo and Mobike have applied for operating licences with Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA), following a July 7 deadline. Mobike has scrapped its security deposit policy, allowing users to access their accounts without a refundable S$49 deposit. Existing users can request a refund through the mobile app, while new users with a Singapore phone number can access the service without a deposit. This move comes after competitor oBike's sudden shutdown of its Singapore operations due to regulatory difficulties.

site_title: Singapore bank lending flat in May: MAS
summary: Singapore bank lending remained flat in May, increasing 0.1% to S$668 billion, according to preliminary data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Business lending rose 0.1% to S$403 billion, while consumer lending increased 0.1% to S$265 billion. This is weaker than the 0.8% increase in April and 5.5% year-on-year growth. The slower growth in business loans reflects the slower pace of growth in the overall economy.

site_title: NUS, Singapore Maritime Institute set up S$18m research centre to boost sector's global competitiveness
summary: The National University of Singapore (NUS) and the Singapore Maritime Institute (SMI) have established an S$18 million research centre, the Centre of Excellence in Modelling and Simulation for Next Generation Ports (C4NGP), to enhance Singapore's maritime and port industries' global competitiveness. site_title: Former HSBC senior VP jailed 10 years and six months for cheating elderly women of their savings
summary: A former HSBC senior vice-president, Emeline Tang Wei Leng, was jailed for 10 years and six months for cheating five elderly women, including family members, out of over S$5.2 million. Tang, 39, pleaded guilty to 34 charges, including cheating and forgery, after she lied to them about high-interest fixed deposit plans and kept the money for herself. She had returned more than S$800,000 to the victims and used the funds to settle debts and pay for her father's cancer treatment.

site_title: Oil prices slip on trade frictions, but crude market remains tight
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday due to concerns over trade frictions between the US and other major economies. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures dropped 0.4% to $73.19 a barrel, while Brent crude futures fell 0.2% to $77.73 a barrel. The declines came amid an escalation of trade disputes, with China's yuan hitting a new low against the US dollar. Traders worry that tariffs on imported goods could feed into oil markets, potentially choking off world economic growth. site_title: China's Xiaomi prices Hong Kong IPO at bottom of range: sources
summary: Xiaomi, a Chinese smartphone maker, priced its Hong Kong IPO at the bottom of its indicative range of HK$17 to HK$22 per share. site_title: Australia passes foreign meddling laws amid China tensions
summary: Australia has passed laws to curb foreign meddling in domestic politics, amid heightened fears of Chinese interference. The new legislation strengthens existing spying offences and introduces new offences targeting covert actions by foreign actors trying to influence or harm domestic politics. The changes require individuals or entities working on behalf of foreign interests to declare their links, aiming to make the political system more transparent. The laws were passed ahead of several by-elections in late July, with the threat environment deemed more acute. site_title: Electricity tariffs to rise by average of 6.9% in Q3

site_title: Women independent directors are good for companies' financial performance: NUS study

Analyzing data from 500 Singapore-listed companies, the study found that for every additional woman independent director, financial performance increased by 11.8%. The study also found a positive and statistically significant impact on corporate governance, with a higher corporate governance score leading to improved financial performance. The findings support proposed revisions to the Code of Corporate Governance that promote diversity policy transparency and board renewal.
