summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.09% to 3,260.44. Gainers outpaced losers 58 to 45, with 90.2 million shares worth S$318 million changing hands. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Passengers stranded as flights to and from Bali are cancelled; airport remains shut due to volcanic ash
summary: Flights to and from Bali's Denpasar International Airport have been cancelled or postponed due to a volcanic eruption of Mt Agung. The airport remains shut until at least 7pm, affecting 74,928 passengers. Many travelers, including German tourists, were unaware of the cancellations until arriving at the airport. Airlines such as Singapore Airlines, AirAsia, and Qantas have cancelled flights, and the Indonesian government has set up refugee centers for those displaced by the eruption.

site_title: Bitcoin falls below US$5,900 to wrap up a gloomy 2018 first half
summary: Bitcoin fell below US$5,900 on Friday, marking the lowest price since November, amid declining demand due to security and regulatory concerns. The cryptocurrency is down 20% or more in June, following a 20% decline in May, and has dropped 60% this year. Nobel economics prize winner Robert Shiller labeled Bitcoin a "speculative bubble" earlier this week, further eroding investor confidence.

site_title: Rich Capital given green light to remain listed
summary: Rich Capital Holdings, formerly known as Infinio Group, has received approval from the Singapore Exchange to remain listed on the Catalist board. The exchange considered the company's successful fund-raising exercises, business diversification, and acquisition of three property development projects in Singapore and Indonesia. However, the company's listing status may be suspended if it fails to demonstrate viability as a going concern. Rich Capital has also completed the purchase of a property in Singapore for S$10.8 million, following its name change to reflect its diversification into the property business.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall on trade spat; won rallies
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.44% on Friday due to escalating Sino-US trade tensions, with investors shifting out of emerging markets. The won rallied, while bond yields remained steady. Shares of Samsung BioLogics surged 4.8% after Biogen exercised its call option to purchase additional shares of a joint venture. Other North Korea-exposed stocks also rose, including Hyundai Cement, which jumped 19.5%.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Del Monte, Rich Capital, Second Chance Properties, Emerging Towns & Cities
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a Q4 net profit of US$12.3 million, excluding a one-off gain of US$14.3 million. Rich Capital Holdings received approval to continue listing on the Catalist board after successful fundraising and business diversification. Second Chance Properties' Q3 net profit fell 61.6% to S$2.1 million, while Emerging Towns & Cities Singapore requested to resume trading on June 29 after meeting conditions set by the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: US appoints long-awaited ambassador to South Korea
summary: The US has appointed Admiral Harry Harris as the new ambassador to South Korea, filling a vacant post since President Donald Trump took office. Harris, a hawkish commander and veteran Asia hand, was confirmed by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. He supports a pause in joint military exercises with South Korea, a position taken by Trump, who met with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un to defuse tensions. Harris's appointment marks a shift in US diplomacy under the new administration, which has sought to promote its "America First" policy.

site_title: Pacific Radiance narrows Q1 net loss to US$12.8m
summary: Pacific Radiance, a marine support services provider, reported a Q1 net loss of US$12.8 million, down 13% from the previous year. Revenue fell 16% to US$11.8 million, mainly due to lower revenue from its Subsea Services business and Shipyard segment. The group's full-year net loss was US$343.2 million, excluding impairment charges. No dividends were declared for the current period. The company's shares were suspended, trading at US$0.076 apiece.

site_title: Apple gets 2nd supplier for OLED iPhone screens
summary: Apple has secured a second supplier for OLED iPhone screens, with LG Display Co initially set to supply 2-4 million units. The deal aims to reduce Apple's dependence on Samsung Electronics Co and lower costs. LG is ramping up capacity to meet demand, which could help accelerate the adoption of OLED screens. The partnership is seen as crucial for both Apple and LG, allowing Apple to diversify suppliers and LG to gain a fresh source of revenue.

site_title: Novel Beauty
summary: The annual Singapore Art Book Fair will take place from June 29 to July 1 at NTU CCA, Gillman Barracks. The event will feature art books, catalogues, monographs, zines, and printed ephemera from notable publishers such as Phaidon and Grey Projects. Additionally, art activities and performances will be available, showcasing a range of art book projects from local and international artists.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Hormel, Tyson accused of inflating pork prices in lawsuit
summary: A class-action lawsuit accuses Hormel, Tyson, and other meat packers of conspiring with Agri Stats to artificially inflate the price of pork products by more than 50%. The alleged scheme involved sharing competitively sensitive information, resulting in a 50% increase in the hog market's year-average price from 1998 to 2015. The lawsuit claims the price boost was facilitated by Agri Stats, a service used by meat packers to exchange sensitive information.

site_title: Broker's take: SAC initiates coverage on Hong Lai Huat with 'buy', citing turnaround story
summary: SAC Advisors initiated coverage on Hong Lai Huat Group (HLH) with a "buy" rating and a target price of S$0.51, citing the company's strong turnaround story, particularly in its mixed-development project D'Seaview in Sihanoukville, Cambodia. The brokerage expects HLH to post a strong recovery in 2018 and 2019, driven by higher sales from D'Seaview and its established track record in property development in Singapore.

site_title: Bike rental wars: ofo, Mobike apply for licences; Mobike scraps deposit
summary: Bike-sharing operators ofo and Mobike have applied for operating licences with Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) ahead of a July 7 deadline. Mobike also announced a deposit-free policy, waiving the one-time S$49 deposit for Singapore-registered users. The move comes after competitor oBike shut down its operations due to difficulties in complying with LTA regulations. oBike customers had raised concerns about recovering their security deposits. The LTA's deadline for dock-less bicycle rental companies to apply for licences will force others to shut down if they fail to do so.

site_title: Japan's jobless rate hits 26-year low
summary: Japan's jobless rate has hit a 26-year low of 2.2% in May, according to the internal affairs ministry, with the jobs-to-applicants ratio reaching a record high. The country struggles with labor shortages due to an aging society and low birth rate. To address the issue, the government has proposed loosening restrictions on foreign workers. Meanwhile, factory output declined 0.2% in May, ending a four-month growth streak, and Japan's economy contracted for the first time in two years in the January-March period.

site_title: Mahathir: Murder case of Mongolian Altantuya Shaariibuu will be retried
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced the retrial of the 2006 murder of Mongolian model Altantuya Shaariibuu. The case, which was previously closed, may reopen following the emergence of new leads. Former Special Action Force personnel Sirul Azhar Umar and Azilah Hadri were convicted of the murder and sentenced to death, with Sirul currently under detention in Australia. A retrial is expected, but no further details on the new leads have been revealed.

site_title: Energy giant BP bets on electric car boom
summary: BP has acquired Chargemaster, the UK's largest electric vehicle charging company, as it bets on the booming electric car market. The deal will expand BP's rapid charging network at its 1,200 petrol stations across Britain, with a focus on ultra-fast charging lasting 10 minutes for a 161-kilometer range. Experts predict a surge in electric vehicle sales, with BP aiming to become the top provider of energy to low-carbon vehicles by 2040, in line with UK government targets.

site_title: CW Advanced Technologies to hold informal noteholders' meeting on July 16 after note default
summary: CW Advanced Technologies, a subsidiary of Hong Kong-listed CW Group, will hold an informal meeting with note holders of its defaulted 7% notes due 2018 on July 16. The meeting aims to provide an overview of the company's business and financial position, discuss the implications of the default, and engage in a discussion regarding the future. The meeting will be private, confidential, and without prejudice, and no decisions or voting will be made. The company failed to redeem the notes on June 25, and a grace period has ended, constituting an event of default under the notes.

site_title: China weekend data to hint at economic readiness for trade war
summary: China's weekend data, including the purchasing managers' indexes, is expected to show the economy easing back further amid tighter credit and trade tensions. The data may indicate how domestic demand is holding up and the impact of expected higher duties on Asian supply chains. Economists predict a slowdown in investment and a possible squeeze on smaller businesses, which may face a credit expansion slowdown. China's central bank is signaling support for growth, but no policy easing is expected, unless a breakthrough agreement is reached with the US on tariffs.

site_title: Nike returns to growth in North America, tops estimates
summary: Nike Inc. reported a 2.76% increase in sales in North America, beating analyst estimates, marking the first time in a year the company's sales in the region grew. New product launches and direct-to-customer sales contributed to the growth. Nike's shares rose 8% to a record high, and the company announced a $15 billion buyback program. The company expects fiscal 2019 revenue to be in the high single-digit range and gross margin to expand 50 basis points.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as weaker yuan stokes trades worries
summary: European shares fell 0.9% and 1.4% on Thursday, with tech and automotive stocks taking the biggest hits, as investors sold risky assets amid trade tensions and a weaker yuan. Tech stocks dropped 2.6%, while chipmakers and automakers declined 5.1%, 4.2%, and 2.4% respectively. Consumer staples stocks, such as Nestle and Unilever, were a rare bright spot, gaining as investors seek safe havens. Analysts say a lasting recovery for stocks is unlikely without tangible progress on trade negotiations.

site_title: Some top oil buyers are thinking about shunning Iran oil
summary: Top oil buyers, including Japan's Fuji Oil Co and Taiwan's Formosa Petrochemical Corp, are considering ending imports from Iran due to US pressure to halt purchases by November 4. South Korea has already suspended imports, while Emirates National Oil Co in the UAE explores alternatives. The US is targeting Iran's economic lifeline with sanctions over its nuclear program, which may exacerbate a global oil shortage and lift prices.

images.alt_text: At least some buyers of Iranian supplies in the world's biggest oil market are considering acquiescing to US President Donald Trump's demands.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares resume losses at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with losses, dipping 0.12% to 28,463.85, amid China-US trade fears. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.10% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.17%. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close for the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq. Investors are also monitoring US-EU trade talks and the Federal Reserve's split views on interest rates.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as yen stays weak
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by gains on Wall Street and the yen's weak trend. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.24% to 22,323.01, while the Topix index increased 0.02% to 1,727.38. This upward trend follows the US market's edge to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore ranks 12th in global real estate transparency index
summary: Singapore ranks 12th globally in real estate transparency, according to JLL's GRETI 2018. The country has opportunities to improve transparency in debt and equity holdings and occupier services through the use of proptech. JLL recommends the government promote proptech adoption through open-data initiatives and blockchain technology. Singapore has strengths in performance measurement and market fundamentals, but lags behind in areas such as financial transparency and sustainability. The country's real estate industry is expected to continue growing, with record-breaking investment volumes in 2017.

site_title: Amazon to buy PillPack in potentially disruptive drug retail push
summary: Amazon is acquiring PillPack, a small online pharmacy, in a move that could disrupt the $450 billion US prescription drug market. The deal, valued at $1 billion, will put Amazon in direct competition with traditional pharmacies, pharmacies benefit managers, and drug distributors. PillPack supplies pre-sorted prescription drugs to customers with multiple medications, a growing market due to the aging US population. Amazon's acquisition could allow it to scale up quickly and negotiate cheap generic drugs, but it will face entrenched competition from major players.

site_title: Amazon plans startup delivery services for its own packages
summary: Amazon plans to launch a startup delivery service, allowing individuals to open and manage their own businesses delivering Amazon packages. For a minimum investment of $10,000, owners can operate up to 40 vehicles, potentially earning $300,000 in profit per year. The program aims to meet Amazon's growing package delivery needs, but raises questions about its potential impact on existing delivery partners, including the US Postal Service and UPS.

site_title: World Cup wide open after dramatic group stage
summary: The 2018 World Cup's group stage has created a wide-open tournament, with several top contenders emerging. Germany's early exit, along with Italy's non-qualification, has opened up opportunities for other teams. France and Argentina's upcoming match will determine which team advances to the quarterfinals, while Spain and Brazil, the only other past winners, face potential quarterfinal opponents Croatia and England, respectively. The knockout stage is expected to feature teams with strong defensive records, such as Uruguay and Spain.

site_title: Messaging app firm Kakao seeks partners for its blockchain venture
summary: South Korea's messaging app firm Kakao is seeking partners for its blockchain venture, Ground X Corp. The company plans to raise funds through a private placement and may collaborate with consumer-service companies to build its crypto platform. Ground X aims to target firms with internet or mobile services that can be offered on a blockchain platform, with plans subject to change. Kakao hopes to use this platform to expand its business overseas, competing with Ethereum. The company has already set up Ground X in Tokyo and has 50 million monthly users predominantly in South Korea.

site_title: Return of mega-deals helps European M&A double
summary: Mergers and acquisitions in Europe surged 96% to $767 billion in the first six months of 2018, the highest level since 2007. Despite a 18% decline in transactions to 6,201, the number of mega-deals ($10 billion+) doubled, with notable deals including Takeda Pharmaceutical's $62 billion bid for Shire and Comcast's $22 billion attempt to acquire Sky. Companies are taking advantage of cheap debt to finance large transactions before borrowing costs rise, with many bankers predicting the market may reach a peak.

site_title: Hilton Grand Vacations acquires NYC's Quin for US$175m
summary: Hilton Grand Vacations Inc has acquired the Quin, a Manhattan hotel on West 57th Street, for $175 million. The Orlando-based company, which spun out of Hilton Worldwide Holdings Inc. in 2017, is expanding its presence in the city with this acquisition. The Quin, a historic Beaux Arts-style hotel, previously sold for $60 million in 2010 and has housed famous artists. This deal follows another urban hotel acquisition by Westgate Resorts, highlighting timeshare companies' growing interest in urban properties to court millennial customers.

site_title: Starbucks CFO Maw to retire, shares tumble
summary: Starbucks CFO Scott Maw is retiring at the end of November, sending shares down 2.61% after a four-year tenure. The company plans to identify $300 million in cost savings over three years, unchanged. Maw's departure is seen as a surprise, with analysts describing him as a competent executive but noting the chain's deteriorating performance. The company has launched an external search for a replacement, and Maw will become a senior consultant until March 2019, earning $250,000 per month.

site_title: Gunman kills at least five, injures others in Maryland newsroom
summary: A gunman killed at least 5 people and injured 3 others in a shooting at the Capital Gazette's office in Annapolis, Maryland. The suspect, a 20-something white male, was arrested without exchanging gunfire with police. Authorities believe he acted alone and had no known motive. The newsroom was described as looking like a "war zone" after the attack, with victims hiding under desks. The FBI is assisting local authorities, and President Trump has been briefed on the incident.

images.alt_text: A gunman killed at least five people and "gravely injured" at least three others when he sprayed a newsroom in the Maryland capital of Annapolis with gunfire on Thursday, authorities said.

site_title: US: Wall St advances with help from technology, financials
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday as technology and financial sectors rebounded from previous day's declines. The technology sector gained 1.1%, led by Accenture's 5.9% increase, while the S&P 500 financial index rose ahead of the Federal Reserve's stress test results. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 98.46 points, and the Nasdaq Composite added 58.60 points. Amazon's entry into the pharmacy business led to declines in several drugstore chains, including Walgreens Boots Alliance and CVS Health Corp.

site_title: Environmental group worries it may be too early for fake meat
summary: Environmental group Friends of the Earth is raising concerns about the rapid advancement of lab-grown and fake meat technologies, citing a lack of research, safety assessments, and transparent labeling. The group wants increased regulation and third-party testing of genetically engineered proteins and lab-made meat. Companies such as Impossible Foods and Memphis Meats have responded, with some claiming their products are sustainable and compliant with regulations, while others acknowledge the need for more transparency and oversight.

site_title: Clearbridge Health plans IPO spin-off for associate
summary: Clearbridge Health's associate, Clearbridge BioMedics, secured S$6.6 million in pre-IPO funding commitments from investors. The funds will be used for business expansion, technology development, and IPO-related costs. Clearbridge BioMedics plans to develop end-to-end cancer diagnostic tests and is expected to list on Singapore's Catalist junior board in the last quarter of this year. The potential spin-off is at a preliminary stage and depends on regulatory approval.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: SIA pays CEO 14% less in fiscal 2018, following lacklustre 2017
summary: Singapore Airlines' CEO Goh Choon Phong received 14% less in total remuneration in fiscal 2018, with a salary increase and lower bonuses and share-based compensation. The airline's net profit rebounded 55.2% to S$892.9 million in FY2018, after a 55.2% decline in FY2017. SIA chairman Peter Seah's remuneration more than doubled to S$763,110 in FY2018. The airline met its safety target for FY2018, and maintained its sustainability goals.

site_title: China's ZTE still in limbo over US Commerce ban
summary: The US Department of Commerce continues to work with China's ZTE Corp to lift the ban imposed in April, despite a Commerce official stating last week that the final steps would be taken in a "couple of days". ZTE, the country's No 2 telecommunications equipment maker, must deposit $400 million into an escrow account to regain access to American-made components and has pleaded guilty to violating US sanctions against Iran and North Korea. The ban has raised national security concerns and is also linked to trade negotiations between the US and China.

images.alt_text: The US Department of Commerce still has not worked out the details necessary for lifting the ban on China's ZTE Corp, a spokesman said on Thursday, even though an official last week said the final steps would be taken in a "couple of days".

site_title: Blockbuster Chinese tech IPOs face bumpy ride as trade tensions rise
summary: Chinese tech companies preparing for initial public offerings (IPOs) in Hong Kong and New York face a bumpy ride due to rising trade tensions between the US and China. Despite a stellar first half, smaller deals are getting hurt, with Qeeka Home and Uxin halting or reducing their IPO plans. Equity capital markets in Asia have been receptive to issuance, but volatility and secondary market deterioration may deter smaller deals. Companies like Xiaomi, Tencent Music, and Meituan Dianping are set to raise billions in the coming months, with some planning Hong Kong floats.

site_title: Japan retail sales miss expectations as customers tighten purse strings
summary: Japan's retail sales slowed in May, with a 0.6% annual increase, the lowest in seven months. This marks a weaker-than-expected result, following a revised 1.5% increase in April. Analysts attribute the decline to one-off factors such as bad weather, and predict a temporary slump. Weak consumer spending is a concern for policymakers, as it hinders inflation and poses a risk to the export-reliant economy.

site_title: Baht is Asia's worst-performing currency, may fall further: Mizuho
summary: The Thai baht is expected to continue its decline, becoming the worst-performing currency in emerging Asia this quarter, according to Mizuho Bank. Foreign funds have pulled $3.8 billion from Thailand's equity market since March, citing concerns over escalating US-China trade frictions and its impact on Thailand's current account surplus. The baht has weakened 6% against the US dollar this quarter, and Mizuho expects the dollar to remain strong, potentially threatening Thailand's currency and economy.

site_title: Glacier-protection bill dropped in Chile and miners applaud
summary: Chile's government has dropped a glacier-protection bill, sparking controversy among environmentalists and the mining industry. The bill, which would have provided special protections for glaciers, was withdrawn by Environmental Minister Marcela Cubillos after opposition from the Mining Council. The move has been criticized by academics, who say it will imperil glacial networks and fail to address the impact of climate change. The bill's withdrawal has left glaciers and environmentally sensitive areas under more general protections, but critics argue that this is not enough to mitigate the effects of climate change.

site_title: UK consumer economy slows, manufacturing perks up: BOE, EU polls
summary: The UK's consumer economy remains sluggish despite a boost in manufacturing, with sales growth across consumer services hitting a five-year low. The Bank of England (BOE) surveys showed a modest upturn in pay deals, but a decline in retail spending growth. Consumer confidence in the UK fell to a six-month low in June, driven by pessimism about economic prospects ahead of Brexit. The BOE is considering interest rate hikes, but the mixed data suggests the slowdown may be temporary.

site_title: Deutsche Bank fails Fed stress test while 3 US lenders stumble
summary: Deutsche Bank's US subsidiary failed the Federal Reserve's second part of annual stress tests due to "widespread and critical deficiencies" in capital planning controls. The bank's shares dropped 1% after hours. The Fed placed conditions on three other banks that passed the test, including Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley. Deutsche Bank must invest in technology and operations, and make changes to its governance and risk management. The failure marks another blow to the bank's financial health, which has been under intense scrutiny.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank AG's US subsidiary failed on Thursday the second part of the US Federal Reserve's annual stress tests due to "widespread and critical deficiencies" in the bank's capital planning controls.

site_title: Mixed Grill
summary: Fuego Fest 2018, a three-day food festival celebrating Latin American and Asian grilling cultures, will take place at Emily Hill from July 6 to 8. The event features unlimited food servings during two-hour time slots, with diners grilling over open fires and embers. Tickets are available at fuego.land.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Heat-stable drug could save thousands from post-childbirth bleeding
summary: A new formulation of the heat-stable drug carbetocin, co-led by the World Health Organization, could save thousands of lives in poorer countries by preventing excessive bleeding in women after childbirth. The drug is as safe and effective as oxytocin, which requires refrigeration and can lose efficacy due to heat exposure. A study of 30,000 women in 10 countries found carbetocin to be equally effective in preventing postpartum bleeding. The WHO is now working to submit carbetocin for regulatory review and approval, with the potential to add it to the list of recommended drugs for post-partum bleeding.

site_title: Serial System CEO assisting in investigations in Taiwan
summary: Serial System's CEO, Derek Goh Bak Heng, has been requested by the Taiwanese authorities to assist in certain investigations under the Securities and Exchange Act of Taiwan. The company's board stated that Goh's assistance would not affect his roles or responsibilities, and business operations will continue as usual. Serial System's latest earnings report showed a 22% increase in sales to US$405.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2018. The company's counter advanced 1.35% to close at 15 Singapore cents.

site_title: Emerging Towns and Cities requests resumption in trading
summary: Emerging Towns and Cities Singapore has requested the resumption of trading for its Catalist shares on June 29, which were suspended. The company has confirmed that sufficient information has been disseminated to the market for fair trading. Additionally, the board has made two undertakings: to procure independent parties to take over Luo Shandong's shares under a convertible loan agreement, and to redeem a portion of the loan if Luo Shandong exercises his right to hold more than 10% of the company's enlarged share capital.

site_title: Sony Music to release bulk of Prince's catalogue of music
summary: Sony Music has announced a deal with Prince's estate to re-issue the bulk of his catalogue, including 19 albums from 1995 to 2010 and 12 albums from his golden era starting in 2021. The deal excludes soundtracks, including "Purple Rain." This is the latest attempt to monetize Prince's legacy, following similar deals with Universal Music and Warner Brothers. Prince's estate has been actively releasing new music and working to manage his posthumous legacy, including starting paid tours of Paisley Park and hiring a manager to handle business decisions.

site_title: Natural Beauty
summary: The Burberry Conservatory, a temporary glasshouse, is part of a series of pop-up spaces in cities worldwide, including Singapore, from June to October 2018. Inspired by English greenhouses, it features lush live plants and limited-edition Belt Bags in various colors and designs. The pop-up is located at The Shoppes at Marina Bay Sands in Singapore until July 8. This is part of Burberry's latest runway collection and offers customers the chance to customize their bags with interchangeable belts.

site_title: Is ESR building its own 'mini pan-Asian GLP'?
summary: E-Shang Redwood (ESR), a pan-Asian logistics developer and operator, is reportedly building a "mini pan-Asian Global Logistics Properties" (GLP) by acquiring the Reit and property managers of Cache Logistics Trust. ESR's parent, Warburg Pincus, has cash to invest and is expanding its platform. The acquisition could lead to a merger with Viva Industrial Trust and potentially other transactions, solidifying ESR's position as a logistics empire in Asia.

site_title: Powell wants 'real economy' to guide Fed
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell is shifting the central bank's approach to monetary policy, prioritizing evidence from the real economy over traditional conceptual benchmarks. He aims to let the labor market "run hotter" with an unemployment rate projected at 3.5% over the next two years, despite concerns about potential bubbles. This approach has benefits for workers, including millions who were previously locked out of jobs due to age or racial bias. However, some Fed officials, including Dallas Fed president Robert Kaplan, express caution, warning that a long period of low interest rates could generate imbalances.

site_title: Revivo Your Spirits
summary: A new holistic wellness center, Revivo, in Bali offers a structured yet gentle approach to stress relief and personal transformation. The three-hectare property features luxury villas, a range of wellness activities, and healthy meals designed to recalibrate taste buds. Guests can choose from various programs focusing on destressing, detoxing, weight loss, and anti-aging. With a focus on individualized guidance, Revivo provides a peaceful retreat from the stresses of daily life, with no pressure to interact with others. The center's aim is to empower guests to make positive changes in their lives upon returning home.

site_title: EDBI joins US$42m funding round for automation firm Puppet
summary: EDBI, Singapore's investment arm, has joined a $42 million funding round for DevOps and automation company Puppet, led by Cisco Investments. Puppet's automation platform helps improve IT efficiency and compliance, with plans to hire 8 more staff in Singapore. The company has over 40,000 customers and is expanding its APAC regional HQ in Singapore. Puppet's CEO Sanjay Mirchandani attributes the growth to rising demand for DevOps transformation and software automation, as companies navigate the new world of software delivery.

site_title: Panasonic flags battery cell shortages as Tesla Model 3 output ramps up
summary: Panasonic, the exclusive battery cell supplier for Tesla's Model 3, reported occasional battery cell shortages as Tesla ramps up production to meet its 5,000 cars-per-week target by the end of June. Despite production improvements, Panasonic sees the risk of over-relying on Tesla and has partnered with Toyota to jointly develop batteries for electric vehicles. The company believes commercialization of all-solid-state batteries will not occur until around 2025.

site_title: Indian rupee hits record low against US dollar; RBI intervenes
summary: The Indian rupee hit a record low of 69.09 against the US dollar on June 28, 2018, amid weak macro-economic fundamentals, broad dollar strength, and declining Asian peers. The Reserve Bank of India intervened with a mild sale of dollars, but analysts expect further losses in the coming days. The rupee's fall is attributed to higher oil prices and trade war tensions between the US and China, which has also affected other Asian currencies like the Indonesian rupiah and Philippine peso.

site_title: Music To The Ears
summary: Bang & Olufsen has launched its digital store, beostore.com, offering its full range of audio visual products. The online shop allows customers to browse and purchase products 24/7, with in-stock items delivered within one to three days. The same warranty and after-sales service are offered for all online purchases, providing convenience for those who have visited the physical store but are still deciding. This move aims to enhance the shopping experience and cater to customers' needs.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Screen And Stage Classic
summary: The Lion King, a Disney classic, has been adapted into a Broadway musical featuring Elton John and Tim Rice's music. The show has won over 70 international theatre awards and is the third longest-running show on Broadway, with a limited run in Singapore until August 26. The musical uses puppetry and dance to tell the story of Simba, a cub who confronts his father's death and grows into a hero. Tickets are available from S$65 at the Sands Theatre at Marina Bay Sands.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Options For The Diet-Conscious
summary: Singaporean eateries are catering to the growing demand for diet-conscious options, offering customizable grain bowls, gluten-free menus, and healthy meal boxes. Restaurants such as The Daily Cut, The Butcher's Wife, and Verde Kitchen are providing nutritional information and adapting dishes to suit various diets, including paleo, keto, vegan, and gluten-free. The trend reflects a shift towards healthy eating and lifestyle, with diners willing to pay more for food with health benefits, with 75% of Singaporeans actively making dietary choices to prevent health conditions.

site_title: When a bottle of well-made wine is an ode to harmony...
summary: A renowned wine maker, Frederic Mugnier, emphasizes the importance of "doing nothing" in wine-making, allowing the grapes to naturally produce the best possible wine. Harmony is key to achieving balance and perfect balance between all components in wine, just as in life. The author shares his experience with Château Montrose 2005, a 13-year-old wine that exemplifies harmony, with a rich, concentrated taste and a lingering finish. Proper cellaring and patience are crucial to unlocking the full potential of a wine, with the ideal aging period varying depending on the type and vintage.

images.alt_text: Château Montrose is not as often seen on dinner tables here as it deserves to be. My own experience with it dates to my visit to the Château in the early 80s, when the owners were the Charmolue family.

site_title: Del Monte posts Q4 profit of US$12.3m on one-off gain
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a Q4 net profit of US$12.3 million, up from US$2.9 million in the year-ago period, due to a one-off gain from the purchase of Del Monte Foods Inc loans at a discount. Excluding this gain, the group incurred a net loss of US$2.1 million. Turnover for the quarter was down 8.5% to US$499 million. The company also generated a full-year net loss of US$28.2 million, down 73.6% from the previous year.

site_title: Losing Weight The Dr Oz Way
summary: Dr. Mehmet Oz recommends a hybrid diet, combining elements of vegan and paleo diets, as the most effective for long-term weight loss. He advocates for intermittent fasting, where individuals eat within a 12-hour window and skip the remaining 12 hours. Dr. Oz also emphasizes the importance of nutrient-dense foods, such as those high in vitamins and minerals, which can help with weight management and overall health. He encourages consumers to prioritize food quality and sourcing, and to make informed decisions about their diet.

site_title: China's gas imports surge as heat wave boosts demand
summary: China has increased its liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports by 3.6% in June, with cargoes coming from Norway, Belgium, and Cameroon, amid a heat wave and efforts to switch to cleaner fuel to curb coal use and toxic air pollution. This surge in demand is driven by households using air conditioners and power plants burning gas to meet electricity needs, with some buyers also seeking winter supplies. Imports have reached 3.9 million tonnes so far this month, up from 3.7 million last year.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Courts Asia is offering to buy back its S$75 million worth of 5.75% notes due 2019 at 100.75% of the principal amount. The company is seeking noteholders' consent to include a call option for early redemption. Second Chance Properties reported a 61.6% decline in net profit to S$2.1 million in its third quarter. Tee Land is purchasing a condo in Upper East Coast Road for S$60 million to build a residential development.

site_title: EY tax practitioners urge Asean to work together on tax matters
summary: EY tax practitioners in Asean urge the region to collaborate more closely on tax matters, particularly in light of rising protectionism. They suggest harmonizing tax rules for digital businesses and addressing double taxation to boost intra-Asean trade. The experts believe that Asean's ambitions to become a single market and production base can be enhanced by improving tax flow and reducing tax frictions. However, harmonization may face challenges, and tax authorities must keep up with changing regulations and technological advancements.

images.alt_text: Asean countries can benefit from collaborating more closely on tax matters, especially in the face of rising protectionism, tax practitioners from EY have said.

site_title: Facebook shows it's got its eye on the ball as it makes biggest push yet into English soccer
summary: Facebook is set to announce a three-year deal to broadcast the English Premier League in Thailand, Cambodia, Laos, and Vietnam, its largest push into top-flight soccer, according to a person familiar with the matter. The deal is seen as a bid to grab global sports rights and boost engagement in Asia. Facebook is competing with Qatar-based broadcaster BeIN Sports, which paid $250 million for the current deal. The Premier League's current contract for domestic broadcasts saw income fall to £4.6 billion over three years, with international deals hoped to make up the shortfall.

site_title: Auction sales in Q2 down 33%
summary: Singapore's auction sales in Q2 2023 declined 33% to S$19.64 million, compared to S$29.48 million in Q2 2017. The decrease is attributed to smaller-ticket sales and a lack of high-quantum properties. The number of units sold remained the same as the previous year, but the total sales value was lower. This decline was partly due to the absence of high-end properties sold through auctions.

site_title: Canberra Link EC site likely to be hotly contested
summary: The Canberra Link EC site, set to be released for sale under the H1 2018 GLS programme, is expected to be highly contested due to its proximity to the future Canberra MRT station and strong demand for executive condominiums. Consultants predict top bids ranging from S$194 million to S$243 million, with some anticipating a bidding war. The site's proximity to the MRT station, limited EC development sites, and strong buyer demand are seen as key selling points, making it more attractive than other sites in the programme.

site_title: Whisky Comfort
summary: Whisky Comfort, a new bar by Italian restaurateur Beppe de Vito, has opened in Dempsey, offering a unique whisky experience. The bar features a curated selection of drams from countries including Scotland, France, and Japan, as well as a collection of rare and old vintages. Prices are kept down, with most pours starting from S$10. Happy-hour prices are also available on weekdays. The bar, called Room for More, is located in the same building as the casual French bistro Atout and aims to make whisky drinking more fun and accessible.

site_title: More companies making their philanthropy more productive
summary: Singapore-based companies are increasingly integrating philanthropy into their business models, with 64% of corporate givers adopting this approach. Companies like Feng Ming Construction use their expertise to benefit both the firm and the community, reducing costs and increasing the impact of their giving. Procurement, marketing, and staff development are common strategies for aligning profit with purpose. Employee-related benefits such as morale, retention, and talent recruitment are key motivators for corporate giving, and "purposeful giving" helps foster a culture of volunteerism within organizations.

site_title: Shanghai Composite Index slumps another 0.9% to two-year low
summary: The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.9% to a two-year low, marking another decline in dollar terms of 13% since MSCI's inclusion of Chinese A shares in June. Foreign investors have lost billions, with overseas funds buying a net $13.5 billion of mainland shares since May. A slowdown in the economy, tightening liquidity, and trade war concerns are contributing to the market's woes. The decline is evoking echoes of the 2015 market panic, undermining efforts to attract foreign investment and stabilize the market.

site_title: Trump stance on China confuses markets
summary: Stock markets in Asia remained volatile due to US-China tensions. US President Donald Trump's stance on China was downgraded after White House adviser Larry Kudlow denied a softened stance, causing market uncertainty. Schroders downgraded equities to neutral in several regions, favoring Singapore. This move was attributed to rising political and economic uncertainty globally, which negatively impacted market sentiment.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Petrobras could raise US$28b selling key offshore oil stake
summary: Brazil's state-controlled oil company Petrobras could raise around $28 billion by selling a 70% stake in a key offshore oil area, according to Mining and Energy Minister Wellington Moreira Franco. The stake is part of the "transfer-of-rights" area, which was granted to Petrobras in 2010, but the contract's value is still disputed. A bill allowing the sale is currently being reviewed by Congress, with a potential auction planned for November 29. If approved, the sale would be a key step towards unlocking Brazil's pre-salt offshore oil play.

site_title: Singapore inks MOUs with UK to strengthen air force and boosting national security
summary: Singapore has signed memorandums of understanding with Boeing and Airbus Defence and Space to enhance its air force capabilities and national security. The agreements include research and development in data analytics, augmented reality, and 3D printing, and will also explore counter-terrorism and logistics management measures. The collaborations aim to strengthen Singapore's defense and deter potential threats, with the UK also participating in the efforts to research and develop defense technologies.

site_title: Style beats substance at Madame Fan
summary: London restaurateur Alan Yau's Madame Fan, a Chinese eatery in the NCO Club, boasts an elaborate stage setting but falls short in its culinary offerings. The restaurant's menu features classic Chinese dishes with some nods to London's Chinese food scene, but execution is lacking. Standout dishes include Salt and Pepper Squid, Sichuan Vegetable Dumpling, and Tiong Bahru Soup, while others, such as the Crispy Aromatic Duck and Cantonese Lobster Noodles, disappoint. Service is inconsistent, but a promising start with efficient server Sarah. Rating: 6.5.

site_title: More power for taxmen to search persons, premises with changes to GST
summary: Singapore is proposing changes to the Goods and Services Tax (GST) Act, granting tax enforcement officers enhanced powers to investigate serious tax crimes. These new powers include the ability to forcibly enter premises, arrest suspects without a warrant, and conduct body searches. The move aims to combat tax fraud syndicates and recalcitrant taxpayers using sophisticated strategies.

site_title: Dollar rally fizzles on euro bounce
summary: The US dollar's rally against other currencies fizzled out due to mixed signals on the trade dispute between the US and its trading partners. Despite concerns about trade dominating global market sentiment, safe-haven currencies like the Japanese yen and Swiss franc remained well-supported. The dollar edged away from a near one-year high against the euro, trading at 95.24 after inflation data showed German regions exceeded the European Central Bank's target rate. The euro rose to a near two-month high against sterling at 88.40 pence.

site_title: Korean Air head grilled over tax evasion
summary: South Korean airline Korean Air chairman Cho Yang Ho, 69, was grilled by prosecutors over alleged tax evasion and other crimes. He and his family allegedly avoided paying 50 billion won (S$60.9 million) in taxes on inherited assets. Cho also faces embezzlement allegations and unfair contract awarding. His family members, including daughters who caused "nut rage" scandals, are being probed for assault and other crimes. Cho has a history of run-ins with the law, including a suspended jail sentence for tax evasion in 2000.

site_title: Extra! Extra!
summary: The Singapore Theatre Festival opens on July 5, featuring eight plays, including the highly-anticipated "Press Gang" by Tan Tarn How. The play explores issues of power, freedom, and censorship in the context of a newsroom, with a star-studded cast. The festival runs until July 22, offering a diverse lineup of plays.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Press Gang.

site_title: When a driverless car knocks down someone, who is to blame?
summary: A proposed approach to regulating AI involves granting legal personality to AI systems, allowing for vicarious liability and enabling the application of existing laws on agency. This would enable the easy attribution of responsibility for AI-related consequences, facilitating agency without the need for new laws. The approach is similar to that taken with corporations, recognizing AI as objectively real entities with rights and obligations. Granting legal personality would allow the law to evolve and address the complexities of AI decision-making, making it easier to regulate the technology without needing to predict its future applications.

site_title: China considers banning short-term US dollar bond sales
summary: China is considering banning short-term US dollar bond sales, which would reduce financing options for property developers that have fueled record sales of such debt. The National Development & Reform Commission is weighing a ban on bonds maturing in less than a year, amid concerns that developers are over-borrowing and refinancing existing debt. The move would further constrain cash-strapped property developers, which are already facing funding problems and tightened liquidity.

site_title: Hospitality Game Changers
summary: Four Singaporean hoteliers are making their mark in the boutique accommodation scene overseas, particularly in Perth. Daniel Tan, the owner of The Melbourne Hotel, re-opened the 1897-built hotel in Perth's City Centre after previously owning and refurbishing another hotel in the city. Tan's vision for The Melbourne Hotel is to recreate the experience of Singapore's iconic Raffles Hotel. The hotel's distinctive facade and spacious balcony are notable features of the re-opening. Tan's success with his previous hotel has paved the way for his latest venture.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Kayoko Francis
summary: Kayoko Francis, founder and CEO of Finesse Digital, has leveraged her childhood experiences in Tokyo to launch a fintech startup. Growing up, Francis's grandfather, a stock market investor, would ask for her advice on selecting stocks, rewarding her with sushi meals. Francis's early success in picking stock market winners led to a government scholarship and a career in banking. Now, she's focused on providing tech-based solutions to banks and investment companies in South-east Asia and Japan. Finesse Digital offers robo-advisory services, aiming to increase efficiency and reduce costs for banks. Francis also prioritizes empowerment, particularly for women, and has started an NPO to educate and increase investment literacy for women in Japan.

site_title: US car trade groups warn against tariffs
summary: US car trade groups warn the Trump administration against imposing up to 25% tariffs on imported vehicles, citing potential job losses of hundreds of thousands, higher prices for consumers, and reduced spending on self-driving cars and electric vehicles. The tariffs, launched amid an investigation into national security threats, could result in an average price increase of $5,800, boosting costs to American consumers by nearly $45 billion annually.

site_title: In Sickness And In Health
summary: This year's Wallpaper* Handmade exhibition in Milan showcased 22 unique wellness objects created by talents worldwide, including seven Singaporean design studios. The 'Wellness & Wonder' theme featured items that promoted self-improvement, exercised the mind and body, and restored balance. Designs included stone dumbbells, foot massagers, back benders, and a biodegradable water vessel, all crafted from natural materials and highlighting the intersection of function and aesthetics in wellness design.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Was oBike just building to sell?
summary: oBike, a Singapore-based bike-sharing operator, has exited the market due to financial pressures and difficulties in complying with new regulations. The company had run up a loss of over S$4 million in 2017 and was looking for an acquirer, but failed to secure a buyer. This exit highlights the challenges faced by startups in the bike-sharing industry, which have been criticized for their high capital expenditure and lack of profitability. The case of oBike serves as a warning that even successful startups can struggle to turn a profit and may be forced to shut down if their financial situation becomes unsustainable.

site_title: Tokyo smoking ban rules could shake up tobacco and retail markets
summary: Tokyo's Metropolitan Assembly has passed an ordinance banning smoking inside 84% of the city's bars and restaurants, set to come into effect in April 2020. This stricter regulation may boost the market for heat-not-burn tobacco products and benefit Japan Tobacco Inc, which is launching new products in the smokeless market. However, the ban may also negatively impact Japanese-style pubs and cafe operators, with some experiencing temporary declines in sales after implementing similar restrictions. The ordinance aims to prepare the city for the 2020 Olympics.

site_title: Stirling Residences open for preview this Saturday
summary: Mega residential project Stirling Residences in Singapore is set to open for preview this Saturday, offering 1,259 units across three 38-40 storey towers. The 99-year leasehold development features forest-themed zones, sky and roof terraces, and ranges from one to four-bedroom units, with prices starting from S$848,000 for a one-bedroom apartment. This marks Logan Property's first project in Singapore, following its record S$1 billion bid secured last May, and is expected to launch on July 14.

site_title: EOL seeks time to table new revamp plan
summary: Emas Offshore Limited, a Singapore-based offshore support vessel-focused company, has sought a four-month extension on its court moratoria to restructure its group of companies. The company needs extra time to negotiate new terms with BT Investment (BTI), a subsidiary of Baker Technology, and other potential investors. BTI had previously indicated it was no longer willing to pursue the current restructuring proposal, but is now prepared to propose fresh terms. Other investors have expressed interest in EOL's business operations and platform.

site_title: Apple, Samsung settle US patent dispute
summary: Apple and Samsung have settled a seven-year patent dispute, with terms not disclosed. The companies had previously been involved in a US$539 million jury verdict, with Samsung facing an additional payment of nearly $140 million. The settlement follows a US Supreme Court ruling in 2016 that patent violators don't have to pay the entire profit from stolen designs. The outcome likely avoids further legal fees for both companies, but the impact on their bottom line is unlikely to be significant. The settlement marks a public relations victory for Apple, but also shows Samsung's success in avoiding certain injunctions.

site_title: Vive La Vitra
summary: Project Vitra, a travelling exhibition showcasing the Swiss furniture brand Vitra, has arrived in Singapore. The exhibition, curated by CEO Nora Fehlbaum, features six categories and over 100 pieces of furniture, including iconic designs by Verner Panton, Jean Prouvé, Isamu Noguchi, Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec, Hella Jongerius, and Antonio Citterio. The exhibition highlights Vitra's commitment to designing versatile and comfortable furniture for various settings, from homes to public spaces. The exhibition runs until July 13 at the National Design Centre.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Putin-Trump summit set for July 16 in Helsinki: Kremlin, White House
summary: US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin will meet in Helsinki on July 16 to discuss Russian-US relations and national security issues. This follows a meeting between Trump's national security advisor John Bolton and Putin in Moscow, where they discussed the summit details. The two leaders aim to improve relations, which have been strained due to Russia's annexation of Crimea, involvement in eastern Ukraine, and allegations of political meddling. Trump's previous comments on re-admitting Russia to the G7 group of industrialized democracies also contributed to the deteriorating relations.

site_title: Sleuths of Shenton Way, in BT Weekend
summary: A rise in white-collar wrongdoing is being tracked in Singapore, with forensic accountants and lawyers working to uncover shady business practices. Meanwhile, a recent struggle by Hyflux has raised concerns about retail investors understanding complex financial products. The article also touches on mental health, highlighting the need for self-care and support in the workplace. Additionally, the World Cup is underway, and classic car enthusiasts are celebrating the Fullerton Concours d'Elegance. A health page emphasizes the importance of paying attention to chest pain, which can be linked to various heart-related conditions.

site_title: I Do? Or I Don't?
summary: A new play, 13.13.13, by TheatreWorks explores the Singaporean phenomenon of cohabitation, where couples live together without getting married. The play, starring Thomas Pang and Sharda Harrison, follows the story of William and Samantha, two successful professionals who see no reason to get married. The production sparked strong reactions from a 2017 public reading, with some audience members expressing their opinions on marriage and the characters. The play touches on the challenges of sustaining romantic longevity in today's dating world, where social media and dating apps can create temptation and choice.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Merkel rejects unilateral steps to curb migration
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel rejected unilateral steps to curb migration and stated that a "debt union" is not feasible in the euro area. Merkel also reiterated her commitment to boosting defense spending and discussed trade conflict with the US, saying leaders should engage in talks to avoid further tariffs. Merkel expressed concerns that EU leaders won't agree on a comprehensive migration plan this week, amid a clash with her ruling coalition.

images.alt_text: Ms Merkel with Slovenian Prime Minister Miro Cerar as they attend the European Union leaders summit in Brussels on Thursday.

site_title: Eight new members join Singapore Business Federation Council
summary: Eight new members have joined the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) Council, including three elected members and five co-opted members representing trade associations and chambers. The new members include Chong Ee Rong, Andrew Kwan, and Ron Sim, who were elected as new members, while Roland Ng, Jonathan Asherson, Ramasamy Dhinakaran, and Takuhiko Tochiori joined as representatives of trade associations and chambers. SBF chairman SS Teo was re-elected for his third consecutive two-year term. The new council aims to effect change through newly formed committees and the TAC Alliance, with support from Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing.

site_title: EOL seeks time to iron out new debt revamp terms with Baker Tech unit
summary: EOL, the Singapore-based offshore support vessel-focused company, has sought a four-month extension for restructuring its group of companies amid debt revamp talks with Baker Technology's BT Investment unit. The court had initially granted a moratorium until June 30, but EOL needs more time to iron out terms with BTI and other potential investors. BTI had expressed a willingness to propose fresh terms, while other investors have shown interest in EOL's business operations and vessels.

site_title: Koh Bros' maiden Korea project 96% sold
summary: Koh Brothers Group's maiden project in South Korea, Nonhyeon I'PARK, has sold 96% of its 99 apartments and 53 retail units within three months of its launch. The project, spanning 4,611 sq m, has 14 units left on the market. The company expects to complete the redevelopment by the fourth quarter of 2020, with the project contributing positively to its financial performance. Koh Brothers is confident in selling the remaining units and plans to continue pushing sales until they are sold out, citing promising prospects in the South Korean market.

site_title: Facebook payout in Oculus copyright spat cut to US$250m
summary: Facebook has won a US$250 million verdict in the Oculus copyright spat with ZeniMax Media Inc. A US District Judge in Dallas ruled that the jury's original US$500 million verdict was halved, with ZeniMax awarded US$200 million for breach of contract and US$50 million for copyright infringement. The judge rejected ZeniMax's request to ban sales of Oculus headsets, citing it would place an unfair hardship on the company and its business partners.

site_title: Creative industries hit back at internet critics of EU copyright revamp
summary: Europe's music, broadcasting, and publishing industries have pushed back against internet critics of an EU copyright overhaul, labeling claims it will harm the internet as misinformation and scaremongering. The EU's copyright reforms aim to make tech giants share revenues and include article 11, which could force Google to pay publishers for news snippets, and article 13, requiring online platforms to install filters to prevent copyright infringement. Industry groups and lawmakers argue the reforms are necessary to address online companies' free-riding on content, while critics claim it will burden small companies and stifle innovation.

site_title: Singapore's third desalination plant officially opens
summary: Singapore's third desalination plant, the Tuas Desalination Plant, officially opened on June 28, 2018, producing up to 30 million gallons of drinking water per day. This brings the country 30% closer to water self-sufficiency, with the plant's capacity adding to the existing SingSpring and Tuaspring Desalination Plants. The facility is the smallest in Singapore but most space-efficient, using solar power and advanced technology to purify water.

images.alt_text: The S$217 million Tuas Desalination Plant can produce up to 30 million gallons a day of drinking water, the amount used by around 200,000 households daily. With it, 30 per cent of Singapore's water needs can now be met by desalination, up from 25 per cent.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as Amazon buy hits drug stocks
summary: Amazon's acquisition of PillPack, a digital pharmacy, sent US drug stocks sliding, contributing to a lower opening on Wall Street. The Dow Jones fell 0.22%, the S&P 500 0.03%, and the Nasdaq 0.09%, despite gains in financial and technology stocks.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 53.40 points, or 0.22 per cent, at the open to 24,064.19.

site_title: Intimate, Unrivalled, Inimitable
summary: Uniworld's river cruise collection offers a unique, ultra-luxurious experience on a "floating boutique hotel" that visits four European countries. The SS Antoinette, a 443-foot ship, features luxurious décor and accommodations with private balconies. Guests can enjoy an all-inclusive fare with unlimited beverages, 24-hour room service, and complimentary Wi-Fi. The eight-day Castles along the Rhine itinerary includes stops in The Netherlands, France, Germany, and Switzerland, with opportunities to admire scenic landscapes, historic castles, and vineyards. Uniworld also offers a Generations Family Programme for families to enjoy together.

images.alt_text: Marksburg Castle is one of the only castles on the Rhine that has never been destroyed.
L'Orangerie Sky Lounge on the SS Antoinette.
A luxurious cabin bedroom aboard the ship.

site_title: Clearbridge Health announces planned spin-off for cancer diagnostics associate
summary: Clearbridge Health, a Catalist-listed medical technology company, announced plans to spin off its cancer diagnostics associate, Clearbridge BioMedics, which has secured fresh funding of S$6.6 million ahead of its IPO debut. The spin-off aims to develop end-to-end cancer diagnostic tests using its proprietary ClearCell FX System. The IPO is proposed for the fourth quarter of 2018 and is contingent on regulatory approvals. Clearbridge's founder, Johnson Chen, stated that the pre-IPO funding will accelerate growth and create a sustainable model of diagnostic solutions in Asia.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: It's time for Beijing to apply a bolder capital markets strategy
summary: Beijing should revise its capital market strategy to accelerate the renminbi's internationalisation, as data shows the dollar remains the major currency for cross-border lending and borrowing. Despite the Belt and Road initiative, lending in renminbi has declined, and issuing activity remains small. To achieve reserve status, a country must export its currency massively, which China can do by boosting cross-border lending and issuing debt in renminbi. A revised strategy is necessary to challenge the dollar's status and promote the renminbi's global use.

site_title: Asian currencies tumble on multiple fear factors
summary: Asian currencies tumbled due to a broad-based US dollar rally and concerns over the escalating US-China trade rift, which may escalate into a currency war. The Chinese yuan slid 3% against the US dollar, prompting speculation that Beijing could use it as a weapon to counter US tariff threats. This has sparked fears of capital flight from emerging economies, with some predicting a wider correction if the trade spat worsens or the Chinese economy weakens unexpectedly.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets dropped at the start of trading on Thursday, with the FTSE 100 index down 0.5% to 7,584.87 points. The DAX 30 and CAC 40 also declined 0.5% and 0.4% respectively. The decline was attributed to uncertainty over US-EU trade talks and tariff policies.

site_title: Q1 growth slows more than estimated on weak consumer spending
summary: The US economy slowed more than initially estimated in the first quarter, growing at a 2% annual rate due to weak consumer spending. This marked the weakest performance in nearly five years. However, growth is expected to have regained momentum, driven by a robust labor market and tax cuts. The Commerce Department revised its estimate, increasing the GDP growth rate from 2.2% to 2%.

site_title: Koufu plans S$85m IPO, plans to debut on July 18
summary: Koufu, a Singapore-based food court operator, plans to list on the Singapore Exchange mainboard with an initial public offering (IPO) of around S$85 million. The company aims to debut on July 18 and intends to recommend dividends of at least 50% of net profit after tax generated in 2018 and 2019. Koufu's market capitalization is expected to be around S$350 million upon its debut. The IPO will be used to fund expansion plans, including the construction of a new facility and F&B outlet revamps.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Finance is seeking public feedback on proposed changes to the Goods and Services Tax (GST) for imported services, including a "Netflix tax" on imported digital services. The GST prices of completed condos and private apartments increased 1.5% in May, while Singapore Airlines' CEO received a 14% pay cut in FY2018. Additionally, EDBI invested in Puppet, a US$42 million funding round for software automation company, and four residential sites were released under the 2018 Government Land Sales Programme.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages maintain buy recommendations on CapitaLand and Sheng Siong Group, citing steady sales and prices in China and a resilient business model, respectively. They attribute recent share price weakness to global trade tensions. Cache Logistics Trust is maintained at a "hold" with a target price of S$0.80, following the consolidation of ownership and decision-making.

site_title: The Adventurer
summary: Dhiren Doshi, vice-president at SAP Asia, is also an adventurer who has scaled the 8,167m summit of Dhaulagiri, one of the Himalayan mountains. He is driven by a passion for positive change and personal growth, and in his free time, he enjoys mountain-climbing, meditation, and travel. Doshi believes in living mindfully and respecting time, and has recently taken a digital detox at a retreat in India. He is also involved in various automotive reviews and articles, showcasing his diverse interests.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Auf wiedersehen, Germany
summary: Germany is experiencing a "spoiled summer" as national pride is hit by several setbacks. Chancellor Angela Merkel is fighting a mutiny in her government, the car industry is reeling from scandals, and Deutsche Bank is struggling financially. The national soccer team's humiliating defeat in the World Cup, which has not occurred since 1938, has sparked widespread outrage and raised questions about the future of coach Joachim Loew. The country's economic woes, including a growing trade war with the US, are also taking a toll on the country's reputation.

site_title: Asian stock photos marketplace Pixerf gets S$2m seed funding; launches in region
summary: PIXERF, an Asian-centric visual content marketplace, has raised S$2 million in seed funding from undisclosed private investors. The platform, founded by Sa'at Ismail and Michele Lee, aims to address the shortage of authentic Asian visual content. With the funding, PIXERF will enhance its platform, acquire users, and support client demand. The company will also introduce stock videos and vector illustrations into its marketplace. PIXERF empowers visual artists to showcase and earn from their work, while brands and agencies can source authentic Asian content to meet their business needs.

site_title: Balancing voting control and economic ownership
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has introduced a new listing rule, allowing companies to list with a dual class share (DCS) structure, where some shares carry more voting rights than others. This move aims to increase the competitiveness of the exchange, attracting more diversified groups of companies, particularly family-run businesses and technology startups. The new framework is seen as a balance between the US and Hong Kong's approaches, and is expected to entice companies to list in Singapore, potentially leading to a surge in listings.

site_title: Tee Land buys Teck Guan Ville in S$60m collective sale
summary: Tee Land has entered into an option-to-purchase agreement to acquire the freehold Teck Guan Ville condo in Upper East Coast Road for S$60 million. The proposed acquisition, subject to due diligence, aims to build a residential development on the 3,928.8 sq m plot. The acquisition will be financed by internal funds and bank borrowings, with no expected impact on Tee Land's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the financial year ending May 31 2019.

site_title: Capella Hotel Group to manage Regent Singapore from 2019
summary: Capella Hotel Group will manage Regent Singapore starting January 1, 2019, replacing Four Seasons, which has managed the hotel since 1993. The change comes after the Kwee family, owners of Pontiac Land Group, purchased the hospitality company from Horst Schulze in 2017. The three parties will work together to ensure a smooth transition, with Pontiac Land Group unveiling plans for the hotel before the end year.

site_title: Thyssenkrupp closer to steel joint venture as unions say yes
summary: Thyssenkrupp is closing in on a European steel joint venture with Tata Steel after a revised deal that addresses concerns from activist shareholders and labor representatives. The new agreement gives Thyssenkrupp 55% ownership and Tata 45%, with equally split voting rights. The deal, which has been in talks for over a year, represents a 600 million euro increase for Thyssenkrupp shareholders. The union has approved the deal, but labor representatives are warning that Thyssenkrupp's management should not be "scrapped like a used car."

site_title: US first-quarter GDP growth revised down to 2%
summary: The US economy experienced slower-than-expected growth in the first quarter, with GDP increasing at a 2% annual rate instead of 2.2%. This was largely due to weaker consumer spending, which slowed to a 0.9% rate, its lowest pace in nearly five years. However, growth is expected to rebound in the second quarter, driven by a robust labor market and tax cuts, with estimates suggesting a 5.3% rate.

site_title: Singapore shares end flat
summary: Singapore shares ended flat on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,257.57, up 2.8 points or 0.09% from the opening price. The market saw a listless trade amid global trade friction. Local banks United Overseas Bank and OCBC gained, while DBS eased.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Why are so many political parties blowing up?
summary: The US, Italy, Britain, Germany, and France are experiencing party splits due to climate change, globalization, and technological advancements. The US Republican Party has shifted to a protectionist stance, while the Democrats are divided between a quasi-socialist wing and a centre-left wing. Italy's centre-left party was replaced by a coalition of far-left and far-right populists, while Britain's Labour Party has moved to the left. Germany's ruling party formed a fragile coalition, and France's centrist party did not exist three years ago. These changes are reshaping the ecosystems of work, learning, geopolitics, ethics, and community, making it challenging for traditional parties to contain and balance new choices.

site_title: Second Chance Properties Q3 net profit falls 61.6%
summary: Second Chance Properties reported a 61.6% drop in Q3 net profit to S$2.1 million, despite a 3.2% increase in revenue to S$9.7 million. The company attributed the decline to lower profits from its securities business and higher unrealized losses. It also expects losses in its apparel and gold businesses, as well as lower rental income, due to rising interest rates and labor laws. The company plans to close four more apparel stores to prevent future losses.

site_title: Xi warns Mattis China won't surrender 'one inch' of territory
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping warned US Defense Secretary James Mattis that China won't give up any territory considered its own, amid security disputes over the South China Sea and Taiwan. The comments were made during their meeting in Beijing, where Xi emphasized China's sovereignty and territorial integrity. The warning came as tensions between the US and China continue to escalate, with the US branding China a "strategic competitor" and restricting its participation in international military exercises.

site_title: Powell wants "real economy" to guide Fed
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell is shifting the focus of monetary policy from traditional economic models to the "real economy," aiming to gauge the labor market's room to run. Powell wants to let the labor market run hotter, with a projected jobless rate of 3.5% over the next two years, despite concerns that a tight labor market could generate bubbles and imbalances. This approach is seen as a departure from previous Fed chairs, with benefits including improved labor force attachment and boost in productivity, but also risks, such as triggering excesses and imbalances.

site_title: Qantas Airways says chairman to retire
summary: Qantas Airways Chairman Leigh Clifford will retire in October 2018. Richard Goyder, a board member, will assume the role of chairman following the annual general meeting on October 26.

site_title: Australian shares edge up on banks, materials; NZ little changed
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Thursday, snapping a four-session losing streak, driven by gains in banks and materials. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,215.4, with financials leading the gains after a weak start. The recovery in commodity prices also spurred demand for materials.

site_title: Regulating Time
summary: Swiss watch manufacturer Chronoswiss is celebrating its 35th anniversary with the launch of the Flying Regulator Open Gear Anniversary Edition, a limited-edition Regulator model. The watch features a unique design with the anniversary year displayed on the minute scale. Additionally, Hautlence has unveiled the HL Vagabonde model with a satellite-inspired dial, while EBEL has launched the EBEL Wave collection for women with minimalist and colorful dials.

The EBEL Wave continues to evolve.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.4 points to 1,665.68. The index saw 1.6 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion in volume, with 419 losers outnumbering 365 gainers.

site_title: A crib sheet for getting more women leaders
summary: Singapore's corporate boards lack gender diversity, with only 8% of board seats held by women as of 2016. Research shows that increasing women's representation on boards can improve organizational health, decision-making, and financial performance. To address this issue, companies must adopt a sense of urgency, expand their criteria for qualified candidates, and maintain an active pipeline of female executives. McKinsey & Company recommends companies create programs to develop and retain women, promote flexible work arrangements, and openly proclaim their interest in gender balance.

images.alt_text: In Singapore, as in many other places, progress towards gender equality on corporate boards has been a long, slow crawl.

site_title: Emerging Town and Cities Singapore requests lifting of trading suspension from Friday
summary: Emerging Town and Cities Singapore has requested the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to lift the trading suspension of its Catalist shares starting June 29. The company has disclosed satisfactory results from an internal audit and confirmed sufficient working capital for the next 12 months. It also assured shareholders that material information has been disclosed and will be updated if there are any developments. Additionally, the company has made undertakings to address concerns related to its largest shareholder, Luo Shandong. Trading is expected to resume on June 29, pending SGX Regco's approvals.

site_title: China turmoil batters last emerging-market haven
summary: Emerging markets are experiencing a downturn, with China's yuan slump sapping confidence in peers worldwide. India's rupee is at an all-time low, South Africa's rand is near a record low, and the Indonesian rupiah is at its weakest level since 2015. The MSCI index of developing-nation stocks is heading towards a bear market, and average yield spreads of sovereign bonds are near a two-year high. China's economy is poised for its worst quarter since 2015, with speculation that authorities are allowing the yuan to weaken in retaliation against the US in the deepening trade war.

site_title: Koh Brothers Group receives strong demand for maiden entry into South Korea
summary: Koh Brothers Group's maiden project in South Korea, Nonhyeon I'PARK, has seen strong demand with 96% of units sold within three months of its launch. The mixed-use development, located in Seoul's Gangnam district, achieved 75% sales in its first seven days and 45% ownership by the joint venture with Daeryun D & I Co. The project is expected to contribute positively to Koh Brothers' financial performance and the company is confident to sell the remaining 14 units by Q3 2018.

site_title: French transport minister says Air France-KLM CEO should be air transport expert
summary: France's transport minister Elisabeth Borne suggested that Air France-KLM's new CEO should be an expert in air transport due to the airline's global competition. Borne stated that the ideal candidate would have experience in the sector to quickly take leadership. Air France-KLM's search for a new CEO is ongoing, with Philippe Capron, Veolia's chief financial officer, reportedly considered for the position. The airline hopes to reach a decision soon.

site_title: Koufu plans S$85m IPO in July
summary: Koufu, a Singapore-based food court operator, plans to launch an initial public offering (IPO) worth around S$85 million, with the goal of raising its market capitalization to around S$350 million. The company, founded by executive chairman and CEO Pang Lim in 2002, manages 47 food courts, 14 coffee shops, and plans to expand with new outlets. Koufu's net profit last year was S$26.8 million, with revenue steady at S$216.7 million. The IPO will fund expansion plans and a new central kitchen facility.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended Thursday with a 0.5% gain, lifting the Hang Seng Index to 28,497.32, following three days of losses. Energy firms rose on a surge in oil prices, but investors remain cautious due to China-US trade tensions. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index retreated 0.93% and 1.19%, respectively.

site_title: Prices of completed condo, private apartments up 1.5% in May from April: NUS index
summary: Singapore's completed non-landed private homes experienced a 1.5% price increase in May, rebounding from a 0.2% drop in April. The National University of Singapore's (NUS) flash estimates show apartments in central and non-central locations rose 1.8% and 1.3%, respectively. Prices for small units climbed 1.2%. Year-to-date, prices are up 3.4% for completed private apartments, with a 9.3% year-over-year increase.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: British media rejoice in German World Cup despair
