summary: British newspapers celebrate Germany's early exit from the World Cup, labeling it "Schadenfreude" and reveling in their historic rivalry. The press mocks Germany's underperforming team, with The Sun printing a table of English footballers who suffered at their hands. The Daily Mail jokes about Germans starting their holidays early, while The Guardian and The Times take a more measured tone, with some Italian papers drawing parallels between Germany's failure and broader societal issues.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on renewed trade war worries
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Thursday due to renewed trade war concerns, despite mixed messages from the US administration on a US-China commercial confrontation. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.01% and the Topix index dropped 0.26%. The decline was attributed to revived trade war worries, with fresh comments from the US administration sending mixed signals.

site_title: Korean Air head grilled over tax evasion
summary: Korean Air's patriarch, Cho Yang Ho, was grilled by prosecutors over alleged tax evasion and other crimes. He and his family allegedly avoided paying 50 billion won (S$61.5 million) in taxes on overseas assets inherited after their father's death in 2002. Cho expressed remorse and vowed to cooperate with the investigation. The case is part of a series of probes targeting the Korean Air business dynasty.

images.alt_text: Cho Yang Ho, 69, and his brothers and a sister allegedly avoided paying 50 billion won (S$61.5 million) in taxes on the overseas assets they inherited after their father Cho Choong Hoon died in 2002.

site_title: Qantas names former Wesfarmers CEO as chairman
summary: Qantas appoints Richard Goyder as its new chairman from October, replacing Leigh Clifford who is retiring. Goyder, former CEO of Wesfarmers, has been a Qantas board member since 2017. The airline is set to report record full-year underlying earnings before tax of up to A$1.6 billion in August, but rising oil prices may temper the global airline outlook. Clifford will step down after the annual meeting in October, marking the end of his 11-year tenure.

images.alt_text: Qantas Airways said on Thursday it is appointing former Wesfarmers Ltd CEO Richard Goyder (pictured) as its new chairman from October, replacing long-serving chairman Leigh Clifford who is retiring at a time of record earnings at the airline.

site_title: China to lift ban on imports of UK beef: Hammond
summary: China has agreed to lift its ban on imports of British beef, a decision made after negotiations with UK Finance Minister Philip Hammond. The ban, imposed in the 1990s due to a BSE crisis, will be lifted, providing a boost to British farmers.

site_title: Trump favours tougher foreign investment oversight but stops short of targeting China
summary: US President Donald Trump supports tougher foreign investment oversight, particularly for sensitive technology, but stops short of targeting China. A plan to enhance the powers of the Committee on Foreign Investment in the US (CFIUS) to review potential foreign investment has been approved by both the House and Senate, but needs reconciliation. Trump backs broader measures that would apply to any country, instead of singling out China, which has seen a decline in investment in the US. He instructs the Commerce Department to look at new export controls to defend American technology and intellectual property.

site_title: Ipco board warns of fiscal 2018 loss
summary: Ipco International's board warned of a net loss for the 2018 fiscal year due to impairment of intangible assets and translation effects on foreign currency denominated subsidiaries. The group is finalizing its FY2018 results, which will be released by June 30. Ipco's shares closed at S$0.002 apiece on the same day.

site_title: China to crack down on property irregularities in 30 major cities
summary: China will crack down on property irregularities in 30 major cities from July to December, led by seven government entities. The crackdown aims to stem speculation, crack down on illegal agencies and developers, and fake advertisements. The move follows recent concerns over property market irregularities. The entities involved include the housing ministry and the Ministry of Public Security, as well as banking and insurance regulators.

site_title: Courts Asia offers to buy back S$75m of 5.75% notes due 2019 at 100.75% of par
summary: Courts Asia is offering to buy back S$75 million of 5.75% notes due 2019 at 100.75% of par, with a call option to redeem the bonds early at 100% of par. Noteholders can receive an early consent fee of 0.25% if consenting by July 13, or 0.15% if consenting after the deadline. The company plans to exercise the call option within 15 days if approved. This move is part of Courts Asia's capital and liability management initiatives, citing existing surplus cash.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won plunge as global trade spat dents sentiment
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index plummeted 1.19% to 2,314.24, its lowest since May 2017, amid global trade tensions. The won also fell, reaching a one-year low of 1,124.2 per dollar. Shares of Samsung Electronics and LG Electronics declined 2.4% and 3.4%, respectively, while cosmetics companies rose due to strong export demand, particularly to China, Vietnam, and the EU.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.91 points to 1,659.17. Losers outnumbered gainers 80 to 51, and volume was 21.36 million lots worth RM11.8 million.

site_title: Four residential sites released under H1 2018 GLS programme
summary: Four residential sites were released for sale under the 2018 Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme, with 1,920 units available. The sites, launched by the URA and HDB, include Jalan Jurong Kechil and Canberra Link, with tenders closing on September 4. Two additional sites, on the Reserve List, will be put up for tender when a developer submits a minimum acceptable price.

site_title: Company director who cheated SME crowdfunding firm gets 10 years' jail
summary: A Singapore company director, Choy Peiyi, has been sentenced to 10 years' jail for cheating a crowdfunding firm out of S$25 million. Choy, 35, used fake invoices to deceive Capital Springboard Singapore, which lends to small and medium-sized enterprises. He repaid about S$20 million, but the company still suffered losses of over S$6.8 million. Choy pleaded guilty to 23 counts of cheating on June 8.

site_title: Indonesia launches infrastructure investment fund: SOE ministry
summary: Indonesia's state-owned enterprise ministry has launched an infrastructure investment fund, PT Bandha Investasi Indonesia, aiming to finance 4 trillion rupiah worth of infrastructure projects. The fund, valued at 1.8 trillion rupiah, targets several years of investment and will be formed as a sub-unit of PT Bahana Pembinaan Usaha Indonesia (Persero) and Danareksa Capital.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon trading at 3,258.61, up 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading at 3,258.61, up 0.1% on Thursday, driven by a 0.1% gain in the Straits Times Index. Gainers beat losers 150 to 141, with active stocks including Venture Corp and Genting Singapore. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite US tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: US says India talks "a priority" after postponing twice
summary: US Ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley says a top-level strategic dialogue with India will take place "as soon as possible" after the talks were postponed twice. The dialogue, which includes discussions on US sanctions against Russia and Iran, arms sales, and trade, was originally planned for July 6 but was rescheduled due to unavoidable reasons. Haley emphasized that the talks are a priority and will happen soon, with the goal of strengthening the US-India strategic partnership, particularly in regional security.

images.alt_text: US Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley said on Thursday that a top-level strategic dialogue with India will take place as soon as possible, after Washington put off the meeting for a second time in months.

site_title: Draft GST bill to give taxman powers to force entry, make arrests without warrant for serious tax crimes
summary: The Finance Ministry has proposed draft GST bill to give taxman enhanced powers, including forced entry, arrests without warrants, and body searches, to combat serious tax crimes. These powers will be exercised by trained investigation officers and used only where necessary. The bill also allows for information sharing with law enforcement agencies and introduces stricter rules for unauthorised GST collection, including custodial sentences. The proposed changes aim to counteract syndicates and recalcitrant taxpayers, particularly those committing tax fraud by absconding with collected GST or fabricating refund claims.

site_title: BP buys UK's largest electric vehicle charging company
summary: BP has agreed to acquire UK's largest electric vehicle charging company, Chargemaster, with 6,500 charging points across the UK. The deal, undisclosed terms, aims to provide fast and ultra-fast charging at BP sites. The acquisition is part of BP's efforts to invest in clean energy, with plans to spend $500 million annually. BP estimates 12 million electric vehicles will be on UK roads by 2040, and convenient charging will be key to adoption. Chargemaster will operate as a wholly owned BP entity, marking BP's expansion into the growing market for greener transport.

site_title: SIA paid CEO 14% less in FY2018, reflecting year-before performance
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) paid its CEO, Goh Choon Phong, 14% less in FY2018, reflecting lower bonuses and valuations for his share-based compensation. The airline's net profit rebounded to $892.9 million, up 55.2% from FY2017. SIA chairman Peter Seah's remuneration more than doubled to $763,110, while directors' fees declined 1.6% to $1.91 million. The airline met its safety target for FY2018, with 0.96 incident reports per 1,000 flights, and maintained its goal to reduce electricity consumption and waste generation by 2021.

site_title: EDBI joins US$42m funding round for software automation company Puppet
summary: EDBI has joined a $42 million funding round for Puppet, a software automation company, alongside Cisco Investments, Kleiner Perkins, and True Ventures. Puppet's automation platform helps manage IT assets and improve efficiency. The company, which has over 40,000 customers, aims to drive DevOps and automation gains for its customers. With the investment, Puppet plans to scale up its local talent pool in Singapore and augment the country's digital transformation strategy. The funding round values Puppet at over $1 billion.

site_title: Australia: Shares tick up on materials and banks; NZ rises
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 6,211.10, driven by gains in materials and financial stocks. BHP jumped 1.4% and Rio Tinto climbed 0.9%, while top lender Commonwealth Bank rose 0.7% and Macquarie Group gained 2.2%. Oil-focused firms also benefited from US crude price gains. Real estate stocks fell, limiting gains. In New Zealand, the benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.2% to 9,013.79.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Thursday; STI down 0.15% to 3,249.97
summary: Singapore stocks opened relatively flat on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.15% to 3,249.97. A total of 37.7 million shares worth S$113.1 million changed hands, with 59 losers outnumbering 49 gainers. Ezion was the most actively traded counter, rising 1.1% to 9.2 Singapore cents. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Public feedback sought on proposed GST changes for imported services, including 'Netflix tax'
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Finance is seeking public feedback on proposed Goods and Services Tax (GST) changes, including a "Netflix tax" on imported digital services, set to take effect on January 1, 2020. The changes aim to ensure the GST system remains "fair and resilient" in a digital economy. Businesses importing digital services, such as movie and music streaming, will be required to register with the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore and collect GST on B2C supplies. The feedback period ends on July 18.

site_title: Asia: Shares flirt with 9-month low on mounting trade war fears
summary: Asian stocks plummeted to nine-month lows on June 28, 2018, amid growing trade war fears. US oil prices surged to a 3½-year high, and the US yield curve flattened further, raising recession concerns. The US S&P 500 lost 0.60% on Wednesday, and MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan fell 0.25%. The US administration's approach to trade has been modified to curb Chinese investments in US technology firms, but markets remain anxious about the damage to the global economy.

site_title: Goldman Sachs lunch at Singapore's Taste Paradise set the scene for 1MDB's money probe
summary: Goldman Sachs bankers Roger Ng and Tim Leissner, who facilitated a $1.75 billion bond offering for 1MDB in 2012, are under investigation by Singapore and US authorities. The probe focuses on the role of Ng and Leissner in siphoning off $577 million in proceeds from the bond sale, which ended up in an account at Swiss bank BSI SA. Leissner is barred from finance in Singapore and the US, while Malaysian authorities are preparing a warrant for Ng's arrest. The investigation is part of a larger probe into 1MDB's alleged misappropriation of $4.5 billion.

site_title: S$1b worth of GST Vouchers, MediSave top-ups to benefit 1.6m Singaporeans
summary: The Singaporean government has announced that 1.6 million citizens will receive a total of S$1 billion in GST Voucher benefits and MediSave top-ups. Eligible individuals will receive notifications by July 6, with criteria including age and annual home value. The GST Voucher Scheme, introduced in 2012, aims to offset GST expenses for lower- and middle-income Singaporeans.

site_title: US business spending on equipment cooling; trade gap narrowing
summary: US business spending on equipment cooling, with new orders for capital goods and shipments unexpectedly falling in May. Despite this, data suggests moderate growth in business spending in the second quarter, driven by the Trump administration's tax cut package. The goods trade deficit narrowed 3.7% to $64.8 billion in May, offsetting an anticipated drag from inventory investment. Trade tensions between the US and its major trade partners, including China, remain a concern, with economists warning that escalating tensions could hurt business sentiment and undercut economic growth.

site_title: MinLaw appoints DP Information Network as operator of Moneylenders Credit Bureau
summary: Ministry of Law (MinLaw) has designated DP Information Network (DP Info) as the operator of the Moneylenders Credit Bureau (MLCB) under the amended Moneylenders Act. DP Info will facilitate the implementation of amendments, including a new regulatory regime for borrower data and an aggregate loan cap. The new designation is valid from the commencement of the amended Act to March 1, 2020. DP Info, a Singapore credit and business information bureau, was first appointed by MinLaw in 2015 to design and develop the MLCB, which was launched in 2016.

site_title: Argentina stocks plunge amid emerging markets concerns
summary: Argentina's Buenos Aires Stock Exchange plummeted 8.8% on Wednesday, its worst closing performance in years, amid concerns over emerging markets and IMF loan tensions. The Merval index fell to 25,965 points, following four days of consecutive losses. The peso has dropped 30% against the dollar this year, and the country is struggling to stabilize its economy after receiving a $15 billion IMF loan. Analysts believe the government's plan to introduce a tax on shares may be a sign of efforts to trim the deficit and halt inflation.

site_title: Goodluck Garden en bloc sale goes to court
summary: The owners of Goodluck Garden condominium will head to court after the Strata Titles Board issued a stop order on the collective sale of the 210-unit freehold residential development. The stop order was issued after mediation with dissenting owners failed, who claimed they were misled about a development charge. The collective sale committee has 14 days to apply to the High Court to seek approval for the sale, which could happen in early September.

site_title: Bank of England under fire for expenses
summary: The Bank of England is under fire for excessive expenses, with lawmaker Simon Clarke citing £11,000 in flight costs and £400 in taxi bills as evidence of wasteful spending. Clarke compared the BOE's expenses to the UK Parliament's scandal in 2009, where lawmakers were criticized for reimbursements. The BOE's policy of flying business class and hosting expensive summer parties has raised questions about value for money for UK taxpayers. The central bank has promised to investigate and report back to lawmakers.

site_title: Ultra-luxury Bijan bag seized from Najib-linked residence is from 'most expensive store' in the world
summary: Malaysian police seized a "Bijan special order" bag from former Prime Minister Najib Razak's residence, valued at an unknown price, linked to the 1MDB scandal. The bag is from the House of Bijan, known as the most expensive store in the world. The seizure is part of ongoing raids and investigations into Najib's alleged corruption. The bag's exact value and price tag remain unknown, but its origin from the world's most expensive store adds to the luxury and intrigue surrounding the seizure.

site_title: Sunway Property builds presence in Singapore
summary: Malaysian conglomerate Sunway Property is expanding its presence in Singapore through new projects and land acquisitions, including a S$530 million en bloc purchase of Brookvale Park condominium. This move aims to strengthen its position in the local property market. The acquisition is part of Sunway Property's efforts to increase its footprint in Singapore, which is seen as a strategic location for growth.

site_title: Merkel's weakness at home exposes shaky French liaison
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's struggles to form a stable government have hindered Franco-German relations, undermining French President Emmanuel Macron's efforts to revitalize their partnership. Merkel's problems in assembling and holding together a coalition after the September general election have led to a sense of drift and isolation, damaging the French president's efforts to address competitiveness gaps between the two countries. This development is particularly concerning for Macron, who had made progress in promoting European unity and economic restructuring at home.

site_title: Oxley unit acquires 5% stake in Malaysia land owner
summary: Oxley Holdings Limited has acquired a 5% stake in Beverly Heights Properties Sdn Bhd (BHP) in Malaysia for RM22.5 million. Oxley Star Sdn Bhd, its wholly owned subsidiary, will hold a 10% stake in BHP after the acquisition. The deal grants Oxley Star exclusive authority to develop the land, which is valued at RM410 million. The consideration was funded by internal funds and bank borrowings. BHP, the land owner, plans to develop the land into a township.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust issues S$130m, 3.25% four-year bond
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) is issuing a S$130 million, 3.25% four-year bond with semi-annual coupons. The bond, with a face value of S$250,000, is being managed by DBS Bank as the sole lead manager and bookrunner. The coupon rate is 97.7 basis points above the four-year Swap Offer Rate. The bond matures on July 4, 2022.

site_title: NTUC Income eyes all-digital services across its business
summary: NTUC Income, Singapore's largest composite insurer, aims to digitize its entire business within one to two years. The company has already introduced an all-digital Integrated Shield plan and is exploring ways to make its life and health insurance services online. Income's chief operating officer, Peter Tay, believes that digitization will attract customers who prefer online services and change the way insurance is sold. The company is investing heavily in digital transformation, with a team of 20 working on the project, and expects to offer its core business entirely online in the near future.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Sterling heads for biggest drop in two weeks as US dollar rebounds
summary: Sterling falls 0.7% to a one-week low against the US dollar as the dollar rebounds, with the pound trading at $1.3127. The decline is attributed to imminent Brexit talks and doubts about a potential interest rate hike by the Bank of England this summer. The pound had rebounded from seven-month lows last week after a Bank of England meeting raised expectations for rate hikes, but analysts now question whether the window for a hike will close after August due to Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on renewed trade war worries
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on June 28, 2018, due to renewed trade war worries, with the Nikkei 225 index losing 0.33% to 22,197.50. This followed losses on Wall Street, as revived trade tensions between the US and other countries raised concerns. The broader Topix index also declined 0.32% to 1,725.90.

site_title: AC Milan banned from Europa League as bidders circle
summary: AC Milan has been banned from the Europa League for the next two seasons due to uncertain finances, according to UEFA. The ban follows an investigation under Financial Fair Play regulations, which found the club had not provided sufficient evidence of its financial stability. A second US sporting tycoon, Rocco Commisso, has expressed interest in taking over the club, with a bid for a majority stake reportedly worth 70% of AC Milan. The club's Chinese owner, Li Yonghong, is trying to secure funding to improve his negotiating position in any potential sale.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at open on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened flat on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 11.75 points to 28,368.01, amid a brewing trade war between China and the US. However, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.47% and 0.34% respectively. Investors remain cautious due to the ongoing trade tensions, despite the Hang Seng Index reaching a new record high.

site_title: Serial System CEO assisting in 'certain investigations' in Taiwan
summary: Serial System's CEO Derek Goh Bak Heng has been requested by the Taipei District Prosecutors Office and the Investigation Bureau in Taiwan to assist in certain investigations under the Securities and Exchange Act of Taiwan. The company's board stated that Goh's roles and responsibilities as executive chairman and group CEO remain unaffected, and business operations will continue as usual. The company's counter retreated 1.33% following the announcement. The exact nature of the investigations is unclear.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ipco, Serial System, Vallianz, EpiCentre
summary: Ipco International expects a net loss for the 2018 fiscal year due to impairment of intangible assets and translation effects. Serial System's executive chairman has been called upon by Taiwanese authorities to assist in investigations. Vallianz Holdings has entered into a swap agreement with trade creditors, exchanging payables for shares. EpiCentre Holdings is exploring a reverse takeover and issuing new shares to raise funds.

site_title: Disney clears hurdle for Fox tie-up with US regulator approval
summary: US regulators have conditionally approved Disney's proposed $71.3 billion acquisition of 21st Century Fox, subject to Disney selling 22 regional sports networks. The deal, which includes the 20th Century Fox studios and Hulu, must still be approved by a federal court. Comcast, which had bid $65 billion, is exploring a joint bid with another company, potentially reaching $90 billion. The deal aims to reshape the media-entertainment landscape, but regulators noted that an asset sale would prevent higher prices for cable sports programming distributors.

site_title: Lyft value jumps to US$15.1b in new funding round
summary: Lyft raises $600 million in a funding round, valuing the company at $15.1 billion. The financing is led by Fidelity Management & Research Company and joined by Senator Investment Group. This valuation is more than double Lyft's previous $7.5 billion figure. The company's growth follows scandals affecting ride-share giant Uber, with Uber's valuation rising to $62 billion in a recent funding round. Lyft has expanded to Toronto and other Canadian cities, and its business continues to grow.

site_title: Malaysian police to quiz Najib and wife soon over haul of riches
summary: Malaysian police plan to question former Prime Minister Najib Razak and his wife Rosmah Mansor over the seizure of nearly $275 million in jewelry, handbags, watches, and other luxury items from six properties linked to the couple. The items, valued at between $307.9 million and $376.3 million, were found as part of the investigation into the missing billions from state fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad. Najib has been barred from leaving the country and has faced criticism for his family's lavish spending. The police plan to verify the ownership of the seized items, with Najib claiming most were gifts to his wife and daughter.

site_title: China's solid industrial profits tamp trade war worries for now
summary: China's industrial firms saw a significant increase in profits in May, with profits rising sharply despite slowing economic momentum and a trade dispute with the US. Policymakers have been trying to balance growth and financial risks by cutting reserve levels for banks. This move aims to temper potential growth drag from the trade dispute. The news provides a positive outlook for China's economy for now, but raises concerns about the country's slowing growth and the impact of the trade war.

site_title: Spooked no more? Hong Kong's 'haunted apartment' prices levitate with white-hot market
summary: Hong Kong's housing market has seen a surge in demand for "haunted apartments" due to their lower prices, despite their dark history. Landlords like Ng Goon Lau have bought these flats at discounts of up to 40% due to their past tragedies, such as suicides and murders. The market has narrowed these discounts, and now buyers are willing to overlook the flats' history. Property analysts predict further price increases, making these flats more affordable, and banks are providing mortgages for them. The market's obsession with property has led to a psychological hurdle for some, but others see them as a practical way to own a house.

site_title: Trump decides against harshest measures on China investments
summary: US President Donald Trump has decided against invoking a law to curb Chinese investments in the country, opting instead to push Congress to strengthen an existing review process. The decision comes amid allegations of widespread intellectual property theft by China. Trump wants to bolster the Committee on Foreign Investment in the US (CFIUS) to prevent companies from violating US intellectual property rights. The move is seen as a more measured strategy, favoring coordination with Congress over executive action.

site_title: CapitaLand acquires prime mixed-use site in Chongqing worth 5.7b yuan
summary: CapitaLand acquired a 32-hectare prime mixed-use site in Chongqing for 2.2 billion yuan (S$454.3 million), boosting its residential pipeline in China by over 2,100 units. The site includes 1,900 residential units, a shopping mall, and office and retail space. The acquisition is strategic, given Chongqing's strong investment potential and favorable market conditions. CapitaLand expects to recognize gains from sales of soon-to-be-completed residential units and expand its retail network in the city.

images.alt_text: One of the brownfield sites of CapitaLand's newly acquired 32-hectare prime mixed-use site in Chongqing. As at end-March 2018, China accounted for 37% of CapitaLand group's total assets.

site_title: Facebook, Google 'manipulate' users to share data: study
summary: A Norwegian Consumer Council study found that Facebook and Google set the least privacy-friendly options as defaults, despite the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) aiming to give users more control. The study, Deceived By Design, concluded that these companies manipulate users into sharing private information, contradicting consumer expectations and the regulation's intention. The findings have boosted the case for the new laws, which can fine companies up to 20 million euros for breaching data rules, with the US tech giants facing their first official complaints under the law.

site_title: A different kind of school
summary: School of Concepts (SOC), a unique learning center in Singapore, focuses on play-based education for children aged three and above, with a 30:70 ratio of resources for underprivileged families. Founded by Mint Lim, who has dyslexia herself, SOC's curriculum emphasizes language acquisition, phonics, and positive education, with a focus on bridging the gap between children and their parents. The center aims to provide equal opportunities for all children, regardless of their socio-economic situation, and has seen success stories such as teaching a young girl to read within six months and instilling social etiquette.

site_title: Temasek invests US$250m in UST Global
summary: Temasek has invested US$250 million in UST Global, a digital transformation solutions company, for a minority stake. Founded in 1999, UST Global provides services in digital customer engagement, data analytics, and more. The investment marks Temasek's first institutional investment in UST Global. CEO Sajan Pillai stated that the partnership will help UST Global reach new clients and design digital-impact strategies. This investment is seen as a strategic move to further UST Global's growth, particularly through acquisitions.

images.alt_text: Temasek has invested US$250 million in UST Global for a minority stake, the digital transformation solutions company announced on Wednesday night.

site_title: Affordable rockets push boundaries of space travel
summary: US space agency NASA is increasingly relying on private companies, such as SpaceX, to resupply the International Space Station. SpaceX has launched 15 missions for NASA since 2012, marking a revolution in space travel. The US now leads the global launch market, surpassing Russia and China. Miniature satellites, known as CubeSats, are becoming increasingly accessible, with prices as low as tens of thousands of dollars. Companies like SpaceX and OneWeb plan to launch constellations of small satellites for internet access and Earth observation. NASA is also working on a lunar space station and plans to send astronauts to Mars in the coming decades.

site_title: Teams gear up for 9th BT Corporate Golf League
summary: The 9th BT Corporate Golf League is set to tee off on July 11 at Sentosa Golf Club's New Tanjong course. The event features 24 teams, including 11 competitive and 13 social teams, with OrangeTee & Tie teaming up with company directors and developers. The defending champions are Boustead, while Edrington will participate in the social section. The league aims to foster friendship among business partners, with organizers welcoming more teams to participate.

site_title: Healthcare AI set to revolutionise the way illness is managed
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is set to revolutionize healthcare in Asia, transforming the way illnesses are discovered and treated. AI systems can rapidly interpret health data, suggesting fast and effective healthcare solutions, and produce more meaningful insights than humans. This leads to more thorough diagnoses, enabling doctors to predict, prevent, and treat diseases more effectively. AI also enhances treatment, enabling precision medicine by combining individual and collective data to determine the most effective treatment. As a result, patients are expected to visit doctors less, with home monitoring systems and mobile devices becoming more prevalent, and receiving tailored, effective, and less toxic treatments.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Megachem Limited, an integrated solution provider for specialty chemicals, is expected to deliver top and bottom line growth due to a growing global economy, strong demand from Asia, and a focus on the biotech segment. The company trades at a 9.6 times price-to-earnings multiple, offering an attractive dividend yield of 4.8-5.7%. StarHub announced the axing of 11 pay-TV channels and introduction of 7 new channels, while DISA initiated a buy recommendation with a forecast of 135% net revenue growth. Companies also reported on their Q2 performance, including Creative Technology's potential revenue shortfall.

site_title: Apple and Samsung settle lengthy iPhone patent battle
summary: Apple and Samsung have settled a seven-year-old patent battle over iPhone design, following a federal court jury's $539 million award against Samsung for copying patented iPhone features. The settlement ends the litigation, which began in 2011, and dismisses all remaining claims and counterclaims. Financial terms were not disclosed, and neither company elaborated on the brief court order. The case was seen as a victory for Apple, which argued that design was essential to the iPhone, and had implications for whether design can be considered an article of design in complex products like smartphones.

images.alt_text: Apple and Samsung have ended a years-long patent battle over copied iPhone design with an undisclosed settlement, according to a US court filing Tuesday.

site_title: Europe: Fresh optimism on trade lifts shares
summary: European shares rose 0.7% on Wednesday after the US and China de-escalated their trade dispute, with the Stoxx 600 index closing at an 11-week high. The news, which sparked fears of higher global trade barriers, was fueled by the Trump administration's decision to use a strengthened security review for investments in technologies rather than China-specific restrictions. The US stock market also opened higher, boosting Wall Street and lifting optimism for European shares.

site_title: Turkish Airlines set to finance construction of Istanbul's 3rd airport
summary: Turkish Airlines is in talks with 12-13 Turkish and Chinese banks to secure $800-1 billion in financing for its facilities at Istanbul's new airport, with a deal expected to be signed in July. The airport, set to open on October 29, has received $10.25 billion in investment and will have an initial passenger capacity of 90 million per year. The airline needs financing for building and equipment costs, with maturity terms between three and five years.

site_title: Reds vs Blues: America's two political tribes are at it again
summary: US politics have become polarized into two distinct tribes, the "Reds" and the "Blues", who often see each other as living in separate universes. The Reds, comprised of Republicans and conservatives, believe in a strong national identity and security, while the Blues, comprised of Democrats and liberals, advocate for open borders and global economic integration. This divide is reflected in their differing narratives on issues like immigration and is fueling an increasingly bitter and divisive atmosphere, with some even using social media to "unsee" each other.

site_title: Indian steelmaker eyes more deals in Europe, US on expansion drive
summary: Indian steelmaker JSW Steel Ltd plans to expand its global footprint by scouting for more deals in the US and Europe. The company has already met half its target for 10 million tonnes of capacity overseas and is now looking to buy more facilities, with a total planned investment of $1 billion in the US. Despite US tariffs on steel imports, JSW believes the US economy is buoyant and demand is picking up, making it an attractive opportunity for investment. The company aims to boost its capacity by over a third to 25 million tonnes a year by 2020.

site_title: Bitcoin drops back below US$6,000 as 2018 loss approaches 60%
summary: Bitcoin has dropped below $6,000, with a 2.2% decline to $6,044, bringing its 2018 loss to nearly 60%. This marks the lowest price since February, when it briefly traded at $5,988.

site_title: German firms struggle to keep staff who want 'work-life-life-life' balance
summary: German companies are struggling to attract and retain staff, with many offering generous perks such as long holidays, flexible shifts, and sabbaticals to compete. Despite Germans working the fewest hours in the developed world, Deutsche Bahn and other firms are falling over themselves to offer attractive benefits. Women, who make up just 23% of Bahn employees, are particularly drawn to more holidays, while firms struggle to fill skilled trades and engineering roles. The shortage of workers of working age, combined with a strong economy, has made attracting employees a major challenge.

site_title: Chasen clinches S$38.4m worth of contracts
summary: CHASEN Holdings Limited has secured S$38.4 million worth of new contracts in Asia and the US, including specialist relocation services, third-party logistics, and technical and engineering services.

site_title: STI resumes fall with region awash in red
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 26 points, or 0.8%, on Wednesday, amid concerns over a looming US-China trade war. The sell-off was fueled by US President Donald Trump's statement that restrictions on foreign investment in US technology companies would not be confined to China. Experts at KGI Securities recommended taking a defensive stance, citing fundamentally healthy companies that have been sold down with the broader market decline. The STI is now at 3,254.77, with key technical support at 3,200-3,250.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Thrifty Germans look to escape the rat race early
summary: Former German meteorologist Lars Hattwig, 47, retired in his 40s after quitting his job due to financial independence. He attributes his success to living a simple life with a focus on health, a common trait among adherents to the frugalist movement. This trend is gaining popularity in ageing Germany, where individuals seek to escape the "rat race" early.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower on Trump trade uncertainty
summary: US stocks ended lower on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 0.7% to 24,117.59, the S&P 500 shedding 0.9% to 2,699.63, and the Nasdaq Composite Index slumping 1.5% to 7,445.08. The decline was sparked by mixed signals from the Trump administration on China trade, with President Trump backing off aggressive restrictions and White House economic advisor Larry Kudlow suggesting tougher action could still be taken. Investors remain uncertain about the outcome of trade talks, leading to a volatile market.

site_title: Oxley reaps revenue of S$249m from The Verandah Residences
summary: Oxley Holdings Limited sold all 170 units of The Verandah Residences within three months of its launch, generating a total revenue of S$248.8 million. The project, located in Singapore, was launched on April 7 and features 167 apartments and three strata houses. The company attributes the success to strong demand for quality projects with superb locations and buyers' trust in the Oxley brand. The sales progress is expected to continue, with the company aiming to replicate the success of The Verandah Residences in upcoming launches.

site_title: Snooze and you lose
summary: The 2018 World Cup has seen a significant increase in last-gasp goals, with 17 goals scored in the 90th minute or later, a sixth of the tournament's total of 105 goals. These late goals have significantly altered the outcomes of matches, with some teams securing crucial wins in the final minutes of play. Examples include Toni Kroos's 3.50am winner for Germany against Sweden and Harry Kane's 91st-minute goal for England against Tunisia. The trend is expected to continue, particularly in the knockout rounds.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Govt keeps H2 GLS housing supply on par with H1
summary: The Singapore government has maintained a balanced approach to residential land supply in the second half of 2018, keeping it in line with the first half of the year. Six sites under the Confirmed List and nine sites under the Reserve List can yield 2,705 private residential units, 42,200 square meters of commercial space, and 390 hotel rooms. Consultants say the government aims to control property prices by introducing new units without causing a supply glut. Despite a strong demand for land, the government believes the current supply will meet homebuyers' demand over the next one to two years.

site_title: Danone to milk vegan trend as it looks beyond bovines to boost bottomline
summary: Danone, the world's largest yogurt maker, is shifting its focus from dairy products to plant-based alternatives to boost sales. The company plans to add milk-free ranges to its flagship brands, such as Activia and Actimel, capitalizing on the growing demand for veganism. With sales of dairy products stagnating, Danone aims to expand its offerings in the non-dairy segment, which is expected to increase by 5% annually to $7.4 billion by 2027.

site_title: Euro slips on trade war fears
summary: The euro fell 0.1% to US$1.1633 due to concerns over a potential trade war between the US and China, with the yen rising 0.2% against the dollar. The euro was also under pressure from uncertainty over a European Union summit and a row within Germany's governing coalition. The offshore yuan hit a six-month low after the People's Bank of China lowered its midpoint, and US stocks slipped amid trade tensions. Analysts expect trade tensions to continue weighing on global growth.

site_title: No Signboard to launch fast-food chain
summary: No Signboard Holdings is launching a fast-food chain called "Hawker" with hawker food-themed burgers, wraps, and buns in Singapore. The first outlet is expected to open by end-2018, with plans for at least three outlets by early 2019. The venture will be funded with S$0.5 million per outlet, with 20% coming from the company's IPO proceeds and 80% from bank loans. The new brand aims to serve a different demographic and expand the company's dining-in and takeaway sales.

site_title: 3M opens new headquarters in Singapore
summary: 3M officially opened its new Singapore headquarters in Ang Mo Kio, featuring a 10,000 sq m Customer Technical Centre showcasing technologies such as virtual reality and sign sheeting. The facility houses over 500 employees and is part of the company's S$1 billion investment in Singapore since 1966. 3M aims to grow its Singapore staff numbers by 5-10% over the next six to 12 months, focusing on collaborations with local partners and developing Asia-centric solutions to address customers' sustainability challenges.

site_title: Will Trump get a China trade war or a grand bargain?
summary: US President Donald Trump is poised to impose tariffs on $34 billion of Chinese goods, further escalating tensions in the US-China trade war. Beijing has vowed to oppose US trade protectionism, and Europe is set to impose tariffs on US products in response. Trump believes a personal relationship with Chinese President Xi Jinping can resolve issues, but it's unclear how much China will be willing to compromise. A grand bargain on economic and security issues could provide stability in the world economy, but Trump's "America First" agenda and Xi's desire for a new great power relationship make a deal uncertain.

site_title: NYC moves to collect data on hosts to curb illegal Airbnbs
summary: The New York City Council has proposed a bill that would require online rental services like Airbnb to disclose the addresses of its listings and the identities of its hosts to the city's Office of Special Enforcement on a monthly basis. The bill, which is expected to pass with a veto-proof majority, aims to curb illegal online home-sharing listings that have turned residential apartments into year-round hotels for tourists. If passed, companies that fail to share the data would be fined up to $25,000 for each listing that they did not disclose.

site_title: Land Rover promises a made-in-China electric car
summary: Jaguar Land Rover plans to build an electric vehicle in China, aiming to tap into the growing demand for electric cars in the country. The carmaker will utilize its current capabilities in China to produce an electric vehicle similar to the I-Pace, with details to be disclosed within a year. As China promotes zero-emission cars to fight pollution and cut oil imports, Jaguar Land Rover faces competition from rivals such as Tesla and Audi, with the goal of capturing a significant market share. The company expects to produce one new vehicle in China annually for the next three to five years.

site_title: Facebook retools political ad rules after media blowback
summary: Facebook has retooled its political ad rules to distinguish between journalistic content and sponsored content. The company will divide its political ad archive into two sections: one for news stories and one for advertisements promoting candidates and issues. Verified media advertisers and those from major national publications will be placed in a separate "Promoted News" section. The move comes after criticism from publishers and media groups, and is part of Facebook's efforts to combat manipulation of its platform following the 2016 US presidential election.

site_title: Bringing farming back to nature
summary: Agroecology, a farming approach that regenerates soil fertility and biodiversity, is gaining global attention and support. The UN's Food and Agriculture Organization and over 70 countries have endorsed the approach, which uses natural assets to grow food. Key countries such as India, Tanzania, and France are investing in agroecological practices, and the US is developing a system to support locally grown, sustainably produced food. Research has shown that agroecology can outperform conventional farming methods in terms of soil regeneration and carbon sequestration. As the world's population grows, agroecology is seen as a crucial solution to ensure food security and sustainability.

site_title: NZ plans to draw in more overseas workers to build homes
summary: New Zealand's government plans to propose new steps to draw in more overseas workers to build houses, addressing labour shortages blamed for a chronic housing crunch. The proposals include fast-tracking visa procedures for plumbers, electricians, and other skilled workers, and pre-approving companies with good employment practices. The government aims to speed up the process and alleviate the shortage of about 30,000 skilled workers in the construction industry.

site_title: 53 firms, agencies recognised for summit contribution
summary: The Singapore Summit Appreciation Dinner, held to commemorate the June 12 summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, recognized 53 firms and agencies for their contributions to the event. Paris Baguette, a South Korean bakery chain with roots in the North, sponsored 5,000 sets of sandwiches to journalists. Other companies, including food firms and airport ground handlers, provided services such as meals, wireless internet, and massage chairs. The summit's success was attributed to the team effort between private and public sectors, with Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran praising the companies for their cooperation.

site_title: German banks invest in digitisation to boost revenue
summary: German banks are investing billions of euros in digitization to boost revenue, with 50 top lenders planning to spend up to €6 billion by 2020. However, some critics argue that these investments are one-dimensional and poorly thought through, with many relying on fintechs without a comprehensive digital strategy. The lack of innovation governance, high risk aversion, and insufficient know-how are identified as major obstacles to successful digitization. Despite this, some banks are seeing positive results, such as the successful launch of a robo-adviser by Hamburg-based private bank MM Warburg & CO.

site_title: Ageing Hong Kong waterfront gets a timely face-lift
summary: Hong Kong's ageing waterfront is undergoing a $2.6 billion transformation into a modern art and design district, Victoria Dockside, with retail, residential, and commercial interests. The project, led by New World Development, will feature a shopping complex, redesigned promenade, and a skyscraper with Class A offices and a hotel. Enlisting over 100 artists and consultants worldwide, the project aims to bring art to the masses and encourage residents to slow down and interact with nature. The flagship shopping mall, K11 Musea, will offer art exhibitions, live music, and cultural events, with a focus on creating an immersive experience that the digital world cannot replicate.

site_title: Addictive in-car technology lures distracted drivers down rocky road
summary: The AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety has found that carmakers are not effective in minimizing driving distractions, which kill 3,500 people and injure 390,000 annually in the US. A study by David Strayer found that aftermarket devices like Apple's CarPlay and Google's Android Auto are safer than in-car infotainment systems, shaving seconds from distracted driving. Drivers are more likely to stay focused on the road with shorter, easier interactions. Despite concerns, many drivers admit to making calls and sending texts while driving, citing reasons such as convenience and staying in touch with family.

site_title: Conagra to buy Pinnacle for US$8.1b
summary: Conagra Brands Inc agreed to buy Pinnacle Foods Inc for about US$8.1 billion in cash and stock, gaining freezer-aisle brands such as Birds Eye to capitalize on growing demand for frozen foods. The deal values Pinnacle at US$68 a share, 23% above its closing price on April 19, when an activist investor disclosed a stake in the company. Including assumed debt, the deal values Pinnacle at about US$10.9 billion.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The New Silkroutes Group has entered into memoranda of understanding to acquire 60% stakes in six medical practices for S$11.7 million. M1 has acquired AsiaPac Distribution for up to S$20 million, while Asiatravel.com Holdings is facing a lawsuit over hotel room bookings. Mapletree Industrial Trust has acquired 7 Tai Seng Drive for S$95 million, and Yanlord Land Group is acquiring Yanlord Property for S$215.9 million. These deals are part of the companies' expansion plans and are expected to have minimal impact on their financials.

site_title: Britain committed to free and open trade, Hammond tells China
summary: UK Finance Minister Philip Hammond has expressed Britain's commitment to free and open trade during a visit to China. Hammond wrote in a Chinese financial magazine that Britain sees the Belt and Road initiative as "unlimited opportunities" and hopes to deepen economic and financial trade relations with China. Hammond also highlighted the UK's support for globalised Britain, a firm supporter of trade liberalisation and a free market, and expressed his desire to set ambitious economic and financial trade goals with China.

site_title: Drop in yuan triggers warnings of potential contagion
summary: A sharp decline in the Chinese yuan has triggered warnings of potential contagion in the global markets, with some analysts predicting a significant, sustained depreciation of the currency. The yuan fell 0.5% against the US dollar for the third straight day, its largest drop in a short stretch since 2015. Investors are concerned that China might adopt a policy of devaluation to counter US trade tensions, which could have spillover effects on other yuan assets, such as stocks. Experts predict that the yuan may stabilize, but warn that a sustained weakening could have significant implications for the global economy.

site_title: EpiCentre plans to move into regional property on RTO plan
summary: EpiCentre Holdings, a loss-making Apple reseller, plans to exit its core business and divest its recently acquired beauty unit through a reverse takeover of regional property developer Asia ThaiYuan. The deal, valued at S$400 million, will be funded by issuing new shares and a share placement, targeting strategic investors to support the new businesses. This move follows EpiCentre's announcement to sell its Apple reselling operations in Singapore, which will incur a deficit of S$950,000.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: ECB delays monthly QE data until Tuesday
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has delayed publishing its monthly asset purchase data by one day to accommodate end-of-quarter accounting procedures. The data will now be released on Tuesday, July 3, instead of its usual weekly release.

site_title: Core capital goods orders drop 0.2% in May
summary: US capital goods orders dropped 0.2% in May, contrary to forecasts, but data for April was revised higher, suggesting moderate growth in business spending. The decline in core capital goods shipments could impact second-quarter GDP growth. However, the goods trade deficit narrowed and retail and wholesale inventories increased, indicating accelerating economic growth. Escalating US trade tensions with major partners, including China, may undercut growth, despite the Trump administration's tax cut package supporting business spending on equipment.

site_title: UK's John Lewis warns on profit and "no deal Brexit" chaos
summary: John Lewis Partnership, a UK department store, warned of a significant fall in annual profit due to a no-deal Brexit and economic uncertainty. The 154-year-old group expects 2018-19 profit to be substantially lower than the previous year's £289 million, citing subdued consumer spending, rising labor costs, and growing online competition. The company plans to shed stores and focus on differentiation and innovation in products and customer services. Partnership chairman Charlie Mayfield described a no-deal Brexit as "chaotic" and warned of significant consequences for the UK economy.

site_title: Vallianz tables equity swop for S$3.1m trade debt
summary: Vallianz Holdings, a Catalist-listed offshore support vessel owner-operator, has agreed to swap almost S$3.15 million in trade debt for shares in the company. The shares, priced at 1.6 Singapore cents apiece, represent about 1.19% of the company's issued share capital. The proposed settlement will set off almost all of the trade payables, with a small balance remaining. The shares will be listed and quoted on the Singapore Exchange, pending approval.

site_title: Crude surges to 3 1/2-year high after US stockpiles plunge
summary: US crude oil stockpiles plummeted by 9.89 million barrels last week, the largest decline since September 2016, leading to a surge in oil prices to a 3 1/2-year high. Domestic crude inventories shrank for a sixth straight week, while refiners boosted oil processing rates and exports soared to a record. Oil futures rose 3.4% in New York, with West Texas Intermediate crude reaching $72.93 a barrel, the highest intraday price since November 2014. The US is now shipping out more oil than Iran, despite efforts to isolate the Islamic Republic.

site_title: Raising the governance bar: Disclosure mindset must change
summary: Singapore's corporate governance regime has been strengthened over the past two decades, but compliance remains a concern. Industry observers view it as a "box-ticking" exercise, with companies prioritizing regulatory compliance over transparency and honesty. Many release vague and meaningless information, failing to disclose executive remuneration as recommended by the Code of Corporate Governance. This undermines the regime's effectiveness in facilitating informed investment decisions, leaving room for improvement in transparency and good governance practices.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after new US plan for China investments
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday after the Trump administration announced a strengthened security review process for Chinese investments in domestic technologies, rather than imposing China-specific restrictions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 20 points, the S&P 500 gained 5.39 points, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 24.70 points. The move was seen as a positive step for investors, who had been concerned about the impact of US-China trade tensions on the market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 9.78 points to 1,666.08. Volume reached 2 billion lots worth RM2 billion, with 558 losers outnumbering 278 gainers.

site_title: The costs of going cashless
summary: Singapore aims to be a cashless society by 2025, with the government and companies set to use PayNow, a mobile payment service. However, some concerns have been raised about the transition, including the complexity of linking multiple bank accounts to a single app and the potential impact on vulnerable populations such as the elderly and lower-income citizens. The move is expected to save the country around S$2 billion a year, but may also lead to job losses and social costs. Experts warn that the transition should be handled carefully to avoid financial exclusion and potential crises.

site_title: Trendlines seeks investors' patience amid weak share price
summary: Trendlines, a Singapore-based startup incubator, is urging investors to be patient as its share price struggles at 12 cents, down from 33 cents at its 2015 flotation. Despite weak trading, Trendlines has no interest in delisting from Singapore and has expressed confidence that the market will eventually catch on to its business model, which focuses on exits through trade sales and public listings. The company attributes its modest exits to its business model, where some startups may not succeed, and notes that a large exit as a public company will attract more attention to the stock.

site_title: Ryobi Kiso suspends trading after unit defaults on loan repayments
summary: Ryobi Kiso Holdings' subsidiary Ryobi Kiso (S) has defaulted on loan repayments, breaching banking facilities and triggering potential cross-default provisions. The company has requested a voluntary suspension of its mainboard-listed shares and appointed PricewaterhouseCoopers as a financial adviser to assist in restructuring. Ryobi Kiso's financial struggles are attributed to intense competition, shrinking margins, and a tight labor market in the construction sector. The company warned that its financial performance is unlikely to improve in the next reporting period.

site_title: Singapore's hospitality game-changers, in the Weekend magazine
summary: Singapore hoteliers are featured in Weekend magazine, highlighting their unique boutique accommodations in Bali, Perth, and Indonesia. Four entrepreneurs share their passion for heritage architecture, marine wildlife, and relaxed island lifestyles. Meanwhile, fintech expert Kayoko Francis discusses the future of the financial services industry, and Mehmet Oz shares health tips for dieters. Restaurants catering to various diets are also highlighted, along with articles on corporate purpose, financial literacy, and sustainable living.

site_title: Learning from the Cambridge Analytica fiasco
summary: Cambridge Analytica's data scandal exposed the vulnerability of social media companies to unethical data mining and brokerage. The scandal, which affected 80 million Facebook users, led to a significant loss of Facebook's share price value. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg acknowledged that it would take several years to "fix" the platform. The incident highlights the need for data giants to reach a new equilibrium on how they function, and the importance of moderating their growth strategies to avoid significant costs. The company's response will be crucial in determining its future.

site_title: Singapore stocks end lower, with rest of Asia in the red
summary: Singapore shares ended in negative territory, falling 26.1 points or 0.8% to 3,254.77, as the rest of Asia followed suit amid escalating trade tensions between China and the US. Banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC led the decline, while Singtel and ComfortDelgro bucked the trend.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Manulife plans to free up C$5b in capital by 2022
summary: Manulife, Canada's largest insurer, aims to free up C$5 billion in capital by 2022 through business sales and cost cuts. The company plans to cut expenses by C$1 billion and automate functions to streamline operations. This move is part of new CEO Roy Gori's strategy to run the business more efficiently, leveraging technology to automate tasks. As part of the cost-cutting measures, Manulife plans to cut 700 jobs in Canada and merge its Canadian headquarters.

site_title: Opec supply buffer shrinks as it heeds call to pump more oil
summary: OPEC's oil supply buffer is shrinking as the organization increases production, but the move has raised concerns about the market's vulnerability to disruptions. The buffer, which can supply around 3.4 million barrels a day, will dwindle to 2.6% of global supply as OPEC implements a 1 million-barrel-a-day supply boost. This reduction leaves the market more exposed to pricing risks, with analysts warning of potential supply disruptions from Venezuela, Libya, and Iran, which could further reduce the buffer and drive up prices.

site_title: ECB sees domestic demand offsetting stronger euro, for now
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) notes that robust domestic demand has offset a stronger euro, preventing it from weighing on euro-area inflation. Despite the euro's 10% appreciation against the US dollar, prices of imported consumer goods declined 2% in April, and domestic producers have maintained pricing power due to rising labor compensation and capacity utilization. The ECB warns that effects from the exchange rate may still weigh on inflation in the near future, but the impact is spread out over several quarters. This development is a positive sign for the central bank's efforts to stimulate low inflation.

site_title: Yanlord Land buying all shares in Yanlord Property
summary: Yanlord Land Group has acquired all remaining shares in Yanlord Property for 1.045 trillion yuan, paying 466.9 million yuan for the 40% shareholding interest and 579 million yuan for a shareholder loan. The acquisition is expected to have no material impact on the group's financial year earnings. Yanlord Land Group's shares closed at S$1.56, three cents lower, following the announcement.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust completes purchase of 7 Tai Seng Drive
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) has completed the purchase of 7 Tai Seng Drive in Singapore for S$68 million. The property will undergo upgrading works and be leased to an established IT company for 25 years with annual rental escalations. The total cost, including upgrading works, is expected to be S$95 million. This acquisition expands MIT's portfolio to 86 industrial properties in Singapore and 14 data centers in the US.

site_title: The Verandah Residences yields revenue of S$249m for Oxley
summary: Oxley Holdings Limited's The Verandah Residences sold all 170 units within three months of its launch, yielding S$248.8 million in revenue. The project, launched on April 7, features 167 apartments and three strata houses, purchased at S$964 psf and sold at S$1,795 psf. CEO Ching Chiat Kwong attributed the success to strong demand for quality projects and buyer trust in the Oxley brand, promising to deliver the project in good quality and on time.

site_title: China spends big to win friends and influence across East Asia
summary: China invested over $48 billion in East Asia and the Pacific from 2000 to 2016, primarily through infrastructure development, to win friends and influence. This surpassed other forms of public diplomacy, including humanitarian aid and debt relief. The spending aimed to support countries that consume Chinese products and align with its foreign policy positions. The report, released by US research lab AidData, highlights China's significant efforts to expand its influence in the region.

site_title: Countries boycotting Qatar want flying-rights case moved to ICJ
summary: A Saudi-led bloc is seeking to move a case on reopening Qatar's airspace to the International Court of Justice (ICJ) from the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO). The four Arab nations, which cut diplomatic and transport links with Qatar, claim the ICAO was not competent to consider the dispute. Qatar filed the case, seeking to force the boycotting countries to reopen their airspace, citing a dispute resolution mechanism in the Chicago Convention. The ICJ decision could impact Qatar Airways, which has warned the boycott will result in significant losses.

site_title: European chip industry seeks more EU help to extend revival
summary: European chip industry leaders are seeking more EU assistance to sustain a tentative revival, citing concerns over trade wars and Beijing's "Made in China 2025" plan. They request a 10 billion-euro research and development program, doubling the current 5 billion-euro budget, to support innovation and self-reliance in semiconductors. The industry also advocates for extending state support for strategic investment projects beyond 2020 and boosting Europe's skills and research efforts in emerging technologies like artificial intelligence.

site_title: Temasek takes minority stake in UST Global
summary: Temasek, a Singapore-based investment company, has invested $250 million in UST Global, a digital transformation solutions provider. UST Global, with 35 offices worldwide, offers services such as digital customer engagement and cybersecurity solutions to multinational corporations. The investment will help UST Global expand its reach and design digital impact strategies for its clients. This partnership aims to capitalize on the convergence of the physical and digital worlds, allowing UST Global to stay competitive in the rapidly evolving technology landscape.

site_title: Ex-NTUC Income financial associate jailed 4 years for pocketing nearly S$500,000 in premiums
summary: A former financial associate at NTUC Income Insurance Cooperative, John Koh Zhan Loong, was jailed for 4 years for misappropriating nearly S$500,000 from 11 clients between 2012 and 2013. Koh, 39, used the funds for gambling and his wife's insurance policy. The crime came to light after a compliance manager alerted the police, and Koh made no restitution. The court accepted Koh's remorse and lenient plea, reducing the potential 15-year sentence.

site_title: Bank of England under fire for "unconscionable" expenses
summary: The Bank of England is facing criticism for its "unconscionable" expenses, including £11,000 in flight costs and £400 in taxi bills, which have raised concerns about public trust. Conservative lawmaker Simon Clarke cited these figures, along with £390,000 in travel expenses by external Financial Policy Committee members, as evidence that the bank needs to review its spending. The Bank of England defended its policies, stating that business-class flights and other expenses are reimbursed, and the head of the Court of Directors vowed to investigate.

images.alt_text: Flight costs amounting to £11,000 (S$19,876.9) and more than £400 in taxi bills have been cited as evidence that the Bank of England (BOE) needs to review its spending and not undermine public trust.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets edge higher at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets edged higher at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index increasing 0.2% to 7,552.13 points. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also rose 0.1% each. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares. US stocks also reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging higher.

site_title: World's LNG giant is pumping US$20b into US oil, gas
summary: Qatar Petroleum, the world's largest LNG seller, is investing $20 billion in US oil and gas fields over five years, aiming to increase its production from 4.8 million barrels of oil equivalent per day to 6.5 million. The investments will be made alongside US companies, including ExxonMobil, and are seen as a bid to secure gas supplies for the Golden Pass LNG export project in Texas. The move is part of Qatar's efforts to diversify its energy portfolio and strengthen its ties with the US, amid a blockade by Saudi Arabia and others.

site_title: Australian shares steady; NZ stocks tread water
summary: Australian shares ended little changed, with the S&P/ASX 200 index falling 1.70 points to 6,195.90. Gains from energy and materials stocks, led by BHP and Rio Tinto, were countered by declines in banks and industrials. Oil prices pushed Qantas Airways down 2%, while energy stocks rose. In New Zealand, the S&P/NZX 50 index edged up 0.1% as telecommunication services gained. Business confidence in New Zealand sank to a seven-month low in June.

site_title: Russia's unpredictable past is complicating economy's future
summary: Russia's economy is experiencing an unpredictable future due to its complex past. A recent revision of factory output data by the statistics service has revealed that industrial production increased by more than double last year's gain, suggesting a new reality for the country's growth story. However, this shift has added uncertainty for investors and analysts, as the economy is already affected by US sanctions, tax system changes, and declining oil prices. The revised data indicates a better momentum going into this year, but its implications remain unclear.

site_title: Facebook, Google 'manipulate' users to share data despite EU law: study
summary: A Norwegian Consumer Council study found that Facebook and Google are pushing users to share private information despite EU data protection laws. The tech giants' default options are deemed "invasive" and do not align with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which requires companies to clarify users' choices. The study's director, Finn Myrstad, stated that these companies "manipulate" users into sharing information about themselves, violating the GDPR. This raises concerns about user control and data protection.

site_title: M1 to buy ICT solutions provider AsiaPac Distribution
summary: M1, a telco, announced it will buy 100% of AsiaPac Distribution Pte Ltd for up to S$20 million. The purchase will "fast track" M1's entry into the ICT segment and enhance its corporate ICT solutions. The deal was made via M1 Net Ltd, a wholly owned subsidiary. The acquisition is expected to bolster M1's proposition as an integrated ICT solutions provider.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Cromwell European Reit completes acquisition of Italy property
summary: Cromwell European Reit completed its acquisition of a property in Italy for 16.9 million euros (S$27.3 million). The Italian state did not exercise its pre-emption right to acquire the property. This acquisition brings the total number of properties in Cromwell's portfolio to 75. Units of the Reit rose 0.5 euros to close at 0.58 euros on the day of the announcement.

site_title: Stop order issued for Goodluck Garden collective sale
summary: A stop order has been issued for the collective sale of Goodluck Garden, a 210-unit residential development in Singapore, after a group of seven minority owners objected to the sale. The sale was initially agreed upon for S$610 million, with owners set to receive S$924,000 to S$3.51 million each. The collective sale committee has 14 days to apply to the High Court for approval, with a potential hearing in August or September. This is the first stop order of the year, following two rounds of mediation.

site_title: EpiCentre Holdings announces planned reverse takeover
summary: EpiCentre Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, has announced a planned S$400 million reverse takeover under a memorandum of understanding. The acquisition involves the entire issued and paid-up share capital of MacroCap Asia Capital, which owns Thai property developer Asia ThaiYuan and Chinese hotel manager Gloria International. In exchange, EpiCentre will issue 1.74 billion new shares. The deal will dispose of its Apple reselling business and Japan IPL Holdings beauty business, with the new shares being used to repay liabilities and fund general working capital. The proposal requires approval from the Singapore Exchange and EpiCentre shareholders.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.65 points to 1,675.06. Volume reached 38.88 million lots worth RM13.7 million. Despite this, the overall market trend remains positive, with 85 gainers outnumbering 43 losers.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,286.52, up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading at 3,286.52, up 0.2% on Wednesday, with 696.3 million shares worth S$470.2 million changing hands. Losers edged out gainers 146 to 133, as Ezion and Keppel Corp led the gains. Active index stocks, including OCBC Bank, also saw increases. The rally follows a 5-day streak, ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore government launched six land parcels for sale in the second-half of 2018, including a hotel site. A collective sale of Goodluck Garden was halted due to a stop order from the Strata Titles Board. No Signboard Holdings announced a hawker-themed fast food chain, while EpiCentre Holdings is set for a S$400 million reverse takeover. CapitaLand acquired a 32-hectare site in Chongqing for S$459 million. Ryobi Kiso's subsidiary defaulted on loan repayments and Chasen Holdings secured S$38.4 million worth of new contracts.

site_title: Najib, Rosmah and 'gift givers' to be quizzed soon in 1MDB probe, no arrests so far: Police
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak and his wife Rosmah Mansor will be questioned by police in connection with the 1MDB probe. Over 30 statements have been recorded, but no arrests have been made. The couple's alleged "gift givers" will also be called in for questioning. A total of RM900 million to RM1.1 billion in cash and items, including 12,000 pieces of jewelry, were seized from residences linked to Najib. Police are still investigating and gathering evidence, with no timeline set for potential arrests.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended sharply lower on Wednesday, extending a recent sell-off due to concerns about a possible China-US trade war. The Hang Seng Index fell 1.82% to 28,356.26, while the Shanghai Composite Index retreated 1.1% to 2,813.18. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 1.29% to 1,575.57. This decline follows a similar trend in other markets, including Singapore and the US, where investors are cautious amid trade tensions.

site_title: London house prices fall as UK property continues to cool
summary: UK house prices have slowed to the weakest pace in five years, with London values falling 1.9% in the second quarter. Nationwide Building Society reports a 2% year-over-year rise in UK prices, down from 2.4% in May. The lender expects UK property-price inflation to continue weakening, with prices rising just 1% this year. Squeezed household budgets and subdued economic activity are driving the decline, with the Bank of England hinting at potential interest rate hikes later this year.

site_title: Facebook no longer building an Internet-beaming aircraft
summary: Facebook is discontinuing its efforts to build an Internet-beaming aircraft, known as Aquila, which was designed to provide connectivity to regions with limited access. The company will no longer design or build its own aircraft and will instead partner with companies like Airbus SE on high-altitude connectivity technologies. Facebook's UK drone facility will also be closed, marking the end of its foray into aerospace engineering, which began in 2014.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Wednesday; STI up 0.08% to 3,283.48
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.08% higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index rising to 3,283.48. Gainers edged out losers 46 to 39, with Ezion being the most actively traded counter, rising 2.15%. The market followed a positive trend in US stocks, despite lingering trade tensions, and ahead of GDP data.

site_title: US dollar comes off 2-week lows, slight easing in risk aversion checks yen
summary: The US dollar rebounded from two-week lows against its rivals, gaining 0.4% against a basket of six major currencies, as the yen sagged amid easing risk aversion. The dollar index was steady at 94.663, snapping a four-session losing run. The yen fell to 110.11 yen, as concerns over the escalating US-China trade row eased. Despite the dollar's recovery, it was expected to remain listless due to uncertainty over US policy, and was influenced by the flagging euro and pound.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index edges down
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index fell 0.31% to 22,271.77, due to investor concerns over US protectionist policies and rising oil prices. The broader Topix index rose 0.02%. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data, and amid new US trade threats. Despite this, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US edged to fresh records.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.33% on Wednesday, driven by a surge in oil prices, but trade war fears limited gains. The Hang Seng Index reached 28,976.66, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.07%. The rally followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a boost in US stocks despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: CapitaLand acquires 32-ha prime mixed-use site in Chongqing for 2.2b yuan
summary: CapitaLand acquired a 32-hectare prime mixed-use site in Chongqing for 2.2 billion yuan, boosting its residential pipeline in China by over 2,100 units. The site, located in Xinpaifang, a mature residential and commercial zone, will yield 1,900 residential units and a shopping mall with a combined GFA of 335,000 sq m. The acquisition is expected to contribute to the group's land bank in key gateway cities in southwestern China, with a high-income population of about 600,000 people within a three-kilometre radius.

site_title: Airbnb, Uber woes show Japan does not share easily
summary: Japan's sharing economy giants, including Airbnb and Uber, face significant challenges due to strict regulations and public skepticism. Despite being the world's third-largest economy, Japan has been slow to adopt the sharing economy, with a 2016 figure of 50 billion yen (S$620 million) attributed to it.
