This has led to thousands of Airbnb reservations being scrapped and Uber reducing its services to food delivery, highlighting the difficulties faced by these companies in Japan.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on lingering trade war worries
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on June 27, 2018, due to lingering trade war worries. The Nikkei 225 index lost 0.14% to 22,311.19, while the Topix index fell 0.08% to 1,729.61. Despite a cheaper yen and gains on Wall Street, investors remained cautious amid ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Deloitte & Touche appointed China Sports' joint judicial managers
summary: Deloitte & Touche LLP has been appointed as the joint judicial managers of China Sports International, a sportswear maker, by the High Court of Singapore. The appointment comes after a hearing on June 26, where the court confirmed the move to keep the company afloat. The judicial managers will oversee arrangements or compromises between China Sports and any parties, and seek a more advantageous realisation of the company's assets instead of a winding up.

site_title: Worries over German government crisis pin down bond yields
summary: Germany's government bond yields fell to recent one-month lows due to a row over migration policy in the coalition government, raising concerns of snap elections. Four hours of talks between Chancellor Angela Merkel and her Bavarian allies failed to resolve the issue ahead of an EU summit. The uncertainty benefited German bonds, with yields edging closer to lows. Bond yields across the eurozone were also lower, following a recovery in prices after investors digested bond supply from France and Spain.

site_title: Asiatravel.com unit faces lawsuit from supplier of Peninsula.Excelsior Hotel rooms
summary: Asiatravel.com Holdings' online travel reservations unit, AT Reservation Network, is facing a lawsuit from supplier YTC Hotels over S$430,208.40 in unpaid hotel room charges for stays at Peninsula.Excelsior Hotel from January 14, 2018 to May 30, 2018. AT Reservation Network is seeking legal advice.

site_title: New Silkroutes to buy stakes in 6 clinics for S$11.7m
summary: New Silkroutes Group has entered into memoranda of understanding to acquire 60% stakes in six medical practices for S$11.7 million. The target companies are registered with the Singapore Ministry of Health and the doctors are registered with the Singapore Medical Council. The acquisitions are in line with the company's strategy to expand its healthcare business, which is expected to reinforce earnings, strengthen operations, and enhance shareholder interests. The sale and purchase agreements are expected to be finalized within one week after due diligence is completed.

site_title: Singapore's bubble tea space gets more crowded with entry of Taiwan brand TP Tea
summary: Taiwanese bubble tea brand TP Tea has entered the Singapore market with its first outlet at Changi Airport Terminal 2. The brand, established in 2005 with over 300 stores in the region, will offer its bestsellers Tie Guan Yin Tea Latte and Pearl Black Tea Latte. TP Tea's unique roasting process in Taiwan and strict preparation time ensure high-quality products, aiming to win over Singaporean consumers. This addition joins existing bubble tea chains, including Gong Cha and ShareTea, and Manna is confident TP Tea will establish itself in the competitive market.

site_title: Chinese firms cash in on Xinjiang's growing police state
summary: China's construction of a vast police state in the Xinjiang region has led to a massive government spending spree worth billions to firms providing surveillance equipment and "re-education centers." The region's security spending has ballooned nearly 100% last year, totaling over 58 billion yuan, and is financed largely through debt. Chinese companies like Hikvision, the world's largest supplier of surveillance equipment, are benefiting from the increased spending, with contracts totaling over 1.85 billion yuan in 2017. The region's government claims the spending is necessary to combat terrorism, but human rights activists describe it as a human rights disaster.

site_title: Y Ventures scores exclusive online distribution for Disney merchandise in South-east Asia
summary: Y Ventures Group has secured an exclusive online distribution deal with Beast Kingdom Co Ltd for Disney merchandise in South-east Asia for three years. The partnership aims to be the largest online retailer of official Disney products in the region, offering a wide range of merchandise including Disney, Marvel, Star Wars, and Pixar items. Products will be available on Beast Kingdom's online platforms and online marketplaces in the region.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: China's robust industrial profits keep trade war risks at bay for now
summary: China's industrial profits surged 21.1% in May to 607.1 billion yuan, driven by price gains and lower costs. For the first five months, industrial firms posted a 16.5% increase in profits, surpassing the 15% growth in the January-April period. Despite slowing momentum in the economy and a trade spat with the US, the earnings jump is attributed to a hot property and infrastructure construction market. However, activity in other sectors, such as infrastructure investment and industrial output, suggests softening growth in the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won fall on escalating US-China trade tensions
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index and the won fell on Wednesday due to escalating US-China trade tensions. The won dropped 0.25% to 1,117.6 per dollar, while the KOSPI index fell 0.38% to 2,342.03. Market heavyweight Samsung Electronics rose 2%, but shares of Korean Air Lines and Jin Air plummeted as much as 5.9%. The US dollar has risen 4.79% against the won this year, and the KOSPI index is down 4.60% in the past 30 days.

site_title: Birkin bags, jewellery, cash seized from ex-Malaysian PM Najib Razak's residences worth up to RM1.1b: Police
summary: Malaysian police seized cash, jewellery, and other assets from former Prime Minister Najib Razak's residences, valued between RM900 million and RM1.1 billion. The items, including 35 bags of cash worth RM116.7 million, were seized after a three-day calculation process assisted by Bank Negara officers. The seizure is part of Najib's ongoing corruption case.

site_title: Pentagon chief Mattis reduced to carrying out orders he dislikes
summary: US Defence Secretary Jim Mattis is facing increasing pressure to carry out presidential orders despite his disapproval, following the appointment of Mike Pompeo as secretary of state and John Bolton as national security adviser. Mattis has been demoted in Washington's power circles and has been caught off guard by snap decisions on subjects where he would normally be consulted, including the deployment of National Guard troops on the US-Mexico border and the cancellation of joint US-South Korea military exercises. Mattis may quit if he feels ineffective and has no voice, according to former intelligence chief James Clapper.

site_title: Facebook retools political ad rules after media blowback
summary: Facebook has retooled its political ad rules in response to media criticism, dividing its ad archive into two sections: one for news articles about politics and one for ads promoting candidates and issues. This change comes after weeks of criticism from publishers who argued that Facebook's previous approach would confuse readers about fact and opinion. The move aims to combat manipulation of the platform, following revelations of Russian operatives spreading misinformation on Facebook during the 2016 US presidential election. The new approach is set to be implemented in the "coming days."

site_title: Thrifty Germans look to escape the rat race early
summary: A growing number of Germans, inspired by the "Financial Independence Retire Early" (FIRE) movement, are retiring in their 40s and living on savings, defying the country's traditional retirement age of 67. Thrifty individuals like Lars Hattwig, who quit his job at 43, and Oliver Noelting, a 29-year-old computer programmer, are chronicling their journeys online. The movement emphasizes living below one's means, investing wisely, and pursuing personal goals, rather than conforming to societal expectations. Critics argue that this approach could lead to a burden on the public social security system, while proponents see it as a viable solution to the demographic challenge facing Germany's aging population.

site_title: Singapore government keeps pace in residential land supply for H2 2018
summary: The Singapore government has announced the launch of six land parcels for sale in the second-half of 2018, including four private residential sites, one hotel site, and two commercial sites. The Confirmed List sites can yield up to 8,040 private residential units and 124,200 square meters of commercial space. The government aims to maintain the same level of supply as the first half of 2018, which saw 7,045 units and 114,900 square meters of commercial space. The launch is seen as a response to strong demand from developers and a healthy supply of private housing in the pipeline.

site_title: Facebook eases ban on cryptocurrency ads
summary: Facebook has eased its ban on cryptocurrency ads, allowing companies to place ads on its platform if they are pre-approved and have licenses or trade on a public exchange. This move comes five months after the company initially banned all ads related to cryptocurrencies to curb scams. The change aims to strike a balance between protecting users and allowing legitimate cryptocurrency businesses to advertise.

site_title: Chasen bags S$38.4m worth of new contracts in Asia, US
summary: CHASEN Holdings Limited secured S$38.4 million worth of new contracts in Asia and the US, including specialist relocation services, logistics, and technical services. The contracts, valued at S$25.2 million, S$3 million, and S$10.2 million respectively, will keep the company's three business divisions busy in FY2019. The contracts include a US$9.3 million specialist relocation contract in the US and new relocation contracts from Asia-based manufacturers. These new contracts are expected to have a positive impact on the group's financial results for FY2019.

site_title: Huawei lobbies hard to allay Australia's security concerns
summary: Chinese telecom firm Huawei's Australian chairman, John Lord, denies security concerns, stating Huawei's products are "safe and secure". Australia is considering banning Huawei from its 5G mobile network due to fears of Beijing's influence and eavesdropping risks. The move comes amid strained Sino-Australian relations and criticism from Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull about China's interference in domestic affairs. Huawei's lobbying efforts aim to allay security concerns, but the decision is expected to impact the industry and prices of services in Australia.

site_title: More than 10,000 jihadists in Africa, US-led coalition hears
summary: Morocco's foreign minister, Nasser Bourita, stated that Africa is home to over 10,000 jihadists from the Islamic State group and Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb. The US-led coalition aims to defeat the group, with a focus on sharing information and combating terrorism financing. The coalition has allocated nearly $90 million for reconstruction programs in Syria and Iraq. A regional meeting between 50 delegations, including 20 from Africa, was held to discuss strategies and cooperation against the terrorist group.

site_title: Apple reseller EpiCentre calls it a day
summary: EpiCentre, a Singaporean Apple reseller, is selling its four stores and online store to iStudio for S$516,275. The decision comes due to increased competition from other Apple resellers and the opening of the Apple store at Orchard Road. EpiCentre will focus on its beauty and wellness business, exiting the Apple Authorised Reseller and Apple Premium Reseller business. The sale will allow EpiCentre to pay suppliers and exit a business that has seen declining sales and profits since 2017.

images.alt_text: EPICENTRE - where queues used to form when Apple launches new products - is throwing in the towel and selling all four of its Singapore storefronts, as well as its online store to a rival Apple reseller for just S$516,275.

site_title: Ryobi Kiso suspends trading after unit defaults on loan repayments; hires independent financial adviser
summary: Ryobi Kiso's subsidiary Ryobi Kiso (S) Pte Ltd has defaulted on loan repayments to certain bank lenders, breaching banking facilities. The firm has suspended trading and hired PricewaterhouseCoopers as an independent financial adviser to assist in restructuring. Ryobi Kiso reported a loss of S$6.5 million in its latest fiscal third-quarter results due to lower work value and prolonged project phases. The company has a S$168.9 million order book and warned of unlikely financial improvement in the next reporting period due to a challenging construction sector.

site_title: When England play Belgium, neither may really want to win
summary: England and Belgium face a World Cup conundrum as they vie for a spot in the knockout rounds. Both teams have identical points and goal tallies in Group G, making a draw decisive. The winner will travel to Moscow, while the runner-up will play in Moscow as well, but with a more favorable schedule. England coach Gareth Southgate is unsure if winning is an advantage, citing the risk of yellow cards and the potential for a tougher opponent in the knockout rounds. A draw could give the team with the better disciplinary record the top spot.

site_title: US charges Chinese university tied to army with export scheme
summary: US prosecutors have charged Northwestern Polytechnical University, a Chinese university linked to China's army, and Chinese national Shuren Qin with conspiring to violate US export laws. Qin exported 78 hydrophones to the university from 2015 to 2016, allegedly to aid Chinese military capabilities. The indictment also accuses Qin of visa fraud. Qin, 41, is scheduled to be arraigned on Wednesday. The US Commerce Department requires export licenses for US goods to be shipped to the university due to national security risks.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Asiatravel.com, No Signboard, Viking Offshore & Marine, Ryobi Kiso
summary: Asiatravel.com Holdings is facing a lawsuit from YTC Hotels over S$430,208.40 in unpaid hotel room costs. No Signboard Holdings is launching a chain of hawker food-themed fast-food outlets. Viking Offshore & Marine has suspended business with Marshal Systems after Keppel Singmarine commenced legal proceedings. Ryobi Kiso's subsidiary has not met repayment obligations to certain bank lenders, prompting a voluntary suspension of its mainboard-listed shares.

site_title: Judge restores Uber's London licence for 15 months
summary: A London judge has restored Uber's operating licence for 15 months, overturning a decision to strip the ride-hailing app of its licence amid safety concerns. Uber had appealed the decision and implemented reforms, which were accepted by the judge. The licence was granted while the case was being heard, allowing Uber to continue operating in London.

site_title: 'Predictor of recession' has Wall St taking notice
summary: The yield curve, a key indicator of economic health, has inverted, sparking concerns of a potential recession. The curve, which compares short-term and long-term interest rates, has narrowed to 0.34 percentage points, its lowest level since 2007. This inversion has occurred 9 times in the past 60 years, all preceding a recession, according to research. Wall Street is taking notice, with economists warning of a potential slowdown in economic growth, despite low unemployment and rising corporate investment.

site_title: Europe: Trade war worries persist as shares close flat
summary: European shares closed flat on Tuesday, ending a modest bounce after a 2% slide the previous day due to trade tensions. The Stoxx 600, a pan-European index, remained at its lowest level since mid-April. Despite concerns over trade, basic resources and oil stocks rose, while tech stocks recovered. Analysts believe the economic impact of a trade spat will be limited, with some focusing on decent economic fundamentals and strong corporate earnings growth.

site_title: China's factories weaker in Q2, but retail sector, credit growth solid: Beige Book
summary: China's manufacturing sector showed slower growth in Q2, with companies reporting the lowest growth in new export orders since late 2016, according to a private survey. The sector's weakness could add to pressure on China's economy amid trade tensions with the US. However, the retail sector and credit growth showed signs of resilience, with firms borrowing the most in five years and interest rates lower than a year ago. China's central bank cut reserve requirements for banks to channel funds to struggling debt-ridden firms, indicating a willingness to support the economy.

site_title: US House backs tighter foreign investment rules amid China worries
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a bill to tighten foreign investment rules, primarily aimed at addressing national security concerns and China's alleged unfair trade and intellectual property practices. The bill, passed 400-2, includes measures to restrict foreign investment in US technology and prevent the expansion of Chinese telecommunications companies Huawei and ZTE. This move follows a series of measures, including tariffs on goods and efforts to prevent Chinese expansion in the US.

site_title: No Signboard to launch hawker-themed fast food chain
summary: NO Signboard Holdings is launching a hawker-themed fast-food chain called "Hawker" through its subsidiary Hawker QSR Pte Ltd. The brand will debut its first outlet by end-2018 and have at least three outlets by early 2019 in Singapore's central, East, and West regions. This marks the group's entry into the fast-food market with a unique concept inspired by Singapore's hawker culture.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sembcorp Industries appointed Namesh Hansjee as its new head of merchant and retail business, starting August 27. The company aims to capture opportunities closer to customers and in multiple markets, enhancing competitiveness and returns. Renewable Energy Asia Group faces a special general meeting to remove four directors and one company secretary, following a requisition by Xu Jian. KeppeL Offshore & Marine suspended business with Marshal Systems after Viking Offshore & Marine commenced legal proceedings against Keppel Singmarine.

site_title: Millennials, Toyota wants you to go for its Internet-ready Corolla
summary: Toyota is targeting a new generation of buyers with its redesigned Corolla Sport hatchback, featuring internet connectivity. The car will come standard with a data communication module, enabling tasks such as remote window control and virtual assistant navigation. Toyota aims to sell 2,300 Corolla Sports per month in Japan, with a starting price of around $19,000. The company's goal is to have 70% of its new vehicles connected by 2020, as part of its efforts to transform into a mobility-services provider, with revenue from car data expected to reach $750 billion by 2030.

site_title: BOJ's Amamiya signals future adjustment to easy policy: newspaper
summary: Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Masayoshi Amamiya signaled the potential for future adjustments to the ultra-loose monetary policy, citing the rising cost of prolonged easing. He ruled out a near-term exit, warning that premature reduction of stimulus could lead to deflation. Amamiya emphasized the need to carefully monitor the demerits of prolonged easing, such as damage to bank profits, to avoid accumulating negative consequences.

site_title: Fresh off its Time Warner win, AT&T is buying yet another company
summary: AT&T has acquired digital advertising company AppNexus, expanding its new media empire and bolstering its ability to analyze customer behavior and advertise against Time Warner content. The deal gives AT&T control over one of the world's largest Internet advertising exchanges, challenging Google and Facebook's dominance in online advertising. The acquisition is expected to close in the third quarter of 2018 and will rule out a public offering for AppNexus.

site_title: When social impact and healthy returns go hand-in-hand
summary: Declan Ee, partner and founding investor of TLG Capital, a UK-based frontier market investment firm, has found success in combining social impact and commercial returns. Founded in 2009, TLG Capital has invested in various projects, including a pharmaceutical plant in Uganda and a cancer clinic in Ghana. The firm's approach involves creating a movement, equipping beneficiaries with a skill set, and building an ecosystem to sustain itself. Since 2012, investors in TLG have more than doubled their money invested, with the company's credit fund paying out a 10% annualized coupon for eight consecutive quarters.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: World Cup: Messi, Rojo rescue Argentina from humiliating early exit
summary: Lionel Messi and Marcus Rojo led Argentina to a 2-1 win over Nigeria, securing their spot in the World Cup's last 16. Messi scored his first goal of the tournament, but Nigeria's Victor Moses equalized with a penalty. Rojo's late goal sealed the win, with Messi admitting to having survived the most nerve-wracking 90 minutes of his career. The victory keeps Argentina's World Cup hopes alive, avoiding a humiliating group stage exit.

site_title: Oil surges as US pushes allies to halt imports of Iranian crude
summary: US crude oil prices surged over 2% on June 26, reaching $70 for the first time in two months, as the US pushed its allies to halt imports of Iranian crude. This move, aimed at constraining global supplies, led to a $1.58 gain in Brent crude to $76.31 a barrel. The US official stated that no waivers would be granted to sanctions, potentially reducing Iranian oil exports to Asia and Europe. This development overshadowed Saudi Arabia's plans to pump 11 million barrels of oil in July, and analysts expect reduced flows to Asia and Europe.

site_title: Enhancing supervision, cyber risk among key issues for next decade: MAS's Menon
summary: Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) managing director Ravi Menon emphasized the need for regulators to evaluate reforms and enhance supervision, focusing on cyber risk, over the next decade. Possible areas of examination include trade finance, infrastructure finance, and market liquidity, where reforms may have led to "sub-optimal social outcomes." Menon also highlighted the importance of technology, including data analytics and behavioral psychology, in regulatory work, and the need to balance stability with innovation and growth. Cyber risk and setting standards for distributed ledgers are also key areas of focus.

site_title: What to know about iOS 12 beta
summary: Apple has released the iOS 12 beta to the public, allowing users to try out new features such as group FaceTime conversations, Screen Time tools, and revamped social features. The beta version includes new emojis, improved Siri capabilities, and an enhanced "Measure" app. However, users are warned to be cautious as the beta version is unfinished and may cause problems with their smartphone. To participate, users can sign up for an early access account on beta.apple.com and follow the instructions to download and install the beta version. A full version of iOS 12 is expected to be released in the fall.

site_title: 'You cannot be serious': IBM taps emotions for Wimbledon highlights
summary: IBM is using its Watson AI platform to analyze Wimbledon tennis players' emotions, crowd noise, and match data to compile video highlights. The AI platform recognizes players' emotions after exciting shots or rallies, and combines it with crowd noise analysis to identify key moments. This is the latest use of AI at Wimbledon, which has been an early adopter of the technology since 2015. The AI-powered highlights package will be used to create engaging content for fans.

site_title: US senators want Trump to reconsider lifting ban on China's ZTE
summary: US senators Mark Warner and Marco Rubio urge President Trump to reconsider lifting the ban on China's ZTE Corp, citing national security concerns. ZTE, a state-backed enterprise, is seen as loyal to the Chinese Communist Party and government, not shareholders. Several Congress members, including some Republicans and Democrats, have pushed for stricter regulations on ZTE and Huawei, citing similar national security risks. The senators' letter to Trump highlights the potential threat to national security posed by lifting the ban on ZTE.

images.alt_text: Two US senators urged President Donald Trump on Tuesday to reconsider his agreement with ZTE Corp, saying lifting a ban on China's second-largest telecommunications maker poses "a significant threat" to national security.

site_title: Easing of supply pressures a boon for hoteliers in 2018
summary: Hoteliers in Singapore are experiencing a boost in revenue due to easing supply pressures, with RevPAR growing 4.4% year-over-year to $191.1. New room supply is expected to slow down, from a 5.5% CAGR in 2014-2017 to 2.5% this year, and further easing in the following years. Rising visitor arrivals, particularly from China, are also contributing to the growth. Analysts predict a continued recovery in the hotel sector, with companies like Far East Hospitality Trust and Hotel Properties Limited expected to benefit.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Trump adviser talks down trade policy threat to calm markets
summary: US trade adviser Peter Navarro sought to calm investor concerns by downplaying the severity of a Treasury Department report on American restrictions on foreign investment. He stated that no investment restrictions will be imposed on countries interfering with US interests, contradicting previous statements. US equities initially pared losses after Navarro's comments, but Chinese shares tumbled into a bear market, and other Asian and European markets declined. The report is part of the Trump administration's response to China's alleged intellectual property theft.

site_title: Netpoleon focuses on people for a digital edge
summary: Netpoleon Group of Companies, a leading provider of network security solutions, prioritizes human capital in its pursuit of regional leadership. The firm focuses on creating "winning partnerships" with employees and customers to drive growth. With double-digit growth expected in the cyber security industry, Netpoleon aims to be an Employer of Choice through continuous training and mentorship. The company has also expanded internationally, operating in seven countries with eight offices and over 280 staff. Netpoleon's strategic partnerships, including with Macnica Networks Corporation, have helped the firm grow and expand into new markets.

site_title: China Development Bank tightens property redevelopment oversight
summary: China Development Bank (CDB) has halted funding for new shantytown redevelopment projects due to concerns about rising debt for local governments. The bank has transferred approval authority from local branches back to its headquarters. This move aims to mitigate risks associated with local government debt. The bank's decision is part of efforts to oversee property redevelopment projects more closely.

images.alt_text: The move by CDB is due to concerns about risks associated with rising debt shouldered by local governments.

site_title: Brexit Bill passed, UK can leave the EU
summary: A Brexit Bill enacting the UK's decision to leave the European Union has become law after months of debate, with royal assent given by Queen Elizabeth II. The bill, which repeals the 1972 European Communities Act, transfers decades of European law onto British statute books and enshrines Brexit day in British law. Prime Minister Theresa May hailed the approval as a "historic moment" and a significant step towards delivering on the will of the British people. The bill now paves the way for the UK to officially leave the EU on March 29, 2019.

site_title: American businesses will at some point also start to feel the pain of trade wars
summary: US President Donald Trump believes the country is in a strong position to "win" trade wars due to its growing economy and lower reliance on exports. The Trump administration has imposed tariffs on Chinese and European goods, prompting retaliatory measures. However, the US economy's vulnerability to trade wars is growing, as China exports more to the US than it imports. The global economy is also at risk, with trade tensions disrupting supply lines and creating uncertainty. Ultimately, American businesses will feel the pain of trade wars, especially if the US economy slows down.

site_title: H2 industrial land supply to be close to H1 level
summary: The Singapore government has decided to maintain a similar industrial land supply for sale in the second half of 2018, similar to the first half, amid waning interest from manufacturers. Six sites will be launched, totaling 4.09 hectares, and seven sites under the Reserve List will be made available for application. This decision may stem from the low demand for industrial land, which has been on a downward slide since the government introduced smaller plots with shorter land tenures.

site_title: Zuellig family scion said to be keen on selling Singapore-based feed firm Gold Coin for US$500m
summary: A scion of the wealthy Zuellig family, Peter Zuellig, is seeking to sell Singapore-based animal feed firm Gold Coin for approximately US$500 million. Golden Springs Group, Zuellig's holding company, is in talks with potential buyers, with international feed producers likely to show interest. The company, which employs 2,600 people and runs 19 production facilities, has annual revenues of about US$800 million from its livestock arm and US$90 million from its aqua business. Deliberations are ongoing, with other options such as partnerships or an initial public offering also being considered.

site_title: Will Singaporeans grow tired of the status quo?
summary: Singaporeans may grow tired of the status quo due to the country's stagnant leadership and economic policies. The government's five core tenets, which led to Singapore's transformation, may need to adapt to changing times and engage in national conversations to address social-economic challenges such as income disparity and social integration. The new leadership will be judged on its ability to address these issues and ensure balanced economic growth, as Singapore continues to face new challenges and opportunities in the global stage.

site_title: STI rebounds 0.6% but trade fears weigh
summary: STI rebounds 0.6% as trade fears continue to weigh on global markets. Despite a volatile Q3 outlook, DBS Group Research sees upside limited and market unlikely to return to January's high. China's yuan slumped to a near six-month low, and the US is drafting curbs to block firms with Chinese ownership from buying US tech companies. Regional markets, including Australia, Hong Kong, and Shanghai, closed lower, while Singapore and Japan posted modest gains.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: LG Display to open China OLED plant
summary: LG Display is set to start producing 130,000 OLED plates per month in its Guangzhou factory in China after obtaining approval. The plant's expansion will increase OLED production, a technology used in high-end phones, TVs, and cars. Despite Chinese rivals entering the market, LG Display remains ahead in OLED technology, with a production timeline of four to five years. The company aims to boost OLED adoption by expanding its customer base, but faces increasing competition from Chinese firms.

site_title: Alliance Mineral, Tawana to ramp up lithium concentrate output after merger
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets and Tawana Resources, a proposed merger, are targeting to increase lithium concentrate output at their Bald Hill mine in Western Australia to 90,000 to 100,000 tonnes by year-end, up from the current minimum commitment of 80,000 tonnes.

site_title: Enterprise-wide cyber agility for the digital age
summary: EY Asean Cybersecurity Leader Gerry Chng emphasizes that organizations must undergo organizational transformation to effectively counter persistent cyber threats. Despite decades of strengthening cyber defenses, large organizations continue to suffer significant financial and data losses due to attacks on their corporate systems. Chng attributes this to the rapid evolution of the digital landscape, making it increasingly difficult to detect and assess data loss. To address this, he advocates for a mindset shift, assigning responsibilities across the company, and implementing a clear reporting structure to instill a "holistic risk culture."

site_title: China to become top gas importer in 2019, boosted by LNG: IEA
summary: China is expected to become the world's top importer of natural gas in 2019, driven by a surge in liquefied natural gas (LNG) purchases, with demand rising by 60% between 2017 and 2023. China's LNG imports will increase to 93 bcm by 2023, while global LNG exports will rise 30% by 2023, with the US becoming the second-largest supplier. China's energy transition from coal to cleaner-burning energy sources is driving the growth in LNG demand.

site_title: JCDecaux to buy APN Outdoor for A$1.12b
summary: JCDecaux SA agreed to acquire APN Outdoor Group for A$1.12 billion, its largest acquisition in nearly two decades. The deal, which has received unanimous support from APN's board, will complement JCDecaux's Australian business and challenge Ooh!media, the country's largest outdoor advertiser. The combined companies will have around 35% of the Australian market, meeting the regulatory threshold. The acquisition is expected to be approved and is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2018.

site_title: US coal miners worry Trump-China trade spat could dampen exports
summary: US coal mining companies are concerned about the potential impact of the US-China trade spat on their exports, which have been booming. Beijing's inclusion of coal on its list of US goods facing import tariffs could dampen Chinese demand, with some companies already pulling back from supply talks. The US coal industry, which has seen exports to Asia double in 2017, is worried that tariffs could slow down momentum, particularly for companies relying heavily on export trade.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia to recognise S$43.5m loss from unit's revamp
summary: Hong Leong Asia, a Singapore-based industrial conglomerate, expects to recognize a S$43.5 million loss from the deconsolidation of its consumer products unit following a court-sanctioned restructuring plan. The company will transfer its equity stake in the unit to new investors at zero consideration, with creditors having a recovery rate between 1.51% to 9.82%. Hong Leong Asia will derecognize all assets and liabilities of the unit, with any future recovery treated as income. The company's stock closed at S$0.91 after the announcement.

site_title: Remembering the seafarer
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) marked the Day of the Seafarer on June 25, highlighting the importance of improving seafarers' welfare. In Singapore, a coalition of organizations presented 600 gift hampers to 9,000 seafarers, acknowledging their contributions to the maritime industry and global economy. The IMO aims to address factors affecting seafarers' quality of life, including shore leave, abandonment, and access to basic facilities. The organization notes that seafarers' jobs can be both rewarding and challenging, emphasizing the need for better support.

site_title: EU signals no easing up on default financial market access
summary: The European Union has announced it will not ease its default market access for foreign financial firms after Brexit, leaving Britain with the bloc's "off the shelf" system of direct market access, known as equivalence. This means that British banks and insurers will likely face restricted cross-border trade with the EU. The EU's proposed improvements to the equivalence regime will apply to all third countries, not just Britain. The EU's regulations are being tightened to adapt to the UK's significant foreign financial presence, and the UK's government and financial trade bodies reject the scheme, citing concerns about access and politicization.

images.alt_text: Mr Hammond said last week that changes to equivalence proposed so far were more about forcing business to move to the EU, rather than making a one-sided system acceptable.

site_title: Hidden shorts build as London funds seek casualties of cycle
summary: London investors are shorting European companies with high corporate leverage, citing concerns of a potential credit crisis. Strategists at firms like BNP Paribas and Antler Capital Partners are creating baskets of companies with above-average debt and heightened bankruptcy risk, encouraging investors to short the group. The market is bracing for a wave of maturing debt in 2020, which could lead to a financial crisis, with some warning that the real bubble is in the corporate sector. Defaults are expected to be lower than historical averages, but investors remain cautious.

site_title: Horangi targets SMEs, the most vulnerable to cyber security threats
summary: Horangi, a Singapore-based cyber security startup, has focused on helping small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) develop customized solutions to combat cyber security threats. The company's CEO, Paul Hadjy, notes that SMEs are most vulnerable to cyber security threats due to a lack of security professionals and complexity. Horangi's three main products - Storyfier, Scanner, and Hunter - aim to address these issues with modular, cost-effective, and easy-to-implement solutions. The company has raised US$3.1 million in Series A funding and is currently releasing its second version of Storyfier, which provides an "always-on cyber security command centre" for companies to understand and respond to vulnerabilities.

site_title: GE to spin off healthcare business, divest stake in Baker Hughes
summary: General Electric Co plans to spin off its healthcare business and divest its stake in Baker Hughes as part of a year-long strategic review. The company aims to reduce net debt by $25 billion by 2020 and will sell 20% of the healthcare business, with the rest being spun off to shareholders. GE will also sell its stake in Baker Hughes over the next two to three years. The moves are part of a radical reshaping of the company, which will focus on power, aviation, and renewable energy, and maintain its dividend.

site_title: Dollar rebounds from early lows as trade jitters rise
summary: The US dollar rebounded from early lows, rising nearly half a percent against its rivals as trade tensions escalated between the US and China. The Chinese yuan weakened to a fresh six-month low, and Asian currencies also came under selling pressure. Risk appetite was muted, with safe-haven currencies like the Japanese yen and Swiss franc supported, while high-yielding currencies like the Australian dollar were on the back foot. The dollar is set for a third consecutive month of gains.

site_title: 'Look, a woman driver!': Saudis tackle onslaught of sexism
summary: Saudi women have taken to the roads for the first time since a royal decree lifted a decades-long ban on female driving, sparking jubilation and concerns about sexism and harassment. Despite warnings from authorities, many women are wary of aggressive behavior from male drivers, with some predicting accidents and others ridiculing female motorists on social media. Rights groups say the driving reform is a tokenism until the kingdom dismantles its male "guardian" system and addresses pervasive sexism.

site_title: Expect a whole new experience with next generation of chatbots
summary: The next generation of chatbots is expected to revolutionize the customer experience with increased flexibility and power. Improved cognitive machine learning capabilities and greater data availability will enable chatbots to handle complex tasks, deliver personalized experiences, and interact in a more natural conversational flow. This technology will improve customer journeys across various channels, leading to enhanced online shopping experiences, improved healthcare services, and more efficient financial management. As chatbots become more autonomous, they will become fundamental in delivering the customer experience, regardless of the industry.

site_title: SGX enters new era as it starts dual-class shares for qualifying IPOs
summary: SGX has approved a new rule allowing companies with dual-class shares to list on its main board, paving the way for start-ups and tech firms to raise funds through IPOs in Singapore. The change, effective immediately, comes with safeguards in line with market standards. This move aims to attract new-economy stocks to the Singapore market, enabling them to access capital and grow.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

SingaporeExchange (SGX) on Tuesday approved the biggest change to its listing rules, giving the go-ahead for companies with dual-class shares (DCS) structures to seek a primary listing on its main board with immediate effect.

site_title: China drops tariffs on animal feed from Asian countries
summary: China will drop import tariffs on animal feed ingredients, including soybeans, soymeal, and rapeseed, from five Asian countries starting July 1. The move aims to reduce dependence on US soybeans amid the escalating trade dispute. Tariffs on these commodities will be eliminated for imports from Bangladesh, India, Laos, South Korea, and Sri Lanka. This is a sign of China's willingness to import from other countries, signaling a shift in its trade policies.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Cache Logistics Trust announced that ARA Asset Management will purchase the remaining 40% of the trust manager and 60% of the property manager, resulting in ARA owning 100% of both. This consolidation of ownership is seen as positive for the trust, allowing it to tap into ARA's Asia-Pacific network and ensuring continuity in property management. DBS Equity Research recommends buying Singapore Reits, citing a period of easing supply pressure, a buoyant economy, and rising rents, which should lead to tightening yield spreads.

site_title: Mizuho's online stock platform crashes as IPO counter debuts
summary: Mizuho's online stock platform crashed on Tuesday due to a network failure, hindering individual investors from trading on the same day a company it underwrote listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The glitch affected 1.2 million account holders, making it difficult for them to trade via the Net Club website. The outage occurred despite the bank's recent major systems upgrade. Mizuho reported the issue to the Financial Services Agency and will provide more details when available.

site_title: US Supreme Court rules for Trump over travel ban
summary: The US Supreme Court ruled 5-4 in favor of President Donald Trump's travel ban, upholding its constitutionality despite claims that it targeted Muslims. The ban, affecting seven countries, indefinitely bars over 150 million people from entering the US. The court rejected contentions that Trump exceeded his authority and violated the Constitution. Chief Justice John Roberts wrote that Trump's campaign comments against Muslims were not enough to strike down the policy, which has been a defining aspect of Trump's presidency and a major controversy since its inception in 2015.

site_title: The perils of using nationalism to attack foreign influence
summary: A surge of nationalism is driving global politics, but it's largely fueled by xenophobia rather than a genuine desire for patriotism. Countries like Italy, Britain, and the US are turning to scapegoating foreigners, whether through immigration or trade, to divert attention from economic hardships and inequality. This approach is doomed to failure, as it fails to address the root causes of discontent and instead creates new problems, such as higher prices and interest rates. In reality, the opposite of populist nationalism is economic realism, which prioritizes facts over emotions and seeks to address the underlying issues facing societies.

site_title: Singapore is third in sustainable trade index, down from first in 2016
summary: Singapore ranks third in the Hinrich Foundation's sustainable trade index, down from first in 2016. The city-state scored well in social and economic aspects, but fell in environmental indicators, particularly air pollution. Singapore's standing in the index declined due to higher levels of particulate matter 2.5 from transboundary haze pollution and lower scores in transfer emissions and environmental standards in trade. The index aims to support long-term sustainable development and is used as a benchmark for Asian economies.

site_title: Make auditing a public service?
summary: The Big Four accounting firms, Deloitte, Ernst & Young, KPMG, and PricewaterhouseCoopers, have compromised on independence in pursuit of revenue, threatening the quality of audits for major listed companies. Despite regulations aimed at preventing this, the firms continue to prioritize revenue over independent analysis. This has led to declining standards in training and career progression, with employees often seeking advisory services or joining clients rather than auditors. The Financial Reporting Council has criticized the Big Four's audits, with half of KPMG's requiring significant improvement and 27% being censured. A public service approach to auditing is proposed as a solution, but this would require significant investment and commitment from governments.

site_title: Fortescue unit seeks orders to delay Hancock bid
summary: A unit of Fortescue Metals Group, NCZ Investments Pty Ltd, has requested to delay a takeover bid by Hancock Prospecting's Redstone Corp Pty Ltd for Atlas Iron Ltd. NCZ alleges "misleading statements and material omissions" regarding Redstone's intentions for Atlas' business and its ability to achieve them. NCZ seeks interim orders to restrain Hancock from dispatching its bidder's statement and buying more Atlas shares until further disclosure is provided. The Australian Takeovers Panel has not yet decided on the matter, and no sitting panel has been appointed.

site_title: Briton made honorary citizen for contributions to Singapore's biomed industry
summary: A British business executive, Andrew Witty, 53, was made an honorary citizen of Singapore for his contributions to the country's biomed industry. Witty, former CEO of GlaxoSmithKline, was conferred the award by President Halimah Yacob for his work in establishing a joint 10-year roadmap with the Singapore Economic Development Board. This led to significant investments and growth in Singapore's biomedical sciences industry, with GSK's cumulative investments exceeding S$2.5 billion.

site_title: #MeToo has snared 400 high-profile people in 18 months
summary: The #MeToo Movement has identified 417 high-profile individuals, including 193 who were fired or left their jobs, in 18 months. This includes celebrities like Bill Cosby and Louis CK, as well as corporate executives like Intel CEO Brian Krzanich, who resigned after an affair with an employee. The rate of accusations has slowed, but the percentage of people being fired has increased. The majority of accused individuals are men, and most incidents are related to past behavior that has surfaced due to changing social norms. The movement's collective power has empowered women to speak out.

site_title: Ex-Toys 'R' Us CEO working on reboot of retailer
summary: Jerry Storch, former CEO of Toys 'R' Us, is working with investors to revive the US retailer. Credit Suisse is advising on the plan, which includes winning a bankruptcy auction for intellectual property and leasing space from shopping-centre landlords. A successful revival faces long odds due to the company's significant decline. Storch's group aims to create hybrid stores combining toy and baby brands, a concept he introduced during his tenure. A bankruptcy auction for the chain's intellectual property is expected within a month, with competition for its brands anticipated.

site_title: i-Sprint stays ahead of the competition
summary: i-Sprint Innovations, a Singapore-based identity, credential and access management (ICAM) solutions provider, has maintained its leadership in the market. Founded in 2000 by Dutch Ng and Albert Ching, the company has developed a suite of ICAM solutions, including AccessMatrix, which includes universal authentication, single sign-on, and end-to-end encryption. i-Sprint has expanded its offerings to include cloud-based solutions, mobile security, and brand protection. The company has received numerous awards and has partnerships with educational institutions to develop secure digital environments and e-logistics cyber security protocols. With a compound annual growth rate of over 20% from 2014 to 2017, i-Sprint is poised for continued growth in the IAM market, expected to grow at a CAGR of over 13% from 2018 to 2022.

site_title: Asean-India need to respond to GDPR in Europe
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) and India must align their data protection standards to comply with the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) in trade agreements with the EU. With over 7.1 billion identities exposed in data breaches worldwide, Asean countries and India have varying data protection laws, with some lacking legislation altogether. The EU's endorsement of horizontal provisions for cross-border data flows and personal data protection in trade negotiations may lead to the GDPR being re-incorporated into bilateral and multilateral free trade agreements, including the EU-Asean FTA.

site_title: CapBridge, ConsenSys to deploy blockchain technology for upcoming private exchange in Singapore
summary: CapBridge, a private financing platform, and ConsenSys, a blockchain developer, have partnered to deploy blockchain technology for 1exchange (1X), a Singapore-based private exchange. The exchange aims to improve exit options for private company shareholders, reduce inefficiencies in record-keeping and anti-money laundering processes, and promote liquidity in the capital market. The partnership is seen as a testament to Singapore's technology innovation and adoption. The exchange is expected to create a new global market for secondaries and encourage active capital recycling.

site_title: 'Outright bear' ahead for emerging markets, Morgan Stanley says
summary: Morgan Stanley's chief Asia and emerging markets strategist, Jonathan Garner, warns of an "outright bear market" in emerging economies due to US-China tensions, US interest rate tightening, and oil price volatility. The strategist cites accelerated global growth slowdown and weakening of the Chinese renminbi. This has led Morgan Stanley to lower its 12-month target for the MSCI emerging-markets gauge to 1,000 from 1,160. Garner describes the market as "dangerous" and notes that car stocks, technology hardware, and financial sectors are under pressure.

site_title: Total to co-charter Pavilion Energy's first LNG bunker vessel
summary: Total, a French energy company, has agreed to co-charter a liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunker vessel with Pavilion Energy in Singapore, marking a significant step in building infrastructure for ship-to-ship LNG bunkering operations. The vessel, set to be commissioned by 2020, will have a capacity of 10,000 cubic meters. This agreement is part of Singapore's efforts to become a leading bunkering port in South-east Asia, with a goal of using LNG as a marine fuel.

site_title: Australia, NZ central banks shun 'volatile' digital currencies
summary: Australia's Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) and New Zealand's central bank have ruled out issuing official cryptocurrencies due to their volatility and vulnerability to hacking, which could cause economic and social harm. RBA head Tony Richards stated that bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies have not proven themselves as reliable stores of value or means of payment. This decision aims to protect their banking systems from potential damage.

site_title: Changi consortium wins bid to operate Fukuoka Airport
summary: A consortium led by Changi Airports International (CAI) has won the bid to operate Fukuoka Airport in Japan for a 30-year period, with the option to extend up to 35 years. The consortium, which also includes Fukuoka Airport Holdings, Nishi-Nippon Railroad, and Mitsubishi Corporation, aims to revitalize the airport and unlock its potential as a transport hub in the region. Fukuoka Airport, Japan's fourth-largest airport, handles over 20 million passengers annually. The consortium plans to incorporate a special purpose company and leverage the airport's city centre location for its operations.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
A consortium, which includes Changi Airports International (CAI), has won a bid to operate Fukuoka Airport, starting from April 1 next year.

site_title: Singapore factory output defies expectations to grow 11.1% in May
summary: Singapore's factory output grew 11.1% in May, exceeding expectations and beating April's 9.1% rise. Electronics production, led by semiconductor growth, expanded 17.1% for the 27th consecutive month. However, economists warn that the strong showing may not last due to a divergence between rising electronics production and shrinking exports. Global trade tensions and a slowdown in demand could also impact the sector.

images.alt_text: Singapore's factory output continued to outperform in May, defying expectations of a slowdown in manufacturing.

site_title: Cyber security takes no prisoners
summary: Singapore was the top target for cyber attacks during the Trump-Kim Summit in June, with nearly 40,000 attacks in a 21-hour period. The majority of attacks (92%) were reconnaissance scans, while 8% were exploit attacks. Russia accounted for 88% of attacks on Singapore, with Brazil and Germany also involved. The attacks were largely targeting vulnerable devices and ports, with the SQL database port and Telnet being among the most targeted. The frequency and scale of attacks are increasing, with cyber criminals leveraging digital innovations to mount their attacks.

site_title: Singapore is 4th most expensive city in the world for expats, up a notch
summary: Singapore has risen to the 4th most expensive city for expats, according to Mercer's Cost of Living Survey, with Hong Kong taking the top spot and Tokyo in second place. Asian cities dominate the top 10, with six cities leading the rankings. Singapore's cost of living has increased due to currency fluctuations and inflation, but high salaries and a stable economy balance this out. The survey covered 209 cities and measured over 200 items, including housing, food, and entertainment costs.

site_title: UK inflation expectations rise to joint-highest level since 2013
summary: The British public's inflation expectations for the next 5-10 years have risen to a joint-highest level since 2013, reaching 3.3% in June. Short-term price expectations also increased to 2.6% from May's 2.5%. The rise is attributed to rising fuel prices. The Bank of England may be monitoring potential second-round effects on wage settlements. This data was based on a YouGov survey of 2,006 British adults.

site_title: US consumer confidence drops in June
summary: US consumer confidence dropped to 126.4 in June, down from 128.8 in May, according to the Conference Board survey. Despite remaining above the year-ago level, the expectations index fell to a six-month low, while the present situation index dipped slightly. Analysts attribute the decline to concerns about the economy's growth potential and the impact of trade tensions on the stock market, with the share of consumers expecting the economy to improve falling to 21.4%.

site_title: US Defence Secretary Jim Mattis in China for first Pentagon chief visit since 2014
summary: US Defence Secretary Jim Mattis visited China on June 26, 2018, for the first Pentagon chief visit since 2014, amid strained US-China relations. Mattis aimed to press China on North Korea's nuclear programme and economic issues, despite tensions over trade and Taiwan. The trip coincided with President Trump's "maximum pressure" campaign against North Korea and China's growing economic influence. Mattis' visit was seen as a diplomatic effort to maintain cooperation on North Korea disarmament talks, with China's President Xi Jinping playing a crucial role in keeping the North Korean leader engaged.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets attempt rebound at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded 0.3-0.7% in Tuesday's opening deals, reversing Monday's 2% decline due to US President Donald Trump's plans for new curbs on Chinese investment. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.3%, while the Paris CAC 40 rose 0.5% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 added 0.7%. The rebound was attributed to investors taking a defensive approach amid concerns of a global trade war, which could send the US back to recession.

site_title: Hwa Hong acquires 2 freehold commercial plots from CDL
summary: Hwa Hong Corporation acquired two commercial freehold plots in Jalan Besar, Singapore from CDL for S$13.8 million. The sites, totaling 300.1 square meters, are zoned "commercial" with a gross plot ratio of 3.0, near City Square Mall and Little India. Hwa Hong plans to develop one or two commercial buildings with a maximum total gross floor area of about 900.3 sq m.

site_title: Weakening FX better than selling US debt for China: Goldman Sachs
summary: Goldman Sachs has found that China would benefit more from weakening its currency than selling US debt in response to a growing trade conflict. Simulations by the bank's strategists suggest a 5% currency depreciation would boost China's growth by 0.4%, while selling $1.8 trillion in US debt would lead to a 0.1 percentage point tightening of US financial conditions. This is why Goldman Sachs believes an abrupt sale of Chinese Treasury holdings is unlikely.

site_title: Trump's obsession with trade deficit is misplaced
summary: US President Trump's trade deficit-focused approach on China is deemed misplaced, as it may hinder efforts to curb China's acquisition of advanced technologies. Economist David Dollar notes that the US cannot accomplish this alone, requiring a global coalition to curb abuses. Trump's bombastic attacks on traditional trading partners and allies are causing harm to US national security, including distortion of alliance relationships and loss of leverage against China. Experts argue that a more effective approach would involve cooperation with other countries to address the issue, rather than solely focusing on the trade deficit.

site_title: A third of European firms to cut investment because of Brexit: UBS survey
summary: A third of European firms plan to cut investment spending due to Brexit, with 34% citing the uncertainty as a reason. 82% of the surveyed firms have investments in the UK, and 13% plan to pull all capacity out of Britain. Companies are increasingly vocal about the potential threat to their investments and presence in the country. The survey also found that uncertainty over Brexit has halved new investment in the British car industry.

site_title: China stock rout may worsen, as analysts warn of prolonged losses
summary: China's stock market has entered a bear market, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 20% from its January high. Analysts warn that selling is likely to continue due to concerns over China's economy, yuan weakness, and a trade feud with the US. The yuan has weakened to its lowest level since December 28, and experts predict further losses. A Hang Seng measure of Chinese companies in Hong Kong is also down 19% from five months ago, indicating a prolonged market downturn.

images.alt_text: The Shanghai Composite Index closed at 2,844.51 points on Tuesday, 20% below a January high. A Hang Seng measure of Chinese companies in Hong Kong is down 19% from 5 months ago.

site_title: Daimler to invest 600m euros to expand South African plant
summary: Daimler is investing 600 million euros to expand its factory in East London, South Africa, with the goal of producing the next generation of its C-class model. The expansion will include new paint and body shops, an upgraded assembly shop, and logistics warehouses, covering approximately 100,000 square meters. The move aims to increase production capacity and enhance the company's manufacturing capabilities in the region.

site_title: Singapore poised to host 'world's largest base oil plant of its kind'
summary: ExxonMobil is set to build the world's largest base oil plant in Singapore, a multi-billion dollar expansion expected to enter production by 2023. The plant will produce a high-viscosity Group II base stock, which will be used in applications beyond traditional lubricants. The move aims to tap into the growing demand in the Asia-Pacific region, particularly in China and India, and respond to regulations requiring lower sulphur content in marine fuels. The project is part of ExxonMobil's expansion efforts in the region, including upgrades to its Singapore refinery and manufacturing plants in the US and Netherlands.

images.alt_text: ExxonMobil's Ted Walko says the plant is progressing towards a final investment decision in H1 2019.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.24 points to 1,675.86, following a day of significant trading volume of 1.9 billion lots worth RM1.9 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 547 to 264.

site_title: VW to close main plant 1-2 days a week due to new emissions tests
summary: Volkswagen plans to shut its main Wolfsburg factory for 1-2 days a week between August and September due to new engine emissions tests. The company is facing delays in official road certification and sales due to the stricter Worldwide Harmonised Light Vehicle Test Procedure (WLTP). This has resulted in a potential dip in sales, with Volkswagen throttling back production at various plants and closing some factories, including Zwickau and Emden. Audi's Ingolstadt headquarters will also be visited by Germany's KBA motor vehicle authority to discuss progress on emissions issues.

site_title: Activist investor Icahn raises stake in oil producer Energen
summary: Activist investor Carl Icahn has increased his stake in Energen, a US-based oil and gas producer, to 4.3% after acquiring 2 million shares from Corvex Management. Icahn's move may signal a potential takeover bid, as he previously partnered with Corvex to consider acquiring the company. Energen operates in the Permian Basin, a key oil-producing region in Texas and New Mexico.

site_title: Sembcorp appoints energy veteran Namesh Hansjee to head new merchant and retail business
summary: Sembcorp Industries has appointed Namesh Hansjee, a veteran energy expert, to head its new merchant and retail business line starting August 27. Hansjee, with over 25 years of experience in energy trading, will help the company capture opportunities closer to customers and in multiple markets. Sembcorp aims to enhance competitiveness and returns through the new business line, which comes after the acquisition of UK Power Reserve earlier this month.

site_title: Menswear razing runways as luxury brands seek new BFF
summary: Luxury brands are shifting focus to menswear, driven by the growing demand for stylish and functional clothing. French conglomerates LVMH and Kering are investing in male attire, hiring eye-catching designers to cater to the young, urban male market. This trend is also driven by the increasing popularity of streetwear-like hoodies and the loosening of traditional fashion rules. As a result, menswear is expanding faster than women's clothing, with big fashion houses rebranding themselves to appeal to this new audience.

site_title: 1MDB audits don't show "true and fair" assessment: KPMG
summary: KPMG, the auditor of 1MDB, has withdrawn audit reports for 2010-2012 due to lack of access to relevant documents, which would have significantly impacted the assessments. The Malaysian government, led by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, is seeking to recover $4.5 billion from 1MDB. The declassified auditor-general report highlights possible anomalies in transactions, but notes limited access to data. Asri Hamidon has been named as the new chairman of 1MDB, and the fund's day-to-day management will be handled by an executive committee.

site_title: Brexit bill becomes law, allowing UK to leave the EU
summary: The UK's EU withdrawal bill has become law, allowing the country to formally leave the European Union. The bill, which repeals the 1972 European Communities Act, received royal assent from Queen Elizabeth II and transfers decades of European law onto British statute books. Brexit day is now set for March 29, 2019, and International Trade Minister Liam Fox said the chances of Britain not leaving the EU are "now zero". The bill's passage paves the way for a "clean Brexit" and strengthens the prime minister's negotiating hand.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end down on volatile day in Asia
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day down 0.28% due to volatile trading in Asia amid US-China trade tensions. The Hang Seng Index closed at 28,881.40 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.52%. The Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.56%. Global markets followed sharp drops in the US and Europe, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 20.03 points, or 0.61%, to 3,280.87, driven by a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. 1.8 billion shares worth S$1.1 billion were traded, with losers outpacing gainers 210 to 184.

site_title: Indonesian election season is a gauge of rise of political Islam
summary: In Indonesia, the upcoming election season is seen as a gauge of the rise of political Islam, with hardline Islamist groups and some Islamic leaders emerging as vocal opponents of President Joko Widodo. The opposition's anti-Widodo sentiment has crystallized into a movement called "#GantiPresiden2019" or "Change the president in 2019", with many affiliated supporters coming from Islamic parties and groups that opposed the jailing of Jakarta's Christian governor in 2017. Despite election laws prohibiting campaigning in mosques, Islamist groups continue to push their message through sermons, with some supporters saying they are smart enough to decide for themselves.

site_title: Five sectors of opportunity in Vietnam
summary: Vietnam is poised to become a developed nation by 2020, with a trading flow of US$340 billion and a foreign direct investment sector accounting for 22% of its economy. Five emerging sectors with the greatest potential for growth and investment are highlighted by PwC, including business process outsourcing (BPO), solar and wind energy, luxury hotels, modern agribusiness and food, and retail banking. These sectors offer opportunities for foreign investors, with government incentives, favorable geography, and growing demand for services.

site_title: China Development Bank tightens approvals for property redevelopment programme: source
summary: China Development Bank (CDB) has halted new funding for shantytown redevelopment projects due to concerns over rising debt for local governments. Existing projects continue to operate normally. The bank has transferred approval authority back to its headquarters from local branches, citing a need to strengthen risk management. This move comes as China has invested hundreds of billions of dollars in shantytown redevelopment, boosting home sales and prices in smaller cities.

site_title: Australian shares fall on materials slump; NZ mostly unchanged
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 6,197.60 on Tuesday, driven by a decline in materials stocks, particularly BHP, which dropped 1% after settling a 20 billion reais lawsuit with Brazilian authorities over a 2015 dam disaster. The NZ benchmark remained largely unchanged. Global miners Rio Tinto and BlueScope Steel also fell, while healthcare stocks declined, with CSL and Ramsay Health Care losing 0.7% and 2% respectively.

site_title: Last straw for McDonald's, Burger King in Mumbai plastic ban
summary: Burger King, McDonald's, and Starbucks have been fined for violating a new ban on single-use plastics in Mumbai, India. The ban, which prohibits items under a certain size, has collected 660,000 rupees in fines since its implementation on Saturday. 132 premises, including the restaurants, have been penalized for using banned plastic straws and disposable cutlery. Authorities hope the ban will help clean up Mumbai's beaches and streets, which are plagued by plastic rubbish.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's factory output surged 11.1% in May, outperforming expectations. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) introduced new rules for dual-class shares, and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) discussed future regulatory scenarios. Industrial sites will be launched for sale, and CapBridge and ConsenSys partnered to deploy blockchain technology for a private exchange. Singapore ranked as the 4th most expensive city for expats, and Hong Leong Asia reported a S$43.5 million loss due to deconsolidation of a consumer unit.

site_title: Total to co-charter Pavilion Energy's first LNG bunker vessel
summary: Total, the marine fuels arm of France's Total, has agreed to co-charter Pavilion Energy's first LNG bunker vessel, commissioned by Pavilion Gas by 2020. The vessel will facilitate ship-to-ship transfer of LNG as marine fuel, meeting new regulations on ship emissions. The partnership aims to provide environmentally friendly fuels, particularly in Singapore, the leading bunkering hub. Total has signed LNG supply contracts with CMA CGM and Brittany Ferries, while Pavilion Energy has secured a co-funding grant to build the vessel.

images.alt_text: From left to right: Patrick Pouyanné, chairman and CEO of Total, and Mohd Hassan Marican, chairman of Pavilion Energy, at the signing of the agreement to jointly develop an LNG bunker supply chain in the port of Singapore .

site_title: Keppel unit suspends business with Viking Offshore Marine unit amid litigation
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine has suspended business with Viking Offshore & Marine's unit Marshal Systems amid a litigation dispute. The suspension follows a court case initiated by Viking HVAC, which claimed S$5.07 million for subcontracting works. Viking Offshore & Marine denied all claims and counterclaimed for alleged backcharges of S$3.8 million, which Keppel Singmarine denied. The dispute is ongoing, and Keppel Offshore & Marine declined to comment on the details.

site_title: General Electric to spin off healthcare unit, divest Baker Hughes stake
summary: General Electric will spin off its healthcare business and divest its stake in Baker Hughes over the next 12-18 months and 2-3 years, respectively. The moves aim to strengthen GE's balance sheet, reduce debt, and reward shareholders. GE shares jumped 5.2% after the announcement, which concludes a year-long strategic review. The remaining businesses, including jet engines and power plants, will focus on similar technologies and industrial markets, but lack synergies with GE Healthcare.

site_title: Renewable Energy Asia Group requisitioned to hold EGM to vote out 4 directors, company secretary
summary: Renewable Energy Asia Group has received a requisition to hold a special general meeting to vote out four directors and one company secretary. The requisition, made by Xu Jian, representing 52.31% of the company's shares, aims to remove Zheng Lei, Lien Kait Long, Tan Sin Huat, and Wong Gang as directors, and Soh Yeow Hwa as company secretary. The move is seen as a significant shake-up at the company, with Xu Jian seeking to replace the existing board with two new directors.

site_title: Millennials, Toyota wants you to buy its Internet-ready corolla
summary: Toyota has launched its first fully connected cars, the Corolla Sport hatchback and Crown sedan, in Japan. The company aims to attract a new generation of buyers, particularly millennials, with internet connectivity and services such as artificial intelligence-driven navigation assistance and a 24/7 live operator. The Corolla Sport has a starting price of around 2.1 million yen and Toyota targets selling 2,300 units per month. The company's goal is to have 70% of its new vehicles connected by 2020, as part of its transformation into a mobility-services provider.

site_title: CAI consortium wins bid to operate Fukuoka Airport
summary: A consortium led by Changi Airports International (CAI) has won a bid to operate Fukuoka Airport in Japan for a 30-year period, with the option to extend to 35 years. The consortium, comprising Fukuoka Airport Holdings, Nishi-Nippon Railroad, Mitsubishi Corporation, and Kyushu Electric Power, aims to revitalize the airport and unlock its potential as a key transport hub in the region. The partnership is expected to stimulate Kyushu's economy through trade and business activities, with a focus on safe and secure airport operations.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Audi partners with Israel's autonomous vehicle simulation startup Cognata
summary: Audi has partnered with Israel-based autonomous vehicle simulation startup Cognata to speed up the development of autonomous vehicles. The partnership will utilize Cognata's simulation platform to virtually recreate real-world cities and test autonomous vehicles in various scenarios, reducing the time to market. Cognata's simulation technology is seen as a key tool for increasing development speed and validation of autonomous vehicles, with several major companies investing in autonomous capabilities. This deal comes as Israel's auto tech startups continue to raise significant funding, with $814 million raised last year.

site_title: Australia, NZ central banks shun "volatile" digital currencies
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia and the Reserve Bank of New Zealand have ruled out issuing official cryptocurrencies, citing volatility and hacking concerns. The central banks warn that the potential damage to their banking systems could outweigh benefits. The RBA's Tony Richards stated that cryptocurrencies have structural flaws, making them unsuitable for many uses. The RBNZ's Deputy Governor Geoff Bascand expressed concerns that a central bank digital currency could increase the likelihood of bank runs during financial instability, undermining financial stability.

site_title: 'Order-ahead' app Eatsy raises S$550,000 in funding round
summary: Eatsy Technologies, a Singaporean food delivery app, has raised S$550,000 in funding from investors including Quest Ventures and Wee Teng Wen. The app allows users to order ahead from restaurants and pay in-app, with the option for group ordering. Eatsy has partnered with over 80 merchants since its launch seven months ago and plans to use the funding to enhance its in-app functions and partner new restaurants. The startup was previously backed by Quest Ventures and Enterprise Singapore under the Startup SG Founder scheme.

site_title: 'Green gold': Pakistan plants hundreds of millions of trees
summary: Pakistan has planted over 1.06 billion trees, a significant portion of its "Billion Tree Tsunami" program, to combat deforestation and mitigate climate change. The initiative, launched in 2014, aims to increase forest cover from 5.2% to 12% of the country. The program has seen the planting of 300 million trees, with 150 million given to landowners, and 730 million trees regrowing naturally. The effort has been praised by conservation groups and officials, but critics question the long-term sustainability of the project.

site_title: ExxonMobil eyes multibillion expansion for base stock output
summary: ExxonMobil plans a multibillion-dollar expansion project at its Singapore facility, aiming to produce higher-value products and increase lubricant base stocks output. The project, targeted for a final investment decision in the first half of 2019, will move the facility to the top quartile worldwide in refining competitiveness. The expansion will result in the production of fuels complying with the International Maritime Organization's global sulphur cap and introduce a new high viscosity Group II base stock. Production is expected to start in 2023.

site_title: Peak Japan: Hello Kitty bullet train debuts this week
summary: A "Hello Kitty" bullet train, part of Japan's national railway service, has been unveiled and will debut this week on the Osaka-Fukuoka route. The special train features Hello Kitty-themed carriages, including a "life-sized" doll and seats adorned with the character. The train aims to boost tourism and local economy, as Hello Kitty has become a global icon since its introduction in 1974. The special train will run for three months, offering regional specialties and goods in one car with no passenger seats.

site_title: SGX to allow listing of dual-class shares with immediate effect
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has approved rules for dual-class shares (DCS) structures, allowing companies with such share structures to list on the exchange with immediate effect. The rules aim to support high-growth companies while mitigating governance risks. Key safeguards include capping multiple voting shares at 10 votes per share, limiting holders to named individuals or permitted groups, and requiring an enhanced voting process for independent directors and auditors. The move is part of Singapore's transition to a new economy and aims to broaden investment options for investors.
