site_title: Former Toys 'R' Us CEO is working on the retailer's reboot
summary: Former Toys 'R' Us CEO Jerry Storch is working with investors to revive the US toy chain. Storch, who previously led the company from 2005 to 2013, has enlisted the help of Credit Suisse and Fairfax Financial Holdings Ltd. to develop a plan to reboot the business. The revival effort faces long odds due to the company's significant decline and potential competition for its brands. Storch's group aims to win a bankruptcy auction for the chain's intellectual property and lease space to operate several hundred hybrid stores combining toy and baby brands.

images.alt_text: A revival of Toys "R" Us might be in the works. Jerry Storch, a former chief executive officer of the defunct toy chain, has been working with multiple investors on a plan to reboot the retailer in the US.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,259.12, down 0.05%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Tuesday afternoon at 3,259.12, down 0.05% from the previous day's close. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 1.72 points, with losers outnumbering gainers 193 to 112. A total of 903.4 million shares worth S$520.9 million changed hands. Key movers included Nico Steel trading flat, Noble Group declining 9.14%, and Genting Singapore advancing 0.83%.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks tumble on global trade war worries, won recovers
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.30% on Tuesday due to concerns over a potential global trade war. The US Treasury Secretary hinted at investment curbs for countries trying to steal US technology, targeting China but not others. Meanwhile, European stocks rose despite US President Trump's threat of a 20% tariff on imported European cars. The Korean won recovered from its previous close, closing at 1,114.8 per dollar, while the Kospi is down 4.4% this year.

site_title: UK car sector investment collapses on Brexit impact: industry data
summary: UK car sector investment plummeted by 47% in the first six months of 2018, largely due to Brexit uncertainty, according to industry data. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders reported £347.3 million in investment, down from £647.4 million in the same period in 2017. The organization urged the government to make swift progress on Brexit negotiations, prioritizing the automotive sector's needs. With new investment projects hindered by uncertainty, the industry is calling for a deal that maintains customs union membership and delivers single market benefits.

site_title: Mizuho's online trading platform crashes as IPO stock debuts
summary: Mizuho's online trading platform crashed on the day of a company it underwrote for its initial public offering (IPO), making it difficult for individual investors to trade. The crash was due to a network failure, unrelated to a recent systems upgrade, and affected 1.2 million account holders. Shares of the listed company, Kokusai Pulp & Paper Co, jumped 37% on its debut. The outage may have cost investors the opportunity to sell shares at a high price, according to an analyst. Mizuho has reported the issue to the Financial Services Agency and is working to resolve the problem.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher helped by tech stocks
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with tech stocks driving a turnaround, after the S&P 500 posted its steepest one-day loss since early April due to trade dispute fears. The Dow Jones rose 29.09 points, the S&P 500 gained 5.05 points, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 21.73 points, all at the opening bell. The gains followed a day after the S&P 500 fell, but traders appear to be brushing off new US threats to extend the rally.

site_title: CPF members to pay less for home protection insurance from July
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) will lower home protection insurance premiums for over 510,000 members starting July 1. The reduction is due to better-than-expected investment returns and claims experience. This is the first reduction in 11 years, with 95% of HPS members eligible for a reduction, including 75% who will receive at least a 10% decrease. The new rates will apply to new and existing members who renew or adjust their coverage on or after July 1.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks inch higher on bargain-hunting
summary: Tokyo stocks rose slightly, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.02% to 22,342.00, driven by bargain-hunting purchases amid US-China trade frictions. The broader Topix index was up 0.16%. This follows a rally in Singapore stocks and US shares, which edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. Meanwhile, eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion.

site_title: Australia's Fortescue asks watchdog to delay Rinehart's Atlas bid
summary: Fortescue Metals Group, a major iron ore miner, has requested the Australian Takeovers Panel to delay a takeover bid by Hancock Prospecting's Redstone Corp Pty Ltd for Atlas Iron Ltd. Fortescue, which holds a 19.9% economic interest in Atlas, alleges "misleading statements and material omissions" in Redstone's intentions for Atlas' business. Fortescue seeks interim orders to restrain Hancock from buying more Atlas shares until further disclosure is provided. The panel has not yet appointed a sitting panel to consider the matter.

site_title: LG Display is set to open China OLED plant, braces for competition
summary: LG Display is set to start OLED production at a new factory in Guangzhou, China, despite Chinese rivals' entry into the market. The company expects to manufacture 130,000 OLED plates per month once approval is granted. LG Display faces competition from Chinese display makers, including BOE Technology Group Co., which is turning its attention to OLEDs. Despite being four to five years behind China in OLED technology, LG Display remains competitive due to its head start in mass-producing OLED televisions.

images.alt_text: LG Display Co. is close to starting OLED production at a new factory in Guangzhou to sell more of the next-generation screens, even as Chinese rivals gear up to enter the market.

site_title: Hwa Hong buys 2 commercial sites from CDL for S$13.8m
summary: Hwa Hong Corporation acquired two commercial freehold plots in Singapore from CDL for S$13.8 million. The sites, with a combined land area of 300.1 square meters, are zoned "commercial" and located near City Square Mall and Little India. Hwa Hong plans to develop the sites into one or two commercial buildings with a maximum total gross floor area of 900.3 square meters. The acquisition is in line with the group's strategy to expand its commercial property portfolio and strengthen its recurrent rental income and capital appreciation.

site_title: Ex-Amazon executive tapped to run luxury store Bergdorf Goodman
summary: Neiman Marcus Group has appointed Darcy Penick, former Amazon executive and CEO of Shopbop, to run luxury department store Bergdorf Goodman. Penick will accelerate digital transformation and speed up global growth, with a goal of achieving a 50-50 split between stores and online sales. This move comes as online luxury retail becomes increasingly crowded, with major luxury houses now having their own online shops. Penick will step into the job on September 4, bringing her experience in digital and international retail to the role.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia to recognise S$43.5m loss from deconsolidation of consumer unit
summary: Hong Leong Asia expects to recognize a S$43.5 million loss from deconsolidating its consumer unit following a court-approved restructuring plan. The company will transfer its equity stake in Xinfei to new investors at zero consideration, with creditors having a recovery rate of 1.51-9.82%. Hong Leong Asia will derecognize Xinfei's assets and liabilities, treating any future recovery as income. The restructuring plan aims to restructure Xinfei, which was previously a subsidiary of Hong Leong Asia, after the court approved the plan.

site_title: Australia buys high-tech drones to monitor South China Sea, Pacific
summary: Australia is investing A$7 billion in high-tech US drones, including six MQ-4C Triton maritime surveillance drones, to enhance its anti-submarine warfare and maritime strike capability in the South China Sea and Pacific. The drones, which can support missions for up to 24 hours and provide a 360-degree view of their surroundings, will replace the AP-3C Orion spy plane. The investment aims to protect Australia's borders and make the region more secure, as the country navigates rival claims in the South China Sea. The drones will also support search and rescue operations.

site_title: Scion of Zuellig family is said to seek US$500 million feed firm sale
summary: A scion of the Zuellig family is seeking to sell Singapore-based animal feed manufacturer Gold Coin for approximately US$500 million. Golden Springs Group, the holding company of Peter Zuellig, is considering a sale and has also explored other options, including partnerships or an initial public offering. Gold Coin employs 2,600 people and operates 19 production facilities in nine countries. The sale is likely to attract interest from international feed producers, following a surge in agriculture-related deals in Southeast Asia, which have reached US$1.1 billion this year.

site_title: Japan blogger killed after 'dispute' resolution talk: reports
summary: A Japanese blogger, Kenichiro Okamoto, known as Hagex, was stabbed to death after giving a talk on managing online disputes in Fukuoka, Japan. The 41-year-old was followed to the toilets and attacked several times. A 42-year-old suspect, who had argued with the blogger online, has been arrested and confessed to the crime, stating he "hated" the blogger. Okamoto was a specialist on online security and appeared on television to discuss internet issues in Japan.

site_title: For "French Tech", Macron's global appeal a double-edged sword
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's "French Tech" initiative, aimed at turning France into a startup nation, faces a double-edged sword. While Macron's support has benefited startups, it has also attracted global tech giants like Google, Apple, and Amazon, which compete with French firms. This has frustrated some entrepreneurs, who feel that Macron's efforts to attract foreign investment are overshadowing local talent. Despite hurdles, including a complex legal framework and fragmented European markets, there is optimism about France's growing tech sector, with some startups even returning to the country after brain drain.

site_title: Trump boasts of "great" hair
summary: President Donald Trump boasted about his "great" hair, attributing its durability to a hairpiece, contradicting long-standing speculation it might be a wig. He claimed he's been in harsh weather conditions without it falling off. Trump's doctor had previously prescribed medication to prevent hair loss. The president's statement was unrelated to the current news headlines, which include Malaysia seizing assets, China's GDP growth slowing, and the UK economy shrinking.

site_title: Singapore now 4th most expensive city in the world for expats: Mercer
summary: Singapore has moved up one spot to become the fourth most expensive city for expatriates, according to Mercer's Cost of Living Survey. Hong Kong tops the table, followed by Tokyo and Zurich. Asian cities dominate the top 10, with Luanda, N'Djamena, and Bern also in the top 10. Singapore's soaring rents and high salaries are balanced by its stable economy. The survey ranked 209 cities across five continents, with Western European cities rising in the rankings due to strengthening local currencies.

site_title: US: Stocks join global selloff on trade war worries
summary: US stocks plummeted 1.3% on Monday, joining a global equities selloff due to growing trade war concerns. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 2% earlier, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined 1.4% and 2.1%, respectively. Investors are wary of further escalation of tensions between the US and China, with President Trump set to unveil "specific investment restrictions and enhanced export controls" tied to "industrially significant technology."

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 1.14 points to 1,679.24. Volume was 47.75 million lots worth RM13.9 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 103 to 62.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on trade war worries
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, June 26, 2018, amid growing worries about a potential escalation of US trade frictions with China. The Nikkei 225 index lost 0.85% and the Topix index declined 0.70%. This follows a global selloff, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Koreas hold talks on connecting railways
summary: North and South Korea held talks in Panmunjom on connecting their railways, a physical link that would transform the relationship between the two sides. The discussions, the first in 10 years, aim to link up the two railway systems, modernizing the North's ageing infrastructure and giving trade-dependent South Korea a land route to China, Russia, and Europe. However, sanctions on North Korea must be eased before practical steps can be taken, according to South Korea's chief delegate. The talks are a result of diplomatic warming on the peninsula, including summits between Kim Jong Un and President Moon Jae In.

site_title: HBO website is down in China after John Oliver skewers Xi
summary: HBO's website has been blocked in China after John Oliver's segment criticizing President Xi Jinping's censorship on his show "Last Week Tonight" aired. The move comes as US companies seek access to China's growing online streaming market. The segment, which criticized Xi's amassing power and censoring online discussion, may have contributed to the blockage. HBO, a unit of AT&T, licenses shows in China through Tencent Holdings, but its website remains unavailable to users. Authorities have not commented on the issue, and analysts warn that future plans may be affected.

site_title: JTC to launch 6 industrial sites for sale in H2 2018, 7 other sites on Reserve List
summary: Singapore's government agency JTC will launch six industrial sites for sale in the second half of 2018, totaling 4.09 hectares, under the Confirmed List of the Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) Programme. Seven other sites, totaling 8.5 hectares, will be made available on the Reserve List. The sites are zoned for Business-2 use and may be used for clean industry, light industry, and other public installations. The sites' land tenure and gross plot ratio vary, with some offering 20-year leases and others 30-year leases.

site_title: Asia stocks extend global slide on intensifying trade row
summary: Global stocks slid on Tuesday as trade tensions between the US and other major economies intensified, with Asia equities following Wall Street's lead. US technology shares were particularly hard hit after a report on curbs on companies with Chinese ownership buying US tech firms. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq suffered their steepest losses in over two months, while safe-haven US Treasuries rose. The US dollar remained on the defensive amidst ongoing trade uncertainty, with investors seeking safer assets.

site_title: 8Telecom proposes to place 22.5m new shares at 10.3 Singapore cents apiece to raise S$2.3m
summary: 8Telecom International Holdings plans to issue 22.48 million new shares at 10.3 Singapore cents apiece, raising S$2.3 million. The shares represent 16.66% of the firm's enlarged share capital. The company will use half of the funds for acquisitions and the rest for operating expenses. Shareholders' approval is sought at a special general meeting. The placement is subject to in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST).

site_title: AVA launches 7 land parcels for farming at Lim Chu Kang
summary: The Agri-Food & Veterinary Authority of Singapore (AVA) has launched seven land parcels for farming at Lim Chu Kang, including five for vegetable farming and two for quail-egg farming, through public tender. The land parcels have a lease term of 20 years and range from 16,096.3 to 20,500.2 square metres. The tender for the land parcels will close on September 4.

site_title: China's largest stock exchanges say risks from share-backed loans controllable
summary: China's largest stock exchanges, the Shanghai and Shenzhen exchanges, have stated that risks from share-backed loans can be controlled. The exchanges reported that the scale of share-backed loans is decreasing and that lenders are more likely to negotiate with troubled parties and request new security rather than immediately liquidating their positions. The Shanghai exchange noted that share-backed loans account for only 3% of the exchange's total value, and the Shenzhen exchange said that the risks are controllable. This reassurance aims to calm investors worried about the impact of global trade tensions on the market.

site_title: Global Yellow Pages' 1-for-5 rights issue fully taken up, but by only some of its shareholders
summary: Global Yellow Pages (GYP) has fully taken up its 1-for-5 rights issue, but only 25.6 million of the 41.82 million offered shares were accepted, resulting in 16.22 million excess shares. The company will receive approximately S$8.4 million in gross proceeds. The rights shares will be issued on June 27 and begin trading on June 29.

site_title: Uber claims U-turn in bid to restore London licence
summary: Uber has submitted an appeal to London's transport authority, Transport for London (TfL), claiming it has made significant changes in response to concerns raised by TfL, which led to the licence being stripped last September. The company has agreed that TfL's decision was justified but argues that it has undergone a "wholesale change" since then, including reforms such as reporting serious incidents to the police and insuring drivers are licensed by TfL. A decision is expected by Tuesday.

images.alt_text: Uber claimed on Monday to have mended its ways as the ride-hailing app started its appeal against being stripped of its licence to operate in London.

site_title: BMW executive says would shut UK plants if Brexit hits supply chain
summary: BMW executive Stephan Freismuth warned that the company would close its Mini and Rolls-Royce plants in the UK if Brexit seriously disrupts its supply chain. Around 60% of Minis made by BMW last year were produced in Oxford, with 90% of parts coming from mainland Europe. Freismuth stated that a disruption to imports would increase costs and damage BMW's just-in-time manufacturing model. The warning comes amid concerns about the impact of Brexit on British industry, with similar warnings from Airbus and Siemens.

site_title: US dollar slips vs yen as trade tensions weigh
summary: The US dollar fell to a two-week low against the Japanese yen, slipping 0.44% to 109.48 yen, amid escalating trade tensions between the US and other leading economies. The US Treasury Department is drafting curbs on firms with significant Chinese ownership from buying US companies with "industrially significant technology." Global stocks markets also declined as investors showed caution, with the dollar index down 0.28% at 94.249.

site_title: S$5.2m discrepancy due to restructuring exercise: Asiatravel
summary: Asiatravel announced a S$5.2 million discrepancy between its unaudited and audited financial statements for fiscal 2017 due to its restructuring exercise. The main difference came from the allowance for doubtful debt of two subsidiaries, with S$4.5 million attributed to this. The company attributed S$2.6 million of the loss to its owners, with the remainder due to intangible asset amortization and goodwill impairment. Asiatravel's shares closed at S$0.029 apiece prior to the announcement.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday, STI down 0.5% to 3,245.79
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index retreating 15.05 points, or 0.5%, to 3,245.79. The decline follows a selloff in US stocks, driven by escalating trade disputes. Losers outnumbered gainers 57 to 31, with active index stocks such as Venture Corp and OCBC Bank falling 1.9% and 0.8% respectively.

site_title: 70 years on, Berlin remembers Airlift 'Candy Bombers'
summary: Germany marks 70 years since the start of the Berlin Airlift, a humanitarian rescue mission that provided food and fuel to war-ravaged West Berlin from June 1948 to May 1949. The airlift, led by American and British pilots, cemented the post-war German-American friendship and was a key moment in the Cold War. The operation, which included over 277,000 flights and 2 million tonnes of relief goods, was dubbed the "Candy Bombers" for the pilots who threw sweets and raisin packages from the skies. The blockade was finally lifted on May 12, 1949, after 322 days, and the airlift claimed at least 78 lives.

site_title: MYP enters definitive agreement to sell freehold MYP Plaza
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED MYP has entered a definitive agreement to sell its freehold MYP Plaza for S$247 million to Golden Estate Properties Pte Ltd, affiliated with Filipino billionaire Lucio Tan's group. The 14-storey office tower at 135 Cecil Street has a net lettable area of 82,334.28 square feet. Completion of the disposal is expected on July 20.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at the open on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.28% in opening trade on Tuesday, tracking sharp losses on Wall Street amid growing concerns over a China-US trade war. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 28,881.18, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.03% to 2,829.99. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 1.29% to 1,566.86. The losses follow sharp losses on Wall Street, with investors increasingly worried about the potential impact of a trade war on global markets.

site_title: Google tackles Facebook in India with hyper-local social network
summary: Google has launched a hyper-local social network called Neighbourly in India, aiming to tap into the country's vast smartphone user base. The app allows users to share local expertise and crucial information with others in their vicinity, reducing the need for group chats and online discussions. Neighbourly's features include crowd-sourced recommendations, a focus on local expertise, and strict data protection measures. The move is part of Google's aggressive global expansion, with the company seeking to become a one-stop shop for search, social networking, and payments in India.

site_title: Trump blasts Harley-Davidson plan to shift US production to avoid EU tariffs
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized Harley-Davidson for shifting US production to avoid EU tariffs, calling it a "White Flag." The motorcycle maker plans to move production overseas to avoid retaliatory tariffs, expected to cost it up to $100 million per year. Trump vowed to make Harley-Davidson great again, but analysts cut profit forecasts due to the near-term impact of the tariffs. Harley-Davidson aims to boost overseas sales to 50% of annual volume, but ramping up production overseas could take 9-18 months.

site_title: A sombre economic reality for Turkey's Erdogan after poll win
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has won a poll, but the economic reality of his victory is uncertain. Despite an economic boom in his first 15 years in power, Turkey's economy has threatened to turn into a bust, with the currency plunging and capital fleeing. Erdogan has granted himself sweeping new powers and has promised to take greater control of monetary policy, which has shaken investor confidence. Economists warn that his track record and autocratic style may lead to policy decisions prioritizing economic growth over taming inflation, putting the country's economy at risk.

site_title: S&P raises Greece debt rating to B+ on reduced debt risks
summary: S&P Global upgraded Greece's debt rating to "B+" with a stable outlook, citing reduced debt risks due to debt relief and cash buffers. The upgrade comes after eurozone ministers extended maturities and disbursed €15 billion. The ratings agency noted that while public and private debt remains high, the country's track record on attracting foreign direct investment is weak. To restore economic health, S&P advises Greece to resist rollback of economic reforms and implement additional measures to attract foreign capital. The upgrade is seen as a positive step for Greece's economic recovery.

site_title: China's Huawei top sponsor of Australian politicians' overseas trips: ABC
summary: Chinese telecommunications equipment maker Huawei is the top sponsor of Australian politicians' overseas trips, with 12 trips paid for by the company between 2010 and 2022, including trips by Foreign Minister Julie Bishop and Trade Minister Steve Ciobo. The Australian Strategic Policy Institute's research found Huawei accounted for 12 out of 55 corporate-sponsored trips by federal politicians. Huawei's Australian spokesman Jeremy Mitchell said the company invited politicians for "study tours" to understand China's technological growth, but some politicians described the trips as "all-expenses paid".

site_title: Big Tech lags S&P 500 by most since March on China-blowback fear
summary: US technology stocks, particularly semiconductors, declined 2.9% on Monday, the largest drop since April 6, amid concerns about a potential trade war with China. The Nasdaq 100 fell 2.9% and the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index dropped 4.4%. President Trump threatened "more than reciprocity" in response to China's trade barriers and tariffs. The decline is the widest since March, with the tech sector lagging the S&P 500. Experts warn that a trade war could push the world into a global recession.

site_title: Atlantic Navigation narrows Q1 loss
summary: Atlantic Navigation Holdings reported a narrowed Q1 loss of US$63,000, compared to a net loss of US$2.44 million in the same period last year. Revenue more than doubled to US$12.25 million, driven by a surge in marine logistics services. The company attributed the increase to higher vessel utilisation and the deployment of new vessels. Despite higher income tax expenses, the group expects performance to improve from the third quarter onwards due to increased demand in the Middle East exploration and production sectors.

site_title: Oil drops as market braces for more Opec crude and Wall Street slips
summary: Oil prices dropped as investors awaited an expected 1 million barrels per day increase in production from Opec, while US equity markets declined due to escalating trade tensions. Brent crude futures fell 1.1% to $74.73, and US light crude dropped 1.1% to $68.08. Analysts attributed the decline to trade tensions and concerns about tight US supplies, despite Opec's plan to boost production. The US Energy Secretary expressed doubts about the agreement being sufficient to stabilize inventories.

site_title: China to protect a quarter of land from development by 2020
summary: China aims to protect at least 25% of its land from development by 2020 and increase forest coverage to over 23% by the end of the decade under its "ecological red line" scheme. The country also plans to reduce pollution levels, cut smog in key industrial regions, and ensure more than 70% of its water supplies are fit for human contact by 2020. China's president Xi Jinping has vowed to fundamentally improve the environment by 2035 through the transformation of its industrial structure and lifestyle.

site_title: Singapore factory output stays strong with 11.1% surge in May
summary: Singapore's factory production surged 11.1% in May, exceeding economists' expectations, with the electronics cluster driving growth. Semiconductors saw a 26.9% increase, while the biomedical sector rebounded with a 17.7% growth. General manufacturing also showed a 5.2% growth, despite a decline in land transport output. This beats April's 9.1% growth and comes ahead of forecasted 9% increase.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams
Singapore's factory production continued to outperform in May, defying expectations that the manufacturing sector will cool.

site_title: Condo in Bidadari to debut soon
summary: Park Colonial, a 99-year leasehold condominium in Singapore's Bidadari enclave, is set to be launched on July 14. Developed by CEL Development, Heeton Holdings, and KSH Holdings, the estate will feature six towers with 805 units, priced at an average of S$1,700 per sq ft, with one-bedders starting at around S$780,000. The project is expected to garner strong interest, despite stiff competition in the area, due to its central location near Woodleigh MRT station and amenities.

site_title: Toronto condo market may hit turbulence
summary: Toronto's condominium market may face turbulence due to new mortgage rules and rising borrowing costs, reducing its appeal. Average condo prices exceed C$560,000, and projects are taking longer to sell, with developers offering incentives to move units. Demand for high-end condos remains active, but generic inventory is slowing sales. Condos, which accounted for 30% of total Toronto sales in May, may join the slump in single-family homes, potentially signaling a broader Canadian housing market correction.

site_title: Skyfy goes the extra mile to scale new tech heights
summary: Singapore-based Skyfy Technology, a fleet management system provider, has experienced significant growth under the leadership of director Joseph Ng. Since being bought in 2015 for S$20,000, the company's turnover has increased to S$3.5 million. Ng's strategy, which includes investing in technology and building strong customer relationships, has helped the company acquire 1,600 customers, including major names like ZTP and NTUC Unity. The company is now expanding into other parts of Southeast Asia, with plans to enter Indonesia and Malaysia within the next six months.

site_title: StarHub confirms loss of Discovery channels
summary: StarHub has confirmed the loss of Discovery channels from its pay-television stable after negotiations failed. The telco will axe the suite of TV channels from Discovery Networks, with the departure taking place in two phases. Despite this, analysts believe the impact on StarHub's bottom line will be minimal due to customer migration towards over-the-top (OTT) media. The company will offer bill rebates and free previews of new channels to affected customers.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Europe will strike back in case of new US tariffs: France
summary: The European Union will retaliate with tariffs if the US imposes a 20% tariff on European car imports, French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire said. The EU previously imposed tariffs on $4.5 billion worth of US goods in response to US tariffs on steel and aluminum exports. Le Maire stated that the EU aims to make US President Donald Trump understand that the policy is unacceptable, particularly if it affects Republican states. The EU's trade dispute highlights the importance of deeper integration in the eurozone, but a deal on a common budget and corporate taxes remains uncertain.

site_title: Reform evaluation, supervision, tech could shape next decade's regulatory agenda: MAS' Menon
summary: MAS managing director Ravi Menon predicts that the next decade's regulatory agenda will focus on evaluating reforms, enhancing supervision, and managing cyber risk. By 2021, regulators will assess the impact of post-2008 reforms, while by 2028, they will establish "culture and conduct supervision" to deter bad apples. Technology will play a key role, with data analytics and behavioral psychology used to gain insights. Cyber risk, distributed ledgers, cloud computing, and artificial intelligence will also be major areas of focus, as regulators strive to balance stability, growth, and innovation.

images.alt_text: Financial regulators could grapple with evaluating reforms, enhancing supervision and cyber risk over the next decade, MAS managing director Ravi Menon said.

site_title: Keppel looks to sell stake in Vietnamese developer
summary: Keppel Land is selling a 30% stake in Vietnamese developer Quoc Loc Phat Joint Stock Company (QLP) for S$41.2 million. The sale is part of Keppel Land's strategy to recycle assets for higher returns. Keppel Corporation expects to recognize a gain of about S$13 million from the divestment, which is expected to be completed by the end of June 2018.

site_title: Tesla-loving Norway wants to be a pioneer in electric planes
summary: Norway, a major market for electric cars, aims to be a pioneer in electric planes. Wideroe, a local airline, plans to launch its first commercial aircraft propelled by electric power within the next 10 years. The company has already tested an electric two-seater plane, demonstrating its feasibility. While environmentalists are skeptical, Wideroe believes that electric planes can reduce emissions, similar to the car industry's transformation. Norway's aviation industry is set to undergo significant changes, with the country aiming to reduce emissions by 40% by 2030.

site_title: The first layoffs from Trump's tariffs are here
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade war has resulted in the first layoffs, with 60 workers at Mid-Continent Nail losing their jobs in Missouri. The company blames the tariffs on steel imports from Mexico and Canada, citing a 25% tariff imposed by Trump. Harley-Davidson also announced plans to move production offshore due to the trade war. Economists warn that more job losses are likely, with the Tax Foundation predicting 48,585 job losses from existing tariffs and potentially over 250,000 if additional tariffs are imposed. The layoffs have become a hot election issue in Missouri.

images.alt_text: The first casualties of US President Donald Trump's trade war are 60 workers at Mid-Continent Nail, America's largest nail manufacturer.

site_title: In St Petersburg, a tall order to manage sleep and football
summary: During the 2018 World Cup in St Petersburg, Russia, players and teams struggled with sleep due to the city's unique "White Nights" where the sun remains above the horizon for 24 hours in June. This disrupted the body's natural 24-hour clock, affecting sleep patterns and athletic performance. Experts advise players to reduce light exposure before bedtime to mitigate the negative effects. Teams have taken measures such as installing thick curtains and bringing in special mattresses to help players sleep, but the issue remains a concern.

site_title: UK lawmakers approve expanding London's Heathrow airport
summary: UK lawmakers have approved plans to build a third runway at London Heathrow airport, with 296 votes in favor. The £14 billion project aims to boost Britain's post-Brexit economy and create up to 114,000 local jobs by 2030. Environmental campaign group Greenpeace UK has vowed to challenge the plan in court, while anti-expansion activists staged a "lie-in" in parliament's lobby. The government claims the project will be funded by the private sector, but concerns over costs and environmental impact persist.

site_title: Europe: Trade war sell-off hits shares hard
summary: European shares dropped 2% on Monday, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index falling to its lowest level in a month, amid growing fears of a global trade war. US President Donald Trump's plans to bar Chinese companies from investing in US tech firms and block more tech exports to Beijing hit Asian stocks overnight, with the tech sector falling 2.7%. Harley-Davidson Inc. forecast $90-100 million in annual losses due to EU retaliatory tariffs. Analysts downgraded earnings expectations for global autos stocks, and investors became more risk-averse, driving some to buy into market weakness.

site_title: Funds still have ample room to cut EM debt: IIF
summary: Global bond funds overseeing $4.8 trillion have about 11% allocated to emerging markets debt, higher than the 9.7% in 2016's global deflation scare. Despite the sell-off pressure in emerging markets, funds still have ample room to cut holdings, with investors pulling $1.7 billion from funds dedicated to emerging-market debt in the week to June 20. Analysts estimate that net purchases of bonds and stocks in April were $40 billion, offsetting withdrawals in Latin America and Eastern Europe.

site_title: Ride-hailing app welcomes Saudi women drivers
summary: Saudi Arabia's ban on female drivers has been lifted, with ride-hailing app Careem welcoming its first female drivers, including Reem Farahat, who said she felt tears of joy after her first ride. Nearly a dozen women, from their 20s to 50s, have signed up to drive, with 70% of Careem's customers in Saudi Arabia being women. Uber also plans to introduce female drivers to its service this autumn, citing the need for a "ripple effect" of change. The move is seen as a step towards greater equality and empowerment for women in Saudi Arabia.

site_title: RH Petrogas gets nod for new 20-year terms for two contracts
summary: RH Petrogas Limited, a Singapore-listed oil and gas company, has received approval from Indonesia to enter into new 20-year terms for two production sharing contracts, one for the Kepala Burung (Basin PSC) and the other for the Salawati Kepala Burung (Island PSC). The company will hold a 70% participating interest, with Pertamina holding the remaining 30%. The new terms are based on the gross split model, replacing the existing cost recovery terms, and include financial commitments of US$61.2 million and US$36.3 million for the Basin and Island blocks, respectively.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Stamford Tyres Corp reported a 36% year-on-year drop in net profit to S$5.19 million for FY18 due to higher costs. Despite a 3.6% rise in total revenue to S$247.86 million, earnings per share fell to 2.2 Singapore cents. SPH Reit's manager secured a S$45 million three-year loan to purchase The Rail Mall. STRACO Corporation's insurance claim for the Singapore Flyer's breakdown was denied due to policy exclusions. China Kunda Tech plans to diversify into furniture manufacturing and consultancy services.

The shares of these companies traded flat or rose on June 13-26, 2018.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Jumbo Group Limited is targeting to open its sixth Singapore Jumbo Seafood outlet in Jewel Changi Airport, expected to generate S$12 million in annual sales by FY20. The company is also expanding in China and Taiwan, with a franchise agreement in Taiwan inked in December 2017. Analysts forecast strong earnings growth for FY19, with RHB predicting a 9.7% net profit growth and CGS-CIMB initiating coverage with an "add" rating.

site_title: How the gig economy can help alleviate Singapore's talent crunch
summary: Singapore's growing talent crunch is being alleviated by the gig economy, where freelancers with sought-after skills can help SMEs and startups. With 10% of the workforce opting for freelance work, these skilled individuals can provide flexibility and autonomy to businesses, addressing their need for specialized skills. By leveraging gig platforms, companies can hire freelancers on a project basis, embracing the "gig mindset" and reaching a wider pool of talent, ultimately future-proofing the workforce and overcoming the talent crunch.

site_title: EU watchdog tells banks to speed up Brexit preparations
summary: The European Union's banking watchdog, the European Banking Authority (EBA), has urged banks to speed up their Brexit preparations, warning that inadequate preparations could lead to financial instability. The EBA has set out a series of tasks for banks to complete, including quantifying exposures to counterparties and explaining how they will continue to swap data between units in Britain and the EU. The watchdog has also warned that banks should not rely on a "public policy miracle" to help them, and that time is running out for preparations to be completed by March 29, 2019, when Britain's withdrawal from the EU is set to take effect.

site_title: Two years from Brexit and EU is on the back foot again
summary: The EU is facing a resurgence of challenges two years after the Brexit referendum, which has exposed divisions across the continent. The EU summit this week will focus on Brexit talks, with little expected progress, and other contentious issues such as asylum and immigration. The EU's political and economic climate has improved since the Brexit vote, but the rise of far-right populists and economic uncertainty are threatening the continent's stability. European leaders are concerned about the growing nationalist sentiment and the impact of Brexit on the EU's future, with some even suggesting that France might vote to leave the EU if given the chance.

site_title: Magnus Energy confirms former MD's lawsuit
summary: Magnus Energy's former managing director, Charles Madhavan, has filed a lawsuit against the company for wrongful termination. Madhavan had raised concerns about loans made by the company, including a S$5 million loan to an Indonesian contractor that had not been collected. He also questioned the company's handling of a luxury car purchased for a key management personnel. Magnus has yet to address these concerns, despite promising to respond to them after reviewing them.

site_title: China online firm files for HK IPO; aims to raise over US$4b, say sources
summary: China's online food delivery-to-ticketing services platform Meituan-Dianping has filed plans for a Hong Kong IPO aiming to raise over $4 billion, making it the second multibillion-dollar tech float in the city this year. The firm, backed by Tencent Holdings, aims for a $60 billion valuation but faces challenges due to its money-losing business model. Meituan-Dianping disclosed a 19 billion yuan loss in 2017 and a revenue rise to 33.9 billion yuan in the same year, with CEO Wang Xing owning 11.4% of the company.

site_title: Dalvey Court up for S$160m en bloc sale
summary: Dalvey Court, a condominium development in Singapore, is up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$160 million. The freehold, nine-storey building has 32 apartment units on 4,103.1 square meters of land and is zoned for residential development. The site may be built up to 1.6 times the site area, with a potential for 93 apartments. The tender closes on August 2, with no development charge payable and no requirement for a traffic impact study.

site_title: Euro slips as trade jitters keep FX markets on edge
summary: The euro slipped against the dollar as investors steered away from risk amid escalating US-China trade tensions. The US President Donald Trump plans to bar Chinese companies from investing in US technology firms and block more tech exports to Beijing. Asian equities retreated, and Treasury yields declined, contributing to the euro's decline. The dollar edged up, further exacerbating the euro's decline.

site_title: ARA to fully acquire Cache's Reit, property managers in deal with CWT
summary: ARA Asset Management has agreed to acquire all remaining shares in Reit manager and property manager of Cache Logistics Trust (Cache), ending its sponsor-Reit relationship with CWT. Analysts believe ARA's regional network may outweigh the benefits of having pipeline acquisition assets from CWT. The acquisition, likely to be completed on July 2, will give ARA full control over Cache, which has grown from S$730 million at its 2010 listing to over S$1.4 billion. ARA's consolidation of interest in Cache is seen as a strategic move to align interests with unitholders in the long term.

site_title: Singapore among region's top cross-border investors in commercial real estate
summary: Singapore was the third-highest source of commercial real-estate capital outflow in the Asia-Pacific in 2018, with a 35% growth in cross-border purchases to US$19.9 billion. This surge is attributed to the strength of the domestic markets in the Asia-Pacific region, which saw a 36% increase in investment activity. Singapore and Hong Kong were among the top sources of cross-border real estate capital, with China also playing a significant role. The Asia-Pacific region surpassed Europe and North America as the top source of cross-border real estate capital, with total investments reaching US$90 billion.

site_title: Iron awe: How Singapore became world's main trading hub in just 10 years
summary: Singapore has emerged as the world's main trading hub for the $100 billion iron ore industry over the past 10 years. The city-state's strategic location and modern infrastructure have enabled it to refuel and reposition large vessels, including Very Large Ore Carriers (VLOCs). The industry's traditional annual price benchmark system, which relied on secretive negotiations between executives, broke down between 2008 and 2010 due to market volatility and imbalances caused by the global financial crisis and China's rapid urbanization. This led to the industry's modernization, solidifying Singapore's position as a key trading hub.

site_title: New York takes aim at Chinese male smokers in ad campaign
summary: New York City has launched a public service ad campaign targeting Chinese male smokers, aiming to reduce the city's high smoking rates among Asian men. Lung cancer deaths among Chinese men in the city have increased 70% in the past 15 years, with 27% of Chinese men smoking. The campaign, which includes a Mandarin-language ad, aims to address cultural norms and language barriers that contribute to high smoking rates among Chinese men. The city's health department is also providing free nicotine patches and gum in Mandarin to help smokers quit.

site_title: Yuan sinks to six-month low on worsening trade outlook
summary: China's currency, the yuan, slid to a six-month low of 6.5414 per US dollar after the central bank eased capital controls and investors braced for a trade dispute with the US. The Shanghai Composite Index declined 0.7% and stocks are heading for a two-year low. Analysts attribute the decline to escalating trade tensions and a credit crunch, with investors seeking the safety of government debt instead. The People's Bank of China cut the required reserve ratio for some banks, further weakening the currency.

site_title: CWT chief buying Good Class Bungalow for S$36m
summary: CWT's group chief executive Loi Pok Yen has purchased a two-storey freehold bungalow in District 10 for S$36 million, or S$1,416 per square foot. The property, which sits on 25,429 sq ft of land, is being sold by the wife of Tee Yih Jia's executive chairman Sam Goi. Agents believe the property is ripe for redevelopment, with estimates suggesting it could cost S$8-9 million to build a new bungalow on the site. This purchase comes amid a surge in Good Class Bungalow (GCB) prices in prime locations, with 17 deals totaling S$419 million since the start of the year.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: A better experience for staff, too
summary: The Grand Park City Hall hotel has implemented a mobile application to enhance the experience for both guests and staff. The app allows for paperless check-in, instant room requests, and control of air-conditioning and lighting. This has reduced staff workload and enabled more meaningful interactions with guests. Additionally, the hotel has introduced an automated uniform control system, streamlining the process for staff. These innovations have resulted in time savings, reduced manual labor, and improved efficiency for both staff and guests.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

Guest services officer Dimitria Hamzah (left) and guest services executive Daniel Peh find that the app not only saves time, but also encourages more meaningful interaction with guests. Linen attendant Peggy Tan (centre) is now able to concentrate on her role as a seamstress, with the automated uniform control system.

site_title: PropNex to list at S$0.65 per share come July 2
summary: PropNex Limited has successfully registered its prospectus for a mainboard listing on July 2 at S$0.65 per share. The IPO consists of 42.5 million shares, with net proceeds expected to raise S$38 million. The company will use the funds for local and regional expansion, real estate brokerage, business services, technology, and working capital. CEO Ismail Gafoor addressed concerns over the transfer of 845 salespersons from DWR and the differences in disclosed revenue and profit figures between the prospectus and previous press statements.

site_title: Vard to build 3 Norwegian coast guard vessels for more than 5b kroner
summary: Vard Holdings has secured a contract to build three coast guard vessels for the Norwegian Defence Materiel Agency for over 5 billion Norwegian kroner (S$839 million). The vessels, designed for worldwide operations in all weather conditions, will be built at Vard Langsten in Norway and Vard Tulcea in Romania, with deliveries scheduled from 2022 to 2024. The contract does not expect to impact Vard's earnings or net tangible assets per share for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Trial preserves hopes for Roche's Tecentriq in lung cancer treatment
summary: Roche's immunotherapy cocktail Tecentriq, combined with chemotherapy, showed positive survival data in a trial for extensive-stage small cell lung cancer. The treatment significantly boosted overall survival and helped patients survive longer without disease progression. The results are considered "clinically meaningful" and could give Roche a "first-mover advantage" in this rare type of lung cancer, potentially adding $1.5 billion to Tecentriq sales. The Swiss company's shares rose 1.1% following the announcement.

site_title: Global oil benchmarks diverge in the aftermath of Opec pact
summary: Global oil benchmarks diverged after Opec's meeting in Vienna, with Brent crude dropping due to Saudi Arabia's pledge to boost output, while West Texas Intermediate (WTI) rose due to shrinking US stockpiles and a North American supply shortage. Despite a promised 1 million-barrel-per-day increase, Goldman Sachs predicts a slim surplus, leaving the market with little spare capacity. WTI prices have nearly halved in under a week, while Brent's premium to WTI has narrowed to $5.81 from over $10 last week.

site_title: China, EU agree to fight protectionism, but latter repeats complaints
summary: China and the EU agreed to oppose protectionism and unilateralism in a bilateral investment agreement, taking aim at US President Donald Trump's tariffs. However, an EU official emphasized the need for China to address market access issues and overcapacity in sectors such as steel and hi-tech. The EU reiterated its concerns about China's business practices, despite the agreement.

site_title: German business morale ebbs as trade fears linger
summary: Business confidence in Germany fell to its lowest in over a year, with the Munich-based Ifo institute's business climate index dropping to 101.8, as trade fears and uncertainty weigh on the economy. The decline is attributed to concerns over a potential trade war with the US, as well as internal divisions within Chancellor Angela Merkel's coalition government. Economists predict the economy will continue to grow, albeit at a slower pace, and warn that a snap election could cause further economic damage.

site_title: Changi Airport handled 5.29m passengers in May, up 5.8% yoy
summary: Changi Airport handled 5.29 million passengers in May, a 5.8% increase from last year, with aircraft movements rising 3.6% to 32,330 landings and takeoffs. Airfreight also saw a 1.8% growth to 180,490 tonnes. Traffic to and from Europe grew 17% due to added capacity, while China led gains among top 10 markets with a 12% increase. This marks a record month for Changi Airport, following a 6% year-on-year growth in 2017.

site_title: Australia failing to protect Great Barrier Reef, say activists
summary: Australia is breaching its commitments to protect the Great Barrier Reef, environmental groups claim. The reef faces mass coral bleaching and coral-eating starfish due to pollution and agricultural runoff. Despite Canberra's pledge to step up protection efforts, activists are calling on the UN to probe the alleged failures. The reef's health has been deteriorating due to land clearing, which is not being adequately addressed.

images.alt_text: Environmental groups have called on the UN to probe alleged failures by Canberra to protect the embattled Great Barrier Reef from the effects of land clearing.

site_title: oBike blames new rules for Singapore exit, but writing already on the wall
summary: oBike, a bike-sharing operator, is shutting down its Singapore operations due to financial difficulties and new regulations. The company cited compliance with proposed regulations as the reason for its exit, but observers believe financial pressures played a significant role. oBike had run up a loss of over S$4 million last year and owed various service providers months of fees. The company's exit is seen as a warning for the bike-sharing industry, with experts predicting a consolidation of the sector. Other bike-sharing operators are applying for licenses, but financial pressures and regulatory costs remain a challenge.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, exceeding expectations. In other news, US stocks opened lower amid a fresh tariff salvo on Canada by President Trump. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue below target and operating losses similar to the first half of the year. Meanwhile, Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case, and Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth day ahead of GDP data. Tan Teck Long is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO.

site_title: SISV, SGX launch reporting guide on real estate valuation
summary: The Singapore Institute of Surveyors and Valuers (SISV) and the Singapore Exchange (SGX) have launched a reporting guide on real estate valuation, aimed at providing clarity and completeness of information for investors. The guide, aligned with global standards, sets minimum requirements for valuation reporting and will be adopted for asset classes including office, retail, and hotel properties. It is not a disclosure requirement under SGX's listing rules, but will be included as supplements to existing guidelines. The guide is expected to improve transparency and safeguard investors' interests.

site_title: Grand new approach to hotel stays
summary: Grand Park City Hall, a Singapore hotel, has introduced a new mobile app to enhance the guest experience and tackle existing challenges. The app allows guests to check in, access their room, and control various hotel services. The app also provides efficiency and customer insights for the hotel, including data on traveler profiles and preferences. Developed with funding support from the Singapore Tourism Board, the app has already reaped benefits, such as reducing manual tasks and increasing staff productivity. The hotel aims to continue refining the app to keep pace with consumer behavior and expectations.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: KL, Singapore must comply fully with 1962 water pact terms: MFA
summary: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Malaysia stated that both Malaysia and Singapore must comply fully with the 1962 water agreement, which was guaranteed by both governments in the 1965 Separation Agreement. The agreement's terms were criticized by former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, who said the price of raw water sold to Singapore is "ridiculous." The Ministry emphasized the agreement's importance and urged both countries to fulfill their obligations.

site_title: China extends lead over US as world's most prolific supercomputer maker
summary: China has surpassed the US as the world's leading producer of supercomputers, with 206 of the top 500 fastest machines on the list. Chinese companies, including Lenovo, Inspur, and Sugon, dominate the market, while US companies like Hewlett-Packard Enterprise and Cray rank second and fifth. China's rapid advancement in supercomputing is seen as a key component of its broader technology strategy, with implications for its economic and geopolitical ambitions.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank of Australia spins off wealth, mortgage broking to focus on lending
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia plans to spin off its wealth management and mortgage broking businesses into a separately listed company, CFS Group, to focus on traditional lending. The move is seen as a response to regulatory scrutiny and community expectations following scandals that damaged the bank's reputation. The bank's shares fell 2.7% after the announcement, with analysts suggesting the move may be an attempt to get ahead of potential reforms from the Royal Commission. The spin-off is expected to have a market value of A$6.5-A$10 billion.

site_title: Bids sought for US$5.5b Thailand to China high-speed rail project
summary: Thailand is seeking bids for a US$5.5 billion high-speed rail project to China, with the bidder building the first half of the network in Thailand. The project, part of a wider train network to China, aims to generate economic growth and employment opportunities. Detailed designs are expected this month from China, with the bidding process expected to start in Q4. Construction on a small portion of the network began in December, and Thailand is in talks with China for a loan to fund the project.

site_title: Global economy, corporate earnings expected to continue growing in 2019: UBS
summary: Global economy and corporate earnings are expected to continue growing in 2019, according to UBS. The firm is overweight in China and Singapore, but underweight in Malaysia and Taiwan. Despite trade tensions and geopolitical risks, UBS expects exports to grow 14% year-over-year, and overall growth to spread to domestic demand. The Federal Reserve is likely to hike interest rates quarterly, but Asian policy rates will rise within a manageable range. UBS forecasts strong earnings growth in the US, driven by a changing regulatory environment and tax reforms, but warns of volatility due to trade negotiations and the US mid-term elections.

site_title: China Kunda proposes diversifying into furniture manufacturing and consulting
summary: China Kunda Technology Holdings proposes diversifying into furniture manufacturing and consulting, aiming to complement its main business and enhance shareholder value. The company believes a healthy demand for furniture products in China, driven by rural urbanization and digital commerce, will support its growth prospects. China Kunda will hold an extraordinary general meeting to obtain shareholders' approval for the proposed diversification, which is substantially different from its existing business and may change its risk profile.

site_title: India's Jet Airways says to buy additional 75 Boeing 737 Max jets
summary: Jet Airways agrees to purchase 75 Boeing 737 Max jets, expanding its fleet to meet India's growing domestic passenger demand. This deal brings the airline's total 737 Max orders to 225 aircraft, valued at up to $9.7 billion. The Indian aviation market is expected to see significant growth, with Boeing forecasting up to 2,100 aircraft orders worth $290 billion over the next 20 years.

site_title: US to curb China investments, citing risks
summary: The US Treasury Department plans to use an emergency law to limit Chinese investments in sensitive US industries, citing national security risks. The move, which could be irreversible, would target investments in new-energy vehicles, robotics, and aerospace, and would be administered through a special inter-agency panel. The plan is part of the Trump administration's efforts to address growing concerns about Chinese economic aggression and intellectual property theft. The move could lead to a further escalation of the trade war between the US and China.

site_title: Musk-backed bot conquers e-gamer teams in AI breakthrough
summary: OpenAI, backed by billionaire Elon Musk, has developed software capable of beating teams of five skilled human players in the video game Dota 2, a milestone in computer science. This achievement demonstrates the ability to master complex games that mimic real-world uncertainties and complexity. The breakthrough puts OpenAI ahead of other AI researchers in developing software that can learn and adapt to human-like levels in complex video games, a crucial step towards advancing AI capabilities.

site_title: It's possible to stamp out ad fraud if all quarters of industry pitch in
summary: Ad fraud in digital advertising costs marketers up to $7.2 billion annually, with an estimated three billion smartphone users globally creating opportunities for fraudsters. To combat this, advertisers and industry players must work together to develop robust, multi-tiered anti-fraud solutions. Key measures include having control over ad placements, conducting audits of campaign results, and aligning objectives with concrete business metrics. Third-party tracking companies and ad networks are also building their own anti-fraud systems, and monitoring user activity data can help uncover fraudulent activity. Eradicating ad fraud will require industry-wide vigilance and cooperation.

site_title: India and China cosy up as Trump threatens trade war
summary: India and China are strengthening their trade ties as a response to US President Donald Trump's threats of tariffs. Following the US's imposition of tariffs on steel and aluminum, India retaliated with tariffs on US products worth $235 million. China also warned the US of countermeasures if its imports were targeted. The two countries aim to increase bilateral trade to $100 billion by 2020, with China seeking to import non-Basmati rice and Indian sugar to address the trade deficit. As India is also in Trump's crosshairs, China views India as an ally and "insurance policy" in case of a full-blown trade war with the US.

site_title: Noble ups stake in ASX-listed East Energy Resources in satisfaction of debt
summary: Noble Group has acquired an additional 52.5% shareholding interest in ASX-listed East Energy Resources (EER) in satisfaction of a $28 million debt owed by EER to Noble. This deal increases Noble's stake in EER to 93.4% and effectively makes EER a subsidiary of Noble. The consideration paid for the transaction was negligible, as the book value and net tangible asset value attributed to the additional shares were also negligible. The acquisition was made following a debt impairment of $28 million since the third quarter of last year.

site_title: Han Solo's Jedi blaster of 1983 is sold for US$550,000 at auction
summary: Han Solo's Jedi blaster prop from the 1983 film "Return of the Jedi" was sold at auction for US$550,000 to Ripley's Believe it or Not!. The prop, a BlasTech DL-44, was made by US art director James L. Schoppe and was one of the best-known weapons in the Star Wars universe. The sale price exceeded the pre-sale estimate of between US$300,000 and US$500,000.

site_title: SPH Reit takes S$45m loan to partially finance The Rail Mall purchase
summary: SPH Reit has taken out a S$45 million three-year loan to partially finance the purchase of The Rail Mall for S$63.24 million. The mall, consisting of 43 single-storey shop units, was initially announced for S$63.24 million. The loan will help reduce the initial purchase price.

site_title: US, a nation of immigrants, turns on them
summary: The US, under President Donald Trump, has shifted its stance on immigration, moving away from democratic values and human rights. Trump's anti-immigration policies, including separating children from parents at the southern border, have sparked a national outcry. The administration's zero-tolerance policy led to the detention of over 2,300 children, with reports of them being kept in makeshift facilities. This has fueled a global migration crisis, contributing to a rise in far-right nationalism in Europe. The policy remains in force, setting the stage for prolonged battles over immigration and asylum requests.

site_title: Keppel looks to offload stake in Vietnamese developer
summary: Keppel Land is selling a 30% stake in Vietnamese developer Quoc Loc Phat Joint Stock Company (QLP) for S$41.2 million. The sale, part of Keppel Land's strategy to recycle assets, is expected to be completed by June 2018. Keppel Corporation will recognize a gain of about S$13 million from the divestment. This follows Keppel Land's acquisition of a 45% stake in QLP in 2016.

site_title: The 3 minutes that everyone in Japan is talking about
summary: A Japanese worker was docked half a day's pay for leaving his desk three minutes before his official lunch break, sparking widespread outrage on social media. Senior officials at the city waterworks department in Kobe apologized for the worker's misconduct, stating it was "deeply regrettable." The incident has drawn attention to Japan's strict work culture and the consequences of minor infractions. The worker's punishment has been widely criticized, with many calling for a more lenient approach to workplace discipline.

site_title: US launching an all-out trade war: Case of status anxiety?
summary: The US is launching a trade war against China, imposing tariffs on $50 billion in Chinese imports and China retaliating with similar measures. The US aims to address trade deficits, intellectual property theft, and China's industrial policy, known as Made in China 2025. However, experts suggest that the real target is China's industrial policy, which includes investments in strategic sectors such as 5G networks and advanced manufacturing. Economists estimate that the tariff measures could trim China's economic growth by 0.3 percentage point and US output by 0.2 of a percentage point. The trade war is seen as a case of status anxiety, with the US fearing a loss of technological superiority to China.

site_title: Thailand signals election could be delayed until May
summary: Thailand's deputy prime minister has announced that the country's general election, previously set for February, may be delayed until May 5, 2019. This marks another push back from the military, which has been in power since a 2014 coup. The delay comes amid ongoing efforts to reform the country's politics and pave the way for a democratic transition. The military has repeatedly promised to hold a general election, but has struggled to meet its own timelines. The new date has sparked concerns about the country's democratic progress.

site_title: EU in agreement with Amazon, eBay to tackle dangerous product listings
summary: The European Commission has signed an agreement with Amazon, eBay, AliExpress, and Rakuten-France to combat the listing of dangerous products on Europe's online shopping sites. The companies agreed to remove listings within two days and respond to customer notifications within five days. The deal aims to increase consumer safety, following a 20% rise in online sales in Europe in 2016. The companies will also train sellers to comply with EU safety law and utilize the EU's Rapid Alert System to monitor and prevent unsafe product listings.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as trade fears weigh
summary: Wall Street opened lower on Monday due to ongoing trade tensions between the US and its trading partners, with Chinese investments in US technology firms being curbed. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.48%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.43%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.80%. The US-China trade dispute continues to weigh on markets, despite recent US stock records.

site_title: STI falls 0.8% as trade war fears linger
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 0.8% due to lingering trade war fears. US President Donald Trump's protectionist approach, including tariffs and trade agreements, has affected major markets. The US leader plans to bar Chinese companies from investing in US technology firms and block additional technology exports to China. This led to a decline in stocks, with three banks shedding between 9 cents and 23 cents.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: 5.5-magnitude quake hits southern Greece
summary: A 5.5-magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of southern Greece on Monday, approximately 70 km southwest of the city of Kalamata. The epicenter was in the sea off the town of Pylos. There were no immediate reports of damage or casualties, with the Mayor of Pylos describing the situation as "absolute calm." This is the second significant earthquake to hit Greece in recent years, following a 6.7-magnitude quake in July that killed two people on the island of Kos.

site_title: Straco Corporation's insurance claim for Singapore Flyer breakdown denied
summary: Straco Corporation's insurance claim for the Singapore Flyer breakdown has been denied due to policy exclusions. The observation wheel was suspended from January 25 to April 1 for a technical issue. The insurance policy excludes claims for "gradually developing flaws" and damages due to third parties or law enforcement. Straco Leisure had taken out a property damage and business interruption insurance policy, but the denial means they will not be reimbursed for repair costs or lost profits.

site_title: Grandmaster in a flash: Indian prodigy chess champ at 12
summary: A 12-year-old Indian boy, Rameshbabu Praggnanandhaa, has become the world's second youngest chess grandmaster, achieving the feat at an event in northern Italy. He surpassed the current record holder, Sergey Karjakin, who was 12 years and seven months old when he made the grade in 2002. Praggnanandhaa, who practices six hours a day, has been playing chess since he was six and was awarded 400,000 rupees by the Indian government for training.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 16.05 points to 1,678.10. Volume was 2 billion lots worth RM2 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 520 to 298. This marks a decline from previous sessions.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific, Tong Eng ink agreement to sell 117 Clarence Street for A$153 million
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings and Tong Eng Group have agreed to sell 117 Clarence Street in Sydney for A$153 million, following their acquisition of the 14-storey freehold commercial building for A$81 million in 2016. The sale is expected to contribute positively to Roxy-Pacific's financial performance. The two companies have divested other commercial investments in Sydney, including 59 Goulburn Street, and plan to recycle the capital into other yield-accretive investments to enhance shareholder value.

site_title: Bids sought for US$5.5b Thailand to China high-speed rail
summary: Thailand is seeking bids for a US$5.5 billion high-speed rail project to China, with the first half of the 253-kilometer route to be built in Thailand. The project, part of a larger network, is expected to start in the fourth quarter after the Transport Ministry approves the designs and procures a contractor. The project is part of Thailand's infrastructure plans, driven by its military government, which aims to generate employment opportunities. Loan negotiations with China are underway, and a contract for rolling stock worth 8 billion baht is also being discussed.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies should be regulated like securities, says BIS research head
summary: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) research head, Hyun Song Shin, has stated that cryptocurrencies should be regulated like securities, considering them as stocks and bonds. This stance aligns with a growing consensus among global regulators seeking to establish a clear definition for these new financial instruments.

site_title: Will MyRepublic's multi-play telco strategy give it the edge?
summary: MyRepublic, a 7-year-old fibre broadband player, has launched its mobile offerings with plans starting at S$35, higher than the lowest SIM-only monthly fees of its competitors. The company's strategy, led by CEO Malcolm Rodrigues, aims to compete on traditional telco ground, bucking industry predictions that MVNOs would slash prices. MyRepublic plans to capture a large enough market share within the MVNO segment, leveraging its broadband business and established customer base to outpace its MVNO rival Circles.Life.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Europe: Stock markets slide at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets dropped 0.7% on Monday, amid concerns over the global trade war and US President Donald Trump's threats to impose tariffs on European cars and curb Chinese investments. London's FTSE 100 index fell to 7,629.01 points, while the Paris CAC 40 declined to 5,350.96 points. Investors shifted to safer assets, such as mining and healthcare, in response to the economic uncertainty.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher as investors shrug off trade woes; won drops
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index ended 0.66 points higher at 2,357.88, despite concerns of a trade spat between the US and China. The Korean won slipped 0.9% to 1,117.2 per US dollar. Posco rose 3% on new leadership expectations, while Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix fell 1.27% and 5.3% respectively. The US dollar has risen 4.66% against the won this year, with the won's high for the year at 1,053.55 per US dollar on April 2.

site_title: Ant Financial's Hong Kong venture launches blockchain-based remittance service
summary: Ant Financial's Hong Kong venture, AlipayHK, has launched a blockchain-based remittance service between Hong Kong and the Philippines. The service allows real-time transfers of cash between individuals in Hong Kong and the Philippines, in a digital wallet service. The launch aims to improve Hong Kong's fintech reputation, which has been criticized for lagging behind mainland China and Singapore. AlipayHK is a collaboration with GCash, a Philippines-based micropayment service, and marks the first blockchain-powered remittance service globally.

site_title: Apple is said to amplify its audio-device strategy in 2019
summary: Apple is set to expand its audio-device strategy in 2019 with new products, including higher-end AirPods with noise-cancellation and water resistance, a new HomePod, and studio-quality over-ear headphones. The earbuds are expected to cost more than the existing $159 pair and may segment the product line like iPhones. Apple is also working on a wireless charging case compatible with the upcoming AirPower charger and has discussed adding biometric sensors to future AirPods. The company's audio push aims to increase revenue and build on its earlier success in the field.

site_title: China will play bigger role in North Korea
summary: US President Donald Trump met with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Singapore, where Kim had orchestrated events to shift from missile tests to diplomacy. However, talks were put on hold after Trump blamed China for changing Kim's attitude, and the US leader informed Kim that their planned meeting was no longer possible. North Korea turned to South Korean President Moon Jae In for help, and later met with Chinese President Xi Jinping to discuss denuclearization. China will play a bigger role in North Korea's future, particularly in facilitating economic sanctions' lifting and providing economic reforms.

site_title: Bombardier, Toronto union reach new agreement, averting strike
summary: Bombardier Inc and Unifor, the union representing over 2,100 Canadian workers, have reached a new labor agreement, averting a potential strike. The agreement includes greater job security for workers assembling the company's strong-selling Global 7500 business jet. The union had sought a three-year contract with increased job security, while Bombardier aimed to grow business aircraft revenues to $8.5 billion in 2020. The deal was reached hours before a strike deadline on Saturday and was ratified by union members on Sunday, ensuring continued operations at Bombardier's Toronto plant.

site_title: Future of Big Oil increasingly shaped by the fate of global gas
summary: Big Oil's fortunes are increasingly tied to natural gas, with major companies like Royal Dutch Shell, BP, and Chevron boosting their gas output. Gas is seen as a cleaner-burning alternative and a complement to renewables, with demand expected to grow 4-7% annually from 2023. A "potential shortage" in the mid-2020s may be overcome by new export projects, and LNG is becoming a safe place for the industry due to its high cash margins. Industry heavyweights are discussing global gas dynamics at the World Gas Conference, with the US's shale-prodded gas clout playing a significant role.

site_title: Amid Arab boycott, Qatar's new friends find rich openings
summary: Qatar, which faced an economic boycott by several Arab countries, has rapidly made new friends and found alternative partners for trade and investment. The boycott, launched a year ago, disrupted Qatar's shipping routes and blocked imports, but the country's massive natural gas wealth and sovereign wealth fund have helped it weather the storm. As the 2022 World Cup approaches, Qatar is pushing ahead with infrastructure projects, including seven new stadiums, which are drawing in building materials from far afield, including Turkey and Oman. The boycott has led to a significant increase in imports from Turkey and Oman, with growth rates of 48.2% and 150% respectively.

site_title: Amazon-Berkshire-JPMorgan health venture takes aim at middlemen
summary: Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway, and JPMorgan's health venture, led by Harvard surgeon Atul Gawande, aims to reduce wasteful spending in the healthcare system by targeting middlemen, administrative costs, high prices, and improper usage. The venture, independent of the three firms, will initially focus on improving care for 1 million individuals with insurance from the companies and later make its innovations available to other companies. Gawande seeks to simplify the system, reduce costs, and potentially disrupt the role of employers in providing health insurance.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's inflation rose 0.4% year-on-year in May, in line with economists' expectations. ARA Asset Management acquired full control of Reit manager and property manager of Cache Logistics Trust, while Dalvey Court owners launched a collective sale with a reserve price of S$160 million. oBike stopped its bike sharing operations in Singapore, and Noble Group increased its stake in East Energy Resources. Vard Holdings won a contract to build three Norwegian coast guard vessels for over S$839 million. Singapore shares closed lower on Monday due to escalating trade war concerns.

site_title: Stamford Tyres' FY18 net profit down 36%
summary: Stamford Tyres Corp reported a 36% year-on-year drop in net profit to S$5.19 million for FY18, driven by higher costs. Total revenue rose 3.6% to S$247.86 million, but earnings per share fell to 2.2 Singapore cents. Total expenditure increased by 4.8% to S$241.27 million, partly due to higher cost of goods sold. The company declared a final dividend of one Singapore cent per share, down from 1.5 cents previously.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Australian shares dip as banks fall on CBA spin-off plans; NZ treads water
