summary: Australian shares declined 0.2% on Monday, weighed down by a 2.3% drop in Commonwealth Bank of Australia due to its plans to spin off its wealth management business. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 6,210.40, despite gains in materials and energy stocks. New Zealand's benchmark index also slipped 0.3% on the day. The negative impact on CBA was the largest drag on the Australian market, with the bank's stock falling to its lowest level in over a year.

site_title: Mnuchin suffers setback in US plan to limit China investments
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's plan to limit China investments has faced a setback, as the Trump administration opted for a more aggressive approach. The plan, which would use the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977 to declare Chinese investments in US companies a threat to national security, was pushed by President Trump and other Cabinet members. The move could rattle the US stock market and trigger reprisals against US firms operating in China, and is seen as part of the Trump administration's escalating trade war with Beijing.

site_title: StarHub TV axes channels from Discovery, garners 7 new channels
summary: StarHub to discontinue Discovery Networks channels, including Discovery Channel, TLC, and Animal Planet, due to unsuccessful negotiations. The 7 channels will be axed in two phases on June 30 and August 31. StarHub aims to meet customer entertainment needs while minimizing inconvenience.

site_title: Valuation reporting guide for listed companies, Reits and IPOs launched
summary: The Singapore Institute of Surveyors and Valuers (SISV) has launched a valuation reporting guide for listed companies, Reits, and IPOs, in collaboration with the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The guide aims to provide clarity and completeness of information for investors, and is seen as crucial for quality disclosures on matters such as valuations. This move follows a joint review of valuation practices and reporting by real estate valuers engaged by listed issuers. The guide is expected to meet investors' needs and enhance transparency in the market.

site_title: Singapore stocks close lower, rattled by escalating trade war jitters
summary: Singapore shares closed lower on Monday, down 0.81% or 26.56 points, as escalating trade war concerns continued to affect investors. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,260.84. Commodities group Noble was a notable exception, rising 24% after securing a binding commitment for US$100 million of trade finance facilities. Losers outpaced gainers 270 to 139, with about 1.9 billion securities changing hands.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: En bloc sale: Dalvey Court launches tender with S$160m reserve price
summary: The owners of Dalvey Court, a nine-storey condominium in Singapore, have launched a collective sale tender with a reserve price of S$160 million. The freehold building comprises 32 units on 4,103.1 square meters of land, zoned for residential use with a plot ratio of 1.6 times the site area. The site is located in the prestigious District 10 region, close to the Singapore Botanic Gardens and high-profile schools. The tender closes on August 2, with no development charge or traffic impact study required.

site_title: Taiwan's Tsai urges world to stand up to China
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-Wen has urged the international community to stand up to China and "constrain" its expansionist aims, citing the island as a global threat to democracy. Tsai made the comments amid increased pressure from Beijing, which views Taiwan as part of its territory to be reunified by force if necessary. Tsai called for unity with Taiwan and other countries to protect liberal values, and said she would meet with China's President Xi Jinping on an equal footing, despite Beijing's insistence that Taiwan acknowledge "one China."

images.alt_text: Her comments in an exclusive interview with AFP on Monday come as Taiwan faces what Ms Tsai called "immense pressure" from Beijing.

site_title: Vard clinches contract to build 3 Norwegian coast guard vessels for over 5b kroner
summary: Vard Holdings has secured a contract to build three Norwegian coast guard vessels worth over 5 billion Norwegian kroner (S$839 million) for the Norwegian Defence Materiel Agency. The vessels, scheduled for delivery in 2022-2024, will feature ice-strengthened hulls and be designed for worldwide operations in various weather conditions. The contract was awarded after a review of offers from three competing yards, with Vard Langsten being selected for its ability to meet the defined requirements for the solution and the Navy and Coast Guard's needs.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: British lawmakers set to vote on Heathrow Airport runway plan
summary: British lawmakers will vote on a plan to build a new runway at Heathrow Airport, potentially paving the way for the airport's expansion after decades of delays. The 14 billion pound plan, which faces opposition from local communities and environmentalists, aims to enable new trade links and secure economic growth. Although the government is expected to win the vote, the result could be close, with some lawmakers opposing the extra noise and air pollution it will bring to London.

site_title: China, Europe warn trade war could trigger global recession
summary: China and the European Union have warned that a trade war between the US and either of them could trigger a global recession. China's Vice Premier Liu He and the EU's Vice President Jyrki Katainen agreed to oppose trade protectionism and defend the multilateral trading system, following talks in Beijing. The US has imposed tariffs on billions of dollars' worth of Chinese and European imports, prompting retaliatory measures and further escalation of tensions. Economists warn that a prolonged trade war could cut China's economic growth by half a percentage point and impact the US economy.

site_title: Opec's newest member may boost output as much as 65% this year
summary: The Republic of Congo, Opec's newest member, plans to increase oil production by 65% this year with the start of two new projects, Moho North and Banga Kayo. The country, which currently produces 291,000 barrels per day, aims to boost output to 479,000 barrels per day. This increase is expected to help the country deal with an economic crisis caused by a drop in oil prices, with the economy forecast to grow 0.7% in 2018. The new projects are dominated by Total and Eni, with commercial production expected to start this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by a surge in oil prices following Opec's agreement to increase output. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.20% to 29,397.17, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks down on fears over trade war, strong yen
summary: Tokyo stocks declined on June 25, 2018, due to fears over a US-China trade war and a strong yen. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.79% to close at 22,338.15, while the Topix index dropped 0.95% to 1,728.27. The market concerns were fueled by US President Donald Trump's recent threats against China, leading to a decline in investor sentiment.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon trading at 3,269.78, down 0.5% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Monday afternoon at 3,269.78, down 0.5% from the previous day's close. The Straits Times Index lost 17.62 points, with 194 losers outnumbering 122 gainers. Trading volume reached 1.21 billion shares worth S$524.5 million.

site_title: China extends lead as most prolific supercomputer maker
summary: China has extended its lead as the world's most prolific supercomputer maker, producing 206 of the top 500 fastest machines, while the US produced 124. The US had dominated the market for years but China pulled even two years ago and now surpassed it. China's advancements in supercomputing are seen as a key part of its "ambitious whole-of-government plan" to achieve technological dominance. The country's progress has also sparked concerns in the US about its grand plan and potential economic and geopolitical implications.

site_title: China to protect quarter of land from development by 2020
summary: China aims to protect a quarter of its land from development by 2020 and increase forest coverage to over 23% of its total landmass under the "ecological red line" scheme. The country's cabinet announced the plan as part of efforts to combat pollution. China has also set a goal to keep at least 25% of its land protected by the end of the decade.

site_title: Xiaomi super-syndicate lifts noise-to-signal ratio
summary: Xiaomi's initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong could raise over $6 billion, but the presence of a large syndicate of 34 banks may make it difficult for investors to distinguish between genuine demand and hype. The syndicate, led by Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and CLSA, has raised concerns about the lack of independent voices and the potential for banks to influence the market. The IPO's valuation range of $55 billion to $70 billion is below previous estimates, and the deal's terms have been criticized for creating a conflict of interest between banks and investors.

site_title: With driving ban lifted, ride-hailing app welcomes Saudi women drivers
summary: Saudi Arabia has lifted its ban on female drivers, allowing women to drive for ride-hailing apps like Careem and Uber. Nearly a dozen Careem drivers, including Reem Farahat, were ready to pick up riders on the first day of the ban's lifting. Women make up 70-80% of Careem's customers in Saudi Arabia, and the company plans to hire more female drivers. The move is seen as a step towards greater equality and women's empowerment in the conservative kingdom.

site_title: Google tackles Facebook in India with hyper-local social network
summary: Google has launched a hyper-local social network called Neighbourly in India, aiming to tackle Facebook's dominance in the country. The app allows users to share local expertise and crucial information with others in their vicinity, with features such as crowd-sourced recommendations and voice-activated searches. Neighbourly is designed to be a safer alternative to group chats, with users' profiles and personal information kept private. The app has the potential to generate significant revenue through targeted local ads and could help Google become a major player in the Indian social media market.

site_title: PBOC reserve cut not aimed at helping housing market, BOC says
summary: China's central bank released 700 billion yuan (S$147.4 billion) from reserve cuts, with no direct aim to aid the housing market. Instead, the funds will be channeled to debt-to-equity swaps (500 billion yuan) and smaller banks to lend to small firms (200 billion yuan). To prevent the money from flowing into the overheating property market, the funds will be closely monitored, with every transaction documented and reviewed quarterly. This move aims to promote financial stability and control the rapid expansion of loans to property developers and households.

site_title: China takes gas crown as clean-air push powers it past Japan
summary: China has surpassed Japan to become the world's largest buyer of natural gas, with imports totaling 34.9 million tons for the first five months of the year. The nation's drive for cleaner skies, fueled by President Xi Jinping's pollution-cutting goals, has led to a rapid increase in natural gas use at the expense of dirtier fuels like oil and coal. China's soaring demand has boosted the global liquefied natural gas market, with the country on track to become the world's biggest LNG importer by 2021.

site_title: Tantalum miner threatens expansion at Australia's biggest lithium mine
summary: A private-equity backed company, Global Advanced Metals (GAM), is set to go to trial in Australia's Western Supreme Court to determine if an expansion at the Greenbushes lithium mine would unfairly impact its tantalum mineral rights. GAM, which processes tantalum as a by-product of lithium production, claims that the mine's expansion by Talison Lithium, a joint venture between Tianqi Lithium and Albemarle Corp, would waste tantalum resources. The trial dates are set for October 16-31.

images.alt_text: A partner in one of the world's largest lithium mines said on Monday trial dates have been set to determine whether expansion at the Western Australian mine, in which China's Tianqi Lithium holds a stake, would unfairly impact its minerals rights.

site_title: Trade fears sap German business morale
summary: German business confidence decreased in June, falling to 101.8 points, according to the Ifo economic institute. Fears of a damaging transatlantic trade war and domestic political infighting are affecting the economy. The survey showed business leaders are less satisfied with their current situation and have mixed expectations for the future. The Ifo institute has drastically slashed its German growth forecast for 2018 from 2.6% to 1.8%. Analysts attribute the decline to escalating trade tensions, higher oil prices, and domestic politics, particularly the EU's tariffs on US products and the US's threat of tariffs on car imports.

site_title: Brent oil prices drop by 2% as traders expect output rise after Opec deal
summary: Brent oil prices dropped 2% to $73.90 per barrel, following an expected output increase from Opec and its partners, including Russia. The agreement, announced on Friday, aims to reverse the market's deficit and prop up prices. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 0.3% to $68.36 per barrel. Analysts expect the deal to take the market from a deficit to a surplus, with Barclays predicting a 0.2 million barrels per day surplus in the second half of 2018.

site_title: oBike to stop bike sharing in Singapore due to new regulations, viability issues
summary: oBike, a Singapore-based dock-less bicycle sharing company, has shut down its operations in the country due to new regulations imposed by the Land Transport Authority. The company cited the regulations as making the business model "not viable" and would cause further losses. This move follows a similar shutdown of another bike-sharing company in Singapore, and oBike's decision to not apply for a license to continue operating.

images.alt_text: Bicycle sharing company oBike is ceasing operations in Singapore from June 25, citing difficulties in complying with regulations, the company announced on a Facebook post on Monday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.91 points to 1,705.06, with 131 gainers outpacing 53 losers. Volume was 26.35 million lots worth RM45.8 million.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start week with losses
summary: Hong Kong shares began the week with losses, falling 1.29% due to concerns over a trade war, despite the People's Bank of China easing measures. The Hang Seng Index closed at 28,961.39, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined by 1.05% and 0.63%, respectively. The losses overshadowed a brief rally in energy firms and followed a positive session in Singapore, where stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index slipped 1.29 per cent, or 377.31 points, to close at 28,961.39.

site_title: Indonesia posts US$1.52b trade deficit in May on higher oil prices
summary: Indonesia posted a trade deficit of US$1.52 billion in May, narrower than expected, due to higher oil prices. Imports grew 28.12% from a year earlier, exceeding analyst expectations of 13.88%. This follows a revised April deficit of US$1.63 billion, the largest in four years. The country's trade deficit narrowed from US$1.64 billion in May 2017.

site_title: Singapore's inflation up in May, in line with economists' expectations
summary: Singapore's inflation rate rose 0.4% year-on-year in May, in line with economists' expectations, according to the Department of Statistics. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and private road transport, increased 1.5% year-on-year, faster than the previous month. The increases were largely due to faster price increases across major CPI categories, except food. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry attributed the rise to the acceleration of price increases.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Australia failing to protect Great Barrier Reef: activists
summary: Australian environmental groups claim the federal government is failing to protect the Great Barrier Reef from land clearing, despite promises to step up efforts. The groups, including the Wilderness Society and WWF-Australia, called for a UN investigation into alleged failures to stop bulldozing of large swaths of land in reef catchments. The Australian Conservation Foundation says 36,600 hectares of old-growth forest are set to be cut down, contradicting Canberra's conservation plans. Environment Minister Josh Frydenberg disputes the allegations, citing a A$2 billion "Reef 2050" plan and additional funding for reef protection.

site_title: Singapore merchants can now collect their Nets terminals one day after applying online
summary: Singapore merchants can now collect their Nets terminals one day after submitting their online applications, reducing the processing time from two weeks to one working day. This initiative aims to enhance service for merchants, increase productivity, and speed up the onboarding process. Nets has also equipped its sales team with tablets to streamline the process for non-retail merchants. The company supports various payment methods, including chip and PIN transactions, credit card payments, and contactless payments. The move is part of Nets' digital transformation journey to improve its services and speed to market.

site_title: European countries to formalise EU defence force plan
summary: Nine European countries, including France, Germany, Britain, and others, will formalize a plan to create a European military intervention force on Monday. The force, known as the European Intervention Initiative, aims to rapidly deploy to deal with crises. The initiative is separate from other EU defense cooperation, allowing Britain to participate after Brexit. The plan involves joint planning work on crisis scenarios, including natural disasters and intervention in crises, and is seen as a way for Paris to maintain strong defense ties with the bloc.

site_title: On NY's rooftops, old-style wooden water tanks hang tough
summary: New York's iconic wooden water tanks, a relic of the past, continue to serve the city's skyscrapers. As buildings exceed six stories, water must be pumped to the roof and stored in a tank due to the city's weak water pressure. These tanks, made of plain old wood, have become a staple of the city's skyline and a testament to the ingenuity of its infrastructure. Despite the rise of technology, these traditional water tanks remain a popular choice for buildings, ensuring a reliable supply of water to the city's residents.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall as trade war fears weigh on sentiment
summary: Asian markets fell on June 25, 2018, due to ongoing trade war fears, with Donald Trump threatening fresh tariffs on European cars and considering curbs on Chinese investment. Despite a modest increase in oil output by Opec and Russia, concerns about a global trade war's potential damage to the world economy weighed on investors. The uncertainty overshadowed China's easing measures, including a reduction in reserve requirements for banks, set to free up over $100 billion for lenders.

site_title: Mattis visits China amid Korea talks, strategic tensions
summary: US Secretary of Defence James Mattis is visiting China amid rising tensions between the two countries, with a focus on nuclear talks with North Korea. Mattis aims to assess China's strategic ambitions and confirm its commitment to pressuring Pyongyang to give up its nuclear weapons. The visit comes amid bilateral strains, including China's military buildup in the South China Sea, which has sparked security concerns in Southeast Asia. Mattis will also meet with South Korean and Japanese officials to reassure them of the US regional defense commitment.

site_title: Study preserves hopes for Roche's Tecentriq in lung cancer
summary: Swiss drugmaker Roche's immunotherapy cocktail Tecentriq, combined with chemotherapy, showed positive survival data in a trial for extensive-stage small cell lung cancer. The study, known as IMpower 133, found Tecentriq significantly boosted overall survival compared to chemotherapy alone. Roche's shares rose 1.1% following the announcement. The company hopes to prove Tecentriq's merits in rare types of lung cancer, potentially gaining a "first mover advantage" in the market and increasing sales by $1.5 billion. This is Roche's first positive Phase III survival result for an immunotherapy-based combination in initial lung cancer treatment.

site_title: BOJ should continue powerful easing, guard against side effects: policymakers
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers advise the central bank to continue its powerful monetary easing while monitoring potential side effects. Despite five years of stimulus, inflation remains below the 2% target. Policymakers emphasized the need to improve communication on the central bank's commitment to meet the price stability goal. Some members suggested examining the potential side effects of prolonged easy policy, including unrealized losses on securities and risks of impairment losses at branches with low profitability. The BOJ will continue its stimulus, but with a focus on sustainability and communication.

site_title: Noble Group ups stake in ASX-listed East Energy Resources in satisfaction of debt
summary: Noble Group has acquired an additional 52.5% stake in ASX-listed East Energy Resources, increasing its stake to 93.4%. The acquisition was made in satisfaction of a $28 million debt owed to Noble by EER, effectively making the consideration paid nil. EER will cease to be an associated company of Noble and become its subsidiary. The deal was finalized as East Energy Resources' market cap stands at $1.78 million. Shares in Noble rose 25.5% following the announcement.

site_title: Han Solo's Jedi blaster gun sells for US$550,000 at auction
summary: Han Solo's Jedi blaster gun from the 1983 movie "The Return Of The Jedi" sold for US$550,000 at an auction to Ripley's Believe it or Not!. The prop, a BlasTech DL-44, was made for the film by US art director James L Schoppe and had a pre-sale estimate price of between US$300,000 and US$500,000. This sale follows other notable Star Wars memorabilia, including Luke Skywalker's original lightsaber prop selling for US$450,000 last year.

site_title: Flash payments means credit risks are growing for Norway's banks
summary: Norway's central bank is increasing efforts to improve the country's banking infrastructure due to the growing use of instant payments, which is driving up credit risk at banks. The problem lies in that customers receive their money before it's actually transferred to their banks, leading to increased credit risk. Regulators are looking to establish "guardrails" to mitigate this issue.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday, STI down 0.3% to 3,278.55
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Monday, retreating 8.85 points, or 0.3%, to 3,278.55. Losers outnumbered gainers 70 to 55, with Ezion rising 1.1% and Genting Singapore falling 1.6%. The release of the Singapore consumer price index (CPI) data on Monday was expected to influence market sentiment. Globally, stocks were muted, with Asia's markets largely unchanged or down, amid ongoing trade tensions and a loosening of policy in China.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp Industries, Citic Envirotech
summary: Sembcorp Industries won a 50-megawatt solar project in Singapore, becoming a major solar player, while Citic Envirotech secured a 2.5 billion yuan ecological restoration contract in China's Sichuan province.

site_title: VistaJet leverages technology for added lift
summary: VistaJet, a private jet service provider, is leveraging technology to enhance the travel experience for its premium passengers. The company invests millions in technology annually, offering features such as flight alerts and personalized meal options through its app. VistaJet has seen significant growth, with a 22% rise in flight revenue and 28% increase in Ebitda last year, and has attracted over $2.5 billion in valuation. The company is targeting a specific segment of customers with a new program and has hundreds of members who prepay for 50 hours of flight time per year.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: ARA acquires full control of Reit manager and property manager of Cache Logistics Trust
summary: ARA Asset Management has acquired full control of the Reit manager and property manager of Cache Logistics Trust through separate share purchase agreements. ARA currently owns 40% of the Reit manager and 60% of the property manager. The acquisitions are made through wholly owned units ARA Cache (Holdings) Pte Ltd and a separate entity, respectively. The move aims to consolidate ARA's control over the trust's operations.

site_title: Trump planning major new curbs on Chinese investment, citing security risks
summary: The US Treasury Department plans to heighten scrutiny of Chinese investments in sensitive US industries under an emergency law, citing security risks. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin will suggest using the International Emergency Economic Powers Act to declare China's investments in technologies like new-energy vehicles and robotics a threat to economic and national security. The move could put the US-China trade war on a potentially irreversible course, with some administration officials concerned it could harm the stock market or hurt US firms operating in China.

site_title: Bitcoin erases loss, bounces back from lowest level in 2018
summary: Bitcoin rebounded from its 2018 low, closing at US$6,181.84, after a 5.2% drop earlier in the day. The volatility was attributed to increased scrutiny by regulators and concerns over its viability. The Bank of International Settlements' economic adviser stated that many cryptocurrencies should be regulated like stocks and bonds. Regulatory pressure in Japan, a crypto-friendly jurisdiction, and security concerns following a hack on South Korean exchanges also contributed to the market's fragility.

site_title: Jasper shareholder to capitalise US$700,000 loan at 0.85 Singapore cent per share into 2.89% stake
summary: Jasper Investments shareholder Phang Chung Wah has taken over a $700,000 loan, capitalizing it into shares at 0.85 Singapore cents per share, resulting in a 2.89% stake in the company. This move increases Phang's stake to 125.9 million shares, following his existing 1.08% interest. The capitalization price matches Jasper's 30-day volume-weighted average price, a 21.4% premium to its last traded price.

site_title: World Cup: Kane fires England to knockout stage
summary: Harry Kane scored a hat-trick as England defeated Panama 6-1 in the World Cup, securing a spot in the knockout stage alongside Belgium. Kane's five goals now lead the Golden Boot race, while England's youthful team showed resilience and imagination in the victory. The win sets up a crucial match against Belgium on Thursday, with both teams level on points and goal difference.

images.alt_text: Harry Kane struck a hat-trick as England thrashed Panama 6-1 on Sunday to ease into the World Cup last 16 alongside group rivals Belgium.

site_title: Meituan-Dianping files Hong Kong IPO, said to raise over US$4b
summary: China's Meituan-Dianping, an online food delivery-to-ticketing services platform backed by Tencent Holdings, has filed for a Hong Kong IPO to raise over $4 billion. The firm, valued at around $30 billion last year, aims for a $60 billion valuation with the IPO, but faces competition from food delivery giant Ele.me and relies on a cash-burning business model. Meituan-Dianping reported a 19 billion yuan loss for 2017, but revenue rose to 33.9 billion yuan, and is expected to list in October.

images.alt_text: China's Meituan-Dianping, an online food delivery-to-ticketing services platform, filed for a Hong Kong IPO on Monday, an offering that aims to raise more than US$4 billion, three people with knowledge of the plans said.

site_title: Malaysia Smelting mining its own business
summary: Malaysia Smelting Corp (MSC), the world's third-largest refined tin maker, is converting a lead smelting facility into a tin smelter in Pulau Indah, Malaysia. The state-of-the-art plant aims to cut costs, reduce dust emission, and increase capacity by over 50%. CEO Patrick Yong expects the plant to be test-fired by year-end and operational in 2019's second half. The move is part of MSC's plan to increase its own smelter input to 30% from 95% reliance on customers, aiming to reduce volatility in tin prices and improve profitability.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB probe: Ex-PM Najib's former aide remanded
summary: A Malaysian court has remanded a former aide to ex-PM Najib Razak, Amhari Efendi Nazaruddin, for seven days over 1MDB saga investigations. The aide, 42, was brought in by the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) on June 25. The remand order is related to the 1MDB scandal, in which Najib is accused of misusing billions of dollars in state funds. This move comes as part of ongoing efforts to investigate and prosecute those involved in the scandal.

site_title: The children of Japan's single mothers have become an underclass
summary: Japan's single mothers and their children are facing extreme poverty, with many living below the national median income. According to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, one in seven children in Japan experiences poverty, leading to a lost workforce and a burden on the elderly population. Single mothers often struggle to secure jobs, with working women earning 30% less than men, and many rely on part-time or contract work with limited benefits. The government's efforts to address child poverty have been criticized, with some experts arguing that policies have not been effective in reducing poverty.

site_title: France arrests 10 ultra-right suspects over plot to attack Muslims
summary: France has arrested 10 suspects linked to the radical far-right over an alleged plot to attack Muslims. The arrests were made in operations across France, including Corsica, following the monitoring of intercepted messages and searches for weapons. The suspects had an "ill-defined plan to commit a violent act targeting people of the Muslim faith." This is the latest in a series of jihadist attacks in France, which have resulted in over 240 deaths, including a wave of bombings and shootings in Paris in 2015. The arrests are aimed at preventing further violence.

site_title: Airbus, Boeing eye after-sales market, but there's room for Singapore players
summary: Airbus and Boeing are expanding their presence in the after-sales service market, which is expected to be worth nearly US$8.5 trillion over the next two decades. This shift could pose a challenge to maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) companies in Singapore, but local firms can maintain their edge by partnering with the jetmakers or focusing on niche segments. Analysts suggest that Singapore's robust aerospace ecosystem, skilled labour force, and government support can help the country withstand this competition and reap benefits from the growing demand for services.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: RH Petrogas awarded new 20-year terms for two Indonesian contracts
summary: RH Petrogas Limited, a Singapore-listed oil and gas company, has secured new 20-year contract terms for two Indonesian production sharing contracts. The company, through its subsidiaries, will hold a 70% participating interest in the Kepala Burung and Salawati Kepala Burung projects, with Pertamina holding the remaining 30%. The new terms, based on the gross split model, replace the existing cost recovery regime and include a financial commitment of US$61.2 million and US$36.3 million for firm work programmes. The final award is conditional on agreement of terms and signing.

site_title: Changi Airport handled 5.29m passengers in May, up 5.8% y-o-y
summary: Changi Airport handled 5.29 million passengers in May, a 5.8% increase from last year. Aircraft movements grew 3.6% to 32,330 landings and takeoffs, while airfreight increased 1.8% to 180,490 tonnes. Traffic to Europe grew 17% due to added capacity to Germany, Poland, and Britain. China led gains in Changi's top 10 markets, with a 12% increase in passengers. The airport also saw strong growth in passenger traffic to Australia, India, Japan, and Vietnam.

site_title: US trade issues in spotlight as oil plays second fiddle
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade skirmishes with countries like Mexico and China overshadowed OPEC's announcement to raise oil production, which could impact oil prices. The US is set to announce new measures to restrict Chinese investment, potentially worsening trade relations. This could have a significant impact on Asia economies, including Singapore, which are highly geared towards exports. Investors are advised to consider adding portfolio protection or defensive positioning, while some analysts recommend accumulating fundamentally healthy companies that have been sold down.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index edging up 0.20 points to 22,517.03, despite worries over a US-China trade war. Optimism about the US economy partly offset these concerns, while the broader Topix index fell 0.11%.

site_title: British tourist killed in Cyprus hit-and-run
summary: A 39-year-old British tourist was killed in a hit-and-run incident in Cyprus on Sunday near the resort city of Paphos. The car was later found in the sea, and two suspects, a 32-year-old British man and a woman, were arrested and charged with pre-meditated murder. The incident occurred after the tourists and the suspects got into an argument at a pub earlier in the evening. A second British tourist, who was also hit by the car, is being treated at hospital with a condition described as "out of danger."

site_title: Singapore shares stagnate as investors pivot to US and China
summary: Singapore's stock market has stagnated, with the Straits Times Index falling 3.4% since the year began and closing below the 3,300 mark at 3,287.4 points on June 24, 2018. This mirrors regional market weakness.

site_title: Mahathir revives Singapore water dispute, takes swipe at Trump
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has revived a longstanding water supply dispute with Singapore, criticizing the 1962 agreement as "too costly." Mahathir also took shots at US President Trump, while seeking to renegotiate the deal. The move comes after he announced plans to cancel a multibillion-dollar high-speed rail project with Singapore. Mahathir stated that Malaysia will sit down with Singapore to discuss the issue like "civilised people."

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has revived the muscular foreign policy that characterised his first stint in power, seeking to renegotiate a longstanding water supply agreement with Singapore and taking shots at both the US and China.

site_title: Bitcoin slips to 2018 low as rising scrutiny fuels scepticism
summary: Bitcoin plummeted to a 2018 low of $5,832.68, a 5.1% drop, amid rising scrutiny and regulatory pressure. The decline comes after two South Korean exchanges were hacked, raising concerns about the security of investor holdings. Japan's Financial Services Agency ordered six major crypto trading venues to improve anti-money laundering measures, further fueling skepticism. The market's fragility to regulatory moves was demonstrated, with no recent positive news to counterbalance the pressure.

site_title: Young, local and with global experience? Employers here want you
summary: Singapore is seeing a trend of young, local, and globally experienced professionals returning home to work in the country. Employers value these candidates for their ability to bring a global perspective and knowledge of the local work culture. Recruiters attribute the trend to economic uncertainty in the West and greater opportunities in Asia, with companies seeking to fill talent gaps and attract top talent. These returning professionals may secure more senior roles or have access to perks such as flexible work arrangements, making them attractive to employers.

site_title: Sembcorp clinches solar project from HDB and EDB
summary: Sembcorp Industries' wholly owned unit, Sembcorp Solar, has won a 50-megawatt solar project from the Housing & Development Board and the Singapore Economic Development Board. The project will be built, owned, operated, and maintained across 848 HDB blocks and 27 government sites in Singapore. This deal marks Sembcorp as a major solar player in Singapore, with its combined portfolio extending to 104 megawatts. Construction is set to begin in the third quarter of 2018 and be completed by Q2 2020, aligning with Sembcorp's Climate Change Strategy to double its renewables portfolio by 2022.

site_title: GE nearing deal to sell industrial engines unit to Advent: WSJ
summary: General Electric Co is close to a deal to sell its industrial gas engines business to private equity firm Advent International for $3 billion or more. The sale would help streamline GE's power division, whose profit plummeted 45% last year. The deal, which could be announced on Monday, would divest the Jenbacher and Waukesha engines, a key business unit.

images.alt_text: General Electric Co is close to a deal to sell its industrial gas engines business to private equity firm Advent International for US$3 billion or more, The Wall Street Journal reported on Sunday, citing people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Ikea bets big on India, with first store set to open in July
summary: Ikea, the world's largest furniture retailer, is set to open its first store in India in July with a 37,000 square meter outlet in Hyderabad. The store will feature a 1,000-seater cafeteria, but Swedish meatballs, a popular Ikea item, will not be on the menu. This marks Ikea's entry into the Indian market after years of planning. The store's opening is a significant milestone for the company's expansion into the Asian market.

site_title: Australia's Commonwealth to spin off wealth, mortgage arms
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia announced plans to spin off its wealth management and mortgage-broking arms, CFS Group, which will list on the Australian stock exchange next year. The move aims to unlock value for shareholders and focus on core businesses. The demerged entity will include Colonial First State, Colonial First State Global Asset Management, Count Financial, Financial Wisdom, and Aussie Home Loans businesses, with over A$342 billion in assets under administration. The decision follows a review of the group's businesses and comes amid scrutiny over allegations of misconduct in the sector.

images.alt_text: Commonwealth, Australia's biggest bank, announced plans on Monday to spin off its wealth management and mortgage-broking arms as it looks to streamline operations and focus on core businesses.

site_title: Trade war could give Airbus an edge over Boeing in China
summary: China's trade tensions with the US may give Airbus an advantage over Boeing in the Chinese market, with French Prime Minister Edouard Philippe visiting Beijing to seal a deal for over 180 Airbus A320 jets worth $18 billion. This order would signal to the US that China has alternatives and is not afraid to clash on trade. A trade war could hurt both companies, as Chinese carriers would lose leverage to command discounts from Airbus if Boeing is shut out of the market, and the airlines have limited options for shifting orders between the planemakers.

site_title: HDB closer to solar power target after awarding latest tender
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has awarded a tender for the installation of solar panels in public flats, aiming to reduce carbon emissions and combat climate change. The project, set to begin in the third quarter, will be carried out by a consortium of Sembcorp Solar Singapore and Japan's Kurihara Kogyo. This move is part of Singapore's efforts to increase its use of renewable energy sources.

site_title: China cuts some banks' reserve requirements to boost lending
summary: China's central bank cut reserve requirements for some banks by 50 basis points, releasing $108 billion in liquidity, to boost lending and debt-for-equity swaps. The move was larger than expected and aims to accelerate economic growth and support smaller firms. Economists predict further reserve cuts for the rest of the year due to rising borrowing costs and uncertainty over trade ties with the US. The decision follows weaker-than-expected Chinese growth data and a decline in the yuan's value against the dollar.

site_title: As housing prices soar, New Zealand tackles surge in homelessness
summary: New Zealand is struggling with a surge in homelessness, with Auckland consistently ranking among the 10 least affordable housing markets. The country has the highest homelessness rate among wealthy nations, with one in 100 people experiencing homelessness. The government has pledged to build more public and low-cost housing, create emergency residences, and cut red tape around land use. However, many homeless individuals face difficulties navigating the system, and a lack of affordable housing options continues to exacerbate the problem.

site_title: About S$16.3m spent on Trump-Kim summit: MFA
summary: About S$16.3 million was spent on the historic Trump-Kim summit in Singapore on June 12, 2018, down from an earlier estimate of S$20 million. The majority of the funds, around S$8 million, was allocated to security costs, with media spending totaling around S$4 million. The summit concluded with a joint document outlining commitment to the complete denuclearization of the Korean peninsula, in exchange for Pyongyang dismantling its nuclear program and Washington stopping joint military exercises with Seoul.

site_title: Britain's Prince William in Jordan for historic Middle East tour
summary: Prince William, the Duke of Cambridge, began a historic Middle East tour on Sunday, becoming the first British royal to visit both Israel and the Palestinian territories. The 36-year-old royal was greeted by Crown Prince Hussein bin Abdullah in Jordan and will meet with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian President Mahmud Abbas during his two-day visit. The trip aims to bond with Prince Hussein, a fellow graduate of Britain's Royal Sandhurst Military Academy, and highlights the region's complex history and sensitivities, with the visit coming at a volatile time after US President Donald Trump's recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's capital.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: There is no article to summarize. The provided content appears to be a collection of unrelated news articles from July 10 and 11, 2025.

site_title: Trump's trade war sets bigger booby trap for strong US economy
summary: The escalating US trade war with China and the EU is raising concerns about the impact on the US economy, despite the existing tariffs barely affecting growth. Economists predict a 0.3-0.4 percentage point dent in gross domestic product (GDP) growth, with potential further losses if tensions affect consumer and investor confidence. The US economy, which is performing well, is more resilient due to its domestically driven nature, but the global economy could be affected if the trade tensions escalate, particularly if the euro weakens against the US dollar.

site_title: Vard delays EGM on proposed delisting
summary: Vard Holdings, a Singapore shipbuilder, has delayed an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on its proposed delisting, as the updated delisting circular is still being reviewed by bourse regulators. The company's parent, Fincantieri, has made an exit offer to buy the remaining shares at 25 Singapore cents apiece, holding over 80% stake. The EGM was initially set for April 30 but was postponed due to errors in the circular and disputes over the delisting proposal. Further updates on the review status will be provided by the company.

site_title: MyRepublic CEO lays out game plan
summary: MyRepublic CEO Malcolm Rodrigues outlined the company's game plan, focusing on expanding mobile services and achieving a 5% market share in 3-5 years. The company aims to break even at 3% market share, with projected average revenue per user (ARPU) of S$50 for broadband and S$30 for mobile customers. Rodrigues also stated that MyRepublic will not compete directly with StarHub, instead focusing on being an efficient and cloud-based operator that can service multiple markets. The company plans to list on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 2020 and aims to raise its footprint to 8-10 markets within two years.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Working smart
summary: Singaporean business leaders and experts emphasize the need to radically redesign work processes, buildings, and office spaces to reduce resource usage. Flexible working, hot-desking, and technology-enabled initiatives are seen as key to improving productivity, staff retention, and competitiveness. Experts propose decentralizing offices, using collaborative software, and embracing trust and empowerment to foster a more agile and efficient work environment. The trend towards less office space per person is expected to continue, with great offices and distinctive experiences becoming the norm.

site_title: Thermostats, locks and lights - digital tools of domestic abuse
summary: Digital tools, such as thermostats, locks, and lights, are being used as means of harassment, monitoring, and revenge in domestic abuse cases. Victims reported experiencing unexplained changes in their home's settings, hearing doorbell rings without anyone present, and feeling like they were going crazy. This trend highlights the growing concern of technology being exploited in domestic abuse situations.

site_title: Capitalise on trade war-inspired selloff
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) announced further tapering of its asset purchase program, reducing it to 15 billion euros from October through December 2018, but failed to meet market expectations for a more defined timeline for interest rate hikes. The ECB now expects the interest rate hike cycle to begin between June and September 2019, with a delay in the cycle due to ongoing economic uncertainty. Despite this, the ECB's dovish stance is expected to support the European equity market, which has been affected by trade war tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Citi raises S$110k for charity concert ChildAid
summary: Citi Singapore has raised over S$110,500 for charity through its annual ChildAid concert, supporting disadvantaged children through The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund. The concert, titled The Jumping Jukebox Jive, will take place on November 25-26 at Resorts World Sentosa, featuring young performers singing pop hits from the 1960s to today. This marks one of the largest community campaigns by a private organization, with over 100,000 volunteers serving 1,400 service projects across 450 cities.

site_title: JPMorgan to sell stake in Saudi bank at 24% discount
summary: JPMorgan Chase plans to sell its 7.5% stake in Saudi Investment Bank at a 24% discount for $203 million. The stake, held for over 40 years, will be sold back to the Saudi bank at 13.5 riyals per share. This sale is part of JPMorgan's efforts to consolidate its non-core holdings globally. The deal is expected to be completed by September 30, and analysts see it as advantageous for Saudi Investment Bank, which is poised for international attention after MSCI's EM inclusion decision.

site_title: Vietnam busts 600b dong online betting ring: state media
summary: Vietnamese authorities busted an online football betting ring worth around $35 million, arresting four people in Ho Chi Minh City. The ring, which operated through a website in the Philippines, was accused of taking in over 600 billion dong (equivalent to $35 million) in transactions since 2017. The arrests come as authorities crack down on illegal sports betting, which is prohibited in Vietnam except for state-run lottery and a few casinos. The illegal market remains dominant despite recent efforts to ease restrictions.

site_title: Protectionism threatens 'vintage' global growth, says BIS
summary: The Bank of International Settlements (BIS) warns that rising protectionism could undo a year of "vintage" global growth, citing a decade of extraordinary monetary policy that led the world out of the 2008 financial crisis. The BIS credits free and open trade with laying the foundation for global progress in improving living standards, urging policymakers to safeguard it. An escalation of protectionist measures could trigger a fresh downturn, potentially crippling growth if reciprocal measures undermine confidence in the open multilateral trading system.

site_title: Stocks dip as tariff threats cast pall over global trade
summary: US stocks declined last week due to tariff threats from President Donald Trump, casting a shadow over global trade and the economic cycle. Trump threatened China with tariffs on $200 billion of imports and European tariffs on Harley Davidsons, bourbon, and lobster, prompting a decline in Chinese stocks and US markets. However, China showed little signs of backing down, and analysts warned that China could dump US Treasuries or use its leverage as the biggest US creditor. The yield curve is flattening, indicating increased risk in the short term, and emerging market bourses have already fallen into bear-market territory.

site_title: JLL, Lendlease launch proptech accelerator in Singapore
summary: Global real estate giants JLL and Lendlease have partnered to launch Propell Asia, the first Singapore-based regional property technology (proptech) accelerator. The 10-week program aims to kickstart innovation in the real estate industry, with five startups from the Asia-Pacific region receiving a S$20,000 grant and up to 5% equity in exchange for their participation. However, observers have expressed concerns that the investment sum may be too small, with some experts suggesting that more substantial funding is needed to drive meaningful transformation.

site_title: Australian banks face rural lending reckoning
summary: Australian banks face scrutiny over their lending practices to rural farmers, with many borrowers alleging that banks are not adequately considering the unique challenges faced by farmers. A Royal Commission into financial misconduct is examining agriculture lending practices, citing examples of farmers being forced into receivership due to unrealistic loan demands. Experts argue that farm banking requires different regulations to mitigate the risks of drought, wildfires, and trade disputes. The commission's recommendations could lead to tighter lending rules, with some banks already facing reputational damage and a potential decline in share prices.

site_title: Citic Envirotech wins 2.5b yuan ecological restoration contract
summary: Citic Envirotech, a Singapore-based environmental engineering company, has secured a 2.5 billion yuan (S$515 million) ecological restoration contract in China's Sichuan province. The project involves designing an ecological system for 20 million sq m of land across 36 townships, with residents to be relocated to new areas. The project aims to improve the quality of life for Meigu County residents and is part of China's environmental protection plan. The project will start in Q4 2018 and be completed by Dec 31, 2020.

site_title: Saudis pledge decisive oil supply boost to comfort consumers
summary: Saudi Arabia has pledged to increase its oil supply by around one million barrels a day, promising to keep oil prices under control and ease consumer anxiety. The move is seen as a response to pressure from US President Donald Trump and major oil buyers. Saudi Energy Minister Khalid Al-Falih assured that the kingdom will do whatever is necessary to balance the market, and Russia has also pledged to contribute 200,000 barrels a day. However, some OPEC member countries, including Iran and Venezuela, have expressed concerns that the deal may not be fair and could lead to market share losses.

site_title: In Russia, a safe environment for fans to enjoy the Beautiful Game
summary: A Singaporean writer reflects on his experience attending the 2018 World Cup in Russia, where he found the environment to be safe for fans despite initial concerns over racism and credit card fraud. The writer praises the Russian government's efforts to provide a secure and organized experience for fans, including the use of Fan ID passes and free overnight sleeper trains. However, he notes that the introduction of Video Assistant Referee (VAR) has been inconsistent and disrupted the natural flow of the game. The tournament has seen several top favourites struggle, but the writer speculates that this may be a sign of a shift in the balance of power in football.

site_title: Vard's delisting EGM delayed
summary: Vard Holdings, a shipbuilder, will delay its extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on its proposed delisting due to ongoing review by bourse regulators. The EGM, initially set for June, has been postponed as the company updates its delisting circular. Italy's Fincantieri, which owns over 80% of Vard, has extended its exit offer to buy remaining shares at 25 Singapore cents apiece, initially set for late July. The review is in response to concerns from minority shareholders and regulators regarding the circular's accuracy and governance.

site_title: Keppel Corp commences buybacks after new mandate approved in April
summary: Keppel Corp initiated its share buyback program after receiving approval in April, with a total consideration of S$37.3 million over five sessions. Seven STI stocks conducted buybacks, including Keppel Corp, UOL Equity Investments, UOB-Kay Hian Holdings, Envictus International, Avi Tech Electronics, Hwa Hong, and No Signboard Holdings. Notable director and substantial shareholder transactions included increases in stakes by Wee Ee Chao, Sam Goi Seng Hui, and Andy Luong.

site_title: Uber operator watching The Voice before self-driving crash in Tempe, Arizona
summary: A 318-page report by the Tempe Police Department reveals that the backup "safety driver" in an Uber self-driving vehicle that killed a pedestrian in March was streaming TV show "The Voice" on her phone before the crash. The driver, Rafaela Vasquez, claimed she wasn't using her mobile devices, but records from Hulu show she streamed the show for 42 minutes, ending just before the crash occurred. The report refutes Vasquez's previous statement, suggesting she was using her phone at the time of the incident.

site_title: Oilfield service investors pull back on worries about US crude production
summary: US oilfield service investors are pulling back due to concerns about margins in the shale patch. The Philadelphia SE Oil Service Index fell 8.3% in the past month as some producers warned of potential production slowdowns in the Permian due to pipeline space constraints. Shares of pressure pumpers have declined by 16-21% in the past month, with companies like ProPetro Holding Corp and Liberty Oilfield Services hit hardest. Analysts warn that the sector's recovery may be fragile, with exposed stocks at risk of further decline as operations become more visible.

site_title: Parted at US border by Trump policy, migrants seek their children
summary: US President Donald Trump's policy of separating children from parents at the US-Mexico border has been met with outrage, with many mothers unable to locate their children. Over 2,300 children were separated, and it remains unclear how and when they will be reunited with their parents. Trump has reversed the policy, but the fate of the separated children remains unknown. Congress is scrambling to address the issue, with some lawmakers opposing the separation of families, while others support stricter immigration laws. The Trump administration has drafted plans to house up to 25,000 immigrants, but it is unclear if the children will be housed separately.

site_title: US Fed may adjust tool on bank reserves again: TD Securities
summary: The US Federal Reserve may adjust its tool to control bank reserves again if the overnight borrowing cost rises further from current levels, TD Securities strategists said. The federal funds rate has risen, potentially complicating the Fed's path to shrinking its US$4 trillion balance sheet by half in 2020. The decline in excess reserves is partly due to the Fed's balance sheet normalization. A possible interest on excess reserves (IOER) adjustment may come as early as September to discourage banks from profiting on higher IOER by leaving reserves at the central bank.

site_title: Amazon is winning the online retail game again
summary: Amazon has successfully expanded its in-house brand portfolio, leveraging its marketplace expertise to drive sales. The company initially entered the private-label business with AmazonBasics in 2009, starting with unglamorous products like batteries. Today, AmazonBasics offers a range of products, including electronics, home goods, and more, often at lower prices than national brands. This strategy has contributed to Amazon's online retail dominance, further solidifying its position as a market leader.

site_title: Xiaomi puts indefinite delay on CDRs in blow to China's plans for tech listings
summary: Xiaomi has indefinitely delayed its China depositary receipts (CDRs) issuance process, casting doubt on Beijing's efforts to lure foreign-listed Chinese tech giants back home. The company had been expected to raise up to $10 billion through a mainland share offering, but postponed it until after its scheduled July 7 listing in Hong Kong. The delay has raised concerns about China's plans for tech listings, which have been seen as a key part of the government's efforts to promote domestic tech companies. The exact reason for the delay remains unclear.

site_title: UBS Youth Finance Academy visits SPH
summary: Approximately 60 students from 12 tertiary institutions visited Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) as part of UBS's Youth Finance Academy programme on June 19, 2018. The students met editors and journalists from The Business Times and Money FM 89.3, and also visited global long-term investor company GIC. The programme aims to support students considering finance as a career path by enriching their understanding of the industry through hands-on activities and interactive talks. UBS Singapore aims to continuously invest in young talents, with a focus on developing the next generation of finance professionals.

site_title: Former South Korean Prime Minister Kim Jong Pil dies at 92
summary: Former South Korean Prime Minister Kim Jong Pil died on June 23, 2018, at the age of 92. He was taken to a hospital in Seoul after being taken from his home, where he was already deceased upon arrival.

site_title: Pentagon indefinitely suspends some training exercises with South Korea
summary: The US and South Korea have agreed to indefinitely suspend two exchange programme training exercises, FREEDOM GUARDIAN and Korean Marine Exchange Program, following the Singapore summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The decision was made to support implementing the summit's outcomes and in coordination with South Korea. The exercises were scheduled to take place in the next three months and are mostly focused on computerised simulations. The suspension is seen as a follow-up measure to North Korea's productive cooperation, with additional measures possible if North Korea fails to follow suit.

site_title: Argentina gets first US$15b from IMF
summary: Argentina received its first $15 billion from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to stabilize its fragile economy. This is the first tranche of a $50 billion loan package, following a currency crisis in April and May. The peso has dropped 30% against the US dollar since the start of the year. The IMF's assistance aims to support Argentina's budget, reduce debt, tackle inflation, and strengthen the central bank's independence while maintaining social spending. This marks a significant move for Argentina, which has a complex history with the IMF.

site_title: New digital tech art studio for needy kids
summary: A new digital tech art studio has opened at The Little Arts Academy's Northpoint City campus in Singapore, offering virtual reality art experiences for needy children. This unique opportunity is typically reserved for tertiary institutions. The studio is part of the academy's efforts to provide accessible art education to a wider audience. The official opening marked a significant milestone in the academy's mission to foster creativity and artistic expression among young children.

site_title: Netflix fires spokesman over his use of racial slur at work
summary: Netflix fires Chief Communications Officer Jonathan Friedland after he used a racial slur in a work setting, citing "insensitive" comments and "unacceptably low racial awareness and sensitivity." CEO Reed Hastings wrote in a memo that Friedland's behavior was not in line with the company's values, leading to his departure. This move follows a series of high-profile officials being forced out over their behavior, including Intel CEO Brian Krzanich and Athenahealth CEO Jonathan Bush.

site_title: World Cup: Neymar 'is a human being', says Brazil coach Tite as he seeks to protect star
summary: Brazil coach Tite defended teammate Neymar after the forward was seen crying during a 2-0 World Cup win over Costa Rica. Tite attributed Neymar's emotional state to the pressure of representing Brazil, but assured he will return to his best. The coach disputed the VAR decision that rescinded a penalty Neymar was awarded, saying it was clear the foul occurred. Neymar, who was 3.5 months into his recovery from injury, praised the win and vowed to continue working towards his objective, despite facing challenges.

site_title: Diana King, a leading teacher in overcoming dyslexia, dies at 90
summary: Diana King, a renowned teacher and expert in overcoming dyslexia, died at 90 on June 15. She helped generations of students with reading, writing, and spelling difficulties, transforming the perception of people with dyslexia from being backward to intelligent despite their learning challenges. King's work emphasized early diagnosis and intensive tutoring, and she wrote 15 books on the subject. Her legacy includes Camp Kildonan, which continues to serve children with dyslexia, and her 2016 Lifetime Achievement Award from the National Teachers Hall of Fame.

site_title: Ten days after Trump-Kim summit hard work yet to begin
summary: US President Donald Trump's summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un ended with a pledge of "complete denuclearization," but no timetable for action has been set. Despite Trump's claims that the process will start quickly, senior US officials acknowledge there is much work to be done as negotiators thrash out the details. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo insists that the term "complete" in the document encompasses "verifiable and irreversible" disarmament, but critics question the lack of clarity on the definition of denuclearization and the reliability of Kim's assurances.

site_title: Trump urges Republican lawmakers to drop immigration bill until election
summary: President Donald Trump urged Republican lawmakers to drop their efforts to pass comprehensive immigration legislation until after the November elections, citing a desire to focus on midterm elections that could shift the balance of power in Congress. Trump's tweets sent mixed signals, with some lawmakers expressing frustration and others pledging to move forward with the legislation. The House rejected a conservative immigration bill and postponed a vote on a more moderate bill, leaving its fate uncertain.

site_title: Trump widens global trade war with tariff threat on EU cars
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened a 20% tariff on European Union cars unless the EU removes import duties and barriers to US goods, escalating a global trade war. The EU planned to retaliate with equivalent penalties, which could endanger $300 billion in US commerce. The move follows EU tariffs on $3.3 billion of American products in response to Trump's barriers to imported aluminum and steel. The US auto industry could be severely impacted, with shares of major carmakers falling and US auto companies potentially losing sales.

site_title: As housing prices soar, New Zealand tackles a surge in homelessness
summary: New Zealand is grappling with a surge in homelessness, with the country having the highest homelessness rate among wealthy nations. The housing market has been deemed dysfunctional, with prices doubling in some areas since the 2008 global financial crisis. The government has pledged to build more public and low-cost housing, create emergency residences, and cut bureaucratic red tape. A community-led initiative in South Auckland, funded by private donations and government grants, has successfully housed and supported homeless families. However, many homeless individuals face a confusing and discouraging system, with some waiting weeks for appointments and struggling to navigate the bureaucracy.

site_title: Melania Trump, agent of coat chaos
summary: Melania Trump sparked outrage when she wore a $39 Zara jacket to a Texas children's shelter with the phrase "I really don't care, do U?" scrawled on the back. Her communications director said it was just a jacket with no hidden message, but critics interpreted it as insensitive and heartless. The first lady, who has experience with being scrutinized for her fashion choices, is believed to have intentionally worn the jacket to convey a message, possibly to her husband or critics of his policies.

site_title: Largest US banks eye more share buybacks, investments after clearing 1st stress test stage
summary: The 35 largest US banks have cleared the first stage of the Federal Reserve's annual stress test, demonstrating sufficient capital to withstand an extreme recession. Despite facing $578 billion in losses, the banks' high-quality capital exceeds the required threshold, surpassing pre-2007-2009 crisis levels. The test's second part, focusing on operational factors, will be released next week, with the Fed to decide on capital plans. The results could boost the case for regulatory relief and allow banks to pursue more share buybacks and investments.

site_title: Drumming it up
summary: Local percussion instructor Er Chow Kiat has developed a unique drumming school concept using images instead of music notation for total adult beginners. His drumming school, Drum Tutor, uses visual aids to teach drumming basics, making it less intimidating for students. Er plans to turn this concept into an app, which will also feature play-alongs, a marketplace, and social media functions. The app aims to make drumming lessons more engaging, interactive, and user-friendly, allowing students to learn and practice without pressure.

site_title: European shares bounce but trade jitters linger on
summary: European shares rose 1.1% at the end of a tumultuous week, driven by better-than-expected euro zone economic data and an Opec agreement on a modest increase in oil production. Despite this, shares in European carmakers and German companies fell due to trade war worries and President Trump's threat of a 20% tariff on car imports. Euro zone private business growth recovered, while manufacturing growth was the weakest in 18 months.

site_title: Once again, Hong Kong has the world's priciest office market
summary: Hong Kong's office market remains the world's most expensive, with occupancy costs 30% higher than London's West End. For the third consecutive year, the city's Central district tops the list. Global prime office space costs rose 2.4% in the first quarter, driven by strong economic growth and demand from finance, technology, and e-commerce tenants. This marks a departure from the usual trends, with growth in all three regions above expectations, according to CBRE global chief economist Richard Barkham.

site_title: Political, trade uncertainties cloud euro's longer-term outlook
summary: The euro rose 0.5% against the dollar on Friday, driven by improved regional economic growth data and assurances from Italian politicians that they would not leave the single currency. Business activity in Germany and France, the eurozone's top two economies, picked up in June despite trade tensions with the US. The euro's advance also came as Greece clinched debt relief and received a cash infusion from the eurozone. Despite this week's gains, the euro remains vulnerable to regional political instability and US tariffs, with US President Donald Trump calling for a 20% levy on European Union-assembled car imports.

site_title: Making a splash for a good cause
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) CEO Sherman Kwek made a splash for a good cause at the Assisi Fun Day, raising S$183,846 for Assisi Hospice's patients and families through a dunking machine. The event, attended by Education Minister Ong Ye Kung and Temasek Holdings' Ho Ching, supports palliative care. Last year, Kwek raised funds by peddling a trishaw. The Assisi Fun Day is the hospice's biggest fundraising event of the year.

images.alt_text: Sherman Kwek (left), Group CEO of CDL, made a splash for charity and was dunked by Minister Ong Ye Kung (centre) and Ho Ching.

site_title: US: Dow snaps losing streak on energy lift
summary: US stocks ended the week on a positive note, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.49% to 24,580.89, snapping an eight-day losing streak. The energy sector led the gain, driven by a 4.6% surge in US crude oil prices after oil producers agreed to modest output increases. Despite the boost, trade tensions remained a concern, with US President Donald Trump threatening to impose tariffs on European Union car imports.

site_title: Telcos - dial D for dividend?
summary: Telecom companies are viewed as defensive shares, offering reliable dividends to compensate for lower interest rates. Over the last decade, the median annual total return for a basket of global telecom companies is 8.7%, primarily due to reinvested dividends. The return on equity has been in the high teens, indicating a bright outlook for future dividend payouts. However, investors should focus on the ability of telecom companies to pay affordable and sustainable dividends, rather than rapid share-price growth. The free cash flow yield is also an important consideration, with median yields ranging from 1% to 7%.

site_title: Switzerland beats Serbia in a game tinged with history and politics
summary: Switzerland defeated Serbia 2-1 in a World Cup match, with Xherdan Shaqiri scoring the winning goal in the 90th minute. The game was marked by questions of identity and belonging, as three Swiss players born in Kosovo, including Shaqiri, were involved. Shaqiri's goal was accompanied by a nationalistic gesture with his hands, sparking controversy. The match tightened the competition for the top two spots in Group E, with Brazil and Switzerland tied for first place. The game highlighted the complex history and politics surrounding Kosovo's independence from Serbia.

images.alt_text: It was Xherdan Shaqiri's right boot that made the headlines before his match on Friday, but it was his left boot, and his hands, that were the story after the game ended.

site_title: Despite summit, North Korea still a nuclear threat, says Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump extended sanctions on North Korea's regime, citing an "unusual and extraordinary threat" from its nuclear arsenal despite touting the success of a historic summit with Kim Jong Un earlier this month. The declaration, sent to Congress, states that the risk of proliferation of nuclear material on the Korean Peninsula remains a threat to the US national security, foreign policy, and economy. The summit agreement stopped short of US demands for North Korea's complete disarmament, sparking concerns about the effectiveness of the deal.

site_title: Top US, Russia energy officials to meet on Tuesday: source
summary: US Energy Secretary Rick Perry will meet Russia's Energy Minister Alexander Novak on Tuesday in Washington, as the two countries compete to supply global markets with natural gas and crude. The meeting comes amid a backdrop of strained US-Russia relations, with the US opposing Russia's Nord Stream 2 pipeline to Europe. Perry and Novak will discuss natural gas, oil markets, and potential cooperation, including Russia's recent decision to cooperate with Opec. The meeting is seen as a rare high-level engagement between top US and Russian energy officials in recent years.

site_title: Why some Saudi women will keep their driving licences a secret
summary: Saudi Arabia has lifted its driving ban, but many women face cultural and societal challenges in embracing the change. Women like Shahd, who plan to take driving lessons, must keep their licenses secret from their families due to societal shame and conservative traditions. The country's patriarchal laws and guardianship system limit women's freedom, and some women are hesitant to drive due to concerns about their reputation and family honor. Experts predict that the transition will take time, with some areas like cosmopolitan cities and liberal pockets experiencing more rapid changes.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's monarch may have opened the door for Saudi women like Shahd to start driving, but she still needs to sneak out of the house to take lessons.

site_title: 'I could play until 50': Djokovic wants more after reaching 800 wins
summary: Novak Djokovic has reached 800 match wins, becoming the 10th Open-era player to achieve this milestone. At 31, Djokovic aims to continue playing beyond his 40th birthday, with a semi-final appearance at the Queen's Club tournament. He will face Jeremy Chardy in the final on Saturday, seeking a second Queen's final appearance. Djokovic considers reaching 800 wins as just another step in rewriting the record books, with no intention of retiring anytime soon.

site_title: Want to feel happier? Your phone might help
summary: A recent app called Happy Not Perfect, created by Poppy Jamie, aims to promote mental well-being and happiness among millennials. After hosting a Snapchat talk show, Jamie realized a widespread stress issue among young people worldwide. The app offers brain health tools and resources to help users manage stress and improve their mental health. Jamie's experience was sparked by the high-profile suicides and a CDC report showing a 30-year high in the national suicide rate. The app seeks to address these issues and provide a platform for users to share their feelings and connect with others.

site_title: Airbus tells Britain it wants details of a Brexit deal, or it might leave the country
summary: Airbus has warned the British government that it needs more clarity on a Brexit deal or risk leaving the country. The European aerospace giant, which makes commercial airliners, delivered the stark warning in a published report and remarks by a company executive. With months left to agree on a withdrawal deal, Airbus is concerned about the uncertainty affecting future investments and planning. The company's direct warning is unusual, but trade groups have previously warned of the need for notice to plan for future investments. Airbus' threat highlights the growing unease among businesses about the UK's Brexit negotiations.

images.alt_text: Britain voted almost exactly two years ago to leave the European Union, and with months before it must agree on a withdrawal deal or crash out of the bloc, much remains undecided. Too much, for at least one company.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close slightly higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.83 points to 1,694.15, with a gain in volume of 2.0 billion lots worth RM2.2 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 480 to 350.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher as financials lead
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, ending an 8-day losing streak, as bank stocks gained after passing the Federal Reserve's annual regulatory stress test. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.27%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.4% and 0.35%, respectively, at the opening bell.

site_title: Swedes just love to get technology under their skin
