summary: Malaysia's government-linked companies (GLCs) are expected to undergo a major shake-up, with over 100 politically-appointed heads and officials on a "watch list" due to their ties to the ousted Barisan Nasional government. The new Pakatan Harapan government, led by Tun Dr Mahathir Mohamad, aims to reform the GLCs. Key individuals expected to leave their positions include Tan Sri Leo Moggie, Abdul Ghani Othman, and Abdul Wahid Omar, who will be replaced by new leaders as part of the reform program.

site_title: Euro area growth unexpectedly quickens as slowdown risks persist
summary: Euro area economic growth unexpectedly accelerated in June, with a composite purchasing managers' index rising to 54.8, driven by a jump in services growth. However, manufacturing growth remained subdued, and the slowdown in the region persists. The increase was driven by stronger growth in services, while exports remained subdued. The European Central Bank's decision to end bond purchases this year has raised concerns about the region's underlying momentum. The slowdown risks persist, and the region's growth is expected to slow further in the second half of the year.

site_title: Advancer Global to raise S$22m in tie-up with Tokyo-listed Fullcast
summary: Advancer Global has agreed to allot and issue 65 million new shares to Tokyo-listed Fullcast Holdings for S$21.78 million, representing 25.19% of its enlarged share capital. The subscription price is a 10% premium to the one-month average closing price. The deal includes a strategic alliance to form a joint venture (JV) in Japan to provide foreign labour staffing and employment services. The JV aims to address Japan's labour shortages, driven by its ageing population. Advancer's CEO expects the partnership to strengthen the company's financial position and drive growth.

site_title: Noble Group to get US$100m trade finance facilities from minority shareholders
summary: NOBLE Group secured a binding commitment for $100 million in trade finance facilities from a consortium of existing shareholders, comprising Value Partners and Pinpoint Asset Management. The consortium, holding a 5% combined equity interest, has agreed to vote in favor of Noble's restructuring plan. In exchange, the consortium will receive $7.5 million in new asset company bonds, $7.5 million in new trading company bonds, $10 million in new trading holding company bonds, and a $5 million arrangement fee. The facilities will support the expansion of Noble's trading activities, particularly in the LNG industry.

site_title: New Zealand's 'prime miniature' baby keeps Ardern busy
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern spent her second night in hospital with her newborn daughter, dubbed the "prime miniature" by Twitter users. Ardern, 37, gave birth to a 3.3kg baby girl while in office, becoming only the second world leader to do so. The baby's name has not been released, and Ardern's plans for a public appearance with her baby were cancelled twice due to her exhaustion. Ardern's partner, Clarke Gayford, will become a stay-at-home dad when she returns to work after six weeks' maternity leave.

images.alt_text: New Zealand leader Jacinda Ardern will spend a second night in hospital with her "very alert and hungry" newborn daughter who Twitter wags have dubbed the "prime miniature".

site_title: Largest US banks would survive recession: Federal Reserve
summary: The Federal Reserve announced that the largest US banks are "strongly capitalized" and would survive a severe global economic recession. Stress testing showed that banks would still be able to lend to households and businesses, despite projected losses of $578 billion over nine quarters. The tests, required under the 2010 Dodd-Frank financial reform laws, envisioned a deeper economic shock than previous rounds, but found that banks would end a recession in better shape than they started the last one.

site_title: Singapore Kitchen Q1 loss doubles on higher costs, dual listing expenses
summary: Singapore Kitchen Equipment reported a first quarter net loss of S$905,000, doubling the previous year's loss, due to higher distribution costs and administrative expenses. Revenue surged 43.6% to S$6.93 million, but was partly offset by a 50.7% increase in cost of sales. The company's potential dual listing on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange is expected to negatively impact its net profit for the next 12 months.

site_title: Kuroda's job of explaining Japan's inflation grows tougher
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda faces the challenge of explaining Japan's stagnant inflation, which has remained at 0.7% for two months, falling short of the 2% target. This marks a significant setback for Kuroda's efforts to normalize monetary policy, putting him out of sync with global peers. The Bank of Japan's stimulus has been in place for over five years, but its effectiveness is being questioned, leading to increased pressure on Kuroda to justify the central bank's actions.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets firm at open
summary: European stocks rose 0.2-0.3% on Friday, despite the escalation of a global trade war, as the EU imposed retaliatory tariffs on US imports. The FTSE 100, DAX 30, and CAC 40 indices rose 0.2%, 0%, and 0.3% respectively. Analysts warned that trade tensions remain a dominant theme, with concerns about a full-blown flare-up potentially pummeling the global economy. The EU's move comes after the US hit steel and aluminum imports from the bloc, and amid uncertainty over US-China trade relations.

site_title: Singapore Air CEO sees risk to cargo yields beyond trade dispute
summary: Singapore Airlines CEO Goh Choon Phong warns of potential threats to cargo yields due to a US-China trade dispute and increased supply, despite last year's record cargo demand. The airline is well-positioned to manage rising fuel costs and has a hedging strategy in place. Shares declined 0.4% as of the interview, trimming the year's gain to 2.8%. The company is also exploring new fees to fund Changi Airport construction.

site_title: Greece says Eurogroup debt deal positive, debt now viable
summary: Greece's finance minister, Euclid Tsakalotos, announced a positive outcome from the Eurogroup debt deal, stating that Greece's debt is now viable and the country is on track to exit its bailout in August. The deal includes a 10-year deferral and maturity extension on past loans and 15 billion euros in new credit, allowing Greece to access the markets and implement its growth strategy. Tsakalotos believes this marks the end of the Greek crisis and a new chapter for the country.

site_title: Mahathir says Malaysia seeks to recover US$4.5b 1MDB funds, Goldman fees
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced plans to seek recovery of $4.5 billion in 1MDB funds and Goldman Sachs' fees, stating that the funds are owed to the Malaysian government. Mahathir expressed concerns over the large commission paid to Goldman Sachs for arranging bond sales for 1MDB, with a 10% fee and 6% interest rate. The government plans to pursue legal action against Goldman Sachs if there's a case, with Finance Minister Lim Guan Eng seeking restitution.

images.alt_text: Malaysia will seek to recoup US$4.5 billion of funds that were potentially lost through 1MDB, as well as fees paid to Goldman Sachs Group, according to Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad.

site_title: Malaysia names ex-1MDB investigator as new central bank governor
summary: Malaysia named Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus, a former central bank official who investigated 1MDB, as its new central bank governor, replacing Muhammad Ibrahim who resigned amid questions about the central bank's role in a 1MDB deal. The appointment comes as the country faces its biggest political upheaval in decades following Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's election win. Nor Shamsiah's main challenges will be stabilizing the economy, dealing with a stronger dollar, and rising US interest rates, amid a credit-rating downgrade risk.

images.alt_text: Malaysia named Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus, a former central bank official who investigated the scandal-plagued state fund 1MDB, as governor of the regulator.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon trading at 3,287.28, down 0.4% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Friday at 3,287.28, down 0.4% from the previous day's close. The Straits Times Index fell 12.72 points, with 837.5 million shares worth S$524.5 million changing hands. Noble Group rose 21% after securing a US$100 million trade finance commitment, while Singtel retreated 1.27% after a strong previous day. Losers outnumbered gainers 178 to 112, with the most actively traded stocks including Noble Group, Nico Steel, and DISA.

site_title: Versalink announces management changes
summary: Versalink Holdings announced management changes, effective July 13. Executive directors Law Pei Ling and Law Kian Guan will assume new roles, with Law Pei Ling becoming corporate strategy director and Law Kian Guan overseeing special projects. Promotions include Shashi Dharan Nair to general manager of Jemaramas Jaya Sdn Bhd and David Tann Beng Soon to general manager of Versalink Marketing. Calvin Chang Chee Keong resigned as sales and marketing director of Jemaramas Jaya to pursue another career opportunity. The changes are part of a broader leadership restructuring within the company.

site_title: World Cup: Argentine fans weep as dream fades
summary: Argentina's World Cup dream has faded after a humiliating 3-0 loss to Croatia, leaving fans devastated. Lionel Messi's under-par performance drew criticism, with fans feeling the team's struggles are a reflection of the nation's economic woes. Argentina now faces a tall order to advance, requiring a win over Nigeria and favorable results from other teams, leaving fans uncertain about their country's future.

site_title: Opec strives for deal to raise oil output as Iran resists
summary: OPEC is trying to agree on a deal to raise oil output, with Saudi Arabia proposing a 1 million barrel per day increase. However, Iran is resisting the deal due to US sanctions and the prospect of lower exports, which could lead to a supply deficit of up to 1.8 million barrels per day. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries meets on Friday to decide output policy, with top consumers such as the US, China, and India calling for more production to cool down oil prices and support the world economy.

site_title: Singapore, Asian equities extend weekly losses as trade tensions show no sign of abating
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.4% to 3,285.38, extending weekly losses, amid escalating trade tensions between the US and other major economies. Asian stocks also declined, with the Nikkei 225 and Hang Seng Index down 1.6% and 4% respectively. The European Union imposed 25% tariffs on US products in response to US tariffs on steel and aluminum. US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, while the US dollar index edged 0.1% lower.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 9.07 points to 1,683.25. Losers outnumbered gainers 83 to 67, and volume was 34.89 million lots worth RM15.91 million.

site_title: Japan says halting missile drills after Trump-Kim summit
summary: Japan has suspended evacuation drills simulating a North Korean missile attack following the historic talks between US President Donald Trump and North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un in Singapore. The decision comes as a result of the joint document calling for the denuclearization of the Korean peninsula.

images.alt_text: Japan is suspending evacuation drills simulating a North Korean missile attack after historic talks between Washington and Pyongyang, its top government spokesman said Friday.

site_title: Japan inflation stuck at 0.7% in May, way below target
summary: Japan's inflation remained stagnant at 0.7% in May, below the country's target of 2.0%, according to government data. This marks the fourth consecutive month of low inflation, indicating the country's long battle against deflation is ongoing. The Bank of Japan has signaled no plans to adjust its monetary policy, despite other major economies tightening their monetary policies. The country's economy contracted 0.2% quarter-on-quarter in the January-March period, ending eight consecutive quarters of growth.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks suffer losses at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.27% at the open on Friday, following a sell-off on Wall Street due to trade war fears. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 29,215.54, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined.

site_title: Indonesian cleric sentenced to death over 2016 terror attack
summary: Indonesian cleric Aman Abdurrahman was sentenced to death for his role in a 2016 terror attack that killed four people at a Jakarta Starbucks cafe. Abdurrahman, considered the de facto head of IS supporters in Indonesia, was found guilty of masterminding the attack. The sentence was handed down by a Jakarta court, which cited his involvement in other attacks. Executions are carried out by firing squad in Indonesia, and authorities have also linked Abdurrahman to recent suicide bombings in the country's second-largest city, Surabaya.

site_title: Tesla to close a dozen solar facilities in nine states: documents
summary: Tesla plans to close about a dozen solar facilities in nine US states, downsizing the residential solar business it acquired in a $2.6 billion deal two years ago. The closures will end a retail partnership with Home Depot and significantly reduce sales. About 60 installation facilities remain open, according to an internal company list. The move is part of a broader effort to cut 9% of its workforce, affecting the SolarCity division founded by Elon Musk's cousins.

site_title: Airbus warns could leave Britain if no Brexit deal
summary: Airbus warns it may leave the UK if Britain exits the EU without a deal, citing severe disruption and interruption to UK production. The company would reconsider its investments and long-term footprint in the country, undermining the UK's competitive aerospace industry. This scenario would also impact high-value jobs and competences.

site_title: 'I really don't care': Melania Trump jacket stuns on migrant visit
summary: Melania Trump visited child migrants on the US-Mexico border, sparking international outrage over her choice of clothing: an olive green jacket with the phrase "I really don't care, do you?" First Lady Melania Trump's spokeswoman denied a hidden message, while President Trump tweeted the phrase referred to the "Fake News Media." The visit came after President Trump ended the practice of separating migrant families, and the first lady called for political compromise to end the practice.

site_title: Driving change: Saudis to end ban on women behind wheel
summary: Saudi Arabia, the only country to ban female drivers, will allow women to drive for the first time in decades starting Sunday, June 24, 2018. King Salman's decree issued in September 2017 led to the issuance of driving licenses to women, with 3 million expected to receive licenses by 2020. Women will be allowed to drive cars, motorbikes, vans, and trucks, with licenses issued at age 18 for private vehicles and 20 for public transport. The government has also taken steps to address concerns of sexual harassment and arbitrary authority.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia, the only country that does not permit female motorists, will allow women to get behind the wheel for the first time in decades on Sunday.

site_title: EU slaps tariffs on US as trade war erupts
summary: The European Union imposed tariffs on US products worth 2.8 billion euros, including bourbon, jeans, and motorcycles, in response to President Donald Trump's decision to slap tariffs on European steel and aluminum exports. The move raises concerns of an escalating global trade war, fueling jitters on world stock markets. The tariffs, which took effect at midnight, will hike prices on US-made products and further strain transatlantic relations, which are already at their lowest level for many years due to trade tensions and disagreements on various issues.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as yen firms on trade war fears
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on June 22, 2018, due to escalating trade tensions and a stronger yen against the dollar. The Nikkei 225 index lost 1.02% and the Topix index declined 0.94%. The losses followed a similar trend in global markets. The decline was attributed to fears of a trade war between the US and other countries.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday; STI down 0.5% to 3,282.54
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.5% to 3,282.54 on Friday, mirroring global market declines. The index dropped 17.46 points as 61.4 million shares worth S$112.9 million changed hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 73 to 40, with Singtel, Noble Group, and ComfortDelGro being the most actively traded counters.

site_title: Watch the tech stocks as caution reigns over markets
summary: Tech stocks face caution as markets remain volatile. With the 10th anniversary of the 2008 stock market crash approaching, investors are becoming increasingly cautious. Historically, when markets reach their bottom, brave investors can capitalize on the rebound, often resulting in significant gains. The article suggests that investors should remain vigilant and consider buying stocks that have fallen further before they turn around, as the market tends to take off during this period.

site_title: US: Dow down for 8th straight day on trade war worries
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.8% on its eighth consecutive day due to trade war fears, with automakers particularly affected after Daimler's profit warning tied to US-China tariffs. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, with General Motors, Ford, and Tesla Motors experiencing significant losses. Analysts expressed concerns about the negative impact of tariffs on the US economy, while online retailers fell after the US Supreme Court ruled in favor of states taxing online sales.

site_title: Indonesia's growing thirst for coffee drains premium bean supplies
summary: Indonesia's increasing coffee consumption is depleting premium coffee bean supplies, particularly in Sumatra, where unique arabica beans are in short supply. As younger generations adopt coffee and independent coffee shops proliferate, demand is outpacing supply, driving up prices for foreign buyers. This shift is a significant change for Indonesia, which traditionally favored tea over coffee.

images.alt_text: For decades, Indonesia has supplied coffee roasters worldwide with prized beans that give a distinctive taste to brews favored by connoisseurs. Most locals, however, preferred tea.

site_title: The Kings Of Swing
summary: A British trio, Stephen Triffitt, Mark Adams, and George Daniel Long, pay tribute to Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin, and Sammy Davis Jr. in "The Definitive Rat Pack," a show that has been seen by over 10 million people worldwide and earned an Olivier Award nomination.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: China Environment denied allegations of misappropriating rental income from its subsidiary Anhui Dongyuan Environmental Protection Co, citing pressure from creditor Li Qun Bin. Lee Metal Group lost its public float after a takeover bid from BRC Asia, while GIC invested in Verra Mobility in a $400 million private placement. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: Singapore Myanmar Investco faces summons linked to US$10.8m share sale
summary: A joint venture partner, Golden Infrastructure Group, has filed an originating summons against Singapore Myanmar Investco (SMI) to block the proposed US$10.8 million sale of TPR Myanmar. The summons claims that SMI's board resolution approving the sale is in breach of a 2014 shareholder agreement. SMI plans to focus on less capital-intensive business segments, citing telecommunications as a capital-intensive industry. The summons was filed against SMI, its parent company MIG, and the buyer, Tiger Infrastructure.

site_title: UFC Gym to open 15 outlets in Singapore over next decade
summary: UFC Gym is set to open 15 locations in Singapore over the next decade, offering private and group fitness classes, as well as mixed martial arts training. The gyms will cater to different ages and fitness levels, featuring workout concepts inspired by UFC fighters' training regimens. The first location is expected to open by February next year, marking the franchise's entry into the eighth Asian country. This expansion follows the gym's global growth, with over 150 locations worldwide since its debut in 2009.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit by fresh Italian scare, Daimler tariff hit
summary: European shares fell 0.9% as the Italian parliament appointed eurosceptics, and Daimler warned higher US tariffs would hit profits. The autos sector dropped 3.5%, its biggest loss in two years, amid ongoing US-China trade tensions. Market analysts fear President Trump will target the EU next, contributing to the uncertainty.

site_title: Largest banks clear Federal Reserve's toughest annual stress tests
summary: The 35 largest US banks have cleared the first stage of the Federal Reserve's annual stress test, demonstrating sufficient capital to withstand an extreme recession. Although they would suffer $578 billion in total losses, their high-quality capital exceeds the regulatory threshold and surpasses pre-2007-2009 crisis levels. The test is the first of a two-part exam, with the second test next week, which includes operational factors. The results could boost the case for regulatory relief and allow banks to increase dividend payments and share buybacks.

site_title: Nico Steel: Reclassified interest expense led to difference between audited, unaudited cash flows
summary: Nico Steel Holdings reported a discrepancy between its audited and unaudited cash flows due to a reclassification of interest expense on working capital borrowings. The company reclassified $133,000 from financing to operating activities, affecting its cash flow figures. This change resulted in a net cash used of $135,000 in audited statements versus $2,000 in unaudited statements. The company assured that the reclassification does not alter its financial results or position.

site_title: Daimler cuts 2018 profit forecast on trade tension
summary: German luxury carmaker Daimler has cut its 2018 profit forecast due to trade tensions between China and the US, citing import tariffs on cars exported from the US to China as a major factor. The company now expects earnings before interest and taxes (Ebit) to be slightly lower than previously forecast. This move has sparked fears of a wave of earnings downgrades across the industry, with BMW also facing similar challenges. The US-China trade spat has raised concerns about potential tariffs on vehicle imports, potentially affecting carmakers globally.

site_title: Top US court gives states broad rights for online sales tax
summary: The US Supreme Court ruled 5-4 to overturn its 1992 decision that limited states' ability to tax online sales, giving states broad rights to tax e-commerce. The ruling, in favor of South Dakota, allows states to tax sales from businesses with no physical presence in that state. The decision could significantly impact online and brick-and-mortar retail sectors, with potential revenue increases for states and a shift in the competitive landscape for retailers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Civmec, Singapore Kitchen Equipment, Sunpower
summary: Civmec secured a major A$4 billion deal with Lürssen to build 10 offshore patrol vessels for the Australian Navy, with estimated recurring revenue of A$400 million to A$500 million over the next decade. Singapore Kitchen Equipment reported a net loss of S$905,000 in its fiscal first quarter, with revenue increasing 43.6% to S$6.93 million. Sunpower Group won a tender worth S$22 million from Shanxi Taigang Stainless Steel for flue gas desulphurisation services.

site_title: Smart mobility for a Smart Nation: Are we nearly there yet?
summary: Singapore is working to become a "Smart Nation" by 2030, with a focus on seamless mobility for travelers. The region's 22 megacities in Asia-Pacific account for 70% of the world's population by 2050, driving economic and social growth. To sustain this pace, cities must become "smarter" through automation, artificial intelligence, and the Internet of Things. Singapore has already implemented impressive automation at Changi Terminal 4, but more needs to be done to meet the demands of sophisticated travelers.

site_title: Edmund Cheng to replace Lee Hsien Yang as CAAS chairman
summary: Edmund Cheng will replace Lee Hsien Yang as chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) on July 1, 2018. Cheng, who has been deputy chairman since 2016, brings extensive private and public sector experience. Under Lee's tenure, Singapore developed as an aviation hub, with 7,200 weekly flights and a 65% increase in passenger and airfreight traffic since 2008. Cheng's appointment is seen as a boost to CAAS's mission to grow a safe and vibrant air hub. The Ministry of Transport (MOT) expressed appreciation for Lee's years of service.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Civmec steers into shipbuilding ahead of its dual listing on ASX
summary: Australian builder Civmec has clinched a major A$4 billion deal with German shipyard Lürssen to build 10 offshore patrol vessels for the Australian Navy. The contract is part of the federal government's plan to create a sustainable sovereign shipbuilding industry, with significant revenue expected from FY2021. Civmec plans to expand its shipbuilding capabilities, including investing A$80 million in a new facility in Western Australia. The deal marks Civmec's entry into shipbuilding, which is expected to bring recurring revenue of A$400-500 million over the next decade.

site_title: Days Of Our Lives
summary: Artist Rose Chang, 72, continues to paint scenes of kampung life, drawing from her mother's stories of growing up in a Peranakan family. Despite being afflicted with polio since age three and now suffering from post-polio syndrome, Chang still spends six hours daily in her studio, creating oil paintings of rotund women engaging in domestic chores. Her unique style has gained fans, including renowned personalities, and her works are part of an exhibition titled "The View From Here" at Kplus.sg until June 24.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Instagram allows longer videos in direct challenge to YouTube
summary: Instagram is expanding its video capabilities, allowing users to post videos up to an hour long, directly competing with YouTube. The new feature, IGTV, will debut as a stand-alone app and feature vertical video, targeting social media stars with millions of followers. Instagram aims to entice users to spend more time on video platforms, as younger viewers shift away from traditional TV. The move is seen as a response to the changing nature of online video viewing, with IGTV expected to feature creators building massive audiences.

images.alt_text: Instagram's Mr Systrom answering a question at a news conference in San Francisco on Wednesday. With him on stage are (from left) social media star Bryce Xavier, Instagram product manager Ashley Yuki and Ms Pons.

site_title: EU trade chief says ready to talk with US to fix trade row
summary: EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom says the EU is ready to engage with the US to resolve a trade row triggered by US tariffs on European metals, calling them "illegal" and contravening WTO rules. Malmstrom also expressed support for New Zealand's stance on an open, rule-based trade system. The EU will take retaliatory action to protect European interests and jobs, following the US move.

site_title: China accuses US of trade 'abuses' as India hits back at Trump
summary: China has threatened to retaliate against new US tariffs, with a commerce ministry spokesman saying the country is "fully prepared" to respond. India has also imposed retaliatory levies on US goods, following the European Union's lead. The US has ordered $200 billion in Chinese imports for 10% tariffs, with another $200 billion if China retaliates. Global markets have declined, with emerging markets falling and the US dollar strengthening, as trade tensions escalate. The world's central bankers have warned that international trade tensions are damaging confidence and threatening global economic expansion.

images.alt_text: "The US abuses tariffs to trigger trade wars everywhere around the globe and that will severely damage the world trade order, hurt the interests of trading partners, and also hurt its domestic companies and people," says China's Ministry of Commerce spokesman Gao Feng.

site_title: Four US airlines refuse to carry separated migrant children
summary: Four major US airlines, American Airlines, United Continental Holdings, and Frontier Airlines, have refused to transport migrant children separated from their parents at the US-Mexico border. Greyhound, a private bus line, has also been criticized for allowing Border Patrol to conduct immigration checks on its buses, exposing passengers to potential constitutional rights violations. The airlines' decisions came after President Trump signed an executive order to end the immediate separation of families. The Department of Homeland Security criticized the airlines' decisions, while the American Civil Liberties Union argued that Greyhound should not allow the searches without probable cause or explicit consent.

site_title: Xiaomi will have to work hard to defend its position in India
summary: Xiaomi faces challenges in defending its position in India, where its subsidiary generated $950 million in sales in the first quarter. The company's success in the Indian market is crucial, with a 30% share of smartphone shipments. Xiaomi's shift to more profitable internet services, such as music and video streaming, is also being tested. Despite a scaled-down valuation target of $55-70 billion, Xiaomi will need to grow in India and beyond to justify its valuation.

site_title: Disney boosts Fox bid to US$71.3b to counter Comcast
summary: Disney raised its bid for 21st Century Fox assets to $71.3 billion, surpassing Comcast's $65 billion offer, in a bid to counter the rival bid and create a dominant player in the media entertainment world. The deal would give Disney a controlling stake in Hulu and a stronger foothold in international markets. The stock component of the Disney offer would be non-taxable, making it more difficult for Comcast to match the bid. Analysts say Comcast would need to offer significantly more cash to compete, and this deal appears to be a decisive move by Disney.

images.alt_text: Mr Iger says that the acquisition of Fox's US studios and television assets will better position Disney.

site_title: Chinese coal traders wary of being burnt by escalating trade war
summary: China is imposing steep tariffs on US coal shipments, potentially delaying or blocking deliveries to Chinese steel mills. Three US coal shipments, valued at up to $30 million each, are at risk of being affected by the tariffs, which could kick in before the ships reach their destinations. Chinese traders and steel mills are concerned about the impact on their businesses, with some already canceling plans to buy US coal. The tariffs are part of Beijing's escalating trade dispute with the US, which has already imposed tariffs on over 650 Chinese goods.

images.alt_text: Beijing has not specified when coal would be hit with the steep tariffs aimed at the US.

site_title: Mercedes-AMG C 43 Coupe review: The stormy C
summary: The Mercedes-AMG C 43 Coupe remains a top performer in its class, with a powerful 3.0-litre V6 engine producing 390hp. The car boasts a sporty interior, including an ergonomic steering wheel and AMG-unique displays, and has been fine-tuned for better handling and braking. Despite a 23hp power bump, the car's 0-100km/h time and top speed remain unchanged. The C 43 strikes a balance between power and usability, making it an enjoyable drive both on and off the track.

site_title: Opec works towards deal as Saudis propose plan for higher output
summary: Opec is closer to reaching an oil-production deal as Saudi Arabia proposes a plan to increase output by 600,000 barrels a day, bringing the global market back to target levels. Iran has softened its stance, edging away from a threat to veto any agreement, while Russia pushes for a larger quota increase of 1.5 million barrels a day. The deal, set to be decided at Opec's meeting on Friday, aims to ease consumer anxiety about high oil prices and shape oil prices, energy stocks, and currencies for months to come.

site_title: New Mercedes C-Class review: A shocking change of heart
summary: The Mercedes-Benz C-Class has undergone a facelift, with minor styling updates and significant changes under the hood. The C 200 sedan now features a new 1.5-liter turbocharged engine and mild hybrid technology, which adds 14 horsepower of boost and seamless engine shutoff/restart. The hybrid system is unobtrusive, and the car's fuel efficiency has increased to 6.2L/100km. The updated C-Class will be available in Singapore at the end of 2018, with the same lineup as before, including the C 180, C 200, and high-performance C 43 models.

site_title: Tuaspring move for debt moratorium to be heard on July 6
summary: Hyflux's subsidiary Tuaspring has scheduled a hearing at the Supreme Court of Singapore on July 6 to seek a debt moratorium under Section 210(10) of Singapore's Companies Act. Tuaspring is seeking to facilitate a court-supervised restructuring process amid a total bank debt of S$518.4 million owed to Maybank. This comes after Hyflux and four of its subsidiaries were granted a six-month reprieve from creditors earlier this week. The outcome will determine how to resolve the divergence between Tuaspring's book value of S$1.3 billion and its current market value.

site_title: Women, who are typically paid less than men, face pension poverty
summary: Women face significant pension poverty due to historical lower pay, with retirement savings 30-40% lower than men's. Unpaid gaps in employment, marriage to older men, and unpaid caregiving services exacerbate the issue. Women live 5-7 years longer than their husbands, yet have lower pension savings, increasing the risk of outliving their savings. Urgent remedies, including adjusting social security schemes, providing paid maternity leave and childcare, and incorporating unpaid caregiving services into retirement schemes, are needed to address the disparity and promote pension equality.

site_title: Best Of Luck
summary: Van Cleef & Arpels celebrates 50 years of its iconic Alhambra necklace, launched in 1968, which features geometric quatrefoil medallions reminiscent of the Alhambra Palace in Granada, Spain. The design symbolizes good luck, a theme associated with the maison since the 1920s. To commemorate the anniversary, the jeweler has created new designs with links to the originals, including a rose-gold version and limited-edition pieces featuring lapis lazuli and rock crystal. The company's designers utilize the brand's extensive archives as a point of reference for their creations.

site_title: The Appeal Of Tibetan Tea
summary: Tibetan black tea, grown in Sichuan province and now cultivated along the Tibetan border, is gaining attention for its potential health benefits. Rich in amino acids, polyphenols, and other nutrients, this tea is believed to awaken and benefit the mind, while also promoting physical well-being. With a unique fermentation process that can enhance its flavor and value over time, Tibetan black tea is now being served at a Singapore restaurant, Ganglamedo, as part of a mission to promote a healthier approach to food.

site_title: Marina One Residences launching tower at average S$2,700-S$2,800 psf
summary: Marina One Residences developer M+S is launching 30% of its 521-unit Garden Tower for sale in July at an average S$2,700-S$2,800 psf. This follows a four-year wait to capitalize on market momentum. The remaining units will be released later this year.

site_title: CW Group unable to redeem SGD bonds, faces heat from lender
summary: CW Group, a Hong Kong-listed engineering and renewable energy outfit, faces financial difficulties after being unable to redeem SGD bonds and pay a final dividend to shareholders. The company cited unfavourable market conditions since April for its inability to sell Series 2 notes under a S$500 million multi-currency debt issuance programme. CW Group has hired law firms to work on a refinancing plan and received statutory demands from its lender, Bank of China, for immediate repayment of HK$157.5 million and US$14.5 million.

site_title: Wealth managers need to grasp the digital challenge - or risk irrelevance
summary: Wealth managers face a significant threat as high net worth individuals (HNWIs) consider allocating 11-50% of their assets to "BigTech" firms like Amazon, Google, and Alibaba, with 37.5% globally and 61% in Asia-Pacific willing to make the move. Client satisfaction with traditional wealth managers is low, and hybrid models combining digital capabilities with human advice have seen a decline. Incumbents in the industry should not be complacent, as BigTech firms have technological capabilities, efficiency, and user insights, and have already ventured into financial services.

site_title: Cecilia Leong-Faulkner
summary: British Theatre Playhouse founder and managing director Cecilia Leong-Faulkner has a passion for theatre that began at a young age, growing up in 1960s Kuala Lumpur. She founded BTP in 2004 with her husband, actor-producer John Faulkner, and has since produced over 20 shows in Singapore. Leong-Faulkner's latest offering, The Definitive Rat Pack, integrates the songs of Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin, and Sammy Davis Jr with their lively banter, featuring British actors in key roles. The show has received positive reviews, with Leong-Faulkner confident that local audiences will be convinced by the performances.

site_title: Mazda CX-5 review: Growing the economy
summary: Mazda has updated its CX-5 SUV with a mild makeover, introducing a new cylinder deactivation system that can reduce fuel consumption by up to 20% at low speeds. The system, found in the Skyactiv-G 2.5 model, shuts down half the engine to save fuel when cruising. Other updates include improved engine efficiency, new features such as roof rails and a clearer head-up display, and enhancements to the interior's European-style controls. The CX-5 remains known for its handling and appealing responsiveness, making it a standout in its class.

site_title: Cool Beauty
summary: Richard Mille's new RM 71-01 Automatic Tourbillon Talisman watch, created by Cecile Guenat, a talented young woman, has raised watchmaking standards for women's timepieces. The watch, with an automatic tourbillon movement, is a modern, creative, and luxurious piece, inspired by Art Deco and tribal arts. The 10 variations of the watch feature hand-set dials, diamonds, and gemstones, showcasing the brand's ability to produce high-quality timepieces for women. The watch is designed to be worn daily, with a compact and ultra-light mechanism that meets Richard Mille's performance standards.

site_title: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD
summary: A cryptic crossword puzzle was published on June 21, 2018. Key facts include the puzzle's Across clues, such as "Take sailor by canal" with a 6-letter answer, and "An easy putt? Check, if need be" with a 2,1,5-letter answer. The article does not provide further context or conclusions.

site_title: ExxonMobil starts up world's largest resin plant
summary: ExxonMobil has started production at two new plants in Singapore, producing petrochemicals used in adhesives and tyres. The world's largest resin plant, producing 90,000 tonnes of Escorez hydrogenated hydrocarbon resins annually, and a premium halobutyl rubber plant producing 140,000 tonnes per year, have been completed as part of a multi-billion dollar expansion project. The plants will add 140 jobs to ExxonMobil's existing workforce of over 4,000 employees in Singapore, solidifying the country's position as a key producer of fuels and petrochemical products.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) acquired a 50% interest in 11 logistics properties in China for S$213.9 million, increasing its pro forma portfolio valuation and net property income from China to 9% and 11%, respectively. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to tap into the growing Chinese logistics market amid ongoing trade friction between the US and China. Despite this, analysts at OCBC Investment Research have given MLT a fair value of S$1.34, suggesting that the trust remains a buy.

site_title: When 'diversity' is used against Asian Americans
summary: A recent article highlights the phenomenon of Asian Americans excelling academically and financially, challenging the concept of "white privilege." Studies show that Asian Americans have higher median weekly earnings and lower unemployment rates than white Americans. They are also overrepresented in the private sector and own a higher percentage of businesses. The article draws parallels between the success of Asian Americans and that of Jewish immigrants in the 19th and 20th centuries, who also emphasized education and academic achievement. Some argue that Ivy League schools may be applying an "Asian quota" by considering non-academic criteria in the admission process, leading to accusations of racial discrimination.

site_title: M+ For Art
summary: A new exhibition, "In Search of Southeast Asia through the M+ Collections," is on display at the M+ contemporary art museum in Hong Kong until September 30. The show features 70 works by 28 artists, architects, and designers from nine South-east Asian countries, including Hong Kong, the Netherlands, and the US. The exhibition explores the historical and cultural richness of the region through an inter-disciplinary lens and a transnational framework, with notable artists such as Rirkrit Tiravanija and Simryn Gill.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
South-east Asian art at M+.

site_title: Carlyle raises US$6.55b for new Asia fund
summary: Carlyle Group has raised US$6.55 billion for its new Asia fund, surpassing its initial target of US$5 billion and exceeding the previous fund by 65%. The largest-ever Asia fund will seek buyout and strategic investments across various sectors in the region. Carlyle's existing portfolio firms in Asia include stakes in Chinese Internet giant Tencent and Indian pathology laboratory Metropolis Healthcare, generating an 18% net internal rate of return in its previous Asia fund.

site_title: The King Of Shoes
summary: Spanish designer Manolo Blahnik remains the leader in luxury shoemaking after 47 years in the business. His career was boosted by US Vogue's Diana Vreeland's encouragement to focus on shoes, and he gained widespread recognition after his shoes were featured in the hit TV series Sex and the City. Blahnik's designs, known for glamour and beauty, have remained unchanged despite trends, and he continues to collaborate with top designers. He believes in not compromising with fashion desires and sticking to his unique aesthetic. His brand is synonymous with luxury footwear.

site_title: Guggenheim said to weigh stake sale of its asset manager
summary: Guggenheim Partners is exploring the sale of a stake in its $250 billion asset-management unit, led by Scott Minerd, to global insurers, sovereign wealth funds, and investment pools. The deal could involve taking on Munich Re's asset management unit. Minerd aims to diversify the investment base, which is over 90% from US investors. The firm's largest investors, including Sammons Enterprises Inc, are in talks about strategic options. A sale would require agreement from stakeholders, including family members and co-founders.

site_title: Joanna's Song
summary: Singer Joanna Dong is set to perform her two-night concert, "So Here I Am," at the Esplanade Concert Hall on June 30 and July 1. Following her breakout success at the 2017 Sing! China contest, Dong will showcase her versatile vocals across various genres. Tickets are priced from S$38 to S$98 and can be purchased from Sistic. This concert is a follow-up to her breakout performance at the same event in 2017.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Unpacking the ICO hype, in BT Weekend
summary: A recent article discusses the risks and hazards of Initial Coin Offerings (ICOs), cautioning investors to beware of the hype surrounding these cryptocurrency fundraising events. The article highlights the potential for financial losses and emphasizes the need for investors to carefully evaluate the legitimacy and potential of a project before investing. It also touches on other topics, including ESG investing, finance ethics, and technology innovations. The article serves as a warning to investors to approach ICOs with caution and thoroughly research the opportunities before making a decision.

site_title: Chardonnay, the Oregon way
summary: Oregon's chardonnay has significantly improved over the last decade, thanks in part to the influence of renowned Burgundy producers like Dominique Lafon. Producers have taken chardonnay seriously on its own terms, shifting away from imitating California or Burgundy styles. Instead, they focus on the grape's natural acidity, minerality, and herbaceous flavors. Recent tastings of Willamette Valley chardonnays revealed a range of styles, from lively and energetic to rich and nimble, with some producers successfully balancing acidity with oak flavors. The top-rated wines showcased Oregon's direction with the grape, offering a sense of anticipation and promise for the future.

site_title: Swedish builder ignores Trump in bid to make US green again
summary: A Swedish construction company, Skanska, is prioritizing green construction in the US market despite US President Donald Trump's withdrawal from the Paris climate accord. Skanska's senior vice-president, Lena Hok, aims to focus on state-level initiatives to promote a green business agenda. The company reports a growing proportion of revenue from green construction, with a 40% global energy consumption impact from buildings. Skanska aims to capitalize on the cost advantage and growing demand for green construction, issuing its second green bond.

site_title: Emerging markets get bigger with Saudi Arabia and Argentina
summary: Saudi Arabia and Argentina will be added to the MSCI emerging markets equity index, boosting the asset class by $600 billion. The inclusion is expected to attract billions of dollars in foreign investment, particularly in Saudi Arabia, where it could lead to $40 billion in inflows. Argentina's benchmark index is forecast to rally by up to 20% after a peso rout. The additions are seen as a relief rally after a selloff knocked $2.7 trillion from emerging economies since January, amid global trade war and higher US rates.

images.alt_text: The Buenos Aires Stock Exchange (above) plunged 6.55 per cent on Monday, pulled down by sharp falls in prices for energy and bank shares and amid market volatility as Argentina sought aid from the IMF.

site_title: The Fine Art Of Making Dashi
summary: Chef Shigeo Akiba of Shangri-la Singapore's NAMI restaurant shares his expertise on making dashi, a classic Japanese broth, in a monthly class. After 20 years of training under his mentor, Akiba still learns and perfects the art of dashi-making, which involves building blocks of ingredients such as kombu and katsuobushi. Quality ingredients, including premium-grade kombu and katsuobushi, are key to achieving a rich and umami-rich broth. The class, priced at S$118++, includes a four-course set lunch and covers the various types of dashi, including vegetarian options.

site_title: Global talent crunch will push up salaries for highly-skilled S'pore workers: study
summary: A new study by Korn Ferry found that highly-skilled workers in Singapore's manufacturing, financial services, and TMT industries can expect a US$29,100 annual salary increase by 2030 due to a global talent crunch. This places Singapore second among 20 major economies in terms of average wage premium, with profits under pressure. The study estimates a global talent deficit of 85.2 million workers by 2030, adding US$2.5 trillion to company payrolls annually, and suggests that companies should focus on engaging and reskilling existing employees rather than competing for limited talent.

images.alt_text: A highly-skilled employee in the manufacturing, financial services or the TMT (technology, media and telecommunications) industry in Singapore can expect to be paid an extra US$29,100 per year by 2030 as talent shortages loom, a new study by consulting firm Korn Ferry has found.

site_title: Thinking Out Of The Box
summary: Manfred Schmoelz and his wife bought a 1,700 sq ft Robertson Quay apartment despite its smaller size and less-than-ideal layout. Architects William Ng and Kho Keguang of Studio Wills + Architects transformed the space by demolishing internal partition walls, creating a master bedroom and guest room, and installing white oak timber floors. The apartment features a variety of colours, including white, grey, timber, and black, to create a sense of spaciousness and intimacy. The result is a functional and comfortable living space that accommodates the couple's needs for entertaining and relaxation.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: UK borrowing falls more than expected, Hammond under pressure to spend
summary: The UK government borrowed £5 billion in May, lower than expected, with a total deficit of £11.8 billion this financial year, 26% less than in the same period last year. Finance Minister Philip Hammond may face pressure to spend more after years of deficit reduction, as he aims to lower public debt despite a rise in health spending. The borrowing is primarily for long-term investments, not day-to-day spending, and Hammond plans to deliver a £20 billion increase in NHS spending over five years while meeting his fiscal target.

site_title: Like port wine, Portugal's Ronaldo knows how to age best
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo led Portugal to a 1-0 victory over Morocco in the World Cup, scoring a fourth-minute header. The win puts Portugal on the verge of the knockout stage and eliminates Morocco, the first team to be eliminated from the tournament. Ronaldo's performance was described as "exquisite lack of industriousness" by coach Fernando Santos, who likened the forward to port wine that ages best. Despite not being as active as in previous matches, Ronaldo's goal was enough to secure the win, and he praised his team's victory over the loss.

images.alt_text: A good striker only needs to be in the right place once or twice a game to be world-class, and no one in the world spots those one or two places better than Ronaldo.

site_title: Xiaomi secures seven cornerstone investors for US$6.1b HK IPO
summary: Xiaomi secures $548 million from seven cornerstone investors, including Qualcomm, for its Hong Kong IPO of up to $6.1 billion. The company sets a price range of $2.94 to $2.94 per share and values itself at $54.3 billion. Xiaomi's IPO will be the biggest tech float globally in recent years, with the company selling 2.18 billion shares. The delay of its mainland share offering until after the Hong Kong IPO has cast doubt on Beijing's efforts to lure foreign-listed Chinese tech giants back home.

site_title: Crypto pioneer buys Canada's biggest condo in former Trump Tower in Toronto
summary: Crypto pioneer Anthony Di Iorio has bought the largest condominium in Canada, a three-storey penthouse in Toronto's St Regis Residences for C$28 million. The 16,178 sq. ft. unit features a wrap-around patio overlooking the city skyline. Di Iorio, a co-founder of Ethereum, is the owner of Decentral, an innovation hub focused on blockchain projects. This purchase may not be the most expensive, with a Four Seasons penthouse in the city valued at C$31 million.

site_title: Coal is being squeezed out of power by cheap renewables
summary: Renewable energy sources, such as wind and solar power, are expected to dominate the power generation market by 2050, with 85% of $11.5 trillion in investment going towards zero-emissions technologies. Coal, however, will be squeezed out due to plunging costs and improved grid flexibility, with natural gas becoming a preferred choice for utilities seeking guaranteed generation capacity. Despite this, the decline of coal will not be enough to meet the 2°C temperature target, and renewables will remain increasingly attractive due to falling costs, with solar energy capacity expected to peak in the 2030s.

site_title: Australian telco MNF to acquire Singapore's SuperInternet
summary: MNF Group, an Australian telecommunications firm, has agreed to acquire Singapore-based SuperInternet Group for S$2 million. The acquisition is expected to be finalized before July 31, 2018, and will provide MNF with a fully interconnected voice network infrastructure, domestic dark fibre transmission, and specialist staff in the Singapore market. SuperInternet generates around S$1.6 million in revenue and breaks even on its Ebitda. The deal is part of MNF's Asian expansion strategy, aiming to replicate its successful Australian and New Zealand-based business model in Singapore.

site_title: Former employee sued by Tesla says he was a whistleblower
summary: A former Tesla employee, Martin Tripp, has been sued by the company, alleging he hacked into internal systems and stole confidential photos and video of manufacturing systems. However, Tripp claims he is a whistleblower who reported "dangerously punctured batteries" and raw-material waste, sparking a lawsuit that highlights paranoia over information theft in the automotive industry. Tesla's CEO, Elon Musk, has suggested Tripp may be a corporate saboteur, but Tripp denies hacking and claims he was fired after speaking out.

site_title: MyRepublic moves into telco space; launches 3 mobile plans
summary: MyRepublic, a Singaporean internet service provider, has launched three mobile plans, offering users from 7GB to 25GB of high-speed data at rates starting from S$35. The mobile network rides on StarHub's existing infrastructure as a mobile virtual network operator. Existing MyRepublic broadband customers receive extra data, and users can add more data on a one-time or recurring basis. Plans are contract-free, with free caller ID, SIM card activation, and local talktime and SMS. Users can change plans anytime without extra charge, but overseas roaming data is only available with a separate bundle.

site_title: Theresa May sees off rebels, allowing freedom to negotiate Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May narrowly escaped a vote loss in Parliament and leadership threat after Tory rebels voted for the European Union Withdrawal Bill. Despite this, May vowed to unite the country and party to secure the best Brexit deal, with a "White Paper" on coming negotiations to be produced soon. The UK faces a critical period with the June 28-29 EU summit looming as a deadline to produce answers on the UK's customs relationship with the EU and Northern Ireland.

site_title: STI falls 0.5% on poor market sentiment
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.5% due to poor market sentiment, with a decline of 15.9 points, as trade tensions cast a long shadow over the region. Analysts warn of protracted negativity, citing the US's new tariffs against China, Europe, and Canada. The US-China trade spat continues to impact global markets, with experts predicting a prolonged downturn.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Business should take heed of warnings and be ready for a hard Brexit
summary: The European Union is likely to issue a warning to businesses to prepare for a hard Brexit, also known as a "cliff-edge" Brexit, as negotiations between the EU and the UK appear to be heading towards a no-deal scenario. A hard Brexit would create gaps in regulations and increase costs for businesses, particularly in the car industry, agriculture, and finance. The UK's financial services industry is also at risk, with 77% of ACCA members saying a hard Brexit would be damaging to their business. The EU and UK governments have been downplaying the risk of a no-deal Brexit, but experts warn that it could have severe consequences, including lost revenue and job losses.

images.alt_text: The EU, frustrated by a UK side that has nothing to offer, has been talking about the likelihood of a hard Brexit for more than a year, but that could be just a demonstration of willingness to walk away from the table.

site_title: Major developers vie for Sengkang Central site
summary: Major developers in Singapore, including CapitaLand Singapore, City Developments Ltd, and Perennial Singapore, have submitted bids for the 37,284.8-sqm Sengkang Central site, which is zoned for commercial and residential use. Seven bids were received, with consortiums and big players in the property market dominating the submissions. The site, located next to the Buangkok MRT station, is expected to generate around 700 units or a maximum gross floor area of 78,299 sqm, and will be awarded to the tenderer with the highest bid price.

site_title: A US-China trade war upends long-standing practices
summary: The US-China trade war has escalated, with US President Donald Trump imposing 25% tariffs on Chinese exports worth $50 billion and threatening additional tariffs on $200 billion more. China has retaliated with similar tariffs on US exports, sparking concerns about the future of the post-World War II international trading system. Economists are divided on the impact, with some arguing it will have a minimal effect on the US economy, while others warn it could lead to recession. The trade war poses a dilemma, as China's mercantilist policies are seen as unfair, but Trump's proposed remedies are also criticized for being too harsh.

site_title: Sengkang Central mixed-use GLS site receives seven tender submissions
summary: Sengkang Central, a mixed-use GLS site in Singapore, received seven tender submissions after its launch under the government land sale program. The submissions came from major developers, including CapitaLand Singapore, City Developments Ltd, and Perennial Singapore, as well as Chinese developers MCC Land and Grantral Land. The site will be awarded based on concept proposals and price envelopes, with a 40% weightage for quality of design and 30% for public realm, and 30% for track record. The evaluation criteria will determine the successful tenderer.

site_title: Cushman & Wakefield files for US IPO
summary: Cushman & Wakefield has filed for a US$100 million initial public offering (IPO) to reduce debt and make deferred payments to employees. The commercial real estate firm, backed by private equity firms TPG and PAG Asia Capital, plans to use the proceeds for general corporate purposes and employee payments totaling US$112 million.

site_title: Intel CEO Krzanich resigns after relationship with employee
summary: Intel CEO Brian Krzanich resigned after a consensual relationship with an employee was discovered, violating company policies. CFO Robert Swan took over as interim CEO while the board searches for a permanent replacement. Despite this change, analysts believe Intel's stability and strategy will remain unchanged, as the company continues to perform well financially. The incident marks the latest in a string of CEOs forced out for similar reasons, highlighting a growing trend of boards being less tolerant of CEOs behaving badly.

site_title: Not So Marvellous
summary: Marvel Studios' 10-year celebration exhibition at ArtScience Museum in Singapore features life-size figures and artefacts from various Marvel titles. The exhibition includes sections dedicated to Iron Man, Thor, Black Panther, and Doctor Strange, but lacks significant interactive elements and interesting artefacts. The museum's attempt to inject science into science fiction is evident, but the overall experience feels underwhelming, catering mainly to die-hard fans. The exhibition runs until September 30.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Opec strives for oil deal as Iran insists on modest rise in output
summary: OPEC is set to discuss a potential oil output increase amid rising global demand, with Saudi Arabia and Russia proposing a 1.5 million barrel per day (bpd) boost. Iran, however, is insisting on a modest rise, citing concerns about external pressure and demand justification. The organization's leader, Saudi Arabia, aims to prevent a supply deficit of up to 1.8 million bpd in the second half of 2018, which could lead to higher oil prices. A compromise increase of 0.5-0.6 million bpd is being considered.

site_title: SIA group to transfer SilkAir planes to Scoot as short-haul fight heats up
summary: SINGAPORE AIRLINES will transfer several SilkAir 737-800 aircraft to budget arm Scoot to compete on short-haul routes. The planes will be reconfigured from 162 business and economy seats to all-economy seating. The transfer is expected to take place in late 2018 or early 2019, with Scoot likely to see significant capacity growth. The move aims to improve profitability and strengthen the group's overall positioning. SilkAir will remain on routes with high premium traffic or connecting traffic to SIA's network.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
Singapore Airlines (SIA) will transfer some of SilkAir's aircraft to budget arm Scoot to compete more effectively on short-haul routes in the latest move under its ongoing transformation programme.

site_title: Intel CEO resigns after probe into relationship with employee
summary: Intel CEO Brian Krzanich resigned immediately after a probe revealed a past consensual relationship with an employee violated company policy. Krzanich had been in the role since 2013. CFO Robert Swan will serve as interim CEO, and the board will search for a permanent replacement. Intel forecast better-than-expected Q2 revenue and profit, with $16.9 billion in revenue and 99 cents per share in adjusted profit.

site_title: Dollar hits fresh 11-month high on trade war fears
summary: The US dollar reached an 11-month high against a basket of major currencies on Thursday, driven by concerns over a prolonged trade war between the US and China, as well as anti-euro voices in the eurozone. The euro fell to its lowest level since July 2017, while the eurozone's third-largest economy, Italy, appointed two eurosceptics to key finance committees, fueling worries. The dollar index rose half a percent to 95.483, and long-term Treasury yields bounced back from three-week lows.

site_title: BC cracks down on homes' 'hidden ownership'
summary: British Columbia is preparing legislation to crack down on "hidden ownership" in real estate, aiming to combat tax evasion, money laundering, and fueling a housing crisis. The proposed law requires corporations, trustees, and partnerships to disclose true ownership and control of properties, including names, nationalities, and identification numbers. The move follows concerns over overheated housing prices in Vancouver, driven by foreign buyers and wealthy new immigrants. The law is part of the NDP government's broader plan to create more affordable housing and combat real estate speculation.

site_title: The heat is on at Chengdu
summary: A new Sichuan restaurant in Amoy Street, Chengdu 74, brings authentic and spicy flavors to Singapore, offering a unique dining experience. The restaurant, run by transplanted chefs from Chengdu, has made some concessions to cater to local tastes, but the menu remains true to its roots. Dishes such as cold skewers, spicy beef with bean curd, and Chengdu-style dumplings showcase the restaurant's commitment to authentic Sichuan cuisine, despite some imperfections in presentation and cleanliness. Overall, the restaurant is a refreshing change for adventurous foodies.

site_title: Can Mazda save the petrol engine?
summary: Mazda's Skyactiv-X technology, a homogeneous charge compression ignition (HCCI) method, may extend the life of petrol engines. The technology, set to debut in Singapore in 2019, aims to improve fuel efficiency and reduce emissions, potentially matching electric vehicles. With the ability to deliver up to 30% fuel efficiency and torque improvements, Skyactiv-X could help petrol engines remain relevant for decades, with Mazda predicting 84% of cars will still be powered by internal combustion engines 30 years from now.

site_title: North Korean airline Air Koryo plans new route to China's Xian
summary: North Korea's Air Koryo plans to launch a new route from Pyongyang to Xian, China, in the latest sign of the country's potential re-emergence from isolation. The route, which would make Xian the fifth Chinese city with a direct flight to Pyongyang, aims to boost tourism between the two countries. This follows a visit by North Korean leader Kim Jong Un to Beijing, where the US has offered relief from UN sanctions in exchange for North Korea's nuclear disarmament. The new route is expected to increase travel convenience and satisfaction for Xian citizens visiting Pyongyang.

site_title: Ho Bee may have last laugh by eschewing crowded Singapore market for London
summary: Ho Bee Land has acquired Ropemaker Place in London for £650 million (S$1.16 billion), boosting its total investment portfolio to £1.3 billion (S$2.4 billion). This move shifts the company's focus from property development to investment, potentially forgoing higher profit margins. Despite Brexit concerns, London remains attractive to overseas investors. The acquisition provides a stable source of recurring income, with a 4.7% net yield. Ho Bee's decision may be seen as a strategic move to diversify its portfolio and reduce risks, particularly in the volatile Singapore residential market.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: GIC invests in US-based technology firm Verra Mobility
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has invested in US-based technology firm Verra Mobility through a US$400 million private placement. Verra Mobility, which will be publicly listed after a merger with Gores Holdings II, is valued at approximately US$2.4 billion post-merger. The investment is part of a larger transaction that includes US$400 million of cash held in Gores Holdings II's trust account. Verra Mobility develops technology-enabled solutions and is a portfolio company of Platinum Equity.

site_title: Edmund Cheng to replace Lee Hsien Yang as CAAS chairman
summary: Edmund Cheng will replace Lee Hsien Yang as chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) on July 1, 2018. Cheng, who has been CAAS' deputy chairman since 2016, brings extensive experience in the private and public sectors, including roles at Mapletree Investments, the Singapore Art Museum, and Singapore Airlines. Under Lee's tenure, Singapore has developed as an aviation hub, with significant growth in air traffic and cargo throughput, and the CAAS has implemented various initiatives to modernize the aviation safety regime and establish Singapore as a Centre of Excellence in air traffic management.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: New Zealand prime minister gives birth to baby girl
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern gave birth to a baby girl in an Auckland hospital, becoming the second world leader to do so while in office. Ardern, 37, and her partner Clarke Gayford, 40, welcomed a healthy 3.3-kilogramme baby girl. The birth marks an eventful year for Ardern, who became prime minister in October 2017 and took six weeks maternity leave.

site_title: LifeBrandz unit not acquiring Ramen Champion
summary: LifeBrandz has called off its proposed acquisition of Ramen Champion, a restaurant operator, after a non-binding memorandum of understanding (MOU) was terminated. The deal was set to be financed by a director's loan from LifeBrandz's CEO, but the companies mutually agreed not to proceed. This move comes after LifeBrandz announced plans to start a new sushi restaurant business led by sushi chef Hatch Hashida, with new locations in Singapore, San Francisco, and Tokyo. The decision will not impact LifeBrandz's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Trump is said to plan meeting with Putin in Europe in July
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to meet with Vladimir Putin in Europe in July, with possible meetings before or after Trump's visit to Britain. The White House declined to comment, while Putin's spokesman declined to discuss the plans. Trump has shown interest in restoring Russia's international standing, despite a rocky relationship between the two countries. The meeting would be Trump's third with Putin, following their 2017 meetings in Hamburg, Germany.

site_title: Trump's metal tariffs have yielded more than US$775m so far
summary: The Trump administration has collected over $775 million in tariffs from steel and aluminum imports, with the total expected to top $1 billion within six weeks. Lawmakers from both parties criticize the tariffs as a harmful approach that draws retaliation, hurts the economy, and increases costs for businesses. The Commerce Department has received over 22,500 requests for exclusions, but only 44% have been posted, with many small businesses complaining about the process.

site_title: Najib's 1MDB denials unbelievable, says Mahathir
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir criticized his predecessor Najib Razak for denying involvement in the 1MDB scandal, calling his denials "unbelievable." Najib claimed he knew nothing about millions of dollars from the state fund appearing in his personal bank account, but Mahathir pointed out that Najib's signature was found on documents related to the funds. The new government has relaunched investigations into 1MDB, which has led to allegations of embezzlement, bribery, and abuse of power against Najib.

site_title: Heineken takes minority stake in London's Beavertown Brewery for £40m
summary: Heineken has taken a minority stake in London's Beavertown Brewery for £40 million, providing the craft beer maker with the necessary funding to build a new 450,000 hectolitre brewery and visitor site. The new facility will increase brewing capacity tenfold, creating up to 150 new jobs. Heineken's investment will allow Beavertown to pursue its dream of "Beaverworld," a visitor site featuring the brewery. This is Heineken's latest addition to its craft beer portfolio, following deals with Brixton Brewery and Lagunitas.

site_title: Sunpower wins 105 million yuan tender from Chinese stainless steel manufacturer
summary: Sunpower Group has won a 105 million yuan (S$22 million) tender from Chinese stainless steel manufacturer Shanxi Taigang Stainless Steel to provide flue gas desulphurisation (FGD) engineering, procurement, and construction services for its coking plant. As part of a tripartite consortium, Sunpower will undertake about 60% of the project, expected to be completed by the end of 2018, and is expected to have a positive impact on the company's financial performance. This is Sunpower's fourth FGD tender secured this year, and will allow the company to expand its green investments business.

site_title: Germany pockets 2.9b euros from Greece bailouts
summary: Germany has earned approximately 2.9 billion euros ($4.6 billion) since 2010 from Greek debt bought to help the struggling country. The figure was revealed in a government report, contradicting right-wing myths that Germany profited from the crisis. The Bundesbank earned 3.4 billion euros in interest on Greek bonds, with 527 million euros sent to Greece in 2013. The European Stability Mechanism (ESM) has also received 1.8 billion euros, with 400 million euros paid to Greece.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks end down
summary: Hong Kong and mainland Chinese stocks ended the day down more than one percent due to worries about a China-US trade war reversing early bargain-buying. The Hang Seng Index fell 1.35%, the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.37%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index shed 2.13%. These declines follow a previous 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong performance in the US market, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Israel PM Netanyahu's wife charged with US$100,000 meal fraud
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's wife, Sara, was charged with US$100,000 meal fraud and breach of trust after a police probe. This is the latest legal issue for the Netanyahu family, amid investigations into corruption cases. The Jerusalem district prosecutor filed the charges, which Sara Netanyahu allegedly falsely claimed meals worth the amount.

site_title: Luxury sneakers: high style and a booming market
summary: Luxury sneakers have become a booming market, with limited-edition collaborations between sportswear and fashion labels, rappers, and athletes fetching tens of thousands of dollars. The market has grown globally, with the US, Europe, and Asia being major hubs. The resale market is estimated to be around $1 billion, with online sales accounting for 90% of Stadium Goods' total sales. The company plans to open more stores in the US and abroad, and is targeting women as a key demographic to expand the market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 17.43 points to 1,692.32. Losers outnumbered gainers 748 to 199, with a total volume of 2.1 billion lots worth RM2.7 billion.

site_title: Bawah, A Private Paradise
summary: Bawah Reserve, a private island resort in Indonesia, offers an eco-luxury experience with 70 guest accommodations, six forested islands, three lagoons, and 13 beaches. The resort is located 300 km northeast of Singapore and can be reached in under four hours by ferry and seaplane. With a focus on conservation, Bawah grows 80% of its vegetables and 60% of its fruit, and has a zero plastic bottle policy. The resort offers various activities, including snorkeling, diving, and meditation, and is committed to supporting local villagers through its BAF foundation.

images.alt_text: The night skies of Bawah are filled with stars.
Feast on seafood fresh off the boat, grilled and served in an umami broth.
Finding Nemo at Bawah.
Doe-eyed lionfish in the Anambas are an easy and pretty target for the underwater photography enthusiast.
Relax in a copper bath while being serenaded by the sounds of lapping waves.

site_title: Thai May exports rise 11.4 pct y-o-y, beat forecast
summary: Thailand's customs-cleared annual exports rose 11.44% in May from a year earlier, beating the forecast of a 9.8% increase. This marks a faster pace than the 12.34% jump in April. The export growth is a key driver of Thai growth, and the exceeding forecast is seen as a positive sign for the country's economy.

site_title: EU opens investigation into free flow of gas sold by Qatar
summary: The European Commission has launched an investigation into Qatar Petroleum's sale of liquefied natural gas (LNG) in Europe, focusing on whether agreements restrict the free flow of gas and harm competition. EU Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager stated that such clauses may prevent consumers from enjoying an integrated European energy market. The investigation aims to ensure the free flow of gas and promote competition in the European energy sector.

site_title: China unit won't surrender seals, claims it did not appropriate rental monies: China Environment
summary: China Environment, an industrial waste gas treatment company, says its Chinese unit will not hand over control of its funds despite allegations of misappropriation of rental income. Anhui Dongyuan Environmental Protection Co, citing pressure from a Chinese creditor, claims it did not misappropriate any monies. The company had previously requested the unit's management hand over company seals, but they declined. Trading in China Environment shares is currently suspended. China Environment is seeking advice on subsequent actions and will update shareholders.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets ahead at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded slightly in opening deals on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.4% to 7,658.07 points. The eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also gained 0.3% and 0.4% respectively. Investors remain cautious over the ongoing global trade war, particularly the China-US trade spat. Analysts warn that the modest rebound may not be a sign of investors getting used to the idea of a trade war, but rather a sense of stability returning before escalation risks resurface.

site_title: Chanel posts sales of almost US$10b, rivalling Louis Vuitton
summary: Chanel has reported nearly US$10 billion in sales for 2018, rivaling luxury leader Louis Vuitton. The company's profit reached US$1.8 billion, driven by an 11% sales increase on a constant-currency basis. Chanel's cosmetics division contributed to its growth, fueled by new fragrances and ready-to-wear collections. The disclosure fuels a competition for bragging rights among top fashion brands, with Gucci aiming to surpass Louis Vuitton in revenue.

images.alt_text: The closely held French fashion house published its financial results for the first time, recording a profit of US$1.8 billion last year on sales of US$9.6 billion.

site_title: Court to hear Hyflux unit's application for debt moratorium on July 6
summary: Hyflux's subsidiary Tuaspring will have its application for a debt moratorium heard at the Supreme Court of Singapore on July 6. Tuaspring seeks a stay on creditor claims under the Companies Act to facilitate a court-supervised restructuring process. The company has a total bank debt of S$518.4 million, excluding deposits in reserve accounts and fixed deposit accounts. A six-month reprieve from creditors was granted to Hyflux and three other subsidiaries earlier, but Tuaspring was excluded.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes higher despite trade war fears
summary: Tokyo's main stock market closed higher on June 21, 2018, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.61% to 22,693.04, driven by a cheaper yen supporting shares. Investors shrugged off concerns of a US-China trade war, focusing on the US economy's strong performance. Takeda Pharmaceutical, Sony, and SoftBank rallied on positive earnings reports, while steel companies fell. The dollar edged up to 110.87 yen, further supporting the market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: ExxonMobil launched the world's largest resin plant in Singapore, producing petrochemicals for adhesives and tires. A study predicts Singapore workers will receive a $29,100 annual pay increase by 2030 due to a global talent crunch. Internet service provider MyRepublic entered the telco space with three mobile plans. A summons was filed to block Singapore Myanmar Investco's $10.8 million TPR divestment.
