CW Group faces statutory demands for non-payment of Singapore dollar-denominated bonds.

site_title: Bank of England keeps key rate at 0.5%
summary: The Bank of England kept its key interest rate at 0.5% in its June meeting, as expected by some analysts. Policymakers voted 6-3 to maintain the rate, indicating a possible hike at the next meeting in August. The central bank also kept its quantitative easing stimulus policy unchanged, pumping £445 billion into the UK economy. The decision suggests the Bank of England is closer to the European Central Bank's outlook, with a potential rate hike likely to come slowly and in modest steps. The pound rallied against the US dollar on the news.

site_title: Trading in Lee Metal shares suspended as BRC Asia takeover offer closes
summary: MAINBOARD-listed steel fabricator Lee Metal Group suspended trading in its shares due to the takeover bid by BRC Asia pushing public ownership below 10% threshold. As of the close of the offer, Lee Metal received 96.34% valid acceptances and BRC Asia holds 1.09% of issued shares. The takeover bid priced Lee Metal shares at S$0.42 apiece and was approved by Singapore's competition watchdog. The acquisition aims to delist Lee Metal and tap business synergies.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: China's Weibo blocks comedian John Oliver after Xi Jinping roasting
summary: China's Twitter-like microblogging service Weibo has blocked and deleted posts referencing British comedian John Oliver after he criticized the country's human rights record and mocked President Xi Jinping on his show. Oliver's segment on HBO featured criticism of China's consolidation of power, the "Belt and Road" initiative, and censorship of Winnie the Pooh images. The blockage came after a similar incident last year, when Weibo removed a fanpage of John Oliver's show after it interviewed the Dalai Lama. The move has sparked concern among fans and supporters of the comedian.

site_title: Trade war starts to hit businesses with Daimler cutting outlook
summary: Daimler AG, a German luxury-car maker, cut its profit outlook and blamed escalating trade tensions for the decline, citing fewer Chinese customers buying Mercedes-Benz SUVs due to tariffs on autos imported from the US. The company, which exports over $1 billion in vehicles to China last year, now expects full-year earnings to be slightly lower than last year. This move follows similar warnings from other companies, such as MillerCoors, amid rising prospect of an all-out trade war.

images.alt_text: Daimler AG became the most visible global corporation to cut its profit outlook and blame it on escalating trade tensions, saying fewer Chinese customers will buy Mercedes-Benz SUVs because of tariffs Beijing is slapping on autos imported from the US

site_title: US: Dow drops at open, technology stocks boost Nasdaq
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average opened lower on Thursday due to ongoing US-China trade concerns, but technology stocks boosted the S&P 500 and Nasdaq. The Dow fell 18.59 points, or 0.08%, to 24,639.21. In contrast, the S&P 500 rose 1.96 points, or 0.07%, to 2,769.28, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 18.78 points, or 0.24%, to 7,800.30.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 18.59 points, or 0.08 per cent, at the open to 24,639.21.

site_title: China Vice-Premier Liu to meet EU delegation next week
summary: Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He will meet with a senior European Union delegation in Beijing next week, marking an important juncture in their economic dialogue. The meeting is ahead of a China-EU summit likely to be held in China in July. This meeting is significant as it comes at a time when China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Guide to: Doing business in Yangon
summary: Yangon, Myanmar is emerging as a prime city for business in the region due to economic reforms and a growing labor force. The city accounts for 23% of the country's GDP and is home to 64% of enterprises under the Myanmar Investment Law. Key business must-knows include regulations, tax regimes, and operational costs. Companies must register with the Directorate of Investment and Company Administration and pay corporate income tax rates ranging from 20-25%. The city offers incentives such as corporate tax holidays and special economic zones, and has a daily minimum wage of MMK 4,800 for skilled workers.

site_title: Guilt-Free Dining
summary: The Butcher's Wife, a new restaurant by Spa Esprit Group, has opened in Tiong Bahru, Singapore, with a focus on gluten-free cuisine. The restaurant, designed by consultant chef Diego Jacquet, offers modern European fare with dishes such as Cured Salmon and Grilled Octopus, all made with gluten-free ingredients. The menu caters to gluten-intolerant individuals and those with coeliac disease, with options including beef burgers and grass-fed grilled Argentine rib eye. The restaurant is located at 19 Yong Siak Street and can be reached at 6221-9307.

site_title: Singapore shares close down by 0.48% on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed down 0.48% on Thursday, ending at 3,300, with 1.86 billion shares worth S$1.02 billion traded. Losers outpaced gainers 250 to 147, following a brief rally in the previous session. The decline comes amid market uncertainty, with investors focusing on tariff issues and split Fed views.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Emerging markets grow by US$600b with Saudis, Argentina
summary: Emerging markets are set to receive a $600 billion boost as Saudi Arabia and Argentina are added to the MSCI equity index of developing nations. The inclusion is expected to attract billions of dollars in foreign investment, with Saudi Arabia's market potentially seeing inflows of up to $40 billion and Argentina's benchmark index rallying by 20%. The upgrade is seen as a game-changer for Saudi Arabia's capital markets, with modernization efforts aimed at diversifying the economy away from oil. However, analysts note that Argentina still faces significant economic challenges and the inclusion does not guarantee long-term success.

site_title: Australian telecoms firm MNF to acquire Singapore's SuperInternet Group
summary: Australian telecoms firm MNF Group has agreed to acquire Singapore-based SuperInternet Group for approximately S$2 million. The deal is expected to be finalized by July 31, 2018, pending customary regulatory approvals. SuperInternet operates niche facilities-based services.

site_title: Trump orders halt to family separations
summary: President Donald Trump ordered an end to the separation of migrant children from their parents at the US border, reversing a policy under heavy pressure from Republicans, Democrats, and the international community. The policy change comes after 2,300 children were separated from their parents since May 5, with no plan in place to reunite the children. Trump said the policy will remain "equally tough" while keeping families together, and the order suggests the government intends to challenge an existing statute limiting detention time.

site_title: Malaysia to inject RM2.8b to complete TRX City
summary: Malaysia has announced a plan to inject RM2.8 billion into completing the TRX City project, an integrated financial district that was partially funded by 1MDB funds diverted for debt repayment. The move aims to alleviate concerns among investors about the project's fate. The TRX City project, which includes the nearly-complete Exchange 106, the tallest building in Southeast Asia, had faced financial uncertainty due to the 1MDB scandal. The government's decision is seen as a step to stabilize the project and boost investor confidence.

site_title: Asia: Markets edge up as calm returns but fears remain
summary: Asian markets edged up on Thursday as investors regained a sense of stability after a tumultuous week, despite ongoing concerns over the China-US trade spat. The US Nasdaq hit a new record close, while Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney rose, with Seoul and Wellington also showing gains. However, analysts warned that the next market downturn could come at any moment, and central bankers expressed concerns about the impact of a trade war on the global economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose slightly in the first few minutes of trade on Thursday, stabilizing after the start of the week's ructions, with the Hang Seng Index climbing 0.28% to 29,779.71. Despite investors remaining on edge over a possible China-US trade war, markets are expected to stabilize.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon trading at 3,307.61, down 0.3% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Thursday at 3,307.61, down 0.3% from the previous day's close, with the Straits Times Index dropping 8.29 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 161 to 121, with 951.2 million shares worth S$449.5 million changing hands. Key movers included Nico Steel Holdings and Noble Group, while Venture Corp and Wilmar International also experienced significant price movements.

site_title: CW Group says unable to redeem SGD bonds; faces statutory demands from lender
summary: CW Group, a Hong Kong-listed engineering and renewable energy company, is unable to redeem SGD bonds and pay a final dividend due to its inability to raise new money from investors. The company received statutory demands from its lender, Bank of China, for immediate repayment of HK$157.5 million and US$14.5 million. CW Group had attempted to sell Series 2 notes under a S$500 million multi-currency debt issuance program, but was unable to do so due to unfavorable market conditions. The company has hired advisors to work on a refinancing plan.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.47 points to 1,709.28. Trading volume was 21.98 million lots worth RM11.95 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 100 to 46.

site_title: Salaries for highly-skilled Singapore workers set to surge due to global talent crunch: study
summary: Singapore workers in the manufacturing, financial services, or technology sectors can expect a US$29,100 (S$39,500) increase in salaries by 2030 due to a global talent crunch, according to a Korn Ferry study. This represents the second-highest average wage premium among 20 major economies. The shortage may put pressure on profits, as employers need to pay above normal inflation increases to secure top talent. The study's findings suggest a significant shift in the labor market, with employers competing for highly-skilled workers to stay competitive.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won weaken on foreign selling amid trade woes
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index and the won weakened on Thursday amid trade tensions between the US and China, with the Kospi down 1.10% and the won down 0.69% from its previous close. Foreigners were net sellers of 128.16 billion won worth of shares, contributing to the decline. The US dollar has risen 4.18% against the won this year, with the won's high for the year at 1,053.55 per US dollar and low at 1,116.45.

site_title: Carlyle raises US$6.55b for new Asia fund
summary: Carlyle Group has raised US$6.55 billion for its Asia private equity fund, exceeding its initial target of US$5 billion. The fund will focus on buyout and strategic investments across various sectors in the region. Carlyle's existing portfolio firms in Asia have generated an 18% net internal rate of return in its previous US$3.9 billion Asia fund. The firm's Asia fundraising is part of a growing trend of investor interest in the region, with a total of 342 funds raising US$107 billion in Asia last year.

site_title: Millionaire Australia developer jailed for ordering killing
summary: A 70-year-old Australian millionaire developer, Ron Medich, was sentenced to 39 years in prison for ordering the 2009 murder of Scottish-born property tycoon Michael McGurk in Sydney. Medich had also organized the intimidation of McGurk's wife. The conviction came after a second trial, with Medich found guilty of both crimes. The actual killer remains unknown, with four other men previously jailed in connection with the case. Medich will be eligible for parole in 2048.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Midas, MTQ, RHT Health Trust
summary: Midas Holdings has irregularities worth 755 million yuan in transactions, while MTQ Corporation reported three consecutive years of losses. RHT Health Trust received all outstanding amounts due from Fortis Healthcare for FY18.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.1% to 3,318.5
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 2.6 points to 3,318.5, up 0.1% at 9:05 am on Thursday. Noble Group led gains, rising 9% to S$0.096, while QT Vascular and YZJ Shipbuilding SG also saw significant increases. A total of 49 million shares worth S$69.2 million were traded.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as trade war fears linger
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on June 21, 2018, due to lingering US-China trade war fears. The Nikkei 225 index edged down 0.23% to 22,502.54, while the Topix index fell 0.16%. US Commerce Secretary pledged to continue punitive tariffs on China, contributing to market uncertainty.

site_title: US lawmakers want Google to reconsider links to China's Huawei
summary: US lawmakers have asked Google to reconsider its partnership with Chinese telecommunications firm Huawei, citing it as a security threat. The lawmakers expressed disappointment over Google's decision not to renew "Project Maven", an artificial intelligence research partnership with the US Department of Defence. They argue that Google prioritizes the Chinese Communist Party over the US military, sparking concerns about the company's commitment to national security. The lawmakers urge Google to reevaluate its collaboration with Huawei and consider the implications for US interests.

site_title: Salaries for highly-skilled Singapore workers set to surge due to global talent crunch: study
summary: A new study by Korn Ferry predicts that highly-skilled workers in Singapore will see a US$29,100 (S$39,500) annual salary increase by 2030 due to a global talent crunch. This would put Singapore companies under pressure, with the second-highest average wage premium among 20 major economies. The estimated talent deficit of 85.2 million workers could add US$2.5 trillion to company payrolls annually. To mitigate this, companies should focus on engaging and reskilling current workers, rather than competing for limited talent.

site_title: Australia's A$144b income tax cuts seen boosting PM re-election bid
summary: Australia passed a $144 billion package of income tax cuts after One Nation leader Pauline Hanson backed the legislation, potentially boosting Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's re-election bid. The seven-year plan aims to boost the economy and deliver a political victory for the centre-right government. The bill's passage is seen as a significant victory for Turnbull, who trails the opposition Labor Party in opinion polls ahead of a likely general election. The tax cuts are expected to benefit low and middle-income earners, while higher earners will receive fewer benefits.

images.alt_text: Australia passed a A$144 billion (S$144.5 billion) package of income tax cuts on Thursday after right-wing leader Pauline Hanson backed the legislation, potentially boosting the re-election prospects of the centre-right government.

site_title: S$5m value in PropNex prospectus for agents' transfer causing a stir
summary: A S$5 million value is attributed to PropNex Realty's business takeover agreement with Dennis Wee Realty in the company's IPO prospectus, sparking controversy as it was previously stated to have no dollar value. The prospectus also reveals a difference between unaudited and audited revenue and profit figures for the fiscal year 2016. This discrepancy has raised questions about the accuracy of PropNex's financial reporting.

site_title: MyRepublic moves into telco space, launching 3 mobile plans for all users
summary: MyRepublic, an internet service provider, has launched three mobile plans in Singapore, offering 7GB, 12GB, and 25GB of monthly high-speed data for S$35, S$55, and S$85 respectively. The plans ride on StarHub's existing infrastructure and come with contract-free options, free caller ID, and 1,000 minutes of local talktime and 1,000 free SMS each month. Users can add extra data on a one-time or recurring basis. The plans do not offer overseas roaming data, but MyRepublic plans to launch more mobile plans, including phone bundles, in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Internet service provider MyRepublic has moved into the telco space, offering three mobile plans for all users from Thursday (June 21).

site_title: Raising awareness of diversity through mentoring
summary: Accenture aims to become the most inclusive and diverse company in the world through various initiatives. The consulting firm partnered with SG Enable's RISE Mentorship program, mentoring seven students with disabilities over three runs. One student, Lionel Tan, who is deaf, was hired as an IT consultant after a 12-week mentoring period. Accenture's goal is to focus on individuals' abilities, not disabilities, and increase awareness of different types and impacts of disabilities to reduce perceived barriers in recruitment.

site_title: UK set to publish plans for EU citizens post-Brexit
summary: The UK is set to publish plans for new immigration rules for EU citizens living in the UK after Brexit. The Home Office will outline details of the UK's settlement scheme, allowing EU citizens and their families to apply for a new UK immigration status. The plans, due to be phased in later this year, will provide clarity on who is eligible, costs, and operating procedures. The UK is calling on the EU to provide similar plans for British nationals living in the bloc, citing concerns about the lack of support for British citizens abroad.

site_title: New Zealand economy cools as construction slows
summary: New Zealand's economy grew 0.5% in the first quarter of the year, slightly below expectations, as construction activity slowed. This brings the annual expansion rate to 2.7%. The slowdown in construction activity is attributed to a decrease in building activity, but economists do not expect any near-term interest rate hikes. The data aligns with forecasts and follows a 0.6% expansion in the previous quarter.

site_title: China's wheat output set to drop sharply in wake of bad weather
summary: China's wheat output is expected to drop 15-20% this crop year due to bad weather, potentially boosting imports and increasing international prices. The country's domestic supply will be significantly reduced after droughts and heavy rains damaged crops in major producing provinces. China's increased demand for wheat could lead to higher prices, with Canada and Russia set to capitalize on the shortage. The US, however, is unlikely to benefit due to trade tensions, and Japan and South Korea have suspended Canadian wheat imports over concerns about genetically modified wheat.

site_title: Daimler cuts profit forecast, blaming US-China tariffs
summary: Daimler, the German luxury carmaker, cut its 2018 profit forecast due to US-China tariffs on cars exported to China, citing fewer SUV sales and higher costs. The company blames the tariffs, imposed after US President Trump announced 25% duties on $50 billion in Chinese imports, for its reduced profit forecast. Daimler also warned of sales impact from stricter European fuel efficiency test procedures and a mass recall of diesel vehicles. The company now predicts an underlying profit slightly lower than last year.

site_title: Pete Davidson confirms engagement to Ariana Grande
summary: Pete Davidson, 24, confirmed on "The Tonight Show" that he and pop star Ariana Grande are engaged after less than two months of dating. Davidson, a "Saturday Night Live" cast member, confirmed the rumors to host Jimmy Fallon, stating "I did" when asked about the engagement.

site_title: ExxonMobil starts up world's largest resin plant in Singapore
summary: ExxonMobil has started production at the world's largest resin plant in Singapore, producing 90,000 tonnes of Escorez hydrogenated hydrocarbon resins annually and 140,000 tonnes of premium halobutyl rubber for tires. The plants, part of a multi-billion dollar expansion project, will add 140 jobs to ExxonMobil's existing workforce and further establish Singapore as a key producer of fuels and petrochemical products. The expansion is aligned with ExxonMobil's efforts to serve growing markets in Asia and reduce emissions.

site_title: Oil traders ready for musical chairs as China tariffs loom
summary: US oil exports to China face threat of 25% tariff due to US President Donald Trump's imposition of $50 billion in tariffs on Chinese imports. China has bought an average of 330,000 barrels per day of US crude oil this year, but tariffs could restrict this flow and force US oil firms to find new buyers. China is likely to replace US oil with increased purchases from top suppliers Russia and Saudi Arabia, potentially widening the discount between US and Brent crude oil prices.

site_title: 'Strong' case for further rate hikes: Federal Reserve's Powell
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated there's a "strong" case for continued, steady interest rate hikes due to historically low unemployment and rising inflation. The Fed has adopted its seventh rate hike since 2015, predicting four hikes for the year, amid robust hiring and economic activity. Powell noted the risks to the outlook are balanced, making a case for continued gradual increases in the federal funds rate.

site_title: Summons filed to block Singapore Myanmar Investco's US$10.8m TPR divestment
summary: A joint venture partner of Singapore Myanmar Investco (SMI) has filed an originating summons to block SMI's proposed $10.8 million disposal of TPR Myanmar. The move seeks an injunction against the sale to Tiger Infrastructure, citing a breach of a 2014 shareholder agreement. SMI plans to focus on less capital-intensive business segments, but the suit challenges this decision. This is not the first legal action taken by Golden Infrastructure Group (GIG) against SMI, which previously pursued a lawsuit over the proposed sale of MIG's equity interest.

site_title: UK construction firms rely heavily on EU workers
summary: UK construction firms heavily rely on EU workers, with 28% of London's construction workers between 2014 and 2016 being nationals of other EU countries. This is more than double the percentage of EU workers in other industries in London. The reliance on EU immigrants comes ahead of Brexit next year, highlighting the potential impact of the UK's departure from the EU on the construction sector.

site_title: Asia: Stocks edge higher; US dollar, treasuries steady
summary: Asian stocks edged higher, despite concerns about escalating US-China trade tensions. The S&P 500 broke a three-day losing streak, while the Nasdaq Composite Index reached an all-time high. Treasury yields and the US dollar remained steady, and oil prices retreated. In Singapore, the Straits Times Index rose 0.4% as investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: New dawn for Noble as Goldilocks ends trench fight over debt revamp
summary: Noble Group has reached a revised deal with its Abu Dhabi shareholder Goldilocks Investment Company, securing backing for a $3.5 billion restructuring. Existing shareholders will receive 20% of the new Noble, up from 15%, and Goldilocks will secure a board seat. The deal also includes a reimbursement of up to $5 million in legal costs for Goldilocks. Noble's stock jumped 63% after trading resumed, following a bitter stand-off between the two parties. The agreement paves the way for Noble to complete its restructuring and restore its credibility in the commodities market.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: US crude jumps on stock draw; Brent slips ahead of OPEC meet
summary: US crude futures rose 1.8% to $66.22 a barrel, driven by a 5.9 million barrel drop in domestic inventories, while Brent crude futures fell 0.5% to $74.74 a barrel ahead of an OPEC meeting that may result in increased global production. Refinery crude runs hit a record high, and Libyan supplies were impacted by clashes at oil terminals. OPEC members are expected to discuss production policy, with Saudi Arabia pushing for an increase in oil output, while Iran signaled a possible small increase in output.

images.alt_text: US crude futures rose nearly 2 per cent on Wednesday, supported by a drop in domestic inventories, while Brent edged down ahead of an OPEC meeting later this week that may result in increased global production.

site_title: IMF greenlights three-year US$50b Argentina aid programme
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has approved a three-year, $50 billion aid package for Argentina to address inflation, budget deficits, and a weakening currency. The package, which includes a $15 billion initial tranche, aims to support Argentina's economic reform plans and strengthen the economy. The agreement was welcomed by IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde, who praised Argentina's efforts and said the fund's support was based on the country's domestic situation. The aid package is seen as a positive step for Argentina, which has a history of struggling with IMF financing and economic challenges.

site_title: Instagram takes aim at YouTube with launch of long videos app
summary: Instagram launched IGTV, a mobile app for user-generated videos up to an hour long, intensifying competition with YouTube for consumers' time. The service features videos from rising internet celebrities, artists, and pets, and plans to eventually share revenue with creators. Instagram CEO Kevin Systrom said the move is necessary as teens watch 40% less TV than five years ago, and the company has surpassed 1 billion users. IGTV is available as part of the Instagram app and as a separate app, with no advertising at launch, but expected to have ads in the future.

site_title: UK PM calls for 'free elections' in Thailand
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May urged Thailand's leader Prayut Chan-O-Cha to hold "free and open elections" in line with international standards. The meeting came after Thailand's first execution in nine years sparked human rights outrage. Prayut assured May that Thailand will hold a general election early next year, aiming to boost his image as a politician rather than a military man. The call for free elections is seen as a key step towards Thailand's transition back to democracy.

site_title: Xiaomi starts taking orders for up to US$6.1b Hong Kong IPO
summary: Xiaomi Corp has started taking orders for its US$6.1 billion Hong Kong IPO, offering 2.18 billion shares at HK$17 to HK$22 apiece. The deal, led by joint sponsors CLSA, Goldman Sachs Group Inc, and Morgan Stanley, values Xiaomi at US$53.9 billion to US$69.8 billion. Cornerstone investors include China Mobile and Qualcomm Inc. Xiaomi aims to start trading in Hong Kong on July 9, following a delayed plan to float Chinese depositary receipts in Shanghai.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi Corp started taking orders for the world's biggest initial public offering (IPO) in nearly two years, aiming to raise as much as US$6.1 billion in Hong Kong.

site_title: Hyundai ties up with Audi to boost hydrogen cars
summary: Hyundai and Audi have collaborated on hydrogen car technology, aiming to boost the energy segment lagging behind battery electric vehicles. The partnership will allow the companies to share intellectual property and components, with Hyundai seeking to increase demand for its hydrogen models and reduce costs. The move comes as carmakers focus on greener technologies, with European Union carbon emission limits set to tighten in 2025. Hyundai expects to sell thousands of hydrogen cars this year, with hopes of achieving profitability at a scale of 100,000-300,000 vehicles per year.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends at record on tech, media strength; Dow dips
summary: The Nasdaq Composite Index reached a fresh record on Wednesday, driven by gains in tech and media shares. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2% amid trade war anxiety, while the S&P 500 added 0.2%. Despite concerns over US-EU trade talks, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to new records, marking a positive day for US stocks.

site_title: Europe: Shares enjoy timid rebound though trade war fears linger
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Wednesday, a modest rebound from the previous day's losses, amid lingering concerns over the US-China trade dispute. The auto sector fell 0.6% for a fourth consecutive day, while banking stocks, particularly in Italy, rose, with Banco Santander and Unicredit increasing 1.4% and 2.8% respectively. Healthcare stocks, including Roche and JCDecaux, drove the index higher, while luxury firms such as Salvatore Ferragamo and Gucci owner Kering fell due to concerns over rising trade barriers.

site_title: US, Europe missing a chance to solve migration
summary: The global number of asylum seekers continues to increase, with 3.1 million awaiting a decision in 2017, according to the UN High Commissioner for Refugees. However, many rich countries, including the US and Europe, are not interested in solving the problem, instead using it as a political tool to deter migrants. A new approach, matching migrant flows with unskilled job vacancies and training programs, could be a viable solution, but requires political will. This approach could benefit the economy and provide a more humane solution to the displacement crisis.

images.alt_text: A woman from Syria feeding her baby at a refugee centre in Hamm, Germany.

site_title: An alternative pool of talent to tap on
summary: Deutsche Bank in Singapore has successfully implemented an internship program for students with disabilities, resulting in two full-time hires since 2014. The program, in partnership with SG Enable, provides internship opportunities and real-world experience to individuals with disabilities. The bank's efforts have overcome unconscious bias and highlighted the need for champions within organizations to raise awareness and facilitate opportunities for hiring managers to discover this "latent talent pool."

site_title: Strike a pose for International Yoga Day
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi led the fourth annual International Yoga Day, performing with 60,000 others in Dehradun. Authorities cleared the dense forest area for the event, catching and releasing two snakes. Smaller gatherings took place worldwide, including in New York, Ireland, Australia, and Italy. Modi, a self-proclaimed yoga enthusiast, emphasized the benefits of yoga in reducing mental stress and promoting focus. The event aims to reclaim yoga as an integral part of Indian culture, which has seen a surge in popularity in recent decades.

images.alt_text: Downward-facing dogs, cobras and warriors were set to sprout all over the world Thursday, as the fourth annual International Yoga Day got under way.

site_title: Japan's casino school enrolment increases in anticipation of IRs
summary: Japan's casino school enrollment has doubled, with 24-year-old Takuto Saito training to be a croupier, anticipating the opening of integrated resorts (IRs) with casinos. The Lower House of Parliament has passed a bill allowing the construction of three IR facilities, expected to create tens of thousands of jobs and generate $25-37 billion in revenue annually. However, concerns remain about Japan's significant gambling problem, with an estimated 3.2 million people addicted, and critics argue that the laws do not adequately address addiction issues.

site_title: Brexit: much at stake for Singapore property investors in UK
summary: Singapore property investors face uncertainty with the looming Brexit deadline in March 2019, which could impact the UK's office market and property prices. Recent large investments in London, such as Ho Bee Land's £650 million purchase, suggest confidence in the market despite the uncertainty. However, a weak sterling and potential Brexit-related job losses could erode asset values. The outcome of Brexit will be crucial for Singapore and other countries with significant investments in the UK.

site_title: Manufacturing still matters: 5 reasons why the IMF is wrong
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has joined academics in questioning the importance of manufacturing for economic growth, citing services as a more productive sector. This skepticism dates back to 1976, when sociologist Daniel Bell argued that future societies would rely on services over goods production. New research supports this view, highlighting the potential for digitalized services to drive productivity growth. While manufacturing is still necessary, the IMF's stance suggests a shift in focus towards services for economic development.

site_title: SoftBank's Masayoshi Son remakes his inner circle with 3 new appointments
summary: SoftBank's Masayoshi Son has remade his inner circle with three new appointments: Marcelo Claure, Rajeev Misra, and Katsunori Sago. Claure and Misra were elevated to executive vice-presidents, while Sago joined as a board member after a shareholder vote. This marks the largest overhaul in SoftBank's top management since 2014, and investors will be watching how the new appointees fit into Son's vision, which spans various industries including technology, mining, and sports.

site_title: A construction boom suddenly emerges in Caracas, of all places
summary: In Caracas, Venezuela, a construction boom has unexpectedly emerged, with 73 projects underway in the Las Mercedes district, a hub for the country's richest citizens. Despite the country's economic crisis, investors are investing in luxury buildings and retail spaces, with many affluent Venezuelans parking their wealth in the country due to strict currency controls. Experts believe that a political change may eventually lead to economic stability, but for now, the construction boom is a sign of hope that Venezuela is not completely "sinking into a deep hole."

site_title: Brazil maintains key interest rate at 6.5%
summary: Brazil's central bank maintained its key interest rate at 6.5% on June 20, 2018, amid inflation concerns despite a strong real depreciation and a costly truckers' strike. The strike, which lasted over a week in May, impacted economic activity and led to inflation spikes. The bank cited the strike's impact on economic activity and inflation as reasons for the rate decision. The decision was seen as expected, as inflation was considered under control.

site_title: Will SembMarine chairman leave to lead Petronas?
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has reportedly beckoned Sembcorp Marine chairman Hassan Marican to return to Petronas, Malaysia's national oil company. Marican, a former Petronas CEO, would assume the role if he relinquishes his positions at Sembcorp Marine and Pavilion Energy. Industry watchers question how this transition would affect SembMarine, still navigating a prolonged industry downturn. Marican's leadership and ability to drive strategy are seen as crucial for the company's transformation and success.

site_title: HK in most 'crisis' danger in next three years, says Nomura
summary: Hong Kong is at the highest risk of a financial crisis in the next three years, according to a Nomura research note. The city and China are the only emerging markets in grave danger, with Hong Kong facing more prominent red flags than during the 1997-98 Asian financial crisis. Nomura's early-warning indicators indicate a high risk of a financial crisis or sharp drop in domestic demand in Hong Kong, surpassing even the peak of the Asian financial crisis.

site_title: US housing starts in May approach 11-year high
summary: US housing starts surged to a near 11-year high in May, reaching a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.350 million units, driven by single-family and multi-family home construction. However, building permits fell 4.6% to a rate of 1.301 million units, indicating moderate market activity. The housing shortage remains a concern, with builders unable to meet strong demand due to higher lumber prices, labor shortages, and limited land availability. Economists predict the housing market will remain tight for the remainder of the year.

site_title: Meet the virtual vigilantes who are saving lives
summary: A new breed of digital hacker sleuths is helping authorities track down human traffickers and rescue victims on the internet. Led by Seattle-based computer scientist Sergio Caltagirone, the Global Emancipation Network (GEN) uses cutting-edge knowledge and skills to analyze data and identify patterns of trafficking. GEN shares suspicious online activity with law enforcement and anti-trafficking charities, providing valuable evidence to bust traffickers. While some experts caution against online vigilantism, others argue that private digital sleuths can play a vital role in combating trafficking, particularly when working with the police.

site_title: Amazon's Alexa will now play butler at Marriott hotels
summary: Amazon has partnered with Marriott International to integrate its Alexa voice assistant into select hotels, allowing guests to control various services such as room service, housekeeping, and concierge services using voice commands. The partnership, starting this summer, aims to enhance the guest experience and expand Amazon's presence in the hospitality industry. This move follows Amazon's strategy to increase user engagement with its Echo devices, with owners spending an average of $1,700 per year on Amazon.

site_title: Iran rejects compromise as Opec heads for battle in Vienna
summary: Iran rejects a potential compromise to increase oil production, putting itself on a collision course with Saudi Arabia at the Opec meeting in Vienna. Iran's oil minister, Bijan Namdar Zanganeh, stated that a 300,000 to 600,000 barrel a day hike in the second half of the year is not needed. This stance has led to a rift with Saudi Arabia, which is pushing for a "moderate" supply boost, and Russia, which is seeking an even larger production hike. The disagreement may lead to a unilateral increase in oil production by Saudi Arabia, affecting the oil market and energy stocks.

site_title: Getting the most out of an inclusive workplace
summary: Singapore's SG Enable is hosting its second Inclusive Business Forum on July 25 to promote hiring persons with disabilities (PwDs) in the workplace. The event aims to share best practices and resources available to companies, with keynote speakers including Jim Sinocchi from JPMorgan Chase and Susan Hwee from United Overseas Bank. SG Enable provides technical and funding support to encourage companies to hire PwDs, offering assistance schemes and tools such as the Workplace Disability Inclusive Index and HRM guides. The forum also provides opportunities for companies to learn from others and showcase their inclusive hiring experiences.

images.alt_text: DPM Tharman Shanmugaratnam speaking at the inaugural Inclusive Business Forum in 2016. The second Forum on July 25 will highlight the various resources available to companies when it comes to hiring PwDs in their organisations.
Ku Geok Boon, CEO of SG Enable.

site_title: China digs a trench for US trade siege
summary: China is implementing a major tax reform, lifting the tax-free threshold on personal income from 3,500 yuan to 5,000 yuan and allowing deductions on education, healthcare, and housing costs. The move is expected to boost economic growth by about three-quarters of a percentage point this year and next, and is seen as a response to the US's planned tariff actions. The tax reforms are also intended to rebalance China's economy towards consumption, rather than industry, and to put more money in the hands of Chinese consumers.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies fall as Korean exchange reports 35b won theft
summary: South Korea's Bithumb exchange reported a 35 billion won (S$43 million) theft, with hackers stealing Ripple, Ethereum, and Litecoin. The exchange halted deposits and withdrawals, moved assets to a cold wallet, and will compensate victims. Cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin, dropped as much as 2% due to concerns about digital-asset trading venue safety. This is the second major hack in South Korea in weeks, amid a government crackdown on cryptocurrencies and proposals for comprehensive regulations.

images.alt_text: Bithumb, ranked by Coinmarketcap.com as the world's seventh-largest crypto exchange by traded value, said on Wednesday that it had reported the theft to the Korea Internet & Security Agency and that officials there are investigating.

site_title: Rochor Centre's demolition to commence on June 26
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) announced that the demolition of Rochor Centre's four residential blocks will begin on June 26, 2018, to make way for the North-South Corridor. The demolition is expected to be completed by April 2019, with temporary sheltered walkways and noise barriers in place to minimize disruptions. After the demolition, construction works on the North-South Corridor will follow, with a completion target of 2026.

site_title: AkzoNobel celebrates the power of colour - in useful fashion
summary: AkzoNobel, a paint and coating company, is innovating new uses for paint beyond its traditional decorative and protective functions. The company, operating in over 80 countries, aims to brighten homes and make cities more vibrant with the power of colour. As part of its corporate purpose, AkzoNobel gives back to the communities in which it operates, highlighting the company's commitment to using its products for beneficial purposes.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: PayNow expanding scope to include businesses
summary: Singapore's PayNow service will expand to include businesses starting August 13. Seven banks and the government will be part of PayNow Corporate, allowing business owners to receive payments instantly without revealing their account numbers. This expansion is part of Singapore's Smart Nation drive to adopt digital payments.

images.alt_text: PayNow Corporate will let business owners and the government link their unique entity numbers to local bank accounts and receive payments instantaneously, without revealing details such as their actual account numbers.

site_title: Thailand bucks S-E Asia trend by keeping interest rates on hold
summary: Thailand's central bank kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 1.5% near a record low, bucking a regional trend as other central banks tightened policy amid a global emerging-market rout. The decision aims to support a pick-up in economic growth.

site_title: Art for a broken world, in the Weekend magazine
summary: Yoko Ono's Art Basel installation features broken teacups to convey the hurt in the world, responding to the new world order under US President Donald Trump. The art fair showcases political and socially conscious works addressing the rifts spawned by Trump's presidency. Meanwhile, veteran theatre impresario Cecilia Leong-Faulkner shares her experience with late Singaporean minister Lee Kuan Yew, and the article also explores Tibetan tea and its complexities, as well as a dashi master offering Japanese cooking lessons. The article highlights the intersection of art and social commentary in today's world.

site_title: Supermarket stocks show defensive performance in 2018
summary: Singapore's listed supermarkets, including Dairy Farm International and Sheng Siong Group, have performed defensively since April 2018, averaging 2.9% gains, despite regional concerns over a stronger US dollar and US-China tariff tensions. This brings their 2018 year-to-date total return to 12.3%. In contrast, Singapore's broader FTSE ST All Share index has declined 6.6% since April, while the F&B sector has seen a 6.6% year-to-date gain.

site_title: Xiaomi targets as much as US$6.1b in HK IPO: sources
summary: Xiaomi Corp is planning to raise up to US$6.1 billion from a Hong Kong IPO, selling about 2.18 billion shares at a price range of HK$17 to HK$22 each. The company, a Chinese smartphone maker, plans to bring in eight cornerstone investors, including Qualcomm and China Mobile, and will open the book to institutional investors on Thursday. Xiaomi's delay in a mainland share offering has lowered its likely valuation to US$55-70 billion, casting doubt on Beijing's efforts to lure foreign-listed tech giants back home.

site_title: Blackstone's first-of-a-kind India IPO confronts rate jitters
summary: Blackstone is planning to list its first real estate investment trust (Reit) in India, potentially raising $1 billion, but rising interest rates may delay the IPO. The deal, which could be filed as early as next month, is a result of a partnership between Blackstone and Embassy Group. However, if investors demand a higher-than-expected yield, the listing may be postponed. This would be a significant milestone for India's Reit market, which Blackstone helped establish two years ago.

site_title: Singapore can use less cash and be cheque-free by 2025: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore aims to be cheque-free by 2025, with the government encouraging the use of e-payments and reducing cash transactions. E-payments, including PayNow, have seen a significant growth, with over 8 in 10 consumers adopting e-payments and almost 3 in 5 merchants accepting them. The use of cash and cheques has been steadily decreasing, with cash withdrawals at ATMs falling by over $300 million annually. The government plans to introduce a new Payment Services Bill to boost consumer protection and regulate e-payment activities, with the goal of making Singapore a cheque-free society by 2025.

site_title: Silicon Valley-style coding boot camp arrives in Japan
summary: A coding boot camp called Code Chrysalis has arrived in Japan, aiming to bring the country's software engineering up to global standards. Founded by a Silicon Valley transplant, the program teaches coding, "soft skills," and physical fitness in English, with a focus on project-based learning. Since its launch, a dozen students have graduated, with six more in the pipeline, and have seen an average 80% increase in salary. Industry leaders hope the program will help Japan's companies transform and compete globally, as the country lags behind in software development and AI adoption.

site_title: Australia's Telstra unveils massive job cuts in strategic reset
summary: Telstra, Australia's largest telecom firm, has announced massive job cuts of 8,000 jobs, approximately a quarter of its workforce, to save A$1 billion. The company also forecasts lower earnings next year and plans to separate its fixed-line assets valued at A$11 billion. The move aims to address the company's struggling fixed-line businesses and adapt to changing market conditions, including increased competition and new technology. Telstra's share price has dropped to a seven-year low following the announcement.

site_title: Asian markets facing 'a disconnect': BlackRock
summary: Asian markets are experiencing a disconnect between cautious investor sentiment and strong corporate fundamentals, according to BlackRock. Despite concerns over a potential trade war, the health of the corporate sector is good, with earnings growth projected in the double digits. BlackRock maintains overweight positions in energy, materials, and financials, sectors with strong earnings growth. The company also views Asian credit as attractively valued, despite some defaults in the Chinese corporate bond market. Oil prices may soon reach a peak, providing relief for markets.

site_title: Holland Drive five-room HDB flat sold for S$1.1 million
summary: A five-room HDB flat at Holland Drive was sold for S$1.1 million in June, setting a new record for the area. The 38th-floor unit, with a floor area of 1,259 sq ft, was sold at 16% above a similar unit on the 37th floor. The sale price works out to S$874 per sq ft. This marks a significant increase in property prices in the area.

site_title: Redesigning a job for inclusiveness
summary: Volvo East Asia, the Asia-Pacific headquarters of Volvo Construction Equipment, redesigned its office to accommodate an employee who became a wheelchair user after an accident. The company made three glass doors automatic, automated the handicap toilet, and added a ramp to enable the employee to return to work on a part-time basis in July 2017 and full-time in September 2017. With support from SG Enable's Open Door Programme, the company covered 90% of the office modifications cost. The redesign allowed the employee to interact freely with colleagues and participate in meetings without any issues.

site_title: Maybe the Big Four auditing firms do need breaking up
summary: The Big Four auditing firms (Deloitte, Ernst & Young, KPMG, and PwC) face renewed scrutiny for their failure to detect accounting scandals, echoing the Enron scandal 16 years ago. Lawmakers in the UK suggest breaking up the firms to address potential conflicts of interest, as they provide consulting and other services that may compromise their auditing role. Existing rules, including those in the US and EU, aim to prevent such conflicts, but some issues persist, including auditors' focus on revenue and potential reinterpretation of prohibitions on non-audit services.

site_title: Singapore summit is shifting Asian strategic landscape
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in is visiting Russia from Thursday to Saturday, marking the first state visit by a South Korean head of state in around two decades. The trip is aimed at discussing "denuclearization" of the Korean peninsula with Russian President Vladimir Putin, following the Singapore summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The visit highlights the shifting geopolitical landscape in the region, with major powers jockeying for position as the Korean peninsula's military and strategic landscapes are potentially recast.

site_title: Singtel grooming new talent through mentorship programmes
summary: Singtel has participated in SG Enable's RISE Mentorship programme, mentoring 10 students with disabilities over three runs. The 12-week programme matches students with business managers from local companies, providing mock job interviews, networking sessions, and resume writing skills. Since 2014, Singtel has also hired six students with disabilities for internships and has made workplace modifications to accommodate employees with disabilities. The telco aims to foster awareness and empathy among employees, promoting inclusivity in the workplace.

site_title: European passengers can expect more flight delays by 2040
summary: European passengers can expect more flight delays by 2040, with delays expected to increase sevenfold, reaching around 470,000 passengers per day, due to increased travel demand and limited airport capacity, which is set to rise by only 16%. Eurocontrol predicts 1.5 million flights cannot be handled by 2040, and technology deployment is needed to address the issue.

site_title: Reshaping the workforce through connectivity and intelligence
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Digital transformation is reshaping the workforce, with companies investing in training and upskilling employees to leverage connectivity, predictability, and simplicity. A widening skills gap is a major concern, with 40% of employers reporting talent shortages. Companies are fostering a culture of lifelong learning and partnering with educational institutions to equip students with technical skills. A smart workforce equipped to harness IoT benefits will future-proof companies in the digital age. Investing in nurturing and developing existing talent, as well as training new talent, is crucial to securing a competitive edge in a rapidly changing technological landscape.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Two brokerage firms, HB Securities Research and Citic Envirotech, have upgraded their ratings on Delfi and Citic Envirotech, respectively, due to positive factors such as consumer confidence in Indonesia and the company's efforts to focus on core brands. Delfi's sales have shown positive results since Q1 2018, and Citic Envirotech's environmental business and government contracts are expected to drive growth. Despite risks, the firms maintain "buy" ratings and lower target prices for Delfi and Citic Envirotech, citing undemanding valuations and attractive dividend yields.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Noble Group secured backing from shareholder Goldilocks for its financial restructuring plan, with the firm electing to raise the equity stake from 15% to 20%. Business sentiment in Asia slipped to a 3-quarter low due to trade war fears. Carousell launched its mobile payment service, CarouPay, powered by DBS, Stripe, and Visa. The Singapore Stock Exchange Index rose 0.44% on Wednesday, ending a 5-day losing streak.

site_title: Bargain hunters lift Singapore shares
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index ended its five-day losing streak, rising 14.55 points, or 0.44%, to 3,315.90, amid a mild Asian market recovery. Despite being down 2.56% from the start of the year, the index took cues from a temporary oil price rebound and lower US commercial crude inventories. However, companies with Chinese exposure still faced bearishness, and investors remain cautious about US-China trade tensions and their impact on earnings.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: COE prices for cars at eight-year lows
summary: COE prices for cars in Singapore have reached an eight-year low, with premiums for smaller cars dropping by 6.4% to $34,110. This is the lowest price since November 2010. COE prices for larger cars and motorcycles also decreased, with the open category seeing a 7% drop. The tightening of the Vehicular Emissions Scheme is believed to be the main cause of the price drop, with certain models becoming more expensive due to added surcharges. Industry players expect COE prices to remain low for now, but may rise in the next round.

site_title: S-E Asian firms 'see value in data storage for innovation'
summary: South-east Asian firms are recognizing the importance of data storage for innovation, with Pure Storage, a US-based data storage firm, reporting strong growth in the region. The company's revenue rose 40% to $255.9 million in its first quarter, driven by enterprise accounts in financial services, high-tech manufacturing, and government agencies. Pure Storage sees South-east Asia as one of its fastest-growing regions, with AI initiatives emerging from local businesses, and is positioning data as the "new oil".

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 5.61 points lower at 1,709.75 on June 20, 2018, with 1.85 billion lots traded worth RM2.21 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 439 to 356.

site_title: China-based campaign breaches satellite, defence firms: Symantec
summary: A sophisticated hacking campaign originating from China breached satellite operators, defence contractors, and telecommunications companies in the US and South-east Asia, according to Symantec security researchers. The campaign, driven by national espionage goals, aimed to intercept military and civilian communications, but the extent of the interception is unclear. The attack highlights the rarity of such capabilities and the ongoing threat of state-sponsored hacking.

site_title: Coming out of the shadows
summary: Pan Pacific Hotels Group has made a commitment to providing meaningful employment opportunities to individuals with disabilities. The hotel chain, which owns 40 properties with over 12,000 rooms, partnered with SG Enable's school-to-work transition programme in 2017, recruiting five students and offering four employment contracts. The initiative aims to promote disability inclusion in the workplace, recognizing that individuals with disabilities can contribute effectively through their strengths and abilities.

site_title: Air India sale plan called off after failing to draw buyers
summary: India has shelved plans to sell Air India after failing to attract buyers, citing factors such as the looming election and high oil prices. The decision, made by Civil Aviation Minister Suresh Prabhu, reverses the government's earlier commitment to privatizing the national carrier. Air India is expected to continue losing money, with estimated losses of $1.5 billion to $2 billion over the next two years. The carrier employs 27,000 staff and is facing financial woes due to high oil prices and competition from private operators.

site_title: VW, Ford consider teaming up to develop commercial vehicles
summary: Volkswagen and Ford are considering a strategic alliance to develop commercial vehicles, including vans, to share the burden of meeting tougher environmental rules. The potential partnership won't involve an exchange of equity or ownership stakes, but will enable the companies to collaborate on projects such as electrified models. The move comes as cities worldwide push to improve air quality and demand for delivery of goods rises due to online shopping. The two companies aim to serve evolving needs of commercial vehicle customers, with Volkswagen's head of strategy saying the alliance could improve competitiveness globally.

site_title: Merkel's conservatives warn eurozone budget could split EU
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel's conservative bloc opposed to a larger eurozone budget, which she agreed to with French President Emmanuel Macron, has sparked skepticism and concerns about her authority and coalition government. The proposed budget aims to strengthen economic competitiveness in the eurozone, but details remain unclear. Merkel's conservatives fear the budget could lead to further division within the EU and exclude non-eurozone countries. The agreement has left room for negotiations with other eurozone members, potentially watering down the plans. Merkel's authority and coalition government are now under threat.

images.alt_text: Mrs Merkel and Mr Macron hailed a "new chapter" for the eurozone after talks at the Meseberg retreat outside Berlin on Tuesday.

site_title: Little froth left on Russia's beer sales
summary: Russia's beer sales are experiencing a temporary surge due to the World Cup, but the industry's decline is expected to continue. Consumption has been losing fizz since Russia lost its classification as a soft drink, and higher taxes and declining consumer spending power have contributed to the decline. Beer ranks 32nd in terms of consumption, while spirits, mainly vodka, play a stronger role in social life. Experts warn that the market may not stabilize, and some craft beer brands are bucking the trend, with sales expected to grow.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: RHT Health Trust has received all outstanding amounts due from Fortis Healthcare. Midas Holdings has been found to have irregularities worth 755 million yuan in its transactions. MTQ Corporation has reported three consecutive years' losses, but its market capitalization exceeds the threshold for listing on the watch-list. Accordia Golf Trust's golf courses in Osaka have suffered minimal damage from the earthquake. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss in H2.

site_title: Compact Metal to acquire majority interest in cement plant
summary: Compact Metal Industries plans to acquire a 51% stake in a partially completed cement plant in Mozambique for over US$80 million. The plant, with a production capacity of 5,000 tonnes per day, has been halted due to lack of funds since its construction began in 2012. The company will seek shareholder approval for the deal at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Chinese developers eye US$ bonds even at double-digit coupons
summary: Chinese property developers are seeking to borrow at high interest rates, with some offering double-digit coupons for two-year US dollar bonds. Zhenro Properties Group Ltd plans to issue bonds with a 11.5% coupon. This reflects the increasingly competitive market for offshore Chinese debt, with buyers having more leverage in negotiations. The move aims to secure funding despite economic growth slowing and pressure on policymakers.

site_title: US dollar hits 11-month high amid trade conflict
summary: The US dollar reached an 11-month high against a basket of rivals on June 20, 2018, due to escalating trade conflict, keeping investors away from higher-yielding currencies. The dollar traded at 95.09, its highest since mid-July 2017. Safe-haven currencies like the Swiss franc and Japanese yen remained supported. Market volatility is expected to rise as global central banks pull back from crisis policies.

site_title: As Trump punishes trade allies, Europe expands global alliances
summary: The European Union has expanded global alliances to counter the US's increasingly isolationist stance under President Donald Trump. The EU has opened free-trade negotiations with Australia, following similar agreements with Mexico and Japan, and is seeking to preserve the global trade system. EU leaders are concerned that Trump's actions may undermine the rules-based international order, with EU President Donald Tusk vowing to stand up to the White House's "capricious assertiveness." The EU's efforts aim to demonstrate its commitment to open trade and counter the US's protectionist policies.

site_title: US shale producers warn Chinese tariffs would hit energy exports
summary: US shale producers warn that China's proposed 25% tariffs on US crude imports would significantly impact energy exports, adding pressure on US crude prices. This would be a major concern for the shale industry, as China is its largest customer. The tariffs are part of a mounting trade war between the US and China, with the US planning to impose tariffs on Chinese goods on July 6.

site_title: Najib explains why he had so many luxury handbags, lots of cash, jewellery
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak attributes his luxury handbags and wealth to gifts and donations, not embezzled funds from state fund 1MDB. He claims his advisors and 1MDB's management board kept alleged embezzlement a secret from him. Najib denies any wrongdoing and says he's determined to stay in Malaysia and fight the allegations, even if it means going to jail. The US Department of Justice has filed lawsuits to claim assets linked to 1MDB, including a yacht and luxury real estate, valued at over $1.7 billion.

site_title: DBS, Stripe, Visa to power CarouPay
summary: Carousell, a Singapore-based online classifieds platform, has launched CarouPay, a mobile payment service developed in partnership with DBS, Stripe, and Visa. The service allows users to connect their DBS PayLah! wallets and pay sellers directly within the app using credit and debit cards. CarouPay will be integrated into the Carousell app, enabling seamless payments, and will be available only within the platform at launch. The service aims to help sellers reach more buyers and provide greater peace of mind for both parties.

site_title: Mugabe in Singapore for health check: report
summary: Zimbabwe's former president Robert Mugabe, 94, is in Singapore for a medical check-up, according to a local report. The check-up was reportedly scheduled, not a response to a sudden health issue, and is described as "nothing serious." Mugabe had slipped out of the country two weeks ago after his blood pressure rose to dangerous levels.

site_title: Porsche takes a back seat as Korean cars grab top quality honours
summary: Korean automakers Genesis, Kia, and Hyundai have taken the top three spots in JD Power's 2018 Initial Quality Study, displacing long-time Japanese leaders Toyota and Honda. Genesis ranked No. 1 with 68 problems per 100 vehicles, while Kia and Hyundai trailed closely behind. The study found that reliability has improved, with the average number of problems per 100 vehicles falling to 93. Korean brands were praised for keeping electronics and infotainment systems simple, while Volvo and Tata Motors struggled with complex systems, ranking 29th and 30th, respectively.

site_title: RHT receives outstanding payments for 9MFY18, 4QFY18 from Fortis Healthcare
summary: RHT Health Trust (RHT) has received all outstanding amounts due from Fortis Healthcare for FY18, including service fees and interest on convertible debentures. Fortis had committed to settling the amounts in tranches by June 20, and RHT has now fulfilled this promise.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore can reduce cash use and be cheque-free by 2025: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore aims to become a cheque-free society by 2025, reducing cash use and increasing e-payment adoption. The Monetary Authority of Singapore plans to introduce a Payment Services Bill to boost e-payment regulation and strengthen consumer protection. The bill will cover activities such as e-money issuance, domestic funds transfer, and merchant acquisition by payment platforms. The government also plans to expand PayNow, a mobile payment service, to include businesses and the government, with over 1.4 million registrations and nearly S$900 million in transfers. The goal is to achieve a 20% cash share in e-payment transactions by 2020.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise in early deals
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose in early trade on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index jumping 0.9% to 7,669.93 points. The Frankfurt DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also increased, with the DAX 30 up 0.3% and the CAC 40 adding nearly 0.2%. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Minimal damage to golf courses in Osaka: Accordia Golf
summary: Accordia Golf Trust reported minimal damage to its golf courses in the greater Osaka area following an earthquake on Monday. The company stated that there is no material damage to its assets or casualties, and operations continue as usual. Accordia Golf Trust closed one cent lower at S$0.60 on Wednesday. The company will monitor the situation closely and disclose further information if necessary.

site_title: Tiny central Asian nation - Kyrgyzstan - hoards gold as shield against trade war
summary: Kyrgyzstan, a central Asian nation, is diversifying its international reserves by increasing its gold holdings to 50% of its $2 billion reserves, aiming to protect itself from currency volatility and trade wars with the US and China. The move follows a record low in the Kyrgyz currency in 2015 and a reliance on imports from China and remittances from migrant workers. The country's gold holdings are now comparable to those of Russia and above emerging-market economies, with the US and Germany holding over 70% of their reserves in gold.

site_title: MTQ Corporation files notice of 3 years' losses; 6-month market cap still above SGX watch list threshold
summary: MTQ Corporation, a regional engineering and subsea services group, has filed a notice of three consecutive years' losses, with a full-year loss of S$27.8 million for FY 2018. The company's six-month average daily market capitalisation is above the SGX watch list threshold of S$40 million. This marks the end of the three-year watch period, but MTQ's shares continue to trade above the threshold.

site_title: Disney boosts Fox bid to US$71.3b to counter Comcast
summary: Disney has raised its bid for 21st Century Fox assets to US$71.3 billion, surpassing Comcast's US$65 billion offer. The deal would give Disney a controlling stake in Hulu and a stronger foothold in international markets. Disney chairman Robert Iger said the acquisition would allow the company to create more appealing content, expand its direct-to-consumer offerings, and deliver more exciting entertainment experiences. The move is seen as a bid to counter Comcast's offer and create a dominant player in the media-entertainment world.

site_title: ECB is said to see higher reinvestments cushioning bond-plan end
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to reinvest at least 160 billion euros of maturing debt back into bonds next year, potentially exceeding 200 billion euros, to cushion market volatility and maintain favorable liquidity conditions. This move aims to reduce the risk of economic disruption after the ECB completes its net asset purchases at the end of the year. ECB President Mario Draghi's strategy will help calm bond-market volatility and support economic growth, particularly in the euro area, where businesses are expected to raise capital to expand productive capacity.

site_title: In New Jersey, luxury condos liven up the waterfront
summary: Luxury condos are set to revitalize New Jersey's waterfront in Asbury Park, a city once defined by Bruce Springsteen's working-class roots. Developer iStar Inc. has launched sales on oceanfront condos with prices ranging from $900,000 to $6 million. The Asbury Ocean Club project, featuring 130 condo units and a 54-room hotel, aims to attract high-end homebuyers and development partners. CEO Jay Sugarman believes the city's comeback is a "tipping point," with the luxury condos and reopened music venue, Asbury Lanes, marking a creative balance between past and future.

site_title: General Electric loses place in elite Dow Jones Industrial Average
summary: General Electric (GE) has lost its spot in the Dow Jones Industrial Average after over 100 years, being replaced by Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc. GE, once the world's most valuable public company, has struggled in recent years due to weak profits and a decline in market value. The company is aggressively cutting costs and trying to strengthen its balance sheet. GE's stock has fallen nearly 80% from its peak in 2000, and its exit from the Dow reflects its declining influence in the US economy.

site_title: Iran leader slams US for separating migrant families
summary: Iran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has criticized the US for separating migrant families, calling it a "crime" and an "evil act". The US policy has sparked widespread criticism, including from international rights groups, Christian evangelicals, and the president's own Republican Party. The decision to separate children from their parents is seen as a harsh stance, with over 2,000 children affected. This criticism comes amid heightened tensions between Iran and the US, following the US withdrawal from a landmark nuclear accord in May.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after trade spat selloff
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, led by technology and media stocks, following a selloff due to escalating trade tensions between the US and China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.29%, the S&P 500 gained 0.26%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.50%. Despite US President Trump's recent threats, traders brushed off the uncertainty and stocks continued their rally.

site_title: Strawberries take Singapore towards self-sustainability
summary: Sustenir Agriculture, a Singapore-based company, has successfully grown commercially locally grown strawberries using Controlled Environment Agriculture (CEA) methods, marking a step towards Singapore's self-sustainability. The launch of "Sustenir Splendid Strawberries" is available all year round at select Cold Storage stores, eliminating the need for imports and ensuring fresher, longer-lasting produce. This achievement demonstrates Singapore's potential to transform the way crops are grown through technology, with plans to expand to Hong Kong and explore more efficient and sustainable agri-tech solutions.

images.alt_text: Strawberries (above) are grown locally using Controlled Environment Agriculture methods.

Benjamin Swan (above, left), co-founder and CEO of Sustenir Agriculture, briefing Koh Poh Koon (above, right), Senior Minister of State, Ministry of Trade and Industry, on the method used to cultivate Singapore's first locally grown strawberries.

site_title: Midas' unit found to have irregularities totalling 755m yuan
summary: A wholly-owned subsidiary of Midas Holdings, Dalian Huicheng Aluminium (DLHC), has been found to have irregularities worth 755 million yuan (S$158 million) in its transactions. The irregularities include an undisclosed 300 million yuan Citic loan and a separate 50 million yuan guarantee for Chongqing Huicheng Aluminium Co. The loan and guarantee were not recorded in DLHC's financial records, indicating a potential breach of accounting standards. This discovery may have significant implications for Midas Holdings' financial reporting and governance.

site_title: Government to push for technology adoption in urban farming industry: Koh Poh Koon
summary: Singapore's government plans to encourage technology adoption in the urban farming industry to ensure sustainable food production amid climate change. Senior Minister of State Koh Poh Koon highlighted the importance of technology in farming, citing examples of local companies like Sustenir Agriculture and Sky Greens that use innovative techniques and technology to grow crops. The government will provide financial support and innovative spaces for farmers to leverage technology, and will also partner with institutions of higher learning to implement the Earn-and-Learn Programme. This move aims to promote self-sufficiency in Singapore's food production.

site_title: British PM faces Brexit showdown with pro-EU rebels
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May faces a crucial vote on parliament's role in the final Brexit deal, which could impact her negotiation strategy. Pro-EU MPs plan to pass an amendment that would limit the government's power, potentially undermining May's ability to secure a deal with Brussels. The vote, expected on Wednesday, could have far-reaching implications for the UK's Brexit strategy and may lead to a government collapse.

site_title: Weiye Holdings to hold EGM on July 24 for proposed delisting
summary: Weiye Holdings will hold an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on July 24 to discuss the terms of its proposed delisting from the Singapore Exchange. The EGM will be held at the Novotel Singapore Clarke Quay Hotel. This follows the release of exit offer documents to shareholders, which include a circular and an exit offer letter from Fine Skill Holdings, the offeror. The move aims to facilitate the exit offer from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies fall as South Korean crypto exchange says US$32m stolen
summary: South Korean cryptocurrency exchange Bithumb reported a $32 million hack, with hackers stealing 35 billion won (approximately $42.7 million). The incident led to a decline in cryptocurrencies, with Bitcoin dropping 2% and Ripple, Ethereum, and Litecoin also falling. Despite the hack, investor reactions have been subdued, with the market seeming "battle-hardened." The incident highlights concerns about the safety of digital-asset trading venues and the need for comprehensive regulations in the cryptocurrency market.

site_title: Philippines raises interest rate for second month amid peso rout
summary: The Philippine central bank raised its benchmark interest rate for a second month, increasing the overnight reverse repurchase rate to 3.5% to curb inflation and support the peso, which is Asia's worst-performing currency this year. The move follows a sell-off in global emerging markets and domestic inflation pressure, with consumer prices rising 4.6% in May. The decision is aimed at bringing inflation back into the 2-4% target range, with Governor Nestor Espenilla warning that inflation pressure may spread to other parts of the economy.

site_title: RHT Chestertons enters into strategic partnership with DWG to grow its valuation and advisory business
summary: RHT Chestertons has entered into a strategic partnership with DWG to jointly offer valuation and advisory services, effective July 1. RHT Chestertons will take over DWG's valuation work, with David Ng leading the new division. The partnership aims to tap into RHT Chestertons' and Chestertons' expertise to grow the business and provide a wider range of services to clients. DWG gains access to Chestertons' global network and expertise to support its international property investments. The partnership is seen as a win-win opportunity for both parties.

site_title: In Caracas of all places, a construction boom suddenly emerges
summary: In Caracas, Venezuela, a construction boom has emerged in affluent neighborhoods, despite the country's economic crisis. Investors, including mogul Oswaldo Cisneros and hotelier Salomon Muci, are building luxury mixed-use buildings with marble finishes and exclusive shops. The projects, totaling 73, are underway in Las Mercedes, with prices ranging from 411 times the average monthly earnings of an ordinary Venezuelan. Experts attribute the investment to the strict currency controls, which prevent Venezuelans from moving their money abroad. The construction boom is seen as a sign of optimism among some Venezuelans, but many question the timing and feasibility of the projects.

site_title: EU to impose duties on US imports Friday after Trump tariffs
summary: The European Union will impose 25% duties on US imports worth 2.8 billion euros, starting Friday, in response to US tariffs on EU steel and aluminum. The move escalates a tit-for-tat trade dispute, with potential further tariffs on US goods. EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom said the US decision was "unilateral and unjustified," and the EU response is proportionate and in line with World Trade Organization rules. The duties target US products including steel, aluminum, farm produce, and motorbikes.

images.alt_text: The European Union will begin charging import duties of 25 per cent on a range of US products on Friday, in response to US tariffs imposed on EU steel and aluminium early this month, the European Commission said on Wednesday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.24% on Wednesday, driven by a rebound in Chinese stocks after the US threatened fresh tariffs on Chinese imports. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 22,555.43, while the Topix index rose 0.51%. The rally follows a similar trend in US stocks, which also edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: PayNow platform expanding to include businesses from August 2018
summary: PayNow, a peer-to-peer transfer service in Singapore, is expanding to include businesses as of August 13, 2018. The service, part of the Smart Nation drive, allows businesses to link their unique entity numbers to local bank accounts and receive instant payments without revealing account details. The seven participating banks are Citibank, DBS, HSBC, Maybank, OCBC Bank, Standard Chartered, and UOB. This expansion aims to provide businesses with a simpler way to transfer funds 24/7, 365 days a year, similar to retail customers.

site_title: Major Chinese lenders made illegal loans, Beijing's audit office says
