summary: China's National Audit Office has found that three major Chinese lenders, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), Agricultural Bank of China (AgBank), and China CITIC Group, made illegal loans to polluting industries and the property sector. The lenders provided discounted bills and gold leases to unqualified companies and engaged in shadow banking activities. Over 1,500 people were fined or received administrative punishment, while the lenders corrected most of their problems. The audit was conducted between July and September 2017 and did not punish the banks themselves.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon trading at 3,312.67, up 0.3% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading higher on Wednesday afternoon, with the Straits Times Index gaining 11.32 points, or 0.3%, to 3,312.67. Gainers outnumbered losers 171 to 162, with Nico Steel Holdings being the most actively traded counter by volume. Other notable stocks included Venture Corp falling 5% and OCBC bank gaining 0.7%.

site_title: Asia business sentiment slips from 7-year high on trade war fears
summary: Asian business sentiment declined to 74 in the second quarter, down from a 7-year high of 79 in the previous quarter, due to mounting trade friction between China and the US. The decline was the first in three quarters. Key sectors, such as retail and leisure, remained bullish, while construction, engineering, and autos were downbeat. Experts warn of increasing risks to growth, with US President Donald Trump threatening additional tariffs on Chinese goods. Some Asian economies with strong external balance sheets may be resilient to global turmoil.

site_title: Chaswood Resources to serve scheme for new proposed debt restructuring
summary: Chaswood Resources Holdings, a Catalist-listed firm, will serve a scheme for a new proposed debt restructuring. The High Court of Malaysia has directed the firm to provide further details on the proposed sale of its subsidiaries' assets or businesses. Chaswood is also required to file a supplementary affidavit by June 28, the next hearing date.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with slight gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with slight gains, adding 0.35% to the Hang Seng Index at 29,572.33, following a day of sharp losses. Despite this, investors remain concerned about a potential trade war between China and the US. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the latter easing 0.62%. The gains in Hong Kong come as traders brush off new Trump threats, focusing instead on the upcoming GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Australian shares hit highest since January 2008, led by banks; NZ up
summary: Australian shares reached their highest level in nearly 10-1/2 years, closing at 6,172.60, driven by a rally in banks, led by Commonwealth Bank of Australia's 2.9% gain. Other financial stocks, including Westpac and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, also rose. Healthcare stocks advanced, while Telstra slumped 4.8% after announcing major job cuts and asset sales. The S&P/NZX 50 index in New Zealand firmed 0.5%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher day after sell-off
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.77% on Wednesday, following a day of selling, as investors sought bargains. The Hang Seng Index closed at 29,696.17. Meanwhile, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up, driven by Chinese stocks. Investors remain cautious about a possible trade war between China and the US, despite recent rallies.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index added 0.77 per cent, or 228.02 points, to close at 29,696.17.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday, STI up 0.2% to 3,309.16
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Wednesday, advancing 7.81 points, or 0.2%, to 3,309.16. This came despite US stocks sliding due to an escalation in the US-China trade dispute. On the Singapore bourse, Nico Steel Holdings was the most actively traded counter, with 5 million shares traded. Other active index stocks included Venture Corp and OCBC Bank. Asian stocks rebounded from recent losses as investors sought bargains, with Japan's Nikkei gaining 0.2% and South Korea's Kospi rising 0.7%.

site_title: Singapore budget hotel startup RedDoorz enters the Philippines with US$5m investment
summary: Singapore-based budget hotel startup RedDoorz has entered the Philippines with a US$5 million investment. The startup aims to grow its footprint to 100 properties across the country over the next 12 months. RedDoorz will introduce a new category of properties, RedDoorz Premium, designed for budget business travelers. The move is seen as timely, given the Philippines' strong demand for hotel rooms and its growing internet economy. RedDoorz will target business travelers with amenities such as good WiFi and proximity to business districts.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won recover after heavy losses
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index and won recovered on Wednesday, snapping losses from the past few days amid US-China trade war anxiety. The Kospi rose 1.02% and the won strengthened 0.36% against the dollar. Key stocks like SK Hynix, Samsung SDI, and Samsung BioLogics gained, while cryptocurrency exchange shares Bithumb and its stakeholders declined after a hacking incident. The won's price-to-earnings ratio remains 12.10, and foreigners bought 110 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Scoot's inaugural Berlin flight 95% full
summary: Scoot, Singapore Airlines' budget brand, has successfully completed its inaugural non-stop long-haul flight to Berlin, with 95% of seats occupied. The Boeing 787 Dreamliner, which departed from Singapore, carried 311 passengers from various countries, including Singapore, Indonesia, and Australia. This marks Scoot's third long-haul destination, following Athens and Honolulu, and it will operate the route four times a week.

site_title: Wanted man in 1MDB saga has been shuttling in and out of Indonesia over past three years
summary: Malaysian authorities are searching for Nik Faisal, a key figure in the 1MDB scandal, who has been traveling in and out of Indonesia over the past three years despite being wanted by the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC). Faisal, former managing director of SRC International, has family ties in Indonesia and has been in contact with individuals close to him. His whereabouts are currently unknown, but the MACC believes he is crucial to the case and could provide significant evidence against former Prime Minister Najib Razak.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open slightly higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, edging up 0.31% or 68.21 points to 22,346.69, amid cautious trade due to lingering fears of a trade war. US President Donald Trump threatened fresh tariffs on Chinese imports, prompting traders to brush off the news and extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Trump's tariffs could deliver sizable hit to China's economy
summary: US President Donald Trump's threat to impose tariffs on another $200 billion of Chinese imports could cut China's economic growth by as much as half a percentage point, according to economists. The tariffs, which could be implemented starting July 6, would hit Chinese exports and manufacturing investment, potentially shaving 0.2-0.5 percentage points off China's GDP growth in the first year. China's government has set a growth target of 6.5% for 2018, and officials are already taking steps to counter a slowing economy, including adjusting monetary policy and implementing fiscal measures.

site_title: Australia's CBA says court approves settlement of money-laundering charges
summary: The Federal Court in Australia has approved a settlement agreement between Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) and the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre, closing a money laundering case that cost the bank A$700 million in penalties. CBA admitted to 53,750 breaches of money laundering and terror financing laws, the largest penalty in Australian corporate history. The bank will book the A$700 million provision in its fiscal 2018 results, released in August, and shares rose 2% following the news.

images.alt_text: Commonwealth Bank of Australia on Wednesday said the Federal Court had approved a settlement agreement to civil proceedings related to money laundering charges, closing a chapter that has cost the bank A$700 million (A$700 million) in penalties.

site_title: European firms say China business 'more difficult'
summary: European firms express concerns about the challenging business climate in China, with about half saying it has become tougher over the past year. Uncertainty in the legal environment, higher labor costs, and regulatory headaches are among the issues. The "Great Firewall" censorship also poses difficulties, with two-thirds of companies believing it negatively impacts their business. Despite some optimism about sector growth, nearly half of European businesses expect barriers to business to harden in the coming years.

images.alt_text: European companies complain they still face a tough business climate in China despite Beijing's pledges of openness, with about half saying it has become tougher in the past year, according to a survey released Wednesday.

site_title: North Korea, China discuss 'true peace', denuclearisation: state media
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and Chinese President Xi Jinping discussed denuclearization and "true peace" during a summit in Beijing, according to state media. Kim promised to cooperate with China to secure peace, while Xi praised the positive outcome of Kim's summit with US President Donald Trump. The two leaders assessed the historic meeting and exchanged opinions on ways to resolve denuclearization. A joint US-South Korean military exercise was suspended, pending future developments with North Korea.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 10-year high as banks rally; NZ rises
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% to a 10-year high, led by a rally in banks, driven by the weakening Australian dollar. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 6,148.60, with Westpac Banking Corp and Commonwealth Bank of Australia gaining 2.4% and 1.9% respectively. Telstra slumped 5% after announcing major job cuts and asset sales. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.5% ahead of GDP data.

site_title: China at risk of losing title of world's number two stock market
summary: China's equity market is at risk of losing its title as the world's second-largest after a significant decline. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.6% on Wednesday, with almost 80% of stocks hitting fresh four-week lows. Since January, Chinese stocks have lost over $1.6 trillion in market capitalization, threatening to surpass Japan's market value if another significant drop occurs. The Chinese government's efforts to soothe market nerves have been unsuccessful, with the market continuing to decline despite US tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.4% higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.44% to 3,315.90 on Wednesday, marking a modest recovery from a five-day losing streak. The index was driven by a 0.4% gain on Thursday, as investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and mixed Federal Reserve views. The market saw a slight edge towards Asian markets, which rebounded from recent sell-offs. A total of 1.9 billion shares were traded, with 254 gainers beating 154 losers.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Carousell unveils mobile wallet CarouPay powered by DBS, Stripe, Visa
summary: Carousell, an online marketplace, has launched its mobile payment service, CarouPay, in partnership with DBS, Stripe, and Visa. CarouPay allows users to make payments to sellers directly within the app, eliminating the need for third-party fund transfer platforms or meet-ups. The service uses DBS PayLah! and credit/debit cards, and holds onto funds until the buyer receives the item. Sellers can opt-in to receive payments directly into their bank accounts or on their Visa debit cards. CarouPay aims to increase online transactions and build confidence among buyers and sellers.

site_title: M&A appetite in overdrive for oil-and-gas firms: EY
summary: Oil-and-gas firms have the highest appetite for mergers and acquisitions (M&A) among all industries surveyed, according to a report by EY. 90% of executives expect the global M&A market to improve in the next 12 months. The total reported deal value for oil-and-gas transactions in 2017 was $344 billion, with upstream deal value at its second-highest over the last five years. This surge in M&A activity is attributed to a more stable economic growth environment and better assessment of competition threat.

site_title: India shelves Air India sale plan after failing to attract buyers: reports
summary: India has shelved its plan to sell Air India due to lack of buyers, citing factors such as the looming election and high oil prices. The decision reverses the government's earlier commitment to privatize the national carrier. Air India, which employs 27,000 staff, is expected to make losses of $1.5 to $2 billion over the next two years. The carrier's financial woes and declining market shares could exacerbate the carrier's financial woes and represent a setback for government efforts to cut debt.

images.alt_text: India has shelved its sale of Air India after failing to attract buyers, local media quoted a government minister as saying - a decision that could exacerbate the carrier's financial woes and representing a setback for government efforts to cut debt.

site_title: US dollar steadies vs yen as US yields come off lows, but capped by trade woes
summary: The US dollar steadied against the yen on Wednesday at 110.08 yen, after retreating to an eight-day low on Tuesday due to concerns over a worsening trade feud between the US and China. The dollar's recovery was capped by persistent worries about the trade rift and risk aversion in global markets. US Treasury yields climbed from three-week lows, and better-than-expected housing data also contributed to the dollar's stabilization. However, the threat of a trade conflict remains a concern, and the dollar's safe-haven status may be questioned.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, Addvalue Technologies, Tiong Seng Holdings, Top Glove
summary: Noble Group secured support from shareholder Goldilocks for its financial restructuring, raising the stake of shareholders to 20% from 15%. Addvalue Technologies terminated a placement agreement with KGI Securities due to a stock price drop. Tiong Seng Holdings and Top Glove are also stocks to watch.

site_title: Asia: Stocks recover from earlier rout but trade war fears seen capping gains
summary: Asian stocks rebounded from earlier losses on Wednesday, with Japan's Nikkei and South Korea's Kospi rising 0.1% and 1% respectively. China's Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.3% despite 30 listed firms announcing share purchase plans. US-China trade tensions remain a concern, with the US threatening to impose tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods. Australian stocks gained 0.8% due to weakness in the Australian dollar, while cryptocurrency prices fell after a South Korean exchange was hacked.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies fall after second Korean exchange says coins were stolen
summary: Cryptocurrencies dropped on Wednesday after Bithumb, a South Korean exchange, reported a theft of 35 billion won (S$39.2 million), with hackers targeting Ripple and other coins. The exchange halted deposits and withdrawals, and moved assets to a cold wallet. Bitcoin, Ripple, Ethereum, and Litecoin also retreated, with Bitcoin's decline reaching 2%. This incident follows a similar theft at another South Korean exchange in recent weeks, raising concerns about the safety of digital-asset trading venues.

site_title: Australian telecom giant Telstra to axe 8,000 jobs
summary: Telstra, Australia's dominant telecom giant, announced plans to axe 8,000 jobs, approximately a quarter of its workforce, as part of a cost-cutting strategy to cope with an increasingly competitive industry. The decision aims to create a leaner operation, split its mobile and infrastructure divisions, and achieve A$1 billion in cost savings by 2022. CEO Andrew Penn stated that the changes will enable the company to stay on top in a highly competitive market driven by technological innovation and competition.

site_title: Ford bets its future on new Detroit hub
summary: Ford Motor Company has announced plans to transform an abandoned Michigan Central Station building in Detroit into a 111,500 sqm urban high-tech campus, with a focus on innovations such as autonomous driving and electrification. The company hopes to attract high-tech talent, including millennials, to the area, which it sees as a symbol of Detroit's post-recession renaissance. Ford aims to open the redeveloped train station in three to four years and establish a hub for startups and partner firms, with its main headquarters remaining in nearby Dearborn.

site_title: Oil slips on US-China trade dispute, Opec supply outlook
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday ahead of a possible Opec supply increase, amid escalating US-China trade tensions. Brent crude futures dropped 26 cents to $75.08 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 78 cents to $65.07 a barrel. Russia plans to propose a 1.5 million barrel per day production increase, while Iran doubts Opec will reach a deal. US crude stockpiles fell more than expected, but gasoline and distillate inventories built. The trade tensions and potential Opec supply increase are putting downward pressure on oil prices.

site_title: Malaysia could extend tax breaks for key foreign investors: Mahathir
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced plans to extend tax breaks for foreign investors in key sectors like technology, provided they create better-paid jobs for Malaysians. This move aims to reassure investors and reverse sanctions on major projects sanctioned by former Premier Najib Razak. Mahathir emphasized his government's willingness to welcome investment from China or other countries, as long as companies commit to projects that create jobs for skilled workers.

site_title: Shareholders urge Amazon not to sell facial recognition technology to police
summary: Amazon shareholders are urging the company to stop selling its facial recognition technology, Rekognition, to police due to privacy concerns. The technology, which analyzes images and video to identify individuals, has been criticized by the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) for potential misuse by law enforcement. The shareholders, including firms like Sustainvest Asset Management and the Social Equity Group, fear that the technology could be used to identify innocent citizens, such as protesters. They also worry that it could be expanded to foreign governments, including authoritarian regimes, posing a risk to US consumers and shareholders.

site_title: 'Quit separating the kids!' Trump faces Democratic rage on immigration
summary: President Donald Trump faced a rare public protest from Democratic lawmakers over his immigration policies, including the separation of thousands of children from their parents at the US-Mexico border. The lawmakers, led by Congressman Juan Vargas, shouted at Trump and held signs expressing their disapproval, asking how he would like it if his own children were separated. Trump defended the policy, stating that separating children from parents is necessary when parents are prosecuted for crossing the border illegally. The protest was unusual and came as passions over the issue remain high among lawmakers and others.

site_title: Five injured in 'minor' explosion at London underground station
summary: A "minor" explosion at London's Southgate underground station injured five people, none seriously, on June 19, 2018. The incident was caused by an electrical short circuit, and emergency services responded quickly. The London police and ambulance service treated the injured at the scene and in hospital. The cause of the explosion was later identified as a battery short circuit. The incident was not deemed terror-related at the time, and investigations are ongoing to establish the full cause.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.58 points to 1,719.94. Volume was 27.88 million lots worth RM17.51 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 70 to 68.

site_title: France hotel chain Accor lets option to buy 10% of Banyan Tree lapse
summary: Accor, a French hotel chain, has let lapse its option to buy up to 10% of Banyan Tree Holdings. The option was granted in April alongside a $24 million debt deal and a collaboration agreement. The option was for shares to be sold at a 15% premium, but Accor did not exercise it. The convertible debt will automatically convert into shares once conditions are met.

site_title: Labour could order biggest shake up of Bank of England remit in two decades
summary: Labour is considering asking the Bank of England to target 3% annual productivity growth, the most significant change to the central bank's remit in over two decades. The move aims to boost the economy and address weak productivity growth, which has hindered wage growth and economic success. The proposal, recommended by shadow chancellor John McDonnell, would expand the bank's mandate beyond inflation control and focus on delivering investment in high-tech industries.

site_title: General Electric dropped from Dow Jones stock index
summary: General Electric will be dropped from the Dow Jones stock index on June 26, replaced by Walgreens Boots Alliance, which contributes "more meaningfully" to the index. GE's slump in the past two years, with shares falling nearly 60%, led to the decision. Despite being an original member since 1896, GE's influence on the index is minimal due to its relatively low stock price. The Dow index now features 30 members, with a greater emphasis on technology companies like Apple and Intel.

site_title: Facebook to offer interactive game shows on video platform
summary: Facebook is introducing interactive game shows, quizzes, and polls on its video platform, aiming to compete with rivals like Netflix and YouTube. The new formats will allow interactivity, such as live game shows with cash prizes, and will be available to creators of video content. Facebook has already begun offering original video content and has partners for the new format, including BuzzFeed News. The social network is also offering a combination of professionally produced shows and user videos to engage its audience. This move is part of Facebook's effort to reinvent traditional entertainment formats for a community-centric approach.

site_title: Italy's Osteria Francescana crowned world's best restaurant again
summary: Italy's Osteria Francescana has been crowned the world's best restaurant for the second time, beating out top eateries in Spain and France in the World's 50 Best Restaurants awards. The restaurant, run by chef Massimo Bottura in Modena, Italy, first won the award in 2016 and overtook last year's winner, Eleven Madison Park in New York. The awards were handed out in Bilbao, Spain's northern Basque Country. Osteria Francescana will now face a new challenge to maintain its top spot.

site_title: Rising rates a top concern among Asian financial advisers: survey
summary: A survey by Natixis Investment Managers found rising interest rates to be the top market risk concern among Asian financial advisers, with 59% citing it as a concern. This is followed by asset price volatility spikes (57%) and the current low yield environment. The survey highlights the challenges investors may face in transitioning to a rising rate environment after a decade of low interest rates.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Noble shares soar as firm secures Goldilocks' backing for sweetened restructuring plan
summary: Noble Group secured backing from shareholder Goldilocks for its financial restructuring plan, raising the amount of equity held by shareholders to 20% from 15%. The firm's shares surged 63% to 8.8 cents, with Goldilocks agreeing to nominate a director to the board and support the restructuring. Noble and Goldilocks' parent Abu Dhabi Financial Group will collaborate to expand the group's presence in the Middle East. The two companies also entered into a strategic partnership agreement, with Noble contributing $4 million in funding and ADCM Resources receiving a fee and share of profits.

images.alt_text: Noble Group said it has won support from its shareholder Goldilocks for its financial restructuring.

site_title: US banks seen boosting shareholder payouts by US$30b despite stress tests
summary: US banks are expected to increase their shareholder payouts by approximately $30 billion, a 25% rise, despite undergoing Federal Reserve stress tests. This increase in dividends and buybacks is attributed to the banks having reached sufficient capital levels in recent years.

site_title: Robo-advice provider Quantifeed raises US$10m Series B funding; to open Singapore office
summary: Quantifeed, a Hong Kong-based robo-advice provider, has raised US$10 million in Series B funding led by Cathay Financial Holdings and Legg Mason Inc. to open a Singapore office and boost R&D efforts. The investment aims to fuel regional growth in Asia and accelerate R&D in areas like behavioural analytics and data science. Quantifeed provides B2B robo-advice services to nine financial institutions across Asia, including Cathay United Bank, a subsidiary of Cathay Financial Holdings. The company plans to use the funds to fulfill its mission of transforming financial institutions into wealthcare providers.

site_title: Malaysia Inc reform mustn't become a witch-hunt
summary: Malaysia's government-linked investment companies (GLICs) are facing reform efforts under Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's leadership, with the aim of addressing corruption and mismanagement. The overhaul will target seven major GLICs, including sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional, with a focus on professional management, oversight, and accountability. The goal is to restore public faith in Malaysia Inc and prevent the reform from becoming a witch-hunt, with some experts calling for the removal of politicians from GLIC boards and the introduction of stricter governance standards.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: European passengers set for more flight delays by 2040: Eurocontrol
summary: European air traffic network manager Eurocontrol predicts that flight delays of up to 2 hours will increase seven-fold by 2040, affecting around 470,000 passengers per day, up from 50,000 today. The predicted increase in flights (53%) will outpace airport capacity growth (16%), leading to a backlog of 1.5 million flights. Eurocontrol Director General Eamonn Brennan calls for construction of more runways or deployment of technology to handle the growth, citing a "mess" in current air traffic control and staff shortages as contributing factors.

images.alt_text: The number of European flights delayed by up to 2 hours is set to increase seven-fold by 2040 due to greater travel demand and a lack of capacity on the ground and in the air to keep up with the growth, European network manager Eurocontrol said.

site_title: How an Apple supplier became China's worst performer
summary: BOE Technology Group Co, China's largest screen maker, has experienced a 32% decline in stock value this year, becoming one of the nation's worst performers. The company's fortunes took a turn after supply and demand imbalances led to plummeting prices for large screens, despite being named to Apple's top 200 suppliers list. Analysts predict limited growth due to valuation challenges and a surplus of capacity, hindering the company's prospects of replicating its 2017 success.

site_title: As CEOs condemn splitting up migrant families, Goldman chief offers sympathy
summary: Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein expressed sympathy for the Trump administration's migrant family separation policy, calling it "heart-rendering." This stance contrasts with other corporate leaders, including Apple's Tim Cook and JPMorgan Chase's Jamie Dimon, who condemned the policy as inhumane. Blankfein argued that there are no easy answers to the issue of immigration and that the administration's actions have adverse consequences on both sides. He suggested that criticizing the policy without considering the decision-making process behind it can be unfair.

site_title: Bunker price rises fuel old debate
summary: Global shippers' forum criticizes emergency fuel surcharges, but the rising bunker price highlights the unpredictability of container shipping. The Drewry Container Insight report notes that making a profit is largely outside of carrier control, with external factors such as oil prices and demand driving revenue. The debate on how to price liner shipping continues, with shippers and carriers at odds over the introduction of fuel surcharges.

site_title: EU-Asean Business Council re-elects Eastspring's Donald Kanak as chairman
summary: The EU-Asean Business Council (EU-ABC) has re-elected Donald Kanak, chairman of Eastspring Investments, for a second two-year term. At the council's gala dinner, Singapore's Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat emphasized the potential for collaboration between the EU and Asean in areas like trade facilitation, disaster risk finance, and e-commerce. He called for European support in infrastructure financing and the Asean Smart Cities Network to keep economies relevant and forward-looking.

site_title: Europe: Escalating tariff war hits autos stocks and multinationals
summary: European shares fell for the third straight session, down 0.7%, amid escalating US-China trade tensions. The Stoxx 600 autos sector hit a seven-month low, with German carmakers BMW, Daimler, and Volkswagen dropping 0.8-2.4%. The sector's decline was driven by fears of US tariffs on autos. European companies are more exposed to global trade, making them vulnerable to countries imposing higher tariffs. The Stoxx 600 also fell due to declines in mining shares, tech stocks, and the UK retail sector.

site_title: CapitaLand bags 2 mall management deals in China
summary: CapitaLand secures two mall management contracts in China, expanding its retail presence in Guangzhou and Chengdu. The company will manage a 3.6 million sq ft retail network in South China and its seventh mall in Chengdu. With these deals, CapitaLand targets to open five malls in China in 2018, spanning a total retail GFA of about 4.2 million sq ft, further strengthening its leasing synergies and reach in high-growth retail markets.

site_title: Paul McCartney turns 76 and teases possible new album, Egypt Station
summary: Paul McCartney, 76, has teased a possible new album, Egypt Station, on his birthday. He shared a video on social media featuring the Pyramids and ambient music, sparking speculation about the album's title.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Analysts have made predictions on Singapore Reits (S-Reits). DBS Vickers initiates a buy on AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit due to its diversified portfolio and untapped gross floor area, estimating a 15.8% revenue boost. UOB Kay Hian lowers its target price on Singapore Airlines due to potential decline in cargo traffic, while retaining a "hold" on Starhill Global Reit, citing underperformance and a challenging near-term outlook. The analysts also express a cautious stance on the S-Reits sector due to market and sector volatilities. The recommended target prices range from S$1.55 to S$0.65.

site_title: PBOC calls for cut in banks' reserve ratios, fuelling talk of easing
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has called for a cut in banks' reserve ratio requirements, potentially easing their burdens and supporting the economy amid growing US trade tensions. The move comes as China's economic growth slows, and the central bank aims to address liquidity concerns and debt build-ups. Analysts predict another 100 basis point RRR cut this month or next, and the PBOC may provide more direct funding to the market. The central bank also plans to transform its monetary policy, increasing its tolerance for yuan exchange rate fluctuations and market-based reforms.

site_title: Friendly Russians revel in influx of visiting fans
summary: Friendly Russians are welcoming visitors to the 2018 World Cup, dispelling preconceptions about racism and xenophobia. Despite initial fears, tourists are reporting positive experiences, with locals helping with transportation, translation, and even offering to show them around. Players and fans alike are praising the hospitality of Russians, with some even forming friendships with locals. The tournament is seen as an opportunity to show the world a different side of Russia, with President Vladimir Putin emphasizing the country's hospitable nature.

site_title: Singapore relinquishes top spot in digital-competitiveness ranking
summary: Singapore has dropped to second place in a digital competitiveness ranking, losing its top spot to the US. The US improved in knowledge and technology categories, while Singapore's low attitude towards technology adoption and business agility contributed to its decline. Sweden came in third, while Hong Kong fell to 11th place. The IMD World Competitiveness Center ranked 63 economies, with 29 improving in digital competitiveness, while South-east nations such as Malaysia and Indonesia slid in their rankings.

images.alt_text: Despite its digital-friendly environment and high levels of training and education, Singapore society's attitude towards the adoption of technologies and the agility of businesses here to transform digitally scored relatively low.

site_title: US-China trade spat deepens market woe
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.68% to 3,301.35 on Tuesday, tracking a regionwide decline after US President Donald Trump announced new import taxes on $200 billion worth of Chinese products. The Straits Times Index dropped 22.69 points, with banking, offshore, and marine stocks showing fragile sentiment. Despite some gains in sectors like food and beverages, the overall market sentiment remained negative, with analysts warning of potential risk-off liquidation if US-China trade tensions escalate.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Ernst & Young employees cook up a storm to raise funds for SPD
summary: Ernst & Young employees organized a lunch bazaar to raise funds for SPD, a voluntary welfare organization supporting individuals with physical, sensory, and developmental disabilities. The event, Project Joy Café, was held in May and raised S$6,000. This is part of the firm's CSR initiatives, which include the annual Walk For Rice drive and internal community-driven projects. Employees were involved in organizing and participating in these events, demonstrating the firm's commitment to staff engagement and community support.

site_title: BOE August rate increase in question as UK economy falters
summary: The Bank of England is uncertain about raising interest rates in August due to the UK economy's faltering performance. Less than 55% of analysts surveyed expect a rate hike, down from 60% in May. The UK economy shrank for the second month, adding to concerns about the economic outlook. This decrease in economic growth may influence the BOE's decision, potentially delaying or reversing the planned interest rate increase. The BOE's decision will be closely watched as it aims to balance economic growth and inflation.

site_title: IBM unveils system that 'debates' with humans
summary: IBM unveiled a system called the IBM Debater, capable of debating with humans, at an office in San Francisco. The system, developed over six years, can argue in favor or against a topic, delivering brief speeches and responding to human opinions. While demonstrating its capabilities, the machine's lengthy rebuttal hinted at its ability to stitch together coherent arguments. The technology is part of IBM's effort to build machines that can interact with people like humans, with potential uses in businesses, governments, and education. The system's limitations include its narrow scope and inability to engage in natural, free-flowing conversations.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: China Aviation Oil (S) Corp plans to divest its 39% stake in China Aviation Oil Xinyuan Petrochemicals Co through a listing-for-sale on the China Beijing Equity Exchange. Tiong Seng Holdings secured a S$28.9 million contract for a condominium development project. The Singapore High Court dismissed Shanghai Turbo Enterprises' injunction application against former executive director Liu Ming, allowing the jurisdictional challenge. ABR Holdings' proposed acquisition of PT Bintan Lagoon Resort was also cancelled, with the deposit refunded.

site_title: Intel has paths around Trump's China tariffs, analysts say
summary: Intel, the world's largest chipmaker, may avoid the most severe effects of US President Donald Trump's new Chinese tariffs by shifting production among its facilities. The tariffs, worth $16 billion, target processor and memory chips, a key part of Intel's business. Analysts suggest Intel can mitigate the impact by redistributing production. However, the company may still face some disruption, particularly if it relies heavily on Chinese suppliers.

images.alt_text: Intel's headquarters in Santa Clara, California. The world's biggest chipmaker's shares dropped 3.4 per cent to US$53.22 on Monday on news of a stock downgrade and investor concerns over tariffs.

site_title: Future of logistics in Singapore 'cannot be more exciting'
summary: Singapore's logistics industry is undergoing significant transformation, leveraging technology to enhance efficiency and productivity. The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) has established the Supply Chain Employees' Union to support the upskilling of employees. The sector is adopting automation techniques, such as Automated Guided Vehicles, and investing in state-of-the-art warehouses. Companies are also exploring predictive analytics, telematics, and additive manufacturing to optimize supply chain operations. The industry is shifting towards a data-driven approach, with operators needing to be comfortable with data science, systems thinking, and real-time visibility to manage integrated and automated assets.

site_title: Wah Loon founder buys Boat Quay shophouse
summary: Wah Loon Engineering founder Alan Chong has bought a 999-year leasehold shophouse in Boat Quay for S$21.35 million. The six-level property, with an estimated 6,300 sq ft built-up area, is fully leased and includes a one-Michelin-starred Italian restaurant, a Korean restaurant, and offices. The sale price reflects a close to 3% gross yield. This purchase is part of Chong's property investment efforts, following his recent purchase of a Jervois Hill villa for S$41.2 million.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Sizzling Amsterdam housing market pushes people to other cities
summary: Amsterdam's sizzling housing market is driving residents to other cities, with many opting for nearby locations like The Hague and Rotterdam due to unaffordable prices. The Dutch Central Bank notes a "spill-over effect" as prices in surrounding regions rise, with some cities experiencing price increases of over 20%. The country's largest real-estate association calls for increased housing construction to address the shortage, with the government aiming to build 700,000 new homes by 2025.

site_title: Trump clears way for health plans with lower costs but fewer benefits
summary: The Trump administration is set to issue a rule allowing small businesses to create health insurance plans with lower costs but fewer benefits, potentially covering 11 million Americans. The Affordable Care Act requirements will be skirted, offering cheaper options but reduced coverage. The final rule is expected to be unveiled on Tuesday, following months of anticipation.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble on trade war fears
summary: US stocks plummeted for a third consecutive session on heightened fears of a trade war between the US and China, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 1.2% to 24,700.21. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also fell, with shares of US companies active in China taking a hit. President Donald Trump's threat to impose tariffs on Chinese imports between $200 billion and $400 billion sparked concerns, but investors remain skeptical about a worst-case trade war scenario, with many expecting a resolution.

site_title: UK department store chain Debenhams suffers 20% price fall after profit warning
summary: Debenhams, a UK department store chain, issued a profit warning, citing falling sales, fierce competition, and weak consumer spending as major contributors. Annual profits are expected to miss expectations, with a pre-tax profit of £35-40 million, down from a consensus forecast of £50.3 million. The news led to a 20% slump in its share price, with some 240 stores worldwide, including 176 in the UK and Ireland, potentially facing financial difficulties. This comes amid tough times for UK retailers due to intense online competition and Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Digital future needs to be integrated into education system
summary: The article discusses the integration of digital technology into various aspects of society, including education. Experts argue that traditional education systems are not prepared for the future, where jobs are no longer predefined. To address this, personalized education systems like PeTel, which collects data on students' knowledge and skills, are being developed. The article also highlights the need for governments to develop ideas and tools to shape the future, and for public-private partnerships to bring new technologies into the classroom. Key issues include the impact of AI and automation on jobs, the need for a hybrid world that balances human creativity with machine efficiency, and the importance of education in preparing society for the future.

site_title: The future of chatbots: From niche processes to industry features
summary: Chatbots, powered by AI, are increasingly adopted by businesses worldwide, with Singapore being a notable example of early adoption. Today, these virtual agents can handle specific, niche tasks, but in the next 3-5 years, they will expand into broader domains using machine learning and deep learning, enabling them to understand vast amounts of data and provide personalized experiences. As a result, banks and other industries will utilize chatbots to deliver more complex services, such as personalized finance advice, revolutionizing customer experiences and operations.

site_title: Young people will share data for cheaper premiums
summary: A survey of over 8,000 consumers found that 62% of people between 18 and 34 would share their digital data for cheaper insurance premiums, while 44% of those in this age group would be willing to share their data. In contrast, 45% of 35- to 54-year-olds and 27% of those 55 and older would be willing to share their data. The survey comes as governments increase scrutiny of data collection and use following the Cambridge Analytica scandal. Insurers are investing in digital offerings, but many respondents experience difficulties with online forms and digital services.

site_title: Singapore's protection gap still wide, says AIA chief
summary: Singapore's insurance market continues to have a significant "protection gap," where the average death claim of S$58,000 falls short of the recommended 5-10 times annual income. AIA's group CEO, Ng Keng Hooi, suggests that this gap may need to be addressed by increasing the recommended coverage to 15 times income due to changing demographics and rising medical costs. The company is focusing on life and health protection through its Vitality program and digital enablement to drive growth in the agency channel.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: SMEs still upbeat about rest of the year, but trade tensions weigh on sentiment
summary: Singapore SMEs remain optimistic about the second half of the year, with the SBF-DP Info SME Index dipping slightly to 51.5 from 51.8. The Business Services sector is the most optimistic, followed by Retail/F&B, which saw a significant improvement in outlook. However, the ongoing US-China trade tensions weigh on sentiment, with the Construction/Engineering sector experiencing a slight decline. Despite this, SMEs are advised to "think long-term" and leverage government policies to remain competitive.

site_title: Investors fret about a trade war, but they aren't fleeing the stock market
summary: Investors are not fleeing the stock market despite growing concerns over a potential trade war. The US stock market has gained 2% since the end of February and 30% since President Trump's election in November 2016, driven by a strong economy, rising corporate earnings, and low unemployment. Analysts expect profits to surge 26% this year, with some predicting the market could make a new high despite trade tensions. However, economists warn that the trade battles could still cause economic damage and disrupt business spending, particularly for companies with international operations.

site_title: Roche to pay US$2.4b for rest of genome firm FMI
summary: Roche Holding AG agreed to pay US$137 per share, valuing US genomic profiling firm Foundation Medicine Inc (FMI) at US$5.3 billion. The deal, backed by both companies' boards, is set to close in the second half of this year. FMI, specializing in cancer care, will be preserved as an autonomous company while accelerating progress under Roche's personalized healthcare strategy.

site_title: Top Glove Q3 profit up 51.4% on higher revenue
summary: Top Glove Corp, a rubber glove manufacturer, reported a 51.4% increase in Q3 net profit to RM117.6 million, driven by higher revenue and cost improvement initiatives. Sales volume surged 37% and earnings per share rose to 9.36 sen. The company attributed its better performance to strong demand from Asia, Eastern Europe, and Latin America, as well as technological advances. Despite challenges in the operating environment, Top Glove remains upbeat on its outlook and plans to expand its manufacturing capabilities.

site_title: Temasek-linked firms lift dividends 40% to record S$9.3 billion
summary: Temasek-linked companies, including DBS, Singtel, and others, are expected to pay a record S$9.3 billion in dividends, a 38% increase from 2017's S$6.7 billion. This payout accounts for almost half of the projected total payout of S$19.6 billion from the 30 constituents of the FTSE Straits Times Index. The record dividends are supported by underlying performance and consistent payout patterns, boosting Temasek's performance and contributing to Singapore's national finances.

site_title: China urges lenders 'to support HNA bond issues'
summary: China is urging lenders to support HNA's bond issues, potentially easing the conglomerate's refinancing efforts and minimizing financial risk. At a recent meeting, officials told banks to "support" HNA's bonds, which could include buying new issues from HNA units. This move aims to prevent HNA from paying high interest rates and buying time for more asset sales. China Development Bank will handle creditors' meetings, and lenders will now deal with HNA through head offices, reducing the risk of a crisis.

site_title: Sentosa shuttles to be protected against cyber attacks
summary: ST Engineering partners with Israeli startup SafeRide Technologies to protect autonomous shuttles on Sentosa from cyber attacks. The partnership integrates ST Engineering's cyber security capabilities with SafeRide's vSentry software suite, providing multi-layered security for connected and autonomous vehicles. The driverless shuttles, set to operate from next year, will utilize the integrated security solution to diagnose and eliminate potential cyber vulnerabilities. This collaboration aims to safeguard the integrity and security of the systems as vehicle technology advances.

images.alt_text: The cyber security capabilities of ST Engineering will pair up with SafeRide's software to root out and eliminate vulnerabilities from connected and autonomous vehicles.

site_title: Rare Japanese unicorn Mercari closes up 77% in market debut
summary: Mercari Inc, a rare Japanese unicorn, closed up 77% in its Tokyo stock market debut on June 19, 2018. The company's shares rose as high as 6,000 yen, valuing it at up to $7.4 billion. This surge reflects strong investor appetite for Mercari's US expansion plans, with the company aiming to tap into the US market.

site_title: Tesla hit with 'extensive' sabotage by rogue employee: Elon Musk
summary: A disgruntled Tesla employee broke into the company's manufacturing operating system and sent sensitive data to unknown third parties, causing "extensive and damaging sabotage" to Tesla's operations. The employee, who was denied a promotion, was identified by CEO Elon Musk in an email to staff. Musk described the incident as a "serious breach" of company security, but did not name the employee. The incident highlights the risks of insider threats and the importance of robust security measures to protect sensitive data.

site_title: Cobalt stocks in China poised for upside as EV boom powers ahead
summary: China is poised for an upside in cobalt stocks as the country leads the global boom in electric vehicles, with cobalt prices down 20% since April. China accounts for 60% of the world's refined cobalt production and is home to major refiners, including Zhejiang Huayou Cobalt. Analysts predict a 30% rise in shares of Chinese cobalt companies over the next three years, driven by profitability forecasts. A new round of battery stockpiling in China and global inventory building are expected to push the market into deficit, benefiting cobalt producers.

site_title: Oil declines as traders assess Opec compromise and Trump tariffs
summary: Oil prices dropped below $66 a barrel as traders assessed Opec's compromise on an output increase amid escalating US-China trade tensions. Crude futures in New York fell 0.9% after a 1.2% gain on Monday. The US and China are set to impose new tariffs, with the US targeting $200 billion in Chinese goods. Opec is considering a modest production boost, but Iran's opposition threatens to derail the agreement.

site_title: China vows retaliation as Trump targets US$200b in tariffs
summary: China has vowed to retaliate "forcefully" against US President Donald Trump's threatened tariffs on another US$200 billion in Chinese imports, following a previous round of tariffs. The move comes as trade tensions between the world's two biggest economies intensify. China's Ministry of Commerce stated that any US actions would be met with "comprehensive quantitative and qualitative measures." The US tariffs, if implemented, would add to existing trade tensions between the two countries.

site_title: Kantar opens first Asia R&D hub in Singapore
summary: Kantar, a global insights consultancy, has opened its first research and development hub in Asia, the Kantar Brand Growth Lab, in Singapore. The lab will focus on advanced analytics using big data, artificial intelligence, and machine learning to help companies grow their brands. The three-year partnership aims to develop sustainable growth strategies and transform unstructured data into insights. This move is in line with Singapore's Professional Services Industry Transformation Map, which seeks to develop the country into a global leader in the professional services industry.

images.alt_text: From left: Mr Sanchez, Kantar chief client officer in Apac Tim Kelsall, and Mr Wong at the opening of Kantar Brand Growth Lab.

site_title: Xi can make life difficult for US companies after Trump threat
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping can retaliate against US companies operating in China beyond just tariffs, using customs delays, tax audits, and increased regulatory scrutiny. Despite the US exporting only $130 billion worth of goods to China, the US has a surplus of $20 billion with China, making it vulnerable to pressure. Companies like Apple, Walmart, and General Motors have operations in China and could face backlash, including boycotts and losses, as seen in the cases of South Korean and Japanese companies. Xi may hold back from a full-scale attack due to concerns about the impact on the domestic economy.

site_title: UPS to spend US$130m on new natural gas vehicles, fueling stations
summary: UPS to invest $130m in 730 compressed natural gas vehicles and 5 domestic fueling stations, aiming to have 25% of new vehicles running on alternative fuels by 2020. The company seeks to replace 40% of ground transportation fuel with non-conventional sources by 2020, in response to pressure from regulators to reduce environmental impact.

site_title: German firms grapple with fallout from ageing society
summary: Germany's aging population poses a significant skills shortage, with the working-age population expected to shrink by 2 million by 2030. To combat this, companies like Mercedes-Benz and BMW are launching initiatives to encourage older workers to continue working and training younger employees. These programs include exhibitions, demographic audits, and joint training sessions, aiming to promote age diversity and tap into the expertise of older workers. The efforts are bearing fruit, with the employment rate among those aged 55-60 rising sharply in the last decade, and the German government raising the pension age to 67 by 2030 to address the issue.

site_title: Trump is trashing the things that made America great
summary: US President Donald Trump's actions are eroding the country's values that made it great, including separating children from their parents, investigating his associates, and insulting democratic allies. This rejection of ideals such as freedom, human rights, and the rule of law, which were core to America's greatness after World War II, will not make the country stronger but weaker. Trump's policies, including trade wars, are also likely to harm American workers and make the US less dominant globally, contrary to his claims of making America great again.

site_title: BigTech entry into wealth management could draw up to US$12t: Capgemini
summary: BigTech firms such as Amazon, Google, and Tencent are poised to enter the wealth management market, potentially drawing up to $12 trillion in assets, according to Capgemini's World Wealth Report 2018. Over 50% of high net worth individuals globally are interested in these services, with Asia-Pacific HNWIs showing the highest interest. Despite robust investment returns, client satisfaction with wealth managers remains low, with only 64.6% and 63.4% satisfaction rates for firms and wealth managers, respectively. BigTech's entry is expected to be driven by Asia-Pacific, followed by North America and Europe.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: KL-Beijing relations being tested but they may be far from testy
summary: Malaysia's new government, led by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, is reviewing China-backed investments initiated under the previous regime, including a $14 billion rail link and a deep sea port. Despite concerns over the projects' high costs and lopsided terms, the meeting between Mahathir and Alibaba founder Jack Ma provided a positive signal, with Ma citing Mahathir's vision for the Multimedia Super Corridor as an inspiration for Alibaba's creation. The two nations have emphasized diplomatic cooperation, with Malaysia seeking China's help in addressing its high national debt.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit's Japan properties unaffected by Osaka quake
summary: Parkway Life Reit's Japan properties remain unaffected by a 5.9 magnitude earthquake in Osaka, according to the Reit's manager. Eight of its 46 Japanese properties are located in Osaka, but none have been structurally affected and operations remain uninterrupted. The Reit's Japan assets comply with seismic safety standards and are insured against natural disasters. Parkway Life Reit closed 3 cents lower at S$2.58 following the news.

site_title: Dollar hits 11-month high amid further US tariffs
summary: The US dollar reached an 11-month high against the euro after US President Donald Trump threatened to impose a 10% tariff on $200 billion of Chinese goods. This move heightened global trade tensions, sparking concerns about potential economic harm. The euro slumped in response. Beijing warned of retaliation from China.

site_title: TT International gets nod for further extension for FY2018 AGM
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED TT International has received a further extension from the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority of Singapore to hold its annual general meeting for the 2018 fiscal year by December 14. The company had initially been granted an extension until November 14 to announce its unaudited financial statements. Trading of shares has been suspended since August 4, 2017. TT International is undergoing a debt restructuring process.

site_title: Grab's success lies in its user-centric platform in S-E Asia
summary: Toyota invests $1 billion in Grab, the South-east Asian ride-sharing app, following its strategic alliance with Uber in 2016. Grab's success can be attributed to its user-centric platform, which has toppled Uber in the region and achieved a product/market fit by adapting to local cultures and needs. Grab's ability to balance digital and physical services, such as offering cash payments and police records, has made it an attractive platform for users and investors alike.

site_title: Tiong Seng Holdings' unit awarded S$29m contract
summary: Tiong Seng Holdings' subsidiary, Tiong Seng Civil Engineering, has secured a S$28.9 million contract to erect a condominium development project. The contract, awarded by TSky Balmoral, includes construction of two blocks of residential buildings with facilities. Construction is set to begin this month, with no expected impact on the group's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Theresa May can't accept more Parliament control over Brexit
summary: Theresa May has refused to accept a proposal giving parliament more control over Brexit, potentially setting up a clash with lawmakers. The proposal aimed to give MPs the power to intervene if Britain risks crashing out of the EU with no deal. May had previously tried to find a compromise with pro-EU lawmakers in her Conservative Party but failed. The decision sets the stage for a confrontation between May and lawmakers who want greater control over Brexit.

site_title: Advance SCT to appoint new non-executive chairman
summary: Advance SCT, a supplier of copper-related products, is appointing a new non-executive chairman after Teh Wing Kwan acquired 11.9 billion shares, now holding a 28.7% interest in the company. Teh Wing Kwan, a sophisticated investor, is currently the chairman of China Vanadium TitanoMagnetite Mining Company listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. The appointment follows his significant stake acquisition.

site_title: India is said to call off flag carrier sale after failed attempt
summary: India has decided not to sell its flag carrier Air India after a failed attempt to find a buyer, citing a lack of interest. The government, under Prime Minister Narendra Modi, will instead focus on improving operations and selling non-core assets. Air India is struggling with a US$8 billion debt load and has not made a profit since its merger with Indian Airlines over a decade ago. The government plans to review the failed sale process and may consider selling the airline's building and other assets instead.

site_title: UnUsUaL subsidiary, Sliding Door Entertainment to bring Asia dinosaur tour to 11 cities
summary: UnUsUaL subsidiary Sliding Door Entertainment is partnering to bring the "Walking with Dinosaurs - The Arena Spectacular" Asian tour to 11 cities, starting in the second half of 2019. The tour, which has been watched by over 9 million people in 250 cities, will feature 117 shows in countries such as Singapore, Malaysia, and South Korea. The S$20 million production is based on the award-winning BBC Television Series and is produced by Global Creatures.

site_title: ECB will be patient and gradual with rate hikes, says Draghi
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) will be patient and gradual in tightening monetary policy, according to President Mario Draghi. The ECB will end its 2.6 trillion euro bond purchase program by the end of the year but will keep interest rates unchanged until at least next summer. The bank's decision to delay rate hikes reflects uncertainty over a potential global trade war and the impact of rising wages on inflation. Draghi emphasized the need for a gradual approach to adjusting policy, citing a path of very short-term interest rates that reflect the ECB's principles.

site_title: Pacific Radiance to sweeten the latest offer: observers
summary: Pacific Radiance has improved its restructuring proposal for S$100 million notes, offering equity swaps pegged at S$0.101 per share and convertible bonds at S$0.112 apiece. Noteholders attended an informal meeting, recognizing the efforts made to improve terms after a failed consent solicitation exercise in February. However, noteholders still want more sweeteners, specifically the upfront payment of the S$10 million cash component. Pacific Radiance is concurrently pursuing a scheme application for US$400 million of bank loans and has secured US$85 million in new equity from potential investors. The company's liquidity crunch and potential liquidation of its holding company may impact creditor recovery rates.

site_title: Addvalue Technologies terminates placement agreement with KGI Securities
summary: Addvalue Technologies has terminated its placement agreement with KGI Securities, a Singapore-based investment firm. The agreement, which would have raised up to S$10 million through the sale of 250 million shares at four Singapore cents apiece, was cancelled without KGI's involvement. The company is now exploring alternative funding arrangements, including potential investment from strategic partners.

site_title: SP Group calls for tenders to build charging grid for electric vehicles
summary: SP Group, Singapore's power grid operator, is launching a public electric vehicle (EV) charging network with 30 charging points to be installed in six months, aiming for 500 points by 2020. The network will include DC fast chargers that can fully charge a small EV in 30 minutes and AC chargers that operate at 22kW. The company plans to develop a smartphone app to help EV drivers locate charging points and pay for electricity. The network is expected to stimulate demand for EVs in Singapore, with EV retailers welcoming the move as a catalyst for widespread adoption of the technology.

site_title: Mahathir government eyes multiple charges against Najib over 1MDB
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced plans to bring multiple charges against former Prime Minister Najib Razak over the 1MDB scandal. Najib, who founded 1MDB, is accused of embezzlement, bribery, and abuse of power. Malaysian investigators have an "almost perfect case" against Najib, who has denied any wrongdoing. Madam Rosmah, Najib's wife, is also being investigated in connection with 1MDB. Charges are expected to be brought within months, with a trial potentially starting by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Mr Najib arriving at the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) in Putrajaya on May 24.

site_title: Court gives Hyflux 6-month break from creditors; company in search of S$200m rescue financing
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted Hyflux a 6-month reprieve from creditors, allowing the water project developer to seek rescue financing and explore a buyer for its Tuaspring asset. During this period, Hyflux plans to conduct consent solicitation exercises to term out its notes and perps. The company is under pressure to find a solution to avoid further financial difficulties.

images.alt_text: Tuaspring Plant: Hyflux is in discussions with four parties on a possible sale of the plant, its founder, Olivia Lum, had said.

site_title: Oprah Winfrey is now one of the world's 500 richest people
summary: Oprah Winfrey has become the first black female entrepreneur on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index, ranking 494th among the world's 500 richest people. Her fortune reached $4 billion, largely due to the performance of Weight Watchers International, which has seen its share price more than double since 2015. Winfrey's wealth comes from ownership of the Oprah Winfrey Show and a partnership with Apple to produce original content. Her inclusion brings the total number of women on the list to 65 and female entrepreneurs to six.

site_title: PayPal co-founders back new credit card for startups
summary: Brex, a startup, has launched a credit card for venture-backed companies, bypassing traditional credit history. The company, co-founded by Henrique Dubugras, uses real-time funding data to issue credit limits to companies and employees. PayPal co-founders Peter Thiel and Max Levchin have invested $57 million in Brex, which has already issued cards to around 1,000 people. The company's approach aims to simplify the credit card application process for startups.

site_title: Property crisis looms in US due to sea level rise
summary: A US report by the Union of Concerned Scientists warns that over $1 trillion in commercial and private US property may be at risk due to sea level rise by century's end. Florida's coastal real estate is particularly exposed, with 64,000 homes worth $26 billion at risk of chronic flooding by 2045. The danger comes from "sunny day floods" caused by high tides, not just storms. Experts say market perceptions can shift quickly, and making significant cuts to greenhouse gas emissions could save up to 85% of at-risk property.

site_title: Draghi says ECB will be patient in timing of first rate hike
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Mario Draghi stated that the ECB will remain patient in determining the timing of its first interest rate hike, taking a gradual approach to adjusting policy. Draghi emphasized that the ECB's plan to halt bond-buying doesn't mean it's ready to withdraw support, and that economic developments will dictate interest rate decisions. The euro declined 0.7% against the US dollar after Draghi's speech, citing growing uncertainty due to global protectionism, rising oil prices, and potential financial market volatility.

site_title: US banks seen boosting payouts US$30b after stress tests
summary: US banks, including JPMorgan Chase & Co, Bank of America, and Citigroup, are expected to increase their payouts to shareholders by $30 billion, a 25% rise, following the Federal Reserve's stress tests. The 25 largest lenders are likely to distribute more than 100% of their profits over the next four quarters. However, Goldman Sachs Group and Morgan Stanley may not be as fortunate due to their capital markets earnings being more vulnerable to the tougher economic scenario. The increased payouts are a result of the banks' confidence in their financial stability.

site_title: London construction firms rely heavily on EU workers, figures show
summary: London's construction sector relies heavily on EU workers, with 28% of construction workers employed in the city between 2014 and 2016 being nationals of other EU countries. This contrasts with the UK as a whole, where only 7% of construction workers are from elsewhere in the EU. The sector's reliance on EU workers is particularly concerning ahead of Brexit, with companies reluctant to invest in major projects due to uncertainty. An ageing construction workforce and potential Brexit fallout threaten the sector's future.

site_title: Xi calls on US, North Korea to implement Singapore agreements
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping urged the US and North Korea to implement the agreements reached at the Singapore summit, calling for the two nations to "carry out the results of their leadership summit." During a meeting with Kim Jong Un, Xi praised China's role in promoting denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula. The US and North Korea have agreed to work towards denuclearization, but it remains unclear if they will meet their commitments.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble on latest Trump-China trade threats
summary: US stocks plummeted in early trading on Tuesday as fresh trade threats from the US and China exacerbated trade war fears. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.2%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.7%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index also fell 0.7%. US President Donald Trump directed a 10% levy on $200 billion of Chinese imports, prompting a sharp response from Beijing. Markets remain guarded despite recent resilience, with analysts warning of potential losses if trade tensions escalate further.

site_title: 'Indo-Pacific' as an idea is unlikely to take
summary: The concept of the "Indo-Pacific" has gained popularity, particularly in the context of US foreign policy, but its meaning and implications remain unclear. The term was revived by US Secretary of Defence Jim Mattis, who linked it to a "free and open" region encompassing not only maritime but also internal democracy. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi used the term to describe a natural region, excluding economic or political design. However, the term's meaning may be contested by China, which dismissed it as an "attention-grabbing idea". The "Indo-Pacific" may be a framework for rebalancing regional power dynamics, but its future is uncertain, with Donald Trump's administration unlikely to adopt a "rules-based international order" and the potential for the Quad alliance to be re-established.

images.alt_text: Many at the Shangri-La Dialogue read the prefix 'Indo' as a geopolitical invitation to India to partner more explicitly with states in an 'Asia-Pacific' region, but India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi (left) unloaded the loaded term in his address.

site_title: France's Le Pen must repay 300,000 euros to European Parliament: court
summary: Marine Le Pen, the French far-right leader, must repay nearly 300,000 euros to the European Parliament for incorrectly using parliamentary funds to pay an aide. A top EU court ruled that Le Pen failed to prove the effectiveness of the assistant's work, rejecting her bid to overturn the ruling. Le Pen's National Rally party criticized the court's decision, but she plans to appeal to the EU's highest court.

site_title: ABR Holdings' unit, Resort Venture cease proposed acquisition
summary: ABR Holdings' unit Resort Venture has ceased a proposed acquisition of a 50% stake in PT Bintan Lagoon Resort. The deposit of S$4.05 million, with accrued interest, has been refunded to ABR Land (S). The decision was made "mutually and amicably" after the initial announcement in December.

site_title: China's Xiaomi cuts valuation after pulling mainland offering: sources
summary: Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi has lowered its likely valuation to between $55 billion and $70 billion after delaying its mainland share offering until after its Hong Kong IPO. The delay was triggered by a dispute over the valuation of its China depositary receipts (CDRs), casting doubt on Beijing's efforts to lure foreign-listed Chinese tech giants back home. Xiaomi had previously valued itself at $100 billion. The delay is a blow to Chinese officials, who had designed CDRs as a means for China to compete globally for major tech listings.

site_title: ST Engineering collaborates with SafeRide Technologies to protect autonomous vehicles from cyberattacks
summary: ST Engineering partners with SafeRide Technologies to protect autonomous vehicles from cyberattacks. The collaboration will integrate ST Engineering's cybersecurity capabilities with SafeRide's vSentry software suite to diagnose and eliminate cyber vulnerabilities. The partnership aims to provide multi-layer security for autonomous vehicles and their connected computers. The system will be used in Sentosa's autonomous shuttles set to operate in 2019.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The Singapore High Court granted Hyflux a 6-month reprieve from creditors as the company seeks S$200 million in rescue financing. Singapore dropped to 2nd place in the global digital competitiveness ranking, losing its top spot to the US. The American Chamber of Commerce in Singapore urged the US to rejoin the Trans-Pacific trade pact. Singapore's SMEs remain upbeat despite trade tensions, with caution creeping in. Kantar, a global insights consultancy, launched its first advanced analytics hub in Singapore. CAO plans to divest its stake in a Chinese petrochemical business, while Singapore shares fell 0.7% on Tuesday.

site_title: Most under-35s OK with insurers digital spying if it cuts prices
summary: Most people between 18 and 34 are willing to share their digital data with insurance companies in exchange for lower premiums, with 62% saying they'd be okay with it. This is in contrast to older generations, with 45% of 35-54 year olds and 27% of those 55 and older willing to do so. The survey, of over 8,000 consumers globally, comes as insurers invest in digital offerings amid growing competition from fintech startups, with 58% of respondents citing difficulty with digital services.

site_title: Top Glove Q3 profit up 51.4% to RM117.6m on higher revenue
summary: Top Glove Corp reported a 51.4% increase in third-quarter net profit to RM117.6 million, driven by 26.6% revenue growth to RM1.1 billion. The company attributed stronger earnings to higher glove demand from Asia and Eastern Europe, as well as cost improvements. However, it noted that increased natural gas tariffs and wage costs offset some of the gains. The group declared an interim dividend of seven sen and proposed a bonus issue, subject to shareholder approval.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won extend losses on trade war concerns
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index and the won slid on June 19, 2018, amid US President Donald Trump's threat of new tariffs on Chinese products and a US-South Korea trade spat. The Kospi ended down 1.52% at 2,340.14, while the won hit its lowest since November 2017. The won's value extended losses for a fifth consecutive day. Despite this, some stocks, such as railway-related stocks and cement producers, gained due to the suspension of a joint military drill.

site_title: Singapore slips to 2nd spot in global ranking of digital competiveness
summary: Singapore dropped to 2nd place in a global digital competitiveness ranking, losing its top spot to the US. Despite being ranked 1st in knowledge and technology, Singapore scored low in future-readiness and digital adoption, ranking 15th and 20th respectively. The US made gains in knowledge and technology rankings, while Sweden came in 3rd overall. 29 countries improved their digital competitiveness, with 40% showing a decline.

site_title: Europe and US don't share same "model of civilisation": France
summary: France's government spokesman, Benjamin Griveaux, stated that the US and Europe do not share the same "model of civilization" due to differing values, particularly regarding family separation policies. US President Donald Trump's policy of separating migrant children from their parents at the Mexican border is facing mounting pressure, with reports showing dozens of children held in large metal enclosures. Griveaux expressed concerns that this policy could harm European values, differing from the US approach.

images.alt_text: "I don't want what's happening in the United States to happen in Europe, we don't have the same model of civilisation, clearly we do not share certain values," spokesman Benjamin Griveaux told France 2 television.

site_title: Japan airlines change 'Taiwan' to 'China Taiwan' on websites
summary: Japan's two largest airlines, Japan Airlines and All Nippon Airways, have changed "Taiwan" to "China Taiwan" on their Chinese-language websites, likely to please Beijing but anger the self-ruled island. The change was made on June 12, following a notice from the Chinese Civil Aviation Administration, and remains "Taiwan" on Japanese-language and other websites. Both airlines stated the change was made to accommodate customers and avoid controversy. Taiwan's foreign ministry has announced it will lodge a complaint with the airlines through Japan's diplomatic mission in Taipei.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks plunge on trade war fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted on June 19, 2018, due to fears of a US-China trade war. US President Donald Trump threatened 10% tariffs on hundreds of billions of dollars of Chinese imports, prompting Beijing to label it "blackmail" and vow retaliation. Asian markets, including Shanghai and Shenzhen, saw significant declines, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 3.78% and the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong dropping 2.78%. Analysts warned of uncertainty and irrational behavior, with the Shanghai Composite Index not expected to recover soon.

site_title: Global insights consultancy Kantar locates its first advanced analytics hub in region in Singapore
summary: Kantar, a global insights consultancy, has partnered with the Singapore Economic Development Board to launch its first advanced analytics hub in Asia, the Brand Growth Lab, in Singapore. The lab will utilize Big Data, AI, and machine learning to drive customer-centric decision-making and sustainable growth for companies. The three-year collaboration aims to develop a strong pipeline of Singapore-based talent and expertise in advanced analytics.

site_title: High Court dismisses Shanghai Turbo's application for stay of injunctions
summary: The High Court has dismissed Shanghai Turbo Enterprises' application for a stay of injunctions related to a legal dispute with former executive director Liu Ming. The Mareva and voting injunctions were dismissed, with the company to seek further legal advice and proceed to the Court of Appeal. The dispute began after Liu was voted off the board in April 2017, and Shanghai Turbo is also facing a separate challenge from Zhang Ping and Lin Chuan Jun over a requisition notice for an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Philippines to import rice through 2020 despite rising output - minister
summary: The Philippines is expected to meet 95-96% of its annual rice requirement by 2020, despite a target of being self-sufficient in rice production. The country's paddy rice output is forecast to rise to 19.3 million tonnes, exceeding last year's record-high level. The nation typically imports over 1 million tonnes of rice annually to meet domestic demand, mainly from Vietnam and Thailand, with the state grains stockpiling agency buying rice free of tariffs. The government's economic team has suggested scrapping restrictions on private imports to subject all imports to a 35% tariff.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.7% on Tuesday
