summary: Singapore shares fell 0.7% on Tuesday, tracking regional index declines as US President Donald Trump threatened more tariffs on Chinese goods. The Straits Times Index dropped 22.69 points to 3,301.35. Losers outnumbered gainers 295 to 136, with City Developments and UOL losing 1.34% and 1.58% respectively. Despite this, ComfortDelGro added 0.88% to S$2.30.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: UK's Debenhams warns on profit again, blames weak market
summary: Debenhams, a UK department store, has warned on profit for the third time in six months due to weak market conditions. The company forecasts a pretax profit of 35-40 million pounds for the 2018 financial year, down from market expectations of 50.3 million pounds. Group like-for-like sales fell 1.7% in the 15 weeks to June 16, and the company plans for a material reduction in capital expenditure in the 2019 financial year. Debenhams is conducting a strategic review of non-core assets to maintain a robust balance sheet.

site_title: Roche pays US$2.4b for rest of cancer expert Foundation Medicine
summary: Swiss drugmaker Roche has agreed to pay US$2.4 billion to acquire the remaining stake in Foundation Medicine, a US-based genomic profiling company, valuing it at US$5.3 billion. The deal, worth US$137 per share, is a 29% premium to FMI's closing price and aims to tap into the company's technology to personalize cancer care. Roche plans to preserve FMI's autonomy within the group, similar to its approach with Genentech, a biotech company it acquired 28 years ago.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares slump on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 28.07 points at 1,715.36 points. The index saw 2.31 billion lots traded worth RM2.66 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 673 to 226.

site_title: American Chamber of Commerce in Singapore urges US to rejoin Trans-Pacific trade pact
summary: The American Chamber of Commerce in Singapore has urged the US to rejoin the Comprehensive Progressive Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a trade pact that replaced the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) after the US withdrawal in 2017. The CPTPP, signed by 11 members, aims to eliminate tariffs and non-tariff barriers, improve intellectual property rights, and enhance government procurement contracts. AmCham Singapore chairman Dwight Hutchins stated that the US needs to be a member to ensure US competitiveness in Asia and remain at the forefront of 21st-century trade.

site_title: Intel has paths around Trump's China tariffs, analysts say
summary: Intel, the world's largest chipmaker, may avoid severe effects of US-China tariffs by shifting production among its facilities. Analysts say Intel can shift assembly and test work to non-Chinese facilities, avoiding tariffs on $50 billion worth of Chinese imports. However, memory chips made in China could be directly impacted, and tariffs could also affect US$12.5 billion in revenue from Intel's US plants. Experts warn that trade wars will harm the global economy, and the semiconductor industry will be particularly affected.

site_title: SMEs still upbeat for rest of 2018, but caution has crept in due to trade tensions: index
summary: Singapore Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) remain optimistic about the second half of 2018, with a slight dip in the latest Singapore Business Federation-DP Info (SBF-DP) SME Index to 51.5. The Retail/F&B sector saw the largest improvement in outlook, with Business Services sector remaining the most bullish. However, the ongoing US-China trade disputes have crept in caution, with Ho Meng Kit, CEO of the Singapore Business Federation, stating that the index was expected to improve over the year instead of remaining flat.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slump to 2-month low as US-China spat escalates
summary: European stocks hit a 2-month low, falling 1.2% as investors fret over US-China trade tensions. Mining shares plummeted 3.5% and 5% due to steel and iron ore price drops. Investors are also wary of a potential trade war's impact on exporters. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index is at its lowest level in almost two months, with some analysts calling it a "market response" rather than a "bloodbath."

site_title: Australian shares end flat as materials slide; NZ slumps
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Tuesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing two points lower at 6,102.10, despite gains in healthcare stocks and banks. Materials stocks fell 1.2% due to a sharp drop in iron ore prices, with BHP and Rio Tinto Ltd experiencing significant declines. New Zealand's benchmark index slumped 1.2% to a three-month low, while the Australian dollar reached its lowest level in a year.

site_title: Capgemini sizes up 'Big Tech' threat to wealth management
summary: Capgemini's World Wealth Report 2018 finds that over 50% of high net worth individuals globally are interested in Big Tech firms for wealth management, with Asia-Pacific leading the way at 81.5%. Despite robust returns, global client satisfaction with wealth managers has not risen, with satisfaction levels at 64.6% and 63.4% for firms and wealth managers, respectively. The report suggests that Big Tech's entry into wealth management is likely in Asia, followed by North America and Europe, via collaboration or competition, with nearly 60% of HNWIs willing to start a relationship with a Big Tech firm within six months.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon trading at 3,332, up 0.2% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Tuesday afternoon with the Straits Times Index advancing 7.96 points, or 0.2%, to 3,332. The most actively traded counters included Allied Tech, Venture Corp, and UOB. Losers outnumbered gainers 175 to 147, with about 911.1 million shares worth S$639.4 million changing hands.

site_title: CAO to divest remaining stake in Xinyuan associate
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) plans to divest its entire 39% equity interest in China Aviation Oil Xinyuan Petrochemicals Co, a petrochemical-focused business in China. The Singapore-listed firm will pursue a listing-for-sale through the China Beijing Equity Exchange. This move comes over a decade after CAO sold a 41% stake in its Xinyuan subsidiary in 2007 for 20.5 million yuan. The proposed divestment is expected to proceed without disrupting CAO's operations.

site_title: Russians, foreigners seek love at World Cup
summary: Foreigners and Russians are mixing at the World Cup in Moscow, with many foreign fans seeking romantic connections with local women. Despite warnings from some politicians about potential mixed-race children, thousands of women are taking advantage of the opportunity to meet foreigners. The Kremlin has taken a neutral stance, saying that World Cup romances are personal choices. Some women, like Maria S., are using the World Cup as a chance to "change Russia's image" and challenge stereotypes about Russian women.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index down more than 1.7% over trade row
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index fell 1.77% to 22,278.48, amid US-China trade tensions and a strong yen. The broader Topix index also dropped 1.55%. Investors' jitters over trade row and yen strength led to the decline.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS initiates 'buy' on AA Reit
summary: DBS Group Research initiated a "buy" rating on Aims AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) with a 12-month target price of S$1.55, representing a 13% upside. The broker cited redevelopment of underutilised sites as a potential factor to raise its fair value estimate to S$1.65. At the time of the announcement, the counter was trading flat at S$1.38.

site_title: Trump threatens to hit China with new tariffs on US$200b in goods
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened to impose a 10% tariff on $200 billion of Chinese goods in retaliation for China's decision to raise tariffs on $50 billion in US goods. Trump stated that the tariffs would go into effect if China refuses to change its practices. This escalation in the trade war between the US and China has raised concerns about the impact on global markets and economies.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump threatened on Monday to impose a 10 percent tariff on $200 billion of Chinese goods, escalating a tit-for-tat trade war with Beijing.

site_title: Malaysia's annual inflation seen quickening in May
summary: Malaysia's annual inflation is expected to have accelerated to 1.8% in May, according to a Reuters poll of economists. The increase is attributed to higher fuel and food prices, particularly during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan. This marks a rise from the 1.4% inflation rate in April, driven by higher food costs. The acceleration in inflation is a concern for policymakers.

site_title: Young at heart? Mercedes cultivates its ageing workforce
summary: Mercedes-Benz is launching a company-wide campaign to combat negative stereotypes about older workers, as Germany grapples with an ageing population. The luxury brand has developed an exhibition to challenge stereotypes, offering tests to measure physical and cognitive abilities. The initiative aims to promote age diversity, encouraging employees and management to work together. Meanwhile, rival carmaker BMW expects workers over 50 to make up 35% of its workforce by 2020, and the German government is moving to discourage early retirement and raise the pension age.

images.alt_text: Too slow, inflexible, forgetful, always off sick. Those are some attitudes about older workers that carmaker Mercedes-Benz is trying to dispel as Germany grapples with the challenges of an ageing society.

site_title: Napoleon's hat, dropped at Waterloo, is picked up at auction for US$400,000
summary: A hat attributed to Napoleon Bonaparte, dropped at the Battle of Waterloo in 1815, was sold at an auction in Lyon, France for $400,000, including fees. The black felt bicorn hat is one of only 19 remaining from Napoleon's military dress, and its sale reflects the enduring fascination with the French emperor. Historians have identified the hat's provenance, which includes being a war trophy and showcased at a 1897 world's fair, and experts attribute its high price to Napoleon's enduring popularity and the rarity of such historical artifacts.

site_title: Rate hikes, volatile prices and low yields top financial advisers' concerns: Natixis survey
summary: Financial advisers worldwide cite rising interest rates, asset price volatility, and low yields as top market risks, with 57% focusing on interest rate hikes. Asset price volatility, driven by uncertainty over central bank quantitative easing, is a secondary concern. Only 37% of respondents foresee a bond bubble, while 21% predict a stock bubble. Cryptocurrencies, however, are the most concerning asset class, with three-quarters of respondents expecting a bubble to burst in 2018. Most advisers are only using bond duration management to mitigate rising rates, with only half as likely to deploy alternative investments.

site_title: Court gives Hyflux 6-month break from creditors; company in talks for S$200m rescue financing
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted Hyflux a six-month moratorium on creditors' claims, giving the water and power company a temporary reprieve from its debt burden. Hyflux is seeking S$200 million in rescue financing and is in talks with 27 interested parties. The company is also discussing the sale of its Tuaspring Integrated Water and Power Project, which could fetch S$1.3 billion at its book value. A six-month update will be required to the court and creditors, and the company plans to use the moratorium to restructure its debt and negotiate with creditors.

site_title: China stocks plunge nearly 5% to two-year low on tariff threat; yuan sinks
summary: China's benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell nearly 5% to a two-year low on June 19, 2018, amid a US trade dispute threat. US President Donald Trump's plan to impose tariffs on another $200 billion in Chinese imports weakened the yuan to a five-month low. China vowed to take "strong" countermeasures, while investors feared further restrictions on Chinese tech and Internet products, potentially hurting the domestic economy. The decline also affected other markets, with Shenzhen's technology stocks plummeting 6.7% and ZTE Corp's Hong Kong shares sliding 26%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of an empty area at the Birmingham Bullring shopping centre, owned by mall operator Hammerson, as the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) continues, in Birmingham, Britain, April 9, 2020. REUTERS/Carl Recine/File Photo##########kelreeling##########

site_title: New Zealand softens ban on foreigners' home ownership in amended bill
summary: New Zealand's government has softened its stance on foreign ownership of homes by rewriting a proposed law that would have banned non-residents from investing in housing. The amended bill allows non-residents to own up to 60% of large, new apartment buildings and exempts Singaporeans due to a free trade agreement. The changes aim to attract foreign investment to tackle a housing shortage, but the Real Estate Institute of New Zealand remains opposed to the ban, citing its ineffective in resolving housing affordability issues. The law still requires Parliament's approval.

site_title: Asia: Markets tumble with China, US towards trade war
summary: Asian markets plummeted on June 19, 2018, amid rising trade war fears after US President Donald Trump threatened fresh tariffs on Chinese imports. China retaliated with countermeasures, prompting investors to sell off shares. Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks dropped over 2%, while Tokyo, Seoul, and Taipei also declined. The US had previously imposed tariffs on $50 billion worth of Chinese goods, and Trump announced plans to hit an additional $200 billion if China retaliates. The move sparked concerns of a potentially damaging trade war between the US and China.

site_title: China's stock index falls below 3,000 for 1st time since 2016 amid growing trade tensions
summary: China's stock index fell below 3,000 for the first time since 2016 due to growing trade tensions with the US, with the Shanghai Composite Index retreating 1.7% amid US President Donald Trump's threat to slap tariffs on another $200 billion in Chinese imports. The yuan weakened to its lowest level against the greenback since mid-January, and investors worry that the selloff might topple the market. China's government vowed to take "strong" counter measures if new levies are issued.

site_title: World's oldest Sumatran orangutan dies aged 62
summary: The world's oldest Sumatran orangutan, Puan, died at 62, leaving behind 54 descendants across the globe. Born in 1956, she was noted by the Guinness Book of Records as the oldest verified Sumatran orangutan. Puan lived at Perth Zoo since 1968 and was a founding member of the world-renowned breeding program, contributing 10% to the global zoological population. She had 11 children and was known for her aloof and independent nature. Puan's legacy will live on through her descendants, including her great-grandson Nyaru, who was recently released into the wild.

site_title: ExxonMobil investigating reported vandalism on gas pipe project in Papua New Guinea
summary: ExxonMobil is investigating reports of vandalism on its Angore gas pipeline construction project in Papua New Guinea, amid ongoing unrest in the Highlands region. Security forces are also investigating, following a state of emergency declared by the government after rioters protested a failed court challenge. The 11-km pipeline is being built to connect the Angore gas field to the Hides gas conditioning plant, and production remains normal despite the incident.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, Raffles United, Envictus International, CapitaLand
summary: Singapore's second-largest bank OCBC expects to hit at least S$1 billion in pre-tax profits from the Greater Bay Area by 2023, doubling its current level. Raffles United Holdings has more executives reporting to the Commercial Affairs Department regarding potential breaches of the Securities and Futures Act. Envictus International Holdings is undertaking a rights cum warrants issue of up to 113.5 million new shares. CapitaLand has clinched two new mall management contracts in Guangzhou and Chengdu, expanding its shopping mall business.

site_title: Kraft Heinz is said to consider US$1b Complan sale in India
summary: Kraft Heinz is considering selling its Indian children's milk drink brand Complan for approximately $1 billion. The company is working with an adviser to gauge interest from local companies and private equity firms. This move comes as consumer acquisitions in India have more than doubled to $7.7 billion in the first half of 2018. The sale could also be influenced by GlaxoSmithKline's decision to sell its stake in the Indian consumer health subsidiary that owns malted milk drinks brand Horlicks.

site_title: Kim Jong Un visiting China for third time since March
summary: North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un has begun a two-day visit to China, his third trip since March. The visit comes after a landmark summit meeting with US President Donald Trump in Singapore. Unlike his previous trips, which were not announced until after they ended, China's official news agency announced the visit in advance. The trip highlights China's growing influence in North Korea's international relations.

site_title: Asia: Stocks drop, yen jumps on new Trump tariff threat
summary: Asian stocks declined, following a global downturn, as US President Donald Trump threatened new tariffs on Chinese goods. The yen rose amid market turmoil and political tensions. Trump announced plans to impose a 10% tariff on $200 billion of Chinese goods in response to Beijing's decision to raise tariffs on $50 billion of US goods. Financial markets remain on edge, with investors worried about a full-blown trade conflict that could derail global growth.

site_title: Cardless cash withdrawal app soCash adds 7-Eleven to Singapore merchant network
summary: soCash, a cardless cash withdrawal app, has partnered with 7-Eleven to expand its merchant network to 370 stores in Singapore. This brings the total number of locations to over 1,000, allowing users of DBS Bank, POSB, and Standard Chartered to withdraw cash with any purchase using the app. SoCash is also offering new users a S$5 cash back incentive to sign up.

site_title: Chinese resorts quietly setting up baccarat tables in Hainan
summary: Chinese resorts on the tropical island of Hainan are secretly setting up baccarat tables in entertainment bars, a move that could pave the way for full-blown casinos on the island. The bars, which offer real-money gaming but redeem winnings in points redeemable at local shops and hotels, have been planned by resorts and suppliers in recent months. This development comes after a favorable court ruling in December and follows China's push to turn Hainan into a major tourist destination. The move could pose a competitive threat to Macau's casino industry and may face challenges from regulators, but could also boost Hainan's tourism-related businesses.

site_title: Chinese parents-to-be seek more fertile ground abroad
summary: Chinese parents-to-be are increasingly seeking fertility options abroad due to China's restricted IVF procedures and long waiting lists. Many are turning to Southeast Asia, the US, and other countries for in-vitro fertilization (IVF) treatments, with Thailand being a popular destination. The easing of China's one-child policy has led to a surge in demand, with an estimated 90 million women becoming eligible for another child. Chinese couples are willing to spend thousands of dollars for higher-quality care, and some clinics are now marketing specifically to Chinese clients, with Mandarin-speaking staff and websites.

site_title: In Trump rebuke, US Senate votes to reimpose ban on China's ZTE
summary: The US Senate voted to overrule President Donald Trump's administration's deal with Chinese telecom firm ZTE, reimposing a ban on high-tech chip sales to the company. The ban was initially lifted in 2017 but was later reinstated due to ZTE's violation of trade sanctions. The decision was made as part of a national defense spending bill, which cleared the chamber on an 85-10 vote. This move defied Trump's earlier stance on the issue.

site_title: Jilted Fujifilm sues Xerox for US$1b after aborted merger
summary: Japanese technology giant Fujifilm is suing US firm Xerox for over $1 billion in damages after a merger between the two companies was scrapped due to a lawsuit by powerful shareholders. The merger was halted after a New York judge ruled that it prioritized the interests of the CEO over shareholders. Fujifilm claims Xerox made a "unilateral decision" and accuses the company of mismanagement. Xerox will "vigorously defend its decision" and pursue remedies, with billionaire activist Carl Icahn seen as a victor in the deal's collapse.

images.alt_text: Japanese technology giant Fujifilm said Tuesday it was suing US firm Xerox, seeking more than US$1 billion in damages after a merger between the two firms was scrapped last month.

site_title: Toll rises to four after quake in Japan's Osaka
summary: A powerful earthquake in Japan's Osaka on Monday has raised the death toll to four, with over 380 injured. The fourth fatality was an 81-year-old woman trapped under a chest of drawers in her house. A nine-year-old girl also died after a collapsed wall at her school. Officials have urged vigilance against landslides ahead of heavy rains.

site_title: China slams US trade threats as 'blackmail', warns of countermeasures
summary: China has condemned US President Donald Trump's threat to impose 10% tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods, calling it "blackmail." China's commerce ministry warned that it will take "comprehensive measures" and "strong, powerful countermeasures" if the US goes through with the tariffs, which would significantly impact global trade. The US practice of imposing tariffs has "greatly disappointed international society," according to the Chinese statement.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 6.06 points to 1,737.37. The market saw 37.69 million lots traded worth RM17.34 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 93 to 91.

site_title: Marriage is (literally) good for the heart: study
summary: A study of over 2 million people aged 42 to 77 found that living into old age with a partner significantly reduces the risk of heart disease and stroke. Compared to the divorced, widowed, or never married, those in a spousal union had a 42% lower risk of cardiovascular disease and 16% lower risk of coronary heart disease. The risk of dying from stroke was also 55% lower. While the study couldn't establish a cause-and-effect link, researchers suggest that having a partner may provide emotional support, healthcare monitoring, and financial stability, which could contribute to these protective effects.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on US-China trade jitters
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on June 19, 2018, due to US-China trade tensions. US President Donald Trump threatened to impose a 10% tariff on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods, causing investors to become jittery. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.43% to 22,582.44, while the Topix index dropped 0.39% to 1,764.55.

site_title: Oil rises ahead of Opec, China tariffs loom over US prices
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday as market participants lowered expectations for Opec's potential production increase, amid growing concerns over US-China trade tensions. US crude oil rose 79 cents to settle at $65.85 a barrel, while Brent crude jumped $1.90 to $75.34 a barrel. The market expects Opec to increase production by 300,000-600,000 barrels per day, potentially supporting prices despite growing volumes of US crude from shale without a buyer.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose on Monday in volatile trade as market participants lowered their expectations for how much Opec might increase production and investors assessed the impact of a trade dispute between the United States and China.

site_title: Trump wants to dominate space, Moon and Mars
summary: President Donald Trump announced plans to create a new US military branch, the Space Force, to dominate space exploration and combat potential threats from China and Russia. He also vowed to send humans back to the Moon and eventually to Mars, with the goal of establishing an American presence in space. The proposal, which requires Congressional approval, aims to reclaim the US as the world's greatest space-faring nation and to privatize the International Space Station after 2025.

site_title: ZTE shares plunge 17% after US Senate votes to reimpose ban
summary: US senators voted to reimpose a ban on high-tech chip sales to Chinese telecoms equipment maker ZTE, causing its shares to plummet 17% in the first few minutes of trade. This marks the latest setback for the company, which has fallen 60% since its trading resumption last week. The ban was initially imposed in 2017 due to ZTE's involvement in a corruption scandal. The move is expected to have significant implications for ZTE's business and operations.

site_title: Tesla hit with 'extensive' sabotage by rogue employee: Musk
summary: A Tesla employee, denied a promotion, allegedly broke into the company's manufacturing operating system and sent sensitive data to unknown parties, causing "extensive and damaging sabotage" to Tesla's operations. Elon Musk is leading an investigation, citing potential outside organizations involved. Musk warned staff to be vigilant, referencing a fire that halted car production and referencing Andy Grove's quote "Only the paranoid survive." Tesla is racing to meet production targets, with a goal of building 5,000 Model 3 sedans a week by the end of the month.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly higher on Tuesday, STI up 0.1% to 3,328.41
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.1% to 3,328.41 on Tuesday, despite global markets being unnerved by escalating US-China trade tensions. US President Donald Trump threatened a 10% tariff on $200 billion of Chinese goods, but Singapore's stocks gained as the US market fell overnight. Allied Tech rose 3.6%, UOB increased 1.2%, and Venture Corp fell 2.6%.

site_title: North Korea's Kim 'planning China visit': report
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is reportedly planning a visit to China as early as Tuesday to brief President Xi Jinping on last week's summit with US President Donald Trump. This would mark the third time Kim has visited China since March, and is seen as a bid for economic sanctions relief in exchange for denuclearization. China had suggested easing UN sanctions following the Singapore summit, and US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo briefed Xi soon after. Kim's visit comes amid ongoing US-North Korea talks and a push for a "verifiable" denuclearization deal.

site_title: Biotech billionaire takes over at Los Angeles Times, new editor named
summary: Biotech billionaire Patrick Soon-Shiong has acquired the Los Angeles Times for $500 million, assuming $90 million in pension liabilities. He immediately named Norman Pearlstine, a 75-year-old journalist with 50 years of experience, as top editor. The move aims to revitalize the struggling newspaper, which has seen newsroom unrest and a decline in readership due to the shift to online news platforms. Soon-Shiong's investment is part of a trend of billionaires reviving US metropolitan newspapers, following Amazon's takeover of The Washington Post and John Henry's deal for The Boston Globe.

site_title: Mercari, a rare Japanese unicorn, soars 76 per cent in debut
summary: Mercari, a Japanese unicorn, made its Tokyo stock market debut, with shares surging 76% to 5,280 yen, valuing the company at about $6.5 billion. The popular flea market app has been downloaded 71 million times in Japan, with 10.5 million active users, and expects sales to jump 62% to 35.8 billion yen this financial year. Mercari's debut makes it the most valuable firm on the Tokyo bourse's Mothers market for start-ups.

site_title: CapitaLand to manage two more malls in China
summary: CapitaLand has secured two new mall management contracts in China, one in Guangzhou and the other in Chengdu, expanding its retail network in South China to 3.6 million square feet. The company now owns and manages 11 malls in western China with a total retail GFA of 11.3 million square feet. This latest addition brings CapitaLand's total retail GFA in China to 14.9 million square feet, with plans to open five malls this year, targeting a total retail GFA of 4.2 million square feet.

site_title: Pompeo says he will likely visit North Korea's Kim soon
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said he expects to meet with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un soon to discuss nuclear disarmament. Pompeo laid groundwork for the historic summit between Kim and President Trump in Singapore, and is now planning follow-up talks. He believes Kim is serious about denuclearization and committed to "everything" including dismantling all nuclear systems. Pompeo's team is working to flesh out details of the deal, and he may visit North Korea before the end of the year to finalize agreements.

site_title: Americans own 40% of world's firearms: study
summary: Americans own 40% of the world's firearms, despite making up only 4% of the global population. The Small Arms Survey found that 393 million of the 857 million civilian-owned guns are in the US, more than all of the other top 25 countries combined. Americans have access to powerful firearms due to the country's permissive gun laws, with 121 firearms for every 100 residents, compared to 53 in Yemen and 35 in Canada. The US is the largest market for civilian firearms, with 14 million guns purchased annually.

site_title: OCBC targets S$1b profit from China's Greater Bay Area by 2023
summary: OCBC Bank aims to double its pre-tax earnings from the Greater Bay Area, a region comprising Hong Kong, Macau, and Guangdong cities, to S$1 billion by 2023. The bank plans to invest S$200 million in technology and increase staff by 40% to 4,200, with a focus on capturing investment and capital flows between China and Southeast Asia. The region is expected to contribute significantly to China's GDP, with projected growth of 15% per annum in customer loans, and OCBC is well-positioned to capitalize on this opportunity.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore hotel RevPAR growth appears to have turned a corner after several years of declines. According to CBC Investment Research, the growth is expected to accelerate from Q1 2018 levels, driven by a back-end loaded supply injection last year. Meanwhile, mainland China's RevPAR growth turned positive in Q1 2017, with luxury hotels still in the early stages of recovery.

site_title: Strike-prone French air traffic control big cause of Europe delays
summary: French air traffic control is responsible for a third of Europe's aviation delays, with strikes and outdated equipment being major contributors. Between 2004 and 2016, French controllers were on strike for 254 days, compared to 46 days in Greece and 37 days in Italy. This has significant implications for European air travel, with French air traffic control being a major bottleneck in the region.

site_title: Head of Volkswagen's Audi arrested in Germany over diesel scandal
summary: Volkswagen's Audi CEO Rupert Stadler was arrested in Germany as part of a probe into emissions test cheating, throwing the company into turmoil. The arrest may raise tensions on the supervisory board, putting a fragile truce at risk. Volkswagen is holding crisis talks to find a stand-in boss for Audi, amid ongoing efforts to reform itself after the cheating revelations emerged in 2015.

site_title: Cheaper option to HSR project mooted to M'sian govt: report
summary: A cheaper alternative to Malaysia's planned high-speed rail link with Singapore has been proposed to the government, estimated at RM20 billion compared to the original RM60-70 billion HSR project. The alternative involves upgrading existing rail infrastructure, which could save the government RM500 million in potential compensation. Travel time between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore would remain at 130 minutes, but could be reduced further with new locomotives.

site_title: Singapore LNG inks deal with energy trader Trafigura
summary: Singapore LNG has signed an agreement with energy trader Trafigura for 160,000 cubic meters of firm LNG storage at the SLNG Terminal on Jurong Island for 24 months. This is Trafigura's second storage and reloading agreement with Singapore LNG, following a previous two-year deal that ended in 2017. The agreement was signed on May 30 in response to a call for proposals launched by Singapore LNG in April.

site_title: One dead, five wounded in Swedish shooting: police
summary: A shooting in Malmo, Sweden, on Monday resulted in one death and five injuries. Police have ruled out a terrorist link, with the 18-year-old suspect still being investigated. The incident occurred in the city's centre, and authorities are working to determine the motive behind the attack.

images.alt_text: One person was killed and five wounded in a shooting in the centre of the southern Swedish city of Malmo on Monday, police said, ruling out a terrorist link.

site_title: Europe: Shares retreat on trade tensions
summary: European shares declined 0.8% on Monday, following losses in Asia and a weak US market open, amid ongoing US-China trade tensions. The Stoxx 600 index fell despite the European Central Bank's decision to keep interest rates at record lows. Germany's DAX underperformed, with Volkswagen and Adidas losing 3.3% and 2.7%, respectively, amid concerns over Angela Merkel's government stability. France's Nexans plummeted 16% after a profit warning, while aerospace supplier Cobham rose 4.6% after an upgrade.

site_title: Boeing creates one-stop shop for jets and services in Airbus battle
summary: Boeing has reorganized its sales operations to focus on services, a move that has helped the company take the lead over rival Airbus this year. The US$50 billion services division, established in 2017, aims to provide a one-stop shop for jets and services. This strategic shift has contributed to Boeing's growth in the market, positioning the company as a leader in the aviation industry.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks sink at open on trade war fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.02% at the open on Tuesday as investors reacted to fresh concerns about a China-US trade war. The Hang Seng Index fell to 29,999.01, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also declined. The decline follows tit-for-tat tariffs on billions of dollars worth of goods between the two countries, sparking fears of a trade war's impact on global markets.

site_title: Top US court to rule in Apple case over app monopoly
summary: The US Supreme Court agreed to hear a case about whether Apple can be sued for monopolizing the distribution of mobile applications on its App Store. The case, which could have significant implications for Apple and its mobile ecosystem, centers on whether the iPhone maker has the right to a "closed" system where only the company can distribute mobile apps. A lower court dismissed the complaint, but an appellate panel reversed the decision, allowing the case to proceed. The Justice Department backs Apple's position, and the high court will rule on the case later this year.

images.alt_text: The US Supreme Court agreed Monday to hear a case on whether Apple can be sued under antitrust law for monopolising the distribution of mobile applications on its App Store.

site_title: AT&T is changing Time Warner's name to WarnerMedia
summary: AT&T is rebranding Time Warner as WarnerMedia, following its acquisition of the company in 2018. The name change is intended to avoid confusion with Time Warner, the former cable company, now known as Spectrum. John Stankey will lead WarnerMedia, replacing John Martin as CEO of Turner Broadcasting. Other executives, including Howard Averill and Gary Ginsberg, are also leaving the company. The change reflects AT&T's desire to unify its media assets under a single brand.

site_title: Argentina: Stock market plunges 8.33%
summary: Argentina's stock market plummeted 8.33% on Monday, with the Merval Index dropping to 27,636 points, amid market volatility and President Mauricio Macri's surprise firing of Energy and Production Ministers. The move comes ahead of a "Super Tuesday" debt renewal and as the country seeks a $15 billion IMF loan. The peso has continued to recover, gaining 0.66% on Monday, but investors remain cautious. The IMF loan is seen as a bid to bolster market confidence and prevent a run on the peso, which has lost nearly 35% of its value since January.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo by the US on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss in H2. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a former DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC are deepening cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 fall on trade war worries
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.4% to 24,987.54, and the S&P 500 shedding 0.2% to 2,773.87, amid worries over rising trade tensions between the US and China. Analysts attributed the decline to investors' concerns over a potential escalation of trade measures that could impact the global economy. Petroleum producers saw gains, while consumer-oriented stocks were under pressure, with some companies like CVS Health losing 3.4%.

site_title: Australia's Atlas Iron gets US$290m bid from Hancock Prospecting unit
summary: Atlas Iron Ltd received a $290 million bid from Hancock Prospecting's Redstone Corporation, a unit of Australian billionaire Gina Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting, offering $0.042 per share, a 17% premium. This trumps a $280.2 million bid from Mineral Resources. Fortescue Metals, which owns a 19.9% stake in Atlas, may block Mineral Resources' planned takeover. The bid follows a trading halt announcement by Atlas regarding a "control transaction proposal".

site_title: H1 M&A deals in Singapore up 19% at US$33.8b
summary: M&A activity in Singapore surged 19% in the first half of 2018, reaching $33.8 billion, driven mainly by Q2 activity. Average deal size increased to $127.1 million, with domestic deals totaling $3.8 billion. China was the most active acquirer, capturing half of Singapore's inbound activity, while the US and Japan followed. Outbound M&A activity also increased 24.5%, with materials being the most targeted sector.

site_title: Pacific Radiance pegs direct equity swaps for notes at S$0.101
summary: Pacific Radiance has pegged the straight debt-to-equity swap option for holders of its S$100 million medium-term notes at S$0.101, a slight discount to its last traded share price. This move is part of the company's efforts to restructure its debt. The terms for the options were tabled at an informal meeting with noteholders, providing an opportunity for the company to restructure its debt and potentially improve its financial position.

site_title: Rebel developers are trying to cure our smartphone addiction - with an app
summary: Rebel developers are creating apps to combat smartphone addiction, a growing concern in the digital age. Inspired by BF Skinner's pigeons, these developers aim to counterprogram notifications and social media algorithms that exploit users' psychological vulnerabilities. Recent victories include Google and Apple's incorporation of digital wellness features into their operating systems. Researchers like Nick Fitz and Kevin Holesh are developing apps that track screen time, provide variable rewards, and encourage users to take breaks, resulting in lower stress and improved productivity. The digital wellness movement seeks to reclaim users' attention and promote healthier relationships with technology.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: RAFFLES United Holdings announced that more top executives have bonded to report potential breaches of the Securities and Futures Act. Managing director Teo Teng Beng, CFO Ho Hui Min, and executives Koh Hai Yang and Kwek Che Yong provided a bond to report back to the Commercial Affairs Department. Meanwhile, ENVICTUS International Holdings is undertaking a rights cum warrants issue of up to 113.5 million new shares at S$0.16 per share. The issue is expected to raise approximately S$17.92 million, with the potential for higher revenue if all shares are subscribed.

site_title: Blockchain could be game changer in sustainable development goals
summary: Singapore recently hosted a gathering of businesses and NGOs focused on achieving the 17 UN Sustainable Development Goals by 2033. Blockchain technology has been proposed as a game-changer in sustainable development, with potential applications in areas such as supply chain management, environmental tracking, and resource allocation. The event aimed to leverage blockchain's decentralized and transparent nature to promote accountability and efficiency in achieving the goals. However, progress has been slow, and the UN has acknowledged that time is running out to meet the deadline.

site_title: Astrea IV Class A-1 bonds close first trading day at 103.7
summary: Astrea IV Class A-1 bonds closed their first trading day at 103.7, translating to a yield of 3.53%. The bonds were rated Asf by Fitch and A(sf) by S&P.

site_title: Oil slumps towards US$64 a barrel as Opec clash looms
summary: Oil prices slumped near $64 a barrel as Saudi Arabia and Russia prepared for a potential OPEC meeting, amid rising tensions between the US and China. The decline was also attributed to US President Trump's $50 billion tariff on Chinese imports, which led China to threaten tariffs on US goods, including oil and petrol. Iran's support for blocking a production increase proposal further fueled the decline.

site_title: Liberty refuses to pay ransom after computer systems are hacked
summary: Liberty Holdings Ltd, a South African insurer, refused to pay a ransom after hackers breached its IT infrastructure and accessed some emails. The breach, which occurred in June 2018, did not appear to have resulted in any financial loss to customers. The insurer, which has over 2.5 million life-insurance policies, stated that the hackers primarily stole emails and attachments. Liberty is investigating the breach and has not disclosed the identity of the hackers or the amount demanded. The insurer's CEO, David Munro, emphasized that the company's IT infrastructure is secure and that customer data is protected.

site_title: Last of Henri Jayer's Burgundies sold for 30m euros
summary: The last batch of legendary winemaker Henri Jayer's Burgundies was sold for 30 million euros (S$47 million) at a Geneva auction, exceeding the estimated price. The 1,064 bottles, including Cros-Parantoux, a world's priciest wine, were sold after a six and a half hour auction. The sale price reflects the "speculation effect" and "collector effect" of acquiring a rare wine heritage. Jayer's daughters hope the new owners will drink and enjoy the wines, rather than letting them gather dust.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust to buy three Osaka hotels for 10.29b yen
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust has agreed to acquire three hotels in Osaka, Japan for 10.29 billion yen (S$126.1 million), a 2.9% discount to the latest valuation. The hotels, Hotel WBF Kitasemba West, Hotel WBF Kitasemba East, and Hotel WBF Honmachi, will be managed by White Bear Family and are expected to be completed by September 2018 and January 2019. The acquisition is expected to be fully funded by debt and is projected to be accretive to stapled security holders of the trust, with a potential increase in distribution per stapled security of 4.3%.

site_title: CYBG to buy Branson's Virgin Money for £1.7b
summary: CYBG Plc has agreed to buy Virgin Money Holdings UK Plc for about £1.7 billion in an all-stock transaction, creating a bank with about six million customers. The purchase gives consumer and business lender CYBG greater scale and access to the high street. The deal aims to challenge Britain's largest lenders, with CYBG gaining potential cost savings and increased presence. The acquisition is expected to be completed in the coming months, pending regulatory approvals.

site_title: Helping clients to embark on their overseas and digital journeys
summary: Louken Group, a branding and communication company, has evolved from being a client-led firm to a leading provider of services. Founded in 2001, Louken initially focused on brand management and IP, but soon expanded to serve clients abroad and in the digital space. The firm acquired expertise in digital innovation and expanded its capabilities through mergers and acquisitions. Today, Louken offers a range of services, from brand development to digital implementation, and is grooming and incubating startups. The company aims to help clients, particularly small and medium enterprises, navigate the digital landscape and expand into new markets, including China.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Retail investors of Astrea IV bonds know a good deal when they see one
summary: Retail investors have shown enthusiasm for Astrea IV bonds, a private equity offering from Azalea Asset Management, a subsidiary of Temasek Holdings. The bonds, launched in June, were the world's first listed private equity bond for retail investors and offered a 4.35% annual coupon. Despite initial skepticism, the bonds were oversubscribed, with only half of the Class A-1 tranche allocated to retail investors, who received a lower allocation than institutional investors. The success of the retail offering reflects growing appetite for sophisticated investments among retail investors, who are seeking better yields at a reasonable risk.

site_title: Why Singapore needs to save its offshore O&G services industry
summary: Singapore's offshore oil and gas (O&G) services industry is in disarray due to inefficiencies, debt, and a lack of investment in people, processes, and technologies. The industry has struggled since 2014, with thousands of job losses and vendor unpaid bills. Despite oil prices recovering, the supply overhang remains large, and the industry's internal weaknesses, including fragmentation and overdependence on a few clients, hinder its growth. To revive the industry, Singapore needs a paradigm shift in approach, with a focus on technological change, value-added services, and a financial and technological ecosystem that gives the country an unbeatable edge.

site_title: Asia equities battered again by US-China trade spat
summary: Asia's equities declined as tensions between the US and China escalated, with Singapore's Straits Times Index falling 0.97% and Tokyo losing 0.75%. US President Donald Trump plans to impose $34 billion in tariffs on Chinese imports on July 6, prompting China to threaten equal retaliation. Analysts warn that Asia's export-dependent currencies, such as the Singapore dollar and South Korean won, may depreciate further, posing significant economic harm if the trade tensions escalate.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Starbucks CEO Johnson takes the reins from high-profile Schultz
summary: Starbucks CEO Kevin Johnson is taking over as CEO after Howard Schultz's departure at the end of the month. Johnson, who has been in the role for over a year, will be in charge of the company's transition and navigating operational challenges. Despite Schultz's emotional leadership, Johnson has shown analytical rigour, simplifying the company and improving profitability. Starbucks is a relatively healthy company, with same-store sales growth and a market value of $78 billion. Johnson faces challenges such as meeting the demands of health-conscious consumers and balancing growth with operational efficiency. Schultz is rumored to be considering a presidential run, but Johnson remains committed to the company's success.

site_title: Soilbuild bags Kemaman Point with S$143m bid
summary: Soilbuild Group Holdings won the collective sale of Kemaman Point in Singapore with a bid of S$143.88 million. The 89-unit residential development is expected to be redeveloped into a high-rise development with a gross plot ratio of 2.8, translating to a land price of about S$1,173 per square foot. Each of the 89 owners is set to receive between S$1.4 million and S$2.32 million. The sale is subject to several conditions, including an order from the Strata Titles Board or High Court.

site_title: OCBC, UOB cards now available on NETSPay app
summary: OCBC Bank and UOB customers can now store their NETS ATM bankcards digitally on the NETSPay mobile app, allowing for NETS payments through mobile phones. This feature was announced by NETS on June 18, 2018.

site_title: Hedge funds get bullish on oil again as Opec prepares to meet
summary: Hedge funds have become bullish on oil again as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) prepares to meet. Following two months of cutting bets on rising prices, hedge funds boosted wagers on a price rebound, with some analysts predicting a potential $100 a barrel price. However, recent comments from Saudi Arabia and Russia on production increases ahead of the Opec meeting have injected uncertainty, causing London oil futures to drop 4% over two days. The outcome of the meeting remains uncertain, leaving the future of the oil price in question.

site_title: Funds wary of Malaysia as 1MDB swells debt
summary: Malaysia's debt, largely due to 1MDB, has surged to RM1 trillion (S$337 billion), a 60% increase from previous estimates. Funds are cutting their holdings, with bond yields dropping to the lowest since August. The government faces an increasing fiscal squeeze, and rating agencies may downgrade Malaysia if its fiscal health deteriorates. Despite concerns, some investors believe the economy will gradually decline the debt-to-GDP ratio. The government remains on track to meet its 2018 budget deficit target of 2.8% of GDP.

site_title: Australia unions' decline curbing wage growth
summary: Australian workers are experiencing stagnant wage growth, with annual increases lagging inflation. Despite a record 26 years of economic growth, job security and overall wellbeing are concerns. A decline in trade union membership has allowed employers to set wage rises without challenge, exacerbating the issue. Experts believe this decline has contributed to the lack of collective bargaining power for workers.

images.alt_text: Australian union membership has been plunging because of the demise of traditional manufacturing industries that were heavily unionised, and labour market deregulation in the 1990s.

site_title: OCBC keen to expand into onshore wealth management in China
summary: OCBC Bank is evaluating expansion into China's onshore wealth management space, citing increasing demand from domestic clients and the government's plan to open up its financial sector. The bank plans to build a presence in the Greater Bay Area and tap into its partnership with Bank of Ningbo to create an onshore fund management business. OCBC is not pursuing acquisitions, instead focusing on organic growth, as the Chinese government scraps limits on foreign ownership for banks and other financial institutions.

site_title: STI slips amid trade war, oil price fears
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed down 32.69 points, or 0.97%, at 3,324.04, amid trade war jitters and oil price fears. The decline was attributed to weak sentiment across Asia and mounting concerns over the Fed interest rate hike. Key losers included AEM Holdings, UMS Holdings, and Hi-P International, while Singtel ended flat. The market is also cautious ahead of a US-China trade war, with analysts warning of higher risk and a cautionary stance.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Acing out rivals in e-commerce
summary: Shopee, a Singapore-based e-commerce platform, has been rapidly growing in the South-east Asian market by focusing on a seamless user experience and securing online transactions. The company's strategies include localized approaches, celebrity endorsements, and promotions tailored to individual countries. Shopee also recognizes the diversity of its sellers, providing training and workshops to equip them with e-commerce skills. The platform's ability to adapt to changing trends and user behavior has enabled it to stay ahead of competitors, including Amazon, Zalora, and Alibaba's Lazada.

site_title: When the favourites fail, the underdogs have their day
summary: The 2018 World Cup has kicked off with unpredictable results, as top teams fail to impress. Former World Cup winners Argentina, Spain, and Brazil drew their opening matches, while defending champions Germany suffered a 1-0 defeat to Mexico. Underdog Iceland, with a population of just over 330,000, drew with Argentina, and Mexico shocked Germany with a 1-0 win. The tournament is shaping up to be one of the most unpredictable in history, with 26 days remaining before a new champion is crowned, and it's anyone's guess who will win.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Second fire shrinks storage capacity amid fighting at Libyan oil ports
summary: A second fire at Libya's Ras Lanuf oil port has reduced storage capacity by 400,000 barrels, amid fighting between rival factions for control of two key export terminals. The blaze at storage tank No 2 has cut capacity from 950,000 barrels to 550,000 barrels, and if it spreads, would stop exports from the port completely. Fighting began on Thursday and has been ongoing, with the NOC warning of further damage to key infrastructure if the armed group leader, Ibrahim Jathran, does not withdraw immediately.

site_title: Private bank clients cushion SGD bonds slide
summary: Singapore's SGD bond market has seen a decline in prices, with the Markit SGD corporates total-return index falling to last August levels. The Singapore Fixed Income Index is down 1.80% year-to-date, and volume in the market has fallen 38% with S$8 billion raised. However, private bank clients have cushioned the slide, with perpetual bonds from companies like Cache Logistics Trust and Heeton Holdings trading above water. Experts attribute the resilience to investors' cautious behavior and the relatively illiquid nature of the market.

site_title: Audi CEO arrested for links to VW 'dieselgate'
summary: Audi CEO Rupert Stadler was arrested in Germany for his alleged links to Volkswagen's "dieselgate" emissions cheating scandal. Stadler was charged with fraud and falsification of documents, and prosecutors justified the arrest due to the "risk of concealment of evidence." This arrest is the most high-profile yet in the scandal, which has cost Volkswagen over $25 billion. Stadler's arrest comes as the company faces ongoing legal woes at home and abroad, with former executives and the company itself facing allegations of knowing about the cheating earlier than admitted.

site_title: IPO of flea market app Mercari sheds light on Japan's thriving thrift economy
summary: Japan's flea market app Mercari is set to make its market debut, marking the appearance of a tech unicorn. The app allows users to buy and sell second-hand items, highlighting Japan's thriving "thrift economy" despite weak wage growth and inflation. Founded in 2013, Mercari has been downloaded 71 million times, with users embracing used goods due to deflationary mindset. The company's IPO sheds light on a counter-cyclical trend, threatening Japan's retailers who have been hammered by weak consumption.

site_title: Gloria Mansion at Pasir Panjang up for en bloc sale at S$79m
summary: The Gloria Mansion at Pasir Panjang Road is up for en bloc sale at a reserve price of S$79 million, translating to S$1,234 per square foot per plot ratio. The 12-storey, 31-unit freehold building is located near Haw Par Villa MRT Station and major highways. The sale is the latest in Singapore's collective sale market, which has seen several high-profile transactions in recent years.

images.alt_text: The freehold 12-storey hilltop apartment building is five minutes away from Haw Par Villa MRT Station and close to West Coast Highway and the Ayer Rajah Expressway.

site_title: 'Gig' jobs have not altered long-term employment trends
summary: A recent study suggests that the "gig economy" has not significantly altered long-term employment trends in the US. Despite the rise of digital platforms and alternative work arrangements, the share of workers in these arrangements remains relatively stable, with a 5.1 percentage point decrease from 2015 to 2020. The study, led by Harvard economist Lawrence Katz, estimates that the gig economy accounts for 15.8% of total employment, down from 10.7% in 2005. This finding challenges the notion that the gig economy has had a profound impact on the nature of work and labor markets.

site_title: From consistency to dynamism
summary: Noah Lee, a 33-year-old brand director, reflects on the shift in branding over the past seven years. Prior to 2018, branding was about consistency, but the rise of the digital space has led to new demands. Lee now focuses on building dynamic brands that can adapt to different social media platforms and require harder skills, such as digital research and tech basics. He emphasizes the importance of communication and having a shared language with digital teams and clients. This shift has expanded his job, but also presented new challenges, particularly in creating visually dynamic graphics and managing different social media platforms.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Trade tensions keep FX markets on edge as euro steadies
summary: The euro stabilized at $1.1621, up 0.1% from its recent lows, amid escalating global trade tensions and a dispute in Germany's governing coalition. The US imposed tariffs on $50 billion in Chinese goods, prompting China to retaliate with 25% tariffs on 659 US products. The euro's recovery was limited, and investors worry about the impact of a broader trade conflict on global growth, particularly for Europe.

site_title: Japan's exports accelerate in May, surplus with US lowest since 2013
summary: Japan's exports rose 8.1% in May, the fastest rate in four months, driven by increased shipments of cars, car parts, and semiconductor equipment. The trade surplus with the US fell 17.3% year-on-year to 340.7 billion yen, the lowest since 2013, due to higher US imports of car parts. This decline may not exempt Japan from US President Donald Trump's protectionist policies, which aim to lower the US trade deficit and combat unfair trade practices.

images.alt_text: Japan's exports are likely to continue to grow thanks to increased demand for manufacturing equipment, cars and car parts.

site_title: Emerging Asia hit by biggest foreign investor exodus since 2008
summary: Emerging Asian economies are experiencing a significant foreign investor exodus, with $19 billion withdrawn from India, Indonesia, the Philippines, South Korea, Taiwan, and Thailand so far this year. This marks the largest exodus since the 2008 global financial crisis. Rising US interest rates and trade disputes have led investors to reassess risk, with yields now around 2% compared to 10-year Treasuries in September. Despite solid economic fundamentals, some analysts are raising concerns about global liquidity shrinking and the potential for further Fed rate hikes.

site_title: Unilever takes stand against digital media's fake followers
summary: Unilever, the world's second-largest advertiser, is cutting ties with digital influencers who buy followers, aiming to make advertising more transparent. The company's chief marketing officer, Keith Weed, vowed to never buy followers and prioritize platforms that stamp out fraud. The move comes as Unilever audits its advertising spending and agency relationships amid slowing sales growth. Fake followers, often machine-generated, can mislead consumers and waste money, with estimates suggesting 40% of influencers have been involved in buying followers.

site_title: Sysma unit secures S$37.7m for construction of Pasir Panjang residential development
summary: Sysma Construction, a unit of Catalist-listed Sysma Holdings, secured a S$37.7 million contract to build a residential development in Pasir Panjang. The project, which will take 28 months, includes 4 blocks of 5-storey flats, 3 strata landed houses, and communal facilities. The contract was announced on June 18, 2018, with Sysma shares closing flat at S$0.151.

site_title: Airbus said to study longer range A321 to head off Boeing
summary: Airbus is studying options to extend the range of its A321 narrow-body plane, potentially adding fuel tanks to increase its range to 6,000 nautical miles. This move aims to counter Boeing's planned 797 midmarket plane, which could enter the market by the mid-2020s. The A321XLR model would target long-haul routes, a market currently dominated by Airbus. The decision will depend on Boeing's plans for the 797, and Airbus aims to capture the growing demand for long-range, smaller jets.

site_title: Fintech all set to transform SME financing
summary: Singapore's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) face cash flow constraints, with payment delays affecting operations and long-term survival. However, the emergence of marketplace lending promises to ease these troubles. A new sub-committee under the Singapore Fintech Association aims to promote best practices, adopt standards from mature markets, and raise awareness about marketplace lending. The sub-committee will focus on loan delinquency, risk management, and data sharing. This move is expected to benefit SMEs, with 35% of SMEs experiencing finance-related issues, and marketplace lending helping to secure funds for reasons that do not qualify for a bank loan.

site_title: It's a trade war! Or is it?
summary: US President Donald Trump is considering starting a trade war with China, despite concerns about the potential impact on the midterm elections. Trump's aggressive economic nationalist agenda, which includes imposing tariffs on Chinese imports, was a key part of his presidential campaign. He has been advised by protectionist advisors, but also has to balance this with the desire to avoid a trade war that could hurt his chances in the midterm polls. The decision is seen as a new chapter in Trump's foreign policy, which has been shaped by his populist agenda.

site_title: Are the wheels coming off the Brexit bus?
summary: The UK's Brexit negotiations with the EU are facing significant delays, with fears growing that the country's formal leaving date may be postponed from March 2019. The EU-27 is concerned about the slow pace of talks, and some politicians, including Irish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney, are proposing a five-year transition period. However, neither London nor Brussels are willing to discuss this possibility, due to uncertainty over EU budgets and concerns about ongoing payments to the EU. The lack of progress on key issues, such as the Ireland border, has led to speculation about a potential "no deal" scenario, which could trigger a significant economic shock.

images.alt_text: Pro-EU demonstrators during an anti-Brexit protest outside the Houses of Parliament in London on June 12. Britain's divorce from the EU is proving significantly more difficult than many Brexiteers insisted before the referendum two years ago.

site_title: O&M margins will stay lower for longer
summary: Offshore and marine (O&M) margins are expected to remain low for a longer period, even with contracting activity picking up after oil prices stabilized above US$60. IHS Markit's data shows offshore rig day rates are trending at only a third of pre-crash peaks, and OSV charter rates will only cover operating expenses in 2018 and 2019. Analysts attribute this to excess capacity, with yards struggling to deliver newbuilds and rigs, leading to a bulging supply glut. It's only expected to rebalance by 2025 unless contracting and scrapping of idle units ramp up significantly.

site_title: Credit Suisse gears up for next wave of leveraged loan issuance
summary: Credit Suisse is preparing for a surge in leveraged loan issuance as buyout firms with unprecedented capital levels seek to maximize their firepower. The bank's head of credit, David Miller, predicts a continued explosive growth in the leveraged loan market, despite some warning signs, such as the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes and the European Central Bank's bond-buying halt. Credit Suisse is expanding its leveraged finance unit, hiring staff and increasing its global headcount by 13% in 2018. Miller expects private equity firms to issue $2.5 trillion in debt instruments over the next five to seven years, doubling the current market size.

site_title: Virgin Money's £1.7b merger may spur smaller-bank deals
summary: Virgin Money's £1.7 billion merger with CYBG Plc may accelerate consolidation in the UK banking sector due to cost pressures on smaller banks. The acquisition follows FirstRand's £1.1 billion takeover of Aldermore Group last year. Analysts predict further deals as challenger banks seek to diversify products and cut expenses. Remaining challenger banks include OneSavingsBank, Paragon Banking Group, and Metro Bank, which may be targeted for acquisition. The deal could lead to the emergence of a new consolidator, with the combined company aiming to scale up through acquisitions and partnerships.

site_title: Malaysia shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Monday, down 18.35 points at 1,743.43 points. The index saw 1.90 billion lots traded worth RM2.03 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 583 to 304.

site_title: Artist Christo floats tomb of barrels in London's Hyde Park
summary: Bulgarian artist Christo unveiled a 20-metre high, 7,506 barrel sculpture of an ancient Egyptian tomb in London's Hyde Park, titled "The London Mastaba." The floating installation, which took three months to build, features a pyramid shape with two vertical sides, two slanted sides, and a flat top. The structure is anchored in place and will remain in the park for three months, with the colors changing with the light and reflecting off the Serpentine Lake. Christo's work is known for its large-scale installations, including "The Gates" in New York's Central Park and the Reichstag wrapping in Berlin.

site_title: Russia's RDIF pledges to attract over 7 trillion roubles from global funds
summary: Russia's RDIF sovereign wealth fund aims to attract over 7 trillion roubles (S$149 billion) from global partners for infrastructure and technology projects, part of President Vladimir Putin's economic boost plan. The fund, in co-investments with Asian and Middle Eastern sovereign wealth funds, plans to increase Russia's GDP by 2% annually. This comes as the country seeks to upgrade its infrastructure and technology, following a 1.5-2% growth in 2018. The move is part of Putin's drive to raise living standards and comes after Saudi Arabia agreed to invest $10 billion in Russia.

images.alt_text: Moscow International Business Center(above), also known as 'Moscow City.' Russia's RDIF sovereign wealth fund aims to attract over 7 trillion roubles (S$149 billion) from its global partners into infrastructure and technologies, part of its contribution to President Vladimir Putin's move to boost the economy.

site_title: EU sees signs of improvement after Google antitrust shopping case
summary: European Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager says signs of improvement are seen in Google's reforms after an antitrust case over online shopping, with rivals such as Foundem and Kelkoo benefiting from increased competition. A year after a record 2.4-billion-euro fine, Google has proposed allowing competitors to bid for ads at the top of search pages, giving them a chance to compete on equal terms. Vestager cites figures showing a steady increase in rival products appearing in shopping boxes and a rise in clicks, but notes it's still too early to draw conclusions and warns of potential fines if Google fails to comply.

site_title: A post-North Korea Asia: what will it look like?
summary: US President Donald Trump's historic meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Singapore has been hailed as a success by China, despite no clear agreement on denuclearization. Trump claimed to have solved the North Korean nuclear issue, while praising Kim as a "very talented man." However, the joint statement omitted the phrase "complete, verifiable, and irreversible denuclearization," sparking concerns about the US commitment to the agreement. The meeting has raised doubts about the reliability of the US as an ally, particularly with South Korea and Japan, and has sparked fears of an arms race in East Asia.

site_title: Dentist quits Samsung to disrupt S Korea's payment system
summary: Dentist Lee Seung Gun quit his job at Samsung to start a mobile app startup, Viva Republica, which has become a hit in South Korea with its payments service Toss. The app, which allows users to send money in seconds, has gained 8 million registered users and $1.4 billion in monthly transactions. The company recently secured $40 million in funding from GIC and Sequoia China, bringing its total raised to $116 million. Toss's success has disrupted South Korea's payment system, forcing banks to speed up their online transactions.

site_title: WP Carey plans to buy Corporate Property Associates in US$6b deal
summary: WP Carey Inc plans to acquire Commercial Property Associates 17 - Global Inc in a US$6 billion deal, making it the No 2 US net lease real estate investment trust by market value. The combined company will have a portfolio of 44.4 million square feet, including office, industrial, warehouses, and retail properties, and clients such as The New York Times and Marriott International. The deal, valued at US$10.72 per share, is expected to boost WP Carey's enterprise value to US$17.3 billion and market capitalization to US$11 billion.

site_title: US Supreme Court to review scope of investor protection laws
summary: The US Supreme Court agreed to review a case that could limit the scope of investor protection laws. Francis Lorenzo, a former investment banker, was barred from the industry after the SEC found him liable for sending misleading emails about a struggling clean-energy company. The justices will review a lower court ruling that upheld most of the SEC's liability findings, which could determine whether a person can be held liable for passing along false statements. The case involves whether mere transmission of false statements constitutes a fraudulent scheme.

site_title: US: Wall St falls as US-China trade spat intensifies
summary: US stocks fell Monday as a trade dispute between the US and China intensified, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 208.44 points, or 0.83%, to 24,882.04. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the Nasdaq falling 53.82 points, or 0.69%, to 7,692.55. The decline comes after Beijing's retaliation to US tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump, escalating tensions between the two nations.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports surged 15.5% in May, beating forecasts. Listed construction and real estate group Soilbuild won a collective sale bid for a 89-unit residential development with S$143.88 million. Toyota's US$1 billion investment in Grab was deemed credit positive by Moody's. M&A deals in Singapore reached US$33.8 billion in H1 2018, with the STI closing down 0.97% on Monday.

images.alt_text: Singapore's exports logged another month of strong growth in May, as non-oil domestic exports (NODX) jumped 15.5 per cent over the same month a year ago thanks largely to non-electronic shipments.

site_title: Audi CEO arrested: Volkswagen
summary: Audi CEO Rupert Stadler was arrested on Monday by Munich prosecutors, with a hearing to determine his remand ongoing. Stadler is presumed innocent, and Audi has not made an immediate comment. The arrest is related to Volkswagen, Stadler's parent company.

images.alt_text: Audi Chief Executive Rupert Stadler was arrested on Monday, a spokesman for parent company Volkswagen said

site_title: Lian Beng unit snags S$95.8m deal for construction of condo at Flora Drive
summary: A unit of Lian Beng Group won a S$95.8 million contract to build a 428-unit condominium at Flora Drive in Singapore. The 33-month project will include a clubhouse, carpark, pool, and tennis court. Construction is expected to start in July 2018.

site_title: Jump in May home sales lifts hopes for second half
summary: Singapore's private home sales surged 53% in May, with developers selling 1,121 units, 8% more than the same period last year. The surge is attributed to new launches, with 60% more units sold in May compared to the previous month. Consultants predict a take-off in the second half of the year, with 12,600 new private homes expected to be sold in 2018. However, rising mortgage rates and the sustainability of the en bloc sales cycle are potential risks that could impact the residential sector.

site_title: More execs from Raffles United provide bonds to CAD over potential breaches
summary: Raffles United Holdings' managing director Teo Teng Beng, CFO Ho Hui Min, and executives Koh Hai Yang and Kwek Che Yong have provided bonds to report to the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) regarding potential breaches of the Securities and Futures Act. The interviews were conducted on June 6, 12, and 14. The move follows previous updates on potential breaches, and the executives' reports are expected to provide further insight into the situation.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip on trade tensions
summary: European shares declined 0.3% in early trading on Monday due to trade tensions between the US and China, with US President Donald Trump announcing tariffs on Chinese imports. This prompted Beijing to retaliate, affecting companies such as Nexans, which plummeted 18.2% after a profit warning. Other European benchmarks, including the UK's FTSE 100 and Germany's DAX, also declined.

images.alt_text: European shares dipped in early trading on Monday as worries over a trade war between the United States and China kept investors on the edge, while cable maker Nexans plummeted after a profit warning.

site_title: Behind flashy IPO of Japan's Mercari lies a thriving thrift economy
summary: Japan's flea market app Mercari is set to debut its IPO, marking the country's first tech unicorn. The app has seen 60 million downloads, driven by Japanese shoppers seeking affordable second-hand items due to weak wage growth and inflation concerns. Mercari's success highlights Japan's "thrift economy," where online platforms are reducing costs and cutting out traditional retailers. This trend is expected to continue, with other companies like Rakuten and eBay entering the market, potentially pushing down prices of new goods and challenging the Bank of Japan's inflation goals.

site_title: Japan's Don Quijote: to hit 1 trillion yen sales target year early
summary: Don Quijote Holdings Co Ltd, Japan's largest discounter, expects to hit its 1 trillion yen sales target in the next financial year, a year earlier than forecast. The company, known for its eclectic mix of products, has upgraded its outlook for the year, estimating a 13% increase in sales to 935 billion yen. This would mark the 29th year of unbroken sales growth, solidifying its position among Japan's top retailers. Don Quijote plans to expand its chaotic retail style overseas, with plans to open one to two stores in Southeast Asia annually.

site_title: London, other cities call for new petrol and diesel car ban to start earlier
summary: London Mayor Sadiq Khan and other city leaders are calling for the UK government to bring forward its plan to ban new petrol and diesel car sales from 2040 to 2030. The proposal, part of the "Road to Zero" plan, aims to improve air quality and health. Cities worldwide are introducing restrictions on combustion engine vehicles, while carmakers face declining demand for cleaner diesel models. The government is set to detail its plans soon, with the opposition Labour Party supporting the earlier ban.

site_title: No Signboard to acquire remaining 20% stake in Danish Breweries for S$400,000
summary: No Signboard Holdings announced the acquisition of the remaining 20% stake in Danish Breweries for S$400,000, to be paid in 10 monthly instalments. Danish Breweries owns the Draft Denmark brand and distributes its lagers in Singapore. The acquisition is expected to be completed on June 19, 2018.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won drop on US-China trade spat
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index and the won fell on Monday due to fears of an escalating US-China trade spat. The Kospi dropped 1.15% to 2,376.33, while the won fell 0.64% to 1,104.8 per US dollar, reaching a seven-month closing low. Market heavyweight Samsung Electronics dropped 2.2% and chipmaker SK Hynix fell 3.5%. The decline is attributed to reduced demand for South Korean chips due to the US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down on worries over trade war
summary: Tokyo stocks closed down on Monday due to lingering worries over a US-China trade war, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.75% or 171.42 points to 22,680.33. The impact of a strong earthquake in western Japan was limited.

site_title: Gloria Mansion goes en bloc for S$79m
summary: Gloria Mansion, a 12-storey hilltop apartment building in Singapore, is up for collective sale at S$79 million. The reserve price translates to S$1,234 per square foot per plot ratio, with the option to increase to S$1,121 psf ppr with a 10% bonus balcony. The buyer can keep the existing building or redevelop it into 84 condominium units. The tender closes on July 26, 2018.

site_title: Australian shares edge up, led by banks and real estate stocks; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to close at 6,104.10, driven by gains in financials and real estate stocks. Banks led the gainers, with Commonwealth Bank and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group rising 1% and 1.4%, respectively. Real estate stocks also advanced, with Goodman Group rising 2.1%. In contrast, materials stocks fell due to lower commodities prices, with BHP and Rio Tinto sliding 2.4% and 2%, respectively. The benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index in New Zealand remained flat.

site_title: Singapore shares close down by 0.97% on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 0.97% on Monday, closing at 3,324.04, amid trade war and oil price jitters. The market saw a lopsided 302-118 loss-gain ratio, with 898.5 million securities traded at S$1.38 billion. Key movers included Singtel, which ended flat, and AEM Holdings, which fell 14.53% due to its semiconductor equipment business.
