summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.42 points to 1,760.74. Volume reached 33.18 million lots worth RM16.44 million, with 70 gainers and 59 losers.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Wednesday; STI at 3,430.4
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.29 point to 3,430.4. Trading was mixed, following a lacklustre US session. About 46 million shares changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 63 to 39. Key movers included Ezion, Genting Singapore, and Golden Agri-Resources. Regional markets reacted similarly, with Japan's Topix index rising 0.4% and Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index losing 0.3%.

site_title: US launches another trade case against China
summary: The US Commerce Department announced a new trade action against China, targeting producers of steel propane tanks for dumping and unfair subsidies. This is the latest in a series of disputes between the two countries, including tariffs on $50 billion in Chinese goods. The move has raised concerns of a global trade war, with allies Canada and the European Union also affected. The US has been critical of China's alleged theft of US technology, and tensions have been escalating since President Trump took office.

site_title: Japan would help with initial costs of North Korea denuclearisation only after IAEA inspections
summary: Japan is willing to help with the initial costs of North Korea's denuclearization, but only after the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) resumes inspections, according to Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga. US President Donald Trump stated that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has pledged to move towards complete denuclearization. The US promised security guarantees, following a historic summit. Japan's assistance would be contingent on IAEA verification, as stated by Suga, amid ongoing efforts to verify North Korea's commitment to denuclearization.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly lower on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Wednesday, easing 0.40% to 30,977.56, following two days of gains. The Shanghai Composite Index was flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.31%. Investors await the conclusion of a key Federal Reserve policy meeting.

site_title: Singapore's private and HDB rents both rise 0.2% in May as volumes drop
summary: Rentals in Singapore's private and HDB sectors rose 0.2% in May, the smallest increase in a year, as volumes declined. Private rentals increased 0.8% year-over-year, while HDB rentals dropped 2.7%. Rental volumes fell 3.2% to 4,674 units in May and 12% to 1,885 flats in the HDB segment. The decline in volumes was attributed to a 15.3% drop in HDB rentals compared to its August 2013 peak.

site_title: Far East's Oasia Hotel Downtown wins best tall building award
summary: Oasia Hotel Downtown in Singapore's Tanjong Pagar has been named this year's Best Tall Building Worldwide by the Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat (CTBUH). The 27-storey skyscraper features a plant-covered facade and outdoor communal spaces, earning praise for its commitment to communal space and green design. The award marks the building's first win in the CTBUH's annual Best Tall Building Worldwide competition, beating out regional winners from the Americas, Europe, and Middle East & Africa.

site_title: Senoko Energy launches first solar energy project
summary: Senoko Energy launched its first solar energy project, installing solar panels on three office buildings at Continental Automotive Singapore, generating over 500 megawatt hours of electricity annually. The company aims to grow its capacity to handle solar energy projects as demand for renewable energy increases. With Singapore's growing energy security and efficiency needs, Senoko Energy plans to develop more solar projects and smart energy solutions, including energy management initiatives and smart home solutions.

site_title: Toyota to invest US$1b in Grab, taking lead in latest financing round
summary: Toyota Motor Corp is investing US$1 billion in Grab, the largest investment by an automotive manufacturer in the global ride-hailing sector. The investment values Grab at over US$10 billion, making it smaller than Uber and Didi Chuxing. Toyota's second investment in Grab comes after its 2016 investment in Uber's South-east Asian operations, which were later acquired by Grab. The deal will strengthen Grab's connected car services and expand its O2O services, including GrabFood and GrabPay, in the region.

site_title: Australia consumer sentiment picks up in June
summary: Australia's consumer sentiment increased marginally in June, rising 0.3% from May, as consumers felt more confident about their family finances. The index, 6.1% higher than June last year, showed optimists outnumbering pessimists. The Reserve Bank of Australia held its cash rates at a record low 1.50% and the economy expanded at 1.0% pace in the March quarter. However, experts warn that this lift in sentiment may not translate to sustained consumer demand, potentially disappointing the RBA's forecast for above trend growth this year and next.

site_title: Europe: Shares led down by energy, mining stocks; Italy shines on
summary: European stocks fell 0.1% on Tuesday, led down by energy and mining stocks, but retailers gained as Carrefour partnered with Google, boosting Carrefour's 3.1% gain and H&M's 5% rise. The US-North Korea summit had little impact on markets, with investors focusing on earnings and economic fundamentals. Retailers led the sectoral gains, while mining and healthcare stocks were the biggest losers, with the Stoxx 600 ending the day down 0.1%.

site_title: French farmers call for pursuit of fuel blockades
summary: French farmers, led by the FNSEA union, are calling for continued blockades of refineries and fuel depots until the government addresses their concerns. Despite meeting with Agriculture Minister Stephane Travert, the farmers expressed disappointment, citing inadequate concessions. The blockades began in response to the government's handling of fuel prices and agricultural policies, with protesters demanding more favorable terms.

site_title: Singapore retrenchments fall to 5-year low in Q1 as job vacancies rise
summary: Singapore's retrenchment figures fell to a 5-year low in Q1 2018, with 2,320 workers laid off, a drop from 4,000 in the same quarter last year. The re-entry rate for residents was 61% in the first quarter, lower than 64% in the same quarter last year. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate improved to 2.0% and job vacancies exceeded unemployed people for the first time since March 2016, with 53,900 vacancies reported.

site_title: Amazon halted expansion over a tax. Now Seattle is killing the tax
summary: Seattle officials repealed a corporate tax aimed at raising $50 million annually to help the homeless and fund affordable housing projects, after Amazon and other local businesses opposed it. The tax, which would have charged companies with at least $20 million in revenue $275 per employee, was initially passed unanimously but faced intense opposition from Amazon and other businesses. The repeal comes after Amazon halted expansion plans in protest, and the city's mayor later admitted that the tax was not a perfect solution but necessary to address the city's housing and homelessness crisis.

images.alt_text: Seattle officials scuttled a corporate tax on Tuesday that they had wholeheartedly endorsed just a month ago, delivering a win for the measure's biggest opponent - Amazon - and offering a warning to cities bidding for the retailer's second headquarters that the company would go to the limit to get its way.

site_title: Citic becomes biggest shareholder in Ivanhoe Mines
summary: Citic Metal Co has agreed to buy a minority stake in Ivanhoe Mines, becoming the largest shareholder and pushing founder Robert Friedland to second place. Citic will pay C$3.68 apiece for 196.6 million common shares, worth approximately C$723 million. The deal will allow Citic to invest in Ivanhoe's copper, zinc, and platinum projects in Southern Africa, and Citic will also make a US$100 million interim loan facility available. The deal is subject to regulatory approvals and will see Citic's president, Sun Yufeng, become co-chair with Friedland.

site_title: Plastic straws aren't clogging oceans - it's old fishing nets
summary: A global campaign to eliminate plastic straws is misguided, as they account for only a small percentage of ocean plastic waste. Instead, efforts should focus on reducing the massive amounts of fishing nets and other discarded fishing gear, known as "ghost gear," which harm marine habitats. By implementing a system to mark commercial fishing gear and improving waste management in developing countries, a more significant impact can be made in reducing ocean pollution.

site_title: Trump had a mini-movie made just for Kim
summary: US President Donald Trump unveiled a short film during his meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Singapore, titled "A Destiny Pictures Production." The film, produced by the National Security Council, depicts two alternative futures for the US and North Korea, with one showing a peaceful and prosperous Korean Peninsula. Trump said he showed the film to Kim to demonstrate the benefits of complete denuclearization and to showcase a "vision of a peaceful and prosperous Korean Peninsula." The film's production and narrator were not disclosed.

site_title: Small players take on consumer goods giants
summary: Small consumer goods companies, often from Singapore, are gaining ground on giants like Coca-Cola and Unilever by leveraging social media and digital technologies to connect directly with consumers. This trend is driven by lower barriers to entry and the shift towards digital consumerism. Companies like Supernova and NamZ are achieving success by bypassing traditional retail channels and distributing products directly to consumers. The Boston Consulting Group notes that US$22 billion in industry sales was transferred from large to smaller companies between 2011 and 2016, and a similar trend is emerging in Europe.

site_title: Condo resale prices rise again to new high: SRX
summary: Resale prices of private condominiums and apartments in Singapore rose 1.2% in May, hitting a new high. The Core Central Region (CCR) increased 1.3% and the Outside of Central Region (OCR) rose 1.8%. Prices in the Rest of Central Region (RCR) remained unchanged. The market strength is attributed to the en bloc sale fever and a spillover effect, with buying interest returning to all market segments. Resale volume was 25.5% higher than last May, and median Transaction Over X-Value (TOX) decreased by S$2,000.

site_title: UK offers new visa to attract entrepreneurs deterred by Brexit
summary: The UK government has introduced a new visa program to attract tech entrepreneurs deterred by Brexit. The "Start-Up Visa" will require applicants to have the endorsement of a university or business sponsor. This move comes as tech companies have complained about reduced access to European funding, difficulty in recruiting talent, and uncertainty. Despite these challenges, the British tech sector has seen a doubling of investment last year. The new visa program will start next year and aims to drive growth in the UK.

site_title: Ezion resets conversion price for convertible bond, perpetual security to S$0.28 from S$0.25
summary: Ezion Holdings has reset the conversion price for its Series B convertible bonds and perpetual security to S$0.28 from S$0.25, effective June 13, 2018. The reset applies to 64.4% of Series B bonds and 82.6% of Amended Series 008 Securities, which were converted at a discounted price of S$0.2487. The company's net asset value per share increased to 16.3 Singapore cents from 15.8 Singapore cents previously. The conversion price will be reset every six months, based on the volume-weighted average price in the past six months.

site_title: Aston Martin's US$240,000 Rapide still not as fast as a Tesla
summary: Aston Martin's Rapide AMR, a track-ready sedan, has been announced with a US$240,000 price tag. The car boasts a 580bhp V12 engine, lower stance, and improved aerodynamics, but its top speed is unlikely to surpass that of the Tesla Model S P100D or Porsche Panamera Turbo Sport Turismo. Despite its performance, the Rapide AMR's added features and lower weight are unlikely to justify the significant price difference, with the car's elegance and driving persona being its main brand strengths.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher ahead of Fed, ECB decisions
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by cautious optimism ahead of the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank decisions. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.11% to 22,903.73, while the Topix index increased 0.16% to 1,795.60. Market focus shifted from the US-North Korea summit, with traders brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: Malaysia likely to review foreign insurance ownership directive, say sources
summary: Malaysia is likely to review its directive requiring foreign insurers to reduce their local ownership by nearly a third, as finding domestic buyers for equity stakes is proving difficult. The review may put off deals worth over $2 billion, providing relief to foreign firms such as Great Eastern Holdings and Prudential. The potential review comes after Malaysia's new prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, and changes in the central bank, which had enforced a 70% cap on foreign ownership in 2009. The regulator may relax some conditions or put the requirement in abeyance.

site_title: China's ZTE dives 39% at resumption of trading in Hong Kong
summary: ZTE's shares plummet 39% in Hong Kong after the company settles with the US over a sanctions violation. The ban on US companies selling goods to ZTE for seven years has been lifted, allowing trading to resume. ZTE had suspended trading in April due to the ban, which severely impacted its operations. The company's stock price dropped to HK$15.56 in the first few minutes of trading. This marks a significant turnaround for ZTE, which had faced severe financial consequences due to the sanctions.

site_title: Trade tensions swirl as US Federal Reserve opens policy meeting
summary: The US Federal Reserve opened a two-day policy meeting, with markets expecting a second interest rate hike this year to hold off inflation. Global trade tensions are high, following the contentious Group of Seven summit in Canada, which could disrupt trade and raise prices. Policymakers will face a delicate balancing act, considering the impact of interest rate hikes on the economy.

site_title: Government went after wrong deal in AT&T-Time Warner
summary: US District Judge Richard Leon has rejected the Justice Department's lawsuit to block the AT&T-Time Warner merger, citing the government's "gossamer thin" arguments and a lack of support from expert witnesses. The merger, which was initially opposed by President Donald Trump, will likely be consummated by June 20. The ruling is seen as a significant victory for the merged companies, and it may weaken the antitrust division's ability to challenge future mergers, particularly in the tech industry.

site_title: Italian debt in demand as political storms abate
summary: Italian 10-year government bond yields decreased by 4 bps to 2.81% on Tuesday, narrowing the spread over Germany to 232 bps, its tightest in a week. This follows positive news from the North Korea-US summit and reassuring comments from Italy's new economy minister. The eurozone bond market experienced small moves, contrasting with the volatile trade seen in recent days.

site_title: AT&T wins court approval to buy Time Warner over Trump opposition
summary: AT&T won court approval to buy Time Warner for $85 billion, rebuffing the Trump administration's attempt to block the deal. The merger, which was announced in 2016, was seen as a turning point for the media industry, allowing distributors to buy content companies to add revenue. US District Judge Richard Leon ruled that the government failed to show the merger would substantially lessen competition, paving the way for a wave of corporate mergers. The decision is expected to prompt a cascade of pay TV companies buying television and movie makers, with Comcast's bid for Twenty-First Century Fox assets potentially the first out of the gate.

site_title: Kim, Trump agree reciprocal, step-by-step actions towards denuclearisation: KCNA
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and US President Donald Trump agreed on reciprocal, step-by-step actions towards denuclearization during talks on June 12, 2018. Kim emphasized the need to halt "irritating and hostile military actions" and take institutional steps to prevent antagonism. Trump agreed to halt joint US-South Korea military exercises while talks with the North continued. The agreement aims to promote a peaceful resolution to the tensions between the two nations.

site_title: Malaysia to probe Battersea property deal: Anwar
summary: Malaysia's de facto leader Anwar Ibrahim announced plans to investigate the Battersea Power Station deal, a £10 billion project in London, as part of a broader probe into "dubious" property investments using state funds. The investigation aims to determine if there was any wrongdoing or political influence involved. The move comes as Malaysia's new government reviews major investments made by the previous administration, including those linked to the 1MDB scandal. Anwar stated that the investigation will focus on ensuring the right investment decisions were made and no corruption occurred.

site_title: Trade is more pressing concern than Trump-Kim summit
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's summit in Singapore has concluded, with trade being a more pressing concern than the summit's outcome. Economists say the impact of the summit will be felt in the longer term, assuming continued engagement. While the summit is an encouraging sign of US commitment to the region, trade tensions with China and allies remain a significant concern. A lasting peace on the Korean Peninsula could lead to increased trade and economic cooperation, but sanctions must be lifted first.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: South Korea's business community hails Trump-Kim summit
summary: South Korea's business community praised the historic summit between North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and US President Donald Trump in Singapore, citing potential new business opportunities for the Asian economy. Kim committed to complete denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula, while both leaders agreed to establish "new" bilateral relations and build a "lasting and stable" peace regime. The summit marked a significant shift in relations between the two countries, offering a chance for South Korea to tap into North Korea's vast resources and energy reserves.

site_title: Wrapping debt revamp is no safe harbour for O&M players
summary: Business magnates, including Sam Goi, are investing in offshore and marine (O&M) companies to rescue them from financial struggles. However, retail investors remain skeptical about the future of these companies, citing concerns over the investors' motivations and the companies' ability to recover. Despite some companies, like Marco Polo Marine, emerging from debt restructuring, their share prices have not recovered. Investors must prove their "strategic intent" and deliver actions to validate their claims, which will be crucial in determining the success of these rescue financing deals.

site_title: Docusign helps customers to digitise their workflows
summary: DocuSign helps companies digitize their workflows, reducing costs and increasing efficiency. However, security concerns remain, and solutions like DocuSign's eSignature solution address these issues. The company's general counsel notes that while paper-based processes are comfortable for many, digital alternatives offer superior security, ease, and convenience. As companies increasingly adopt digital processes, organizations like DocuSign play a crucial role in ensuring data protection and trust.

site_title: Crest Nicholson margins hit by higher costs, flat house prices
summary: Crest Nicholson Holdings Plc reported full year operating margins at the bottom end of its guidance due to higher construction costs and flat house prices. The company forecast 18% operating margins, lower than its 18-20% range. Despite robust demand for homes, Crest will invest in areas of greater housing affordability to offset build cost pressures. Revenue rose 13% to £473.88 million, while operating profit rose 1% to £81.4 million.

site_title: Oil mixed as Opec cites uncertain market outlook for 2018
summary: Oil prices were mixed on Tuesday, with US crude settling higher before falling and Brent slipping. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 26 cents to $66.36, while Brent crude futures fell 58 cents to $75.88. A surprise build of 833,000 barrels in US crude stockpiles, contrary to expected decline, led to Brent's losses. Opec's uncertain market outlook for 2018 contributed to the price fluctuations.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were mixed on Tuesday, with US crude settling higher before falling in post-settlement trading, and Brent slipping as investors prepared for a key meeting of the Opec producer group next week.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends at record, Dow flat ahead of Federal Reserve decision
summary: US stocks closed with mixed results, with the Nasdaq Composite Index reaching a fresh record at 7,703.79, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average remained flat at 25,320.73. Tech companies, including Tesla, Apple, Amazon, and Alphabet, gained between 0.5 and 1.0%. Investors are anticipating a potential interest rate hike from the Federal Reserve and await a European Central Bank decision on bond-buying stimulus. Trading volumes are low ahead of these events, with investors adopting a cautious optimistic mood.

site_title: Alzheimer's drug fails; firms decide to halt tests
summary: ELI Lilly & Co and AstraZeneca plc have ended late-stage trials of an experimental Alzheimer's disease treatment, lanabecestat, after it failed to show any significant effects. The medicine targeted a protein called amyloid, a cause of the disease, but many researchers believe administering drugs after amyloid buildup may come too late. This is the latest in a string of failed Alzheimer's treatments, with over 190 having failed in trials. The decision won't have a material financial impact on either company, and their guidance remains unchanged.

site_title: Trial begins in US$20m insider trading case over hacked press releases
summary: A US$20 million insider trading case involving two defendants, Vitaly Korchevsky and Vladislav Khalupsky, began in Brooklyn federal court. The defendants, accused of securities fraud and conspiracy, allegedly made money by trading on inside information stolen through computer hacking of corporate press releases. Prosecutors will use electronic communications, trading records, and witness testimony to prove their case. Korchevsky, a former Morgan Stanley vice-president, and Khalupsky, a Pennsylvania pastor, were arrested in 2015 and face charges related to a landmark case marking the first time criminal charges were brought for a securities fraud scheme involving hacked inside information.

site_title: Tesla cutting 9% of staff; layoffs not to affect Model 3 production
summary: Tesla is cutting 9% of its workforce, mainly salaried staff, as part of a restructuring effort to enhance profitability. The move will not affect Model 3 production targets, which are expected to ramp up. The company aims to focus on costs and demonstrate sustainable profitability to achieve its mission of accelerating the world's transition to sustainable energy. Shares rose 2.8% to $341.01 after the announcement, following a 15% increase since June 5.

images.alt_text: Electric carmaker Tesla Motors announced Tuesday it was cutting nine percent of its workforce to enhance profitability but said the move would not affect an ambitious production ramp-up of its Model 3 sedan.

site_title: Opec resistance to Saudi supply plan grows as Iraq objects
summary: Opec, the world's largest oil-producing cartel, faces growing resistance to Saudi Arabia's plan to increase oil supplies, with Iraq, Iran, and Venezuela opposing the move. Iraq's Oil Minister, Jabbar al-Luaibi, stated that supply curbs have not yet achieved their purpose and that unilateral decisions made by some producers without consultation are rejected. The opposition comes as Saudi Arabia and Russia are reportedly raising production, potentially undermining the cartel's efforts to stabilize oil prices. The Opec meeting on June 22-23 is expected to be fractious, with the US also exerting pressure on Saudi Arabia to relax output restraints.

site_title: The US is finally taking China seriously
summary: The US is finally taking China seriously, marking a significant shift in their relationship. China's goals, which include national reunification and international standing, have long been clear. The US, initially focused on short-term interests, has come to recognize China's growing economic power and its impact on the international system. In recent years, US leaders have acknowledged China's influence, with some even calling for a more responsible stakeholder role. The Trump administration's emphasis on great power rivalry and the threat of a rising China signals a more realistic approach to US-China relations.

site_title: Singapore and Kenya sign two agreements
summary: Singapore and Kenya signed two agreements to promote investment flows, including a Bilateral Investment Treaty and an Agreement for the Avoidance of Double Taxation. The agreements aim to enhance economic ties between the two countries, with a total bilateral trade in goods valued at S$85.4 million in 2017. The BIT protects investors' interests, while the DTA minimizes double taxation on cross-border business activities. The agreements are seen as opportunities for Singapore companies to invest in Kenya's growth sectors, including agri-business, technology, and transport and logistics.

site_title: US, North Korea talks just first step on long road to peace
summary: US and North Korea's talks marked the first step towards peace on the Korean peninsula, with the historic Singapore Summit normalizing North Korea and initiating diplomatic negotiations. The summit did not result in a peace treaty or dramatic overtures, but it laid the groundwork for future talks. Key agreements include the US halting military exercises and North Korea agreeing to denuclearization. The US will not withdraw sanctions until complete, verifiable, and irreversible denuclearization is achieved. A long process of negotiations is expected to lead to a permanent peace on the peninsula.

site_title: Trump-Kim summit promotes 'radical switchover' in US-North Korea relations: KCNA
summary: North Korea's state media reported that the historic summit between Kim Jong Un and US President Donald Trump marked a "radical switchover" in the two nations' relations, ending a "longest period on the earth" of dismal relations. The summit, held in Singapore, aimed to improve the "most hostile DPRK-US relations," according to the report. This marked the first-ever meeting between a sitting US president and a North Korean leader.

images.alt_text: The historic meeting between North Korea's Kim Jong Un and President Donald Trump marked a "radical switchover" in the two nations' fraught relations, the North's state media said Wednesday.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Nippecraft Ltd, a paper products maker, will be removed from the Singapore Exchange's watch list and transferred to the Catalist board, effective Wednesday. The company secured a six-month debt moratorium to restructure its debts. Keong Hong Construction will be allowed to recruit new foreign workers after November 24, while Sunvic Chemical Holdings is considering options to meet listing requirements. Citic Envirotech secured two waste treatment projects in China's Xinjiang province.

site_title: Byton raises US$500m to take on Tesla
summary: Byton, a China-based electric car startup, has raised $500 million to take on rivals like Tesla. The funding is led by FAW Group, Tus-Holdings, CATL, and others. Byton plans to launch cars starting from around $45,000 and expects to launch in China by 2019 and in the US and Europe by 2020. The company, led by former Tesla executives, aims to establish a new benchmark for auto startups with technology, product, capital, and factory. Byton will roll out prototype models in April 2019 for testing and pilot production in the first half of 2019.

site_title: Frasers Property opens second development in Tianjin
summary: Frasers Property has opened its second development in Tianjin, China, with Fraser Place Binhai Tianjin, offering 224 serviced residences. The move aims to double its China portfolio over the next few years, with 16 new properties in the pipeline. The company expects to leverage China's growing domestic tourism market, driven by its huge population and rising consumption power. This is part of its expansion strategy to cater to varying and evolving travelers' needs, with a focus on delivering the best guest experience in China.

site_title: May inflation at six-year high, eats away at wage increases
summary: US inflation accelerated to a six-year high in May, with the consumer price index (CPI) rising 0.2% from the previous month and 2.8% from a year earlier. The annual gain was the biggest since February 2012, eroding wage gains despite an 18-year low in unemployment. The Fed's preferred inflation gauge remains at 2%, but policymakers are considering interest rate hikes, with the central bank set to raise borrowing costs for the sixth time in 18 months.

site_title: Crystal ball for the shipping industry
summary: International freight transport insurer TT Club is celebrating its 50th anniversary, marking a significant transformation in the liner shipping industry since its founding. The industry has seen disruptions such as the shipping container and may see even more with zero-CO2 and autonomous vessels. A new report, "Brave new world?", predicts the industry will undergo significant changes, including the rise of digital natives, automation, and a shift towards more balanced trade flows. The report's authors expect the industry to be shaped by factors such as digitalization, trade development, and the need for zero-CO2 emissions, with the physical characteristics of the industry unlikely to change.

site_title: Singapore is the 9th most expensive Asian city for expats
summary: Singapore ranks 9th most expensive Asian city for expats, according to a cost of living survey by ECA International. The city-state has seen a modest increase in prices over the past year, mainly due to the relative strength of the Singapore dollar versus the US greenback. This move reverses Singapore's position from last year, when it ranked 18th globally. Caracas in Venezuela tops the list of most expensive cities, followed by four Swiss cities and Luanda in Angola.

site_title: Long-time Credit Suisse staffers get new roles in investment banking
summary: Credit Suisse has made two senior appointments in its South-east Asia investment banking business, with Yvonne Voon taking on the role of head of South-east Asia real estate and Felicity Chan becoming head of equity syndicate for the region. Both appointments demonstrate Credit Suisse's commitment to expanding its sector and product coverage in the region. Voon, with 12 years of experience, will focus on attracting clients for real estate services, while Chan, with 14 years of experience, will work with investment banking and private banking teams to serve clients across the region.

site_title: Risk appetites may grow as US, North Korea talk peace
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korea's Kim Jong Un met in Singapore, resulting in a pledge for peace on the Korean peninsula without specifics. Asian markets reacted subdued to the summit, indicating investors had low expectations from the start. This lack of reaction may have a minimal impact on future trade and corporate earnings.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Boohoo has last laugh as retail rivals fall away
summary: Boohoo, a British online fast fashion retailer, reported a 53% increase in Q1 revenue to £183.6m, outperforming traditional retailers like Marks & Spencer and House of Fraser. The company's expansion into new markets and purchase of brands such as PrettyLittleThing and Nasty Gal contributed to its growth. Boohoo reiterated its full-year outlook, predicting 35-40% revenue growth and adjusted core earnings margin of 9-10%. The company is investing heavily in technology and logistics to support its ambitious global expansion.

site_title: Exxon Mobil bulks up energy trading to boost profit
summary: Exxon Mobil is expanding its energy trading operations to boost profit, marking a significant shift for the company. Exxon aims to trade more of its energy assets to secure better prices, adding hundreds of millions of dollars to annual earnings. However, this move also increases risk, and the company is hiring experienced traders and beefing up risk-management systems to mitigate this risk. Exxon's CEO, Darren Woods, is under pressure to lift profit and increase earnings, with a goal of doubling profit and increasing oil and gas output by 25% by 2025.

site_title: HSR postponed, not scrapped, Mahathir tells Japanese media
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad clarified that the high-speed rail (HSR) project with Singapore has not been scrapped, but merely postponed due to its high cost. Mahathir stated that Malaysia cannot afford the project at the moment but left the door open for future consideration. He suggested building an HSR "right through the Peninsula" as an alternative. The project was initially announced as cancelled in May, citing high costs and a steep maintenance burden, but Mahathir's comments indicate a possible reversal of the decision.

site_title: UBS family office unit targets Asia's new billionaire dealmakers
summary: UBS Group AG expects most new family-office clients to come from Asia as global banking rivals compete to manage funds and broker deals for the world's wealthiest clans. The number of family offices being set up in Asia far outpaces the rest of the world, according to Anurag Mahesh, head of UBS's family-office operations in Asia. This shift is driven by Asia's growing economy and increasing wealth among its citizens.

site_title: STI dips 0.3% as caution rules amid summit
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.32% to 3,430.69, despite the historic US-North Korea summit's positive outcome, as investors focused on upcoming central bank meetings and macro data releases, including May inflation figures and the US Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting. Key events include the FOMC meeting and a string of macro data releases, with fears over global trade wars and the potential for retaliatory measures.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Musk promises 'full self-driving' Tesla cars in August
summary: Elon Musk tweeted that Tesla's Version 9 software update would enable "full self-driving features" in August, sparking a surge in the company's stock price. However, safety specialists and consumer groups expressed concerns that the technology is still largely unproven and may lull drivers into a false sense of security. Critics argue that Tesla's marketing has been misleading, suggesting that drivers can take their hands off the wheel, and that the company has a history of using consumers as guinea pigs.

images.alt_text: Mr Musk has tweeted that Tesla's Version 9 will begin to enable full self-driving features.

site_title: China's next big innovation? A used-car market
summary: China is experiencing a surge in its used-car market, with sales growing by 19.3% in 2017 compared to 3.2% for new cars. The market is expected to reach 20 million by 2020, potentially becoming the world's largest secondhand market. This shift is driven by improvements in Chinese-made cars' quality and the lifting of restrictions on used-car sales between provinces. The growth of the used-car market is expected to slow greenhouse gas emissions, as manufacturing accounts for 35% of a vehicle's lifetime carbon emissions, making used cars a more environmentally friendly option.

site_title: A feel-good index now has a fund that targets investors with a heart
summary: Billionaire investor Paul Tudor Jones II has launched a new exchange-traded fund through Goldman Sachs, tracking the top 50% of companies based on his Just Capital metrics, which assess corporate practices on workers, customers, products, environment, jobs, communities, and management. The fund aims to provide socially responsible investment options, outperforming the Russell 1000 by 3.47% over the past two years. The fund, which charges a 0.2% fee, is designed to encourage companies to prioritize societal betterment over profits, with no exclusions based on moral arguments, including companies in industries like coal and tobacco.

site_title: World leaders welcome Trump-Kim agreement; China to benefit from outcome
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un signed a "comprehensive" document at a landmark summit in Singapore, pledging to work towards complete denuclearization of the Korean peninsula. China, a key economic and diplomatic supporter of North Korea, appears to benefit from the outcome, with UN sanctions potentially being adjusted. World leaders, including Japan, South Korea, Britain, the European Union, and Russia, welcomed the summit as a crucial step towards stability in the region. However, US Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell warned that maximum pressure policy would be restored if North Korea does not adhere to the agreement.

site_title: Scrapping stock trading link means a missed opportunity
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamed has announced plans to review the proposed stock market trading link with Singapore, which was initially set to be operational by the end of the year. The link, aimed at increasing liquidity and attracting international investors, would have given access to 1,600 listed firms with a total market capitalization of over $1.2 trillion. However, Malaysia's decision may be driven by concerns about potential short-selling and the "ghost of Clob," a 1998 market that was shut down due to allegations of short-selling. The review may also be influenced by the lack of support from the investing community and regulatory policies in other Asean countries.

site_title: Fifa to choose between North America or Morocco for 2026 World Cup
summary: FIFA members will vote on Wednesday to decide whether the 2026 World Cup will be held in North America or Morocco. The US-Canada-Mexico bid is considered the front-runner, but Morocco's bid, despite being classified as "high risk" by FIFA, has garnered support from many European and African countries. The North American bid has been dogged by concerns about US President Donald Trump's involvement, while Morocco's bid has been criticized for its lack of built infrastructure. The decision is expected to be made on its merits, with FIFA president Gianni Infantino believed to support the North American bid.

site_title: Facebook responds to lawmakers' questions - with 500 pages of submissions
summary: Facebook submitted 500 pages of information to Congress, addressing its investigation into Cambridge Analytica and its data practices, but sidestepped some lawmakers' critical queries. The social media giant acknowledged reviewing apps with access to large amounts of user data, resulting in 200 suspensions, and is still investigating the incident. However, it declined to address concerns about consultants' interactions with Cambridge Analytica and the improper use of Facebook data in presidential campaigns. The submissions may further embolden critics in Congress, who are weighing new regulation in response to recent data mishaps and potential fines.

site_title: Daimler gets slapped with recall, but dodges risk of fines
summary: Daimler has been ordered by the German government to recall 774,000 vehicles in Europe due to allegations of using illegal defeat devices in its engines. The move is estimated to cost the company under €100m. Despite the recall, Daimler avoids facing potential fines, with the government opting not to pursue penalties. Daimler CEO Dieter Zetsche described the consultations as "constructive."

images.alt_text: Daimler CEO Dieter Zetsche after his meeting with the Transport Ministry. Daimler rose 1.6% to 62.43 euros at 9.14am in Frankfurt, paring losses this year to 11.9%.

site_title: US dollar bounce fizzles as focus shifts to US data
summary: The US dollar experienced a brief bounce, but it ultimately fizzled out as markets awaited US inflation data and guidance from the US Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan. The Norwegian kroner rose unexpectedly, driven by a positive survey on Norway's economy. Meanwhile, Wall Street opened lower amid US President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada.

site_title: History made but Trump-Kim meet needs more substance to convince
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un met for the first time, marking a historic event in world history. The two leaders signed a joint statement committing to security guarantees and complete denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula. Trump pledged to suspend military exercises with South Korea in exchange for Kim's commitment to denuclearization, while maintaining US sanctions. However, experts have expressed caution, citing the lack of substance in the joint declaration and the need for tangible commitments from North Korea. The meeting was seen as a major step forward by Trump, who hailed it as "honest, direct and productive," but its long-term impact remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: India's retail inflation accelerates to four-month high in May
summary: India's retail inflation accelerated to a four-month high in May, reaching 4.87%, driven by higher fuel prices and a depreciating rupee. The Reserve Bank of India's interest rate hike in June is seen as the beginning of a gradual tightening cycle, with economists predicting another rate hike this year. The industrial output grew 4.9% in April, while annual retail food inflation remained muted at 3.1%.

images.alt_text: India's annual retail inflation accelerated to a four-month high in May, driven by higher fuel prices and a depreciating rupee, strengthening views that the central bank could raise interest rates again in August.

site_title: A hollowing out of big-name talents for menswear in progress at London Fashion Week Men's
summary: London Fashion Week Men's is experiencing a decline in high-profile names, with top talents like Craig Green and Grace Wales Bonner missing from the schedule. Brands like J.W. Anderson and Burberry have shifted to womenswear, leaving Charles Jeffrey as the top billing designer. Jeffrey will present his third solo outing for Loverboy, showcasing his avant-garde menswear label. Other notable designers, including A-Cold-Wall, Martine Rose, and Nicholas Daley, are also set to showcase their collections. The menswear calendar is becoming increasingly empty, with Pitti and Milan Fashion Weeks also set to take place.

site_title: Expats give back
summary: The Expatland Giving Back Fund, a philanthropic arm of international tax consultancy CST Tax Advisors, encourages expats to volunteer their time to local initiatives. The fund, which aims to make expats feel like they are giving back to their adopted community, has partnered with organizations such as Willing Hearts and Wheel, Walk or Jog Singapore, to provide meals and support for the less privileged. With over a million foreign workers in Singapore, the fund provides a platform for expats to donate their time, with a minimum commitment of three to four hours every three months.

site_title: Chocolatiers branch out to woo millennials
summary: Chocolatiers are adapting to changing consumer preferences by introducing healthier treats, such as hemp-infused chocolate, low-sugar formulas, and new flavors. In response to growing health concerns, companies like Hershey's and Mars are diversifying into popcorn and potato chips, while others are focusing on premium and artisanal brands. Despite falling demand for sugary products, sales of dark chocolate and premium brands are on the rise, particularly among millennials who are willing to pay more for unique flavors and ingredients.

site_title: 'Looking for more details': Investors react to Trump-Kim deal
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un signed an agreement to work toward the complete denuclearization of the Korean peninsula. Investors are skeptical, with one strategist stating "there aren't any details" and questioning the agreement's feasibility. Markets in Asia showed minimal reaction, and the agreement's specifics remain unclear. Trump provided unspecific security guarantees in exchange for North Korea's pledge to ease tensions. The agreement's outcome and effectiveness are uncertain, with many investors awaiting concrete details.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singtel maintains a defensive stance on the telco sector due to its geographical diversification, while TPG's entry as the fourth mobile operator intensifies competition. Analysts from UOB Kay-Hian and RHB Research assess the stock performance of Singtel, M1, and StarHub, recommending buy and sell targets. Meanwhile, HRnetgroup is expected to benefit from flexible staffing and strong economic data, with a possible interim dividend payout. Analysts forecast better financial performance for HRnetgroup in FY2018.

site_title: SembMarine bags 1st polar expedition cruise ship design contract
summary: SembCorp Marine's subsidiary LMG Marin has secured the first polar expedition cruise ship design contract for Quark Expeditions. The 128-metre ship, which can carry 200 passengers and 116 crew, is scheduled for completion by the third quarter of 2020. This marks LMG Marin's first polar expedition cruise ship design contract, reinforcing SembCorp Marine's arctic ship design capabilities and future business opportunities.

site_title: Feline friends: Ed Sheeran waxwork unveiled at cat cafe
summary: Ed Sheeran has been immortalized in wax at London's Lady Dinah's Cat Emporium, a cat cafe. The waxwork figure, dressed in a checked shirt and holding a guitar, is surrounded by felines as customers sip their drinks. The figure will soon be moved to Madame Tussauds museum, where it will be on display starting next week. The museum's general manager said the figure's placement at the cat cafe was a fitting tribute to the musician's love of pets. The waxwork is a unique addition to the cafe's entertainment options.

site_title: Euro mauled by political risk, but ready to be revived: analysts
summary: The euro has become increasingly attractive due to its 5% decline in value against the dollar, fading political risks, and potential interest rate hikes by the European Central Bank. Analysts at Russell Investments favor holding the currency, citing its "quite attractive" prospects. This trend is expected to continue despite China's slowing GDP growth and pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Vietnam's legislators approve cyber law clamping down on tech companies, dissent
summary: Vietnam's National Assembly approved a cybersecurity law that requires global tech companies like Google and Facebook to store "important" personal data locally and open offices in the country, effective January 1, 2019. The law has raised concerns about economic harm and stifling online dissent, with human rights groups calling it a "devastating blow" to freedom of expression. The law also requires social media companies to remove content within one day of receiving a request from authorities, and industry groups warn it could hinder Vietnam's digital economy and limit foreign investment.

site_title: EU seeks to triple border, migration budget
summary: The European Union proposed a 35 billion euro budget to secure its borders and curb migrants, nearly tripling the current 13 billion euro allocation. The funds will be used to bolster borders, deport economic migrants, and integrate genuine refugees. The proposal includes strengthening the European Border and Coast Guard to 10,000 personnel and boosting customs control. The EU aims to agree on the new budget before the next European Parliament elections in May 2019.

site_title: Sydney home bubble deflates as loans revisit 2008 losing streak
summary: Sydney's property market is experiencing a deflationary trend, with a 1.4% decline in housing finance in April, marking the longest losing streak in almost a decade. This is largely attributed to tighter credit, fewer interest-only loans, and reduced Chinese buyer demand. The downturn is most pronounced in Sydney, where prices slid 4.2% in May from the previous year. Sales at auctions have also plummeted to the lowest since early 2016. Experts warn that the current downturn may be just the beginning, and a gradual price decrease could help bolster financial stability.

site_title: Seven ways that blockchain can really be leveraged
summary: Blockchain technology has numerous potential applications beyond fintech, including photography, fine wine, event ticketing, food standards, virtual football assets, and more. By leveraging blockchain, businesses can increase transparency, authenticity, and security, while also providing new opportunities for artists, consumers, and industries. For instance, blockchain can verify the authenticity of artworks, designer goods, and fine wine, making them more valuable. Additionally, it can enable secure and transparent ticket sales, food tracing, and virtual football asset management. While successful real-world applications are still rare, the potential of blockchain is vast, and its exploration is crucial for innovation.

images.alt_text: Louis Vuitton employs a team well-versed in blockchain technology to manage the protection of the company's intellectual property and rights.

site_title: BAT hit by slowdown in heated-tobacco as Japan growth stalls
summary: British American Tobacco (BAT) reported a slowdown in sales of its heated-tobacco product Glo in Japan, casting doubt on its ability to offset declining traditional cigarette sales. Despite reaching a 4.3% share of Japan's tobacco market in its first six months, sales have stalled over the last seven weeks. This slowdown has raised concerns among investors, who are now skeptical about the company's revenue growth projections for the year. The news follows Philip Morris International's struggles to persuade older Japanese smokers to switch to its heated-tobacco device, iQOS.

site_title: Britain fines Yahoo UK Services £250,000 for 2014 hack
summary: Britain's data watchdog fined Yahoo UK Services £250,000 for a 2014 cyber-attack that compromised 515,121 UK accounts, including names, email addresses, and hashed passwords. The ICO found Yahoo UK Services failed to protect the data and comply with data protection standards, despite having ample opportunity to implement measures. The fine follows a probe into one of the largest ever data breaches to impact EU citizens.

site_title: Amazon-Whole Foods: A year later, what's changed?
summary: Amazon's acquisition of Whole Foods Market one year ago marked a significant shift in the grocery industry. The $13.7 billion deal combined Amazon's digital expertise with Whole Foods' established perishables supply chain and network of stores. The integration aimed to revolutionize food shopping, offering customers innovative services and price-cutting. However, no major changes have been reported a year after the acquisition, leaving the future of this merger uncertain.

site_title: Trump hails a 'very special bond' with Kim
summary: US President Donald Trump hailed a "very special bond" with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un after their historic summit in Singapore, declaring the start of a new era that could break a cycle of nuclear brinkmanship. The two leaders met for over four hours, with Trump stating that yesterday's conflict does not have to be tomorrow's war. The summit aimed to stave off a military confrontation, marking a significant shift in US-North Korea relations.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise on historic Trump-Kim summit
summary: US President Donald Trump's historic summit with North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un in Singapore has boosted Europe's stock markets, with London's FTSE 100 rising 0.3% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 adding 0.6%. Analysts attribute the positive market reaction to the historic meeting, which saw the two former foes pledge to meet again and discuss the future of Pyongyang's nuclear program. Trump and Kim signed a document committing to "new US-DPRK relations" and security guarantees, with Trump stating they would begin the denuclearization process "very, very quickly."

site_title: New opportunities in Chinese equities
summary: MSCI has added 226 large-cap Chinese A-shares to its indexes, increasing China's weight in the MSCI EM Index to 31%. This move provides global investors with more complete exposure to the Chinese economy and greater access to attractive growth stories. A-shares have historically had lower correlation with global equities, and their inclusion may offer diversification benefits. However, risks include Chinese equity volatility, US-China trade tensions, and corporate governance issues. Despite these risks, China's near-term economic outlook is solid, and A-shares' greater domestic exposure may help cushion against trade risks.

site_title: US risks missing out on trade liberalisation in Asia-Pacific
summary: The US risks missing out on trade liberalization in the Asia-Pacific region due to its resistance to open trade policies. The US administration has withdrawn from the Trans-Pacific Partnership and proposed reforms to NAFTA, instead favoring bilateral negotiations. This approach limits imports and restricts market access, potentially harming US trade with dynamic regions like Asia-Pacific. Despite partner dialogue and some bilateral agreements, the US's tough interpretation of WTO rules and use of trade actions may create uncertainty and undermine multilateral trade.

site_title: Nobu aims for US$1b sales combining sushi, hotels, condos
summary: NOBU Hospitality, founded by Robert De Niro, chef Nobu Matsuhisa, and Meir Teper, aims to reach US$1 billion in revenue in five years with its growing empire of sushi restaurants, hotels, and condos. The company recently completed a 660-unit condo project in Toronto, selling out in three months, and plans to expand into Asia with mixed-use developments in Sao Paulo and Los Cabos. With hotel room rates expected to be up to C$800 per night and condo units averaging C$850,000, CEO Trevor Horwell hopes to have 10 mixed-use developments and five hotels/restaurants per year.

site_title: Don't tie our hands in Brexit negotiations, British government tells parliament
summary: British government tells parliament to back down in Brexit negotiations, warning lawmakers that rejecting a compromise on a "meaningful vote" could undermine negotiations with the EU. The House of Lords has introduced 15 changes to Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit blueprint, including a demand for a parliamentary vote on any agreement. Brexit minister David Davis warned that rejecting the compromise would risk undermining the government's ability to secure a successful deal, while lawmakers who oppose the government have received death threats and accused the government of wanting too much power.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as bank stocks rise
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with bank stocks rising as the Federal Reserve began its policy meeting. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.10%, the S&P 500 gained 0.13%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.18%. The positive start was despite a historic US-North Korea summit failing to impress investors.

images.alt_text: US stocks opened slightly higher on Tuesday, with bank stocks gaining as the Federal Reserve kicked off its two-day policy meeting, while a historic US-North Korea summit failed to impress investors.

site_title: Malaysian shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysian shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 11.64 points at 1,764.16 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 571 to 309, and volume reached 2.35 billion lots worth RM2.38 billion.

site_title: Top US pancake chain IHOP suffers backlash after name change
summary: IHOP, a 60-year-old US pancake chain, has faced backlash after rebranding to IHOb, International House of Burgers, in an effort to expand its market image. The name change, initially teased as a temporary change to IHOP's last initial, was met with criticism from fans and rival burger chains, who felt the move was a mid-life crisis. The company claims the change is temporary and that burgers are being taken seriously, but some fans are still upset about the name change, with some even joking that "ihop" stands for "I have pancakes."

site_title: Kim, Trump signatures show very different personalities, experts say
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un signed a historic agreement, with their signatures revealing distinct personalities. Kim's signature, described as "ambitious, intuitive, and quick-witted," suggests an open and creative individual. In contrast, Trump's signature, characterized as "angular and closely packed," indicates a more guarded personality. Experts also noted that Kim's slanting signature, similar to those of his family members, is a common trait among North Koreans, who often admire and imitate the handwriting of their leaders.

site_title: Singapore and Kenya sign investment, tax agreements
summary: Singapore and Kenya signed two agreements, a Bilateral Investment Treaty (BIT) and an Agreement for Avoidance of Double Taxation (DTA), to promote investment and economic ties between the two countries. The BIT protects investors' interests, while the DTA minimizes double taxation. The agreements aim to boost trade and investment flows in sectors such as agriculture, technology, and logistics. Senior Minister of State Koh Poh Koon and Kenyan Cabinet Secretary Henry Rotich signed the agreements, witnessed by Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam.

site_title: Astrea IV offering of Class A-1 bonds 7.4 times subscribed
summary: Astrea IV, a subsidiary of Azalea Asset Management and Temasek Holdings, successfully closed its S$121 million retail offering of Class A-1 private equity bonds 7.4 times subscribed. The offering received nearly S$890 million in valid applications, with an allocation process set to be announced on Wednesday evening. This marks the first retail bonds backed by cash flows from private equity fund investments.

site_title: White House aide apologizes over 'special place in hell' comment
summary: White House trade adviser Peter Navarro apologized for comments made about Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau after the Group of Seven summit. Navarro initially condemned Trudeau as "weak, dishonest" and said he would have a "special place in hell" for those engaging in "bad-faith diplomacy" with US President Donald Trump. Navarro later apologized, stating he had made a mistake and intended to convey a strong signal of strength. The comments sparked a backlash, with both Navarro and another White House aide, Larry Kudlow, criticizing Trudeau's response to US President Trump's steel and aluminum tariffs.

site_title: US consumer prices increase as expected in May
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.2% in May, as expected, with a slowdown in gasoline costs. Food prices were unchanged, and the core CPI, excluding volatile components, rose 0.2% with a year-on-year increase of 2.2%. This marks the largest rise in the core CPI since February 2017.

site_title: Trump says Kim makes "unwavering commitment" to denuclearise
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has made an "unwavering commitment" to the complete denuclearization of the Korean peninsula. Trump also announced that the US will stop holding military exercises on the peninsula, saving money, and that sanctions against North Korea will remain in effect. The US will also stop holding joint military exercises with South Korea, which Pyongyang has long demanded an end to.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said on Tuesday North Korean leader Kim Jong Un had made an "unwavering commitment" to the complete denuclearisation of the Korean peninsula but sanctions against North Korea would remain in effect.

site_title: LifeBrandz third quarter loss widens to S$690,000
summary: LifeBrandz, a lifestyle group, reported a widened third-quarter loss of S$690,000, up from S$260,000 in the same period last year. Revenue more than quadrupled to S$898,000, driven by new transactions in tourism and food and beverage sales. Total expenses rose to S$1.6 million, mainly due to high sales activities and increased advertising expenses. Despite the loss, shares closed unchanged at 1.2 Singapore cents.

site_title: Chinese truckers demonstrate over high fuel costs, truck-hailing app Manbang
summary: Chinese truck drivers are protesting against high fuel costs and the dominance of truck-hailing app Manbang, which they claim is squeezing their incomes. Demonstrations have been seen in over a dozen locations across China, with truckers carrying banners and threatening violence against those who don't join the strike. The protests come as oil prices hit their highest level since 2014, and Manbang has raised $1.9 billion in funding from SoftBank and Alphabet. The firm's dominance has led to a squeeze on haulage rates, further exacerbating the drivers' concerns.

site_title: Europe's largest aluminum producer is dodging US tariffs
summary: Norway, Europe's largest aluminum producer, has benefited from the US decision not to impose retaliatory tariffs on its aluminum exports. Only 0.2% of Norway's 31.9 billion kroner (S$5.2 billion) in aluminum exports last year went to the US, with 97% sold to European markets. Norway's trade deficit with the US has led to dismay, with Trade Minister Torbjorn Roe Isaksen calling the decision "completely incomprehensible and grossly unfair." Despite US tariffs on European cars, aluminum producer Norsk Hydro ASA reported unchanged profitability.

images.alt_text: Norway, Europe's largest producer of aluminium, is counting its blessings that only a minuscule amount of the metal it ships abroad is sold to the US.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won steady as US-North Korea summit concludes
summary: Seoul's stocks and the won remained steady on Tuesday, unaffected by the conclusion of the US-North Korea summit. The Kospi index closed virtually unchanged, down 0.05% at 2,468.83, while the won closed at 1,077.2 against the dollar. Analysts attributed the lack of impact to markets having already priced in a successful summit. Despite the summit's outcome, analysts noted potential benefits for South Korean stocks if a peace treaty is achieved, but warned against excessive optimism due to the enormous gulf between the two Koreas.

site_title: Quality and pricing in initial public offerings matter
summary: The initial public offering (IPO) market in Singapore has undergone significant changes since the 1970s and 1980s. Initially, the focus was on local companies, but following the S-chip crash in the late 2000s, the priority shifted to foreign companies, mainly from China. However, the recent trend has reversed, with a focus on Singapore-incorporated SMEs listing on Catalist, the market's second board. While the return to local SMEs is welcome, the post-listing performance of these companies has been underwhelming, with most trading at or below their offer prices. To balance out the offerings, more mature companies with better profit histories are needed to attract investor interest.

site_title: SembMarine bags first polar expedition cruise ship design contract
summary: SembMarine's subsidiary, LMG Marin, has secured its first polar expedition cruise ship design contract with Brodosplit Shipyard. The 128-meter ship, to be completed by 2020, will carry 200 passengers and 116 crew members for Quark Expeditions. This contract marks a breakthrough for LMG Marin, expanding its focus on larger vessels. SembMarine president and CEO Wong Weng Sun expressed confidence in LMG Marin's arctic ship design capabilities, anticipating future business opportunities and growth.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.32% lower
summary: The Singapore bourse declined 0.32% to 3,430.69 on Tuesday, despite a "better-than-expected" outcome of the US-North Korea summit. The Straits Times Index fell 11 points, with 227 counters down and 155 up. Analysts note that the process of denuclearization could be long-drawn, tempering optimism. Regional markets saw mixed trading, with South Korea's Kospi closing flat and Japan's indices gaining. The focus is now on key central banks' meetings and macro data releases, including May inflation figures, amidst fears of global trade wars.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Financial services industry spends US$1.7b on blockchain
summary: Financial services companies have allocated US$1.7 billion annually to blockchain technology, a 67% increase from last year, according to a study by Greenwich Associates. Banks and firms are moving beyond proof-of-concept to commercial distributed ledger technology products, with over one in 10 spending more than US$10 million. Despite challenges in implementation, over three-quarters of projects currently under development are expected to go live within two years, with employees on blockchain initiatives doubling last year.

images.alt_text: Financial services industry spends US$1.7b on blockchain.

site_title: Singapore's first talent incubator Antler announces cohort of 55 founders
summary: Singapore's talent incubator Antler has selected 55 founders from 23 countries for its inaugural program starting July 2. The founders have an average of nine years' industry experience and will receive funding, product management expertise, and legal support. Upon completion, they will pitch to investors to secure seed funding for growth. This marks the first homegrown talent incubator in Singapore, competing with other incubators like Platform E and Entrepreneur First.

site_title: Sydney home bubble deflates as loans revisit 2008 losing streak
summary: Australia's east-coast property bubble is deflating, with housing finance falling 1.4% in April, marking the longest losing streak since 2008. Sydney prices slid 4.2% in May, with sales at auctions at their lowest since 2016. Tighter credit, reduced interest-only loans, and decreased Chinese buyer demand are contributing factors. The central bank views a gradual price decline as beneficial for financial stability, while market bulls point to population growth and record-low interest rates as reasons for a soft landing.

site_title: Analysis: Trump's N Korea summit falls short of Nixon-goes-to-China moment
summary: US President Donald Trump's historic summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un ended without concrete commitments for Pyongyang's nuclear disarmament, despite Trump's claims of success. The joint statement signed in Singapore rehashed old broken promises made by Pyongyang, and experts say the summit's outcome is unlikely to yield significant progress. Trump's supporters hail the summit as a foreign policy win, but fellow Republicans may use it to bolster their contention to retain control of Congress. Analysts compare the summit unfavorably to President Nixon's 1972 visit to China, which led to a breakthrough in diplomatic relations.

site_title: Court grants Pacific Radiance six-month debt moratorium
summary: The Singapore High Court granted Pacific Radiance a six-month debt moratorium, allowing the offshore support vessel owner-operator time to restructure its debts. The company must submit a report on the valuation of its assets and an affidavit supporting its proposed debt-to-equity swap for its S$100 million, 4.3% Series 001 notes due 2018. This restructuring proposal aims to address Pacific Radiance's debt issues and provide the company with time to implement its plan.

site_title: Transcorp loss widens to S$2.68 million for half-year
summary: Transcorp, an investment holding company, reported a widened loss of S$2.68 million for the half-year ended April 30, down from S$2.28 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 7.2% to S$2.91 million, primarily due to a decrease in car sales, but gross profit rose 54.7% to S$199,385 due to cost savings.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un agreed to work towards complete denuclearization of the Korean peninsula. In other news, Singapore condominium resale prices reached a new high in May, while retail sales in the country increased marginally in April. Frasers Property opened its second development in Tianjin, China, and Singapore's shares closed 0.32% lower. Additionally, Malaysia is unable to pursue financier Jho Low, who is hiding in Macau, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Ivory Coast's Presidential coffee may soon become extinct
summary: Ivory Coast's rare arabusta coffee variety, a hybrid of robusta and arabica, may become extinct due to lack of investment and low yields. Developed in the 1960s, arabusta was initially promoted as an alternative to robusta, but production has dropped to almost zero. Founder of Ivoryblue coffee brand, Andre Braud-Mensah, is trying to revive the variety by taking over management or purchasing land to start his own plantation, with hopes of increasing production by 2020.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after US-North Korea summit
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Tuesday, following a rally on Wall Street, as investors welcomed the historic US-North Korea summit. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.33% to close at 22,878.35, while the Topix index rose 0.33% to 1,792.82. The US-North Korea summit's largely positive reception lifted investor confidence, contributing to the Tokyo stock market's gains.

site_title: The dangers of belly fat
summary: Excess belly fat poses significant health risks, including heart disease, cancer, and dementia, even in individuals of normal weight. Visceral fat, located deep beneath the abdominal wall, is metabolically active and secretes hormones linked to disease. Maintaining a waist circumference of 35 inches or less for women and 40 inches or less for men can significantly reduce these risks. A healthy diet, regular exercise, and adequate sleep are essential for weight loss and reducing abdominal fat. Limiting sugar, alcohol, and refined carbohydrates, and increasing protein and fiber intake can also contribute to a healthier waistline.

site_title: Singapore back in the top 20 list of world's priciest cities for expats
summary: Singapore has returned to the top 20 list of the world's most expensive cities for expats, ranking 19th, after a strengthening currency. The city-state saw a modest increase in prices over the past year, with costs driven by the relative strength of the Singapore dollar against the US greenback. Caracas in Venezuela tops the list, followed by four Swiss cities and Luanda in Angola. Hong Kong dropped to 11th, primarily due to the fall in value of the US dollar against the Hong Kong dollar.

site_title: Chocolatiers branch out to woo Millennials
summary: Chocolatiers are adapting to declining demand for traditional sugar-filled chocolate bars by introducing healthier options, new flavors, and formulas that cut down on sugar. Companies like Hershey's and Mars Inc. are diversifying into popcorn, potato chips, and health snacks, while others are focusing on premium brands and dark chocolate with more cocoa and less sugar. The industry is also shifting towards sustainability, with companies like Mars investing in energy-efficient operations and direct farmer purchases.

site_title: Mongolia targets 10-fold increase in meat exports: minister
summary: Mongolia aims to increase its meat exports tenfold in the coming years, targeting 200,000 tonnes annually, as the country seeks to diversify its economy. The country has struggled to boost meat exports due to animal health concerns, but a new animal health law is being implemented to resolve the issue. Mongolia is also exploring new markets in Japan, the Middle East, and Iran, and has the potential to export more than 200,000 tonnes of meat per year, according to Agriculture Minister Batzorig Batjargal.

site_title: South Korea hails Trump-Kim summit as 'talks of the century'
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae In welcomed the historic meeting between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, hailing it as "talks of the century". The summit, held in Singapore, aims to achieve denuclearization, peace, and a new era in relations between the two Koreas and the US. The meeting drew jubilant reactions in Seoul, with many expressing hopes for a breakthrough and a new beginning. Trump and Kim exchanged warm words and handshakes, sparking optimism for a successful summit.

site_title: Australian shares end firmer buoyed by consumer sector; NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 6,054.4, driven by gains in consumer and pharmaceutical sectors, as US President Donald Trump described progress at the North Korea summit. Healthcare stocks surged, with CSL Ltd reaching a record close. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.2% to 8,958.81, led by declines in Ryman Healthcare and Auckland International Airport.

site_title: Standout shows from the men's runways in London
summary: The men's runway shows in London Fashion Week Men's showcased a mix of creativity, new talent, and commercial viability. Standout shows included Charles Jeffrey Loverboy's "Emergence" collection, which blended genderless and artistic elements with commercial appeal; Martine Rose's ode to London's street life and rave scene; A-Cold-Wall's experimental and industrial-inspired collection; Christopher Raeburn's sustainable and utilitarian designs; and Edward Crutchley's coed collection blending conceptual and wearable pieces. Despite a thin schedule, the shows demonstrated the British menswear scene's continued relevance and creativity.

site_title: Canadian dairy farmers cling to protections as Trump demands concessions
summary: Canadian dairy farmers are resisting US demands for greater access to the protected Canadian dairy market, citing concerns that concessions would lead to devastating losses and undermine the industry's growth. The sector, valued at C$21 billion, is a key point of contention in renegotiated NAFTA talks. Canadian dairy farmers are unwilling to give up further market share, with some warning that it could lead to a decline in the value of their production quotas and a lack of investment in modernization.

site_title: Rockwell to take US$1b stake in software maker PTC
summary: Rockwell Automation will invest US$1 billion in software maker PTC, acquiring an 8.4% stake in the company. The deal aims to leverage Rockwell's domain expertise with PTC's technology to capitalize on the industrial Internet of Things (IoT). PTC's shares rose 10.2% to a record US$95.88 following the announcement. Rockwell's chairman and CEO will join PTC's board after the deal closes, expected within two months. The partnership is seen as a strategic positive for PTC, opening doors to thousands of companies that traditionally have not used PTC's core CAD capabilities.

site_title: Full text of historic Trump-Kim summit agreement
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un signed a historic agreement in Singapore, committing to provide unspecified security guarantees in exchange for North Korea's complete denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula. The joint statement, signed on June 12, 2018, also aims to establish new US-North Korea relations and build a lasting peace regime on the peninsula. The agreement includes commitments to recover POW/MIA remains, work towards complete denuclearization, and hold follow-up negotiations.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump and Kim Jong Un signed a document on Tuesday asserting that the US president would provide unspecified "security guarantees" to Mr Kim in exchange for the North Korean leader's "unwavering commitment to complete denuclearization of the Korean peninsula."

site_title: Malaysia's first woman deputy prime minister Wan Azizah seeks tighter abuse laws
summary: Malaysia plans to strengthen its existing laws protecting children against sexual violence, with Deputy Prime Minister Wan Azizah Wan Ismail calling for guardians and teachers to be held accountable for ignoring signs of abuse. The government aims to bolster regulations against domestic violence and sexual harassment, promoting gender equality, following Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's election promises. Wan Azizah believes laws must be in place to hold primary caregivers accountable for ignoring child abuse incidents, citing "horror stories" of unaddressed abuse.

site_title: Trump, Kim launch charm offensive at summit; no word yet on discussions
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un began a historic summit in Singapore on June 12, 2018, seeking ways to end a nuclear standoff on the Korean peninsula. The two leaders displayed an initial atmosphere of bonhomie, but their discussions remained secretive. Trump stated that he had forged a "good relationship" with Kim, while Kim described the meeting as a "good prelude to peace." No immediate word on substantive progress was announced, but the two leaders agreed to work towards complete, verifiable, and irreversible denuclearization.

site_title: Monsanto rival seeks bigger pie of Indian food crop seed market
summary: Kaveri Seed Co. Ltd., a rival to Monsanto in India's food crop seed market, aims to increase its revenue from non-cotton seeds by 60% in three years. The company currently generates 60% of its revenue from cotton seed sales and seeks to reverse this proportion by focusing on rice and vegetable seeds. Executive Director C. Mithun Chand aims to triple the company's vegetable revenues and increase its rice seed sales, driven by higher profit margins.

site_title: Investors say 'so far, so good' on the historic Trump-Kim summit
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un met in a historic summit, sparking mixed market reactions. Investors expressed cautious optimism, with Kazuyuki Terao saying "it's hard to imagine they'll turn out badly from here." Markets saw slight gains in Japan and Hong Kong, while South Korea's shares fluctuated. The dollar lost its earlier gains, and the yen fell, while the South Korean won rose.
