The outcome remains uncertain, but initial reactions suggest a positive tone.

site_title: Singapore retail sales a mixed bag; inches up 0.4% in April
summary: Singapore's retail sales saw a 0.4% increase in April, a marginal improvement from the 1.1% drop in March. The growth was largely driven by petrol service stations, which reported an 8.5% increase. However, other retail industries, such as computer and telecommunications equipment, apparel and footwear, and department stores, experienced significant declines. Excluding motor vehicle sales, retail takings rose 0.7% in April. On a month-on-month basis, seasonally-adjusted retail sales fell 0.2%.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon trading at 3,439.36, down 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Tuesday, down 0.1% at 3,439.36, with 977 million shares worth S$440 million changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 164 to 134. IPCO International was the most actively traded stock, rising S$0.001 to S$0.003. The Straits Times Index has seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Frasers Property opens second development in Tianjin; looks to double footprint in China
summary: Frasers Property has opened its second serviced residence, Fraser Place Binhai Tianjin, in Tianjin, China, expanding its footprint in the country. The 224-unit property offers studios to two-bedroom apartments, following the opening of Fraser Place Tianjin in 2016. CEO Choe Peng Sum said China is key to the company's future growth, aiming to double its presence in the country over the next few years.

site_title: The ascension of cauliflower
summary: Gail Becker's Caulipower brand has become a multimillion-dollar success, selling frozen cauliflower pizzas and baking mix in 9,000 stores nationwide. The trend of using vegetables to replace flour and other simple carbs is gaining momentum, with cauliflower being a popular choice due to its mild flavor and versatility. Sales of packaged cauliflower substitutes have reached $47 million, with cauliflower substitutes doubling in sales over the past year. The trend appeals to a broad spectrum of consumers following various diets, including plant-based and Paleo, and is driving growth across all foods.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks, won steady ahead of US- North Korea summit outcome
summary: South Korean stocks and the won remained steady ahead of the US-North Korea summit outcome, with the Kospi index down 0.07% at 2,468.51 points. The won rose 0.04% to 1,074.8 against the dollar. Analysts expect a potential peace treaty to boost the region's markets, but caution against excessive optimism due to the enormous gulf between the two Koreas. Shares related to inter-Korea projects, such as Hyundai Cement and Seohee Construction, surged, while some declined.

site_title: South Korea president Moon Jae In hopes for 'new era' of complete denuclearisation, peace
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae In expressed hope for a 'new era' of complete denuclearisation and peace after the historic meeting between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Singapore. Moon, who has worked as a mediator, aspired for the summit's success to usher in a new era among the two Koreas and the US. He also pushed for a peace declaration among parties to the Korean War to be signed, paving the way for permanent peace on the Korean Peninsula. The summit's outcome will significantly affect the future of the Korean Peninsula.

site_title: Tearful Rodman claims vindication for Kim ties
summary: Dennis Rodman broke down in tears on CNN, expressing vindication for his ties with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Rodman, a basketball star, has made five trips to Pyongyang and appeared on TV wearing a "Make America Great Again" hat, amid death threats and hostility. He believes the talks between him and Kim, as well as between Trump and Kim, are the right thing to do, aiming to "open doors" and create a better world. Rodman's comments come amid a historic summit between Trump and Kim in Singapore.

site_title: Stocks, US dollar rise as Trump says US-North Korea summit "really very positive"
summary: US President Donald Trump said a summit meeting with North Korea's Kim Jong Un made "a lot of progress" and was "really very positive," boosting hopes for a landmark deal to end a nuclear standoff. The US dollar jumped to a 3-week high and Asian shares rose as a result, with the dollar reaching a 3-week top. The positive comments from Trump came after Kim described the meeting as a "good prelude to peace." The news boosted market confidence, leading to a rise in stocks and the dollar.

site_title: Asia: Stocks open higher amid cautious optimism over Trump-Kim summit
summary: Asian stocks opened higher on Tuesday amid cautious optimism over the highly anticipated US-Korea summit, which could set the stage for ending a nuclear standoff on the Korean peninsula. The US dollar jumped to a 3-week top, while Asian shares rose, with Japan's Nikkei climbing 0.8% and South Korea's shares adding 0.1%. Analysts said a successful summit would be a first step in a long process, but many expect a low bar for success, given past failures in talks with North Korea.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.1% to 3,437.61
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.1% lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,437.61, amid cautious optimism over the Trump-Kim summit. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also gained. In regional markets, Japan's Nikkei and South Korea's Kospi rose, while Australia's benchmark index was firmer.

site_title: Asia: Stocks edge up as Trump-Kim summit gets underway
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un began a historic summit in Singapore, potentially paving the way to ending a nuclear stand-off on the Korean peninsula. Stocks in Asia edged up, with the US dollar reaching a three-week high, amid optimism about the summit's outcome. However, analysts noted that the bar for a successful summit is low, and the impact on markets is likely to be marginal. Other market events, including policy meetings of the US Federal Reserve and a Brexit bill vote, are also expected to influence the market.

site_title: China Resources Cement plans US$534m share sale for business development
summary: China Resources Cement Holdings Ltd plans to sell HK$4.19 billion (S$713 million) worth of new shares at HK$9.30 apiece to its controlling shareholder CRH Ltd, reducing its stake to 68.72%. The sale is to raise capital for business development, debt repayment, and working capital. The Hong Kong-listed firm expects a "significant increase" in first-half net profit due to higher cement product prices. The share sale is facilitated by placing agents China International Capital Corp Hong Kong Securities Ltd and Goldman Sachs (Asia) L.L.C.

site_title: Credit Suisse makes 2 senior appointments in its South-east Asia business
summary: Credit Suisse has made two senior appointments in its South-east Asia business. Yvonne Voon will lead the real estate investment banking and capital markets team, while Felicity Chan will head equity syndicate for the region. Both appointments are part of a push to attract clients and grow the bank's advisory and financing services in the region. Voon joins after 12 years with the bank, while Chan has been with Credit Suisse for 14 years. The appointments are part of Credit Suisse's efforts to strengthen its presence in the South-east Asian market.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices up 1.2% to hit new high in May: SRX flash estimates
summary: Singapore condo resale prices rose 1.2% in May, reaching a new high, according to SRX Property flash estimates. This marks a revision from April's estimate of 0.6%. Resale prices increased 10.8% from May 2017, with the Core Central Region (CCR) hitting a new high at 1.3%. Median Transaction Over X-Value (TOX) decreased by $2,000 to $18,000, with some districts showing significant deviations from the computer-generated market value.

site_title: US unveils de facto embassy in Taiwan amid cross-strait tensions
summary: The US has unveiled a de facto embassy in Taiwan, a $250 million representative office in Taipei, amid escalating tensions with China. The move strengthens Washington's strategic ties with Taiwan, despite cutting diplomatic ties in 1979. The office, known as the American Institute of Taiwan, will conduct relations between the two sides, with the US remaining Taiwan's sole foreign arms supplier. The move is seen as a challenge to China's claims of sovereignty over Taiwan.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.29 points to 1,774.51. The market saw a slight increase in volume with 98.98 million lots worth RM58.41 million.

site_title: Pancakes to burgers: IHOP suffers backlash in name change
summary: IHOP is changing its name to IHOb, International House of Burgers, to expand its market image beyond breakfast. The name change was met with backlash from pancake fans and rivals, with many expressing disappointment and confusion. The company claims the change is temporary, but will allow it to "convey that we are taking our burgers as seriously as our pancakes." The move is seen as a rebranding exercise to promote its new "Ultimate Steakburgers" menu category.

site_title: Trump tweets about stock market ahead of Kim meet
summary: US President Donald Trump tweeted about the stock market ahead of his summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, citing a 40% increase in the stock market since the 2016 election and low unemployment rates among various groups. Trump also praised recent releases of American hostages and Pyongyang's pledge to refrain from further nuclear tests. He stated that the success of the summit will be determined soon, and he is confident that the US will be fine despite pundits' predictions. The US demands North Korea's denuclearization in exchange for security guarantees.

site_title: De Niro's Nobu aims for US$1b sales combining sushi, hotels
summary: Nobu Hospitality, founded by Robert De Niro, chef Nobu Matsuhisa, and Meir Teper, aims to reach US$1 billion in revenue in five years through its growing empire of sushi restaurants and luxury hotels. The company has already added 660 condo units and 36 hotel suites to its Toronto project, which sold out in three months. With over 40 locations worldwide, Nobu Hospitality plans to complete two more mixed-use developments, add 10 hotels and restaurants per year, and expand to Asia, including potential locations in Taipei, Hong Kong, and Jakarta.

images.alt_text: Nobu Hospitality LLC, the sushi restaurant and luxury hotel chain founded by Robert De Niro, chef Nobu Matsuhisa and movie producer Meir Teper, expects to reach US$1 billion revenue in five years as it adds condos to its growing empire.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open amid caution over US-North Korea summit
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, extending Wall Street rallies, despite caution over a US-North Korea summit. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.73% to 22,971.36, while the Topix index gained 0.63%. Investors were cautious amid the historic summit, but the rally continued to extend.

site_title: Trump's top economic advisor Larry Kudlow 'doing well' after heart attack, White House says
summary: US President Donald Trump's top economic adviser Larry Kudlow, 70, was hospitalized after suffering a heart attack, according to a White House spokeswoman. Kudlow is "doing well" and currently at Walter Reed Medical Center. Trump tweeted that Kudlow was working hard on trade and the economy before the heart attack. Kudlow had been a vocal advocate for the president's trade policies, but also expressed concerns about the impact of tariffs on consumers. The incident occurred as Trump was meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Singapore.

site_title: North Korea military 'all quiet' ahead of Trump-Kim summit: Mattis
summary: US Defence Secretary Jim Mattis reported that North Korea's military is "all quiet" ahead of the historic summit between President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Singapore. Mattis stated that the large US troop presence in South Korea would not factor into discussions, as it is a matter for Seoul and Washington to consider. The summit is set to take place on Tuesday, capping a remarkable build-up that had previously been canceled by Trump.

site_title: Malaysian financier Jho Low hiding in Macau: report
summary: Malaysian financier Jho Low, sought by authorities over a multi-billion dollar 1MDB scandal, is believed to be hiding in Macau. Due to the lack of an extradition treaty between Malaysia and Macau, Malaysian authorities cannot pursue him. The information comes from a report by The Malaysian Reserve, citing a government source.

images.alt_text: Financier Low Taek Jho, who is sought by Malaysian authorities probing a multi-billion dollar scandal at state fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB), is believed to be hiding in Macau, according to a report by The Malaysian Reserve.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Hyflux, Imperium Crown, Nippecraft
summary: Hyflux faces a default after failing to pay a coupon, with the trustee threatening to wind up the company if it doesn't get permission from perp holders. Imperium Crown has incorporated a Chinese subsidiary to lead its property development and investment segments. Nippecraft will be removed from the watch list and transferred to the Catalist board after receiving an in-principle approval.

site_title: Virgin Australia Holdings CEO to not renew contract
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd announced that CEO John Borghetti will not renew his contract after January 1, 2020. The airline will start searching for a successor. This decision comes amid the company's efforts to revamp its operations and improve its financial performance.

images.alt_text: Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd said on Tuesday chief executive and managing director of Virgin Australia Group John Borghetti will not be renewing his contract post Jan. 1, 2020.

site_title: Europe: Britain's FTSE rises as pounds weakens; bid war hopes lift Inmarsat
summary: Britain's FTSE 100 index rose 0.7% to 7,737.43, driven by export-oriented firms and big international companies. A weaker pound made UK firms more competitive, while hopes of a bidding war boosted satellite provider Inmarsat 12.6%. Sterling slid against the dollar after factory output fell in April. Defensive stocks dominated the FTSE leaders, suggesting a cautious investor attitude.

site_title: Stock markets rise before Trump-Kim summit
summary: Stock markets worldwide rose on Monday, driven by investor focus on the upcoming summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, despite a contentious G-7 meeting. The summit, set to take place in Singapore, is expected to ease geopolitical tensions in the region. Global equity markets rose, with European stocks up 1.0% and Asian markets up 0.5% to 0.7%. The US Federal Reserve is also set to announce interest rate decisions this week, which could impact markets.

site_title: Huh? China stumped by Ivanka Trump's 'Chinese proverb'
summary: Chinese social media users were puzzled by a "Chinese proverb" posted by Ivanka Trump on Twitter, which read "'Those who say it can not be done, should not interrupt those doing it.'". Despite numerous guesses, no consensus was reached, with some suggesting the phrase "the foolish old man removed mountains" or American origin, while others questioned the White House's distribution of proverbs to China. The post sparked a heated debate, with some users expressing frustration and others defending Ivanka Trump's intention. The incident highlighted the complexities of cultural exchange and language.

site_title: China's CITIC becomes biggest shareholder in Friedland's Ivanhoe
summary: Ivanhoe Mines Ltd. agreed to sell a minority stake to CITIC Metal Co, making the Chinese conglomerate the largest shareholder in the Canadian mining company. CITIC will pay C$3.68 apiece for 196.6 million common shares, worth approximately C$723 million, to invest in Ivanhoe's copper, zinc, and platinum deposits in Southern Africa. CITIC will become co-chair with founder Robert Friedland and have the right to nominate two directors, while Friedland will remain the second-largest shareholder.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down in opening trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly down, with the Hang Seng Index easing 0.11% to 31,029.85, amid traders monitoring the Donald Trump-Kim Jong Un summit and key central bank policy meetings. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index were also marginally higher, adding 0.25 and 0.68 points respectively. The slight decline was attributed to traders' cautious approach ahead of the historic summit and policy meetings.

site_title: US reveals ZTE settlement details, ban still in place
summary: The US Commerce Department has released details of a settlement with ZTE Corp, allowing the Chinese telecommunications equipment maker to resume business with US suppliers. ZTE agreed to pay a $1.7 billion civil penalty, including a $1 billion fine, and overhaul its leadership. The ban on buying US parts remains in place until ZTE pays the fine and places $400 million in escrow. As part of the settlement, ZTE must replace its boards of directors, terminate senior leadership, and provide detailed information on Chinese government ownership and control.

site_title: Nippecraft to exit SGX watch list on Wednesday
summary: Nippecraft will exit the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) watch list on Wednesday, having received an in-principle approval for its removal. The company had been listed on the watch list since 2014 due to consecutive losses and a market cap below S$40 million. Nippecraft will transfer to the Catalist board and begin trading at 9am, with its market cap now deemed to "better resemble" that of companies trading on the Catalist.

site_title: Trump-Kim Singapore summit: Talks off to positive start after one-on-one meeting
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un met for a one-on-one discussion, described as "very, very good" by Trump. The two leaders walked out of the library at the Capella Singapore hotel, smiled and waved at the media, and shared a brief handshake. Trump said he expected a "great discussion" and that the two would have an "excellent relationship." Kim expressed willingness to work in close cooperation, despite the challenges. The summit's outcome is uncertain, with expectations of a broad agreement without set targets.

site_title: Trial opens for Argentine nun, ex-minister who stashed US$9m
summary: A trial has opened in Argentina for former ex-minister Jose Lopez and nun Celia Ines, who allegedly hid $9 million in cash and jewels at a monastery. Lopez, a former public works minister, and Ines, an 80-year-old nun, were caught on security camera and are suspected of corruption. Lopez has been in detention for two years, while Ines has denied knowing the contents of the bags. The trial, expected to last six months, comes as part of the country's efforts to address corruption under the Kirchner administration.

images.alt_text: Celia Ines, an 80-year-old nun, was his accomplice, according to prosecutors, and the entire affair was caught on security camera.

site_title: Chinese tycoon buys S$2b Beijing property
summary: Chinese property brokerage tycoon Zuo Hui is in talks to acquire Beijing real estate from Gaw Capital Partners for approximately $2.08 billion. Zuo Hui's company is discussing the purchase of Pacific Century Place, a downtown complex in Beijing's Sanlitun area. The complex, acquired by Gaw Capital in 2014 for $939 million, includes office blocks, a shopping mall, and luxury residential buildings. The acquisition is part of Zuo Hui's expansion into Beijing's real estate market, further solidifying his position as one of China's biggest realtors.

site_title: Oil near flat as Opec supply hike appears less certain
summary: Oil prices remained relatively flat on Monday, unchanged at $76.46 a barrel for Brent crude, as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries' (OPEC) potential supply hike appeared uncertain. Despite US crude rising to its highest level since June 1, profit-taking and uncertainty over OPEC's decision weighed on prices. OPEC is set to meet on June 22-23 to discuss its supply curb policy, which has been in place for 18 months to stabilize markets and support prices.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were little changed on Monday as comments from the Iraqi oil minister cast doubt as to whether the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries would decide to boost output at its upcoming meeting.

site_title: Founder of China EV batteries maker becomes billionaire overnight
summary: The founder of Contemporary Amperex Technology (CATL), Zeng Yuqun, and his top lieutenant Huang Shilin became billionaires after CATL's shares soared 44% on the first day of trading, valuing the company at $12.3 billion. Zeng's net worth is estimated at $3.4 billion, and CATL is now the largest company on China's Nasdaq-style ChiNext list. The company's shares are expected to rise further due to increasing demand for electric vehicle batteries, driven by government subsidies and restrictions on petrol cars in China, which is forecast to quadruple battery demand in the next four years.

site_title: Germany hits Mercedes with mass diesel recall
summary: Germany ordered a mass recall of 774,000 Mercedes-Benz vehicles across Europe due to "defeat devices" that concealed high emissions during lab tests. The recall affects Vito vans and diesel-powered versions of GLC 4x4s and C-class sedans. Daimler CEO Dieter Zetsche was summoned for talks with Transport Minister Andreas Scheuer. This move follows Volkswagen's "dieselgate" scandal and other German carmakers' recalls. The European car industry is still dealing with the "diesel quagmire," with some experts calling for a shift to hardware-based solutions to address excessive emissions.

site_title: China's US$50b bid for market calm might backfire
summary: China's $50 billion bid to calm the market may backfire as new funds guarantee demand for tech listings, locking up investors' money for three years. The six new funds, each raising up to $10.4 billion, will act as "strategic investors" in exchange for holding shares for extended periods, potentially reducing tradable shares and increasing volatility. Analysts warn that this could lead to unintended consequences, including investors regretting being trapped and regulators facing a potential headache if the market turns sour.

site_title: The Philippines has a lot to celebrate today
summary: The Philippines celebrates its 120th anniversary of independence from Spain on June 12, 2018. The country marks the occasion with peace, a strong economy, and good bilateral ties with Singapore. The Philippines and Singapore have a long history of trade and cultural exchange, with bilateral relations established in 1969. The two countries enjoy strong economic ties, with Singapore being the Philippines' fifth-largest export market and third-largest source of foreign direct investment. The Philippines is also home to a significant number of Filipinos in Singapore, with estimated 180,000 residents.

site_title: Chinese electric carmaker Byton raises US$500m to take on Tesla
summary: Byton, a Chinese electric carmaker, has raised US$500 million to compete with Tesla. The funding is led by FAW Group, Tus-Holdings, CATL, and others. Byton aims to establish a benchmark for auto startups with four essential 'must haves': technology, product, capital, and factory. The company plans to launch in China by 2019 and in the US and Europe by 2020, with a first batch of prototype models set to roll out in April 2019. Byton has also been working on autonomous driving technology and will incorporate some self-driving functions in its first models.

site_title: US: Stocks edge higher ahead of US-North Korea summit
summary: US stocks edged higher on Monday ahead of an historic US-North Korea summit, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.1% to 25,322.31. Despite a contentious G-7 meeting, investors remained skeptical about the impact of a potential trade war, with expectations for the US-North Korea talks being "fairly low." Individual stocks including Tesla, Envision Healthcare, and Boston Scientific also saw gains, while PG&E fell 4% after a California agency concluded that several wildfires were caused by downed power lines.

site_title: Global warming will make vegetables harder to find: study
summary: Global warming is expected to significantly reduce vegetable yields by nearly one-third by the end of this century unless new growing practices and resilient crop varieties are adopted. A 4°C increase in temperature is projected to cut average yields by 31.5%, with southern Europe, Africa, and South Asia particularly affected. Researchers warn that urgent action is needed to support the agriculture sector and increase its resilience to environmental changes, as a 'business as usual' approach will substantially reduce the global availability of these important foods.

images.alt_text: By the end of this century, less water and hotter air will combine to cut average yields of vegetables - which are crucial to a healthy diet - by nearly one-third, said the report in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

site_title: Nomura ramps up global markets business and revamps electronic platform
summary: Nomura, Japan's largest brokerage, is expanding its global markets business to increase its market share in equities, foreign exchange, and structured lending. The company is revamping its electronic platform, citing it as its top priority. This move aims to enhance its offerings and competitiveness in the market.

site_title: HK golf course row exposes city's social divide
summary: Hong Kong's historic Fanling golf course, a favorite among international golfers, is under threat as the government considers listing it for potential housing development. The club argues that sacrificing the world-class sports venue would be short-sighted, while grassroots campaigners say the prime spot should not remain a playground for the elite. The government has 18 options for affordable housing, with Fanling being one of the most valuable sites, sparking concerns about the city's social divide and inequality.

site_title: Trump or no, the US will continue to lead
summary: US President Donald Trump's foreign policy has sparked tensions with allies, particularly over tariffs and trade deals. Despite this, the US remains a dominant economic and military power, with its largest and most advanced economy and largest military. The Trump-Kim summit in Singapore marked a significant shift towards Sino-American cooperation, with China exerting pressure on North Korea to cease nuclear threats. The US and its allies will continue to work together to maintain the global balance of power, with the US remaining the next best thing to being the world's top power.

site_title: Daimler shares fall after 1 million cars 'found with cheating devices'
summary: Daimler shares plummeted 1.76% following a report that up to 1 million of its cars contained illegal "defeat" devices that cheated emissions tests on diesel vehicles. German Transport Minister Andreas Scheuer summoned CEO Dieter Zetsche to discuss the issue, but Daimler disputes the 1 million figure, claiming it is cooperating fully with authorities. The discovery is the latest in the ongoing "Dieselgate" scandal, which has already cost Volkswagen $30 billion in fines and charges.

site_title: Great Eastern, NTUC Income sign up at PLQ
summary: Great Eastern and NTUC Income, two major insurance companies in Singapore, have leased office space at Paya Lebar Quarter (PLQ). Great Eastern has leased about 125,000 sq ft on four floors, while NTUC Income has leased 55,000 sq ft. IWG is also reportedly eyeing 52,000 sq ft for its lifestyle co-working concept, Spaces. The leases were facilitated by CBRE, which is jointly marketing the office space with JLL. The office component of PLQ is expected to be completed in the third quarter of this year, offering over 800,000 sq ft of Grade A-specification space.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Chinese leader's dream city off to a slow start
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping's ambitious high-tech city, Xiongan, has faced a slow start due to delays in development and a lack of investment. Despite initial promises of a futuristic city with leading-edge companies and research institutes, the local economy remains in limbo, with shuttered factories and lost jobs. Investors who had flocked to the area have left, and locals wait anxiously for planners to act. The project, aimed at creating a new development model for China, has sparked concerns about the impact on local residents, with some calling it a "gold rush gone bust."

site_title: Temasek, others to buy Hainan Airlines stake for 7b yuan
summary: Hainan Airlines plans to raise up to 7 billion yuan (S$1.5 billion) by selling up to 20% of its Shanghai-listed shares to investors, including Temasek Holdings Pte, as part of a restructuring plan by HNA Group Co. The sale will be used to fund plane purchases, training, and maintenance. This follows Temasek's exploration of partnerships in aviation and logistics with HNA, which has been scrutinized for its debt. The stake sale announcement comes after Hainan Airlines' controlling shareholder will change to HNA Group and parties acting in concert.

site_title: Euro rises on Italy relief, Canadian dollar dips after G-7 row
summary: The euro rose to a near two-week high after Italy's economy minister assured investors that the country would not leave the European Union or issue securities to pay off companies owed money. This calmed investor nerves ahead of the European Central Bank's policy meeting. The euro rose 0.5% to $1.1816, while the Canadian dollar fell 0.6% after US President Trump's comments on trade. Investors expect the ECB to signal the end of its bond-buying program by the end of 2018, amid ongoing global trade war concerns.

site_title: Hedge fund with 69% return sees more to come
summary: A hedge fund, Titan Opportunities Fund, run by a former associate of billionaire John Fredriksen, has gained 69% in two years by betting on shunned oil-related assets. The fund now manages about $100 million and is expecting more gains as oil prices are expected to rise due to increasing geopolitical tensions. Chief investment officer Espen Westeren believes US shale production will continue to support oil prices, which could reach $100 a barrel within two years. The fund is shifting positions to boost investments in pipeline companies, offshore drilling, and shipping.

site_title: Trump-Kim summit: History or reality TV?
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to meet with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Singapore on June 12, marking a historic summit. Despite the unpredictable nature of the meeting, a positive outcome could lead to a relief rally in markets and a decrease in nuclear risk sentiment, particularly for South Korean and Japanese markets. However, progress towards complete, verifiable, and irreversible denuclearization of the Korean peninsula remains uncertain, as North Korea's top priority is regime preservation and the leverage nuclear weapons provide. Trump's decision to meet Kim without significant concessions has sparked criticism, but diplomatic talks are preferable to nuclear escalation.

site_title: HSBC to spend US$17b on market expansion
summary: HSBC plans to invest up to $17 billion in expanding its presence in key Asian markets and improving technology, with a focus on Hong Kong, the Pearl River Delta, and wealth management in Asia. The investment aims to accelerate growth in areas of strength, particularly in Asia and from its international network. The bank also targets a return on tangible equity of over 11% by 2020.

site_title: Singapore's Q3 job outlook brightest in 3 years
summary: Singapore's Q3 job outlook is the brightest in nearly three years, with a 12% net employment outlook, according to ManpowerGroup. The finance, insurance, and real estate sector is expected to see the most aggressive hiring, with a +26% outlook. Other sectors, including manufacturing, transportation, and utilities, are also expected to see steady gains. The only sector with a weaker outlook is mining and construction, with a +3% increase. This is the highest employment outlook since the fourth quarter of 2015.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies lose US$42b after exchange hack in South Korea
summary: Cryptocurrencies experienced a significant decline, losing US$42 billion in market value over the weekend, with Bitcoin's slump extending to over 50% for the year. The drop is attributed to an exchange hack in South Korea, Coinrail, which did not disclose the amount of digital currency stolen. The incident triggered panic selling, with low market liquidity exacerbating the slump. Other major cryptocurrencies also retreated, sending the market value of digital assets to a nearly two-month low. The hacking incident has raised concerns over market manipulation and money laundering in the cryptocurrency industry.

site_title: Market moves cautiously ahead of summit
summary: The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) posted modest gains of 5.32 points or 0.15% to finish at 3,441.69, kicking off an action-packed week ahead of a historic US-North Korea summit. Analysts expect improved risk appetite if the summit yields encouraging signs of denuclearization, potentially encouraging investors to carry on investing in global stocks. Meanwhile, other Asian markets were mixed, with the US Federal Reserve expected to hike interest rates, while the European Central Bank's meeting outcome is considered less clear.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Offering the right things at the right time, right place
summary: Singapore's ability to attract and retain top international talent is crucial for its technology industry, given the rarity of individuals capable of making significant breakthroughs. The country's reputation as a secure and safe host, politically stable and neutral, and its commitment to education and research, have contributed to its success. Singapore's efficient and well-organized environment, good quality of living, and welcoming culture also make it an attractive destination for professionals. The country's hosting of the Trump-Kim Summit showcases its international standing, and its ability to provide a streamlined environment for businesses and workers to operate, is a major advantage.

site_title: Global info-sharing platform to help central banks fight cyber crime
summary: A global information-sharing platform, CERES (CEntral banks, REgulators and Supervisory entities) Forum, will be launched on July 1 to combat cyber and physical crime and enhance the resilience of the financial sector. The platform will facilitate secure sharing of information about cyber threats, vulnerabilities, and incidents among central banks, regulators, and supervisors. This move aims to address the rapidly evolving cyber threats and bridge the gap in information sharing among authorities, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore playing a key role in its development.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), Singapore's central bank, played a key role in developing the CERES Forum.

site_title: India's most profitable store bets on youth in villages, small towns with online push
summary: V-MART Retail, India's most-profitable department store chain, plans to expand its online presence to attract youth in villages and small towns. The company aims to add 30-40 stores annually, focusing on cities with a population below one million. V-Mart's omnichannel strategy will integrate online and physical shops, with a goal to finalize its e-commerce strategy and omni-channel model within a year. The company's shares have risen 60% this year, driven by its high return on equity and return on capital, making it the highest among its peers.

site_title: Both sides hopeful; consensus is that it's a long road ahead
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un will meet face-to-face for the first time on Tuesday at a luxury hotel in Singapore, marking a historic summit aimed at denuclearizing the Korean peninsula. The meeting, after being cancelled and reinstated, has both leaders expressing optimism, with Trump saying "things can work out very nicely" and Kim discussing a "permanent and durable peace-keeping mechanism" with the US. The outcome is uncertain, with Pompeo stating that complete denuclearization is the only acceptable outcome and analysts warning of a long and precarious process.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Mr Trump (centre), who turns 72 on Thursday, was presented a birthday cake during his working lunch with PM Lee Hsien Loong (extreme left, facing camera) at the Istana on Monday.

site_title: Mahathir floats new national car project
summary: Malaysia's newly elected Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad floated the idea of a national car project, despite its troubled history. He stated that Malaysia would seek support and expertise from other countries to produce its own cars, citing its existing design and production capabilities. However, analysts expressed skepticism, citing the highly globalized market and the difficulty of competing with established brands. Mahathir aims to access the world market with the new national car, possibly with the help of partners in South-east Asia.

site_title: Developer targets NY luxury-home buyers
summary: Developer HFZ Capital Group is launching $3.4 billion worth of new luxury condos in Manhattan, including the Belnord and Eleventh projects, amidst a flagging demand for high-end real estate. The cheapest units start at $5 million, while two penthouses at the Eleventh are priced at $70 million each. Despite competition, luxury buyers are taking their time to assess options, driving hard bargains and pushing prices down 9% on average. The move is seen as a bold attempt to capitalize on exceptional product and unparalleled locations.

images.alt_text: This year, 4,600 newly developed apartments are expected to be listed across Manhattan, with almost half of them priced at US$2,400 a square foot or more.

site_title: Rolls-Royce says engine problem has spread
summary: Rolls-Royce has confirmed a compressor problem affecting Boeing's 787 Dreamliner jet, grounding planes and forcing inspections. The issue, similar to a previous problem with the Trent 1000 package C engine, has now been found in a "small number" of Package B engines, requiring a one-off inspection. The news complicates Rolls' efforts to cut over 4,000 jobs this week and may impact its ability to meet airline clients' demands for alternative planes during the busy summer holiday period.

site_title: US-Korea politics drawing Putin and Xi closer together
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin strengthened their bilateral relationship, with Xi describing their ties as "the highest-level, most profound and strategically most significant relationship between major countries in the world". The two leaders signed several deals, including a nuclear cooperation project worth $3 billion and a $1 billion industrial investment fund. The SCO summit also saw China and Russia agreeing to create alternative financial institutions, such as the New Development Bank, and a $400 billion natural gas supply deal. The growing cooperation between Beijing and Moscow comes as the US-Korea tensions continue, with both countries expressing interest in establishing peace and stability on the Korean peninsula.

site_title: Fleetwood Mac guitarist Danny Kirwan dies at 68
summary: Fleetwood Mac guitarist Danny Kirwan died at 68 in London. He was a co-founder of the band and played a significant role in its early years. Kirwan joined Fleetwood Mac in 1968 and contributed to five albums, including "Then Play On" and "Bare Trees." His departure from the band in 1972 was reportedly due to struggles with alcoholism, following a tantrum on tour. The band went on to achieve massive success in the 1970s, selling over 100 million albums. Kirwan's legacy will be remembered through his contributions to Fleetwood Mac's foundation.

site_title: Harnessing technology to stay in pole position
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can gain a competitive edge by leveraging technology to overcome internal challenges and stay ahead of the market. Despite facing external competition, economic headwinds, and rising costs, SMEs must prioritize digitalization to improve productivity, communication, and security. Key areas for investment include cybersecurity, cloud and collaboration solutions, network optimization, and strong computer power. By adopting these technologies, SMEs can sharpen their competitive edge, build trust with customers, and respond quickly to change, ultimately paving the road to success.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hyflux faces default after missing a coupon payment, with a trustee reserving the right to wind up the company if holders mandate it. China Environment's CFO, Chong Guan Choi, steps down amid possible misappropriation of rental income. Imperium Crown incorporates a Chinese subsidiary to lead its property development and investment segments.

site_title: Ocean's 8 women lead at box office
summary: Ocean's 8, an all-female heist film starring Sandra Bullock and Cate Blanchett, took in an estimated US$41.5 million in North American cinemas, ranking as one of the top 10 openings of the year. The film, led by Bullock as Debbie Ocean, beat earlier Ocean's editions and solo films like Solo: A Star Wars Story and Deadpool 2. Its success marks a notable shift in Hollywood's experiment with female-led casts, following Ghostbusters.

site_title: SGX mulls new rule to protect minority shareholders in delistings
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) is considering new rules to protect minority shareholders in delistings. Recent privatisations have raised concerns about controlling shareholders' voting power and exit offers being too low. SGX RegCo's CEO, Tan Boon Gin, stated that the exchange will monitor developments and conduct a public consultation before proposing any rule changes. Critics argue that current legislation does not effectively protect minority shareholders, while supporters believe that existing rules already provide sufficient protection. The issue highlights the need for better safeguards to prevent forced delistings that harm minority shareholders.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Manage ties, even if not agreeable with each other: DPM Teo
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean urged countries to manage bilateral and multilateral ties despite disagreements, emphasizing the importance of mutual respect and trust in foreign relations. He warned that unilateral actions could harm businesses and undermine the multilateral trading system. Teo also championed the revised Trans-Pacific Partnership deal and expressed hope for better Sino-Japan ties, which he believes would be beneficial to ASEAN.

images.alt_text: Walter Sim

site_title: Authorities across Asia battle illegal gambling surge ahead of World Cup
summary: Authorities in Asia are cracking down on illegal gambling ahead of the World Cup, with law enforcement and regulatory forces targeting operators using technology and cryptocurrencies to evade prosecution. In countries like Thailand and Malaysia, where football is popular but there are no legal betting alternatives, illegal gambling is prevalent. Experts say the surge is driven by the region's football fans and the lack of regulated betting options. Authorities are gearing up to fight back, with efforts to disrupt and prosecute these operations.

site_title: Slum dwellers build own homes with community loans
summary: In the Philippines, community finance is helping address housing finance needs, particularly for slum dwellers. A state-backed program with Habitat for Humanity provides affordable housing options, where residents can build and own their homes with community loans. About 4.5 million people are homeless or living in informal settlements, with many forced out by industrial projects. Community mortgage programs have benefited 250,000 slum-dwellers since 1989, offering access to affordable loans and tenure security. Similar initiatives are being implemented in Thailand, Cambodia, Nepal, Sri Lanka, and the Philippines, aiming to provide affordable housing solutions for millions.

site_title: Youth is no guarantee of your startup's success
summary: A recent US study found that entrepreneurs aged 40 are 2.1 times more likely to start successful startups compared to those aged 25. The average age of a company's founder at startup is 41.9 years, and 45 for the fastest-growing companies. Experts argue that experience and understanding of the industry are key factors in fintech success, making ex-bankers more likely to succeed. Additionally, research suggests that discipline and productivity, not youthfulness, are more important for innovation and creativity.

site_title: Adient CEO resigns, company slashes profit outlook
summary: Adient Plc CEO R Bruce McDonald resigned, and the company slashed its profit forecast for fiscal 2018, citing operating performance behind plan. The company now forecasts free cash flow of up to negative $100 million and adjusted EBITDA of $1.25 billion. Former General Motors CEO Frederick Henderson will take over as interim CEO, while McDonald will remain an adviser until September 30. The company's shares plummeted 17% following the announcement.

site_title: 'Mini-1MDBs' rife across Malaysia, says Daim
summary: Malaysia's top adviser to Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, Daim Zainuddin, has discovered "many mini-1MDBs" during his investigation into corruption, indicating widespread wrongdoing. He found multiple criminal breaches of trust and will submit his findings to the premier. The investigation into the state-owned investment fund, which is at the center of a multi-billion dollar corruption scandal, may be more widespread than previously known, with Malaysia reviving an investigation into 1MDB. Daim's findings signal more resignations to come and efforts to clean up corruption and prevent leakages in state spending.

site_title: Five manufacturing-linked stocks among biggest intraday movers
summary: Five manufacturing-linked stocks - AEM Holdings, Memtech International, Creative Technology, Best World International, and Delong Holdings - were among the biggest intraday movers in the three months from March to May, with average daily price ranges of 4%. The stocks, along with Hi-P International and two non-manufacturing stocks, generated the largest intraday tick ranges. Creative Technology had the highest number of ticks at 51 in March, while Best World had the lowest nine in May.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore Business Federation and Enterprise Singapore leading mission to East Africa
summary: Singapore Business Federation and Enterprise Singapore embark on a business mission to East Africa until June 16, visiting Kenya and Rwanda to meet high-level officials and local conglomerates. The 35-member delegation aims to promote Singaporean businesses in the region, particularly in sectors such as info-communications technology and real estate. The mission coincides with Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam's official visit to the region, highlighting Singapore's increased engagement with Sub-Saharan Africa.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Confident Brazil arrive in Russia
summary: Brazil arrived in Russia on Monday, fresh from a 3-0 win over Austria, ahead of their World Cup opener against Switzerland on Sunday. Neymar, who scored in the victory, marked his return to fitness after a three-month absence due to foot surgery. The team, led by coach Tite, is looking to draw level with Romario's all-time leading scorer record, while Cristiano Ronaldo trained with Portugal ahead of their opening match against Spain. The teams are set to begin their campaigns in Group E, which also includes Switzerland, Costa Rica, and Serbia.

site_title: From machinist to production team leader
summary: Singaporean Yeo Kain Thiong, a former machinist, rose to become a production team leader at Hope Technik, where he helped develop flying machines. Trained as a machinist at the Institute of Technical Education, Yeo joined Hope in 2010 with little knowledge of the firm. He progressed from controlling shopfloor tools to leading production teams, showcasing his career growth and expertise in the industry.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Data management crucial as data becomes critical asset for SMEs
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore are increasingly relying on data to drive their success in the digital economy. The government has introduced initiatives to enhance SMEs' digital readiness, including the SMEs Go Digital Programme and the Open Innovation Programme. To effectively utilize data, SMEs should consider hiring a chief data officer (CDO) to manage and utilize their digital assets. Data-driven insights can provide valuable information on consumer behavior, helping businesses make informed decisions and drive growth.

site_title: Trump and Kim are sticking their necks out on this one. We wish them well
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to meet North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, despite threats and counter-threats of nuclear attack. The meeting comes after lower-level officials worked out details of a potential agreement, with some critics arguing that more preparation was needed. The 1994 Agreement Framework, which aimed to freeze Pyongyang's nuclear programme, is seen as a template for the talks. The outcome of the meeting remains uncertain, with Trump and Kim "sticking their necks out" on this historic encounter.

site_title: Slow pace of developing airports in smaller cities stumps Modi's plan to get more to fly
summary: India's slow pace of developing airports in smaller cities is delaying Prime Minister Narendra Modi's plan to boost air travel and economic growth. The government aims to refurbish or build 31 new airports by 2017, but only 16 are operational. Delays in building air traffic control towers and setting up terminal buildings are hindering progress. The federal government will procure equipment and lease it to states to get 15 remaining airports operational by end-June. The delays highlight the challenges Modi faces in achieving his goal of increasing passenger traffic to 100 million in the next five years.

site_title: Citi's Asia consumer business gains from its digital strides
summary: Citi's Asia consumer business has seen significant growth, posting seven consecutive quarters of growth as of Q1 2018, despite a 30% reduction in physical branches. Revenue reached $4.13 billion, a 12% increase from the previous year, with a 10% decrease in "cost-to-serve" and a net income of $1.12 billion. The bank's digital investments have led to a shift in customer behavior, with 9 out of 10 retail transactions now done digitally and 40% of consumer loans acquired online.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat ahead of US-North Korea summit
summary: US stock indexes opened flat on Monday ahead of a historic US-North Korea summit. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.08%, the S&P 500 gained 0.04%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.02%. Investors focused on the summit, which is expected to bring significant changes to the region.

site_title: Trump's tweets spew ire on Nato allies, EU and Trudeau
summary: US President Donald Trump fired off a series of tweets criticizing Nato allies, the European Union, and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau after a divisive G-7 meeting. Trump backed out of a joint communique on trade, saying "fair trade is now to be called fool trade if it is not reciprocal." The move has cast a cloud over his upcoming nuclear talks with North Korea's Kim Jong Un and raised concerns about a potential global trade war. Trump's attacks on trading partners and allies have sparked unease among US officials and global markets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.52 points to 1,775.80. Losers outnumbered gainers 488 to 404, and trading volume reached 2.6 billion lots worth RM2.4 billion.

site_title: Imperium Crown incorporates China subsidiary
summary: Imperium Crown, a Catalist-listed real estate firm, has incorporated a China subsidiary, Fei County Yin Sheng Real Estate, to lead its property development and investment segments. The new subsidiary will develop two plots of land in Wonder Stone Park, a tourist destination in Shangdong province. The move aims to capitalize on improving market trends and upcoming developments in the area, with executive director Sun Bowen stating the company's commitment to being a real estate player.

site_title: A Hope for the future
summary: Hope Technik, a Singapore-based engineering firm, has undergone significant transformation from its free-spirited start-up days to become a rigorous, multi-faceted engineering firm. This evolution is an example of transformation, not limited to traditional firms, as cutting-edge technology companies also need to reinvent themselves. The firm's transformation demonstrates its commitment to adapting to future-ready approaches and achieving long-term success.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

Hope Technik wants to rely less on projects - which may be irregular - and more on steady product revenue. "We need to create a sustainable business to sustain the innovative side," says chief technology officer Jeff Tang.

site_title: Audi chief investigated in VW emissions scandal
summary: German prosecutors have opened a fraud investigation against Rupert Stadler, head of Audi's management board, in connection with Volkswagen's emissions scandal. Stadler, whose home was raided, is suspected of false advertising and is the first active Audi executive to be identified as a suspect. The investigation follows raids on Audi offices and employees' homes and comes as Volkswagen faces tens of billions of dollars in fines and penalties. Stadler has not been charged, but the investigation is likely to intensify criticism of Volkswagen's slow response to replace executives involved in the cheating scandal.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets higher at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rose at the start of trade on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.3%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 adding 0.4%, and Paris's CAC 40 gaining 0.2%. The rise was despite deep divisions between the US and its allies following the Group of Seven meeting, and investors await interest rate decisions from the European Central Bank and Federal Reserve. The market was also influenced by US President Donald Trump's summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.

site_title: Spot a rat? Real-time map aims to plot Paris sightings
summary: Paris residents can now report rat sightings in real-time through an interactive map created by Geoffroy Boulard, head of the 17th Arrondissement municipal council. The initiative was sparked by a daycare centre infestation, and residents can signal sightings on the map. The goal is to better monitor and address the growing rat problem in the French capital.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: US President Donald Trump met with Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, expressing gratitude for Singapore's role in hosting the US-North Korea summit. The American Chamber of Commerce in Singapore supports the summit, strengthening ties between the US and Singapore. A new information-sharing platform for central banks aims to combat cybercrime, while Malaysia uncovers "mini 1MDBs" across the country. China's $50 billion bid for market calm may backfire, and Singapore shares rose 0.15% today.

site_title: Trump thanks PM Lee for Singapore's hospitality
summary: US President Donald Trump thanked Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong for Singapore's hospitality during a working lunch at the Istana, expressing appreciation for the country's efforts to host the historic summit between him and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Trump also accepted an invitation to make a state visit to Singapore in November. The meeting was seen as a significant step towards peace in the region, with Prime Minister Lee expressing hope for a positive outcome.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

Above: US President Donald Trump with PM Lee Hsien Loong after Mr Trump's visit to the Istana. Over lobster bisque and beef tenderloin, he expressed his gratitude to PM Lee for Singapore's efforts to host the summit.
Above: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un at Gardens By The Bay with Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan and Education Minister Ong Ye Kung.

site_title: Norwegian Air says Roll-Royce engine problem a concern
summary: Norwegian Air expressed concern about Rolls-Royce engine problems affecting its summer traffic, despite overall well-performing summer traffic. The airline is set to receive 11 new Boeing 787 Dreamliner jets with Rolls-Royce motors, which have been impacted by a compressor issue that has grounded some Boeing planes.

images.alt_text: Europe's third biggest budget airliner Norwegian Air said on Monday that summer traffic is running well but expressed concern about Rolls-Royce engine problems.

site_title: N Korea's Kim visits Singapore's sky bar, gardens in surprise evening tour
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un visited Singapore's Gardens by the Bay and Marina Bay Sands hotel on a surprise evening tour, marking his furthest journey since taking power in 2011. He was accompanied by his sister and aides, and took selfies with Singapore officials before stopping at the hotel's rooftop infinity pool. The excursion sparked a stir among guests, who were told to stay behind a barricade. The visit is part of a historic summit with US President Donald Trump on Tuesday aimed at achieving North Korea's denuclearization.

site_title: HSBC's new chief outlines plan to spend US$17 billion by 2020
summary: HSBC's new CEO, John Flint, has outlined a plan to invest up to $17 billion by 2020 to expand in key Asian markets and improve technology. The majority of the investment will be directed towards building presence in Hong Kong and the Pearl River Delta, with the remainder focused on technology upgrades, including cyber security. Flint aims to achieve a return on tangible equity of over 11% by 2020, while also targeting growth in China asset management and insurance.

site_title: Penka the Bulgarian cow escapes death sentence after international outcry
summary: Bulgaria has agreed to spare the life of Penka, a five-year-old cow that was set to be put down for crossing EU borders without paperwork. International outcry, including from animal rights campaigners and former Beatle Sir Paul McCartney, prompted the Bulgarian Food Safety Agency to review the case. Lab tests found Penka to be healthy, and she is expected to be allowed back to her home in Bulgaria by the end of the week. The decision highlights the need for a review of EU legislation regarding stray animals crossing borders.

images.alt_text: Bulgaria agreed on Monday to spare the life of Penka the cow after plans to kill her for crossing European Union borders without paperwork triggered an international outcry.

site_title: Qatar takes UAE to UN human rights court over boycott
summary: Qatar has taken the United Arab Emirates to the UN's International Court of Justice over alleged human rights violations, citing a 2017 boycott that severed diplomatic and transport ties. Qatar denies supporting terrorism and claims the pressure is aimed at stripping it of sovereignty. The UAE denies the claims, calling them "lies." Qatar is seeking reparations and restoration of rights for Qataris affected by the measures, including expelling them from the UAE and closing airspace and seaports. The court is expected to consider Qatar's application, which alleges UAE actions amount to discrimination on the basis of nationality.

site_title: US deepens rift between itself and neighbours as it tears away from the West
summary: The US is deepening the rift between itself and its neighbors, effectively tearing away from the West. The remaining Western countries, including Japan, Germany, France, the UK, Italy, and Canada, must now build new foundations to hold together in the face of friction and fractions. The absence of US leadership has led to a shift in global power dynamics, with China and Russia poised to benefit. Canada and Mexico, US neighbors, are particularly vulnerable, with Canada facing a crisis of its own ambitions and domestic policies. The US' pursuit of autarky under President Trump has created a new environment, requiring the rest of the West to redefine its world and decide its future.

site_title: Hyflux receives notice of default from perps trustee
summary: Hyflux received a notice of default from the trustee of its S$500 million 6% perpetual securities due to its failure to pay last month's coupon. The default has triggered a 30-day moratorium on creditors' claims, but the trustee reserves the right to institute proceedings for Hyflux's winding up if mandated by perp holders. Hyflux will engage with the perpetual trustee and its shares remain suspended from trading.

site_title: Fed, ECB to tighten policy in tandem
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates on Wednesday, while the European Central Bank will likely end its 2.55 trillion euro bond purchase scheme this year. These twin steps signal the end of cheap central bank cash and indicate major economies are strong enough to stand on their own. The move also suggests central banks are preparing to replenish their policy firepower before the next downturn, as the era of crisis-era stimulus begins to dissipate.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with modest gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with modest gains on Monday, driven by a moderate rally ahead of the historic summit between Donald Trump and Kim Jong Un. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.34% to 31,063.70, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.47% and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.58%. The gains were despite a tumultuous Group of Seven meeting and uncertainty over US trade policies.

site_title: Swire unit Haeco surges as parent plans US$382m buyout
summary: Swire Pacific Ltd., parent of Hong Kong Aircraft Engineering Co (Haeco), has proposed a US$382 million buyout of the company, offering a 64% premium for shares. The buyout values Haeco at US$1.5 billion. The proposal, which includes a HK$72 per share payment, aims to provide small investors an opportunity to exit the stock, which has traded at a low level of liquidity. The stock surged 55% to HK$68.10 on Monday after the announcement.

site_title: Iraq accuses other oil producers of exceeding quotas
summary: Iraq has accused other oil-producing countries of exceeding their quotas, according to Oil Minister Jabbar al-Luaibi. This accusation comes ahead of an Opec meeting next week. Al-Luaibi stated that producers must respect the set target and that a fair price for petrol can only be achieved with more support and engagement from producing countries. The Opec meeting aims to address the issue and reach a fair and consistent price.

images.alt_text: Iraq's largest oil refinery in the northern town of Baiji. Iraq on Monday accused other oil-producing countries of extracting more barrels of crude than agreed by Opec and its partners, ahead of a meeting of the cartel next week.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. US stocks opened lower due to Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC named Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong. Singapore stocks rallied for the 5th day ahead of GDP data, with affluents needing approximately US$1.39 million to retire comfortably.

site_title: Microsoft looks past next-gen Xbox to cloud games
summary: Microsoft is investing heavily in its Xbox console and cloud gaming service, with a focus on the next generation of gaming. Phil Spencer, Xbox team chief, announced the addition of five new game studios, including Playground Games and Ninja Theory, and a commitment to architecting the next Xbox. The company is also developing a cloud network to stream console-quality gameplay to various devices, including smartphones and tablets. This move aims to address criticism of the Xbox's lack of exclusive games and compete with Sony's PlayStation 4.

site_title: China's CNPC ships first larger-sized diesel cargo to Brazil
summary: China National Petroleum Corp (CNPC) shipped its first larger-sized diesel cargo to Brazil, a 60,000-tonne shipment from Liaoyang Petrochemical Corp, marking the Chinese major's first move of this size to the Americas. This shipment aims to expand market share in South America and cut logistics costs. The move follows Unipec's recent shipment of very large crude carriers of diesel to Europe and West Africa, indicating China's surplus refining capacity.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Bumitama Agri's 2018-2020 crude palm oil (CPO) ASP forecasts were lowered to RM2,450 per tonne (-6%) and RM2,500 per tonne (-4%) due to lower-than-expected CPO spot ASP and ample palm oil stockpile. The company's cash cost is expected to increase by 5-10% year-on-year. In contrast, Bumitama Agri's earnings per share forecast is revised upwards by 2.2%. Changi Airport will charge an airport development levy on departing passengers starting July 1, potentially impacting airlines' profitability, especially low-cost carriers like Scoot.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover preps for electric era by moving SUV from UK
summary: Jaguar Land Rover is moving all Land Rover Discovery SUV production from a UK plant to Slovakia, with the UK plant to be retooled for electric car production. The move will result in possible job cuts at the Solihull plant, but marks a commitment to UK manufacturing amid Brexit uncertainty. The investment, estimated in the hundreds of millions of pounds, could boost UK manufacturing and offset the country's below-average business investment since Brexit.

site_title: Authorities across Asia battle illegal gambling surge ahead of World Cup
summary: Authorities across Asia are battling a surge in illegal gambling ahead of the World Cup, with illegal bookmakers using technology and cryptocurrencies to evade prosecution. In countries like Thailand and Malaysia, football is a popular draw, but there are no legal betting alternatives. Hong Kong and Macau police are conducting operations to crack down on illegal activities, while Interpol warns that online payment providers and cryptocurrencies are facilitating the illegal betting. The estimated illegal betting turnover in Hong Kong is expected to be at least $68 billion, with potential losses of around $13 billion for the government.

site_title: Trump accepts invitation to make state visit to Singapore in November
summary: US President Donald Trump has accepted an invitation to make a state visit to Singapore in November, following a meeting with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The visit will coincide with the 6th Asean-US Summit and 13th East Asia Summit. Trump and Lee discussed regional and global developments, reaffirming the excellent relations between Singapore and the US across economic, defense, and security spheres. Trump thanked Singapore for hosting the US-DPRK Summit and expressed US support for Singapore's Asean Chairmanship.

site_title: Tharman leads Singapore delegation on business mission to East Africa
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam leads a 35-member business and government mission to East Africa, visiting Kenya and Rwanda. The mission aims to explore opportunities in various sectors, including info-communications technology, real estate, and manufacturing. The East African region's GDP growth of 5.9% in 2017 is the highest on the continent, driven by private consumption and investment. The mission highlights the region's potential for Singaporean Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) to tap into the market.

site_title: With rates below Fed's, Asian markets head for rare ground
summary: Asian markets are moving towards a rare phenomenon where benchmark interest rates are below those of the US Federal Reserve. New Zealand's policy rate will fall below the Fed's for the first time since 2000, while Thailand and Taiwan's current account surpluses provide a buffer. Economists attribute this shift to large current-account surpluses, weak domestic demand, and high domestic debt in some countries. Real interest rates are rising in developing markets, and investors remain comfortable with negative interest rate differentials in some cases.

site_title: Singapore paying for North Korea's hotel stay at Trump-Kim summit: Vivian Balakrishnan
summary: Singapore is covering the hotel expenses for North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and his contingent, totaling S$20 million, during the historic summit with US President Donald Trump. This hospitality was offered to ensure a conducive environment for negotiations, and the North Korean delegation reportedly gained confidence in Singapore's ability to provide a secure and efficient setting. The expenditure is part of the overall S$20 million spent by Singapore on the summit.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won gain ahead of Trump-Kim summit
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index and won rose ahead of the US-North Korea summit on June 11, 2018, with stocks related to inter-Korea projects showing significant gains. The Kospi index rose 18.57 points or 0.76% to 2,470.15, while the won was quoted at 1,075.2 per dollar, up 0.07% from its previous close. However, South Korea's cryptocurrency exchange-related shares plummeted due to a cyber intrusion into Coinrail. The positive sentiment was largely driven by US President Donald Trump's optimistic remarks about the summit.

site_title: CDC warns residents in 8 US states of cut-fruit Salmonella outbreak
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the FDA have warned residents in eight US states of a Salmonella outbreak linked to recalled pre-cut melon products. The outbreak has resulted in 60 illnesses and at least 31 hospitalizations, with no deaths reported. Caito Foods LLC has recalled fresh-cut watermelon, honeydew melon, cantaloupe, and mixed fruit products produced at a facility in Indianapolis. Residents in Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Michigan, Missouri, North Carolina, and Ohio are advised to check their fridges and freezers for recalled products.

site_title: Rain brings wheat relief in Australia's west
summary: Australian wheat farmers in the west are celebrating good rainfall, providing relief after difficult conditions threatened to cut crop yields for a second successive season. The rain has improved conditions for wheat crops, particularly in Western Australia, which generates half of the country's total wheat production. Although eastern states remain parched, lower eastern wheat plantings will reduce national output, with analysts trimming their wheat forecast by 1 million tonnes.

site_title: Yuan inches up as dollar slips at the start of an event-packed week
summary: China's yuan edged up against the US dollar at the start of an event-packed week, with the dollar slipping in global markets following a G-7 meeting's disarray and policy meetings of the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank. The yuan strengthened 37 pips to 6.4053 per dollar, with most traders not expecting a direct impact from a historic summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un on Tuesday.

site_title: Mitsubishi Materials unveils boardroom shake-up as data tampering scandal deepens
summary: Mitsubishi Materials Corp, a Japanese metals maker, has announced a top management reshuffle amid a data tampering scandal. President Akira Takeuchi will step down and assume the position of chairman, while executive vice-president Naoki Ono will take over as president. The company has also found fresh cases of misconduct at its Naoshima copper smelter and refinery, leading to the revocation of its JIS certification. This is part of a series of quality assurance frauds affecting Japanese manufacturers, including Kobe Steel, Toray, Nissan, and Subaru.

site_title: Modi's plan to get millions more Indians flying faces turbulence
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's plan to launch more flights connecting smaller towns and cities is facing delays due to the slow pace of building and upgrading regional airports. The government aims to bring 100 million more passengers to the skies in the next five years, but only 16 of 31 planned new airports are operational. Funding and infrastructure constraints are major hurdles, with some states lacking funds and airports struggling to meet targets. The federal government has stepped in to procure equipment and lease it to states, but delays are expected to impact the government's goal.

images.alt_text: The slow pace of fitting out regional airports risks delaying Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's ambitious plan to launch more flights connecting smaller towns and cities and get millions more people using air travel.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon trading at 3,439.7, up 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Monday afternoon at 3,439.7, up 0.1% on the day. The Straits Times Index rose 3.33 points to 3,439.7, with 989 million shares changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 187 to 128. This marks the third consecutive day of gains for the STI, ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 7.48 points to 1,770.84. Volume was 43.95 million lots worth RM26.31 million, with 100 gainers outnumbering 78 losers.

site_title: Hong Kong golf course row exposes city's social divide
summary: Hong Kong's historic Fanling golf course is under threat as the government considers listing it for potential housing development due to the city's housing shortage. The club argues that sacrificing the venue is short-sighted, while grassroots campaigners believe the prime spot should be reserved for affordable housing, not the wealthy elite. The move highlights the city's social divide, with the affluent elite seeking to preserve their exclusive spaces, while the less affluent face increasing housing unaffordability.

site_title: Oxley units in Cyprus merge
summary: Oxley Holdings' subsidiaries in Cyprus have merged, with Oxley Planetvision Properties absorbing Jemina Properties and Flitous Properties. Oxley Planetvision is the surviving entity, taking over all undertakings, properties, assets, and rights of Jemina and Flitous. The merger was done without liquidation and has dissolved Jemina and Flitous.

site_title: Hong Kong jails top independence leader for six years
summary: Hong Kong jailed Edward Leung, a leading independence activist, for six years for his involvement in 2016 protests that included rioting and setting fires. Leung, 27, was convicted of rioting in Mong Kok. This conviction marks one of the city's worst protest violence in decades.

images.alt_text: Edward Leung, 27, had been convicted of rioting over his involvement in 2016 running battles with police when demonstrators hurled bricks and set rubbish alight in the commercial district of Mong Kok.

site_title: China's US$50b bid for market calm might backfire
summary: China's US$47 billion bid to calm the market by guaranteeing demand for Big Tech listings may backfire. The new funds, which can invest up to 50 billion yuan, will lock up backers' money for three years, potentially leading to thinly traded and volatile stocks. Analysts warn that the move could reduce tradable shares and create a headache for regulators if the market turns sour. This is part of Beijing's efforts to control price swings and ensure demand, but the unintended consequences could be significant.

site_title: US president meets PM Lee at Istana, says Trump-Kim summit will 'work out nicely'
summary: US President Donald Trump met with Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong at Istana, expressing gratitude for Singapore's role in hosting the US-North Korea summit. Trump stated that the summit "will work out nicely" and praised Lee's hospitality and professionalism. The two leaders shared a warm handshake before their working lunch, which included a birthday celebration for Trump. Diplomatic talks between the US and North Korea continue ahead of the summit, with key issues including denuclearization and sanctions easing.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares firm ahead of Trump-Kim summit
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.48% on June 11, 2018, ahead of a US-North Korea summit. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 22,804.04, while the Topix index rose 0.30%. This comes as investors await central bank meetings and the historic summit.

site_title: Kim, Trump in countdown to historic summit
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un are set to meet for a historic summit in Singapore, aiming to discuss denuclearization and a potential peace treaty to end the Korean War. The two leaders have made last-minute preparations, with Trump expressing optimism about the meeting's outcome. Pyongyang is demanding security guarantees and the end of a "hostile policy," while the US is seeking complete, verifiable, and irreversible denuclearization. The summit's outcome is uncertain, with some analysts warning that it may be more of a media event than a substantial diplomatic breakthrough.

site_title: Malaysia PM Mahathir urges TPP 'renegotiation'
summary: Malaysia's newly-elected Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad urged the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) to be renegotiated, citing protection for small countries in international trade. Despite the US pulling out, 11 countries, including Malaysia, signed a slimmed-down version of the deal. Mahathir argued that countries with limited capacity to compete need protection, making competition fairer. The TPP represents 13.5% of the global economy and a market of 500 million people.

site_title: Global information-sharing platform to help central banks combat cybercrime
summary: A global information-sharing platform, CERES (CEntral banks, REgulators and Supervisory entities) Forum, will be launched on July 1, 2018, to combat cyber and physical crime, and build a more resilient financial sector.
