site_title: Seoul: Stocks snap 5 days of gains as Brazil growth outlook dents sentiment
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index snapped a five-day winning streak on June 8, 2018, due to concerns over Brazil's growth outlook and deteriorating investor sentiment. The KOSPI fell 0.77% to 2,451.58, while the Korean won weakened 0.64% against the US dollar. The decline was attributed to widening rifts between the US and its major trading partners and a decrease in bond yields.

site_title: GIC, Temasek participate in Ant Financial's US$14b Series C funding round
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth investors Temasek Holdings and GIC are among a group of investors investing $14 billion in Ant Financial's Series C funding round. The funds will be used to accelerate Alipay's globalisation plans and develop technology to provide inclusive financial services to unbanked consumers and small enterprises globally. Other international investors include Khazanah Nasional Berhad, Warburg Pincus, and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board. Ant Financial aims to replicate its "Alipay model" in emerging markets and expand its user base to 1 billion by 2025.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon trading at 3,450.42, down 0.7% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Friday afternoon, down 0.7% at 3,450.42, due to a 22.66-point decline in the Straits Times Index. About 1.1 billion shares changed hands, with Singtel falling S$0.02 to S$3.23. UOB dropped 0.88% to S$28.31, while DBS rose 0.04% to S$28.81. The market was influenced by US trade uncertainty, but investors remained positive, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Malaysia said to plan arrest of Low and ex-Goldman banker Ng
summary: Malaysian authorities have issued arrest warrants for financier Jho Low, former Goldman Sachs banker Roger Ng, and two others, including Nik Faisal Ariff Kamil, in connection with the 1MDB scandal. The warrants are part of a probe led by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's administration, which aims to uncover the extent of the alleged multibillion-dollar fraud. Low, a central figure in the plot, has instructed his lawyers to cooperate with the investigation, while Ng's representatives declined to comment. The warrants do not necessarily imply charges have been filed, but demonstrate the government's determination to get to the bottom of the scandal.

site_title: Second jobs, once rare in Japan, are reshaping attitudes about work
summary: In Japan, attitudes about work are shifting as second jobs become increasingly common. Kazuhiro Hasegawa, a Tokyo taxi driver, has held a second job for three years but finds it insufficient to meet his financial needs, highlighting the growing need for multiple income sources. With Japan's aging population and shrinking workforce, this trend may become more widespread, forcing individuals to seek alternative means of supporting themselves and their families.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.39 points to 1,789.20. Volume was 54.39 million lots worth RM14.95 million, with 109 gainers outnumbering 63 losers.

site_title: Google won't use artificial intelligence for weapons
summary: Google announced Thursday it would not use artificial intelligence for weapons or to cause injury to people, setting seven principles for its AI development and use. The company will focus on socially beneficial applications, avoid bias, and ensure safety and accountability. Google will also avoid gathering or using information for surveillance violating international norms. The move comes amid growing concerns about the misuse of AI and follows criticism over a contract with the US military, which was not renewed.

site_title: UK starting salaries rise at fastest pace in three years, recruiters say
summary: UK starting salaries rose at the fastest pace in three years in May, according to a survey by the Recruitment and Employment Confederation (REC) and KPMG. The monthly gauge jumped to 63.4 from 60.5 in April, driven by a lack of candidate availability. This may boost the Bank of England's confidence that inflation pressure is rising. The survey also showed the weakest pace of permanent staff starting new jobs this year. Economists predict the BoE may raise interest rates to 0.75% in August to combat domestic price pressures.

site_title: India rate hike upsets Modi's election year budget maths
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) raised its interest rate by 25 basis points to 6.25%, the first hike since August last year, due to rising oil prices, a weakening rupee, and potential stronger consumer spending. This move is expected to push up borrowing costs for the government and companies, making it tougher for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government to borrow from the market ahead of the general election next year. Economists predict one or two more rate hikes this year, which could worsen the fiscal deficit and dampen revenue collection.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, SembMarine, Wilmar International, Citic Envirotech
summary: Sembcorp Industries has finalized a joint venture agreement with Ascendas-Singbridge and Amaravati Development Corporation to develop a 684-hectare startup area in Andhra Pradesh. SembMarine plans to spend US$28 million to acquire Sevan Marine's intellectual property, ending a long-standing dispute. Meanwhile, Wilmar International and Citic Envirotech are also noteworthy, but no specific developments are mentioned in the article.

site_title: Vietnam's second refinery to begin exports in June
summary: Vietnam's second oil refinery, Nghi Son, is set to begin exporting petrochemical products in June, with its first exports expected later this month. The 200,000-barrel-a-day facility, owned by Nghi Son Refinery and Petrochemical LLC, is running at 55% capacity as it undergoes a startup process. Once fully operational, the refinery will deliver 720,000 cubic meters of petroleum products and 150,000 tonnes of petrochemicals per month, reducing the country's reliance on refined product imports.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC downgrades ComfortDelGro to 'hold'
summary: OCBC Investment Research has downgraded ComfortDelGro to "hold" but maintained a 12-month fair value price of S$2.50, citing uncertainty over the taxi operator's plans to enter the private hire car space. ComfortDelGro's decision to terminate a proposed acquisition of Uber's car rental subsidiary in Singapore is seen as positive, freeing up S$295 million in cash consideration. The analysts also view a potential partnership with Go-Jek as a positive, which could lead to more booking jobs for ComfortDelGro taxi hirers and lower fleet idle rates.

site_title: Ride hailing firm Gett raises US$80m from VW, others
summary: Gett, an Israel-based ride-hailing app, has raised $80 million in a funding round valuing the company at $1.4 billion, with Volkswagen and Access Industries participating. This brings total funding to over $700 million. Gett expects to become profitable by the first quarter of 2019, excluding research and development costs. The company's New York City market, operating under the Juno brand, is its fastest-growing market. Gett bought Juno for $200 million last year.

site_title: Oil gains on Venezuela export cuts, Opec production levels
summary: Oil prices surged nearly 2.6% on Thursday, with Brent crude rising $1.96 to $77.32 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rising $1.22 to $65.95 a barrel, due to concerns over Venezuela's steep drop in exports and potential Opec production cuts. Opec's June meeting may not result in increased production, and Algeria's oil minister indicated a focus on balancing the market rather than raising production caps.

site_title: Argentina and IMF agree on US$50b loan
summary: Argentina and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) have agreed on a $50 billion loan over three years to support the country's economic plan, which aims to reduce inflation and budget deficits. The loan includes an immediate payment of $15 billion and will bolster market confidence, allowing the authorities to address long-standing vulnerabilities. Argentina's inflation target is set at 17% for 2019, 13% for 2020, and 9% for 2021, with the goal of balancing the budget by 2020.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB says Trump-Kim and 3,000 reporters a boon for hospitality
summary: Singapore is set to host the Trump-Kim summit on June 12, drawing thousands of reporters, which is expected to boost hospitality, services, and office sectors in the medium term. Despite this, hotel bookings have not shown significant increases or cancellations ahead of the summit. The Singapore International Arbitration Centre (SIAC) has seen a 32% year-on-year jump in new cases in 2017, solidifying Singapore's position as a preferred arbitration hub. The summit is expected to bring increased demand for business services, mainly in legal and consultancy services.

site_title: Amazon to livestream English Premier League in online shakeup
summary: Amazon has secured the rights to show 20 English Premier League football matches a season in the UK, starting from the 2019/20 season. The online retailer will exclusively livestream all 10 matches over a bank holiday period and another 10 during the first midweek fixture programme in December, available to Amazon Prime UK subscribers for £79/year or £7.99/month. This marks a first for the online sector in the Premier League TV rights market, breaking up the dominance of Sky and BT Sport.

site_title: Wilmar, OCBC peg interest rate on US$200m loan to sustainability performance
summary: Wilmar International has partnered with OCBC bank to link interest rates on a $200 million revolving credit facility to the company's sustainability performance. The deal, announced on June 8, 2018, pegs interest rates to environmental, social, and governance (ESG) metrics. Wilmar's sustainability targets, set by ESG research firm Sustainalytics, will be assessed annually, and interest rates will be reduced on a tiered basis if the company meets its pre-set targets, including biodiversity and greenhouse gas reduction programs.

site_title: US household wealth tops US$100t for first time
summary: US household wealth surpassed $100 trillion for the first time in the first quarter of 2018, according to the US Federal Reserve. This growth was driven by rising US house prices, despite volatility in stock markets. Real estate prices increased by $500 million, while household debt growth slowed to 3.3% from 4.6% in 2017. In contrast, consumer credit rose 4.2% and real estate loans rose 2.9%. The US government debt also surged 15.3% after Congress raised a borrowing limit.

site_title: Broadcom profit beats; expects wireless to remain weak
summary: Broadcom Inc reported a quarterly profit that beat Wall Street estimates, driven by strong demand for its networking chips and storage solutions from data centers. However, the company expects wireless revenue to remain flat or decline in the third quarter due to a decline in shipments to a Korean customer, likely Samsung Electronics. Despite this, Broadcom expects healthy demand from cloud data centers and enterprise IT. The company's shares were marginally down in extended trading.

site_title: Mumbai slums get colourful makeover
summary: Mumbai's slums are undergoing a colourful transformation with over 12,000 homes in four areas receiving makeovers. An organisation aims to change perceptions of deprived areas in India's financial capital, Mumbai, where 20 million people live. The project, involving volunteers, has turned homes into a vibrant visual spectacle, offering a fresh perspective on Mumbai's slums.

site_title: Japan confirms its economy shrank after two years of growth
summary: Japan's economy contracted by 0.2% quarter-on-quarter in the January-March period, marking the first time in two years it has slipped into negative territory. This follows a 0.1% growth at the end of 2017. Economists had expected a slightly higher contraction, but the revised figure confirmed the economy's negative territory. The contraction is attributed to a slowdown in various sectors, including manufacturing and exports.

site_title: Foreign property buyers target NZ's economic and scenic hotspots
summary: Foreigners purchased nearly one in five residential properties sold in downtown Auckland in the first quarter of 2018, with 19% of sales going to non-citizens. The majority of foreign buyers came from China and Australia. This surge in foreign ownership has sparked debate about the causes of soaring house prices in New Zealand, with critics arguing it contributes to the country's housing crisis. A law restricting foreign buyers is set to come into force later this year.

site_title: McDonald's plans US layoffs in cost-cutting move
summary: McDonald's plans to cut an unspecified number of US jobs as part of a restructuring effort to save $500 million and boost its US business. The move is part of a previously-announced plan to cut $500 million in spending by 2019. The company aims to streamline its management structure, with details to be outlined at a June 12 town hall meeting. This comes after McDonald's USA President Chris Kempczinski announced the company's efforts to better serve customers and continue to grow its business.

site_title: HNA to sell US building to Samsung for US$320m
summary: HNA Group sold a Minneapolis office tower to Samsung SRA Asset Management for US$320 million. The building, which houses Target Corp as its largest tenant, was sold for about US$5 million more than HNA paid for it less than two years ago.

site_title: US: Tech sell-off ends Nasdaq streak of records
summary: US stocks ended a three-session Nasdaq streak of records, with the Nasdaq Composite Index falling 0.7% to 7,635.07. Big tech companies including Google, Microsoft, and Netflix lost over 1%, while Chevron rose 2.8%, Apache jumped 5.5%, and Halliburton climbed 1.3%. The tech sector's recent outperformance is seen as a pullback, with investors rotating to other sectors. US stocks remain positive for the week, despite trade tensions and economic data concerns.

site_title: Spending pinch, royal wedding give UK shops worst May in 12 years: BDO
summary: British retailers suffered their worst May in 12 years, with turnover dropping 2.2% year-on-year, as shoppers stayed home to watch the royal wedding. The distraction, combined with changing spending patterns and increased competition from online retailers, contributed to the decline. This comes as retailers face store closures and job losses, with House of Fraser planning to shut 31 stores. Wage growth has eased some of the pinch, but it has had little impact on consumer spending on the high street, according to BDO.

images.alt_text: British retailers suffered their worst May in 12 years, a survey showed, hit by the distraction of a royal wedding for many shoppers but also underlining the changes in spending patterns that have contributed to a spate of store closures this year.

site_title: Going the distance in director development
summary: Singapore's regulators propose requiring first-time directors of publicly listed companies to undergo comprehensive induction training, consistent with many Asian markets. However, there is a need for clarity on continuing professional development for directors, as only 76% of companies provide training and the remaining 24% rely on directors to take care of their own training needs. Spending on directors' training is also relatively low, with most companies investing less than S$500 per director per annum. The Singapore Institute of Directors recommends a minimum of 20 hours of training per annum, and other director institutes have similar requirements, emphasizing the importance of ongoing education for directors.

site_title: What sort of welcome will visitors get in Russia?
summary: The FIFA World Cup in Russia is expected to draw over one million fans, creating logistical and cultural challenges for hosts and guests. The tournament has seen a significant increase in ticket sales, with the US, Brazil, and Colombia leading the demand. Russia has invested heavily in infrastructure, spending $13 billion, with a focus on providing an "unforgettable, colourful" experience for fans. However, concerns remain over accommodation prices, security, and the potential for racist incidents, particularly given Russia's laws on LGBTQ+ rights.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday; STI down 0.3% to 3,463.84
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.3% lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index down 9.24 points to 3,463.84, following a risk-off session in global markets. Losers outnumbered gainers 49 to 44, with 45 million shares changing hands. The decline was attributed to technology stocks retreating.

site_title: The hidden costs of 'America First' tariffs
summary: US President Donald Trump's "America First" tariffs have led to hidden costs, including increased prices for US companies and a potential loss of jobs. A small business owner, Bill Adler, lost a contract due to higher steel prices caused by the tariffs, which also led to a loss of investments and new jobs. Economists warn that the tariffs are favoring the first link in the supply chain, ultimately harming American manufacturing and national security. A study predicts that the cumulative cost of the tariffs will be a net loss of over 400,000 jobs.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Citic Envirotech secured a 1 billion yuan (S$209 million) environmental project in Anyang City, China, with a partner. Sembcorp Industries finalized a shareholders agreement for a joint venture to develop a 684ha startup area in Amaravati, India, with a 58% stake. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Porsche Club Singapore at 30: Still going fast and strong
summary: Porsche Club Singapore (PCS) is celebrating its 30th anniversary, coinciding with the luxury sports car manufacturer Porsche's 70th birthday. A charity gala dinner will be held at the Shangri-La Hotel on June 8 to mark the occasion. This event comes as Porsche turns 70 globally, with June 8 designated as a worldwide celebration day.

site_title: With no earnings upside, HPHT stays a dividend play: analysts
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPHT) has become a dividend yield play in Singapore following a major sell-off, but its long-term prospects are uncertain due to rising competition and an announced cut to base port tariffs in China. Despite this, analysts see HPHT as a stable option for investors. The trust's earnings growth is unlikely to bolster its share price, making it a tactical play for most investors.

site_title: Britain remains top European hub for tech investors: study
summary: Britain remains the top European destination for tech investors, with UK tech companies attracting nearly three times more venture capital investment than any other European country over the past two years. London tech firms account for over 80% of all venture capital money invested into the UK since the 2016 EU referendum, with major US companies like Amazon, Facebook, and Google increasing their operations in Britain. The UK capital has topped the European investment charts for funding into emerging sectors like Artificial Intelligence, cyber security, and Fintech, drawing global tech investors with its strengths in developing cutting-edge technologies.

images.alt_text: Britain remains the leading European destination for international tech investors, with UK tech companies attracting almost three times more venture capital investment than any other European country over the past two years, according to a study on Friday.

site_title: Indonesia strengthens laws against biopirates
summary: Indonesia strengthens its laws to protect its genetic resources, the second-largest in the world, worth $14.6 billion. The government has introduced a new Patent Law to prevent biopirates from commercializing local genetic resources and traditional knowledge. The law requires specifying the origin of genetic resources and traditional knowledge in patent descriptions to avoid claims by other countries. Indonesia has ratified the Convention on Biological Diversity and the Nagoya Protocol, and the government is concerned that foreign researchers are exploiting local genetic resources without consent or fair compensation.

site_title: Markets steady ahead of G-7 summit
summary: Markets in Singapore experienced a modest gain on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.15% to 3,473.08 points. The 1.7 billion shares traded saw 201 losers and 188 gainers. Ahead of the 44th G-7 summit, investors are expected to adopt a cautious approach, with some analysts advising a risk-averse strategy.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims drop as labour market picks up steam
summary: US weekly jobless claims dropped to 222,000, beating expectations, as the labor market tightens and inflation pressures rise. The labor market is considered close to full employment, with nonfarm payrolls increasing by 223,000 jobs in May and the unemployment rate at an 18-year low of 3.8%. Economists expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates next week, with some predicting two more hikes this year to prevent overheating. The strong job market has led to a worker shortage, with 6.7 million job openings in April and a decline in the number of unemployed people per vacancy.

site_title: Daimler fights Tesla, VW with new electric big rig truck
summary: Daimler AG unveiled an all-electric big rig truck, promising production in 2021. The German carmaker is challenging European and American rivals, including Tesla Inc. The truck, which will deliver 30 prototypes on two models later this year, aims to capitalize on global regulations to curb truck pollution, lower fuel costs, and maintenance advantages. However, challenges of cost, charging infrastructure, range, and payload constraints remain.

site_title: Whisky pilgrimage
summary: Scotland's whisky industry is experiencing a surge in tourism, with 1.7 million visitors in 2016, an 8% increase year-over-year. The country's 118 active distilleries, spread across five regions, are contributing to the industry's £4.37 billion export value. Key distilleries, such as Cardhu and Glenfiddich, are investing in new facilities and immersive visitor centers, while boutique distilleries like Bruichladdich are focusing on traditional methods and terroir. The industry's growth is expected to continue, with new projects and products being launched, including the Jura Sherry Cask Collection and Bruichladdich's new travel exclusives.

site_title: Astrea IV PE-backed bonds: Looking after retail investors' interests
summary: Astrea IV, a private equity-backed bond structured by Azalea group, offers retail investors a 4.35% annual coupon rate and a 5-year maturity. The bonds will be listed on the stock exchange and are expected to be rated A by Fitch and S&P. The portfolio comprises 36 mature funds with a weighted average age of seven years, and the structure includes safeguards such as a reserve account and a liquidity facility. While there is no guarantee, the issuer has run simulations of a hypothetical portfolio through four scenarios, with the majority generating sufficient cash flows to meet principal repayment.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Shortcut to Peru
summary: Peruvian chef Virgilio Martinez is set to open ICHU Peru in Hong Kong in July, marking his Asian debut. Martinez's flagship restaurant Central in Lima is currently No. 5 on the World's 50 Best Restaurants List. ICHU Peru will be helmed by Korean-born chef Sang Jeong, who has worked with Martinez for over three years. The restaurant will serve contemporary Peruvian cuisine in a bistro-style setting, showcasing traditional local ingredients and cooking techniques. ICHU Peru will be located on 3/F H Queen's in Central, Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: ICHU Peru.

site_title: Time for the spotlight
summary: At Baselworld 2018, luxury watch brands unveiled numerous high-end timepieces, including the Omega Speedmaster Dark Side of the Moon Apollo 8 and Patek Philippe's Nautilus Perpetual Calendar. However, lesser-known watches like Omega's Olympic Winter Games PyeongChang 2018 collection and Hublot's Big Bang Referee 2018 FIFA World Cup Russia received relatively little attention. Other notable releases included Glashutte Original's Senator Excellence Panorama Date and Moon Phase, Chanel's Boy Friend Skeleton, and H Moser & Cie's Swiss Alp Watch Minute Repeater Tourbillon. These watches showcase a range of innovative designs and complications, demonstrating the continued evolution of the luxury watch industry.

site_title: Story Of Fullerton Hotel - Theatre-Style
summary: The Fullerton Hotel in Singapore is celebrating its 90th anniversary with a theatre-style roving show, "Treasures of the Fullerton", featuring a cast of characters, including Auntie Rani, a housekeeping character played by Dwayne Lau. The show takes tour groups through the hotel's corridors and rooms, highlighting its history, including its role as Singapore's first finance minister Goh Keng Swee's former office. The hotel, originally known as Fullerton Building, was built in 1919 and has served as a hospital, Japanese military headquarters, and government office.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Making heads or tails of the penny crash
summary: BT's penny stock crashed in 2013 due to a series of missteps, leaving investors burnt. The company has now found answers, and investors can finally get closure. The article also covers other business news, including NTT DC Reit's oversubscribed Singapore public offer, Creative Technology's revenue concerns, and Indonesia's graft case. Meanwhile, OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, has a background as a former DBS veteran, marking a new era for the bank.

site_title: Toast to Charity
summary: Marcello, an Italian craft cocktail bar in Singapore, is participating in Negroni Week, a charity event that raises money for food banks. Until June 10, the bar is serving a bespoke Limonegroni cocktail, priced at S$18, with S$2 of every Negroni sold donated to Food from the Heart. This is part of Negroni Week, which was launched in 2013 to support charities globally.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
Marcello.

site_title: Smart tech poised to make cities cleaner and safer
summary: Researchers from McKinsey Global Institute found that cities worldwide can save hundreds of lives and lower carbon emissions by utilizing smart technologies like real-time crime mapping and intelligent traffic signaling. These tools can help reduce crime rates, commute times, and fatalities.

site_title: Euro rebounds to three-week high
summary: The euro reached a three-week high of US$1.1838, driven by comments from European Central Bank officials suggesting the ECB may wind down its bond-buying program by the end of the year. ECB chief economist Peter Praet and other officials signaled a possible tapering of the program, sparking optimism about the euro's potential strength. However, some analysts remain cautious due to concerns about a trade war and a potential hawkish Federal Reserve, which may limit the euro's upside.

site_title: House-price inflation in Asia 'under control'
summary: A report by S&P Global Ratings found that house-price inflation in Asia-Pacific nations is under control due to cooling measures and accommodative monetary policy. Mortgage credit growth has slowed, and prices have declined in some markets, including China and Singapore's public housing. However, Australia's residential property market has slowed, particularly in Sydney, and Hong Kong's market remains resilient despite stringent price-cooling measures. The report concludes that the region's property markets have remained resilient due to favourable economic conditions and an accommodative monetary policy.

images.alt_text: The report highlighted that public housing in Singapore is still undergoing 'mild price declines'.

site_title: Better sales likely despite dismal June launches
summary: Singapore's property market saw subdued sales last weekend, with several large projects launching simultaneously. Factors contributing to the slow-down include the school holidays, new pricing regimes, and intense competition among projects. Despite this, market watchers expect buying demand to remain strong, with transactions expected to pick up after the June school holidays. Analysts project sales momentum to roll over to subsequent launches if projects were spaced out. The market is expected to see increased options and attractive choices after June, with take-up rates largely dependent on pricing.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific delays IPO of Philippine unit
summary: Del Monte Pacific has delayed the initial public offering (IPO) of its Philippine unit, Del Monte Philippines Inc (DMPI), due to volatile market conditions. The IPO was initially planned to raise 559.5 million shares, valued at 29.88 pesos each, and would have allowed the company to prepay loans and strengthen its balance sheet. The company cited advice from bankers and advisers that it would be in the best interest to defer the offering until market conditions improve. The IPO would have generated a one-time gain of about US$304 million for the group.

site_title: Rate hike not meant to boost rupee: RBI
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) raised interest rates, signaling it's not aimed at boosting the rupee. Analysts say the move will support the currency, as India's restrictions on overseas investment in its bond market weaken the link between rates and the currency. The rupee snapped a two-day drop and ended 0.3% stronger after the RBI's decision, with some analysts predicting a consolidation between 66.50 and 68 to the US dollar over the next few months. The move bolsters the RBI's inflation-fighting credentials and provides comfort to international investors.

site_title: Low Keng Huat buys 3 plots in Cairnhill for S$100m
summary: Singapore-listed property developer Low Keng Huat's subsidiary Glopeak Development has entered into an agreement to purchase a 19,800 sq ft site at 67 Cairnhill Road and two adjacent plots for S$100 million. The site is zoned for residential use and could yield approximately 200 residential units if the sale order for the adjacent Cairnhill Mansion is approved. If not approved, the development could yield around 55 units.

site_title: Slow-burn mystery novel
summary: Singaporean novelist Clarissa Goenawan's debut novel "Rainbirds" has garnered awards and attention for its slow-burn postmodern murder mystery that explores the human heart. Set in 1990s Japan, the story follows Ren Ishida as he navigates a small town after his sister's violent death, becoming entangled in a web of mysterious dreams and characters. Despite lacking a traditional resolution, the novel succeeds in capturing the effects of bereavement and the search for closure, making it a unique and satisfying read.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Ultimate comeback kid
summary: The domestic manufacturing sector in Singapore experienced a strong turnaround in 2018, growing as a surprise growth engine despite the global economic downturn. This resurgence was driven by a cyclical upturn in major markets and structural shifts towards higher-value industries. The sector's transformation is also attributed to Singapore's move towards advanced manufacturing, giving it a new lease on life.

site_title: ECB pushes banks to pick new lending rate
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is urging banks to prepare for the end of key interbank lending benchmarks, such as Libor and Euribor, which are expected to be replaced this year. The ECB accuses banks of being complacent until regulators stepped up the pressure. The new system aims to prevent rigging, ensuring trust in financial data used to value assets and inform monetary policy.

site_title: The Bentley Mulsanne EWB is almost fit for a queen
summary: The Bentley Mulsanne EWB, a stretched version of the brand's flagship car, has been unveiled in Singapore with features such as aircraft-inspired rear seats, electric privacy curtains, and a refrigerated compartment. The extended wheelbase adds 250mm to the car, providing ample legroom for rear passengers. Priced at S$1.7 million, the EWB is comparable to the Rolls-Royce Phantom and is intended for clients who want to be driven frequently, but still enjoy driving the car themselves. The Mulsanne EWB boasts a 6.75-litre twin-turbo V8 engine producing 512 horsepower.

site_title: BMW M5 review: M for Monstrous
summary: BMW's M5, a high-performance sub-brand, has reached 600 horsepower, joining an elite club of cars with this power. The new model features a 25-horsepower increase, 70 Newton-metre bump in peak torque, and all-wheel drive for improved traction. While hardcore enthusiasts may lament the switch, AWD enhances control for lesser drivers, making the M5 easier to handle. Customization options, including pre-set settings, allow drivers to tailor the car's performance. The M5 also boasts impressive acceleration, with a 0-100km/h time of just 3.4 seconds, and can be further upgraded with the M5 Competition model featuring 625hp.

site_title: US lawmakers press Facebook over Chinese data sharing
summary: US lawmakers criticized Facebook for failing to disclose agreements with Chinese firms, including Huawei, to share user data. The company, led by CEO Mark Zuckerberg, defended its practices, stating that the contracts were standard industry practice. Lawmakers expressed concern over the potential for foreign espionage and the handling of user data, with some calling for further transparency and hearings. Facebook shares declined nearly 1% in response to the criticism.

site_title: Going green at Ganglamedo
summary: Ganglamedo, a Tibetan-inspired vegetarian restaurant in Singapore, offers a unique dining experience with its artistic installation and eclectic menu. The restaurant, run by a Singaporean chef trained in Tibetan cuisine, serves a range of small plates and hotpot options without mock or real meat. The chef's reinterpretation of traditional Tibetan dishes results in addictive condiments, refreshing side dishes, and robust broths, including a standout double-boiled Naqu cordyceps soup. While the dessert is unconventional, the meal is satisfying and leaves diners with a positive impression. Ganglamedo is a promising destination for those looking to explore vegetarian cuisine in a unique setting.

site_title: EPL scores big in Europe's football market: Deloitte report
summary: The English Premier League (EPL) achieved its "most impressive results" ever, with a 9% increase in revenue to 14.7 billion euros in the 2016/17 season, surpassing its nearest competitor, La Liga, by 86%. This reflects a new era of financial stability in the European football market, worth 25.5 billion euros. No EPL club has reported an operating loss, highlighting the league's financial stability.

site_title: Polish Vodka Museum to open in Warsaw next week
summary: Poland's first vodka museum will open in Warsaw on June 12, located in a 19th-century abandoned factory. The museum showcases the history of vodka production in Poland, which spans over 500 years, and features vodka tasting, with exhibits made from old vodka barrels. The museum is a tribute to Poland's role in the origins of vodka and will offer a unique experience for visitors. The museum's opening marks a significant milestone in the country's heritage and cultural tourism.

site_title: South-east Europe targets luxury brands' fast fashion catchup
summary: South-eastern Europe, particularly Bulgaria and Romania, is positioning itself as a hub for luxury brands to adjust to faster fashion cycles. Fashion houses from Paris and Milan are establishing a presence in the region, seeking affordable yet high-quality production. Companies like Armani and Moncler have already invested in manufacturing plants in eastern Europe, and many luxury brands are now looking for local producers to meet their growing demand for quick turnaround of styles. This trend is expected to grow 4-5% this year, benefiting local producers in the region.

site_title: Designer chic
summary: The 2018 Milan Furniture Fair showcased several designer furniture and home accessories, including the EDA-Mame sofa by Piero Lissoni, the Adda bed by Antonio Citterio, the Cambusa Glass wine cabinet by Riva 1920, and the Cestlavie furniture collection by GamFratesi. Other notable designs include the Enfold Sideboard by Thomas Bentzen, the Strap chair by Scholten & Baijings, the Tonbo coat hanger by Junpei and Iori Tamaki, the Birdie lamp by Ludovica and Roberto Palomba, and the Wohlert Bar Chair by Vilhelm Wohlert. These designs blend functionality with aesthetic appeal, making them ideal for modern homes.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Little Prince lives on
summary: The Singapore Philatelic Museum is hosting an exhibition celebrating the 75th anniversary of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry's classic children's book "The Little Prince". The exhibition features stamps and philatelic materials from 30 countries, unpublished illustrations, and personal belongings of the author. It runs from June 7, 2018, to March 17, 2019, with free admission for Singapore citizens and PRs. The exhibition explores the backstory of de Saint-Exupéry and the events in his life that shaped the beloved book.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Flying-car startup backed by Google co-founder is ready for test flights
summary: Kitty Hawk, a flying-car startup backed by Google co-founder Larry Page, unveiled its "Flyer" model for test flights. The electric aircraft features 10 small lift rotors for vertical take-off and landing, and is capable of speeds up to 32 km/h. Test flights began in New Zealand and will expand to the US, with no price specified for buyers. Kitty Hawk's CEO, Sebastian Thrun, described piloting the Flyer as easy as playing Minecraft, and the company aims to make flying accessible to more people.

site_title: Malaysia seeks Jho Low over 1MDB scandal
summary: Malaysia has issued arrest warrants for financier Jho Low, former Goldman Sachs banker Roger Ng, and two others in connection with a graft probe involving former Prime Minister Najib Razak and state fund 1MDB. The Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission is investigating allegations of wrongdoing, including the transfer of $10.6 million to Najib's bank account. The four individuals have not been charged with wrongdoing, but are expected to cooperate with the investigation. The warrants follow a new government's relaunch of the probe, which has alleged that over $4.5 billion was misappropriated from 1MDB.

site_title: Farm to table, Singapore-style
summary: Singapore's locavore movement champions the use of locally-sourced produce, with chefs incorporating ingredients from farms and suppliers across the country into their dishes. Chef Han Li Guang of Michelin-starred restaurant Labyrinth sources over 80% of its ingredients from local farms and suppliers, including goat's milk, silver perch, and quail. Despite challenges in scaling up production, a strong ecosystem of dedicated producers is emerging, with chefs like Ivan Brehm of Nouri and Oliver Truesdale-Jutras of Open Farm Community praising the quality and diversity of local ingredients.

site_title: China's solar firms urge government to rethink capacity cap, subsidy cuts
summary: Chinese solar firms urge the government to delay subsidy cuts and relax a cap on new projects, citing the sector's financial struggles. The firms, represented by 11 companies, claim the policy change will damage the industry, which needs another 3-5 years of government backing. The policy shift, announced by China's state planner, has sent solar stocks plummeting and prompted analysts to lower global installation forecasts. The industry is calling for a "certain grace period" for plants under construction and a re-evaluation of the quota system for renewable power.

site_title: Singapore 'will be top urban real estate market in Asean, regardless of Obor'
summary: A research report by Andrew Haskins of Colliers International predicts Singapore's urban real estate market will remain buoyant in 2018 with 10-12% growth in premium and grade-A office rents. Despite the cancellation of mega-projects in Malaysia, China's One Belt, One Road (Obor) initiative will still benefit investment sectors in South-east Asia, particularly Singapore, which is expected to retain its position as the top urban real estate market in the Asean region.

site_title: World Cup Action
summary: The upcoming World Cup 'live' show, Match Day, will utilize augmented reality to bring 3D animations, team formations, and player profiles to life. Presented by Richard Lenton and Steve Lai, the show will feature live feeds from stadia and expert analysis from Liverpool legend Ian Rush and former English national Darren Anderton, alongside three ex-professional-players-turned-pundits. Match Day will be available on various channels from June 14 to July 15, offering a unique viewing experience for fans.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
World Cup 'live' show.

site_title: Bank Negara governor's exit adds uncertainty to economy in flux
summary: Malaysia's central bank governor Muhammad Ibrahim resigned unexpectedly, adding uncertainty to the economy amid a period of significant political change. The departure leaves the Bank Negara Malaysia without a leader, and a successor has not been named. The government's decision to scrap a 6% goods and services tax has raised concerns about the impact on revenue and credit ratings. Analysts predict the next governor may adjust monetary policy, with some expecting a dovish stance, while others believe continuity is likely. The move comes as emerging markets face heightened volatility and the threat of a global trade war.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental hotel in London catches fire
summary: A fire broke out at London's Mandarin Oriental hotel on June 7, 2018, with around 120 firefighters responding to the blaze on the roof. The 12-storey hotel was evacuated, and no casualties were reported. Firefighters successfully extinguished the blaze, but the extent of the damage was being assessed. Insurers had been notified, and an update will be provided by the hotel's owners in its interim results statement. The hotel, which reopened after a major restoration, is located near Harrods department store in central London.

site_title: Deutsche Bank expects another quarter of falling revenue
summary: Deutsche Bank expects another quarter of declining revenue, with chief financial officer James von Moltke stating the lender will likely report a decline, "a little worse" than peers. The bank is scaling back investment-banking operations and cutting 7,000 jobs to focus on European clients and retreat from non-competitive Wall Street businesses. This marks the sixth consecutive quarterly decline in revenue, with the bank expecting "essentially flat" revenue for the full year.

site_title: India and Singapore: exploring the digital frontier
summary: India and Singapore have begun exploring the digital frontier, with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's visit to Singapore last week focusing on promoting digital financial connectivity between the two nations. The two leaders established a Joint Working Group on fintech, which aims to promote exchanges on best practices, encourage cooperation between fintech firms, and connect payment systems. They also launched India's RuPay card in Singapore and welcomed the acceptance of Bharat Interface for Money (BHIM) QR mobile app, marking the beginning of a productive fintech partnership. The partnership is expected to drive innovation and economic growth, with Singapore seen as a platform for India to internationalize its financial products.

site_title: As fuel prices rise, airlines warn of higher fares
summary: Airlines warn of higher fares due to a 50% rise in jet fuel prices over the past year. Delta Air Lines and American Airlines have cut their profit forecasts, with Delta planning to make decisions on capacity in the fall. Fuel now accounts for 17-22% of airlines' operating costs, down from previous spikes. OPEC is set to discuss oil production limits, which may impact fuel prices. Airlines may raise ticket prices, cut capacity, or reintroduce fuel surcharges, affecting international flights, business-class seats, and fees for ancillary services.

site_title: Answers finally for investors burnt by the saga in 2013?
summary: Singapore's High Court may hear arguments about "wash trading" and forced selling in a historic trial related to the 2013 penny stock crash. Three individuals, John Soh Chee Wen, Quah Su-Ling, and Goh Hin Calm, face over 370 charges for manipulating the stocks of Blumont Group, Asiasons Capital, and LionGold Corp, resulting in a 800% price increase before crashing. Prosecutors claim the defendants controlled 189 trading accounts and used wash trading to drive up share prices. The trial is expected to be one of the largest securities fraud probes in Singapore, with 67 witnesses and a scale rarely seen in market-related cases.

site_title: Rich moms, millennials make Canada a hot market for Rolls-Royce
summary: Rolls-Royce Motor Cars has found significant success in Canada, particularly in Vancouver, where the brand has seen a surge in sales. The country accounts for 10% of Rolls-Royce's sales in the Americas, despite having only 6% of the hemisphere's high-net-worth population. The brand's appeal to young, affluent Canadians, including super-rich immigrants, millennials, and women, is driving growth. With a growing appetite for luxury vehicles, Rolls-Royce is poised to continue its expansion in the Canadian market, with the company's CEO citing the country's "massively developing market" as a key factor in its success.

site_title: Singapore meeting brings former US secret envoy Pompeo centre stage
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo successfully navigated a historic diplomatic mission with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, setting the stage for a nuclear summit in Singapore. Pompeo's efforts have proven more productive than those of his predecessor Rex Tillerson, with whom Trump clashed. Pompeo's ability to interact productively with Trump and pursue a diplomatic strategy has raised hopes for a successful summit, which could lead to nuclear disarmament. Pompeo's experience, showmanship, and understanding of symbolism have also impressed lawmakers, with Senator Mark Warner expressing confidence in his preparation for the meeting.

site_title: Rental property site raises US$40m for expansion
summary: Spotahome, a rental property listing service, has raised US$40 million in funding from Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. The company provides detailed listings and software for landlords to manage multiple properties. This funding round aims to support the company's expansion plans. With its unique approach to letting people rent homes like hotel rooms, Spotahome is poised to grow in the competitive rental market. The funding will likely enable the company to expand its services and reach more customers.

site_title: Black Gold Hunting
summary: New South Wales is experiencing winter truffle season from June to August, with truffle hunting tours available in the Canberra/Snowy Mountain region. Visitors follow truffle dogs, who sniff out Perigord black truffles, and then help unearth them. After cleaning, grading, and weighing, a leisurely three-course truffle luncheon is served in rural surroundings. Truffles can also be purchased to bring home, with tours offered by Macenmist Black Truffles and Wines.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Europe: Markets rise in early deals
summary: Europe's stock markets rose in early deals, with London's FTSE 100 index increasing 0.5% to 7,751.39 points. The eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also rose 0.4% and 0.8% respectively. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks were in focus.

site_title: Can green bonds help power emerging Asia's fixed income markets?
summary: Asia's green bond market is still in its nascent stage, with few Asian banks and firms outside of China issuing green bonds. Despite growing interest from investors, the market faces challenges such as a lack of accepted standards and definitions, underdeveloped local bond markets, and a mismatch of scale between projects, bonds, and institutional investors. To overcome these hurdles, diversification of the green bond market, including expansion to new issuers and transactions in new currencies, is necessary. Additionally, governments and development institutions can support the growth of green bond markets by issuing sovereign green bonds, providing green bond financial incentives, and implementing carbon taxes.

site_title: On green financing, a lack of colour on required standards
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) emphasizes the need for clearer standards on green bonds to boost investor confidence. The region aims to attract $200 billion in green investments from 2016 to 2030, a five-fold increase. Ng Yao Loong, MAS executive, notes that more clarity is required in debt instruments to attract private capital. This comes as Southeast Asia seeks to capitalize on the growing demand for green investments.

site_title: Bayer closes Monsanto deal to cap US$63b transformation
summary: Bayer AG has closed its $63 billion acquisition of Monsanto Co, becoming the world's largest seed and agricultural chemicals maker. The deal, which was reviewed for two years, will double Bayer's agriculture business and enable it to "help the world's farmers grow more healthy and affordable food in a sustainable manner." Integration of the two companies is set to begin in about two months, with the combined unit based in Germany and the North American business led from St Louis.

images.alt_text: Bayer AG closed its US$63 billion acquisition of Monsanto Co, emerging from an arduous two-year antitrust review as the biggest seed and agricultural chemicals maker in the world.

site_title: Dear Dad
summary: Olympic gold-medallist Joseph Schooling has partnered with Hugo Boss as the brand's first Singaporean ambassador. A five-piece limited edition collection, featuring clothing and accessories, is now available in Singapore. Schooling is allocating 15% of the collection's proceeds to support aspiring athletes through the Schooling Sports Academy.

site_title: Bali Deal
summary: The Longhouse boutique resort in Bali's Jimbaran Bay has reopened as a six-suite-only luxury getaway after an extensive renovation. Designed by Indonesian architect Popo Danes, each suite features indigenous materials and handicraft, offering personalized attention from staff. Guests can enjoy various amenities, including a home theatre, infinity pool, and dining options. Prices start at US$190 per night, with a 20% discount for stays of three nights or more until December 31.

images.alt_text: The Longhouse Boutique Resort.

site_title: Picturing Hitler
summary: A Singaporean play, "Framed, By Adolf," explores a woman's claim that a painting owned by her Jewish grandfather was painted by Adolf Hitler. The play follows her attempts to sell the painting to various buyers, who race against time to validate her claims. Featuring a strong cast of veteran players, the production is a continuation of dramatist Chong Tze Chien's fascination with Hitler. The play is set to run at the Victoria Theatre from June 15-17.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Framed, By Adolf.

site_title: US clinches deal with China to resurrect ZTE
summary: The US has reached a deal with China's ZTE Corp, allowing the telecommunications equipment maker to resume buying parts from US suppliers after a 10-year ban. Under the agreement, ZTE will change its board and management, pay a $1 billion fine, and put $400 million in escrow. The ban will be suspended, but can be activated if there are any violations. This deal reverses a ban imposed due to ZTE's failure to comply with US export laws.

site_title: Scapegoating the EU won't fix Italy
summary: Italy's new populist government, formed by the Five Star Movement and League party, blames the EU for the country's problems, citing immigration and economic stagnation. However, experts argue that the real issue lies within Italy itself, including a slow asylum application processing system and inadequate housing. Italy's economic problems are also not solely the EU's fault, as the country's weak growth rate and high public debt are issues of domestic policy. A new government's demands for EU reforms, such as changing the Dublin Regulation, may not significantly impact Italy's share of refugees. Instead, stagnation is a more likely outcome, highlighting the need for domestic reforms.

site_title: Trump's trade war is mostly about politics, not economics
summary: US President Donald Trump's "trade war" is largely driven by politics rather than economics, according to an article. Trump's campaign to convince Americans that foreigners are to blame for economic problems is based on a seductive appeal to nationalism, which is mostly untrue. Trade deficits and job losses are exaggerated, and the US dollar's role as a global currency is a key factor. US multinationals invest abroad to serve developed markets, not just to exploit cheap labor. The article argues that Trump's policies are meant to turn foreign countries into a scapegoat, and that this misinformation has alienated allies and jeopardized worldwide economic growth.

site_title: Demand for American oil heats up as US keeps more for itself
summary: The US is increasing its oil production, sparking a bidding war for American crude among Asian refiners. Following spring maintenance, domestic refineries have restarted, boosting US oil demand. This shift is expected to make US oil cheaper compared to supplies from other parts of the globe, potentially reducing Asian refiners' purchases. The increased US demand is expected to stiffen competition, making it more challenging for Asian refiners to secure American crude. This change is driven by the US's own oil demand rebounding.

site_title: UK Court dismisses challenge to Northern Ireland abortion law
summary: The UK Supreme Court has dismissed a challenge to Northern Ireland's restrictive abortion laws due to a technicality, ruling that the Northern Ireland Human Rights Commission lacked standing to file the case. Despite this, the court concluded that the current law is incompatible with the European Convention on Human Rights, a finding that carries significant weight. The decision paves the way for further pressure on the Northern Ireland government to reform its abortion laws, which remain among the most restrictive in the UK.

site_title: New Lexus ES review: Strong, silent type
summary: The new Lexus ES is a strong and silent sedan that has improved its interior and driving experience. The car is 66mm longer and 51mm wider than the previous model, with a stiffer but lighter new platform. It features improved headroom and legroom in the rear, and a quieter ride thanks to increased sound insulation. The ES 300h hybrid model is particularly quiet, with a fuel consumption of 4.5 liters per 100km on average. The car also offers improved steering feel and agility, making it an engaging drive. The new ES is set to replace the GS and is expected to be a success in key markets.

site_title: It's Trump against the developed world
summary: US President Donald Trump will attend the G-7 summit in Quebec, where he will face isolation on key issues such as steel tariffs, Iran sanctions, and climate change. The meeting is expected to highlight the president's stance against the developed world. Trump's stance on these issues may further strain relationships with other G-7 leaders.

site_title: After dash to HK, Ron Sim aims to strike it right with V3 IPO
summary: OSIM founder Ron Sim is waiting for a better time to relist his company V3 on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, after its IPO application initially lapsed in June. V3's revenue has climbed above S$600 million and net profit has risen, with double-digit growth across all businesses. Sim aims to lead V3 into the live entertainment business, citing a need for innovative and engaging events, and is in talks to manage the Singapore Expo. A valuation of S$1 billion is being sought, with Sim indicating it may be higher than his initial valuation in 2016.

site_title: Lai Chang Wen
summary: Lai Chang Wen, 30, co-founder and CEO of Ninja Van, has led the logistics company to become a leading player in the region with operations in six countries. Ninja Van uses technology, such as mobile scanners and advanced route planning, to offer faster delivery. With a startup-like culture, Lai prioritizes innovation and efficiency, exemplified by his ability to multitask and address both micro and macro issues simultaneously. Under his leadership, Ninja Van has revolutionized traditional delivery processes, making it a prominent force in the logistics industry.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: KSH Holdings exceeded Q4 FY18 profit expectations, with full-year profit rising 19.1% despite revenue decline. Construction margins expanded, and upcoming launches, including Riverfront Residences and Park Colonial, are expected to drive earnings performance. Hutchison Port Holdings Trust's stock has surged 10.9% after a "buy" call, but the trust remains down 26.5% year-to-date due to various factors.

site_title: Shoot, squeeze and save at the Tokyo Toy Show
summary: The Tokyo Toy Show features a range of innovative and quirky gadgets, including the internet-connected cat-shaped device "BankNyan" that demands cash and calculates savings, and the "skid shot" pump-action toy shotgun with toilet roll pellets. Other exhibits include magic putty that changes color and behaves like a gooey substance, and a robot applauding companion for solo karaoke singers. The show, which runs until Sunday, attracts around 160,000 visitors and showcases cutting-edge technology from 200 toy manufacturers worldwide, including unique Japanese designs.

site_title: Mercedes-AMG E 43 review: Fast, but not furious
summary: The Mercedes-AMG E 43 is a high-performance variant of the E-Class sedan, offering a balance of speed and comfort. With a 401-hp V6 engine, it accelerates from 0-100km/h in 4.6 seconds and reaches a top speed of 250km/h. While it lacks the intense performance of the E 63 S, the E 43 provides a more accessible and affordable alternative for drivers seeking a luxurious and sporty driving experience. Its features include a Sport+ driving mode, 20-inch wheels, and a diamond-studded grille, making it a stylish and desirable option.

site_title: WCG to net A$147m in Australia sales proceeds
summary: Singapore-based property group World Class Global (WCG) expects to recognize A$147.3 million in sales proceeds from the first-phase handover of its Australia 108 skyscraper residence in Melbourne. This contribution is expected to positively impact its financial performance in the second and third quarters of 2018. The 101-storey freehold building is located in Melbourne's Southbank, near major attractions. WCG expects over A$251.1 million in revenue from the first-phase handovers of Australia 108 and AVANT. Buyer demand remains robust for the developments, indicating a healthy Melbourne property market.

site_title: Daily average value of securities traded rose 6% in May: SGX
summary: The daily average value of securities traded on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in May was S$1.34 billion, a 6% increase from April and May 2017. Total securities market turnover stood at S$28.2 billion, with S$3.53 billion traded on May 31, the highest daily value since 2013. The total market capitalisation of listed companies was S$1.02 trillion, with 102 new bond listings in May raising S$37.77 billion.

site_title: It may not be a trade war, but it could still be costly and dangerous
summary: US trade policy under President Trump has reignited concerns about protectionism and the potential for global trade wars. The US has imposed tariffs on aluminum and steel imports from European allies, and threatened to impose tariffs on Chinese imports, sparking fears of a trade war. This echoes the trade disputes of the 1980s between the US and Japan, which raised concerns about the collapse of post-World War II Western alliances. The current tensions highlight the risks of protectionist measures and the need for diplomatic solutions to resolve trade disputes.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 5.27 points, or 0.15%, to 3,473.08, driven by a 0.4% gain on Thursday, despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views. Losers outpaced gainers 201 to 188.

site_title: Big tech listings in China loom after release of final rules
summary: China has released final rules for a trial program allowing major tech firms like Alibaba Group to list on domestic exchanges, marking a significant step in bringing international companies back to the country. The China Securities Regulatory Commission unveiled the rules, which are largely in line with published draft proposals, and stock exchanges in Shanghai and Shenzhen will conduct broker tests in the next two weeks. The move is seen as a major push by the government to develop the local market and bring in international capital, with companies such as Alibaba, Baidu, and JD.com expressing interest in listing on Chinese exchanges.

site_title: Tour in Black & White
summary: A local tour company, Jane's Singapore Tours, offers exclusive tours of Singapore's colonial black and white homes, showcasing their history and architecture. Founded by native Brit Jane Iyer, the monthly tours visit three to four private homes, featuring unique stories and characteristics of each home. The tours have gained popularity, including winning the Singapore Tourism Award for Best Tour Experience, with a waitlist of participants. Iyer aims to highlight Singapore's cultural heritage, encouraging more locals, especially young people, to engage with their history and history.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.68 points to 1,785.81 on Thursday, driven by a higher volume of 4.1 billion lots worth RM3.2 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 597 to 357. This follows a broader regional trend, with Singapore's STI up 0.4% and US stocks reaching fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Asia: Markets push in with global rally with G-7 in focus
summary: Asian markets continued their rally on Thursday, driven by a strong lead from Wall Street and upbeat US data. The euro recovered from last week's decline, and the European Central Bank hinted at winding down its crisis-era stimulus. US indexes hit fresh records, with banks and exporters among the big winners. Investors remain optimistic despite simmering trade concerns ahead of the G-7 summit, where tensions between the US and its allies are expected to rise.

site_title: India's Modi to meet China's Xi for second talks in weeks
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi will meet Chinese President Xi Jinping for the second time in weeks on Saturday in Qingdao, China. The meeting comes after a tense border standoff and follows their agreement to maintain "peace and tranquility" at their borders in April. Modi's visit coincides with the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit, where China's Belt and Road infrastructure project is likely to be discussed. The meeting aims to strengthen ties between the two nations, despite a long history of mistrust and ongoing disputes in the Himalayas and the South China Sea.

site_title: Citic Envirotech secures 1b yuan environmental project in Anyang City
summary: CITIC Envirotech secures a 1 billion yuan environmental project in Anyang City, China, with a partner Fengzhu Textile Technology. The project includes a wastewater treatment plant, water purification plant, and production factory, among other facilities. The company will hold 90% of the project's shares. The project's design, construction, and operation will be undertaken by CITIC Envirotech.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise for sixth straight day
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for the sixth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.81% to 31,512.63. The rally was driven by a Wall Street rally and anticipation of the Group of Seven summit over the weekend. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.18%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.63%.

site_title: US reaches deal with China's ZTE that includes US$1b fine
summary: The US has reached a deal with China's ZTE Corp, allowing the telecommunications equipment maker to resume buying parts from US suppliers after a seven-year ban. Under the agreement, ZTE will pay a $1 billion fine, change its board and management, and retain a new compliance team. The ban was imposed in 2017 for violating an agreement related to Iran and North Korea. The deal is seen as a deterrent to other companies and does not affect ongoing US-China tariff talks.

site_title: Chinese equity traders bet US$3b on small-cap revival
summary: Chinese equity traders are betting on a revival of small-cap stocks, with US$3 billion in new assets flowing into funds tracking smaller companies. This influx of capital is driven by China's plans to encourage domestic listings of unicorn companies and boost market sentiment. Despite a downbeat market, small caps have held up better than blue chips, and investors are positioning for a potential rally in new-economy sectors. Policy makers have announced measures to support companies driving future growth, including a trial of Chinese depositary receipts and a new biotech trading venue.

site_title: Beyond a new CEO, a reset for CapitaLand?
summary: CapitaLand's new CEO may face challenges in addressing the company's struggles with return on equity (ROE). The hybrid business model, which combines property development with capital management, relies on efficient asset recycling. However, CapitaLand has been criticized for not recycling assets quickly enough, prioritizing scale over quality earnings. The company's decision to list and delist assets, such as CapitaMalls Asia and The Ascott Group, has also been questioned. Analysts suggest that a potential major restructuring, possibly including privatization or a merger with Mapletree Investments, may be necessary to address the issues.

site_title: Daily average value of securities traded rose 6% in May
summary: The daily average value of securities traded on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) rose 6% in May to S$1.34 billion, up from April and May 2017. This was largely driven by a high trading volume of S$3.53 billion on May 31, the highest since May 2013. Total market turnover stood at S$28.2 billion, with ETFs seeing a 18% increase and structured warrants and DLCs experiencing a 23% increase. The market capitalization of listed companies reached S$1.02 trillion, with one new Catalist listing and 102 new bond listings during the month.

site_title: US: Stocks opens flat, Dow slightly higher
summary: US stocks opened flat on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 45.75 points to 25,192.14. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also saw minor gains, despite a poor report from JM Smucker pulling down packaged food makers. The gains were attributed to a boost for technology firms following the lifting of a ban on China's ZTE Corp. The Dow's slight increase marked the fourth day of gains for the index.

images.alt_text: The S&P 500 opened little changed on Thursday after four days of gains, with a poor financial report from JM Smucker pulling down packaged food makers and countering a boost for technology firms from the lifting of a ban on China's ZTE Corp.

site_title: May resale prices for flats dip 1.8% y-o-y: SRX
summary: Resale prices of Singapore Housing Board flats rose 0.5% in May, but dropped 1.8% year-over-year, with a 13.1% decline since the peak in April 2013. The number of resale flats sold decreased 52% to 1,753 units, with some buyers deterred by the lack of eligibility for the Selective En bloc Redevelopment Scheme. Resale prices for larger flats, such as five-rooms and executive units, are expected to see greater demand in the coming months.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up on weak yen, Wall Street rallies
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index rose for the fourth consecutive session, gaining 0.87% or 197.53 points to close at 22,823.26. The rally was supported by a weak yen and Wall Street rallies. The broader Topix index also rose 0.64% or 11.42 points to 1,789.01. The gains came despite global market uncertainty, including US-EU trade talks and tariff concerns.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won gain on improved global sentiment
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.69% to 2,470.58, driven by improved global economic prospects and gains in steel shares. The won inched up 0.16% to 1,069 per dollar, while bond yields rose. The KOSPI has gained for a fifth consecutive day, with foreign investors buying 166.5 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Cooling measures and an accommodative monetary policy have controlled house-price inflation in Singapore and other Asia-Pacific nations. The Monetary Authority of Singapore partnered with IFC to boost the green bond market in Asia. HDB resale prices rose 0.5% in May, while Singapore shares closed higher, with the Straits Times Index up 5.27 points. In other news, Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.3% in May, and the UK economy shrunk for the second month.

site_title: Sembcorp, Ascendas-Singbridge formalise agreements to develop Andhra Pradesh capital
summary: Sembcorp and Ascendas-Singbridge have formalized an agreement with the Amaravati Development Corporation to develop a 684-hectare startup area in Amaravati, Andhra Pradesh's new capital city. The joint venture company, Amaravati Development Partners, will be developed by the consortium and ADC through a 58-42 stake split. The project will be developed in phases over 15-20 years, with a 12-month timeline to satisfy conditions precedent. The agreement was signed on the sidelines of a joint implementation committee meeting chaired by Singapore's Minister of Trade and Industry and Andhra Pradesh's Chief Minister.

site_title: M17 Entertainment prices US$60m NYSE IPO below range
summary: Taiwanese live-streaming company M17 Entertainment priced its US$60m New York Stock Exchange IPO at US$8 per share, below the initial range of US$10-$12. The company sold 7.5m American Depositary Shares and was seen as less attractive due to its non-Chinese status. M17 provides live streaming in six markets and reported a loss of US$26.9m for the three months ended March 31 2018.

site_title: Switzerland votes on whether to stop banks' money making machine
summary: Switzerland is set to vote on a proposal to strip banks of their power to create new money through lending, a practice known as "sovereign money." The initiative, which aims to replace this system with a "Vollgeld" system, would allow banks to only give credit to customers using funds from long-term deposits, the Swiss National Bank, or money markets. If approved, the law introducing "real money" would be written into the country's constitution and implemented within three years. The proposal has been opposed by the Swiss government and the SNB, but supporters argue it would reduce the risk of bank runs and give customers access to "full money" accounts.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon trading higher at 3,472.58, up 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading higher on Thursday afternoon, advancing 4.77 points to 3,472.58, up 0.1%. Gainers outnumbered losers 163 to 147, with Disa rising 10% and UOB up 1%. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data.

site_title: German industrial orders disappoint again in April
summary: Germany's industrial orders fell for the fourth consecutive month in April, with a 2.5% drop, according to official data. Analysts had forecast a 0.7% increase. Orders from the eurozone and Germany's domestic market declined, while foreign demand rose 5.4%. The slowdown in industrial orders, which is a key indicator of future economic activity, has raised concerns about the European economy, particularly amid uncertainty over US tariffs, the Italian government's spending plans, and Brexit negotiations.

site_title: Low Keng Huat acquires 67 Cairnhill Road and 2 adjacent plots for S$100m
summary: Low Keng Huat's subsidiary Glopeak Development has acquired 67 Cairnhill Road and two adjacent plots for S$100 million. The freehold site has a land area of 1,839.5 square meters and is zoned for residential use. This purchase comes after Low Keng Huat inked a S$362 million deal for an en bloc purchase of Cairnhill Mansion at 69 Cairnhill Road in February 2018. The site has an allowable gross plot ratio of 2.8 times.

site_title: Malaysia agency asks financier Jho Low to assist in probe at former 1MDB unit
summary: Malaysia's anti-graft agency, the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC), has issued a notice to financier Jho Low and one other individual to assist in the investigation into SRC International, a former unit of 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB). The probe is linked to transfers of RM42 million into the personal account of former premier Najib Razak. The MACC has resumed its probe into SRC International, which has been linked to corruption allegations involving 1MDB.

site_title: Remy Cointreau's profits boosted by China's thirst for cognac
summary: Remy Cointreau reported higher-than-expected annual profits driven by strong demand for its premium cognacs in China, boosting profit margins. The company's strategy of selling higher-priced spirits has delivered strong results, with operating profits rising to 236.8 million euros. Remy Cointreau raised its medium-term profitability forecasts, predicting a cumulative increase of 2.4-3.0 percentage points in current operating margin. The company's shares have risen 10% in 2018, trading at 38.6 times its 12-month forward earnings, compared to rival Pernod Ricard.

site_title: Buffett, Dimon say quarterly profit forecasts harming economy: WSJ
summary: Warren Buffett and JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon expressed concerns that the focus on short-term quarterly earnings forecasts is harming the economy. They argue that this pressure discourages companies with a longer-term view from going public, depriving the economy of innovation. The duo urged companies to move away from providing quarterly earnings guidance, which they believe is detrimental to the economy's growth.

site_title: HDB resale prices rise 0.5% in May from April; volume slips 5.3%: SRX
summary: Resale prices of Housing Board flats in Singapore rose 0.5% in May from April, according to SRX Property. Prices have dipped 1.8% from the same month last year and are down 13.1% since April 2013. Resale volume fell 5.3% to 1,753 units sold, down 52% from the peak in May 2010. Median Transaction Over X-Value (TOX) measures whether buyers are overpaying or underpaying, with some areas, such as Bishan and Tampines, showing demand and lower TOX values.

site_title: Australian shares end up on materials, banks; NZ hits new peak
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 6,057.3, driven by gains in material stocks and banks, while New Zealand's benchmark index hit a record high of 8,899.52. Top miners BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto led the gains, and Australian wealth manager AMP fell 5.6% after being served with its fourth class action lawsuit. US economic data and a weaker dollar also contributed to the gains.

site_title: London Stock Exchange opening delayed in rare trading outage
summary: The London Stock Exchange (LSE) experienced a rare trading outage, delaying its opening auction. The cause of the outage is unknown, but it follows recent issues with regulatory news announcements. The LSE operates one of Europe's largest cash equity markets and is a key player in the global financial industry.

site_title: Taiwan military drill repels 'invasion' as China tensions rise
summary: Taiwan held live-fire military drills simulating a Chinese invasion, repelling the "attack" with fighter jets, helicopters, and thousands of troops. The "Han Kuang" exercise, which began on Monday, reflects increasing military threats from China, which views Taiwan as a renegade province. Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen watched the drills, expressing confidence in her country's military capabilities. The drills come amid heightened tensions between Taipei and Beijing, with China having stepped up diplomatic pressure on Taiwan since Tsai took office.

site_title: Tokyo stocks open higher on cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by a cheaper yen, which fueled speculation about the European Central Bank's potential move to end its massive bond-buying program. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.49% to 22,737.66, while the Topix index increased 0.42%. The rally followed a 5-day winning streak for Singapore stocks, which were poised to report GDP data.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday, STI up 0.5% to 3,486.73
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 18.92 points, or 0.5%, to 3,486.73, driven by strong gains in banking shares on Wall Street. The market saw 93 gainers and 40 losers, with UOB and DBS leading the gains. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows recent positive market trends, with investors shrugging off trade war worries.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC Investment Research sees HPHT selldown as overblown
summary: OCBC Investment Research has downgraded its fair value target for Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPHT) to US$0.375, citing a short rally as overblown. The brokerage notes that while a 30% cut in Shenzhen port tariffs has hurt HPHT's price, the impact is less severe than initially thought. The tariffs target less than 2% of HPHT's throughput, and the brokerage believes fears of a complete halt in trade due to tariffs are unfounded. Despite this, OCBC maintains its "buy" call on the stock due to its high distribution yield.

site_title: Financier Jho Low to help in Malaysia's probe into 1MDB
summary: Malaysian financier Jho Low has agreed to cooperate with the country's anti-graft agency in its investigation into the 1MDB scandal. Low, who has been described as a central figure behind some of the schemes, has instructed his lawyers to make contact with the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission after being summoned for questioning. This move comes after US and Singapore investigators have portrayed him as a key figure in the missing funds scandal. Malaysia has enough evidence to proceed with its probe, with Home Affairs Minister Muhyiddin Yassin stating that stern and quick action will be taken.

site_title: More US staffers evacuated from China over mystery illness
