summary: The US State Department has evacuated more staff from China due to a mysterious illness affecting US diplomats, similar to a brain trauma diagnosis in an American employee in Guangzhou. The illnesses have also been linked to a similar incident in Cuba last year. US officials believe the symptoms may be consistent with those experienced by US diplomats in Cuba, and a medical team has been sent to Guangzhou. The US has set up a task force to oversee the response to the mystery ailments, with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo warning US diplomats to report any new symptoms.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Del Monte Pacific, TTJ Holdings, Raffles Education, Mandarin Oriental International
summary: Del Monte Pacific delayed its IPO of its Philippine unit due to volatile market conditions. TTJ Holdings posted a 27% net profit increase in the third quarter, while Raffles Education's A$82 million deal fell through. Mandarin Oriental International's London hotel suffered a fire, but no casualties were reported. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) closed 0.4% higher on Thursday, despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: MAS partners IFC to spur green bond market in Asia
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the International Finance Corporation (IFC) have partnered to boost the growth of the green bond market in Asia. The two agencies aim to raise awareness and knowledge of finance professionals on green finance issues and promote the use of internationally recognized green bond standards and frameworks. The partnership was signed at the IFC-Environmental Finance Green Bonds Asia Conference in Singapore.

site_title: SGX-Bursa link-up risks getting the chop
summary: The proposed link between Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Bursa Malaysia, aimed at offering investors a better trading experience, is on hold due to a review by Malaysia's new government led by Dr. Mahathir Mohamad. The project, unveiled four months ago, will be studied to ensure the Malaysian market is not affected. The government expressed concerns about the project potentially repeating the failure of a similar system, the Central Limit Order Book. The fate of the SGX-Bursa link-up remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Del Monte Pacific delays IPO of Philippine unit
summary: Del Monte Pacific has delayed the initial public offering (IPO) of its Philippine unit, citing volatile market conditions. The company had planned to offer 559.5 million shares, representing 20% of Del Monte Philippines Inc's ordinary shares, with an estimated maximum offering price of 29.88 pesos per share. The delay will allow the company to take advantage of improved market conditions and prepay loans, strengthening its balance sheet.

site_title: China publishes final rules for Big Tech listings trial programme
summary: China has published final rules for its Big Tech listings trial programme, allowing companies like Alibaba Group Holding Ltd to list on domestic exchanges. The China Securities Regulatory Commission unveiled the details, which are in line with published draft proposals. The programme aims to bring tech giants back home after most have listed in New York or Hong Kong to access international capital. The China depository receipts (CDRs) trial programme is a major step in China's push to revitalize its local market.

site_title: China Bearing gets another extension to meet criteria for Catalist listing
summary: China Bearing, a Singapore company, has received another extension to meet criteria for listing on Catalist, the Singapore Exchange's secondary board, until August 20, 2018. The extension is due to sufficient time needed to complete a proposed acquisition of FE Resources, lodge a circular with the Singapore Exchange, and convene an extraordinary general meeting. Shares in China Bearing have been suspended since December 21, 2015, and last traded at S$0.026 apiece.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks build on winning streak at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks extended a six-day winning streak, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.66% to 31,464.63, and the Shanghai Composite Index adding 0.19% to 3,121.18. The rally follows positive leads from Wall Street, despite uncertainty from US-China trade tensions.

site_title: China calls for public's help to catch overseas graft suspects
summary: China has launched a new website to encourage the public to provide information on 50 corruption suspects who have fled overseas. The suspects, suspected of corruption, bribery, or embezzlement, include 23 believed to be in the US. The website, available in Chinese only, provides English descriptions of their suspected crimes and where they might be living. China has previously released lists of 100 most-wanted fugitives, with 6 of the 22 suspects from last year's list having surrendered. The effort aims to enlist public help in bringing corruption suspects to justice.

site_title: Foreigners are snapping up New Zealand homes while they can
summary: Foreigners are rapidly purchasing New Zealand homes ahead of a proposed ban on foreign speculators buying residential property. In the first quarter, about 10% of home transfers in Queenstown and 19% in some Auckland suburbs were to non-New Zealand citizens or residents, nearly double the previous quarter. The government aims to address a housing affordability crisis with the proposed ban, which is yet to become law. Average home prices in Queenstown rose 9.6% to NZ$1.15 million, making it the most expensive place to buy outside of several Auckland suburbs.

site_title: Kate Spade was under treatment for depression, anxiety: husband
summary: Designer Kate Spade, who committed suicide in New York, had been treated for depression and anxiety for five years, her husband Andy Spade said. She was actively seeking help, seeing a doctor regularly and taking medication. This contradicts claims by her sister that Kate Spade needed mental health care but refused treatment due to concerns about hurting her brand.

site_title: Malaysia sets aside RM3b to finance fuel subsidies
summary: Malaysia's government has allocated RM3 billion to finance fuel subsidies until the end of 2018, keeping prices of RON95 petrol and diesel at fixed rates. The funds will also support the weekly floating of RON97 petrol prices. The move comes as Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's administration aims to cut the national debt, which he claims has reached RM1 trillion, amid rising oil prices and concerns over living costs. The subsidies will benefit consumers, but may increase the country's fiscal burden.

site_title: 120 firefighters tackle blaze at Mandarin Oriental hotel in London; no casualties
summary: A fire broke out at the 12-storey Mandarin Oriental hotel in London's Knightsbridge area, prompting an evacuation of the 200-room hotel. Around 120 firefighters and 20 fire engines tackled the blaze on the roof, which pumped thick smoke into the air. The fire was extinguished and there were no casualties, according to the hotel's management. The extent of the damage was being assessed, and insurers had been notified.

site_title: World first EPR nuclear reactor begins work in China
summary: A third-generation European Pressurised Reactor (EPR) in Taishan, southern China, has successfully carried out its first nuclear chain reaction, marking a world first for the technology. The reactor, owned by China General Nuclear Power Corporation and French state utility EDF, began operation after initial setbacks, including "local defects" in the deaerator device. Further testing and commercial operations are still pending, with Taishan 2 expected to enter service next year.

site_title: Spain's new PM unveils pro-EU government dominated by women
summary: Spain's new Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez has unveiled a pro-EU government with 11 female and 6 male ministers, the most women in modern history. The government, which Sanchez formed after ousting conservative Mariano Rajoy, includes EU budget manager Nadia Calvino as economy minister and former European parliament president Josep Borrell as foreign minister. The minority government relies on votes from far-left party Podemos and regional nationalist lawmakers, making its governing challenging. Sanchez's government prioritizes EU commitments and women's rights, with women leading the economy, justice, and education teams.

site_title: Flying car startup backed by Google founder offers test flights
summary: Kitty Hawk, a flying car startup backed by Google co-founder Larry Page, has unveiled a "Flyer" model for test flights, marking an exciting step towards sharing the freedom of flight. The company, created in Mountain View, California, has been testing a prototype in New Zealand and plans to offer the model to aspiring buyers. Kitty Hawk aims to revolutionize transportation with its innovative flying car technology.

site_title: Oil falls on US crude build; global supply seen rising
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday as US crude inventories rose 2.1 million barrels, surprising analysts who had forecast a decrease. Global supply is seen rising, with Saudi Arabia and other big producers considering an increase in output. US crude output hit a record 10.8 million barrels a day, prompting selling as global benchmark Brent climbed above $80 a barrel. The US government has unofficially asked Saudi Arabia and other Opec producers to boost output, which will be discussed at a meeting on June 22-23.

site_title: Trump attorney says Kim Jong Un 'begged' for summit: report
summary: US President Donald Trump's attorney, Rudy Giuliani, claims North Korean leader Kim Jong Un "begged" for a summit with Trump, saying Kim was willing to go to nuclear war but ultimately got on his hands and knees to request the meeting. The summit, rescheduled for Singapore, is seen as a turning point in US-North Korea relations, following a rapid detente between the two countries and South Korea. With the summit rescheduled, the US is perceived to have the upper hand, according to Giuliani. The summit is set to take place in a luxury hotel on Singapore's Sentosa island.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump's attorney said North Korean leader Kim Jong Un begged "on his hands and knees" for a summit with the US president, The Wall Street Journal reported Wednesday.

site_title: Amazon to create more than 2,500 jobs in Britain this year
summary: Amazon plans to create over 2,500 permanent jobs in Britain this year, bringing its UK workforce to nearly 28,000. The new roles will be in head office, research and development, web services, and operations. Amazon has invested over £9.3 billion in its UK operations since 2010 and has also announced plans for a new fulfilment centre in Rugby. Despite Britain's impending EU exit, Amazon remains committed to the UK, stating it will adapt as necessary.

site_title: Oil demand could keep growing until 2050 in conflict-ridden world: Equinor
summary: Global oil demand could peak in the early 2020s or continue growing until 2050, depending on countries' efforts to hit climate goals or the geopolitical backdrop. Norwegian oil firm Equinor predicts 59-122 million barrels per day by 2050, with the Renewal scenario aligning with the Paris climate agreement goal. The company plans to increase investments in renewable energy to 15-20% of total capital expenditure by 2030, as new investments will be needed to close the gap between declining existing production and growing demand.

site_title: Walmart, Visa resume lobbying battle over credit-card standards
summary: Lobbyists for Walmart and other retailers are teaming up with payment companies to push for more companies to have a say in setting standards for card security and new payment technologies. The Secure Payments Partnership, led by Doug Kantor, aims to counter Visa and Mastercard's control over swipe fees and card security. The group argues that retailers should have more representation in setting standards, while financial firms counter that retailers already have a voice in the process. The move is part of a broader battle over swipe fees, which US merchants pay banks annually to process credit and debit-card charges.

site_title: Daimler fights Tesla by unveiling electric heavy-duty truck
summary: Daimler AG unveiled an all-electric heavy-duty truck, the Freightliner eCascadia, with a range of up to 400km, targeting regional distribution and port shipments. The eCascadia will be produced in 2021. Additionally, the company introduced a medium-duty Freightliner eM2 106 with a range of up to 230 miles for local distribution and logistics services. This move challenges European manufacturers and Tesla, marking a significant expansion of Daimler's electric truck offerings.

site_title: Trudeau expects 'difficult' conversations with Trump at G-7
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau expects "frank and sometimes difficult" conversations with US President Donald Trump on US tariffs at the upcoming G-7 summit. The talks are likely to be overshadowed by trade disputes, following the Trump administration's imposition of tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from the EU, Canada, and Japan. Trudeau had hoped to focus on jobs, security, and women's empowerment, but officials acknowledge the agenda will be dominated by trade tensions. The US has refused to grant exemptions to Canada and the EU, prompting retaliatory levies and fears of a trade war.

site_title: Addvalue to sell data gathering services to 'premier global satellite service company'
summary: Addvalue Technologies has agreed to provide data gathering services to a "premier global satellite service company" until at least 2026, with estimated annual revenues of over US$40 million. This is on top of a previous contract for Inter-Satellite Data Relay System (IDRS) terminals, also with the same customer. The company's delivery for the IDRS Terminals is due to start this year, and it will be providing customized design and supply services. The customer's identity remains undisclosed due to non-disclosure agreements.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends at third straight record, shrugging off trade fears
summary: US stocks closed at a record for the third straight session, with the Nasdaq Composite Index up 0.6% to 7,687.03 points. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 gained 1.4% and 0.9%, respectively. Despite trade war worries, investors shrugged off concerns, with strong gains by banking shares contributing to the record highs.

site_title: Polish Vodka Museum opens in Warsaw next week
summary: The Polish Vodka Museum is set to open in Warsaw next week, dedicated to the country's 500-year history of vodka production. Located in a 19th-century abandoned vodka factory, the museum showcases the traditional recipes and methods used in Poland. The museum features five rooms with wooden staves from old vodka barrels, offering vodka tasting and highlighting the country's claim as the "cradle of vodka." The museum is a tribute to Poland's rich vodka heritage and its unique production methods.

site_title: Trump to stick to hard line on trade as G-7 showdown looms
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to maintain his hardline stance on trade at the upcoming G-7 summit in Canada, despite criticism from top allies. Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from Canada, Mexico, and the European Union have sparked a trade war, with Canada and Mexico retaliating with their own tariffs. The White House says negotiations are ongoing, but expectations for a resolution are low. Trump will meet with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and French President Emmanuel Macron, and the summit may be marked by "very, very frank conversations" between the two leaders.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump is not backing down from the tough line he has taken on trade, the White House's top economic adviser said on Wednesday, setting the stage for a showdown with top allies at this week's G-7 summit in Canada.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close flat after a choppy session
summary: European stocks closed flat on Wednesday after a choppy session, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index ending unchanged. The euro and bond yields rose after hawkish comments from the European Central Bank. Germany's DAX and London's FTSE rose 0.3%, while Paris' CAC 40 fell 0.1%. The session was marked by mixed market sentiment, with mining and healthcare shares supporting gains.

site_title: Freeport, Indonesia at loggerheads over mine's waste disposal methods
summary: Indonesia has changed the rules for Freeport-McMoRan Inc's Grasberg mine, requiring the company to operate by heightened standards for waste disposal methods, including the treatment of tailings in the Ajkwa River system. The move, which aims to reduce environmental harm, has sparked tension between the mining giant and the Indonesian government. Freeport has refused to comply, citing concerns over the economic impact of the changes, which could have far-reaching consequences for the mining industry and the environment.

site_title: Honeywell to make flying safer by decoding accents in India
summary: Honeywell International Inc is developing software to decode accents in Indian pilots' English, aiming to enhance air traffic safety in the country. The software, being implemented in India, will automatically transcribe pilots' speech for air traffic controllers. This move follows a fatal 1996 crash in India, partly attributed to a language barrier. The project is part of Honeywell's regional connectivity scheme and may be expanded to other parts of the world, where similar dialects are prevalent.

site_title: Shares in Thailand's Minor jump on debt financing plan for NH Hotel deal
summary: Minor International Pcl surged 7% after announcing plans to use debt financing for its takeover bid of NH Hotels, valued at up to $3.9 billion. The deal, Thailand's largest overseas hospitality acquisition, aims to expand Minor's presence in Spain, Benelux, Central Europe, and Italy. Minor will target 51-55% ownership, aiming to keep NH publicly listed and liquid, and will use bridging facilities for 18 months. The company's shares were valued at around $5.3 billion.

site_title: China publishes CDR rules allowing domestic listing of overseas firms
summary: China has published new rules allowing domestic listing of overseas firms through China Depository Receipts (CDRs), providing the "institutional foundation" for innovative companies to issue CDRs on the domestic market. The rules, effective immediately, will strictly control the size and pace of CDR issuance. The move aims to attract overseas-listed companies and provide a new financing channel for them, while also increasing the country's influence in the global capital markets.

images.alt_text: China has published new rules on the issuing of China Depository Receipts (CDRs) that will allow the domestic flotation of overseas-listed innovators, according to a notice published late on Wednesday.

site_title: US may need to adopt China's weapons to win tech war
summary: The US may need to adopt China's approach to innovation, as the country's government provides significant support to its tech industry, including funding and protection from foreign competitors. This is part of a "Made in China" plan to dominate key industries such as robotics, biotechnology, and artificial intelligence. American tech companies, including Intel, are urging the US government to take a similar approach to invest in and direct the industry. Despite having a technological edge, the US risks losing its innovation advantage if it doesn't adopt a similar strategy to China.

site_title: Singapore's new breed of farmer in Weekend magazine
summary: Singapore is witnessing a surge in artisanal producers and suppliers creating high-quality, locally sourced ingredients, driving demand for locavore produce among fine-dining chefs. These local farmers and suppliers are producing a range of products, including wild fish, farmed quail, and bespoke greens. The trend is not only enhancing the city-state's food scene but also creating new business opportunities, with logistics startup Ninja Van employing 1,000 staff members.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: AUSGROUP will conduct its second informal meeting with noteholders on June 18 regarding its S$110 million 8.45% notes due October 2018. Ezion Holdings reported one of its liftboats capsized in the South China Sea, but expects no material financial impact. Innopac Holdings received a letter from Saxo Bank seeking payment of S$14.69 million. BRC Asia secured 90.45% of Lee Metal Group shares and plans to delist the target company. Sinopipe Holdings' independent auditor raised doubts about its ability to continue as a going concern due to key personnel departures and accounting record losses.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank governor resigns amid overhaul by new govt
summary: Malaysia's central bank governor, Muhammad Ibrahim, has resigned amid a government overhaul by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. Ibrahim, 92, had completed less than half of his five-year term, and his departure follows a string of top official resignations. The new government, seeking to address suspected graft cases during the nearly 10-year rule of former Premier Najib Razak, has not yet announced a successor. Ibrahim's resignation comes after Finance Minister Lim Guan Eng suggested funds from a land sale to the central bank went towards 1MDB's liabilities, a claim Ibrahim had defended.

site_title: Indonesian central bank says no plan for capital controls
summary: Indonesia's central bank Governor Perry Warjiyo stated there are no plans to implement capital controls to support the rupiah during global market volatility. This comes as the country faces an outflow of funds due to rising US interest rates. The rupiah has been among the worst-performing currencies in the region, but the central bank believes emerging markets with sound economic policies should manage capital flows as part of macroeconomic policies. Bank Indonesia has raised its benchmark interest rate twice in two weeks to combat the outflows.

site_title: Dollar crisis on the horizon
summary: The US dollar's status as a reserve currency is under threat as creditors demand a depreciation of the dollar to buy US goods and services. The dollar's value has been overstretched, and creditors are seeking a higher yield or a cheaper dollar to invest in the US. This could lead to a dollar crisis, where the US is unable to meet its debt obligations. The rise of alternative currencies, such as the renminbi, and the emergence of a multicurrency international payments system could further erode the dollar's dominance. The US will need to adjust to a world economy vastly changed since 1945, with reduced influence over global markets.

site_title: ECB to debate ending bond buys next week: official
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) will debate ending its bond-buying program next week, with policymakers likely to decide whether to gradually unwind the purchases as inflation rises and the economy shows signs of growth. The ECB's chief economist, Peter Praet, signaled that the bank is pleased with the current inflation rate and may make a decision sooner rather than later. The decision is seen as a potential cut in stimulus, which could impact investors and the eurozone economy.

site_title: Bold 'open banking' concept prompts bigger questions on transparency
summary: Singapore banks are exploring the "open banking" concept, which involves sharing banking information with partners through application programming interfaces. The goal is to create more innovative services by allowing consumers to easily switch between banks and fintech companies. However, practical hurdles remain, including varied and hard-to-compare fee information, security concerns, and the need for standardized terms and conditions. Regulators are urging banks to be transparent about fees and service standards, and those that fail to do so may trail behind traditional peers and Big Tech companies.

site_title: As China bans foreign trash, S-E Asia profits
summary: China's ban on foreign trash has led to a surge in exports to South-east Asian economies, benefiting emerging markets such as Vietnam and Malaysia. The shift is a result of China's restrictive policies on recyclables, which have increased prices and costs for manufacturers. As a result, South-east Asian countries are now capitalizing on the reduced supply of recyclables, which were previously sourced from China. This trend is expected to continue, with South-east Asia potentially benefiting from a more sustainable and affluent future built on the recyclables that other countries no longer want.

site_title: Iran and North Korea: trick or treat?
summary: The US is using different approaches to address Iran and North Korea's nuclear programs. Despite their connections through Syria, Iran and North Korea have different proliferation records. Iran is a major regional threat, while North Korea has been accused of cheating in past agreements. The US needs to address the gaps in non-proliferation policies, including banning ballistic capabilities and nuclear weapons, and setting a time limit for high-grade nuclear enrichment. The current policy path, favoring immediate delivery and downpayment, is unlikely to lead to breakthroughs, and a change of behavior is necessary.

site_title: If Trump shoots himself in the foot, the EU doesn't have to
summary: US President Donald Trump has imposed tariffs on steel imports from the European Union, Canada, and Mexico, sparking a potential trade war. The EU has vowed to retaliate, but economists argue that this approach will harm European consumers more than US businesses. A more effective response would be for the EU to organize a "voluntary export restraint" (VER), where European producers increase prices and pocket higher revenues, rather than imposing tariffs. This approach would benefit both the EU and the US, and could be a more attractive alternative to tariffs.

site_title: Over 24m barrels of crude waiting to be shipped from Venezuela ports: data
summary: Venezuela is experiencing a bottleneck at its main oil port, Jose, causing delays to export over 24 million barrels of crude oil. Over 80 tankers are waiting in Venezuelan waters, with half of them to load crude and refined products for exports. The delays are attributed to low oil output and congestion at the port, prompting state-run PDVSA to install a new ship-to-ship operation to ease congestion. Negotiations are underway to determine who will pay for the costs of the oil transfers.

site_title: Microsoft expands programme for women returning to work after complaints of discrimination
summary: Microsoft is expanding its returnship program for women re-entering the workforce, following complaints of sexual harassment and gender discrimination. The program, part of its LEAP initiative, aims to hire women from non-traditional backgrounds and tap into untapped talent pools. The company received 238 internal complaints of harassment and discrimination from 2010 to 2016, leading to the firing of 20 employees. The new program will provide six- to eight-month contracts to 40 candidates in Vancouver, with the possibility of full-time offers.

site_title: Continental opens its third R&D building in Singapore
summary: Continental, a technology company and automotive supplier, has opened its third research and development (R&D) building in Singapore, aiming to enhance creativity and innovation. The facility, consisting of seven storeys, will boost employment figures with plans to hire over 500 new employees. The expansion is driven by growing engineering capacities, particularly in Asia, and will focus on emerging technologies such as intelligent mobility and mobility services. The new centre is designed to improve the working environment with innovative, inclusive features, and will have a diverse talent pool of over 20 nationalities.

site_title: Facebook says China phone makers given access to data
summary: Facebook has confirmed that Chinese phone makers, including Huawei, were given access to user data on the social network. Despite being deemed a national security threat by the US, Huawei integrated Facebook's services onto smartphones, with data stored on the device, not on Huawei's servers. Facebook also had deals with Lenovo, OPPO, and TCL of China. The company stated that data was accessed with tight limits and approved experiences reviewed by engineers and managers.

site_title: Ebola outbreak may open door to finding drugs that work
summary: A clinical trial is underway in the Democratic Republic of Congo to test five experimental Ebola treatments, with the goal of finding a cure for the disease. The trial, which began after 53 new cases were reported, will use hundreds of vials of untested medicines developed by companies such as Gilead Sciences and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals. The trial is challenging due to the lack of infrastructure in the region, but health officials hope it could lead to the first-ever treatments for Ebola, which kills about half of those infected.

site_title: Joel Robuchon Restaurant to close; only establishment in Singapore with 3 Michelin stars
summary: Joel Robuchon Restaurant, Singapore's only three Michelin-starred eatery, will close at the end of the month. Its sister outlet, L'Atelier de Joel Robuchon, will also close but may reopen at a different location. This marks the end of the iconic restaurant's presence in Singapore, with F&B players mourning the loss.

images.alt_text: French chef Joel Robuchon's restaurant, located within Resorts World Sentosa, was the only one in Singapore with three Michelin stars.

site_title: Brexit puts a ceiling on London housing demand, prices
summary: London housing prices are expected to fall by 1% this year due to Brexit uncertainty, marking the first annual decline in nearly a decade. The sterling's decline against the dollar has made properties cheaper for overseas investors, but buyer uncertainty remains. Forecasts for national prices range from a 6% fall to a 2.5% rise, with London prices expected to rise 2% nationally and 0.5% in 2019. Experts attribute the uncertainty to Brexit negotiations and a wait-and-see attitude among buyers.

site_title: More supply, rule change needed to solve executive condo crunch
summary: The executive condominium (EC) market in Singapore is experiencing a supply crunch, with a shortage of new units available for sale. EC prices have risen due to the shortage, making it challenging for the "sandwiched class" of households who aspire to own a new private property. The government has allotted three EC sites, but it will take time for these to be launched. To address the supply crunch, the authorities could consider doing away with the 15-month waiting period and injecting more EC sites into the market, which would help ease price pressures and meet demand.

site_title: Tianjin vows to fight property speculation despite growth woes
summary: Tianjin, China, is increasing scrutiny of home buyers and their eligibility to combat property speculation, despite the city's economic growth woes. The city's US$290 billion economy expanded just 1.9% in the first quarter, the worst among all provincial-level regions. Tianjin will monitor home buyer eligibility, increase oversight of property developers and real estate agents, and crack down on market behavior that could cause "panic." The move aims to control property speculation and artificially propped up prices, following similar policies in other Chinese cities.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Apac Realty has proposed to acquire a commercial property at Lorong 6 Toa Payoh for S$72.8 million, which will serve as the headquarters of ERA Asia Pacific. The acquisition is part of the group's expansion strategy and is expected to increase net earnings by 0.9% in FY18. Meanwhile, Venture Corp's share price has shed 25% since its April high due to cyclical concerns, but analysts believe the company remains a beneficiary of economic upcycle and secular growth drivers.

site_title: FEC International buys Royal Oak Residence for S$93m
summary: FEC International has acquired 21 Anderson Royal Oak Residence in Singapore for approximately S$93 million. The acquisition comes after two years of negotiations and marks the firm's intention to hold the site for investment before potential redevelopment. FEC will assume an existing bank loan of around S$103 million. The site, with a total gross floor area of 87,000 sq ft, was previously acquired by Blackstone in 2014 for around S$164 million. FEC aims to replenish its land bank, generate recurring cash flow, and expand its residential pipeline.

images.alt_text: Highest Reach Investments owns - through subsidiaries - the freehold, 34-unit site at 21 Anderson Road.

site_title: Qatar Air boss apologises for saying CEO job must be held by a man
summary: Qatar Airways CEO Akbar Al Baker apologized for comments made at a conference in Sydney, stating that the airline "must be led by a man" due to the challenges of the job. However, he later clarified that the comment was meant as a joke and not a serious stance on gender representation in the industry. Despite this, the comments sparked controversy and Al Baker defended his record of promoting women in leadership positions at Qatar Airways. The airline emphasized its commitment to gender equality and has a high percentage of female staff.

site_title: Ex-Temasek banker emerging as active fintech investor
summary: Ex-Temasek banker Francis Rozario has emerged as an active fintech investor, putting about $40 million into four early-stage fintech transactions. Rozario's private outfit, Asia Capital and Advisors, focuses on consumer finance and SME lending, seeing vast opportunities in the Singapore market. He believes fintechs can fill financing gaps for smaller businesses, but must stay disciplined and maintain "know-your-customer" standards. Rozario has also invested in StashAway, a licensed robo-advisor, and CCRManager, a fintech platform for trade loan sales. He advises banks to collaborate with fintechs to increase income and remains cautious on the payments sector.

images.alt_text: Mr Rozario says fintech can tackle gaps in peer-to-peer lending. Peer- to-peer lenders can mop up Asian SMEs' demand for financing.

site_title: Airbnb culls Japan listings ahead of new rental law
summary: Airbnb has suspended 80% of its listings in Japan ahead of a new law regulating short-term rentals, which requires owners to obtain a government registration number and meet various regulations. The law, set to take effect June 15, aims to boost tourism in Japan, hosting the 2019 Rugby World Cup and 2020 Olympic Games. Airbnb has welcomed the law, saying it removes uncertainty, while some hosts claim it imposes onerous requirements that favor the hotel industry, limiting stays to 180 days a year and allowing local governments to impose additional restrictions.

site_title: Indonesian central bank says no plan for capital controls
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor Perry Warjiyo stated that there are no plans to implement capital controls to support the rupiah during periods of global market volatility. The rupiah has been among the worst-performing currencies in the region due to outflows of funds from emerging markets to US assets. Bank Indonesia has raised its benchmark interest rate for the second time in two weeks to 4.75% to manage capital flows, but Warjiyo emphasized that this should not be a substitute for macroeconomic policies.

site_title: Acesian Star, Takenaka proceeding for arbitration over T4 dispute
summary: Acesian Star, a subsidiary of Catalist-listed Acesian Partners, is proceeding for arbitration with Japanese firm Takenaka Corp over a long-standing payment dispute relating to Changi Airport's Terminal 4. A writ of summons has been filed by judicial manager KordaMentha against Acesian Partners and other companies. The dispute began in 2014 when Acesian Star was engaged as a sub-contractor for air-conditioning and mechanical ventilation works in the T4 project. Acesian Partners disputes the claims made by the plaintiffs, stating there are no merits to the suit.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Three freehold plots up for sale
summary: Three freehold plots in Singapore have been launched for sale, including a high-rise residential redevelopment in District 9, a 75,479 sq ft site in the Newton/Novena enclave, and a 16,160 sq ft bungalow plot at 12 Broadrick Road. Elizabeth Towers, the largest, has a reserve price of S$610m, while Gilstead Court has a reserve price of S$168m. The plots are expected to attract strong interest from developers, with the Cuscaden Road government land sale demonstrating a trend of developers seeking prime sites.

site_title: Macron's dream of banking union out of reach
summary: European leaders are set to meet in Brussels to discuss the euro zone's monetary union, but progress on key goals, such as a European Treasury and a euro zone finance minister, appears unlikely. French President Emmanuel Macron's ambitious plans for a more federalist Europe are at odds with German Chancellor Angela Merkel's cautious approach, with Merkel's proposals for an investment fund and strengthening the banking union failing to address major concerns. The lack of concrete progress raises doubts about the credibility of a genuine banking union, and the potential for a crisis to force action.

site_title: China steel exporters chase buyers in Africa, South America
summary: China's steel exporters are shifting focus to Africa and South America as shipments to Southeast Asian markets decline by double digits, driven by US tariffs and anti-dumping duties. Shipments to top markets like Vietnam and South Korea have dropped by 20% since last year, with stiffer competition from Russia. Despite this, Chinese steel exports to Africa have surged, with shipments to Nigeria and Algeria increasing by 15% and nearly tripling, respectively. The US-China trade dispute is expected to impact Chinese steel exports, with China's direct exports to the US accounting for less than 1% of total shipments.

site_title: White House wants N Korean leader to commit to disarmament
summary: The White House is pressuring North Korean leader Kim Jong Un to commit to a disarmament timeline for his country's nuclear arsenal when he meets US President Donald Trump in Singapore next Tuesday. The US delegation, led by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, will not offer concessions, and Trump is prepared to walk out of the meeting if it doesn't go well. Trump is considering a follow-up summit at Mar-a-Lago if the meeting is successful. The summit's outcome will be determined by North Korea's willingness to disarm, with Vice President Mike Pence and Defence Secretary James Mattis absent from the US delegation.

site_title: More Hawaiian homes destroyed by lava flow
summary: A growing lava flow from Kilauea volcano has destroyed up to 80 more homes, bringing the total number of lost structures to nearly 200. The eruption, now in its 34th day, has surpassed the 215 structures destroyed by lava during the 1983 eruption cycle. The lava flow, 800m wide and 3-4.5m tall, has inundated subdivisions of Kapoho Beach Lots and Vacationland, with many homes feared destroyed.

site_title: UK banks face Brexit blow in France's tilt at MiFID rules
summary: France is proposing a rule change to tighten MiFID II regulations, potentially making life harder for UK banks after Brexit. The current equivalence rules allow non-EU companies to access EU markets as long as their regulatory regime is deemed equivalent. France calls this approach "inadequate" and seeks to require firms to set up a branch inside the bloc before serving EU clients. This move is seen as taking a tough line on the UK and may lead to job losses in the City of London.

site_title: Best performers in May were consumer discretionary stocks
summary: Singapore's consumer discretionary stocks led the market in May with a 3.1% capitalization-weighted total return, trimming the sector's decline in the first five months of 2018 to 3.9%. This was the first month since January 2016 that only three sectors generated gains in market capitalization-weighted total returns. The top performers were Mandarin Oriental (+9.6%), Genting Singapore (+7.7%), and Shangri-La Asia (+4%). The Straits Times Index declined 4.3% in May, with Genting Singapore being the second-best performer.

site_title: Global growth is set to ebb: World Bank
summary: The World Bank has downgraded its forecast for global growth, predicting a 3.1% expansion this year and 3% in 2019. However, growth is expected to slow further to 2.9% in 2020 due to tightening financial conditions and a potential global trade war. Emerging markets and developing economies are seen as particularly vulnerable to these risks, with the US Federal Reserve's interest-rate hikes and the prospect of a trade war between the US and China posing significant threats.

site_title: Faster, more accurate diagnoses and treatments at new cancer centre
summary: A new oncology centre, Advanced Medicine Imaging (AMI) Centre, has been launched in Singapore to address the rising cancer cases in South-east Asia. The 35,000 sq ft facility, valued at over S$100 million, is equipped with advanced imaging and clinical informatics systems to provide timely and accurate diagnoses and treatments. The centre is expected to help clinicians identify cancer early, resulting in better health outcomes and treatment cost savings. It is the first in the Asia-Pacific to house the Philips Vereos PET/CT scanner and will be operational by the end of next year, staffed by 100 employees.

site_title: China smashes steel gangs operating 4.8b yuan export scam
summary: Chinese authorities have detained 245 people in a nationwide raid targeting gangs that smuggled over 2.4 million tonnes of steel scrap worth 4.8 billion yuan (S$1 billion) to South-east Asia. The operation, launched after an investigation into unusual export activity, follows a similar case last month involving improper imports of waste products. The surge in steel scrap exports was linked to a government crackdown on low-tech steel plants using scrap, and customs data shows shipments rose from almost nothing in 2016 to 2.2 million tonnes last year.

site_title: STI dips 0.4% amid lack of direction
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.44% to 3,467.81, erasing Tuesday's gains, due to lack of direction. The tech sector's strength lifted Wall Street shares, with most regional exchanges rising. Losers outpaced gainers 232 to 173.

site_title: Euro rallies on talks of ECB ending stimulus programme
summary: The euro rose to a 10-day high after the European Central Bank (ECB) hinted at ending its stimulus programme by the end of 2018, citing rising inflation and a decade-long growth run. The announcement sparked a rally in euro currency, with the euro reaching a 10-day high. The ECB's decision to wind down its stimulus programme is seen as a positive move for the euro, which has been boosted by the bank's efforts to revive growth in the eurozone.

site_title: Ezion says Teras Lyza liftboat has capsized in the South China Sea
summary: A liftboat owned by Teras Lyza Pte Ltd, operated by joint venture company Ezion Holdings, capsized in the South China Sea on Tuesday while being towed from Vietnam to Taiwan. The unmanned vessel, carrying 75cbm of marine gas oil, is still floating upside down, with a towing tug nearby to ensure safety and prevent pollution. There have been no reports of injuries or casualties. Ezion Holdings is fully insured and expects no material financial impact, but will consider hiring a replacement vessel or building a new one.

site_title: Japanese 'drone-brella' is a flying sunshade
summary: A Japanese company, Asahi Power Service, has developed a drone-powered parasol, dubbed the 'drone-brella,' that can hover over users to protect them from the sun. The hands-free sunshade is set to be released next year and will initially target golfers and others who require a wider head covering.

site_title: SGX-Bursa link-up risks getting the chop
summary: The proposed link-up between the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Bursa Malaysia, aiming to provide a better trading experience for investors, has been put on hold by Malaysia's new government led by Dr. Mahathir Mohamad. The project, unveiled by the previous administration just four months ago, will now undergo a review before proceeding. The fate of the end-to-end connection remains uncertain, raising concerns about its future.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Co-working spaces to help EDB match talent, attract foreign firms
summary: The Economic Development Board (EDB) in Singapore is in discussions with co-working spaces, including US giant WeWork, to help match talent in technology fields and attract foreign companies to set up shop in the country. EDB aims to leverage WeWork's global network to court companies without a presence in Singapore or Asia. WeWork has expanded its presence in Singapore, opening its second space and planning to enter several regional cities by the end of 2018.

images.alt_text: WeWork's newest location in Singapore at 71 Robinson Rd has over 1,400 seats spanning 60,000 sq ft and features amenities such as game rooms and beer and microbrew coffee on tap.

site_title: Ascendas-Singbridge, Temasek to invest 20b rupees in Indian logistics, industrial centres
summary: Ascendas-Singbridge and Temasek are investing 20 billion rupees (approximately $398.24 million) in Indian logistics and industrial centers, focusing on cities like Mumbai, Chennai, and Bangalore. The investment aims to develop 13-15 million square feet of space through the Ascendas India Logistics Programme. This initiative is part of Ascendas-Firstspace, a joint venture between Ascendas-Singbridge and Indian real estate specialist Firstspace Realty.

images.alt_text: Ascendas-Singbridge and principal investor Temasek will together invest some 20 billion rupees (S$398.24 million) in projects in warehousing and manufacturing hubs in the key Indian cities of Mumbai, National Capital Region, Pune, Chennai, Bangalore and Ahmedabad, among others.

site_title: Kate Spade: Designer who defined an era
summary: Fashion designer Kate Spade, 55, was found dead in her Manhattan apartment, characterized by police as a suicide. She built a brand on accessible, stylish accessories that defined an era for American women. Spade's career began as an editor before she designed her first sketches from paper and Scotch tape. Her brand became synonymous with cute, clever bags that were an instant hit with young women, paving the way for female lifestyle designers like Tory Burch and Jenna Lyons. The fashion industry mourned her passing, with Anna Wintour calling Spade "a thoroughly American young woman who changed everything."

site_title: Honda to start selling HondaJet in Japan in 2019
summary: Honda plans to start selling its HondaJet in Japan by mid-2019, targeting high-net-worth individuals and aiming to double the country's business jet usage over five years. The six-seater jet has already received certifications in the US and Europe, and Honda has partnered with trading house Marubeni for domestic deliveries. Honda hopes the plane will enhance its brand image and transfer jet-engineering skills to future car models, with the jet business expected to become profitable around five years after its first full year of sales in 2016.

site_title: Shenzhen to cap private homes at 40% of supply
summary: Shenzhen aims to cap private home supply at 40% of total new apartments by 2035, with the remaining 60% allocated to government-subsidized housing projects for workers with special skills. The city plans to build 1.7 million new apartments, including ultra-low interest-rate loans for renters and 40% discounts for home buyers or renters under the talent scheme. This move aims to address China's under-developed home rental market and reduce speculation. The government's focus on affordable public housing follows President Xi Jinping's call for homes that "are for living in, not speculation".

site_title: China's trade with N Korea set to soar with Trump-Kim deal
summary: China's trade with North Korea is poised to surge if sanctions are eased, driven by a growing middle class in North Korea seeking consumer goods. Chinese businesses have already been exporting goods such as street lighting and mushrooms to the North, despite international sanctions. A recent deal between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un could lead to increased Chinese involvement in the North's economy, with China seen as a key player in any economic reset. China has been secretly helping the North with aid and money transfers, and is ready to extend its dominance over the North's economy.

site_title: Have we hit peak trade?
summary: Global trade has surged over the past 25 years, reaching almost 30% of the world economy, but growth has stalled in recent years. Trade in goods has plateaued, with the world possibly having hit "peak trade." This stagnation is attributed to increased complexity in manufacturing, with countries now importing more goods and outsourcing production. The slowdown in global trade growth has significant implications for economies and policymakers.

site_title: German watchdog orders recall of Audi A6, A7 diesel models
summary: The German motor authority KBA has ordered a recall of Audi A6 and A7 diesel models due to illegal emissions software. Approximately 33,000 vehicles in Germany and 60,000 worldwide are affected. Audi had already stopped deliveries of these models in Germany after discovering unspecified problems with emissions software. The recall is a result of a KBA investigation.

site_title: Credit Suisse paying US$47m to resolve US Dept of Justice's Asia probe
summary: Credit Suisse has agreed to pay a US$47 million penalty to the US Department of Justice to resolve a probe into hiring employees in Asia in exchange for government contracts and favors. The settlement resolves another legal issue for the bank, which has paid roughly US$13 billion in fines since 2008. The bank has made enhancements to its compliance and control functions and no criminal charges were brought in the case. This is part of a broader investigation into global banks' hiring practices in Asia, with others including JPMorgan Chase & Co and HSBC Holdings Plc also implicated.

images.alt_text: The settlement resolves another legal issue for Credit Suisse, which has paid roughly US$13 billion in fines since 2008.

site_title: Tesla's second 'Gigafactory' to be located in Shanghai
summary: Tesla is building its second "Gigafactory" in Shanghai, China, in partnership with government officials, to produce electric cars and battery packs. The move aims to localise production and make vehicles more affordable. Elon Musk stated that localising production to a continent level is crucial for the company's future. The Shanghai plant is part of Tesla's plans to have 10-12 Gigafactories worldwide, with another location in Europe expected to be announced by the end of the year.

site_title: ComfortDelGro taxi bookings up 9% y-o-y in May after Uber's exit
summary: ComfortDelGro taxi bookings rose 9% year-over-year in May, the largest increase since September 2014, after Uber exited the Singapore market. The company's cumulative bookings reached a two-year high of 12.1 million in the first five months of 2018, driven by marketing promotions and the removal of Uber's competition. The company's fleet of 13,000 taxis now holds a 60% market share.

site_title: Mayweather heads Forbes' sports money list
summary: Floyd Mayweather reclaimed his top spot on Forbes' annual list of highest-paid athletes, earning $285 million from his 2017 fight against Conor McGregor and endorsements. Mayweather surpassed Lionel Messi, who earned $111 million. However, female athletes failed to break into the top 100 for the first time since Forbes began publishing the list. Mayweather's earnings topped the rankings for the fourth time in seven years, while Conor McGregor rose to fourth place with $99 million in earnings.

site_title: Default risk in Asia on the rise as states allow failures
summary: Default risk in Asia is on the rise as states allow corporate failures, with China promoting market-driven pricing and India forcing large delinquents into bankruptcy courts. Five companies in the region have defaulted on dollar bonds this year, and S&P Global Ratings forecasts selective defaults in South-east Asia due to increased debt loads from conglomerate acquisitions. Higher refinancing costs and a weakening rupiah could lead to financial difficulties for weaker companies in Indonesia, and analysts predict a higher risk of default in the coming years.

site_title: TTJ profit up 27% at S$3m in Q3, revenue jumps 71%
summary: TTJ Holdings, a Singaporean structural steel fabricator, reported a net profit of S$3.05 million in Q3, a 27% increase from the same period last year. Revenue jumped 71% to S$28.66 million, mainly driven by the structural steel business. This growth is attributed to the company's expanding operations.

site_title: Five places where football fans can catch World Cup matches
summary: The World Cup is being held in Russia, and for those in Singapore, there are various venues offering live screenings of the matches. The Sports Hub in Kallang will host a free Festival of Football with a large outdoor screen and themed seating areas. The Marina Bay Sands has a rooftop club lounge with a 65-inch screen, but entry is subject to weather and fees. Other venues include Resorts World Sentosa, community clubs, and 22 McDonald's restaurants, all offering free screenings.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
An artist's impression of what the Resorts World Ballroom will look like during the World Cup, with seven big screens creating a 270-degree viewing experience for football fans.

site_title: Football cheats beware, the video assistant referee is watching
summary: A 36-year-old writer recalls the 1982 World Cup, where France was unfairly eliminated by West Germany after a controversial penalty shootout. The writer believes German goalkeeper Harald Schumacher should have been sent off for a horrific challenge on French player Patrick Battiston, which left him unconscious and injured. The writer reflects on the need for fair play in football, citing the introduction of the video assistant referee (VAR) rule for the 2018 World Cup in Russia, which aims to correct dubious decisions and ensure fair play.

site_title: Car COEs hit 8-year lows
summary: Singapore's car COE prices hit their lowest in eight years, with COEs for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp falling 4.1% to S$36,426. Commercial vehicle COE remained unchanged, and motorcycle premiums ended at S$7,001. Dealers expect prices to plummet after July 1 when fine particulate matter is included in an emission scheme. The drop is attributed to weaker demand due to the June school holidays and the absence of private-hire players like Grab and Uber.

images.alt_text: Christopher Tan

site_title: Deal for Raffles Education to sell Australia property for A$82m falls through
summary: A deal to sell a six-storey commercial building in Parramatta, Australia for A$82 million (S$83.5 million) by Raffles Education has fallen through due to disagreement over the sale terms. The property is leased to Raffles Education's subsidiary, Raffles College. This resulted in Raffles Education shares closing 0.6% lower at S$0.178 on June 6, 2018.

site_title: UK's Labour tries to force new single market deal, put pressure on PM
summary: The UK's Labour Party has proposed a new single market deal to force Prime Minister Theresa May to reconsider her Brexit strategy, putting pressure on her to stay in the EU's single market after leaving the bloc. The proposal, which Labour will put to a vote next week, calls for full access to the EU's single market, joint institutions, and regulations. The move aims to unite the party and set a clear direction for the economy, but has sparked conflict within Labour and criticism from the Conservative Party, who claim it undermines the referendum result.

site_title: A cornerstone of Singapore banks' digital transformation is the use of AI to enhance customer experience
summary: Singapore's banking sector is poised for technological disruption, with AI playing a key role in enhancing customer experience. Research indicates that 55% of respondents believe sub-optimal communication tools hinder agility and flexibility. Leveraging AI enables banks to provide personalized services, increase customer loyalty, and deliver high-quality service. AI solutions use historical and real-time data to personalize interactions and augment customer service agents' abilities. OCBC is the first bank to launch an AI unit, and industry experts predict that AI will determine the split between winners and losers in the banking industry, with Singapore poised to be a winner.

site_title: Freeport, Indonesia at loggerheads over mine's waste disposal methods
summary: Freeport-McMoRan Inc, a major mining company, is at odds with Indonesia over the disposal of mining waste in the Ajkwa River system. The company, which has been dumping tens of millions of tonnes of waste into the river for decades, is resisting increased environmental standards under a new contract. Indonesia has demanded that the company recover 95% of the waste, a move that could have far-reaching consequences for the company and the environment. The dispute highlights the complexities of the mining industry and the tensions between environmental concerns and economic interests.

images.alt_text: Freeport maintains that much of the sediment in the Ajkwa River system downstream from Grasberg is caused by natural erosion, and that tailings pose no significant or at least unexpected threats.

site_title: 'Proptech' firms angle for riches in US real estate
summary: Proptech firms are leveraging smart building technology to tap into growing data in commercial real estate, aiming to increase productivity. These startups use machine-learning algorithms, improved heating and cooling units, and data analysis to reduce energy consumption and optimize building performance. Investments in proptech firms have exceeded $2 billion, with companies like Rudin Management and Brookfield Property Partners experiencing significant energy savings. The industry is expected to continue growing, with companies like Energy Technology Savings and Honest Buildings providing smart building solutions.

site_title: India hikes rates for first time in 4 years
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), raised interest rates by 25 basis points to 6.25% for the first time in over four years, citing rising inflation concerns. Retail inflation reached 4.58%, above the RBI's target, driven by rising oil prices and increased consumer spending. The rate hike aims to rein in consumer spending and achieve the medium-term target of 4% inflation. The RBI also retained its growth projections for the fiscal year at 7.4%, but warned of geo-political risks and global market volatility.

site_title: Plastics still pose a problem for Singapore
summary: Singapore, known for its cleanliness, faces a growing problem with plastic waste, with its Semakau island landfill expected to be full a decade earlier than initially projected. The island was meant to meet Singapore's waste disposal needs until 2045, but recent estimates show it could be full by 2035. Plastic waste per capita has increased nearly 20% over the last 15 years, and recycling rates remain low, with only 6% of plastic waste recycled last year. The government has not adopted any bans or charges on plastic bags or single-use items, and has yet to set a date to become a "zero waste" nation.

site_title: Trump is making G-7 the toughest in years
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to attend the G-7 summit in Canada, where significant splits are expected among Western partners due to his trade and climate change policies. The US is isolating itself from key allies over tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, and Trump's agenda on Nafta and climate change may stymie Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's agenda. The summit may also address security and geopolitical issues, including the North Korea summit and the Daesh clampdown in Syria and Iraq, amid tensions with Russia and Venezuela.

site_title: Italy's new government to review TAP gas pipeline
summary: Italy's new government, led by the 5-Star Movement, is reviewing the Trans Adriatic Pipeline (TAP) gas pipeline, which is part of the Southern Gas Corridor. Environment Minister Sergio Costa has called the project "pointless" due to falling gas demand in Italy, citing energy policy and environmental concerns. A review of the project, which is valued at $7.05 billion, may create tensions with pipeline developers, including BP and Snam. The decision will be made by a special committee involving multiple ministers, with no clear timeline for a conclusion.

site_title: Russian central bank eyes assets of troubled banks' owners in return for bailouts
summary: The Russian central bank, led by Governor Elvira Nabiullina, plans to take control of assets from owners of troubled banks in exchange for bailouts. The central bank has spent over $40 billion to bail out three banks, Otkritie, B&N, and Promsvyazbank, recovering around $2.1 billion in assets from their former owners. The central bank aims to recover the remaining assets, including financial ones, to compensate for state bailouts. This move is part of the central bank's efforts to clean up the Russian banking system, which has lost half of its banks in the past five years.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher, Nasdaq ticks to another record
summary: US stock indexes opened higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones rising 54.16 points, the S&P 500 gaining 4.45 points, and the Nasdaq Composite reaching another record high at 7,652.81. The tech-heavy Nasdaq led the gains, driven by electric carmaker Tesla and insurer United Health. Despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and uncertainty, investors continued to push stocks higher, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records.

site_title: China smashes steel gangs operating 4.8b yuan export scam
summary: China has detained 245 people after a nationwide raid on steel gangs suspected of smuggling over 2.4 million metric tons of steel scrap worth 4.8 billion yuan (S$1 billion) to South-east Asia. Authorities targeted 65 gangs that were shipping scrap without paying the 40 per cent export duty. The raid was triggered by a sudden increase in the volume of iron and steel scrap exports, leading to suspicions of low-priced smuggling. The investigation aimed to curb the export scam and recover the smuggled goods.

site_title: Trump says Melania 'doing really well'
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that First Lady Melania Trump is "doing really well" following her recent surgery, despite her prolonged absence from public view. Melania underwent a "benign" kidney surgery on May 14 and was released from Walter Reed hospital on May 19. Trump criticized "Fake News" media coverage of her recovery.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares closed 0.44% lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index falling 15.35 points to 3,467.81. Trading volume reached 1.6 billion shares worth S$1.3 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 232 to 173.

site_title: Delta drags down airlines after fuel cost spurs cut to forecast
summary: Delta Air Lines trimmed its profit outlook due to rising jet fuel costs, citing a 12% increase in fuel prices since the start of the second quarter. The airline now expects second-quarter earnings of no more than $1.75 per share, down from a previous forecast of up to $2 per share. Other airlines are likely to follow suit, with Delta's decline being the sharpest on a Standard & Poor's index of five major US airlines. The airline will review seating capacity for the fall, with the industry still benefiting from strong travel demand.

site_title: Elon Musk wins vote to stay on as chairman, says Tesla 'quite likely' to meet Model 3 goal
summary: Elon Musk expressed confidence in Tesla's production capabilities, stating that building 5,000 Model 3s per week by the end of June is "quite likely." Musk attributed this optimism to the company's improved production lines, which can now produce 3,500 vehicles per week. This marks a significant milestone for Tesla as it works towards meeting its Model 3 production goals.

site_title: UK banks face Brexit blow in France's Tilt at MiFID Rules
summary: France is proposing a rule change that would make it harder for UK banks to operate in the European Union after Brexit. The proposed change would tighten MiFID II regulations, requiring UK finance firms to meet stricter regulatory standards. This could limit UK banks' ability to access the single market, posing a significant blow to their post-Brexit plans. The change is part of France's broader efforts to protect its financial interests.

site_title: Europe: Stocks cautious as commodities, tech stocks pull higher
summary: European stocks rose 0.1-0.3% on Wednesday, driven by gains in tech and commodity-related stocks, as investors shifted focus to global growth and lifted shares in cyclical sectors. Despite concerns over Italian debt and trade, stocks were cautious amid worries. The pan-European STOXX 600 index edged higher, while Germany's DAX and Britain's FTSE also advanced.

site_title: Macron wants "more ambitious" deal on euro zone - sources
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron is pushing for a more ambitious reform of the euro zone, which includes a common budget and banking union, than proposed by German Chancellor Angela Merkel. Macron has been calling for an overhaul since taking office, citing the need to prevent a repeat of the 2010-12 sovereign debt crisis. Merkel has agreed to some of Macron's ideas, but French officials say more work is needed to align their positions, particularly on banking union and fiscal capacity. Talks between Macron and Merkel are set to continue, with a June 28-29 EU summit on the horizon.

site_title: ECB to debate next week whether to end QE this year: Praet
summary: The European Central Bank will debate next week whether to end its 2.55 trillion euro bond-buying program this year, a move seen as a potential cut in stimulus. ECB Chief Economist Peter Praet's comments suggest the bank is pleased with rising inflation and may make a decision sooner rather than later. Policymakers are in broad agreement that the program should end, but ECB President Mario Draghi has avoided discussing a formal end date. The decision may come at the June 14 meeting or later in July, with analysts warning that the ECB may maintain flexibility and room for maneuver.

site_title: Alliance Mineral doubles lithium reserves at West Australian mine; tantalum ore reserves up 43%
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets has announced a significant upgrade to its lithium and tantalum reserves at the Bald Hill Lithium and Tantalum Mine in Western Australia. The company's lithium reserves have doubled and tantalum reserves have increased by 43%, supporting a mine life of nine years at current processing rates. The JV partners are reviewing options for expansion, citing strong market demand and superior economics, despite the need for further infill drilling.

site_title: EU-US trade row looms over Nato defence meet
summary: NATO defence ministers are set to meet in Brussels to approve plans to boost the alliance's ability to mobilize forces quickly in the event of a crisis. However, the meeting is overshadowed by a bitter row between Europe and the US over US tariffs and President Trump's decision to pull out of the Iran nuclear deal and Paris climate accord. NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg warned of "serious disagreements" among member countries, but insisted the "transatlantic bond" remains strong. The US ambassador to NATO, Kay Bailey Hutchison, also downplayed concerns, saying the strength of the alliance is not in jeopardy.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Malaysian stocks closed higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 21.99 points to 1,777.13. The market saw a gain of 716 to 267 gainers to losers, with a trading volume of 3.5 billion lots worth RM3.02 billion.

site_title: Record US exports narrow trade gap in April
summary: US trade deficit narrowed in April, driven by record exports of corn, soybeans, fuel oil, and petroleum products. Exports rose 0.3% to $211.2 billion, while imports fell 0.2% to $257.4 billion. The deficit with China in goods fell 9.8% in April, but year-to-date, it remains up 10.4%. The narrowing trade deficit may be less of a drag on GDP growth, but President Trump's trade policies continue to pose a challenge to global economies, with the European Union promising counter-measures by July.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's ComfortDelGro saw an uptick in bookings in the first five months of 2018, surpassing the same period last year. COE prices for cars and motorcycles dropped to their lowest in eight years. DBS Group Holdings priced US$750 million subordinated notes at 4.52%. A judicial manager filed a writ of summons against Acesian Partners. Malaysia's new government linked a massive financial scandal to a China-backed pipeline deal. Singapore shares closed 0.44% lower, while Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.3% in May.

site_title: Tycoon seeks to free millions of Filipinos from loan sharks
summary: Billionaire John Gokongwei's JG Summit Holdings Inc and financial-technology startup Oriente are investing up to $200 million over three years to provide digital loans to millions of unbanked Filipinos, aiming to combat loan sharks. The platform, called Cashalo, will offer loans of up to $127.19 with 2.95% interest and a 4% processing fee. The venture aims to hire 1,000 people and target 500,000 borrowers by the end of 2018, expanding on a market where 70% of adults lack bank accounts and many rely on loan sharks.

site_title: COE for bigger cars lowest in eight years
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices for cars and motorcycles have dropped to their lowest levels in eight years. Cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp ended at S$36,426, while cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp closed at S$36,000. Motorcycle COE reached a six-month low of S$7,001. Dealers predict premiums will plummet when a new emission scheme starts on July 1, making parallel imports less viable and easing competition for COEs.

site_title: Resources Prima Group hopes to submit resumption of trading proposal to SGX by June 28
summary: Resources Prima Group, a suspended Indonesian coal miner, hopes to submit a resumption of trading proposal to the Singapore Exchange by June 28. The group has been operating under severe cash flow constraints since its subsidiary PT Rinjani Kartanegara entered bankruptcy in October last year. Resources Prima Group is currently in advanced discussions with a potential investor to provide financing to the company, providing a possible path forward for the struggling coal miner.

site_title: Malaysia's new government considering replacing stock market chief: sources
summary: Malaysia's new government is considering replacing the CEO of Bursa Malaysia, the national stock exchange, with sources indicating that Tajuddin Atan's term is due to end in March next year. The move comes amid a series of top management changes initiated by the newly elected government, which is seeking to unearth suspected graft during the previous prime minister's tenure. Internal candidates are being considered, with an external candidate from Hong Kong also being considered, according to sources.

images.alt_text: Malaysia is looking to replace the chief executive officer of the national stock exchange, two sources said on Wednesday, the latest in a series of top management changes initiated by the newly elected government.

site_title: Innopac receives letter of demand on negative balances of accounts maintained by 2 subsidiaries
summary: Innopac Holdings received a letter of demand from Saxo Bank seeking S$14.69 million for negative balances under two subsidiaries' accounts. The Danish bank claims liability based on a 2013 Memorandum of Understanding, despite the subsidiaries' unguaranteed balances. Innopac's board has suspended trading of its shares and will evaluate the claim, pending resolution.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks chalk up five straight gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for a fifth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.53% to 31,259.10. The gains were driven by positive reports on China-US trade talks, boosting market sentiment. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, with the latter inching up 0.08%. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid ongoing US-EU trade talks, which traders are viewing as a positive factor for stocks.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei climbs to 2-week high on tech sector gains; Subaru down
summary: Japan's Nikkei share index reached a two-week high, closing 0.38% at 22,625.73, driven by gains in technology stocks. Kyocera, Alps Electric, and Nikon rose 0.6%, 1%, and 1.59%, respectively. However, overall gains were limited by concerns over global trade tensions and geopolitical risks. The market awaits the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting, which is expected to raise interest rates. Subaru Corp declined 1.4% after discovering new cases of product data fabrication.

site_title: Tycoon seeks to free millions of Filipinos from loan sharks
summary: Billionaire John Gokongwei is investing up to $200 million over three years to provide digital loans to unbanked Filipinos through his JG Summit Holdings Inc and Oriente's platform, Cashalo. The venture aims to give credit to millions who turn to loan sharks due to lack of access to formal banking services. With a digital platform, users can apply for loans online and receive money in convenience stores or pawnshops within 24 hours, offering a lower interest rate compared to loan sharks.
