Billionaire John Gokongwei, owner of the Philippines' largest snack maker and budget airline, and a Skype Inc founder will invest as much as US$200 million over three years to lend to millions of unbanked Filipinos.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,469.74, down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday afternoon, down 0.4% to 3,469.74. The Straits Times Index retreated by 13.42 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 185 to 123, with 643.2 million shares changing hands. Active stocks included DBS and OCBC Bank, while Genting Singapore fell 0.02 cents to 1.26 dollars.

site_title: Malaysian reports say Nor Shamsiah tipped as central bank chief
summary: Malaysia's local media speculates that Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus, a former deputy governor of Bank Negara Malaysia, is being considered for the position of central bank governor after incumbent Muhammad Ibrahim offered to resign. The move comes amid questions about the central bank's purchase of land from the previous government. Nor Shamsiah, who left the central bank in 2016, has a background in developing financial industry rules and strengthening the banking system. Details may be revealed at a post-cabinet briefing by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad.

site_title: North Korea's Kim turns from threats to hugs in diplomatic drive
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has shifted from threats of war to diplomatic efforts, with US President Donald Trump's spontaneity playing a key role in his sudden change. After a year of missile launches and nuclear tests, Kim declared his nuclear quest complete and began outreach to South Korea and China. He released American detainees, dismantled his nuclear test site, and halted missile launches, showcasing his diplomatic skills. The historic summit between Kim and Trump in Singapore is seen as a result of Kim's carefully orchestrated diplomacy, which will serve as insurance against US-led pressure if the meeting fails.

site_title: Malaysia draws China link to huge financial scandal
summary: Malaysia's ousted leader Najib Razak denied wrongdoing over a RM9.4-billion China-backed pipeline deal linked to a massive financial scandal. The new government described the project as "highly suspicious" and tied it to allegations of looting billions from sovereign wealth fund 1MDB, of which Najib was prime minister at the time.

site_title: Malaysia's new government considering replacing stock market chief: sources
summary: Malaysia's newly elected government is considering replacing the CEO of the national stock exchange, Bursa Malaysia, amid a series of top management changes. The position is set to expire in March 2019. No reason has been given for the potential replacement, and it is unclear if a decision will be made immediately. The move comes as the government seeks to shake up the financial sector, which has faced criticism for its handling of the stock market.

site_title: Facebook confirms data sharing with Chinese companies
summary: Facebook has confirmed data sharing partnerships with at least four Chinese companies, including Huawei, Lenovo, and smartphone makers OPPO and TCL Corp. The social media company said the partnerships allowed its users to access account features on mobile devices, but denied that data of users' friends could have been accessed without their explicit consent. Facebook is ending the partnerships with Chinese firms, including Huawei, as it comes under scrutiny from US intelligence agencies on security concerns.

site_title: Change a-brewing as health-conscious Brits snub booze
summary: Britain's drinking culture is shifting as health-conscious adults increasingly snub alcohol, with 57% of respondents in a 2017 poll saying they drank in the previous week, the lowest level since 2005. This trend is particularly noticeable among 25-44-year-olds, where the figure rose to 20.6% from 18.8% 12 years earlier. In response, the drinks industry is launching low-alcohol products, with sales of these drinks rising by nearly 28% in 2017. Initiatives like "Dry January" have also contributed to the trend, with five million Britons participating last year.

site_title: DBS prices US$750m subordinated notes due 2028 at 4.52%
summary: DBS Group Holdings priced US$750 million of 10-year subordinated notes at 4.52% interest, redeemable at par on December 11, 2028. The notes offer a call option to redeem in the fifth year, with the coupon resetting to 159 basis points over the prevailing US-dollar mid-swap rate if not called.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Wednesday, down 1.47 points to 1,753.67 at 9am, with 41.37 million lots traded worth RM15.5 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 90 to 48.

site_title: Malaysian reports say Nor Shamsiah tipped as central bank chief
summary: Malaysia's central bank governor Muhammad Ibrahim is reportedly offering to resign, sparking speculation that Deputy Governor Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus will be named as his successor. Nor Shamsiah, a former deputy governor, is among the candidates being considered for the role. The move comes amid questions about the central bank's purchase of land from the previous government, valued at US$520 million. Finance Minister Lim Guan Eng has called for an investigation into the land sale, which was made during Ibrahim's tenure.

site_title: TTJ Q3 net profit up 27%
summary: TTJ Holdings reported a 27% increase in net profit to S$3.05 million in Q3, driven by a 71% rise in revenue to S$28.66 million. The company's order book stood at S$195 million, with expectations to substantially complete orders by 2021. Gross profit margin fell to 21.9% due to differing project margins. TTJ also explored opportunities in waste management and treatment, including potential acquisitions. Earnings per share rose to 0.87 cents, and net asset value per share increased to 39.58 cents.

site_title: Honda to start selling Hondajet in Japan next year
summary: Honda will start selling its six-seater business jet, the Hondajet, in Japan next year, targeting high-net worth individuals and aiming to double the country's business jet usage over five years. The jet has been in development for over 30 years and received certifications in the US and Europe. Marubeni will begin delivering the jets in the first half of 2019, pending certification. Honda hopes the plane will enhance its brand image and improve future car models' efficiency and performance. The jet sells in North America, Europe, and the Middle East for $5.25 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat as trade worries weigh
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on June 6, 2018, due to global trade tensions and European political uncertainty. The Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.04%, while the Topix index rose 0.07%. Investors were also monitoring US-EU trade talks and the impact of US President Trump's threats on the market.

site_title: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust raises S$147.1m from preferential offering exercise
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) raised S$147.1 million from a preferential offering exercise, exceeding initial projections. The offering drew over 287.4 million valid acceptances and excess applications for new units priced at S$0.967 each. The trust's total gross proceeds from the offering, including an earlier private placement, now stand at about S$476 million. The new units will be listed on the Singapore Exchange mainboard on June 11.

site_title: Study warns of alarming decline in Australian fish
summary: Conservation experts warn of a 30% decline in Australian fish populations over the past decade, primarily caused by overfishing and climate change. A 10-year study by the University of Tasmania and University of Technology found a significant decrease in large fish species (over 20cm) and called for more marine reserves and better management to halt the decline. The findings contradict the nation's fisheries management organization, which disputes the results.

site_title: Australia Q1 GDP growth beats expectations
summary: Australia's economy experienced 1% growth in the first quarter, surpassing market forecasts of 0.9%. This brings annual growth to 3.1%, up from 2.4% in the previous quarter. The Reserve Bank of Australia kept interest rates steady at 1.5% due to uncertainty over household consumption and global trade. The strong GDP growth pushed the local dollar up a quarter of a cent, but investors expect policy to remain on hold for a long time.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.32% at open on Wednesday, building on a four-day rally, driven by a strong US economic outlook. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 31,191.51. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.16% and 0.07% respectively. Despite US trade tensions, investors remain upbeat, with the US stock market reaching fresh records.

site_title: China's ZTE signed preliminary agreement to lift US ban: sources
summary: China's ZTE has signed a preliminary agreement with the US to lift a 7-year ban on buying from US suppliers, allowing the company to resume operations. The deal includes a $1 billion fine and $400 million in escrow to cover future violations. ZTE agreed to replace its board and executive team, allow US site visits, and post calculations of US parts in its products on a public website. The Commerce Department plans to amend a 2017 settlement agreement, allowing the US to claim a total penalty of up to $1.7 billion. The deal has faced resistance in Congress, with lawmakers accusing President Trump of bowing to pressure from Beijing.

site_title: Tesla reveals plans to build cars in Shanghai
summary: Tesla has announced plans to build its second "Gigafactory" in Shanghai, China, to produce electric cars and battery packs. The company's head of worldwide sales, Robin Ren, revealed the plans during a shareholders meeting. This move aims to localize production and make affordable vehicles. Elon Musk stated that having a presence in China is crucial for the company's future, with plans to have 10 to 12 Gigafactories worldwide. The Shanghai plant is expected to be operational soon, with discussions with government officials having been "really great."

site_title: Philips, Singapore Institute of Advanced Medicine open oncology centre in Singapore
summary: Philips and the Singapore Institute of Advanced Medicine Holdings opened a new oncology centre in Singapore, providing specialized cancer treatment. The 40,000 sq. ft. Advanced Medicine Imaging (AMI) centre, built with a $100 million investment, features Philips' imaging and clinical informatics systems. It is also home to the first Proton Therapy Centre in Asia-Pacific, set to treat its first patient early next year. The centre aims to improve cancer diagnosis accuracy and provide timely treatment to the growing number of cancer patients in South-east Asia.

site_title: South-east Asia's plastic addiction is blighting world's oceans
summary: The United Nations has called for a global cleanup of plastic pollution, with South-east Asia, home to four of the world's top marine plastic polluters, facing significant challenges. Thailand, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Vietnam are among the top plastic polluters globally, with the region producing eight million tonnes of plastic waste entering the ocean each year. Despite some governments recognizing the impact of plastic waste, progress remains slow, with companies and citizens also playing a crucial role in addressing the issue.

site_title: Rescuers save 23 workers trapped in China mine, 11 others dead
summary: Rescuers in northeast China pulled 23 workers from a mine 11 hours after an explosion killed 11 and left two missing. The blast occurred when miners dropped explosives, destroying the hoisting system. Nine other workers were injured. The incident occurred at an iron ore mine owned by Huamei Group in Benxi, Liaoning province.

images.alt_text: Rescuers pulled 23 workers out of a mine in northeast China on Wednesday, hours after they were trapped underground by an explosion that killed 11 and left two others missing, state media reported.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Straits Trading, CFM Holdings, Ramba Energy
summary: The Straits Trading Company will invest in a Japanese fund via its subsidiary, committing up to S$97.4 million. CFM Holdings' subsidiary is selling 99.99% of its Malaysian unit for an undisclosed price. These developments may impact trading of their shares.

site_title: NUS Enterprise inks MOUs to expand support for Singapore startups
summary: NUS Enterprise has signed four memoranda of understanding (MOUs) with international partners to expand support for Singapore startups. The partnerships include Innospace, Rainmaking Innovation, Wärtsilä, and Wilhelmsen, focusing on maritime and logistics sectors. The MOUs aim to attract and anchor venture-building activities, provide mentorship, and develop solutions for the shipping industry. The partnerships are part of the Port Innovation Ecosystem Reimagined @ Block71 (PIER71) program, launched by NUS Enterprise and the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore.

site_title: Australian winemakers urge PM to mend fences with China
summary: Australian winemakers are urging Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull to visit China to resolve trade restrictions triggered by a diplomatic rift. The restrictions have delayed wine imports worth A$848 million, causing frustration among industry leaders. Treasury Wine Estates, the world's largest-listed winemaker, has seen its share price drop 9% since the delays. The industry is concerned about the prolonged impasse, which could impact their business and relationships with China, an important strategic partner.

site_title: Ascendas-Singbridge, Temasek to invest 20b rupees in Indian logistics and industrial centres
summary: Ascendas-Singbridge and Temasek will invest 20 billion rupees (S$398.24 million) in Indian logistics and industrial projects in cities like Mumbai, National Capital Region, and Ahmedabad. The initiative aims to develop 13-15 million square feet of space and is part of the Ascendas India Logistics Programme, which has two seed assets with operational and development potential. The investment is seen as a response to India's growing middle-income population and the country's "Make in India" vision, with the goal of supporting economic growth through high-quality logistics and industrial facilities.

site_title: ComfortDelGro sees uptick in bookings
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singapore-listed taxi giant, reported a 9% year-on-year increase in bookings in May 2018, the largest jump since September 2014. The uptick is attributed to Uber's exit from the region and ComfortDelGro's marketing promotions, including discounted fares and weekly incentives for cabbies. The company's taxi arm operates 13,000 taxis in Singapore, with a 60% market share, and recently ordered another 700 taxis.

site_title: Lee Metal to be suspended as BRC Asia's control hits 90.45%
summary: BRC Asia has secured 90.45% of Lee Metal Group's shares, meeting the requirement to gain control of the company. The steel prefabrication company will proceed with plans to delist Lee Metal and suspend trading due to the low public float. The offer price is 42 Singapore cents per share, and BRC Asia plans to maintain Lee Metal's business and retain existing employees. The deadline for accepting the offer remains June 21, and trading will be suspended at the close of the offer.

site_title: CFM Holdings disposes of units CFM Precision, PT Hantong for S$1
summary: CFM Holdings announced the disposal of 99.99% of its share capital in Malaysian subsidiary CFM Precision Tooling Sdn Bhd for S$1. CFM Precision will cease to be a subsidiary, and as a result, CFM Holdings will also lose its indirect interest in PT Hantong Precision Manufacturing Batam. The disposal was made through a sale and purchase agreement between CFM Precision and CFM CEO Janet Lim.

site_title: Additional judicial manager files writ of summons against Acesian Partners
summary: A judicial manager of Acesian Partners' subsidiary, Muk Siew Peng, has filed a writ of summons against the company, its private-owned subsidiary Acesian Engineering and Active Building Technologies, and four key employees in Singapore's High Court. This move is part of the judicial management of Acesian Star (S) Pte Ltd. The writ of summons was served on Monday.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Wednesday; STI up 0.02% to 3,483.95
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened flat on Wednesday, rising 0.02% to 3,483.95, with gains outnumbering losses 69-44. Trading volume reached 31.9 million shares worth S$86.1 million.

site_title: Indonesia's coming digital disruption
summary: Indonesia's digital economy is expected to boom, expanding from $1 trillion in 2017 to $2.7 trillion by 2027. Online retail is projected to increase 14-fold, while e-money adoption is expected to rise from 2% to 24% of transactions. Fintech solutions, such as peer-to-peer lending, are emerging to address the unbanked population. The government's infrastructure push and regulatory roadmap are supporting growth, with capital available to fund startups. However, disruption is a risk, particularly in retail, banking, and real estate, with potential losses for offline businesses, banks, and shopping malls.

site_title: Twitter shares jump 5% as they win new follower: The S&P 500
summary: Twitter shares jumped 5% after the company was added to the S&P 500 US index, with its stock price reaching a three-year high of $40.16. The addition, which replaces Monsanto Co, gives Twitter prominence as a platform for US President Donald Trump and celebrities, with over 330 million monthly active users. The move is expected to put pressure on the company to report solid results, with investors now required to own Twitter stock.

site_title: US designer Kate Spade dead at 55 in apparent suicide
summary: Designer Kate Spade, 55, was found dead in her New York apartment after committing suicide, with a note left behind. A fashion icon known for her sleek handbags and playful style, Spade's death has sparked tributes from the fashion world and everyday women who admired her. Her family requested privacy, and her legacy has been hailed by the Council of Fashion Designers of America, with many calling for greater awareness and support for mental health.

images.alt_text: Designer Kate Spade, one of the biggest names in American fashion especially known for her sleek handbags, was found dead on Tuesday in her New York apartment after committing suicide. She was 55.

site_title: Trump fires aide who joked about 'dying' war hero John McCain
summary: US President Donald Trump has fired an aide who made a derogatory comment about war hero John McCain, saying McCain's opposition to a presidential nominee didn't matter because "he's dying anyway". The comment was made by Kelly Sadler, a White House aide, during a staff meeting in May. The White House described the remark as unacceptable and Sadler is no longer employed. The comments sparked bipartisan outrage and criticism from lawmakers, with McCain's family and colleagues defending his character and legacy.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump has sacked an aide who said cancer-stricken Senator John McCain's opposition to a presidential nominee did not matter because "he's dying anyway", the White House announced on Tuesday.

site_title: Qatar says it wants to join NATO
summary: Qatar's defence minister, Khalid bin Mohamed Al-Attiyah, announced the country's long-term strategic ambition to join the Western military defence alliance NATO. This comes on the anniversary of a year-long diplomatic dispute with regional allies. Al-Attiyah stated Qatar's desire to become a full member of the 29-country alliance, citing its significant armament capabilities. The move could potentially alter the regional balance of power.

site_title: Improvement in financial results due to continuing operations, not disposals: Annica
summary: Investment firm Annica Holdings has denied claims by the Singapore Exchange that its 2017 loss was largely due to the sale of loss-making operations. Instead, Annica attributes its improvement in financial results to reduced losses from continuing operations, which narrowed to S$1.3 million from S$4.1 million in 2016. The company's revenue and loss per share also decreased in 2017. Annica plans to streamline its businesses and diversify revenue streams, with a focus on the renewable sector as a future growth driver.

site_title: Tesla's Musk says 'quite likely' will meet Model 3 goal; directors re-elected
summary: Elon Musk stated that Tesla's goal of producing 5,000 Model 3 vehicles per week by the end of June is "quite likely" as production lines have reached 3,500 vehicles per week. Musk also expressed confidence despite the company facing production setbacks and investor concerns over his dual role as CEO and chairman. Shareholders re-elected three directors and rejected a proposal to separate the chairman and CEO roles, with Musk retaining both positions. The company continues to face production challenges and financial scrutiny.

images.alt_text: Tesla Inc Chief Executive Elon Musk said on Tuesday that a goal of building 5,000 Model 3s per week by the end of June was "quite likely" as the company's production lines were now demonstrating the ability to build 3,500 vehicles per week.

site_title: Brent gains after touching one-month low on supply concerns
summary: US government asks Saudi Arabia and other major oil exporters to increase production, prompting Brent crude to reverse losses and settle at $75.38 a barrel, a 0.12% gain. US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude also rose, settling at $65.52 a barrel. The move follows US retail petrol prices surging to a three-year high and President Trump's complaints about Opec policy. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) meets soon to discuss output levels.

site_title: A vision for the future of STEM
summary: Four emerging female STEM leaders - Dr. Guo Huili, Huang Shao-Ning, Karen Tay, and Dr. Juliana Chan - share their visions for the future of STEM. They aim to increase representation of women in leadership positions, promote accessible technology, and foster innovation in Asia. Dr. Guo hopes for a future where women in science aren't seen as exceptions, while Ms. Huang envisions a robust angel community for Southeast Asia. Dr. Tay seeks to make technology understandable to the general public, and Dr. Chan emphasizes the need for improved scientific journalism and overcoming cultural barriers.

site_title: Grab launches venture arm to 'transform South-east Asia'
summary: Grab launches Grab Ventures, a venture arm aimed at developing innovations, pursuing strategic partnerships, and grooming startups valued at $1 billion or more in South-east Asia. The move signals pressure from investors to demonstrate revenue growth and secure Grab's position as the region's most valuable startup. Grab plans to create 100 million micro-entrepreneurs and partner with eight to 10 Series B startups over the next two years.

site_title: US: Nasdaq edges to record as trade fears weigh on Dow
summary: US stocks edged to records on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index leading the way, closing 0.4% higher at 7,637.86. Despite trade tensions and concerns about a potential trade war, the tech-rich Nasdaq mustered a second straight record. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 0.1%, while the S&P 500 rose 0.1%. Trade tensions were fueled by a detailed list of US products facing retaliatory import duties from Mexico, but a strong reading on US service sector activity in May may have countered some of the concerns.

site_title: Indonesia plans to raise diesel subsidies four-fold
summary: Indonesia plans to quadruple its diesel subsidies to 2,000 rupiah ($0.192) per liter, maintaining fuel prices unchanged through 2018 despite high global oil prices and a weak rupiah. The proposal, expected to be approved, aims to control inflation and support people's purchasing power. The government also plans to increase electricity subsidies to keep some tariffs steady this year. Critics argue the move is intended to boost President Joko Widodo's popularity ahead of a national election next year.

site_title: Thailand's Minor plans 2.5 billion euro takeover bid for Spain's NH Hotels
summary: Thailand-based Minor International plans to launch a 2.5 billion euro takeover bid for Spain's NH Hotels, valuing the group at up to 2.5 billion euros. Minor International has agreed to pay 622 million euros for a 26.5% stake in NH, exceeding the 30% ownership threshold requiring a full takeover under Spanish law. The deal would take Minor's stake to around 38% and is subject to certain conditions.

site_title: Harsh Trump trade policies weigh on US CEO sentiment
summary: US CEOs express concerns over President Donald Trump's aggressive trade policies, citing worries on hiring, capital spending, and economic growth. A survey by the Business Roundtable shows the CEO Economic Outlook index fell for the first time in Trump's presidency, with 89% of CEOs describing a decline in US economic growth as a risk. The uncertainty is affecting business decisions, with 61% of companies expecting a decline in capital sales. Despite this, the overall confidence in the US economy remains high, with the Business Roundtable showing broad confidence in the economy.

site_title: Arizona man kills six people in 96-hour murder spree
summary: An Arizona man, Dwight Jones, 56, killed six people in a 96-hour murder spree linked to his contentious divorce. The victims included a psychiatrist, a marriage counsellor, and two employees at a law office. Police tracked Jones down after establishing a DNA link between him and the victims, as well as connections to the victims through his divorce. Jones was shot by police and took his own life. The motive behind the killings was Jones' long-standing dispute with his ex-wife, who had been represented by one of the law office's lawyers.

site_title: Singapore among 'most resilient' in face of risks
summary: Singapore ranks among the world's most resilient cities, with a financial market crash being the top threat, potentially costing up to US$1.3 billion annually. Despite this, its GDP at risk is just 1.01% of its total, and it's considered "very strong" in resilience due to strict financial regulations. Other major threats include floods, human pandemics, and cyberattacks, but recent upgrades have reduced their impact. Strengthening Asia-Pacific cities' resilience could reduce GDP at risk by US$34 billion.

site_title: US Treasury Secretary said to favour less-sweeping investment limits for China
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has recommended to President Donald Trump to rely on legislation to tighten scrutiny of Chinese investments in the US, rather than an executive move, in response to allegations of intellectual property theft and tariff imposition. This approach would involve drawing up new limits through legislation, rather than relying on an executive order. Mnuchin's recommendations are due by the end of June.

site_title: Europe: Tech stocks' surge to 17-year peak a bright spot among stocks
summary: The European tech sector reached a 17-year peak, with the Stoxx 600 index up 1.5% despite a broader market loss of 0.3%. Tech stocks, including Apple and Microsoft, boosted sentiment due to record levels and acquisitions. However, weaker banking stocks and concerns over Italian politics weighed on the broader market, with Italian banks and RBS falling 3.4-5.3%. Analysts attributed the tech sector's success to the growth of companies like SAP and Infineon, which are not heavily reliant on the US market.

site_title: New York City named best city in US
summary: New York City has been named the best city in the US, according to a ranking by Resonance Consultancy. The 10-year-old firm analyzed 27 criteria, including crime rates, air quality, and economic vitality, to produce the rankings. The company collected data from coast to coast and found New York to excel in areas such as cultural diversity and entertainment offerings. This marks the second year of the rankings, which have been released annually.

site_title: Wanted: women in STEM
summary: Singapore's push for a smart nation has highlighted the need for more women to enter science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. Despite progress, women still account for only 20-25% of the global STEM workforce, with a 30% representation in Singapore's 200,000 infocomm employees. Experts attribute the under-representation to biases and lack of exposure to STEM careers. To overcome these biases, initiatives such as IBM's EXITE program and women's support networks are being implemented. The Singapore government also offers support through various schemes and initiatives to encourage talent development in STEM areas.

site_title: UK clears way for Fox-Comcast bidding war for Sky
summary: The UK has cleared the way for a bidding war between US cable giant Comcast and Rupert Murdoch's 21st Century Fox over pan-European TV group Sky. The UK's Culture Secretary Matt Hancock has approved Comcast's £22-billion bid for all of Sky, but has required Fox to sell off Sky News to address concerns about media plurality. Fox's lower offer of £11.4 billion for the remaining 61% stake in Sky will also proceed, with Hancock favouring the sale of Sky News to a third party. A 15-day consultation period will follow before Hancock makes a final decision on the Fox deal.

site_title: If blockchain 'use case' fails, MAS still benefits
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is conducting experiments with blockchain technology, but acknowledges that some "use cases" may fail. Managing Director Ravi Menon views failures as necessary for progress and learning. He believes the biggest potential for blockchain lies in cross-border payments, where it could eliminate transaction costs, increase settlement speed, and reduce risks. The MAS is exploring blockchain-based solutions for interbank payments and securities clearing, despite acknowledging that the current RTGS systems work effectively without blockchain.

site_title: Asia's capital markets seeing strong growth: MAS
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) expects Asian capital markets to drive growth, with the expansion of Asian enterprises and infrastructure development fueling financing activities. Dollar bond issuance by Asian companies reached a record high of $400 billion, while venture capital and private equity investments in Asia surpassed Europe for the first time, reaching $160 billion. MAS aims to make infrastructure financing more attractive to private capital, with plans to securitize project finance loans and create investment benchmarks. Singapore is also positioning itself as an Asian hub for fund management and domiciliation, with new corporate structures and simplified regulations.

site_title: Facebook back on the defensive over data deals
summary: Facebook faced criticism from US and European lawmakers over its sharing of personal user data with hardware manufacturers, including Apple and Samsung. The company had exempted at least 60 hardware-makers from 2015 restrictions, allowing them to access Facebook information without explicit user consent. Facebook executives defended the partnerships, citing its 2011 consent decree with the FTC, but lawmakers questioned the company's rationale and urged further investigation. The FTC is already investigating Facebook's data practices, and some lawmakers called for Zuckerberg's testimony before Congress.

images.alt_text: Mr Zuckerberg arriving to testify before Congress in April in the wake of the Cambridge Analytica scandal. Facebook is now facing criticism over its sharing of personal information with cellphone-makers and other manufacturers.

site_title: Singapore shares top spot with Australia, Sweden in tech readiness, study finds
summary: Singapore shares the top spot with Australia and Sweden in technological readiness, according to a study by The Economist Intelligence Unit. The report, which analyzed 82 of the world's largest economies, found that Singapore's business environment is future-oriented and poised for technological advancements. This ranking is a testament to the country's efforts in fostering innovation and digital growth.

site_title: When democracy goes wrong
summary: Alexander Hamilton and James Madison, two founding fathers of the US, had differing views on democracy. Hamilton, who initially doubted democracy, praised its potential for improvement through institutions like checks and balances. Madison, however, emphasized the importance of representation and the avoidance of factionalism, warning that these flaws can lead to the erosion of democratic principles. Madison's concerns have been borne out by historical examples, including the US's treatment of Native Americans and Japanese-Americans, and the current challenges posed by the Trump era, which threatens the foundations of republican democracy.

site_title: After Starbucks exit, Schultz leaves door open for US presidential run
summary: Howard Schultz, Starbucks' executive chairman, is stepping down, handing management to CEO Kevin Johnson. Schultz will leave on June 26, removing a perceived leadership "safety net" and creating uncertainty for the company. Speculation arises that Schultz, a liberal-leaning executive, may run for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination, despite repeated denials. Schultz has been involved in steering the company through various challenges, including an anti-bias training program and a massive expansion project in China.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Beng Kuang Marine agreed to sell four sets of tugs and barges to Quanta Indonesia for S$6.3 million. The sale is part of the vessel charterer's efforts to restructure and reduce its assets. No further details on the sale or the companies involved were provided.

site_title: Rosmah appears for questioning over 1MDB
summary: Rosmah Mansor, the wife of ousted Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, was questioned for over three hours by the nation's anti-corruption agency regarding her involvement in the 1MDB scandal. The investigation follows police raids on condominiums linked to Najib and his family, which seized cash, jewelry, and designer handbags. Rosmah, known for her luxurious tastes, was asked to reveal her bank accounts and explain the source of the seized funds. Her lawyers stated that she gave her "utmost cooperation" during the questioning.

site_title: Good design's strategic role in business
summary: Philips Design has created the Health Continuum Space, a first-of-its-kind innovation facility, to enhance the company's healthcare efforts. The space, which includes various medical scenarios, allows stakeholders to collaborate on solutions across the health continuum. Philips Design's "iterative co-create" approach enables the space to visualize a patient's journey, from home to diagnosis and treatment. The facility reflects the company's transformation into a solutions-based business, with design playing a strategic role in solving business problems and navigating the Fourth Industrial Revolution.

site_title: Keppel Singmarine wins S$50m deal for S-E Asia's first LNG bunker vessel
summary: Keppel Singmarine has secured a contract worth S$50 million to build South-east Asia's first liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunkering vessel, expected to be completed in Q3 2020. The vessel will have a capacity of 7,500 cubic metres. The deal was awarded by FueLNG, a joint venture between Shell Eastern Petroleum and Keppel O&M.

site_title: Pomex Court sold for S$37.6m
summary: Pomex Court, a 26,471 sq ft freehold residential development in Singapore's Joo Chiat area, has been sold for S$37.6 million through a collective sale. The price works out to S$1,014 per square foot per plot ratio. The existing 19 units will be redeveloped into a potential five-storey project with 34 units, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority's Master Plan 2014. The sale was brokered by Century 21 House & Home Property.

site_title: Sharp has a better shot at PC reboot than Toshiba
summary: Sharp is poised to reboot its PC business with a $48.6 million purchase of Toshiba's personal computer unit, marking a strategic move in a cut-throat market. Toshiba, a former industry pioneer, has struggled to compete due to the rise of smartphones and declining PC sales. Sharp, controlled by Taiwanese tycoon Terry Gou, aims to cut costs and improve margins through its contract manufacturing giant Foxconn. However, the PC business remains highly competitive, and successful comebacks are rare, making it uncertain whether Sharp can turn the business around.

site_title: Ongoing dispute with neighbours might keep Qatar Airways in red
summary: Qatar Airways may face a second consecutive year of losses due to an ongoing dispute with regional neighbours, despite narrowing losses. The airline's CEO, Akbar al-Baker, attributed the potential losses to rising fuel costs, which could increase by 26% this year, and the impact of a blockade on its routes. The airline has no excess capacity and continues to fly all its planes, but al-Baker warned that controlled costs are necessary to mitigate the effects of rising fuel prices.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: No evidence that having sex with robots is healthy, says new report
summary: A new report in the BMJ Sexual & Reproductive Health warns that there is no evidence to support the health benefits of having sex with robots, citing a lack of primary research data on the topic. Doctors Chantal Cox-George and Susan Bewley found that sex robots have been marketed as a solution to social isolation, but this claim is based on unproven and potentially misleading assertions. Experts argue that the use of sex robots could exacerbate social isolation and that their benefits are often exaggerated.

site_title: OCBC is first bank to do instant digital account opening
summary: OCBC Bank has become the first bank in Singapore to launch an instant digital account opening service, allowing customers to open an OCBC 360 Account in under 5 minutes using their mobile or desktop. The service leverages the national data repository MyInfo and real-time digital know-your-customer (e-KYC) process, eliminating the need for in-person visits or document submission. This marks a significant step forward in digital banking in Singapore, with other banks such as DBS and United Overseas Bank (UOB) also exploring similar initiatives.

site_title: Leveraging digital technology for urban living
summary: Keppel Land, a leading real estate player, has been recognized for its innovative digital solutions. The company's Habitap app is Asia's first fully integrated smart home management system, offering residents control over smart home devices and condominium facility bookings. Keppel Land also introduced 360-degree immersive VR show suites for its Highline Residences, and a smart mobile app for its serviced co-office, KLOUD, allowing users to access premises and perform office functions with a tap of their mobile screens. This has earned the company the SG Mark in the Digital Solution category.

site_title: How to survive a trade war
summary: A trade war could significantly impact Singapore companies relying on international trade, with estimated 1% of GDP at risk. Companies should prepare for both a liberalization and a clampdown by considering scenario planning, lobbying, shipping products swiftly, rerouting production, utilizing free trade agreements, reclassifying goods, reducing import values, and strengthening compliance. By taking proactive steps, companies can mitigate the worst effects of a trade war and ensure their survival.

site_title: Aiming for zero CO2 emissions in shipping
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping has set ambitious CO2 reduction targets for the shipping industry, aiming for a 70% efficiency improvement and a 50% CO2 cut by 2050. To achieve these targets, the industry is committed to developing and globally implementing zero-CO2 fuels and propulsion systems, such as hydrogen fuel cells and batteries powered by renewable energy. While liquefied natural gas (LNG) and biofuels will play a role in the transition, they are seen as interim solutions that won't deliver the ambitious targets.

site_title: Indonesia's coming digital disruption
summary: Indonesia's digital economy is expected to boom, with the country's overall economy expanding from $1 trillion in 2017 to $2.7 trillion by 2027. Online retail is projected to increase 14-fold, with e-money adoption rising from 2% to 24% of transactions. Fintech solutions, such as peer-to-peer lending, will target the unbanked population. The government's infrastructure push and regulatory framework are supporting the growth, with capital available to fund startups. Digitalization is expected to create jobs and drive economic growth, but also poses risks, including disruption to offline businesses and banks.

site_title: Quarterly survey finds business sentiment at three-year high
summary: Business sentiment in Singapore has reached its highest level in three years, with the service and manufacturing sectors showing optimism about the third quarter. The Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau's Business Optimism Index rose to +10.58 percentage points, up from +8.5 percentage points in Q2 2018 and +3.58 percentage points in Q3 2017. While some indicators, such as sales volumes and net profits, showed moderation, all six indicators improved year-on-year. The CEO of SCCB attributed the rise in optimism to steady growth rates, but warned of heightened downside risks due to global trade tensions.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Indonesia plans to raise diesel subsidies four-fold
summary: Indonesia plans to increase diesel subsidies four-fold to 2,000 rupiah ($0.192) per liter, from 500 rupiah, to keep fuel prices unchanged through 2018 despite high global oil prices. The move aims to control inflation and support people's purchasing power, with the proposal likely to be approved by parliament. The government will also increase electricity subsidies to cover new customers and keep some tariffs steady this year. The move is seen as a bid to maintain public support ahead of a national election in 2019.

site_title: Ex-heads of Citi, Deutsche, ANZ in Australia charged in cartel case
summary: Australian authorities have charged the former local bosses of Citigroup and Deutsche Bank with "criminal cartel offences" over a US$2.3 billion stock issue in 2015. The charges include Stephen Roberts, John McLean, Itay Tuchman, Michael Ormaechea, and Michael Richardson, as well as ANZ and the two investment banks. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) has laid charges over the share placement, which could lead to changes in institutional capital raisings and further damage to the reputation of Australian lenders.

site_title: Iata piloting virtual reality solution
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) is piloting a virtual reality solution with Europe-based software start-up Inflight VR to enhance the flight experience and boost revenues. Airlines such as Iberia, Vueling, Qantas, and Lufthansa have already started testing the technology, which weighs 300-400 grams compared to 2-5 kilogrammes of inflight entertainment systems. The solution could lead to weight savings, fuel efficiency, and environmental benefits, with potential for a shift away from traditional inflight entertainment systems in the medium to long-term.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Car vending machine that's an industry eye-opener
summary: Autobahn Motors, a used car dealership, has unveiled the world's largest "car vending machine" at its showroom in Singapore. The S$3 million facility, which opened in 2016, can hold 60 cars and dispenses luxury vehicles like Ferraris and Porsches within minutes. The car vending machine has increased sales by 30% and has been awarded the SG Mark Gold for its innovative design. The company's general manager, Gary Hong, credits good design for the showroom's success and encourages other companies to participate in the SG Mark to bring innovation to the car industry.

site_title: Carriers face double whammy of higher oil prices, stronger US dollar
summary: Emirates president Tim Clark warned that the airline faces a "double whammy" of higher oil prices and a stronger US dollar, which could increase costs. However, summer bookings remain strong, with fares at higher prices. Clark noted that Emirates is monitoring demand trends to ensure that price increases do not deter passengers.

images.alt_text: Emirates' president Tim Clark says any merger plan with Abu Dhabi's Etihad Airways is for shareholders to decide and no such development is likely anytime soon.

site_title: Tat Hong offer closes with offeror controlling 93.62% stake
summary: Tat Hong's offer to acquire the crane supplier has closed with valid acceptances of 705.14 million shares, representing 93.62% of the company's total issued shares. The offeror controls 96.51% of the company's total issued shares.

site_title: Japan's Sharp to buy Toshiba's personal computer business for S$48m
summary: Sharp Corp will buy Toshiba Corp's personal computer business for 4 billion yen (S$48 million), marking Sharp's return to the PC market after an 8-year absence. Sharp was previously known for high-end TVs and smartphone displays before struggling to compete and exiting the PC market in 2010. Under the deal, Sharp will acquire an 80.1% stake in Toshiba's PC unit.

site_title: Bad air day: Indian city of Kanpur chokes on world's worst pollution
summary: The Indian city of Kanpur is experiencing severe air pollution, ranking as the world's dirtiest city, according to a World Health Organization (WHO) report. The city's air quality is seven times the normal safe level due to high levels of particulate matter, causing chronic lung and cancer cases. Hospitals are filled with patients, and children under five are particularly affected, with many suffering from breathing-related issues. Authorities blame the pollution on vehicles, industry, and the leather industry, which pollutes the Ganges river.

site_title: Incubator arms of CMA CGM and PSA join hands to drive innovation
summary: French shipping giant CMA CGM and port operator PSA International have signed a memorandum of understanding to drive innovation and digitalisation in the shipping and supply-chain ecosystem. The partnership aims to leverage their complementary strengths to test-bed ideas and achieve better customer experience and operational efficiency. CMA CGM's startup incubator, Ze Box, will receive a $10 million annual commitment, while PSA International's incubator programme has already incubated six startups, including ClearMetal, Haulio, and Deliveree, which have achieved significant growth. The partnership is seen as a step towards transforming the container shipping landscape through digitalisation.

site_title: Dollar heads towards 6-month highs
summary: The US dollar edged towards a six-month high as trade tensions between the US and its commercial partners prompted selling in emerging market currencies. The dollar rose 0.1% against a basket of currencies, with the Mexican peso and Canadian dollar leading losses. US Treasury yields rose, pushing two-year government yields to 2.50%, and investors bought the dollar against the euro and emerging market currencies. The dollar's strength was attributed to the US economy's potential strong June quarter and inflationary pressures, prompting the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.

site_title: Trump aims to split up Nafta talks, says adviser
summary: US President Donald Trump wants to split up North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) talks with Canada and Mexico, aiming to negotiate bilateral accords instead of a multilateral deal. National Economic Council director Larry Kudlow said Trump believes bilateral negotiations are better and that the current approach hasn't been fruitful. Trump's preference is to negotiate with Mexico and Canada separately, despite the need for consensus from all three countries. This move comes at a tense time in US trade relations with Canada and Mexico, with tariffs on steel and aluminum imports already imposed.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: mm2 Asia posted S$192 million revenue in FY18, a 101% increase, driven by broad-based growth across all segments. The company's core net profit rose 39% to S$26.4 million, exceeding forecasts. The company's core production business saw 65% topline growth, with North Asia accounting for 57% of total production revenue. mm2 expects FY19 growth to be driven by its Cathay acquisition, improved box office performance, and cost synergies.

site_title: Designed to fly high
summary: Changi Airport's Terminal 4 has won the Platinum SG Mark 2018 Award for its innovative design concepts, which aim to create a memorable and hassle-free travel experience. The terminal features a two-storey building with a gross floor area of 225,000 square meters, incorporating leading-edge technologies such as facial recognition systems, centralised security screening, and self-service options. The design prioritizes user-centredness, allowing passengers to go through airport processes quickly and efficiently, while also improving productivity for staff. The award recognizes Changi Airport Group's commitment to good design and enhancing the passenger experience.

site_title: South-east Asia's plastic addiction is blighting world's oceans
summary: South-east Asia, particularly Thailand, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Vietnam, are among the world's top plastic polluters, contributing up to 60% of global plastic waste leaking into oceans. The region's high demand for consumer products and inadequate waste management infrastructure exacerbate the problem, with eight million tonnes of plastic entering oceans annually. Governments and corporations are recognizing the issue, with some setting ambitious goals to reduce plastic waste, but critics argue that more needs to be done to address the problem.

site_title: Tycoon Krishnan may take Astro Malaysia private
summary: Tycoon Krishnan T Ananda is considering taking Astro Malaysia private after the company's shares hit a record low. Astro's shares jumped 16% following reports of a potential buyout. Krishnan, Malaysia's fourth-richest person, controls 40.9% of the company and is seeking a 25% premium to attract investors. The move comes after Astro's stock fell 46% this year, making it the worst performer on the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index. Krishnan's buyout offer could value the company at over $2.5 billion.

site_title: Britain sells stake in RBS for £2.5b with eye on privatisation
summary: Britain's government sold a 7.7% stake in Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) for £2.5 billion, resulting in a £2.1 billion loss. The sale, part of the government's plan to return the bank to private ownership, will help reduce the country's national debt. RBS, which received a £45.5 billion bailout during the 2008 financial crisis, now holds 62.4% of the bank, with plans to sell the remaining majority stake by 2023.

images.alt_text: Following the sale, the Conservative government headed by Prime Minister Theresa May still has a majority holding of 62.4% in RBS, much of which it plans to offload through to 2023.

site_title: Grab launches venture arm to 'transform South-east Asia'
summary: Grab has launched Grab Ventures, a venture arm aimed at developing innovations, pursuing strategic partnerships, and grooming South-east Asia's next generation of startups valued at $1 billion or more. The move signals pressure from investors to show more revenue possibilities and secure Grab's position as South-east Asia's most valuable startup. Grab aims to create 100 million micro-entrepreneurs and transform the region, with a focus on sectors such as transport, food, logistics, and financial services.

site_title: US, N Korean leaders to meet at 9am on June 12
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un are set to meet on June 12 at 9am in Singapore, marking the first-ever meeting between the two leaders. The White House is actively preparing for the summit, with a US advance team already on the ground in Singapore. The meeting is expected to focus on US efforts to get North Korea to abandon its nuclear program, with Washington demanding full and verifiable denuclearization. The summit's success is uncertain, with experts questioning Trump's knowledge of North Korea and international diplomacy.

site_title: C&G enters into S$400m reverse takeover of Param Mitra Coal
summary: C&G Environmental Protection Holdings has entered into a reverse takeover deal valued at S$400 million to acquire Indonesia's Param Mitra Coal Resources. C&G will acquire PMCR's assets, including coal mining and trading rights, in exchange for S$400 million of new shares. The deal will give PMCR a backdoor listing on the Singapore Exchange. Post-consolidation, C&G will issue approximately 488.88 million new shares. The transaction is expected to allow C&G to remain listed and meet SGX's minimum free float requirements.

site_title: UK govt may invest in Hitachi's nuclear power plant in Wales
summary: The UK government may invest directly in a new nuclear power plant in Wales, built by Hitachi Ltd, to replace ageing reactors and polluting coal plants. The plant, which would join Hinkley Point C in south-west England, would aim to achieve a lower cost for consumers. The government will consider direct investment alongside Hitachi and other partners, following a recommendation by auditors to explore new financing models. This move comes as private investors have been reluctant to take on the huge costs of new nuclear plants, and costs for other sources of power, such as wind, have decreased.

site_title: STI on upward trend as shares gain 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.45% to 3,483.16, driven by gains in blue chips such as DBS Bank, OCBC, and City Developments. The rally follows Wall Street's solid gains, with tech stocks leading the Nasdaq to a fresh record. Consumer stocks also saw a boost, with DBS Group Research recommending "buy" on Genting Singapore and ComfortDelGro. The benchmark index closed with 1.5 billion shares worth S$1.1 billion traded, with losers outpacing gainers 206 to 185.

site_title: Pimco rises under new team
summary: Pimco, a US$1.77 trillion fixed-income firm, has undergone a significant transformation under its new leadership, led by Daniel Ivascyn and Emmanuel "Manny" Roman. Since Bill Gross's departure four years ago, the firm has adopted a more collaborative approach, with Ivascyn and Roman sharing responsibilities as head of investing and CEO, respectively. This shift in mindset has led to impressive results, with 85% of Pimco's funds beating their benchmarks and total assets increasing by US$300 billion since Roman's arrival in 2016. The firm is also investing in technology, with Roman's focus on luring top tech and finance talent, and has announced plans to open a new office in Austin.

site_title: China pushes state banks into home rental market at their own risk
summary: China's state banks have pledged over $625 billion in rental housing financing to accelerate the development of the rental market, aiming to make homes more affordable and curb speculative sale markets. The loans, offered at ultra-low interest rates with long repayment periods, have found takers in cities like Shenzhen, where home prices have skyrocketed. However, mid-sized and small lenders are hesitant due to default risks and low returns, with some deciding not to offer similar products. Experts warn that the push into the rental market may lead to losses for banks, highlighting the need for a credit-based mechanism to prevent speculators.

site_title: Global inequality reveals policy failings
summary: Global inequality has worsened in the past three decades, with the top 1% capturing 28% of aggregate income growth in North America and Western Europe. In China, over 500 million people live on less than $5.50 per day, and a significant gap exists between coastal urban regions and rural interior areas. India saw the fastest rise in inequality among major world regions, with 55% of income share in the hands of the richest 10% of the population. Governments are failing to address structural causes, with policies often hampered by partisan politics and ineffective measures.

site_title: Weak Japan figures hint at economic recession
summary: Japan's household spending unexpectedly contracted in April and services sector activity slowed in May, raising the possibility of a recession. The economy shrank over January to March, and another quarter of contraction would meet the technical definition of a recession. Economists warn that domestic demand indicators must improve before the end of June to avoid a recession. This suggests Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" campaign is sputtering, and the economy is not bouncing back strongly, increasing the likelihood of a recession.

site_title: Harnessing technology's transformative power for all
summary: A recent article discusses the transformative power of technology, which has been around since the beginning of human existence. It has enabled humans to transform their surroundings and improve their lives, businesses, and future. Technology provides access to opportunity, such as internet connections, and enables businesses to scale and grow globally. It also creates new entrepreneurs and industries, like online platforms and home cooks as restaurateurs. As technology advances, it is being used to solve global problems, such as cancer detection and environmental conservation. The article concludes that embracing technological progress and innovation is crucial, rather than resisting it, to make technology work for everyone.

site_title: It's the women's turn now
summary: Hollywood's trend of gender-swapped remakes, including Ocean's 8 and Overboard, continues despite criticism and commercial failure. The 1987 comedy Overboard, starring Goldie Hawn, was remade with Eugenio Derbez and Anna Faris, grossing $70 million worldwide on a $12 million budget, but received largely negative reviews. Critics argue that these remakes perpetuate the notion that women need male appeal to be successful, while also providing a platform for female-led stories. Despite the controversy, the trend shows signs of progress, with films like Ghostbusters and What Men Want paving the way for more female-led projects.

site_title: Astrea IV private equity bonds launched with retail tranche of S$121m
summary: Temasek's Azalea Group has launched its first private equity-backed bond for retail investors, Astrea IV, with a retail tranche of S$121 million. The Class A-1 bonds carry an interest rate of 4.35% and have a minimum investment of S$2,000. The bonds are backed by a US$1.09 billion private equity portfolio valued at 36 funds, with a 9.2% share held by Blackstone Capital Partners VI. The bonds are expected to be issued on June 14 and traded on SGX on June 18, with a 5-year call date and a one-time step-up of 1% per annum if not redeemed in full.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Singapore Mint unveils 3 commemorative coins to mark historic summit
summary: The Singapore Mint has unveiled three commemorative coins to mark the historic Trump-Kim summit, set to take place in Singapore on June 12, 2018. The coins feature an image of an affirmative handshake between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The move aims to commemorate Singapore's role as host to the historic summit.

site_title: Katong Plaza to be put up for collective sale at S$188m
summary: Katong Plaza, a mixed-use development in Singapore, will be put up for collective sale on June 7, 2018, with a price tag of S$188 million. The site has a land area of 34,044 sq ft and a 3.0 allowable gross plot ratio, yielding a possible 102,133 sq ft of gross floor area. The sale will see 80% of the price going to commercial owners and 20% to residential owners, with a minimum 60% of the GFA needing to be zoned for residential use.

images.alt_text: The building's 132 commercial units have a total strata area of 38,643 sq ft, while its 14 residential units have a total strata area of 19,612 sq ft.

site_title: MyRepublic plans HK IPO; postpones market debut date
summary: MyRepublic, a Singaporean fibre broadband company, plans to list on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange with a multimillion-dollar fund injection from CLSA. The listing was initially scheduled but has been postponed. The company aims to raise funds to further expand its business, despite potentially lower second-half revenue. This move marks MyRepublic's entry into the Hong Kong market, following a similar path by other Singaporean companies.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Rare dinosaur skeleton sells for 2m euros
summary: A rare dinosaur skeleton, believed to be a new species of carnivorous allosaurus, sold for 2 million euros at the Eiffel Tower in Paris. The 150-million-year-old skeleton, 70% intact, was discovered in Wyoming in 2013 and features a unique set of characteristics, including longer shoulder blades and a different number of teeth. The buyer, a French art collector, plans to display the specimen in a French museum, and part of the proceeds will fund further archaeological digs.
